This section provides information on the dcTrack client and pages functions are performed.Note: If you find a function that is not listed, please contact the Documentation team. See Support and HelpResources.From the Sunbird Support website at http://support.sunbirddcim.com.A username and password are required to access the Sunbird Support portal at http://support.sunbirddcim.com.If you do not have a username and password, contact Professional Services and Support from the Support websiteor via email (tech@sunbirddcim.com).For details on performing a download, see Item Models Library.

From the Sunbird Support website at http://support.sunbirddcim.com.A username and password are required to access the Sunbird Support website at http://support.sunbirddcim.com.If you do not have a username and password, contact Professional Services and Support from the Support websiteor via email (tech@sunbirddcim.com).

File Import templates are downloaded from the File Import Wizard.To access the File Import Wizard in dcTrack, click the Import icon in the upper-right corner of the screen.In the Download Templates panel on the right, click the name of the required import template to download it.For information on specifying a save location, see How to Specify a Default Save Location for Downloaded Files.New circuits are built in the Web Client.Select Connectivity > New Data Circuit or Connectivity > New Power Circuit respectively, or click the Create New Cir-cuit icon on the Circuits List page.You can also import data circuits and power circuits once items they are connected to exist. You can also import Vir-tual Power Chain connections and power outlet circuits.Building Power CircuitsBuilding Data Circuits

This section outlines basic functions such as logging in, changing passwords, updating user information and so on.Terminology is also covered. Terms can be specific to dcTrack or industry standard terms that may be used in cer-tain contexts in dcTrack.High-level overviews of the dcTrack interface and how to navigate dcTrack are included as well.Interface overviews references to interface elements on a page. The specific functions performed on each page areexplained throughout help.Navigation refers to the various ways you can access items and pages in dcTrack. Refer to Quick Links for inform-ation on what functions are performed where in dcTrack.

The dcTrack ISO file, as well as additional files, templates, help and so on, are obtained fromhttp://support.sunbirddcim.com.A username and password provided by Sunbird are required to access the website.Sunbird suggests obtaining your username and password as soon as possible.Contact Professional Services and Support via the Support site for your username and password.Make sure your Browser allows popups. Popups are required when running Item Detail reports among other fea-tures.

Note: The instructions here are specific to non-System Administrators.To log in to dcTrack for the first time:1. First, access dcTrack via a supported browser by entering the IP address or name assigned to your version ofdcTrack and provided to you by your System Administrator.Answer yes to any security alerts and accept all certificates.Note: As an end user, you do not need to add a dcTrack license file(s) the first time you log in. Contact your SystemAdministrator if you are prompted to do so.2. At the dcTrack Log In page, log in by entering the username and password provided to you by your SystemAdministrator.3. Click Log in.Once you are logged in, the Web Client Dashboard opens.Note: The widgets on the Dashboard show no data. This is because no items are added yet and/or configured forSNMP discovery, or integrated with Power IQ to get readings.dcTrack provides SSO capability using SAML 2.0. Once enabled, dcTrack users configured through your IdentityProvider (IdP), will be automatically authenticated through SAML. To implement SAML/SSO in your dcTrack envir-onment, first complete the configuration settings required by your IdP to register the dcTrack application. Once com-plete, enable the SAML feature on dcTrack by supplying the appropriate information on the SAML configurationpage. Please note, if you are currently using LDAP you must disable the LDAP feature prior to enabling SAML.Note: Once converted to a SAML account, an account cannot be reverted back to a non-SAML accountNote: SAML accounts cannot be used to make API callsThe following table summarizes the fields in the SAML Configuration Panel:Enable SAML Must be checked to enable SAML and to enter Edit mode in the SAML Configuration PanelThe unique identifier of the IdP formatted as a URL containing information about the IdP so Power IQIssuer URLcan validate that the SAML assertions it receives are issued from the correct IdP. Required.The URL for the IdP’s login page. When SSO is enabled, Power IQ will redirect users to this login pageLogin URLwhen they choose to sign in using SSO.The URL for the IdP’s logout page. If supplied, when a user is logged out of Power IQ ill be redirectedto the IdP’s logout page and given the option of ending their SSO session. Users who end their SSOLogout URLsession completely will be redirected to the IdP’s login page the next time they attempt to accessdcTrack. Required.SAML User Iden-NameID format that will be included in the assertions from SAML to identify the user on dcTrack. Sup-tifierported options include “Email Address” or “Persistent (Username. Required.SSO Click-through ButtonLabel displayed on the login page for the SSO login button.LabelWhen enabled, Power IQ will automatically create users that do not already exist in Power IQ. OnlyEnable Auto-users who are successfully authenticated by SAML and are members of the group selected in thematic User Pro-'Registered SAML Group' will be added. Users who are automatically added to Power IQ will not auto-visioningmatically be assigned Roles. However, pf a User belongs to a Group, they will inherit the Group’sRoles.When enabled, if the SAML assertion contains Group information, Power IQ will automatically createEnable Auto-Groups that do not already exist in Power IQ. The User will then also be added to the specified Group.matic GroupGroups that are automatically added to Power IQ will not automatically be assigned Roles. You mustProvisioningassign the appropriate Group Roles manually in Power IQ.Enable Auto-matic RedirectWhen enabled, you can log-in automatically using SAML, without needing to click the SSO button.for LoginUsernameNameID is used if this field is blank.AttributeEmail AttributeEmail address. An email address is required for user creation, even if the user is not a local user.NameFirstnameFirst nameAttributeLast NameLast nameAttributeGroup AttributeThe attribute name contained in the SAML assertion that identifies Group names.NameRegisteredThe SAML group on Power IQ that all new SAML users will be automatically added to.SAML GroupSAML SigningThe Certificate provided by the IdP, used to verify the signature provided by the IdP in the SAMLCertificateresponse.

dcTrack generates the metadata you need to configure the SAML server. To extract the metadata to configure yourSAML serve:1. Open the Metadata URL in a new Chrome or Edge browser.2. Copy the page text to a new XML file on the SAML server. This text contains all the necessary details to integratewith dcTrack.Note: Do notuse Firefox to extract the metadata, because Firefox does not parse and render the XML correctly,instead use Edge or Chrome to get the metadata.When dcTrack® is configured to use SAML as a source of authentication, it can be configured to completely bypassthe normal login screen and redirect automatically to the identity provider (IDP). See the screen shot below. If theuser is already authenticated with the IDP, this means that the user will be taken directly to dcTrack without having toexplicitly login. If both dcTrack® and the container web application are provisioned to use the same SAML IDP, thisresults in a single sign on experience. Note that if it is necessary to login using “local” username / password (e.g. totroubleshoot issues with the SAML setup), the automatic redirection can be prevented by going to the URL:https:// <my-dctrack-ip-address>/login/login?saml=falseFor additional information please see Procedure to add users to groups that were created by SAML.

This application note applies to user’s wanting to migrate from either Active Directory (AD) or Lightweight DirectoryAccess Protocol (LDAP) Authentication to Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) authentication. In con-junction with the User’s Guide, it provides the steps necessary to migrate user from either Active LDAP\AD to SAML.

Before starting this procedure, please be aware of the following:The procedure must be run using an account that that both authenticates locally with dcTrack and has theSystem Administrator role. For example, the default ‘admin’ account could be used.AD\LDAP support must be disabled before SAML can be enabled.Collect all of the required information to setup SAML within dcTrack before starting. Note that the setup insome Identity Providers may take time to propagate and become active.NameID identity information in dcTrack MUST match the value returned by the SAML assertion in order forthe account to be migrated. The procedure below will provide ways to address mismatches.This procedure is broken up into a procedure to migrate user’s and a secondary procedure to correct information asneeded. User’s should start with the Procedure to Migrate User’s and only run the secondary procedure if directed todo so.

1. As a local (non-AD\LDAP user) user with the System Administrator role, login to dcTrack.2. Disable AD\LDAP Authentication.3. Configure SAML Authentication and confirm it’s working. (Help link)4. Ensure that Enable Automatic User Provisioning is enabled in the dcTrack SAML Configuration.5. In the SAML assertion, the value returned in the NameID field must match the username or email address indcTrack. The field that must match depends on what was selected for the SAML User Identifier in dcTrack.The options are:a. “Email Address”: The email address in dcTrack must match the value returned in the NameID fieldb. “Persistent (Username)”: The username in dcTrack must match the value returned in the NameID field6. If you are able to see SAML information on the Identify Provider, for instance if you are a SAML SystemAdministrator, you can confirm the values match. If the values don’t match, use theProcedure to correct amismatched username or email address below to fix the information in dcTrack.7. If you can’t see the SAML information, perform the following steps to detect mismatches and also migrate theusers.a. Have a user login via SAML authentication. Note whether or not a new user account is created indcTrack.b. If a new account is not created, the information matched an existing account and that user wasmigrated. No additional steps are needed.c. Otherwise:i. Record the Username\Email information from the newly created account (these are the valuesreturned via SAML).ii. Delete the new account (duplicate username\emails aren’t allowed)iii. Using the information from the new account, correct the Username\Email information in the pre-existing account using the Procedure to correct a mismatched username or email addressbelow.iv. Have the user login again and confirm that another new account was not created. If one was,confirm the information and repeat step 7c.v. Repeat step 7 for each user.1. As a local (non-AD\LDAP user) user with the System Administrator role, login to dcTrack.2. Navigate to the Settings tab.3. Select Authorization & Authentication àUser Accounts from the left-hand navigation.4. Click on the user whose login or email information needs to updated5. Select Edit6. Update the information and select Save.

dcTrack's SAML implementation can currently only add users to groups that were created by SAML. Use the stepsbelow to add existing LDAP Users to a SAML group.1. Temporarily rename the LDAP group. For instance, append _ldap to it.2. Have user log in.3. Observe the creation of the new SAML group.4. Give the new group the right permissions5. Delete the old LDAP group.Users with the System Administrator role can set the password requirements for user passwords. These require-ments will then be enforced whenever passwords are created or changed.dcTrack supports the Password Requirements described below.Failed Attempts Before Lockout - This is the number of failed login attempts before the users account islocked out. If set to 0 there is no limit so bad attempts will never cause the user to be locked out. The max-imum accepted value is 10.Auto Unlock Duration (Minutes) - The setting controls how long dcTrack should wait before automaticallyunlocking a users account. 0 means the account will never be automatically unlocked and can only beunlocked by the Admin. The maximum value is 999.Minimum - The minimum number of characters a password must contain. The minimum setting is 1.Maxmum - The maximum number of characters a password can contain. The maximum setting is 40Passwords must contain at least one number - Check this setting if you require passwords to contain at leastone number.Passwords must contain at least one UPPERCASE letter - Check this setting if you require passwords to con-tain at least one upper case character.Passwords must contain at least one lower case letter - Check this setting if you require passwords to containat least one lower case character.Passwords must contain at least one of these special characters ~!@#$%^&*()_+{}|:"<>?/.,';][=-`")Additional requirements can also be set basedTo change the default Password Requirements follow the steps below:1. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Authorization & Authentication > Password Requirements2. Select the appropriate settings3. Click Save.Once the settings are saved, newly created or modified passwords will be required to adhere to the new require-ments. Users whose current password does not adhere to the new rules will still be allowed to log into dcTrack.Note: Password rules are not respected for LDAP users.

Only Application administration refers to tasks performed exclusively by dcTrack System Administrators.The tasks in this section are performed on the dcTrack server, or by users with System Administrative privileges inthe dcTrack application.dcTrack Administrators (System Administrators) are assigned to the dcTrack System Administrators user group bydefault in the "admin" role. This role has permission to do every action in dcTrack, no exceptions.A System Administrator is responsible for installing and configuring dcTrack, including creating users and teams,LDAP user and user group management, importing items, maintaining lists and libraries, and so on.In most cases, this user is separate from the Gatekeeper but in some cases may be the same user.System Administrators can change the System Administrator password.Change the default System Administrator password as soon as possible to prevent unauthorized System Admin-istrator-level access to dcTrack.If you are a System Administrator and want to change your own password you may follow the steps below or see:Change Your End User PasswordSteps for System Administrator to change other users password:1. Navigate to Settings -> dcTrack Settings -> Authorization & Authentication -> User Accounts2. Select the User Account whose password you want to change3. Click Change Password.2. The Change Password dialog displays. Enter your old and new passwords.3. Click Change Password to save your changes.These steps apply to users with a role of Viewer, Operator, Gatekeeper or System Administrator. For specific Pass-word Requirements see: Setting dcTrack Password RequirementsTo change your password:1. In the Web Client, click your username in the upper right corner of the main toolbar.2. From the drop down, click Change Password to open the Change Password dialog.3. Enter your old password, enter your new password, and reenter the new password to confirm it.4. Click Change Password to change your password.Use this password the next time you log in to dcTrack.In addition to setting their own password, System Administrators may change any users password including otherSystem Administrator's passwords. See Changing User Passwords.

These steps apply to users with a role of Viewer, Member, Manager and Gatekeeper who do not have SystemAdministrator privileges to dcTrack. Users in these roles have different Admin menu options available in dcTrack.Note: For new users, the admin's account (username "admin") user preferences for Language, Theme, Unit Sys-tem, Data Separator, Date Format and Cabinet Elevation preferences are used as the default preferences, how-ever the Language used on the Login screen for new users is set from the setting on the Display & Locale page.To edit your user information:1. Click the user icon in the upper right corner of the page.2. Select User Profile from the User Profile menu.3. From this page click Edit to change your user details and preferences3. Edit your information, then click Save.Edit your first and last name, and your email address as needed.Information on the Groups and Global Roles panels is not editable by non-System Administrators.4. Click Save on the User Information page, then click OK on the Success message.Other User Preferences may be set from the Preferences Tab.User Preferences include options for the following:As of version 7.0.0 dcTrack supports processing in 5 different languages. Supported lan-Languageguages include English, French, German, Japanese, Simplified Chinese and Turkish.Theme Light or Dark modeUnits System Units may be displayed in either SI International (Metric) or U.S formats.The delimiter used when displaying dates for the current user. Options are:"-"Date Separator"/""."The format used when displaying dates for the current user. Options are:MMDDYYYYDate FormatDDMMYYYYYYYYMMDDThese settings control how Cabinet Elevations are displayed in dcTrack. Default values may beset for the following:Cabinet ElevationView - Controls which view of the Cabinet Elevation is initially displayed (Front orDefaultsBack).Show Items As - Controls whether Items should be initially displayed as Text orImage in the Cabinet Elevation.U Position Numbering - Controls whether numbering is displayed from the BottomUp only (Bottom Up), or the Bottom Up on the right side of the Cabinet and TopDown on the left (Both Directions). The Top Down numbers are for reference only,the UPosition specified when placing items should always reflect the Bottom Upnumber.Identify Items With - Controls what is displayed for items in the Cabinet Elevation.The following options are supported:Make & ModelItem NameItem AliasSerial NumberAsset TageAsset TagOnce you have selected your User Preferences, click the Save button to save your selections. Settings will takeaffect after the user logs out and back into dcTrack.dcTrack supports either Firefox, Safari, Edge or Chrome™.If this is the first time you are accessing dcTrack, additional steps are required.See Log In for the First Time (Non-System Administrators), depending on your role.1. Connect to dcTrack via a web browser by entering the IP address or name assigned to dcTrack. The IP addressis provided by your System Administrator or Gatekeeper - not Sunbird.2. Answer yes to any security alerts and accept all certificates.3. Enter your username and password on the dcTrack log in page and click Log In.Click the Logoff link at the top left of the Web Client.

dcTrack uses a hierarchy to organize the data center assets it manages.dcTrack refers to data center asset items as classes. Within item classes are subclasses of items.For descriptions of each item class and subclass, as well as port types, connections, circuits and so on, seedcTrack Terminology.dcTrack uses a hierarchy consistent with that of Power IQ. For information on the Power IQ enterprise data mod-el/hierarchy, see Power IQ Data Model.At a high level, the hierarchy consists of the following:From the top of the hierarchy to the bottom, the dcTrack data model consists of:LOCATIONS (Sites): LOCATIONS can be a data center, a floor within a data center, a room within a data cen-ter, or a room within a floor within a data center. There can be multiple LOCATIONS in dcTrack.LOCATIONS are the root of the asset management hierarchy.LOCATIONS contain ITEMS.AISLES and ROWS are considered SUB-LOCATIONS in dcTrack.ITEMS: Assets within the data center.ITEMS belong to a LOCATION.ITEMS include (in no specific hierarchical order):CABINETDEVICENETWORKRACK PDUDATA PANELFLOOR PDUUPS UNITPOWER OUTLETHVAC UNITPROBES and SENSORSFACILITY ITEMSITEMS are assigned MODELSMODELS have MANUFACTURERS such as SunbirdITEMS have PORTS when applicable and based on the ITEM class.For example, servers and switches may have data, power and sensor ports, but wire managers andshelves do not have any ports.All ITEMS are assigned a STATUS such as Planned, Installed, Archived and so onDepending on the CLASS, ITEMS can be assigned a SUBCLASS and MOUNTING TYPE.For example, a STANDARD DEVICE ITEM is a SUBCLASS of a DEVICE CLASS ITEM.PORTS: PORTS include DATA, POWER, and SENSOR portsPORTS belong to ITEMS.Depending on the PORT type, PORTS include PORT SUBCLASSES.SUBCLASSES of DATA PORTS include:LOGICAL PORTSVIRTUAL PORTSACTIVE PORTSPASSIVE PORTSSUBCLASSES of POWER PORTS include:POWER SUPPLY PORTSRACK PDU INPUT PORTSRACK PDU OUTLET PORTSPOWER OUTLET PORTSRECEPTACLE PORTSBREAKER PANEL POLESSENSOR/PROBE (ENVIRONMENTAL) PORTSCONNECTIONS: A CONNECTION can be made between two DATA PORTS or two POWER PORTS.SENSOR PORT CONNECTIONS are N/A. CONNECTIONS form CIRCUITS.CONNECTIONS belong to PORTS.CIRCUITS: A data port-to-data port CONNECTION forms a CIRCUIT or a power port-to-power portCONNECTION forms a CIRCUIT.CIRCUITS belong to CONNECTIONS.CIRCUITS have a status such as Planned and Installed for DATA CIRCUITS and POWER CIRCUITS orPowered-off for POWER CIRCUITS.This section covers common terms and, in some cases, how they are related to each other.

In previous versions of dcTrack, the Sites functionality was located in the Classic View and used a flat structure. IndcTrack 5.2 and above, Sites have been renamed to Locations and leverage a hierarchical structure.Upon upgrading an existing system to dcTrack 5.2, previous Locations (Sites) will be designated as Data Centers. AData Center is the top level in the hierarchy and can have Floors and Rooms as its children. Floors can have Roomsas children.At a minimum, creating a location entails entering required basic information.Once required information is entered, upload a drawing file of the data center in the Web Client, and Sync the file ifobjects were not imported during the upload.See Quick Reference - Build Your First Data Center Locations and Add Items and Connections.In the dcTrack hierarchy, ITEMS belong to LOCATIONS.Any data center asset being managed by dcTrack is called an item. All items are assigned a model and make.While Item names are not required to be unique across the database, they must be unique within a Location.Items are broken into classes :AC DistributionBatteryCabinetData PanelDeviceFloor PDUHVACPower OutletPower SourcePassiveProbeRack PDUUPSDepending on the class, items may contain subclasses such as standard, rackable, chassis and so on.

A cabinet is the structure that contains other items such as devices, network equipment, data panels, rack PDUs andso on. Cabinets are also referred to as racks.A cabinet can be an enclosed cabinet/rack or an open bay rack.Cabinets and racks have mounting screw holes that are spaced apart according to an EIA industry standard. Thisspacing is known as a rack unit (RU), which represents a mounting height of 1.75".Items can be mounted on the front or rear rails in a cabinet, or mounted on both the front and rear rails.Items can be referred to as being mounted in, on, above and below a cabinet.A Items mounted in cabinets are placed inside the cabinet and mounted on rails.B When an item is mounted on a cabinet, such as a rack PDU, it can be mounted on the left or right side of acabinet either on the front or back of the cabinet.The orientation is the direction an item faces when it is mounted in a cabinet. In dcTrack, item orientation is either:C "Item Rear Faces Cabinet Front" - the back of the device faces the same direction as the front ofthe cabinet, so that the back of the device is accessible from the front of the cabinet.D "Item Front Faces Cabinet Front" - the front of the device faces the same direction as the front of the cabinet,C "Item Rear Faces Cabinet Front" - the back of the device faces the same direction as the front ofthe cabinet, so that the back of the device is accessible from the front of the cabinet.so that the front of the device is accessible from the front of the cabinet.When an item is mounted below or above a cabinet, it is a standalone item such as a PDU, busway and so on.These items are not displayed in the Cabinet Elevations in dcTrack.The distance between the front and back rails is determined by the Depth of the cabinet as specified in the Model:The depth is the outside measurement (outside surface of back rail to outside surface of front rail).The offsets are always positive and they indicate how far into the cabinet the edge extends.For example:A cabinet whose depth is 935mm with a front offset of 10 and a rear offset of 10 would actually have an inside depthof 915mm. If placing items at the same RU (Front and Back) and their combined depth is greater than 915, the sideview would appear to intersect.
In dcTrack, IT items are combined into three(3) classes. Each item class may contain subclass items such as stand-ard, rackable, chassis and so on.Device ClassNetwork ClassData Panel Class

A device item is any computer system and its peripherals that are placed into a cabinet in the data center.There are various device items in each subclass such as servers, disks, storage, tape drives, KVMs, etc.Devices contain the following subclasses:Standard Device Item Subclass: These include servers, KVM switches, and so on.Chassis Device Item Subclass: These include blade chassis that contain blade servers.Blade Device Item Subclass: Blade servers that are housed in blade chassis.Virtual Machine Device Item Subclass: Any standard, rackable device or standard, blade server can be or beconverted to a virtual machine.A network item is any piece of network equipment that provides network connectivity to devices. For example,blades are network items.Network equipment typically has many more ports than device items.Multiple network items can be grouped into a network stack and given a logical name.Network class items contain the following subclasses:Chassis Network Item SubclassBlade Network Item SubclassNetwork Stack Item Subclass - A grouping of network items. Identified in dcTrack by "NetworkStack".Note: On the Items List, network stacks are identified as NetworkStack.

A data panel (communication panel) is used to terminate both ends of a grouping of a certain number of fixed struc-tured data cables installed in the data center.Typically, one end of the grouping of data cables resides in or near a device cabinet while the other end resides in ornear a network cabinet.Data panels can take a variety of types and form factors such as Category 5e/6/6A RJ45 patch panels, 110-typepunch down blocks, fiber patch panels, etc. Collectively, the comm panels, data cables, and patch cords are referredto as the structured cable plant.In dcTrack, power items are combined into groups called classes. Classes include:UPS Unit ClassFloor PDU ClassPower Outlet ClassRack PDU Class

An UPS unit (Uninterruptable Power Supply) is an electrical system that provides continuous and uninterruptedpower by switching very quickly to a local power source in the event the electrical utility feed is interrupted.The local power source is composed of battery cells that are charged by the electrical utility feed during normal con-ditions.The size and quantity of batteries determine the duration of the local power source.Typically, a UPS feeds PDUs downstream in the power chain.A floor PDU (floor Power Distribution Unit) is an electrical system unit that typically houses a step down transformerand circuit breaker panel boards.In some cases, the electrical panel boards are housed outside the floor PDU in remote power panel (RPP) cabinetsdistributed throughout the data center raised floor. A panel board contains circuit breaker positions called poles.An alternate method of electrical distribution is an electrical busway system whereby the floor PDU main circuitbreakers feed the busway instead of the internal panel boards or RPPs. In this system, the circuit breakers reside onthe busway modules that house the power outlets. Typically, a floor PDU is fed by one or more UPS systems.Note: Do not confuse a rack PDU item with a PDU item. Rack PDU items are essentially a power strip and PDUitems are an electrical system unit that typically houses a step down transformer and circuit breaker panel boards.

A power outlet is the housing unit that contains one or more electrical receptacles of varying types. The electricalreceptacles are, in this case, ports.Each power outlet is fed from a circuit breaker.A rack PDU item is a specialized power strip that is used to provide additional electrical receptacles for a particularelectrical outlet.The rack PDU can be mounted horizontally or vertically in or on the cabinet.Some rack PDUs may be “metered” whereby they include an internal electronic measurement unit to measure thecurrent draw at the receptacle or aggregate level of the rack PDU, and report this reading on an LED display internalto the rack PDU.Other rack PDUs may be “intelligent." This means they can report the current draw as well as other electrical meas-urements at the receptacle level or at the aggregate level of the rack PDU via SNMP to an IP network device.Additionally, some of the “intelligent” rack PDUs can have temperature and humidity probes.PX2 devices that are managing asset sensors are added to dcTrack as a Rack PDU.Note: dcTrack 7.1.0 introduced "AC Power" as a subclass for Rack PDUs. After migrating to 7.1.0 the subclass forall existing Rack PDU Items and Models will be automatically set to "AC Power".

dcTrack 8.2.0 introduces a new class HVAC. This class have following subclasses.Cooling UnitCooling ZoneHeat RejectionNote : After upgrading to 8.2.0 all existing CRAC items and models will be migrated to Class HVAC and SubclassCooling Unit and CRAC Group will be called Cooling Zone.A Cooling unit provides cold and, usually, pressurized air under the raised floor to cool the heat dissipative data cen-ter equipment.

Cooling Zone refer to an area in the data center where all the Cooling Equipments are placed. In dcTrack you canhave one or more Cooling Units assigned to a Cooling Zone.A Heat Rejection unit removes heat from one element and deposit into another. Some examples of Heat RejectionUnits in data center are Chiller, Cooling Tower, Condenser.

Sensors monitor environmental conditions in the data center.For the purpose of asset management, dcTrack includes asset management sensors (AMS) as sensor class items.Asset management tags (AMT) are electronic IDs that are adhered to data center items so you can remotely trackthe item's location.AMTs are plugged in to an Asset Management Sensor, and the AMS is then configured in either Raritan's PX2 orEMX.
The Raritan EMX is added to dcTrack as a probe class item.

In dcTrack, an item's lifecycle refers to the moment space is reserved for an item in a cabinet or the item is placed ina cabinet, to moment the item is decommissioned.A circuit's lifecycle refers to the moment either the complete circuit is created and connected, or a Virtual PowerChain or partial circuit is created, to the moment the circuit is permanently deleted.Requests, or action requests, are submitted in dcTrack when a physical action must be performed for an item or cir-cuit in a data center.For example, submitting an Install Item Request to install a new item, submitting a Decommission Item to StorageRequest to decommission an item to storage, submitting a Connect Request to create a new power circuit, and soon.Requests are applied in the Web Client by selecting the Actions menu for both items and circuits.Alternatively, provided you have the appropriate permissions, you can change an item's status directly on the item'spage by selecting from the Status drop-down menu.Statuses are applied to items and circuits based on an action request or lack of an action request.For example, an item or circuit is in a Planned status when they are first created.Circuits are in a Connected status once the work order to connect the circuit is marked Complete.Items are in an Installed status once they are installed in the data center and their work order is marked Complete, ortheir status is changed manually from the <status>, and so on.dcTrack uses a Change Control workflow to track items and connections in the data center throughout their lifecycle.Even if you are working in Request Bypass, where dcTrack automatically processes the request rather than requir-ing you to manually process it, the item or connection is still tracked in Change Requests.Stages refer to the current point in the Change Control workflow an item or connection is in after a request is sub-mitted.For example, when an item is in a Planned status, it is in the Request Issued stage of the workflow.Once an item is installed, it is in the work order complete stage of the workflow.PORTS belong to ITEMS in the dcTrack hierarchy.An item can have many power, data or sensor ports depending on the item's class. For example, servers have bothpower ports and data ports, while passive items such as cabinet shelves and wire managers do not have powerports or data ports.Ports also have classes. The classes are types of ports -Data PortsPower PortsSensor/Probe PortsIf an item has ports, they are already defined for it the Sunbird Models Library file. This means you do not need tomanually create ports for an item. For example, all of the data ports and power ports for a server are included withthe server.You can create additional ports, delete existing ports, and edit ports if you have Edit privileges to an item.Data ports and sensor ports are created in the Web Client.Create power ports for Device, Network, and Probe class items in the Web Client.Data and power port connections are created in the Web Client.See Manage Circuits and Power in Your Data Centers.Ports that are already connected cannot be deleted until they are disconnected.

DATA PORTS belong to ITEMS in the dcTrack hierarchy.Any port on an item used for voice or data communications is a data port (also referred to as a comm port).Data ports have subclasses. The subclasses assign the port certain attributes and behaviors.A port is defined with a name, connector, communications protocol, transmission speed, address and comments.Data ports are created and managed from the Data - Ports tab on an item's page in the Web Client.Data ports contain the following subclasses:Physical PortsPhysical network ports connect cables to computers, routers, modems and other peripheral devices.Several different types of physical ports are available such as Ethernet ports, serial ports, and so on.Active PortsPhysical ports on an item such as data and power ports.Passive PortsPorts on data panels.Logical PortsLogical ports apply only to bladesA logical port uses the internal communication paths on a blade chassis housing the blades.For example, a device blade logical port-to-network blade logical port within the same chassis, a device blade logicalport-to-its blade chassis.Virtual PortsAny data port on a virtual machine.

POWER PORTS belong to ITEMS in the dcTrack hierarchy.Any port on an item used to provide power to the item. Additionally, there are ports assigned as power ports due toan attribute or behavior.Each receptacle in a power outlet and each inlet cord or outlet in a rack PDU is represented as a power port.Create power ports for Device, Network, Rack PDU and Probe class items in the Web Client.Types of Power PortsPower ports include the following:Power Supply PortsEach power supply on device or on network equipment is represented in dcTrack as a power supply port.Rack PDU Inlet PortsEach inlet cord ports on a rack PDU is represented as a power port.Rack PDU Outlet PortsEach outlet port in a rack PDU is represented as a power port.Power Outlet PortsEach receptacle on a power outlet is represented as a power port.Receptacle PortsEach receptacle port on an item is represented as a power port.Breaker Panel PolesA PDU, RPP or electrical busway module contains panel boards. The maximum number of poles a panel can have is96 for sites with the address in the United States. Sites defined in all other countries can have a maximum of 96poles. Poles are either numbered sequentially in an odd/even layout, or using numbers and letters.A panel is laid out such that odd poles are on the left and even poles are on the right.There are 3 types of circuit breakers: 1-, 2-, or 3-pole breakers. As the name implies, a 2-pole breaker requires twopole positions and a 3-pole breaker requires three positions.CONNECTIONS belong to PORTS in the dcTrack hierarchy, and CIRCUITS belong to CONNECTIONS.Data port-to-data port CONNECTIONS form a CIRCUIT, and power port-to-power port CONNECTIONS form aCIRCUIT.

Implicit ConnectionImplicit connections are those representing structured cabling infrastructure. They are connections made by applic-ation for infrastructure components.For example, a data panel port-to-data panel port, and a power outlet-to-circuit breaker are implicit connections.Explicit ConnectionExplicit connections represent connections to other items. Explicit connections made by users.For example, a patch cord connecting a server to a data panel, a switch to a data panel, or data panel to data panelare explicit connections.Power ports can be connected to other power ports, and data ports can be connected to other data ports.Data port connections and power port connections form a circuit.Sensor ports do not form connections; they are simply tracked from the sensor port on the item.

dcTrack refers to patch panels as 'data panels'.dcTrack organizes and refers to data center assets as items.Items are grouped into classes and there are subclasses of items to further identify and group them.For example, a blade server that belongs to the Device Class is part of the Blade Device Item Subclass. This dis-tinguishes the blade server from Standard Device Items, Chassis Device Items and Virtual Machine Device Items,which are all part of the Device Class.DC Power Classes and Subclasses will appear only when the DC Power feature is enabled.The following table summarizes the classes in dcTrack with examples of the types of items that fall within eachclass:AC Bay, Load Device, OtherItems that are connected to ACAC Distribution Device, Power Panel, Switch,PowerTransformer, UPS BankIndividual batteries that belongBatteryto a UPS unit or DC PowerPlant.A cabinet can be an enclosedCabinetcabinet/rack or an open bayContainerrack.Cabling patch panel of anyData Panelcable type: copper or fiberAny computing equipment,Blade Chassis, Blade Server,Deviceserver, host, disk, host or kvmStandard, Virtual MachineequipmentMain unit that contain panelsFloor PDUhousing circuit breakers or feed-Busway, Local, Remoteing remote power panels (RPP)Heating, Ventilating and AirConditioning; the cooling andheat-rejecting units in the dataCooling Unit, Cooling Zone,HVACcenter, include those inHeat Rejectionbetween cabinets called In-Row cooling unitsAny networking equipmentNetworksuch as switches, routers, fire-Blade, Chassis, NetworkStackwalls, etc.These include wire managers,Passiveblanking plates, cabinet shelvesBlanking Plate, Shelf, Generaland so on.It is a housing unit that con-Power Outlettains one or more electricalBusway Outlet, Whip Outletreceptacles of varying types.Any equipment that is mainFuel Tank, Generator, UtilityPower Sourcesource of power for data cen-Feedter.Any equipment that con-Probecentrates many sensors andconnect to the network.A specializes strip that is usedto provide additional electricalAC Power, Rack TransferRack PDUreceptacles for a particular elec-Switch, Rack UPStrical outlet.An electrical system thatprovides continuous and unin-terrupted power by switchingUPSvery quickly to local powersource in the event the elec-trical utility feed is interrupted.DC Power ClassesPlant, Plant Bay, Plant Panel,Group of all the main com-RectifierDC Power Systemponents for DC Power system.Components that are used inBattery Distribution Fuse BayDC DistributionDC Bay, DC Panel(BDFB) or Battery DistributionCircuit Breaker Bay (BDCBB).A specializes strip that is usedto provide additional electricalDC FAP, Rack Inverter, Rack Rec-Rack PDUreceptacles for a particular elec-tifier,trical outlet.

This is a physical appliance mounted in a data center cabinet is referred to as dcTrack device hardware.dcTrack comes installed on the device.You can use a dcTrack appliance instead of this dcTrack VMWare.For the purposes of dcTrack, appliance refers to Power IQ® hardware devices installed in data center locations.Appliance is also used when referring to dcTrack settings. For example, you access the Settings page by selectingAdmin > Appliance Settings in the Web Client.
dcTrack uses a web-based interface.Following are descriptions of the highest-level Web Client interface elements.

Username Username of the user currently logged into the system. Click to access User Settings.The Default Location drop-down at the top right of the dcTrack Web Client is for information pur-poses only.Selecting from the Default Location drop-down does not cause a change to the application.This is not the same as the Location drop-down, which allows you to change the location you areDefault Locationworking in.drop-downThe drop-down contains a list of all other locations in dcTrack. It displays your default locationunless you make another selection.Your default location is configured by your System Administrator.See Define a User's Default Site/Default Location.Units of measure The units of measure applied to dcTrack - U.S. or S.I. (metric)Web ClientD These tabs provide access to various functions available in dcTrack.Function tabsDashboard Tab - Web Client Dashboard DescriptionVisualization Tab - Floor Map DescriptionCapacity Tab - Intelligent Capacity Search Page DescriptionAssets Tab - Page DescriptionConnectivity ManagementReports Tab - Page DescriptionChange ManagementEventsThe Location drop-down lists all locations you have access to in dcTrack.Location drop-downs that appear at the top left of a page allows you to switch to a dif-ferent dcTrack location by selecting from the list.Location drop-For example, on the Web Client Dashboard you can select a new location to view read-Edownings for, or on the Floor Map under Visualization you can select a new location to view anew data center floor map.Location drop-downs on pages such as a New Item page allow you to select a locationfor the new item and apply it.Use the Refresh button to get the most up-to-date information for the current location,meaning the location indicated in the Location drop-down.F Refresh iconNote that in most cases you must click refresh to get the most current data available,such as power and sensor readings, Dashboard readings and so on.

Log on or Log off link Used to log on to and log off of the dcTrack Web Client.Help link Used to access dcTrack online help and API Guide.Note: The privileges assigned to your role impact what you can access and view in dcTrack, so not all interface ele-ments may be accessible to all users.

There are various views in dcTrack you can access to get information on your overall data center health and cabinet-level health. Note that you must be integrated with Power IQ to retrieve some of this information, floor maps must besynced with locations, and items must be configured to send readings.dcTrack provides an Enterprise Health Dashboard as a way to view the overall health of your data centers. Toaccess the Enterprise Health Dashboard, go to the Dashboard tab and select the second dashboard page.Drill down to a specific location's Health Map from the Enterprise Health Dashboard by clicking on a location tile.You can also apply the Health Map report view from a location's floor map. See and View Data Center ConditionsUsing Floor Map Reports respectively.You can drill-down from a location's Health Map to the cabinet-level to view Cabinet Live Charts. You can alsoaccess these charts by opening cabinet pages from the Items List. Cabinet Live Charts provide several charts youcan use to view power and event information. This information is a summary of the items in the cabinet. SeeCabinet Live ChartsFloor map report views can be applied to a location's floor map. These views provide power, capacity and data cen-ter health information. See View Data Center Conditions Using Floor Map Reports.Cabinet Inspector provides capacity and power data for specific cabinets. Access Cabinet Inspector from a loc-ation's floor map. See Cabinet Inspector.dcTrack provides an Enterprise Health Dashboard as a way to view the overall health of your data centers. Toaccess the Enterprise Health Dashboard, go to the Dashboard tab and select the second dashboard page.In order to display information for each location, you must be integrated with Power IQ and you must have a floormap synced with the location in dcTrack.In order to add tiles in the Enterprise Health dashboard, a Floor Map type widget for the site has to be created in thePower IQ dashboard first.

The Visualization tab in the dcTrack Web Client contains the Floor Maps and Data Network Diagrams.A floor map is rendered when you upload a .DWG drawing file for each of your data center locations in dcTrack. Theobjects on the floor map are then synced with items in dcTrack.From here:View Data Center Conditions Using Floor Map ReportsSet Floor Map Report ThresholdsPrint a Filtered Floor Map ReportZoom In on a Report Section to Print ItDownload a Location's Existing Floor Map Drawing FileExport the Floor Map Report Data List to a .CSV FileFloor Maps can be viewed in two modesFloor Map 2D ModeFloor Map 3D ModeData Network Diagram provides capability to visualize entire Data Network for a single location or across multiplelocations.Data Network Diagrams can be viewed in two formats.Mesh ViewTier ViewFor details see Data Network DiagramsThe Capacity tab provides access to:Use Intelligent Capacity Search to Locate or Qualify Cabinet Space for One or More ItemsUse Capacity Search to Locate a Destination Cabinet

Users who are able to add and edit items manually do so from the Assets tab. This includes adding cabinets anditems, editing information, submitting requests such Install Item Requests, Move Item Requests and so on, cloningitems, using the Export to CSV feature and more.This page can also be customized using filters and through sorting. Once customized, you can save the page set-tings so it is your default view of the page.Sort Data on a List Page in the Web Client and Search and Filter Grids in dcTrackReorder Columns on List Pages, Show or Hide Columns on List Pages and Update the Rows per Page onList PagesExport Data from the Items List or Circuits List to a .CSV File for Reporting, Auditing and ReimportsManage LocationsAdd and Edit ItemsPerforming an Asset AuditCreating New Items and Cabinets Using CloningSubmit an Install Item RequestUse Quick Item Search to Find Items and InformationRequest Bypass and Manual Change ControlConverting an Item to a Virtual Machine - Convert Item to VM RequestAssigning IP Addresses to Data Ports and Port TeamingCreating and Managing PortsDrag-and-Drop an Item to a Different CabinetMoving Items Off Site and Back On Site - Take Item Off-site Request and Bring Item On-site RequestPower Items On and Off - Power-on Item Request and Power-off Item RequestPut Items in Storage - Decommission Item to Storage RequestArchive Items - Decommission Item to Archive RequestDepending on your role, the Connectivity tab enables you to:Customize your circuits list viewExport list data to .CSV from the Circuits ListBuild Data and Power CircuitsCreate Structured Cabling and Data Panel PortsCreate Structured Cabling between Data Panel and Network (Port Mirroring)Connect to a virtual power chainSwitch circuits (connect and reconnect)Switch to and from virtual power chains (connect and disconnect)Tracie circuits from the web client circuits listView, edit, deleting and re-set circuits

Depending on your role, the Change tab provides access to:Requests and Work OrdersManage Work OrdersAdd and Manage ProjectsAdd and Manage TicketsUse the reports to access interactive Reports where you can-Run, View and Print Application ReportsSave Application Report Settings/ViewsPDF reports are accessed from the Asset List or Asset Detail pageCabinet Elevation ReportCabinet Detail ReportItem Detail Report

Depending on your role, the Events tab provides access to Manage Application Events - Review, Export, Clear andPurge dcTrack, Power IQ and AMS EventsYou are able to filter data based on the day an event occurred, the event type, status and so on.For details on managing events, see Event Management.Cabinet Elevations are graphical and text representations of cabinets and their contents.Cabinet Elevations are found on various pages and dialogs in dcTrack.The information that is displayed or the action that is invoked by double-clicking on an item in a Cabinet Elevationdepends on the page you are currently viewing.For example, if you open a cabinet's item page and double-click on an item in the Cabinet Elevation, dcTrack opensthe item's page in a new tab.However, if you are on the item's page and click on that item's image in the Cabinet Elevation, a menu containingoptions to view the Items ports view image (if one is available).You can move items from one position to another in Cabinet Elevations and move blades from one slot to anotherslot. For details, see Move an Item to Another Position within a Cabinet Elevation (Drag-and-Drop) and Move aBlade to Another Chassis from a Cabinet Elevation.You can also access Cabinet Inspector from a Cabinet Elevation when you are viewing a location's floor map or anyFloor Map report on the Floor Maps page, with the exception of the Health Map report which displays Health Detailsinstead of the Cabinet Elevation. For information on Health Details, see .

Rackable items include any items that are mounted in a cabinet such as servers, wire managers and so on.Non-rackable/side-by-side items are mounted next to each other at the same U position in a cabinet or sit on thesame shelf in a cabinet. For example, modems that are on a shelf in a cabinet.The width of each item is divided equally between each of the non-rackable items.The height of each side-by-side item is reflective of the actual height of the item in rack units.Each non-rackable item is displayed from left to right according to the Order field value for each item.Non-rackable items are placed in the front, while other non-rackable items occupy the back of the cabinet at thesame U Position.A text view of side-by-side items is available in the Cabinet Elevation view, but images are not available.Zero U items are mounted on the cabinet.They are displayed to the right and/or left of the cabinet as shown from the 'Back' Cabinet Elevation view.The color of an item in a Cabinet Elevation is determined by the item's current status and its item subclass. For moreinformation on item subclasses, see dcTrack Hierarchy.The same color coding is used in the Web Client Cabinet Elevations.To access the Cabinet Legend, click the hamburger icon in the upper right of the Cabinet Elevation, then select theLegend option from the drop-down menu.Hover your mouse over an item in the cabinet while in Image view to view information. While double clicking an Itemin the cabinet will redirect you to the Item Detail page for that Item.You may switch between Text view and Image view by clicking the camera icon in the tool bar and you can rotate thecabinet between front and rear view by clicking the rotate icon.Clicking the Cabinet Inspector icon displays specific Power, Port and Rack PDU information for the entire cab-inet.

The Cabinet Elevation drop-down menu is available on every page a Cabinet Elevation is available and the drop-down's contents are the same.Use the rotate icon in the Cabinet Elevation to switch between the Front and Back view of the cabinet. You can alsoswitch between images and text by clicking the camera icon.Note: Front and Back images can be viewed when the Items's "Rails Used" option is "Both". If "Rails Used" is either"Front" or "Back" you will be limited to that view only since the assumption is the reverse side is occupied by a dif-ferent Item.

Use the camera icon in the Cabinet Elevation tool bar to switch between a Text or Image view of items in the cabinet.Text is the default view.Images displayed in Cabinet Elevations are pulled from the Item Models Library.If an item's image is not available in the Item Models Library, a Text representation of the item is displayed instead.Once an item is added to dcTrack and saved, it is visible in Cabinet Elevations.If an item's page is open or the item is selected from a list on a page with a Cabinet Elevation, arrows on the rightand left sides of the item indicate its current or proposed U position in its cabinet.If you do not see an item in the Cabinet Elevation, it may be positioned on the other side of the cabinet.For example, if you open a Network Item's page but do not see it in the Back view of the Cabinet Elevation, it may beinstalled in the Front of the cabinet.Use the Rotate Image Icon to view the reverse side.See View the Front or Back of the Cabinet from a Cabinet Elevation.

A In Text view, the item's status and name are displayed in text on the item. Color coding is used toindicate when the item is in a Planned status (red) or the item's subclass (once it is no longer in aPlanned status). See Cabinet Elevation Color Coding.B Image view does not provide color coding and text to provide information about the item.While in Image view or Text view, hover your mouse over an item to view information in a pop up. Specifically, viewthe item's:SubclassNameStatusLocation in the cabinetItems fields displayed in the Cabinet Elevation can be customized. You need to have System Administrator role toselect up to 10 fields including standard fields, custom fields and IP Address.Steps to customize Item fields in Cabinet Elevation:1. In the Cabinet Elevation click the gear icon.2. Click Customize in the menu.3. In Customize Text View Fields dialog, select the fields.Optionally you can also select one field as default field and that field will be displayed in the Cabinet Elevationfor other dcTrack users.4. Click close.From these set of these fields, you can select one item field to display in the Cabinet Elevation. This setting is spe-cific to the individual user and is persisted even after log out and log in.Note: This setting to select a field to display in the Cabinet Elevation will replace existing User Preference setting"Identify Items with"Default field set by the System Administrator will be used when a user does not have a preference selected. Oncethe user select another field, that field will be displayed in the Cabinet Elevation.When a field is removed by the System Administrator from the Customize Text View dialog, that field will no longerdisplay in the Cabinet Elevation for any user. If there are no default field set then Item Name field is displayed inCabinet Elevation.Note: Only the users with System Administrator role can see Customize options. Other users will see the list offields selected by the System Administrator and can select one field to display in Cabinet Elevation.

Double-clicking on an item in the Cabinet Elevation opens its item page from any of these pages:Floor MapIntelligent Capacity SearchA cabinet's item pageFrom the Item's tab on a cabinet's item pageA dialog with a Cabinet ElevationNote: You can also access an item's page from the Items tab on a cabinet's item page. Double-click on an item inthe list to select an item and then click the View icon.

After opening an item's page, double-click on the item in the Cabinet Elevation to open a dialog containing a close-up image of the item.View the item's port labels and identify the item's port connection status from the item's image dialog.Clicking a port status button lights the corresponding ports on the image. For example, click Connected to view con-nected ports, and all ports on the device that are connected glow green.If not item exists for the item in the Item Models Library, this feature is not available for the item.Double-click on any other item in the cabinet to access its item page a new tab. See Access an Item's Page from aCabinet Elevation.Use the Cabinet Inspector to quickly obtain cabinet item totals, available ports, and power data for the cabinet.Cabinet Inspector is accessed from cabinet elevations on every page and dialog cabinet elevations are provided.For details, see Cabinet Inspector.

In addition to identifying the color-coded items in the Cabinet Elevation, the Cabinet Legend contains an illustrationdepicting the front and back of the cabinet, and the front and rear rails of the cabinet.This is the top view of the cabinet, in other words the cabinet seen as if you were looking down at the cabinet fromabove.This is a useful reference when creating an item and selecting position information. Specifically:The rails used to mount a rackable item in the cabinet.Enter one of the following:Front: The item is mounted only on the front rails of the cabinet.Rails UsedBack: The item is mounted only on the rear rails of the cabinet.Both: The item is mounted on both the front and rear rails of the cabinet.Applies to rackable items only.Either:OrientationItem Front Faces Cabinet FrontItem Rear Faces the Cabinet FrontApplies to zero U items only.When items are mounted vertically on a cabinet, this indicates the side of the cabinet they are moun-ted on:Cabinet SideLeftRightApplies to zero U items only.When items are mounted vertically on a cabinet, this indicates whether it they mounted on the cab-inet's front, center, or back:Depth PositionFront: Front is considered the position closest to the rear door of the cabinet.Center: Center is considered the position between the front and back of the cabinet.Back: Back is considered the position furthest from the rear of the cabinet door.

You can move an item to another U position from the Cabinet Elevation using drag-and-drop. See Drag-and-Dropan Item to a New U Position in a Cabinet.For the available U position, you will notice a green highlight.For example, U positions 30 and 31 are free in a cabinet. You can drag-and-drop a 2 RU server from its current loc-ation of U position 28 to U position 30 and you will notice green highlight when you place it at U position 30. If you tryto drop the item at U position 31 you will notice a red highlight, the item will move back to the original U position andcannot be dropped.You can also move an item to another cabinet from a Cabinet Elevation. This feature is available in the Items Listwhere you can select multiple cabinets and view the cabinet elevation for selected cabinets. See Drag-and-Drop anItem to a Different Cabinet.You cannot move an entire cabinet using drag-and-drop. Instead, submit a Quick Move Item Request.

Blade chassis that are contained in a cabinet are displayed in a Cabinet Elevation.You cannot perform any kind of move for blades in the Cabinet Elevation. However, you can:Drag-and-Drop a Blade to a New Slot in a ChassisChanging a Blade's Slot Position in a Blade ChassisMove Item Requests for Blade Servers and BladesCabinet Elevations are available on the floor map after you have synced cabinet objects by uploading a drawing file.Prior to syncing, the Cabinet Elevation is blank when it is expanded.The Cabinet Elevation view is available to the right of the floor map. The cabinet's objects are available in the elev-ation view when the cabinet is populated with items such as servers, wire managers, switches and so on. Mouseover the text or image specific to a device to see more information.Mouse over the cabinet label header row at the top of the Cabinet Elevation view to display a menu of controls thatyou can use to view information in the Cabinet Elevation.To interact with the Cabinet Elevation view:1. Click the rotate icon to switch from the front to the back view of the cabinet. The front view displays by default.2. Click the Camera icon to switch between text and images. Text displays by default. If viewing the images, textwill display if no image is available for a specific device.3. Cabinet Inspector is displayed by default. Click the Eye icon if you want to hide the Cabinet Inspector.4. Click the Hamburger icon to display further options.5. Click the Cabinet Details link to view the cabinet's Item Details page in the Assets tab.6. Click the Legend link to view the color legend.7. The Text View field link displays options for the text you see when you are viewing text versus images in theCabinet Elevation. Item fields displayed here can be customized. See Cabinet Elevation Item Label Cus-tomization for more details.For example, if you select to view Serial Number, the Serial Number for each device will display in theCabinet Elevation view.

Item action requests are submitted in dcTrack when a physical action must be performed for an item in a data cen-ter, such as installing items by submitting an Install Item Request, decommissioning items to storage by submitting aDecommission Item to Storage Request, and so on.You submit action requests for items from the Actions menu or, if you have permissions, immediately change anitem's status directly on the item's page. For information on performing a status change on an item's page, seeChange an Item's Status from the Status Drop-Down.When submitting requests from the Actions menu, you can select multiple items from the Items List and submit arequest for them at the same time. This applies to all requests except Quick Move Item Requests and Prepare MoveItem Requests.An item's status reflects the item action request submitted for it, or the lack of an action request if no action has beensubmitted for it.When an item is created, Planned is its initial status; it remains in this status until an action is submitted for it.Once an action request is submitted for the item:If you are working in Request Bypass, the request is processed automatically and either approved or rejected.The request is submitted for review if Request Bypass is disabled.For information on the Change Control workflow process and Request Bypass, see Request Bypass and ManualChange Control.For information on checking a request status, see Requests and Work Orders.Instead of using the Actions menu, an item's status can be changed directly on the item's page in the Web Client byselecting from the Status drop-down menu while the item is in Edit mode provided you have privileges to do so.This function is useful if:You are adding a new item and want to place it into Storage until it is to be deployedIf Gatekeepers need to make corrections to item statuses under certain conditions, such as:An item has been in operation and is discovered during an audit. The Gatekeeper can enter the item into thesystem, provide the required data, and set the item’s status directly to Installed.An item was entered into dcTrack and is in the Planned status. Instead of deleting the item, the Gatekeeperwants to keep a record of the item for possible future reference. The Gatekeeper can set the item's status dir-ectly to Archived.Later, the Gatekeeper decides that the item will be used, so they can set its status back to Planned.When a status is selected from the Status drop-down menu, it is applied to the item immediately. The status changeis not submitted to Change Control workflow or processed in Request Bypass, and a request is not issued.For information on when to use the Status drop-down menu rather than submit an action request, see When toChange an Item's Status From the Status Drop-Down.The statuses available for selection depend on your role as Gatekeeper, Manager or Member, as well as on theclass of the item.For more information, see Item Action Request Types.

If you are integrated with Power IQ and Power IQ Integration is enabled for the location, you can easily identify itemsthat are mapped to Power IQ by sorting or filtering the PIQ Mapping column on the Items List.Note: Access a mapped cabinet's page by double-clicking on it and then click the Live Cabinet icon to view CabinetLive Charts. For details on Cabinet Live Charts, see Cabinet Live Charts.The Quick Search feature in the Web Client enables users to search and gain access to asset details based on abroad range of criteria, including custom fields. Users simply enter the search criteria, select the desired assets fromthe results in the Items list, and click the assets to view their Item Details pages.The Quick Search bar is available above the navigation menu in the Web Client user interface so users can searchitems regardless of the page they are currently viewing.

To initiate a search, simply start typing your search criteria into the Quick Search bar. Press the Enter button on yourkeyboard to initiate your search after you have entered your criteria.Your criteria will be evaluated against multiple fields, including custom fields, and will be marked with the Multi-Fieldkey in the search bar. The Items list will populate with the results of your search.You can copy and paste text from Item Details pages into the search bar for faster, more accurate search results.Following your initial search, you can refine your results against any standard and custom field that is currentlyshown on the Items List. Simply return to the Quick Search bar and select the criteria by which you want to filter thesearch results.The results of your search can be exported to CSV. You can also save your search criteria in the Items list by click-ing the gear icon > Save Current List Settings in the bottom right corner of the Items list page.The following wildcards are supported by Quick Search:*ABC: Ends in ABCABC*: Starts with ABC*ABC*: Contains ABCABC: Returns an exact match of ABCNote: Multifield quick search does not support wildcards in date fields (e.g., 03/*/17).Standard fields and their types included in the multi-field search are as follows:HardwareMakeModelClassSubclassMountingForm factorSerial numberAsset tagIdentityItem nameAliasTypeFunctionCustomerPlacementLocationCabinetChassisLocation referenceStatusAsset and MaintenanceProject numberPO numberContract numberData PortsIP AddressOtherOriginPower IQ MappingRequest StageNote: Quick Search and the default Search and Filter feature on the Items list are mutually exclusive, so they won’tbe used at the same time. If you are using Quick Search, the Search and Filter feature in the Items list will be dis-abled. However, you can still sort the columns by Ascending and Descending order. If you clear your criteria fromthe Quick Search field, the Search and Filter feature will be available.

Being able to provide a dcTrack user with a link to search results can save time and simplify the process of sharinginformation, especially for organizations that have many novice users. With a shareable link, users can copy andpaste the link into other applications and share it with their teams, without having to explain to those other users theexact search parameters. The link obscures any information that may otherwise be included in the URL that is notintended to be shared with all users.Once a link has been shared with another user, that user will be able to access the same search results, which willbe revised based on the user's permissions if necessary. For more information, see Notes on Role-Based AccessControl (RBAC) for Shareable Links to Quick Search ResultsNote: If a user who is not logged in clicks on a shared link, that user will need to login before being redirected to theappropriate search results.To share a link to results for a Quick Search query:1. To initiate a search, simply start typing your search criteria into the Quick Search bar. Press the Enter button onyour keyboard to initiate your search after you have entered your criteria.2. The Items list will populate with the results of your search.To share the resluts, click the Share Link icon in the tool bar4. In the Quick Link popup, click the Copy Link to Clipboard button to copy the link to your clipboard. Alternatively,click in the link field, highlight the entire URL and either right-click > Copy or use your keyboard shortcut to copythe link.4. Share the link with other users.Note: Only the original search results will be provided via the shareable link, based on the user's permissions. Thelegacy Search and Filter feature, column reordering and selection, and sorting by ascending or descending order,are not supported.

Shareable links respect granular permissions based on role-based access control (RBAC). The results shown forthe shared link search results should be the same as the original results, with the following exceptions:If a user who receives the link does not have access to specific search terms, those terms will be removedfrom the shared search parameters. This will not alter the list of results, unless the user does not have per-missions to view specific items or columns.If a user does not have permissions to view specific items or columns, those inaccessible items or columnswill not be displayed in the shared link search results.If a user has the appropriate permission to view an item, the item will be displayed.If the item includes custom fields, those custom fields will be displayed only if the user has the appropriate per-missions. Inaccessible custom fields will not be displayed.Note: Links do not expire; however, the oldest links may be deleted to accommodate new links. Up to 10,000 linksmay be saved.Being able to provide a dcTrack user with a link to a specific Item Details page can save time and simplify the pro-cess of sharing information. With a shareable link, users can copy and paste the link into other applications andshare it with their team, without having to explain to other users how to navigate to the specific page. The linkobscures any information that may otherwise be included in the URL that is not intended to be shared with all users.Once a link has been shared with another user, that user will be able to access the same item, provided that the userhas the appropriate permissions. For more information, see Notes on Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) forShareable Links to Item Detail Pages.Note: If a user who is not logged in clicks on a shared link, that user will need to login before being redirected to theappropriate page.To share a link to the Item Details page for an asset:1. Navigate to the Item Details page that you want to share.2. On the Item Details page, click the Share Link icon.3. In the Get Quick Link popup, click the Copy Link to Clipboard button to copy the link to your clipboard. Altern-atively, click in the link field, highlight the entire URL and either right-click > Copy or use your keyboard shortcutto copy the link.Note: A new link will be generated each time the Copy to Clipboard button is selected.4. Share the link with other users.Note: The original item will be provided via the shareable link, with revisions based on the user's permissions.

Shareable links respect granular permissions based on role-based access control (RBAC):If a user has the appropriate permission to view an item and clicks the item's shared link, the item will be dis-played.If a user does not have the appropriate permission to view an item and clicks the item's shared link, an errormessage indicating that the user does not have the appropriate permission will be displayed.If the item includes custom fields, those custom fields will be displayed only if the user has the appropriate per-missions. Inaccessible custom fields will not be displayed.Note: Links do not expire; however, the oldest links may be deleted to accommodate new links. Up to 10,000 linksmay be saved.

dcTrack provides a linking mechanism that allows users to access Items directly from the browser. These links canalso be embedded in documents, copied to wiki pages, included in emails or used as field data in other applications.Provided the user accessing the link is a valid dcTrack user and has the appropriate permissions within dcTrack toview the item, clicking the link will open a new tab in the current browser navigated directly to the Item Details pagefor that Item.The format for creating these links is as follows:https://<dcTrack IP Address>/link/search/items?field=XXX&value=YYYFor example, if you use a separate system to track Incident Tickets for assets in dcTrack, you might want to includea link to the dcTrack Item to allow users to view additional information about the item.In the example above, clicking the dcTrack Item Link would open a browser window directing the user to the ItemDetail page for the "CLARITY-123" Item.Note: If the Item Name is unique within dcTrack, users are directed to the specific Item Detail Page for the Item. Ifthe Item Name exists in multiple Locations on dcTrack, users are redirected to a filtered list of all applicable Items.Note: The syntax from previous versions of dcTrack has been deprecated in favor of the current syntax illustratedbelow. The deprecated syntax is not supported in version 9.1.0 and above.https://<dcTrack IP Address>/link/search/items?field=XXX&value=YYYExamples:https://<dcTrack IP Address>/link/search/items?field=tiName&value=1A - Item name containing thetext 1A anywhere in the stringhttps://<dcTrack IP Address>/link/search/items?field=tiName&value="1A" - Exact match of Item Name1Ahttps://<dcTrack IP Address>/link/search/items?field=cmbCabinet&value= 1A- Items whose Cabinetname contains 1Ahttps://<dcTrack IP Address>/link/search/items?field=tiClass&value=Probe - All Items in the ProbeClasshttps://<dcTrack IP Address>/link/search/items?field=tiSerialNumber&value=IS NOT EMPTY - AnyItem whose Serial Number is not blankhttps://<dcTrack IP Address>/link/search/items?field=cmbUPosition&value=5 - Any Item in U Position5 of any Cabinethttps://<dcTrack IP Address>/link/search/items?field=tiCustomField_Country&value=Taiwan - AnyItem with the value of Taiwan for the Custom Field "Country"Application administration refers to tasks performed exclusively by dcTrack System Administrators.The tasks in this section are performed on the dcTrack server, or by users with System Administrative privileges inthe dcTrack application.dcTrack System Administrators are assigned to the dcTrack System Administrators user group by default. This rolehas permissions to do every action in dcTrack.A System Administrators is responsible for installing and configuring dcTrack, including creating users and teams,LDAP user and user group management, importing items, maintaining lists and libraries, and so on.In most cases, this user is separate from the Gatekeeper but in some cases may be the same user.

Installing dcTrack for the first time refers to a clean installation of dcTrack.This means:You are not upgrading to the latest version of dcTrack.You are not currently using dcTrack and are not integrating dcTrack with Power IQ.See the dcTrack Quick Setup Guide for steps on installing dcTrack for the first time.See Reinstalling dcTrack for high level steps to reinstall dcTrack.Note: Upgrading to the newest version of dcTrack may require you to upgrade to a mre recent version first, depend-ing on theSee Virtual Machine Requirements and Recommendations for information on the number of virtual processorsand the amount of memory allocated for the virtual machine.These instructions apply to both new installations and reinstallations of dcTrack.Note: The following steps are provided as an example of a virtual machine installation; follow your installation pref-erences if they differ.1. Connect to the VMware server using the VMware ESXi 6.5 web GUI.2. Ensure you are logged in as a user that has permission to create, start, and stop virtual machines.3. On the Virtual Machine page (check that Virtual Machines is selected in the left Navigator pane), clickCreate/Register VM.4. The New virtual machine wizard opens. In Step 1 of the New virtual machine wizard, Select the Create a newvirtual machine option. Click the Next button.5. On Step 2, type in the name of your virtual machine and select the Guest OS family and verions.a. For the Guest OS family, select Linux.b. For the Guest OS version, select Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8. Click the Next button.6. On Step 3, select a destination storage location for the virtual machine files. Click the Next button.7. On Step 4, configure the VM hardware with the appropriate specifications based on the Virtual MachineRequirements and Recommendations for VMware and your network. In this example, the follow spe-cifications are used:a. CPU: 4 (Note: Adjust the number of CPUs allocated for the virtual machine based on your minimumconfiguration or number of PDUs.)b. Memory: 8192 MB (Note: Adjust the amount of memory allocated for the virtual machine to at least theminimum required.)c. Hard disk: 200 GB (Note: 160 GB is the recommended minimum.)a. Expand the Hard Disk options by clicking the arrow to the left of the field.b. Under Disk Provisioning, select one of the following depending on your needs.i. Thin Provision to save storage space. For the thin disk, you provision as much datastorespace as the disk would require based on the value that you enter for the disk size.However, the thin disk starts small and at first, uses only as much datastore space as thedisk needs for its initial operations.ii. Thick Provisioned, Lazily Zeroed. Creates a virtual disk in a default thick format. Spacerequired for the virtual disk is allocated when the virtual disk is created. Data remainingon the physical device is not erased during creation, but is zeroed out on demand at alater time on first write from the virtual machine.iii. Thick Provisioned, Eager Zeroed. A type of thick virtual disk that supports clustering fea-tures such as Fault Tolerance. Space required for the virtual disk is allocated at creationtime. In contrast to the flat format, the data remaining on the physical device is zeroedout when the virtual disk is created. It might take much longer to create disks in thisformat than to create other types of disks.d. SCSI Controller: VMware Paravirtuale. Network Adapter: Select an available network adapter based on your own configuration and access.Ensure that the Connect checkbox next to this field is checked.f. CD/DVD Drive: Datastore ISO file (Note: Ensure that the Connect at power box next to this field ischecked.)g. CD/DVD Media: When you select Datastore ISO file in the previous field, you will be prompted toselect an ISO image for the CDROM. Click the Browse button to select the dcTrack file for theCDROM.Leave the other options at their default values.8. On Step 5, review your selections. Click Finish to create the virtual machine.9.
