Verify the Firmware option is set to BIOS. This may be set to EFI by default, but you must change it to BIOS toensure the VM can be booted successfully.10. Power on your virtual machine.

1. Connect to the VMware server using the VMware ESXi 6.5 web GUI.2. Ensure you are logged in as a user that has permission to create, start, and stop virtual machines.3. On the Virtual Machine page (check that Virtual Machines is selected in the left Navigator pane), right-click onthe VM where you want to load/install/reinstall dcTrack and select the Edit Settings option.4. In the Edit Settings pop up > Virtual Hardware tab > CD/DVD Drive 1, select Datastore ISO File from the drop-down.5. Use the file browser dialog to select the dcTrack ISO file. If needed, you can download the file from the Sun-bird Support Portal.6. Under Status, check the Connect at power on checkbox to connect the device when the virtual machinepowers on. Optional.7. In the Virtual Device Node drop-down menu, select the node that the drive uses in the virtual machine.8. Click the Save button to save your settings.9. Power on the virtual machine.10. Press Enter to begin installation.11. When the installation completes, press Enter to reboot the dcTrack virtual machine.12. The virtual machine reboots and displays a console prompt.13. Next, Configure dcTrack Network Access.Note: Changing the Hostname through the Console does not modify the externally-facing hostname. The systemhostname is only used internally within the Sunbird appliance and is not advertised outside of the appliance. Theexternal hostname is controlled through an external DNS server. Sunbird strongly recommends leaving hostnameas the default of "localhost.localdomain" to prevent operational issues.To change the System Host Name for your dcTrack, perform the following steps:1. Log into the dcTrack console with the "config" username2. Select the first menu option "Networking Setup"3. Select the "Change Hostname" option4. Enter the new Host Name and Accept.

Note: You should not configure any value in this screen unless directed to by Sunbird Support.The Webserver Settings screen enables an System Administrator to configure allowed hosts or domains. It isaccessible via the console in the Security Configuration menu.See Also Dynamic Content-Security-Policy.

Depending on the current version of dcTrack you are using, you will either upgrade or reinstall dcTrack to move tothe current Release.Contact Sunbird Professional Services and Support at http://support.sunbirddcim.com with issues or questions.

If you are running dcTrack version 6.x or prior please contact Sunbird Professional Services and Support athttp://support.sunbirddcim.com for upgrade instructions.If you are running dcTrack version 7.2.1 or prior, and you want to move to a release after 7.2.1, you must do a fencerelease to upgrade.

Note: We recommend that you back up your dcTrack database manually and update your Models Library beforeupgrading dcTrack.Important: Do not reboot your dcTrack server before the upgrade is complete or your database may be corrupted.Note: Disable all integrations, including your Power IQ, VMware, Ticketing and CMDB integrations, in dcTrackbefore you begin your upgrade.Manually Back Up Your dcTrack DatabaseUpdate the Item Models LibraryDownload the dcTrack Upgrade BIN FileChange the Web Session Timeout for dcTrack

1. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Appliance Administration > Product Upgrade2. Click Browse and select the upgrade file.Note: The upload may take 90 minutes or more.The new firmware uploads to dcTrack, and a series of status bars and validations are displayed.3. Click Check System Compatibility on the Release Notes dialog once the upgrade validation is complete.Contact Sunbird Professional Services and Support at http://support.sunbirddcim.com with any issues that areencountered.4. Click Install on the System Check Status dialog once you receive a Success message.5. A progress shows the upgrade progress, and the system reboots when the upgrade is complete.6. On the Upgrade Success dialog, click OK.7. Log out of dcTrack.8. Reopen your browser and log back in to dcTrack to begin using the application.Important: Clear your browser's cache entirely, including all temp files, cookies, favorites and so on to ensure allcontent is removed, then close the browser. See your browser help for steps on clearing your browser's cache.Contact Sunbird Professional Services and Support at http://support.sunbirddcim.com with issues or questions.Note: It is recommended that you manually back up your dcTrack database before upgrading or reinstallingdcTrack (to create a database backup file that you will use to restore your dcTrack data).

Manually Back Up Your dcTrack DatabaseRetrieve the ISO FileVerify The Datastore and Upload the ISO File to the DatastoreCreate the dcTrack Virtual MachineLoad/Install/Reinstall dcTrack on the Virtual MachineConfigure Network AccessRestore a dcTrack Database from a Backup FileAll Rack PDUPort Names on both Models and Items are renamed from their existing values of "Input"and "Output" to "Inlet" and "Outlet". This port renaming happens as part of the upgrade process. If youhave previously modified the Port Name to a custom name, the custom name value will be saved in anew column "Port Alias" on the Rack PDU Power Port subtab of the Item Details page.The Port Name column for all Rack PDUs will now be a read-only column that can no longer be mod-ified. Any customized names should be set in the "Port Alias" column, and for integrated Rack PDUs, itis the "Port Alias" column that will be synchronized with Power IQ.The Auto Update Rack PDU feature has also been enhanced to more clearly identify and control thePort Names of integrated Rack PDUs. When this feature is enabled the new "Port Alias" column will nolonger be visible. This is because with this feature enabled you are indicating you would like dcTrack tocontrol the Port Names that are synchronized with Power IQ.Once enabled dcTrack will immediately set the Port Alias on dcTrack using the following format for allconnected ports on integrated Rack PDUs and push this name to Power IQ.Format = Connected Item Name:Connected Port Name:Circuit StatusExample: NJESX09:PS1:InstalledAs long as the feature remains enabled, dcTrack will use this same process as new port connectionsare made. dcTrack will also clear the Port Name in Power IQ and on the Rack PDU if the port is dis-connected.If the Port Name is manually changed in Power IQ or on the Rack PDU while this feature is enabled,dcTrack will reset it back to the value based on the format above when the port is connected, or clear itwhen the port is disconnected.To enable this feature navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration > Applic-ation and select the Customized Power Port Names on Integrated Rack PDUs feature.When this feature is enabled, dcTrack will rename the Inlet and Outlet Port Aliases on dcTrack for allintegrated Rack PDUs using the following format:Format = Connected Item Name:Connected Port Name:Circuit StatusFor example if Outlet 4 on an integrated Rack PDU is connected to a server named "NJESX09" on port02 and the connection is still in a planned state, the Port Alias for Outlet 4 would be automaticallyrenamed to:NJESX09:PS2:PlannedAs each Port Alias is modified, the new value is automatically pushed to Power IQ.As long as this feature remains enabled, all future connections created for integrated Rack PDUs willalso rename ports using this format, and automatically push new Port Alias to Power IQ.

System Administrators add license files the first time they log in to dcTrack.If you have not already done so, retrieve your dcTrack license from Sunbird via the link provided in the Welcomeemail you received after registering dcTrack.If you have not received a Welcome email or license file, contact Professional Services and Support from thehttp://support.sunbirddcim.com.Your dcTrack license file is retrieved from the Sunbird website after you activate your registration.To activate your registration, click the link in the "Thank you for registering" email from Sunbird and create your useraccount.Once you create your account, look for a "Your Sunbird software license key is available" email containing a link toyour license file download page.Save the license file locally so you can access it when you need to add it the first time you log in to dcTrack.Additional licenses can be added as needed once you are using dcTrack. See Add a License.dcTrack is licensed based on the number of cabinets maintained by the application. The following table explains thevarious ways cabinet licenses are counted.Cabinet Height in Rack Units: 0 RU Not counted against the licenseCabinet Height in Rack Units: 1 - 12 RU Counted as 1/4 CabinetCabinet Height in Rack Units: 13 - 24Counted as 1/2 CabinetRUCabinet Height in Rack Units: 25 orCounted as a full Cabinetgreater RUCabinet Status: Archived Not counted against the licenseCabinet in a Location with 4 or lessCounted as 1/2 CabinetcabinetsExamples of 0RU Cabinet usage:1. Master plan the cabinet layout in the entire data center. Utilizing 0RU Cabinets provides you with the totalnumber of cabinets that can fit in your data center based on a realistic layout that does not affect your report-ing of available Rack Units based on their Installed or Planned status. A Planned cabinet would representwould-be near term projects, versus a 0RU cabinet which would indicate where a cabinet could fit in a space,but there are no plans to add one there yet2. 0RU Cabinets can also be used for floor space reservations. Because 100% of the cabinets in the DataCenter could be placed and known to dcTrack, dcTrack would now be able to perform calculations and report-ing on those cabinets answering questions like “Do I have space for 5 new contiguous cabinets?". BecausedcTrack’s new calculation does not count 0RU Cabinets against your license, they can be used freely in yourplanning process.3. 0RU cabinets are also useful for Storage rooms. The 0 RU cabinet serves as a representation of a palettewith the equipment stacked on top of it. Create as many 0RU cabinets within these Storage Rooms asneeded. Then assign the Items stored on each palette to a cabinet and select "Above" for the U Position.Examples of a Location with 4 or fewer Cabinets:1. IDF (Intermediate Distribution Frame) or a Telecommunications Closet are typically found in large buildingswith multiple floors and are used to distribute structured cabling to a floor or a section of a floor such as anoffice. These rooms are typically small and contain a few cabinets, or open frame racks mostly full of patchpanels and a new network switch. As noted in the table above, cabinets in locations with four or fewer cab-inets use half a license. For example:a. A room with three cabinets uses 1.5 licensesb. A room with two cabinets uses one licensec. A room with five cabinets uses five licenses (Note: Rooms with more than four cabinets do not get thediscount)You will notice the effects of these changes when viewing licensing information in dcTrack Settings or the dcTrackLicenses Remaining widget, as each could now display a fractional value.Note: Use your dcTrack license in order to make a disaster recovery backup of your database, if needed.

If this is your first time logging in and you need to add a license file, see Retrieve Your dcTrack LicenseLicenses are added after they are bought and retrieved from Sunbird. They are then uploaded to dcTrack.Once you add a license file and log in for the first time, follow the instructions in this topic to add or remove additionallicense files as needed.Typically, System Administrators add and remove licenses.1. If you have not already done so, get a dcTrack license file by contacting Customer Support.2. Click Settings > Application Administration.3. Click Product Licensing in the Application Administration section.4. Click Add in the Licenses section.5. Use the browse function to locate and add the license file.Licenses are .LIC files.Repeat this step to add incremental licenses.Note: If you see error messages AND you are unable to use dcTrack or add the total licensed number of cabinets,contact Sunbird Technical Support. There may be a problem with your license file.The dcTrack Product Licensing page can be viewed by System Administrators. This page provides a licensing sum-mary that encompases the following:Customer NameTotal LicensesUsed LicensesAvailable LicensesThe count of Licensees as defined in the imported License fileExpiration Date of each Licensees LicenseTo view dcTrack License information, navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration > ProductLicensing

Note that you cannot add cabinets once you have reached your dcTrack license limit. Specifically, you cannot savea new cabinet if it exceeds your license.If you perform a cabinet import using File Import, dcTrack does not let you add cabinets beyond your license, andlets you know if this is the case.Your dcTrack license permits you to have a recovery system license at no extra charge. This is used when creatinga backup file of dcTrack.

Only Application administration refers to tasks performed exclusively by dcTrack System Administrators.The tasks in this section are performed on the dcTrack server, or by users with System Administrative privileges inthe dcTrack application.dcTrack Administrators (System Administrators) are assigned to the dcTrack System Administrators user group bydefault in the "admin" role. This role has permission to do every action in dcTrack, no exceptions.A System Administrator is responsible for installing and configuring dcTrack, including creating users and teams,LDAP user and user group management, importing items, maintaining lists and libraries, and so on.In most cases, this user is separate from the Gatekeeper but in some cases may be the same user.System Administrators can change the System Administrator password.Change the default System Administrator password as soon as possible to prevent unauthorized System Admin-istrator-level access to dcTrack.If you are a System Administrator and want to change your own password you may follow the steps below or see:Change Your End User PasswordSteps for System Administrator to change other users password:1. Navigate to Settings -> dcTrack Settings -> Authorization & Authentication -> User Accounts2. Select the User Account whose password you want to change3. Click Change Password.2. The Change Password dialog displays. Enter your old and new passwords.3. Click Change Password to save your changes.The web session timeout determines the length of time dcTrack remains idle before logging a user off.1. Click Settings.2. Click Authorization & Authentication2. Click Session Security.3. In the Security section, click Other Security Settings.3. In the Log users out field, select an option from the "Log users out" drop-down:4. Click Save Timeout.A "User sessions will not time out" confirmation appears at the top of the page.5. To apply the new session timeout, log out of dcTrack, then log back in.

dcTrack uses the system clock to time-stamp events.Set the system clock as soon as possible to keep an accurate record of eventsUsing an NTP server is recommended to keep the system clock synchronized.Note: If your dcTrack is integrated with Power IQ, it is important that both dcTrack and Power IQ are setup to useNTP with the same NTP servers.1. In the Web Client navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration and click the Display &Time menu option.Note: If the Time Zone and "Set time manually" fields are disabled, NTP may be enabled. Deselect the Enable NTPcheckbox if you no longer want to use that options.2. In the Time Settings section, select the Time Zone the dcTrack server resides in from the Time Zone drop-downlist.4. Select the date and time using the tools in the "Set time manually" fields. Select the date from the pop-up cal-endar. Select the 24-hour time from the drop-down list.5. Click Save Time Settings.Note: The Web Client displays the time and date of the local machine it is accessed from, not the system clock.However, database records created from Web Client events such as add item, delete item and so on are recordedin the database using the system clock time.Certain display settings can be managed by System Administrators. Admins can choose to display a Custom Logoin the dcTrack header and can also control whether users can view HTML widgets in Dashboards The Display &Local Settings are accessible in the Settings Tab Application Administration > Display & LocalNote: For new users, the admin's account (username "admin") user preferences for Language, Theme, Unit Sys-tem, Data Separator, Date Format and Cabinet Elevation preferences are used as the default preferences, how-ever the Language used on the Login screen for new users is set from the setting on the Display & Locale page.

Allowing the system to display HTML widgets introduces the risk that an HTML widget may exploit web security vul-nerabilities. For this reason, this capability is not enabled by default.See Also Dynamic Content-Security-Policy.Steps to allow users to view HTML Dashboard Widgets:1. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration > Display & Time2. In the Display Settings panel, check the Allow user-created HTML widgets on the dashboard check box3. Click the Save buttonOnce enabled users will be able to view HTML widgets on dashboards. If this feature is not enabled users will bepresented with the locked widget display when attempting to view HTML widgets.Steps to define a custom Logo in the dcTrack header:1. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration > Display & Time2. Check the Show a custom uploaded logo check box3. Use the browse button to navigate to the image file4. Select the image5. Click the Save button6. Click the Save Display Settings buttonNote: Logos must not exceed 150 pixels wide, 48 pixels high, or 512 KB in size.

A PEM file upload is required to replace the current certificate and private key. The PEM file needs to contain anRSA private key and an X.509 certificate.To view the current HTTPS certificate or to upload a new certificate, navigate to Settings > Appliance Administration> HTTPS Certificate.Note: dcTrack does not provide a Certificate Signing Request (CSR). OpenSSL or any other utility can be used togenerate CSR. dcTrack does not use encrypted private keys. You must remove the password from the Private keybefore it can be used. To remove the encryption from the key, issue a command like: "openssl rsa -in server.key -out server2.key". Use "server2.key" when using openSSL utility.It is not required to provide a root certificate of CA signing dcTrack certificate signing request (CSR).After a review of the ciphers and key exchanges supported by dcTrack’s web server, weak ciphers and those thatdidn’t support Forward Secrecy were removed. The list of supported ciphers in dcTrack 9.1.0 is:Protocol Cipher Suite Name (RFC) Key Exchange Strength--------------------------------------------------------------------------TLS1.3 TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384 x25519 256TLS1.3 TLS_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256 x25519 256TLS1.3 TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256 x25519 256TLS1.3 TLS_AES_128_CCM_SHA256 x25519 256TLS1.2 TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256 x25519 256TLS1.2 TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384 x25519 256

This example procedure is for generating a private key using OpenSSL on a Linux server.1. This command creates an RSA key with Triple DES 2048 byte encryption.openssl genrsa -des3 -out server.key 20482. Remember the key password from this command.3. Generate a Certificate Signing Request. Be prepared to complete the following information:private key passwordtwo character country codefull state or province namecity namecompany nameorganizational unit or leave it blankservers common name or fully qualified domain nameadmin email addressother attributes can be left blank4. Create the request.openssl req -new -key server.key -out server.csr5. Display the CSR request.cat server.csr6. Copy the CSR request and send it to the certificate authority to be signed. Make sure to copy everythingbetween the first "-----" and the last "-----".7. Submit CSR to certificate authority and receive signed X.509 certificate.8. Modify the server key to remove the passwordcp server.key server.key.secureopenssl rsa -in server.key.secure -out server.keyNote: The server.key file must be kept private and secure. If this key file is compromised, the certificate should beremoved and then reissued.9. Create PEM file.The PEM file should contain both the RSA private key without password and the X.509 certificate.Concatenate the unprotected private key to the signed X.509 certificate file from the top level certificateauthority.Use this file in the upload in Step 2.You may want to manually load the certificate in your browser first to prevent issues while everything loads andrefreshes in dcTrack. If you see any issues, such as bad labels or a partially loaded UI, refresh your browser toresolve them.1. In the Settings tab, click HTTPS Certificate in the Appliance Administration section. If uploaded, the currentHTTPS certificate displays.2. To replace the current certificate or to add a new certificate, click the Upload New HTTPS Certificate button. TheUpload New HTTPS Certificate dialog displays.3. In the Upload New HTTPS Certificate dialog, click the Choose File button to open the file selector dialog andselect your PEM file.3. Click the Upload button.

To increase security, dcTrack® can be configured to restrict web interface and SSH access by IP address.When trusted hosts are specified, dcTrack blocks attempts to connect from addresses not specified.When no hosts are specified, ports 22, 80, 443, 5432 are open to all hosts.To restrict web and shell access:1. In the Web Client, navigate to Settings > Appliance Administration > IP Based Access Control. The IP BasedAccess Control panel displays.2. The global options will override any options that allow access to the SSH and ODBC service.a. Allow ICMP ping responseb. Block all SSH accessc. Block all ODBC access: See Configuring ODBC Access to dcTrack.3. Identify the hosts to allow access to in the Access Policy fields.Note: You can enter an IP address, or a subnet using CIDR notation such as 192.168.45.0/24.4. For each address, select how it is permitted to access dcTrack.a. Select the Enable SSH to allow SSH access checkbox.b. Select the Enable HTTP/HTTPS checkbox to enable access through the web interfaceSelect Enable ODBC to allow third party access.5. Click the Save button.dcTrack uses the configured proxy for outbound connections. The main purpose of this feature is for CMDB integ-ration.Check your firewall and security settings to ensure that communication between the proxy server and dcTrack isallowed.To configure proxy connections to dcTrack:1. Click Settings > Appliance Administration.2. Click the Proxy tab in the Application Administration section.3. Select your proxy protocol: HTTP or HTTPS.4. Type in your Proxy Host and Proxy Port.5. Click Clear Proxy Configuration to clear all proxy fields.6. Select the Authentication Required checkbox if your proxy requires authentication and provide a Username andPassword.7. Click Save to save your changes.

Configure the SMTP server settings to determine how email notifications are sent.1. In the Settings tab, select dcTrack Settings > Appliance Administration >Email.2. In the SMTP Server Settings panel, enter the basic settings for the SMTP server.SMTP Server address: Enter the email server's domain name or IP address.Port: The default port is 25. Change this number if you use a different port.Sender email address: Enter the dcTrack's IP address or a designated email address.In the Authentication and Encryption Settings section, select the settings for your SMTP server.Authentication type: Select None or Password. If you select Password, enter the Username, Pass-word, and Confirm password.3. Select an Encryption method: None, SSL, TLS.4. Click Send a Test Email to enter your email address and try sending an email message using the settings youconfigured. If you see a success message, click Save SMTP Settings.5. If you see a failure message, edit your settings and try again. A password must be entered in the page to testthe settings. Once saved, passwords do not display in the page for security.*Note: dcTrack does not currently support SMTP through MFA/2FA. Office365 Users can utilize Microsoft Applic-ation Passwords to work around this case."External Syslog servers can be used to record events occurring on dcTrack. Using a Syslog provides a separateexternal log of events.All servers listed under Current Syslog Destinations record events on dcTrack. Recorded events include new users,configuration changes, and failed login attempts.To configure logging through Syslog:1. Click Settings. The Settings page displays .2. Click Application Administration .3. Click Log Forwarding4. In the Server Addresses panel, click Add Server, then type the IP address of a Syslog server in the IP or Host-name field. This must be in the form of a numeric address.5. To stop a syslog server from recording events: Click the trash can icon next to the server you want to remove.6. Click Save to save your changes.

We recommend that you configure a remote storage location for your system backup files to prevent data loss and toautomatically store your back up archive files. All files that are not being actively written to are automatically storedon the configured server.System configuration archives (system configuration backup files), including daily automatic backups and manuallycreated backups, can be archived.Ensure the server date and time is correct. If the date and time is not correct, dcTrack® may fail to send thebackup files.If you are using Amazon's S3 account to store backup files, make sure dcTrack is configured with the DNSserver, otherwise dcTrack cannot communicate with Amazon.

To configure remote storage of backup files:1. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Appliance Administration> Data Management > Backups RemoteStorage.2. In the Remote Storage Configuration panel, select your remote storage service type from the drop-down. Thepanel updates with fields for additional information depending on your selected serviceNone: Stop automatic remote storageAmazon Web ServiceFor AWS, you must provide the following information: Amazon Web Services ID, Secret key, Bucket and Path. Youcan also check the Require SSL checkbox to require SSL encryption.SCP or SFTPIf you use SCP or SFTP you must have the remote servers public key. This allows dcTrack to connect to the remoteserver.If you use user key authentication, then the private key is the user’s private key. You need to create either aned22519, DSA or RSA public and private key. Once you have a private key, you must also add the matching publickey to the user's ~/.ssh/authorized_keys while adding the private key in the DcTrack's private key dialog box.For FTP, simply provide the applicable Host Name, Port, Username, Password, Password Confirmation and Stor-age directory4. Complete the authentication and location information for your selected remote storage service.5. Click Save.The remote storage backup file does not immediately appear in the remote storage location since the file is sched-uled to be transferred when the daily cron job runs.Note: The remote storage settings page no longer displays the actual values for Private Key and Host Public.Instead, it shows the SHA-256 digest of the values.Note: DSA certificates are deprecated in dcTrack 9.2.0. NIST has deprecated the use of DSA (Digital SignatureAlgorithm) because it is no longer considered secure. If you currently use a DSA certificate, dcTrack will continue touse it for securing HTTPS traffic. However, you can no longer upload these certificates via the web UI.Sunbird suggests you keep at least four (4) database backup copies at a time.Note: Four backup files are kept in dcTrack by default.

Backups of system data, users and configuration settings are automatically created every 24 hours.Optionally, you can create a backup as needed by following the steps in this topic, or automating backups. SeeAutomated Database Backups.Use your dcTrack license in order to make a disaster recovery backup of your database, if needed.To back up or restore the dcTrack Database, navigate to Appliance Administration > Data Back Ups, where you canview and manage your backups.To create a new back up, click Create Back up. The back up is generated and the backups list automaticallyupdates. Local back ups are saved to your dcTrack system. dcTrack displays a Backup in progress status bar toshow the status of a backup process.To restore a back up:1. Click Restore Backup. The Restore Backup dialog displays2. Select if you want to restore from a Local or Remote file.3. If restoring from a Local file, select the file and then click Restore Backup4. If restoring from a Remote file saved to your local machine, click Remote Archive.5. Click Choose File to select the file and then click Restore Backup.6. dcTrack displays a Restore in progress status bar to show the status of a restore process.

When performing a dcTrack database backup, Sunbird suggests the following in order to minimize the risk of dataloss and system downtime.If you are running dcTrack from a virtual machine:Check with your virtual machine group to make sure your virtual instance is backed up.If the virtual machine is backed up, ask for the backup frequency and retention duration.If you are running dcTrack on a hardware appliance or you do not want to rely on your virtual machine instancebackup, Sunbird recommends:Set up your nightly back-ups so they are automatically moved to an FTP server, or manually move them to alocal computer each day.Restore the back-ups to a recovery system on Monday, Wednesday and Friday each week. See Restore adcTrack Database from a Backup File.Spot checking your standby system.Note: Your dcTrack license permits you to have a recovery system at no extra charge.Backups of system data, users and configuration settings are automatically created every 24 hours or can be con-figured to run based on a user defined schedule (See Automated Database Backups). Optionally, you can create abackup as needed by following the steps in this topic.It is recommended that you manually back up your dcTrack database before upgrading or reinstalling dcTrack (tocreate a database backup file that you will use to restore your dcTrack data).Use a dcTrack recovery license in order to make a disaster recovery backup of your database, if needed.The Backup page contains a grid list of available archives with the following columns:File - Archive Filename (link to download archive file)Timestamp - Timestamp when the archive was generatedmd5sum - md5sum generated hash value. Click the folder icon to copy the hash value to your clip boardSize - Size of the archive file

SchedulingBackup Interval - How often automatic backups should be runEvery HourEvery 2 HoursEvery 4 HoursEvery 8 HoursEvery DayDaily Backup Schedule - Time of day to begin the automatic backupEncryptionNote: dcTrack encrypts data backup files using a GnuPG/PGP public key that you generate. You can gen-erate PGP Encryption Keys using free tools. Go to https://www.gnupg.org and look for a binary for your oper-ating system on the Downloads page.Encrypt Backup - Check if you want backups to be encryptedIf encrypting backups you are required to provide the GnuPG/PGP Public KeyRemote StorateService used for storing backups remotely.Available Services include:AWSSCPSFTPFTPYou must supply the required configurations for each service typeTo manually create a new Backup1. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Appliance Administration > Data Backups.2. In the Backup Tool bar, click the Create button.The file is created and added to the top of the list under Filename.An MD5 file is also created along with the backup file for verification purposes.Unless manually deleted, four days of backups are retained before they are deleted and no more than two backupsare retained for any given day.After you create a backup database file, verify it is not corrupted.dcTrack® 3.0.1 (and later) creates an MD5 file along with each dcTrack database backup file you create. Verify theintegrity of the database backup file using the MD5.To verify database files uses MD5:1. In the Web Client navigate to , Settings > dcTrack Settings > Data Management > Data Backups2. In the Backup Archives section, click on the link for the MD5 file you want to view or download. Save or open thefile when prompted.

dcTrack provides the ability to schedule backups. Previously backups of system data, users and configuration set-tings were automatically scheduled and created every 24 hours. The backup feature now allows users to schedulebackups to occur every hour, every 2 hours, every 4 hours, every 8 hours or every day.Steps to schedule backups:1. Navigate to Settings > Appliance Administration > Data Backups2. In Backup Configuration Panel, select the desired interval3. If the Backup Interval is "Every Day", select the desired time of day for backups to begin4. Click Save to save your settingsNote: Backup intervals are based on Start Time, not End Time. For example if a backup is scheduled hourly and thebackup begins at 1:00 and takes 15 minutes to run, the next backup will begin at 2:00 not 2:15. Additionally if abackup takes longer than the specified interval, the next backup is skipped. For example if the backup is scheduledhourly and begins at 1:00 and takes 75 minutes to run, the next backup will begin at 3:00.The script mechanism is independent of the share file system used.Example using a Windows 7® machine:1. Mount a CIFs share drive onto the Windows 7 machine using Windows Explorer®.2. Open a Cygwin session on a Windows 7 machine.3. Change directory to the mount share drive and directory4. Execute:curl -k --user [user name]:[password] https://[hostname]/admin/backups/latest >latest.datThis downloads the latest .DAT (backup file) onto the share drive.

Note: This topic is specific to a general database restore.For details on restoring your database after you reinstall dcTrack 4.0.0 when moving from a lower dcTrack version,see Reinstalling dcTrack.Provided you created a backup file of your dcTrack database, you can use the file to restore your database.As a best practice, restore your database with a backup from the same version of dcTrack.For example, restore a dcTrack 6.0.0 database with a dcTrack 6.0.0 backup file, restore a dcTrack 7.2.0 databasewith a dcTrack 7.2.0 backup file, and so on.You can restore your database with a backup from an earlier version of dcTrack but the backup cannot be olderdcTrack 3.1.0. Sunbird does not recommend doing this as standard practice.Note: Since you cannot use a database backup file from dcTrack 3.0.1 and earlier, you must first upgrade todcTrack 3.1.0 at a minimum. Follow the recommended upgrade process outlined in Upgrade Compatibility, and/orcontact Sunbird Customer Support for assistance.Note: Database versions prior to 7.0 can not be applied directly on dcTrack version 8.0.0. If you are running anearlier dcTrack version you must first upgrade to at least version 7.0 and then to 8.0.1. In the Settings Tab, click Appliance Administration > Data Back ups2. Click Restore Backup. The Restore Backup dialog box3. In the Restore Backup dialog box, select your desired backup file.4. Click Restore BackupThe amount of time it takes to restore your database depends on the size of your database.Once the completed, dcTrack data and configuration settings are restored to the backup's configuration settings,and the server is rebooted.5. Log out of dcTrack.6. Important - Clear your browser's cache entirely, including all Temp files, cookies, favorites and so on, then closethe browser. See your browser help for steps on clearing your browser's cache.7. Reopen your browser and log back in to dcTrack to begin using the application.

You can change the default message that displays on the dcTrack login page, sometimes called the dcTrack splashscreen, to a customized message.To change the login page message:1. Click Settings.2. In the Login Page Message section. provide the Header and Body text.3. You can use html tags for formatting.Header: Text entered in this field displays on the login page in a bold font, as the heading to the messageBody: Text entered in this field displays in a normal font, as the main content of the message.Allowed html tags: strong, em, a, fontAllowed html attributes: href, title, color4. Click Save Message. Log out of dcTrack to return to the login page and view the message.Important: This topic applies to users who are configuring remote LDAP authentication for the first time, meaningyou are adding a new LDAP server and new users and/or user groups.Note: dcTrack version 7.2.0 introduced support for One Time Passwords via LDAP. Prior releases required issuing2 requests to authenticate a user, one to authenticate and one to gather the user's details. As a result the secondrequest failed if the user was flagged with a One Time Password. In dcTrack 7.2.0 and beyond a single request isissued which will both authenticate the user as well as gathering the user's details.However, you must take some additional steps to now move to remote LDAP authentication. For detai

This topic walks you through gathering server information, adding the LDAP server, configuring general server set-tings and sync settings in dcTrack, as well as searching for and adding users and/or user groups.This topic also describes enabling and disabling LDAP in dcTrack, and how to delete an LDAP server.An Active Directory server section and LDAP server section are provided since the information you need to gatherand the steps vary slightly.System Administrators can use LDAP and/or Active Directory (AD) in to automatically add and manage users and/oruser groups in dcTrack. This is an alternative to local authentication, or manually adding and managing LDAP users.See Local User Authentication and Manually Add and Manage Users and Groups via LDAP or Active Directory(Search), respectively.Unlike manually adding LDAP users, you can add both users and user groups with this feature.Additionally, changes to individual users and user groups on the remote LDAP server are automatically reflected indcTrack. Syncs are performed at intervals you configure in dcTrack's Common Settings.For example, if you change a user's email address on the LDAP server, once a sync occurs, the address is changedin dcTrack. Another example would be when you add a user to an LDAP user group. Once the user is added to theuser group, the user is automatically added to dcTrack with the same permissions as the other members in thegroup.

1. Click Add Server on the LDAP Servers page.The Add LDAP Servers page opens.Complete the fields in each section that apply to your specific needs. Use the configuration information you gatheredearlier to complete each section.Note: Configuration settings vary slightly between Active Directory and LDAP.

1. Select Active Directory Server as the server type.2. Select the order in which the server will be listed in the LDAP Servers table. This dictates the order in whichdcTrack communicates with the servers when multiple servers are configured.3. Select the Active checkbox to enable the server, or leave it deselected and return to activate it at a later time. Itmust be active in order to be in use.The information you enter in the remaining sections is specific to the server type you are configuring: either ActiveDirectory or LDAP.For this reason, Active Directory and LDAP settings are broken out into two sections on this page: Active DirectoryServer Configuration in dcTrack and LDAP Server Configuration in dcTrackScroll down the page to view LDAP setting instructions.4. Domain - applies if Active Directory only. The domain name of the server.5. Use Host - select if you want to use a specific hostname or IP Address to access the Active Directory server.6. Hostname/IP Address - enter the Active Directory server's hostname or IP address if Use Host is selected.7. Use TLS/SSL - select if using TLS/SSL encryption.8. Port - the default is Port 389 if TLS/SSL encryption is not enabled, and Port 636 is the default if TLS/SSL encryp-tion is enabled. The port number can be edited to a different value, if necessary.

9. If you need to validate certificates, select Check Server Certificate.10. Next, click the Manage Certificates link to open the Trusted Certificates page. The certificate needs to be PEMformat to upload.11. Click Import Certificate to open the Import Trusted Certificate page. The certificate needs to be PEM format toupload12. Click on the "Choose File" text box to open your browser to locate the certificate, then click Import to import thecertificate.You can use the Back button in your browser to return to the Add LDAP Server page.The information entered here identifies where searches are performed to locate users on the server.13. Base DN - specify a Base DN (directory level/entry) under which the authentication search query will begin.dcTrack can do a recursive search downward from this Base DN..For example, depending on the scope of the search, if the Base DN is dc=sunbird,dc=com, the search query for theuser entry will be made over the whole directory structure.If the Base DN is cn=Administrators,cn=Users,dc=sunbird,dc=com, the search query will begin in the Administratorssubdirectory (entry).14. Login Name Attribute - the login name that corresponds to the server type. The default for Active Directory issAMAccountName.15. Search Filter - enter a user's attributes in this field if you want the search query to be restricted to only thoseentries that meet the criteria. The default for Active Directory is (objectClass=user).16. Search Scope - level of the server directory to look for users; either the Base DN and one level below the BaseDN, or the Base DN and the entire subtree below.17. Follow Referrals - select this option to allow the dcTrack LDAP client to follow referrals provided by the LDAPserver if referral objects are encountered.18. Search Credentials:Leave "no search" to use the credentials provided by the user on log in.Select "anonymous" if no credentials are required.Select "use admin credentials" and enter the admin user credentials in the Admin DN and Admin Passwordfields. The admin credentials will be used for the service account when conducting searches.

19. User Groups for Authorization and Common Setting – ‘Sync Group Members’ will be used to enable the ability toautomatically add and manage users from imported user groups.20. Use Group Search DN - select to specify the group DN to search. Select this option if the group DN search is dif-ferent than the search used for users.21. Group Search DN - this is where the search for the user group will begin in the directory.22. Group ID Attribute - the default for Active Directory is sAMAccountName.23. Group Member Attribute - the default for Active Directory is member.24. Group Search Filter - the default for Active Directory is (objectClass=group).25. Group Search Scope - level of the server directory to look for groups; either the Base DN and one level belowthe Base DN, or the Base DN and the entire subtree.26. Optional Test Connection is to test with an account. If you have a known, valid test account to use to test theserver setup, you can test from here without having to try to login with that account.27. Click Save to save the settings and add the server.Once added, the server is listed on the Add LDAP Server page.

1. Select LDAP Server as the type.2. Select the order in which the server will be listed on the LDAP Servers table. This dictates the order in whichdcTrack communicates with the servers when multiple servers are configured.3. Select the Active checkbox to enable the server, or leave it deselected and return to activate it at a later time. Itmust be active in order to be in use.The following steps describe LDAP settings you configure. Scroll up to view Active Directory settings if you are con-figuring an Active Directory server.4. Domain - does not apply to LDAP.5. Use Host - select to use a specific hostname or IP address to access the LDAP server.6. Hostname/IP Address - enter the LDAP server's hostname or IP address when Use Host is selected.7. Use TLS/SSL - select if using TLS/SSL encryption.8. Port - the default is Port 389 if TLS/SSL encryption is not enabled, and Port 636 is the default if TLS/SSL encryp-tion is enabled. The port number can be edited to a different value, if necessary.

9. If you need to validate certificates, select Check Server Certificate.10. Next, click Manage Certificates to open the Trusted Certificates page. The certificate needs to be PEM format toupload.11. Click Import Certificate to open the Import Trusted Certificate page.12. Click on the "Choose File" text box to open your browser to locate the certificate, then click Import to import thecertificate.You can use the Back button in your browser to return to the Add LDAP Server page.The information entered here identifies where searches are performed to locate users on the server.13. Base DN - specify a Base DN (directory level/entry) under which the authentication search query will begin.dcTrack can do a recursive search downward from this Base DN.For example, depending on the scope of the search, if the Base DN is dc=sunbird,dc=com, the search query for theuser entry will be made over the whole directory structure.If the Base DN is cn=Administrators,cn=Users,dc=sunbird,dc=com, the search query will begin in the Administratorssubdirectory (entry).14. Login Name Attribute - login name that corresponds to the server type. The default is the user ID.15. Search Filter - enter a user's attributes in this field so the search query will be restricted to only those entries thatmeet this criterion. The default is (objectClass=inetOrgPerson).16. Search Scope - level of the server directory to look for users; either the Base DN and one level below the BaseDN, or the Base DN and the entire subtree below.17. Follow Referrals - select this option to allow the dcTrack LDAP client to follow referrals provided by the LDAPserver if referral objects are encountered.18. Search Credentials - leave "no search" selected if no search is required.Select "anonymous" if no credentials are required.Select "use admin credentials" and enter the Admin DN username and Admin Password. These credentialswill be used for the service account when conducting searches.

19. User Groups for Authorization and Common Setting – ‘Sync Group Members’ are used to enable automaticallyadding and managing users from imported user groups.20. Use Group Search DN - select to specify the group DN to search. Select this option if the group DN search is dif-ferent than the search used for users.21. Group Search DN - this where the search for user groups will begin in the directory.22. Group ID Attribute - the default is gidNumber.23. Group Member Attribute - the default is memberUid.24. Group Search Filter - the default is(objectClass=posixGroup).25. Group Search Scope - level of the server directory to look for groups; either the Base DN and one level belowthe Base DN, or the Base DN and the entire subtree.26. Optional Test Connection is to test with an account. If you have a known, valid test account to use to test theserver setup, you can test from here without having to try to login with that account.27. Click Save to save the settings and add the server.Once added, the server is listed on the Add LDAP Server page.1. On the Add LDAP Server page, click Search.The Search for LDAP Users and Groups page opens.2. Select the server you want to search.The remaining server information is completed based on the server you selected earlier, or you can edit the inform-ation by entering a new server to search.3. Select the type of search - Users or Groups, depending on how the server is configured in dcTrack.4. Select the Follow Referrals checkbox, if desired.5. Search Scope is prepopulated based on the scope you defined when adding the server.You can change the scope of the search, if desired.This is the level of the server directory to look for users or groups. You can search just the Base DN by selecting"Base", search the Base DN and one level below the Base DN by selecting "One", or search the Base DN and theentire subtree by selecting "Subtree".6. Click Search to locate users or user groups on the server.7. A list of results is displayed once found. You can now add users and/or groups to dcTrack from those found.To add users or groups found in an LDAP search, select the checkbox next to each user and/or user group in the list,then click Add.In order to search and add user groups, the ‘Use Groups for Authorization’ option must be enabled on the Serverpage.When searching for and adding user groups, one or more groups can be selected at a time. The users will not beautomatically added unless the Common Settings – ‘Sync Group Members’ is enabled.When searching for and adding user groups, clicking on a user group causes the group members to be listed belowthe user group grid. One or more group members can be selected to be added.Successfully added users/user groups are listed as "Exists as LDAP user" and the checkbox next to the name isremoved.Once added, individual users are granted distinct permissions and authenticated on a per user basis.Users in user groups are granted common access to specific features or functionality.Any changes you make to a user or user group on the server are reflected in dcTrack. For example, if you delete auser from a user group, they are no longer able to access the features they previously could in dcTrack.

This information can be edited and configured now or at a later time.8. To edit user information or login credentials, navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Authorization & Authentic-ation and select User Accounts.You can easily identify users added via LDAP since the LDAP DN field is populated in their row.9. Click on a user's name to open their User Information page.10. Click Edit on the User Information page.11. All editable fields are activated.12. Login is required and must contain the username. 3 characters minimum. 40 characters maximum.Important: If authentication is required by your email system, the dcTrack username must be the same as the user'semail account username*. If the usernames do not match, emails cannot be successfully sent from dcTrack.For example, if the username assigned to an email account is jqpublic, the dcTrack username must be jqpublic.If authentication is not required by your system, usernames do not have to match.13. Required Mail is required and must contain a correctly formatted email address.Note: Account username refers to the username assigned to the email account; it does not refer to the name por-tion of the user's email address. Typically, the username and name portion of an email are the same, but this maynot be the case.dcTrack allows you to configure common settings that control the number of users and/or user groups returned in asearch. This feature also allows you to enable LDAP syncing. LDAP syncing controls the interval between whendcTrack and the LDAP server are synchronized.There are several times when group synchronization will occur. Note that in each of these scenarios both the "SyncGroup Members" option found on the Common Settings page and the "Use Groups for Authorization" option foundon the Settings page for each individual server must be enabled. If either of these options is not enabled, group syn-chronization will not occur.Group Synchronization occurs:During periodic sync as determined by the Sync Interval defined in Common SettingsWhen performing a manual sync by clicking the "Sync Now" button in Common SettingsWhen a new user that does not exist in dcTrack but does exist in LDAP/AD logs into dcTrack for the first timeWhen an existing dcTrack user logs in, his groups are not automatically synchronized. Groups for existing users willbe synchronized during the next manual or periodic sync. The user information for existing users (Name, Email) how-ever is updated each time the user logs into dcTrack.1. Click Common Settings on the Add LDAP Servers dialog opens.The Editing Common LDAP Settings page opens.2. Select Enabled to enable the dcTrack LDAP client3. To sync immediately, click Save and then click Sync Now.8. Click Save to save the settings. You can use the Back button in your browser to return to the Add LDAP Serverpage.

1. Click Add Server on the LDAP Servers page.Complete the fields in each section that apply to your specific needs. Use the configuration information you gatheredearlier to complete each section.Note: Configuration settings vary slightly between Active Directory and LDAP.

1. Select Active Directory Server as the server type.2. Select the order in which the server will be listed in the LDAP Servers table. This dictates the order in whichdcTrack communicates with the servers when multiple servers are configured.3. Select the Active checkbox to enable the server, or leave it deselected and return to activate it at a later time. Itmust be active in order to be in use.The information you enter in the remaining sections is specific to the server type you are configuring: either ActiveDirectory or LDAP.For this reason, Active Directory and LDAP settings are broken out into two sections on this page: Active DirectoryServer Configuration in dcTrack and LDAP Server Configuration in dcTrackScroll down the page to view LDAP setting instructions.4. Domain - applies if Active Directory only. The domain name of the server.5. Use Host - select if you want to use a specific hostname or IP Address to access the Active Directory server.6. Hostname/IP Address - enter the Active Directory server's hostname or IP address if Use Host is selected.7. Use TLS/SSL - select if using TLS/SSL encryption.8. Port - the default is Port 389 if TLS/SSL encryption is not enabled, and Port 636 is the default if TLS/SSL encryp-tion is enabled. The port number can be edited to a different value, if necessary.

9. If you need to validate certificates, select Check Server Certificate.10. Next, click the Manage Certificates link to open the Trusted Certificates page.11. Click Import Certificate to open the Import Trusted Certificate page.12. Click on the "Choose File" text box to open your browser to locate the certificate, then click Import to import thecertificate.You can use the Back button in your browser to return to the Add LDAP Server page.The information entered here identifies where searches are performed to locate users on the server.13. Base DN - specify a Base DN (directory level/entry) under which the authentication search query will begin.dcTrack can do a recursive search downward from this Base DN..For example, depending on the scope of the search, if the Base DN is dc=sunbird,dc=com, the search query for theuser entry will be made over the whole directory structure.If the Base DN is cn=Administrators,cn=Users,dc=sunbird,dc=com, the search query will begin in the Administratorssubdirectory (entry).14. Login Name Attribute - the login name that corresponds to the server type. The default for Active Directory issAMAccountName.15. User Email Attribute - a configurable custom mail property used when the default property "mail" is not used.Note: If the admin specifies a value, that value will be used. If left blank, the servers default value will beusedLDAP servers default "mail"AD servers default "mail" and then "userPrincipalName"16. Search Filter - enter a user's attributes in this field if you want the search query to be restricted to only thoseentries that meet the criteria. The default for Active Directory is (objectClass=user).17. Search Scope - level of the server directory to look for users; either the Base DN and one level below the BaseDN, or the Base DN and the entire subtree below.18. Follow Referrals - select this option to allow the dcTrack LDAP client to follow referrals provided by the LDAPserver if referral objects are encountered.19. Search Credentials:Leave "no search" to use the credentials provided by the user on log in.Select "anonymous" if no credentials are required.Select "use admin credentials" and enter the admin user credentials in the Admin DN and Admin Passwordfields. The admin credentials will be used for the service account when conducting searches.

20. User Groups for Authorization and Common Setting – ‘Sync Group Members’ will be used to enable the ability toautomatically add and manage users from imported user groups.21. Use Group Search DN - select to specify the group DN to search. Select this option if the group DN search is dif-ferent than the search used for users.22. Group Search DN - this is where the search for the user group will begin in the directory.23. Group ID Attribute - the default for Active Directory is sAMAccountName.24. Group Member Attribute - the default for Active Directory is member.25. Group Search Filter - the default for Active Directory is (objectClass=group).26. Group Search Scope - level of the server directory to look for groups; either the Base DN and one level belowthe Base DN, or the Base DN and the entire subtree.27. Optional Test Connection is to test with an account. If you have a known, valid test account to use to test theserver setup, you can test from here without having to try to login with that account.28. This information can be edited and configured now or at a later time.8. Required Mail is required and must contain a correctly formatted email address.Note: Account username refers to the username assigned to the email account; it does not refer to the name por-tion of the user's email address. Typically, the username and name portion of an email are the same, but this maynot be the case.dcTrack allows you to configure common settings that control the number of users and/or user groups returned in asearch. Note that in each of these scenarios both the "SyncGroup Members" option found on the Common Settings page and the "Use Groups for Authorization" option foundon the Settings page for each individual server must be enabled. If either of these options is not enabled, group syn-chronization will not occur.Group Synchronization occurs:During periodic sync as determined by the Sync Interval defined in Common SettingsWhen performing a manual sync by clicking the "Sync Now" button in Common SettingsWhen a new user that does not exist in dcTrack but does exist in LDAP/AD logs into dcTrack for the first timeWhen an existing dcTrack user logs in, his groups are not automatically synchronized. Groups for existing users willbe synchronized during the next manual or periodic sync. Manually configure dcTrack to find users and groups on an LDAP server or an Active Directory (AD) server, and useLDAP for centralized authentication.This feature as an alternative to local authentication. As a result the secondrequest failed if the user was flagged with a One Time Password. Click on a user's name to open their User Information page.15. Click Edit on the User Information page.16. All editable fields are activated.17. (Required) Login is required and must contain the username. 3 characters minimum. 40 characters maximum.Note: If authentication is required by your email system, the dcTrack username must be the same as the user'semail account username. If the usernames do not match, emails cannot be successfully sent from dcTrack.Account username refers to the username assigned to the email account; it does not refer to the name portion of theuser's email address. Typically, the username and name portion of an email are the same, but this may not be thecase.For example, if the username assigned to an email account is jqpublic, the dcTrack username must be jqpublic.If authentication is not required by your system, user names do not have to match.18. Click Save.Check the Messages column to view errors for users who could not be added.

Authentication of Local Users is dependent upon your systems Password Requirements.When a user logs into the application, their local user account is checked to ensure the password is correct and if thefailed attempts option is activated, determining if the account has been locked due to too many failed attempts.If the Failed Attempts password requirement is configured, each time a user logs into the application with an invalidpassword, the number of failed attempt is incremented. Once the number of failed attempts reaches the configuredamount, the account is Locked. If the account is locked, the user will not be allowed to log in even if a valid passwordis entered.

Depending on how the password requirement is configured, user accounts can be unlocked in one of two ways.Auto Unlock Duration. - If this option is configured, the user account will be automatically unlocked after theconfigured amount of time based on the time the account was locked.Manually unlocked by an Admin - If the number of failed attempts is configured and the Auto Unlock Durationis set to zero, accounts will never be unlocked automatically. In this case an Admin will have to unlock theaccount. This can be done from the Users List page. When an account is locked, the "Locked At" column willdisplay the date and time the account was locked. To unlock the account, select the User from the list andclick the Unlock Button.Note that authentication is required by your email system, the dcTrack username must be the same as the user'semail account username. This may require you to contact your System Administrator in order to confirm the userauthentication method and username.For details on creating users and user groups, see Manage dcTrack Users and Groups .When you are initially building dcTrack and your first data center, you do not have to create all of your users and usergroups at the same time.

User groups are used to organize users within dcTrack. For example, you can create a group called dcTrack Viewerthat will contain only users with Viewer-level permissions.User groups are created and maintained by System Administrators or Gatekeepers in the Web Client.Typically, user groups are created before users are created. This allows you to add users to a user group when youcreate their user account. However, you can create users before you create user groups, then assign the users toteams at a later time.When you are first building your dcTrack, at a minimum, consider creating essential user groups and users, meaningthose users who will help you build your data center in dcTrack, test it and manage it. This may include defining yourGatekeeper, users with Operator permissions to perform add and edit item tasks, and users with Viewer-level per-mission to verify access data and reports in dcTrack.Note: If you are using LDAP for authentication, you have the option to import users and/or user groups. For moreinformation, see Import LDAP User Groups and Add Users Automatically.Site Admins access User Groups from the Settings tab, in the Authorization and Authentication section. This pagelists all user groups in the system.The User Groups list displays an actions bar with options as outlined in the following table. First select a user thencomplete the desired action.Add Local Group Click to add a new local user. See Add User Groups to dcTrackDelete Select a user group then click to delete the user group.Find LDAP Group Search for an LDAP GROUP.Refresh Click to refresh the user group list.To view the group details page, click the group name.The Groups details page displays an actions bar with options as outlined in the following table. First select a userthen complete the desired action.Back to List Click to return to the User Group ListEdit Click to edit the group name. System Groups cannot be edited.Delete Click to delete the user group.The group details page displays the following information:

NameGroup TypeLDAP DNCreated By: User who created the groupCreated At: Create date and timeSite Administrate can manage the roles for a group.On the group details page, click the Add/Remove dropdown to add or remove roles. Check a role to add it anduncheck a role to remove it.For more information on user management in dcTrack, see Manage dcTrack Users and GroupsTo add/remove a user from a group or to delete a user from dcTrack, see Edit Users - Local and LDAP

You can create as many users as needed.dcTrack supports up to 80 (eighty) concurrent users, meaning up to 80 users can use the application at the sametime.The User Accounts List is accessible from the User Accounts tab in the Authorization and Authentication section ofthe Settings tab. It lists all dcTrack users and is the primary page for user management. As with other grids indcTracj, you can search and filter the list using the filter fields in the header row.The User Account List also displays the account Authentication Type (LDAP or Local) for each user.To view a user's details, click their user name.The User Accounts list displays an actions bar with options as outlined in the following table. First select a user thencomplete the desired action.Add Click to add a new local user. See Add Local dcTrack UsersActivate Select a deactivated user, then click to reactivate the deactivated user.Deactivate Select an activate user, then click to deactivate the active user.Delete Click to delete a userRefresh Click to refresh the user account listFind LDAP UserExport All Per-Click to export permissions for all users in the system to a spreadshee. See Export a List of UsersmissionsPermissionsdcTrack supports both local authentication and remote authentication. Contact your System Administrator to determ-ine if you are creating one or the other account exclusively, or both local and LDAP accounts.Note that only System Administrators can create configure dcTrack for remote authentication and user man-agement, or locate users via LDAP.System Administrators can create, edit, and delete accounts for any dcTrack local user.Viewers and Operators cannot create user accounts.Note: As of dcTrack version 7.0.1 the User Name supplied when logging into dcTrack is no longer Case Sensitive.This applies to both Local and LDAP user accounts.

This section describes the various roles and privileges that you can assign to users or user groups within dcTrack.Privileges allow users to perform specific actions in dcTrack, such as the ability to add an item.Actions are performed on objects, which include locations, items, and circuits.Roles are sets of privileges required to perform specific tasks. Roles in dcTrack include the following primary roles:System Administrator, Gatekeeper, Operator and Viewer. dcTrack also includes the following auxiliary roles: BulkImport, Data Circuit Manager, Power Circuit Manager, Field Management Operator, Field Management Viewer,Library Operator, Library Viewer, Manage IP Address, Rack PDU Manager, Request Bypass, High Availability Ser-vice Role, Operator without DeleteThere are also auxiliary functional roles that can be assigned in conjunction with another assigned role. Assigningpermissions with an additional role allows more granular control over who can perform specific tasks and whichobjects are affected.Roles are assigned globally from Settings > Authorization & Authentication > Users Accounts OR >User Groups.You can assign any role to apply globally (at the enterprise level or appliance level), meaning access to perform spe-cific actions will be granted for every object in dcTrack. Roles are assigned globally from the Settings tab > dcTrackSettings > Authorization and Authentication > Users Accounts OR >User Groups.A list of roles is available from the dropdown in the User Roles section.Some roles also can be assigned locally (at the object level or for specific locations, items, and/or circuits) for moregranular permissions. Permissions can be assigned locally via the Permissions dialog on the appropriate LocationDetails or Item Details pages.Permissions are applied and inherited following a parent-child (top-down) hierarchical structure. All permissionsapplied to the parent node are inherited by default for the children.Note: In a few cases, roles may be assigned globally but the objects (locations, items, and circuits) affected aredefined by locally assigned roles. For example, a user with globally assigned Bulk Import privileges is assigned per-missions as an Operator in a single location. Therefore, that user is limited to Bulk Import within only the single loc-ation for which they are an Operator.

Roles are aggregated collections of individual privileges required to perform specific tasks. Roles in dcTrack includeSystem Administrator, Gatekeeper, Operator, and Viewer.The table below provides the roles, privileges, and assignments available in dcTrack.Full privileges to all system resources and settings,including:System Admin-Yes NoistratorManage Appliance Settings and dcTrack Set-tingsAdd, edit and delete all data for locations,items, and circuitsView, manage and assign IP AddressesManage eventsManage requests and work ordersView and print reportsAssign permissions of items and circuitsover which I have controlManage their own user settingsDelete Archived ItemsNote: The Administrator role is renamed System Admin-istrator in dcTrack 9.2+.Note: The "Manage Item Status" Auxiliary role is auto-matically assigned to the "admin" user, but must beexplicitly assigned to any other users with the SystemAdministrator role".Full privileges to all system resources and settings,excluding Appliance Settings and dcTrack Settings, andincluding:Add, edit and delete all data for locations, items,and circuitsView, manage, and asign IP AddressesManage eventsManage requests and work ordersYes (LocationView and print reportsGatekeeperYesLevel)Assign permissions of items and circuits (basedon local permissions)Manage their own user settingsCertain roles are not automatically assigned to Gate-keepers but can be assigned as Auxiliary Roles. TheseRoles include:Manage Library (Library Operator)Manage Lists (Field Management Operator)Request BypassFull privileges to add, edit, and delete all information for Yes (LocationOperator Yesitems and circuits, including:View IP addressesand Item Levels)Manage eventsSubmit requests and work ordersView and print reportsManage their own user settingsView Locations List and Location Detail pagesLimited privileges and including:Yes (LocationView system resourcesViewerYesand Item Levels)Manage own user settingsView Locations List and Location Detail pagesdcTrack supports auxiliary functional roles, which can be assigned in conjunction with another assigned role. Assign-ing permissions with an additional role allows more granular control over who can perform specific tasks and whichobjects are affected.Functional roles are provided by default to System Administrators, Gatekeepers, and Operators (when applicable).Locally assigned functional roles can be added, edited, or deleted by System Administrators and Gatekeepers(when allowed based on location).The available functional roles, privileges, and assignments are summarized in the table below.Users can export items in bulkCan be assigned globally, how-ever the locations, items and cir-cuits the export can beperformed on are governed byBulk ExportYes Yes Nopre-existing roles that can bedefined locally or globally. Forexample Bulk Export + Operatordefined locally on a location,allows Bulk Export of items andcircuits contained therein butnot in other locations (The BulkExport priviledge is limited tobulk export You can add as many user groups to dcTrack as your organization needs.User groups are added from the dcTrack Settings menu, which is accessed from the Web Client.1. To add a new group, navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Authorization & Authentication and click on theUser Groups menu option2. On the User Groups page, click Add.4. Enter a name for the user group and click Add to create the group.5. From the Group Roles panel on the group Details page, select one or more Roles associated with the Group.Each member of the group will inherit the Group's Roles. To add each Role, select the Role from the drop downlist.6. From the Group Members panel on the Group Information page, select the Users you want to add to the Group.To add each Menber, select the User from the drop down list and click the "Add" button.Note: : The user group name character limit is 255 characters.To remove individual Users from a Group, uncheck the user from the Members list on the Group details page..

Local users are validated based on credentials you configured in dcTrack and provide to users.User accounts are added from the dcTrack Settings tab.Note: Only users with the system administrator role can change user names in the user accounts settings page. Allother users can only view user names and do not have access to change their own user name in their user profile.1. From Settings > dcTrack Settings > Authorization & Authentication, click User Accounts. The User list pageopens displaying a list of all the user accounts created for the system.2. Choose Add > Add. A blank user information page opens.3. Enter the following required fields:Username - must be at least 3 characters, but no more than 255 charactersFirst NameLast NamePasswordConfirm Password4. You can optionally enter the following fields:EmailDescriptionMail ServerSMTP PortNo PasswordRequest Emails - Applicable only for user accounts with the Gatekeeper roleNote: As of dcTrack version 7.0.1 the User Name supplied when logging into dcTrack is no longer Case Sensitive.This applies to both Local and LDAP user accounts.In order for a user with the role of Gatekeeper to automatically receive a notification each time an action request issubmitted for an item or circuit, the " " checkbox must be enabled on their User page in dcTrack on the Settingspage.To enable request email notifications for Gatekeepers:1. In the Settings tab, click Authentication & Authorization2. Click User Accounts.3. Select the Gatekeeper user to open the user's user infornation panel to edit their information or add the user asa Gatekeeper if you have not already done so. See Add a User.4. Click Edit5. Select the "This GateKeeper receives request notifications" checkbox on the "User Information for" panel.5. Click Save.

A user's ability to edit an item is based on whether or not the user's role has Edit privileges.For example: Viewers cannot edit any items. System Administrators can edit all items.In dcTrack 5.2 and later, System Admin and Admin Team have been relabeled to Contact and Contact Teamrespectively. These fields are for informational purposes only and do not affect ownership permissions.Note: The item's workflow status also can limit the ability to edit it. Items with an Approved request cannot be edited;the item's Work Order must be marked Complete to edit the item.For more information, see Assign User Permissions Locally for Locations, Items, and Circuits.

Some roles can be assigned locally (at the object level for specific locations, items, and/or circuits) for more granularpermissions. Permissions can be assigned locally by assigning roles via the Permissions dialog on the appropriateLocation Details or Items Details pages or on the Locations list or Items list. You also can assign Permissions onGrid Report widgets to control the view of data from ODBC views.Locally assigned roles can be added or deleted by System Administrators and Gatekeepers (when allowed basedon location). For example, users with the role of Viewer can only view items; they cannot make changes to items.System Administrators can edit all items.Note: The System Admin and Admin Team labels used in earlier versions of dcTrack have been relabeled toContact and Contact Team respectively. These fields are for informational purposes only and do not affect own-ership privileges. You can continue to use System Admin and Admin Team or Contact and Contact Team in FileImport, but do not use both.For descriptions of roles, see dcTrack User Roles and Privileges.To add permissions for Locations and Items:1. On the Locations or Items lists under Assets, select the location or Item whose permissions you want to edit.You can also set permissions from the Item Detail or Location Detail pages2. Click the Permissions button to open the Permissions dialog.3. The Permissions Dialog opens and displays a grid of users and user groups, roles, and sources of the per-missions. Only adding or deleting permissions is allowed.4. To add permissions, click Add. You can then select the user or user group and appropriate role, then clickAdd Permission.5. To delete permissions, select the appropriate row for the permission and click the Delete button. You canselect multiple rows to delete multiple permissions.6. To cancel and close the dialog box, click Cancel.Note: Permissions cannot be edited. To change a permission, delete the existing permission and then add the newpermission.Permissions for Items, Locations and Circuits can also be managed in bulk via the Items or Locations Lists. To man-age explicit permissions for multiple objects:1. Select the objects from the List2. Click the permissions button from the list tool bar to open the Permissions dialog box3. Click the Add button to open the Add permission fields4. Select the User/Group and Role you want to grant for the selected objects.5. Click the Add Permission button to add the Role to the selected User/GroupTo Delete permissions, select the row(s) of the Users/Groups whose permissions you are deleting and clickthe Delete button. You will be prompted with a warning you are deleting permissions. To cancel the deleteclick the Cancel button, to delete the selected permissions click OK.5. Click the Done button to close the dialog boxYou can assign roles to multiple Users/Groups or multiple roles for a single User/Group by selecting the User-/Group and Role from the drop downs prior to clicking the Done Button.

A user's default location (site) is the location that is automatically selected each time the user logs in to dcTrack. Thesystem default location is defined by the System Administrator.If a default location is not defined for a user, the system location is automatically selected each time the user logs in.Each time a user logs in to dcTrack, the default location is displayed in the:Default Location drop-down: All of the locations the user has access to are listed in this drop-down. Making aselection from the Default Location drop-down has no impact on the application.Location drop-down: All of the locations the user has access to are listed in this drop-down. Users canchange the location they are working by selecting another location from the Location drop-down.To define a system default location:1. Click Assets > Locations2. On the Locations list, select the location you want to make the system default. Click Edit to open the Locationpage in Edit mode.3. In the Settings panel, select the System Default Location checkbox.4. Click Save.Units of measure can be either US or SI (metric) measurements.
