U.S. settings are the default.Measurement settings are applied on a per user basis.The selected measurement units apply to all measurements captured in the dcTrack Web Client such as cabinetheight, item weight, and so on.Users can define their own default units in the User Settings panel:1. To access the User Settings panel, click your username in the upper right corner or click Settings > User Settings.2. On the Preferences tab, use the radio buttons to select your units.3. Click the Save button.

The dcTrack Internationalization feature provides the ability to define a language setting on a per user basis allowingusers to better utilize the dcTrack application in their native language. In addition to English, dcTrack supportsFrench, German, Japanese, Simplified Chinese and Turkish. The language selection applies to all Menu Items,Field Labels, Messages and Prompts for that user.To set your language preference:1. Click your username located in the upper right corner of the main menu.2. Click on the Preferences option3. Select the desired language from the Language selection drop down list4. Click the Save button to save your selectionLanguage preferences will take effect after logging off and back into dcTrack,Dates in dcTrack can be formatted to conform to the ISO Standard Date format as well as severalother localized formats.Date Format settings are applied on a per user basis, so each user can select their preferred formatwithout affecting how dates are displayed for other users.The selected Date Format applies to all dates visible in the Web Client as well as dates exported infiles.The only exceptions are for dates appearing under the dcTrack Settings menu. Most of these datesare formatted using the ISO Standard Date format.Users can define their own Date format.1. To access the User Settings panel, click your username in the upper right corner or click Settings >User Settings.2. On the Preferences tab, use the dropdown to select your preferred Date Separator. Valid optionsare:"-""/""."3. After selecting the Separator, select your preferred format. The current date formatted with the selec-ted Separator is displayed in the list box for each available format. Valid Options are:MMDDYYYYDDMMYYYYYYYYMMDD4. Click the Save button.Note: The admin account's user preferences for Language, Theme, Unit System, Data Separator,Date Format and all Cabinet Elevation preferences are used as the default preferences for all newusers.

You can view and edit all users, including local and LDAP, in the User Accounts page.Edited information is saved only to dcTrack, not to your LDAP server.For information on editing user permissions, see Assigning Roles for User Permissions.1. In the Settings tab, click Authorization & Authentication > User Accounts.2. Click the orange username for the user you want to edit.3. To change a user's password, click Change Password.3. Click Edit to enter edit mode and edit the information as needed.Username: 3 characters minimum. 40 characters maximum.First Name: 1 character minimum.Last Name: 1 character minimum.Email: Must contain a correctly formatted email address.Description: OptionalNote: The Username supplied when logging into dcTrack is not case sensitive. This applies to both Local andLDAP user accounts.To delete a user, simply click Delete1. In the Settings tab, click Authorization & Authentication > User Accounts.2. In the User Accounts list, select the user you want to delete, then click Delete.3. Alternatively, click the orange username link for the user you want to delete. The user's account page dis-plays. Click Delete.

To remove a user from a group:1. In the Settings tab, click Authorization & Authentication > User Accounts.2. In the User Accounts list, click the orange username link for the user you want to remove from a group.3. The user's account page displays. Click Edit.4. In Edit mode, click the Add/Remove Groups dropdown in the User Groups panel on the right side of the page.The dropdown lists all groups in dcTrac. All groups that the user is a member of are checked.5. To remove the user from a group, uncheck the checkbox next to the group nameYou can delete users that no longer need access to dcTrack. Both local and LDAP users can be deleted. When auser is deleted, all data, roles, and public shared reports that may be used by other users, are deleted. Only oneuser can be deleted at a time.To delete users:1. In the Settings tab, click User Accounts.2. Select the checkbox for the user you want to delete.3. Click Delete. A confirmation message appears. Click Delete User to confirm.

dcTrack provides you with the ability to access ODBC views of dcTrack data that are contained in the dcTrack data-base such as requests, work orders, items, ports, circuits, custom fields and so on.This allows you to then create custom reports using ODBC compliant applications such as Crystal Reports® orMicrosoft Access®.See dcTrack ODBC View Tables and Sample Queries in the dcTrack REST API and the Web Client API Guidewhich can also be downloaded from the Sunbird Support website at http://support.sunbirddcim.com.Note: Views that are specific to Power IQ are blank. All dcTrack ODBC views begin with 'dc'. All other views are spe-cific to Power IQ and do not contain any data.To enable ODBC access to dcTrack:1. In the Web Client, click Settings > Appliance Administration > ODBC Access. The ODBC Access page displays.2. Click the Add Network icon then click the 0.0.0.0/0 addresses to type the ODBC network address with the maskin CIDR formatCIDR format example: 192.168.43.0/24 instead of 192.168.43.0 and 255.255.255.0.Use the network mask value to specify a single address or a range of addresses.Repeat to add new addresses as needed.Use the default value 0.0.0.0/0 to allow access from all IP addresses.To remove a network, click the trashcan icon next to it3. In the Configure ODBC Security section, type the User Login and password intended for ODBC authentication.4. In the configure ODBC Security section, provide the following information:User LoginPasswordPassword Confirmation5. In the Timeout field, specify the number of minutes that should elapse before an ODBC query times out.6. Click the Save button when all authorized addresses have been added. The dcTrack database restarts.7. After the restart, ODBC compliant applications are allowed to access the database from the authorized IPaddresses.Note: If you are using a Microsoft Windows® 64-bit operating system, you must install the PostgreSQL 64-bit driverin order to access the database from Microsoft Office® 2007 or later applications.Factory default user credentials for ODBC access in dcTrack are:Username: odbcuserPassword: sunbirdThe ODBC user credentials can be customized as needed. After ODBC user credentials are modified, you must alsochange the user credentials entered in the ODBC Client and driver.To change the ODBC user credentials:1. In the Web Client, click Settings > Appliance Administration > ODBC Access. The ODBC Access page dis-plays2. In the Configure ODBC Security section, type the User Login and password intended for ODBC authen-tication.3. In the Configure ODBC Security section, type the user name and password intended for ODBC authen-tication.Note: ODBC users are not the same as dcTrack users, but rather a database user defined in PostgresNote: For restrictions that apply to the ODBC user credentials, see Restrictions of ODBC User Credentials.4. Click Save.

The ODBC username is NOT subject to the restrictions applied to a dcTrack user name.Certain restrictions apply to the ODBC user name and password.ODBC username:Support 1 to 63 characters longConsist of alphanumeric characters and/or underscores only, including 0 to 9, a to z, and _No number used for the first characterNo uppercase charactersNo support for multi-byte charactersDo not use names such as public, postgres, raritan, sunbird, odbc and floormapsODBC password:The password must follow the requirements selected in Settings > Password Requirements. See Con-figuring Password Requirements.Note: ODBC users are not the same as dcTrack users, but rather a database user defined in PostgresNote: The PC you use to access the dcTrack ODBC views is referred to here as the ODBC client.1. ODBC Client must install and configure a suitable PostgreSQL driver. PostgreSQL drivers are available athttp://www.postgresql.org/ftp/odbc/versions/msi/.2. ODBC Client must configure dcTrack as a ODBC Data Source with the following credentials:a. Database Name: raritanb. User ID: odbcuserc. Password: raritand. Port Number: 5432e. Server: dcTrack IP AddressFor a description of the ODBC views, see ODBC Views in the dcTrack REST API and External Ticketing Web Ser-vices API Online Help or PDF version of the help available on the dcTrack Support page.

ODBC tables use the dcTrack® system time setting, which is EST/EDT. This setting is converted to your selectedtimezone when you are using the dcTrack web interface, but this conversion is not applied to ODBC connections.The time data available via the ODBC connection can be changed on a per session basis. By using a specific SQLstatement to adjust the client session, you can run reports and view information in the desired timezone.This link contains documentation on setting the timezone for the database using an SQL statement. Use the "SETSESSION ...." syntax, because dcTrack ODBC users do not have super user privileges.http://www.postgresql.org/docs/manuals/Create advanced reports and charts with reporting programs such as SQL report writer, Crystal Reports®, andMicrosoft Access®. Follow these instructions to use Microsoft Access.ODBC Access must be enabled. See Configuring ODBC Access to dcTrack.You must install a PostgreSQL driver first. See Install and Configure a PostgreSQL Driver.

When you upgrade to dcTrack 3.0.0 (and later), port information is added to the models in the Item Models Library.If you made changes to port information for models in the Item Models Library prior to upgrading to dcTrack 3.0.0,ports on those models may be duplicated.For example, if you added a port to a server model in the dcTrack 2.6.1 Item Models Library, after you upgrade to3.0.0, there may be two of the same port on the model.To fix this, use the Item Models Library Port Clean Up feature to purge any added or modified 2.x data ports andpower ports from models in the Item Models Library.Purging ports does not impact data center items you have added to dcTrack; only additional or modified ports onmodels in the Item Models Library are impacted.To purge 2.x ports from models in the Item Models Library:1. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration, then click on the Application tab.2. In the Models Library Ports Clean Up section of the page, select the Delete only from Models with 3.x Portsoption to limit the purge to just those models that have been updated to include version 3 and up ports.3. click Delete Data Ports or Delete Power Ports to delete the 2.x ports from models in the Model's library.

A Sunbird appliance ships with a console user account that has a preconfigured password. By default,this account is disabled such that no one can log in, even if they know the password. When the userprovides access, this account is used by Sunbird’s support team to troubleshoot issues.The ‘config’ user is the only user that can unlock this account. This password for the ‘config’ user is con-figurable through the console.The ‘config’ user can also reset the password for the administrative account on A Sunbird appliance’sweb application.CAUTION: Do not lose the password for the ‘config’ user. If the console account is locked and you losethis password, there is nothing Sunbird can do to help you recover from an error other than performinga clean install and restoring from a backup.

Through IP Access Control (settable in the console or via the Settings tab on the web interface), youcan disable SSH access, ODBC access, and whether the appliance will respond ICMP pings. Altern-ately, you can limit access to certain IP address rangesBy default, the username for the administrative user account is ‘admin’. This username can also bechanged.

If you enable ODBC access to the appliance, be sure to change the password for the odbcuseraccount. Also consider limiting access to known good IP addresses. By default, ODBC access is dis-abled.All SSH and UI access attempts are logged to the audit log. Monitoring this can help you identify unau-thorized access attempts

A Sunbird appliance can be configured to send audit log messages to an external system log server.Sending these to an external system helps to maintain an audit log and allows for searching\alertingon certain events.A Sunbird appliance ships with a default unsigned certificate. Installing a certificate that’s signed by atrusted certificate authority will allow clients to establish trust in the server.
A Sunbird appliance allows you to create encrypted backup and provides a feature to automaticallypush the daily backups to a separate system. Refer to the user’s guide on how to set these featuresup.

Sunbird provides regular maintenance and feature releases that include security updates. We fre-quently update the OS, database, and other components to keep the appliance secure.Note: Sunbird performs penetration testing at the application and network level on every release.

dcTrack allows you to define specific password security requirements, including an Account Lockoutfeature.For information on Password security settings see Setting dcTrack Password RequirementsSunbird takes security seriously. Please report any security issues to our support team such that wecan address them.

In order to improve the security of the solution, the appliance will provide a Content-Security-Policy (CSP) responseheader to all web requests.The content and complexity of the response headers will vary based on several factors:1. There will always be a CSP directive to control the allowed frame-ancestors to prevent click-jacking. See:https://owasp.org/www-community/attacks/Clickjacking. The default secure value is:"frame-ancestors 'self'".If the web server settings are changed in the console (See: Web Server Settings In the Console) then addi-tional servers/domains can be included in this response.2. If HTML widgets are allowed, no other CSP directives are included in the response (See: Configure DisplaySettings).3. The CSP directive for connect-src depends on the settings provided for the geocoding server and the tileserver used for the World Map feature. For example, if the values are the default values of https://-nominatim.openstreetmap.org and https://tile.sunbirddcim.com respectively,then the CSP directive will be:connect-src 'self' nominatim.openstreetmap.org tile.sunbirddcim.comThis value for the geocoding server may be left blank for higher security but then the "Resolve Address" fea-ture of the world map will not function and the users must manually enter the longitude and latitude of theirdata centers.4. The CSP directive for img-src depends on the settings provided for the tile server for the World Map feature.For example, if the value is the default value of https://tile.sunbirddcim.com then the CSP directive will be:img-src 'self' tile.sunbirddcim.com data:This value for the tile server may be left blank for higher security but then the entire world map feature will notfunction.At this time, the CSP header requires a full appliance restart in order to reflect any changed selections foritems 2, 3, and 4 above. In a future release, it will be possible to have the changes to CSP show up without afull restart.

Use SNMP to retrieve dcTrack system health information, such as application up time, IP routing, system contactsand so on.1. In the Web Client, navigate to Settings >dcTrack Settings > Appliance Administration > SNMP Settings. TheSNMP Settings panel displays.2. In the MIB-II section, in tthe Read Community String field, enter the community string used to access theSNMP network. Required.3. Enter the system contact, system name and system location if needed.4. Click the Save button. A confirmation message is displayed.You can now use any third-party SNMP manager, such as an SNMP MIB Browser, to access the system health viaMIB-II.The following table summarizes performance indicators from the MIB-II and Host Resources MIB that are exposedby the SNMP agent:System Information (e.g., sysUpTime, Number of users, Number of system processes) hrSystemhrDevice: hrDeviceT-Device Information (e.g., Device types, Processors, NICs)ablehrDevice: hrPro-CPU Utilization/Processor LoadcessorTablehrDevice: hrNet-Network and Partition Table InformationworkTable, hrPar-titionTableMemory and Disk Usage hrStoragehrSWRun, hwSWRun-Running processesPerfInstalled software hrSWInstalledTable

User log-in and log-out activity is captured in the audit log. See Access Audit LogsAudit trails capturing item creation, deletion and update activity are accessed from the Audit Trail sub tab on eachItem's Item Detail pageUser logins, failed logins, remote storage logs and so on are captured in the audit log.dcTrack audit logs can be viewed in a browser, or exported to a file for viewing or storage.Note: Audit logs are automatically deleted from the system after three calendar months. If you need to maintain acomplete audit trail, export logs regularly and store the files outside dcTrack.To access audit logs:1. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Appliance Administration > Audit Log2. The audit log displays.To download audit logs to a CSV file:1. Click Export.2. Save the audit log to the location of your choice. All audit log entries are exported to a CSV file. For informationon specifying a save location, see How to Specify a Default Save Location for Downloaded Files.

Any changes to an item's information are tracked in the Audit Trail log. This includes Inserts, Updates and Deletes.Each Item's Audit Trail log is accessible from the Item's Audit Trail sub tab on the Item Detail page and can be expor-ted in either CSV or PDF format.The Audit Trail grid contains the following columns:Asset Audit ID - System generated unique identifier for the Audit recordAction - Insert, Update, DeleteField - The name of the field that was changedChanged From - The value in the field before the update (for Inserts this value will always be blank)Changed To - The value in the field after the updateChanged By - The full name of the user that performed the updateNote: In the item audit trail, changes made in dcTrack as part of an internal system process are indicated inthe Changed By column as changed by the "System Process" user.Changed Date - The date and Time the update was performedYou can sort and filter the audit trail grid as needed.To view the Audit Trail log for Items across the database, use the Item Audit Trail sql grid widget accessible from theData Reports dashboard. This widget lists Audit Trail records for the entire database, but can be sorted and filteredto report only the records you are interested in viewing.You can also design your own custom sql grid widgets to create frequently used views of the Audit data. For addi-tional information about creating Sql Grid Widgets see Custom Sql Grid Widgets.

dcTrack has a "sunbird" user account in place for Sunbird use when supporting the product. You may be asked toaccess the console as the "config" user to enable this account during the support process. You cannot change thepassword for this account. When disabled, there is no external access to the system using this account.New installations of dcTrack have this account disabled by default. Upgrading will not change the enable/disablestatus of this account.Note: As of dcTrack version 9.0.0, the Locations feature has been moved to Assets > LocationsSystem Administrators and Gatekeepers are able to add, edit, and delete Locations. Users with the Operator orViewer roles will not be able to view or manage Locations. For more information, see Adding, Editing, and DeletingLocations.The Locations page is accessible by clicking Assets > Locations in the dcTrack header. For a summary of the Loca-tions page and supported actions, see Viewing Locations.For better data analysis and readability on the Locations List page, you can select columns to show or hide. You alsocan pin columns to the right or left of the grid. For more information, see Showing/Hiding and Pinning Columns onthe Locations List .

The Locations List or grid page is accessible by clicking Assets > Locations in the dcTrack Header.The Locations page appears.The Locations List page is organized in a grid layout, with one row dedicated to each location and location attributesin the column.The following attributes are listed in the columns and can be edited from the Locations List for each Location:Full Code Path: The full path of the Location based on your data center hierarchy. For example, this is a con-catenation of the data center code, the floor code and the room code. The full code path will be included inlocation selection pick lists throughout the application.Name: The user-specified name of the Location.Level in Hierarchy: The level of the Location based on your data center hierarchy (Data Center, Floor, orRoom).Parent: The parent node of the Location based on your data center hierarchy.Type : The type of Location.Owner : The contact details of the user who owns this Location.Can Contain Assets: Designates a location that can contain assets. This is limited to leaf nodes in the loc-ation hierarchy. Locations with child locations will not be designated as Can Contain Assets.Area: The area of the Location. This is required for locations that will contain assets.Country: The country of the Location.Power IQ Association: The Power IQ instance associated with the Location.VM Manager : The VM Manager associated with the location.Enable AC Virtual Power Chain: Indicates if the Virtual Power Chain for the Location is enabled or disabledfor AC PowerEnable DC Virtual Power Chain: Indicates if the Virtual Power Chain for the Location is enabled or disabledfor DC PowerSystem Default Location: Designates the default location for dcTrackNotes : Additional Notes about the Location.To view the details page for a specific Location, double-click on the Location in the grid or select the Location andclick the View button and icon. The Location details page will open in View mode in a new tab. To return to the Loca-tions List page, click the Locations icon and button ( ) in the upper-left corner.You also can add, edit, or delete Locations. For more information, see Adding, Editing, and Deleting Locations.To see the most up-to-date information, refresh the Locations List page by clicking the Refresh icon and button.Locations can be exported to CSV by clicking the Export Locations List button and icon ( ) in the bottom rightcorner. The CSV File will automatically be downloaded.You can save your custom Locations List view or revert to the default view by clicking the List Settings icon and but-ton ( ) in the bottom right corner and selecting the desired option.For better data analysis and readability on the Locations List page, you can select columns to show or hide. You alsocan pin columns to the right or left of the grid.To show or hide columns on the Locations List page, click the Show/Hide Columns icon and button ( ) on the farright of the grid.Select or deselect the columns that you want to show or hide.To pin a column, click the downward arrow in the header for the column and select the Pin Left or Pin Right optionfrom the dropdown.To unpin a column, click the downward arrow in the header for the column and select the Unpin option from the drop-down.

System Administrators and Gatekeepers can add, edit, or delete Locations from the Locations List page.1. Navigate to Assets > Locations2. Click Add Location button to open a New Location page in edit mode.3. Fields with an asterisk (*) are required.4. The Location Details page includes the following panels: Identity, Settings, Address and Dimensions.5. Edit the Identity attributes.a. Location Code: Required. A user-defined label used to identify the Location in the code path. For adata center, the Location Code must be unique within dcTrack. For a floor or room, the LocationCode must be unique within its parent. Maximum of 255 characters.b. Location Name: Required. A user-defined name that can be longer and more descriptive than theLocation Code. The Location Name must be unique within dcTrack.c. Level in Hierarchy: Required. You can select the Location from the following options: Data Center,Floor, or Room. The default Level in Hierarchy is Data Center.d. Location Parent: You can select the parent of the Location from a list of codes for available parents.This is disabled when the Level in Hierarchy is designated Data Center. Floors can have DataCenters are parents. Rooms can have Floors or Data Centers as parents.e. Location Type: You can designate the Location from the following options: Main, Regional, Local orDisaster Recovery.f. Can Contain Assets: You can select or deselect the checkbox to designate the Location as one thatcan or cannot contain assets. Locations with child locations cannot contain assets. Enabled bydefault.6. Edit the Settings attributesa. Power Capacity (kw): Optional. Maximum Power Capacity for the Location.b. Power IQ Host Association: Optional. If the Location is integrated with Power IQ, select the asso-ciated Power IQ instance from the drop down list of integrated Power IQs. This will enable this loc-ation to be synchronized with the selected Power IQ.c. VM Manager: - Optional. If the Location is associated with one or more VM Managers, select theVM Managers from the drop down list of integrated VM Managers. This will enable dcTrack to besynchronized with the virtualization environment.d. Enable AC Virtual Power Chain: Optional. The Virtual Power Chain (VPC) is an automatically cre-ated power chain available for each Location you create. The 'Enable AC Virtual Power Chain'checkbox allows enabling the use of AC VPC in this Location. The VPC includes A and B redundantpower chains, each consisting of a UPS, UPS Bank, Floor PDU, Power Panels and Power Outlets.The VPC has infinite capacity and supports all possible voltages. The VPC is intended to allow youto create a power circuit without having to first create the actual components of the power chain inyour location. A real power chain and VPC may co-exist in a location and power circuits can bemoved from one to the other.e. Enable DC Virtual Power Chain: Optional. The Virtual Power Chain (VPC) is an automatically cre-ated power chain available for each Location you create. The 'Enable DC Virtual Power Chain'checkbox allows enabling the use of DC VPC in this Location. The VPC includes A and B redundantpower chains, each consisting of a UPS, UPS Bank, Floor PDU, Power Panels and Power Outlets.The VPC has infinite capacity and supports all possible voltages. The VPC is intended to allow youto create a power circuit without having to first create the actual components of the power chain inyour location. A real power chain and VPC may co-exist in a location and power circuits can bemoved from one to the other.f. System Default Location: This field allows you to set a default Location that will be automaticallyselected in Location Lists when the user does not have a default Location specified in their UserPreferences.7. Edit the Address attributes. Note: This panel is displayed only if the Level in Hierarchy is designated as DataCenter. Floors and Rooms inherit these attributes from their parent data centers.a. Country: Required. You can select the country of your data center from a dropdown. The defaultcountry is the United States.b. Streetc. Street (Line 2)d. State or Province: If the Country selected is the United States, you can select the State from a drop-down.e. Postal Code5. Edit the Dimensions attributes. Must be entered as numeric values.Note: The units of measurements for each attribute is determined by your Settings. To change the units yourmeasurements are displayed in, click your username in the upper-right corner to access User Settings >Preferences and select your preferred Units displayed in option.a. Location Areab. Outer Dimension Lengthc. Outer Dimension Widthd. Raised Floor Heighte. Finished Floor to Ceiling Heightf. Finished Ceiling to Slab Ceiling (Plenum) Height6. Click the Save icon and button to save your changes.To navigate to the floor map for a Location click the Floor Map button in the tool barTo navigate to the world map focused on the location, click the World Map button in the tool bar

1. On the Locations List page, select the Location that you want to edit.2. Click the Edit icon and button. The Location Details page will open in Edit mode.3. Make your desired edits. The Save icon and button will be enabled.4. Click the Save icon and button to save your changes.5. Click the Locations List icon to return to the Locations List page. The page will display your changes.To delete a Location on the Locations List page, select the Location that you want to delete and click the Delete iconand button. You will be asked to confirm the deletion.When deleting Locations from the Locations List page, you may only delete a single Location at a time. If multipleLocations are selected the Delete button will be disabled even if all Locations qualify for deletion.You can also delete a Location from the Location Details page by clicking the Delete icon and button on that page.Note: You can only delete a Location if it does not contain items or if all of its items are in the Planned state.

For easier data analysis, you can search and filter Locations from the Locations List page.1. Click in the search bar on the Locations List page to display a dropdown of available search attributes.2. Select the attribute you want to search or filter by.3. Enter or select the desired criteria.The Location Lists page will refresh automatically based on your selections; you do not have to click the Refreshicon and button.You can search and filter by multiple criteria.Any of the Location attributes on the Locations List page can be used for sorting and filtering:Code: Enter all or part of the location code to search for the location(s) matching the search text.Name: Enter all or part of the location name to search for the location(s) matching the search text.Level: Select Data Center, Floor, or Room from a list to search for the location(s) matching the search cri-teria.Parent: Enter all or part of the parent location code to search for the location(s) matching the search text.Can Contain Assets: Select YES or No to search for the location(s) matching the search criteria.Location Area: Provide a value =, <, > for area to search for the location(s) matching the search criteria.Country: Enter all or part of the country name to search for the location(s) matching the search criteria.Power IQ Association: Select a Power IQ association from a list to search for the location(s) matching thesearch criteria.Virtual Power Chain: Select YES or No to search for the location(s) matching the search criteria.System Default Location: Select YES or No to search for the location(s) matching the search criteria.Sort by ascending or descending values in a column by clicking the column header or by clicking the downwardarrow in the column header and selecting the desired option from the dropdown.On the Locations List page and the Location Details pages for individual Locations, System Administrators or Gate-keepers (with appropriate access) will see the Permission icon and button ( ) in the menu.Clicking this button opens the Permission dialog, where permissions can be added to users and user groups for theselected location.For more information, see Assign User Permissions Locally for Locations, Items, and Circuits.1. Select the Locations that you want to assign permissions for.2. On the Location List page or on the Location Detail page in Edit mode, click the Permission button.3. The Permissions Dialog opens and displays a grid of users and user groups, roles, and sources of the per-missions. Only adding or deleting permissions is allowed.4. To add permissions, click the Add button. You can then select the user or user group and appropriate role,then click the Add button.5. To delete permissions, select the appropriate row for the permission and click the Delete button. You canselect multiple rows to delete multiple permissions.6. To cancel and close the dialog box, click the Cancel button.Note: Permissions cannot be edited. To change a permission, delete the existing permission and then add the newpermission.

dcTrack 8.1.0 allows the users to manage favorite locations. Users can select one or more location and mark it theirfavorite. Only the leaf node locations that contain assets can be marked as favorite location.Steps to manage favorite locations :1. In the Web Client click user name at top right and select the option Manage Favorite Location2. In the Manage Favorite Location Dialog, you will see the list of locations that you have permission.3. Check the locations in the Favorite column that you want to make your favorite locationsNote: The users who have System Administrator role will have an option to select the user and mark favorite loc-ations for other users. The users who do not have System Administrator role can only select favorite location forthemselves and not for other users.3. To mark favorite locations in bulk, click the arrow in the Favorite column and select the option Check All.4. Click Close.All the columns support filtering and sorting. The list also have Show/Hide feature(click three dot), so that you canselect only the columns that you want to see in this list.The locations that are checked in the Favorite column for the selected user become the favorite locations for thatuser.dcTrack users can manage the Location drop downs across dcTrack application. Location Filtering option allowseach user to select the locations they would see in the Location field drop down.Steps for Location Filtering :1. Click user name at the top right and select the option Location Filtering.2. In the Location Filtering Dialog, you can select the locations that you want to see in the Location drop down. Fol-lowing options are available for selection.My Favorite Locations - Selecting this option will include all the locations that you have marked favorite.All Permitted Locations - Selecting this option will include all the location that you have permission.These Selected Locations - This option lets you select the locations from the drop down. You can select oneor more locations. All the locations that you have permission will show in the drop down.Locations in these States - With this option allows you can select the locations based on the State. The dropdown will include the states for all the locations that you have permission.Locations in these Countries - With this option you can select the locations based on the Country. The dropdown will include all the countries for all the locations that you have permission.Locations of these Types - With this option you can select the locations based on location type. The dropdown will include the location types.3. After you select the option for Location Filtering, you can select your default location. The drop down options forthis field will depend on the selection made above for Location Filtering. For example, if you select locations for StateNJ, default location drop down will only show the locations in state NJ.4. Click Save.The selection made here will immediately affect Location drop down across dcTrack .For example, if you are inAsset List screen and click Location column drop down, the list of locations you will see in the drop down will be thesame set of locations you selected in Location Filtering dialogue.Location Filtering dialogue can be launched from anywhere in dcTrack where you see the Location Field except fol-lowing screensAssets -> Locations screenData Model SyncVMware Inventory SyncNote: When you are in dcTrack Settings screen, Location Filtering option will not show when you click the username.

dcTrack 6.0.0 introduces the ability for users with the appropriate permissions to add, edit, and delete the powercapacity value for locations, cabinets, and sub-locations to help them better track and plan capacity.For locations, users with Edit permissions on the location can manage the power capacity value in the Settings tabof the Location Details page.For cabinets, users with Edit permissions on the cabinet can manage the power capacity value in the Configurationtab on the Item Details page.For aisles and rows, users with Edit permissions on the item can manage the power capacity value in the respectiveAdd or Edit dialogs for aisles and rows, accessible through the Placement (Cabinet) panel on the Item Details page.Note: Power Capacity is synchronized on objects integrated with Power IQ.

dcTrack 5.3.0 introduces REST API Version 2 support for Webhooks. A REST API client in dcTrack will push noti-fications to the service specified to receive the notifications. The notifications provide summaries of the changes thathave resulted in an auditable event in dcTrack. These include changes to item details, port details, item status, andport connection status.The REST API client is configured from Settings > dcTrack Settings > Integrations > Webhooks as shown inthescreenshot below.The table below summarizes available settings. All values are required except “aggregationTime” and “aggreg-ationCount.”If not defined, these parameters will be set to the default values. You only need to provide values for the parametersyou want to update.Used to enable notifications to the specified service.Enable Notification“Enabled” refers to whether the notification is enabled and has a value of true or false.External URL The URL of the service where notifications will be sent. Requires the use of https.“urlString” has a maximum length of 255 characters.The time period to aggregate auditable event notifications before sending out a notification.Aggregation Time“aggregationTime” is an integer measured in seconds, ranging from 15 to 86400 seconds, with adefault of 15 seconds.The number of auditable events to aggregate before sending out a notification. The lesser oftime period or count will be used to determine if a notification is to be sent.Aggregation Count“aggregationCount” is an integer in seconds, ranging from 100 to 1000 seconds, with a defaultof 200 seconds.The username to be used by the REST API client for notifications.Username“userName” has a maximum length of 255 characters.The passphrase to be used by the REST API client for notifications.Passphrase“passPhrase” has a maximum length of 40 characters.Once all of the required fields have been supplied, use the Test Connection button to verify your configuration.You can use also the following APIs to retrieve or modify the Webhooks configuration or to delete the Webhook.Retrieve the Noti-fication ConfigurationRetrieve the current Webhook configuration information.Update the Webhook configuration information. You can update the Webhook configurationModify the Noti-with payload when the service is turned down. You only need to provide values for the para-fication Configurationmeters you want to update. Returns updated Webhook configuration information.You can use also the following new APIs to retrieve or modify the Webhook configuration or todelete the configuration.Clear the Notification Deletes the Webhook configuration.Note: To view a Webhook JSON payload example, see Webhook JSON Example in the dcTrack API Guide.High Availability is a dcTrack feature that enables virtually 100% uptime by detecting lost connectivity situations andautomatically or manually switching to a secondary system to avoid loss of service. The High Availability feature canhelp you minimize downtime due to outages, support redundancy as part of disaster recovery configurations,provide scalability, and eliminate single points of failure for large and geographically dispersed deployments.When a node is inactive (e.g. in the standby, isolated or incomplete state), users will not be able to log into the fulldcTrack application. Instead, they will be presented with the High Availability Standby Application (HASA) that canonly be used to review the cluster status and to restore an inactive node to service such that the full dcTrack applic-ation will be accessible. Only users with a local (non-LDAP/SAML) account that has System Administrator privilegescan log into this application.Note: A local (non-LDAP) System Administrator account is required to login to the system when it’s in the standbyor inactive states.The High Availability feature can be configured through the High Availability settings page in dcTrack in the Settingstab > Appliance Settings > High Availability.dcTrack supports a number of services that facilitate integration with Power IQ and third-party systems. As part ofthe High Availability feature, these services can be disabled or enabled (restored) as a group to avoid complicationsof having two active dcTrack systems due to either automatic or manual failover.

A High Availability cluster consists of one primary node and one secondary node, each with a dcTrack system thathas been configured to support automatic or manual failover. When configured, data from the primary node will act-ively be replicated to the secondary node to provide a hot standby system in the event of an issue with the primarynode.When a node is inactive (e.g. in the standby, isolated or incomplete state), users will not be able to log into the fulldcTrack application. Instead, they will be presented with a High Availability Standby Application (HASA) than canonly be used to review the cluster status and to restore an inactive to service such that the full dcTrack applicationwill be accessible. Only users with a local (non-LDAP) account that has System Administrator privileges can log intothis application.The High Availability feature on dcTrack supports two types of failover:Pessimistic automatic failover: When automatic failover is enabled, if the primary dcTrack detects lost con-nectivity, it automatically will assume that the secondary dcTrack is active and will go offline. The primary willmaintain its data and can be re-enabled by users with the System Administrator role. When the secondarydcTrack detects lost connectivity, it will automatically assume that the primary dcTrack has failed and willbecome active.Manual failover. A user can manually initiate a failover from the primary dcTrack to force a failover to the sec-ondary dcTrack. They can either disable integration services or leave them active as part of this action. Notethat a manual failover can only be initialed when the cluster is operational.1. High Availability requires two dcTrack installations.2. Ensure that your environment meets the prerequisites. For more information, see High Availability Pre-requisites.3. When you initially set up a High Availability cluster, data on the designated secondary node is deleted andthe data from the designated primary is replicated to the secondary.4. When setting the Heartbeat Interval and Heartbeat retries values, be sure to take the following into account:You don’t want too low of a value that could cause nuisance failovers or for the cluster to transitionto a not operational state during restarts or short-term network issues.You don’t want to high of a value such that you lose operation of the system for too long of a periodof time in the event of an issue on the primary.Note that if the primary is down:For Auto Failover: The failover won’t occur until after the internal/retry periodexpires.For Manual Failover: You can’t make the secondary operational until the intervaland retry period elapses and the secondary declares lost connectivity and movesto the cluster to the Not Operational state.See Lost Connectivity (Heartbeat Intervals and Retries) for more information onthese values.5. Once a failover occurs, you will need to rebuild the cluster. You can rebuild it from either node but be sure tochoose the one that has the data you wish to preserve.6. It is recommended to configure an email notification in the event that a node declares lost connectivity. Formore information, see Lost Connectivity Email Notifications.7. When managing the nodes, you want to avoid a scenario where both nodes become active. Issues thatcould arise from this are:This could create integration issues between dcTrack and other systems. The High Availability fea-ture does provide a capability to disable the integration services on dcTrack.Users could make changes on the wrong system.8. Inactive nodes will not redirect to the active node. Consider using the appropriate networking equipment toensure that users are directed to the correct node.9. Ensure that you have at least one local (non-LDAP) user account with System Administrator privileges con-figured on the Primary node. A local System Administrator account is required to manage an inactivenode. User accounts on primary are replicated to the secondary and can be used when the secondary is instandby mode.10. Leverage dcTrack’s Remote Backup feature to ensure you have an extra recovery mechanism.11. Be sure to read the High Availability help section in its entirety.

The following are required for correct High Availability cluster operation:The primary and secondary nodes must have the same number of CPUs.Minimum of 1 GigE network path between High Availability cluster nodesFirewalls cannot terminate idle or active SSH connections between HA cluster nodesTwo dcTrack installations are required (one for the primary and one for the secondary).Both dcTrack installations must have the same memory configuration.Cluster nodes must be at the same dcTrack software versionAt least one user who has a local non-LDAP account with System Administrator access or above to both theprimary and secondary dcTrack nodesSSH tunnel must be allowed between High Availability cluster nodesIn addition to the standard ports required to run dcTrack, the High Availability feature requires port 22 beopen for SSH. For additional details on dcTrack's VM Requirements see Virtual Machine Requirements andRecommendations.On the all-in-one system or split node system that will become the Secondary, ensure you know the login fora Local account that has System Administrator privileges on the node. An example would be the ‘admin’account. This account is needed to login to the ‘new' application node once the split setup is completed.Make a back-up from the live all-in-one box (Note: When converting a server from an all-in-one server to adatabase server or an application server, remember to make the back-up first to avoid losing data during theconversion process).Only users with the System Administrator role can enable High Availability on dcTrack and configure each dcTrackas either the primary or secondary node.Manual failover can only be initiated by a user with the System Administrator role.All other users can access both the primary and secondary dcTracks based on their existing permissions.

The High Availability feature can be configured through the High Availability settings page in dcTrack in the Settingstab > Appliance Settings > High Availability.The High Availability Configuration page provides the ability to:Enable or disable High AvailabilityDesignate the role of the dcTrack as either primary or secondaryDefine the IP Address or hostname for the secondary node (primary dcTrack only)Define the service account username and password to be used for authentication when establishing com-munications with the secondary dcTrack (primary only). This account must have System Administrator priv-ileges on the secondary node.Set the heartbeat interval and retries used to determine availability of the other dcTrack (set on primary butsynced to secondary). These values are used to detect lost connectivity.Test the connectivity to and service accessibility of secondary node (primary only). This confirms that thesecondary node is reachable, the service account is correct, that the node is configured as a secondary, andthat both nodes are at the same software version.Enable automatic failover of the cluster when failover conditions are met (set on primary but synced to sec-ondary)Force a manual failover from either the primary or secondary dcTrackEnable or disable integration services as a groupSetup and email notification for when a node declares lost connectivityA High Availability cluster consists of one primary node and one secondary node, each with a dcTrack system thathas been configured to support automatic or manual failover.Users with the System Administrator role can create and enable a High Availability cluster through the dcTrack GUIby configuring the secondary and primary dcTracks and then beginning the process to initialize the creation of thecluster.The high-level steps to setup a High Availability Cluster in dcTrack are:1. On the secondary node, Enable High Availability and configure it as a secondary dcTrack node.2. On the primary node, Enable High Availability and configure it as primary dcTrack node. In this step, youwill provide the address of the secondary node as well as the credentials to an account with SystemAdministrator privileges on that node.In the dcTrack GUI, the Enable High Availability checkbox under the Settings tab > Appliance Settings > High Avail-ability must be checked to use the High Availability feature. Checking the Enable High Availability checkbox in thesecondary dcTrack will enable the High Availability feature and unlock the ability to configure the secondary dcTrackas the secondary. Checking the Enable High Availability checkbox in the primary dcTrack will enable the High Avail-ability feature, unlock the ability to configure the primary dcTrack, email notifications, and integration settings, andbegin the initialization process for creating the cluster.Before starting the initialization process, the primary dcTrack will confirm the following prerequisites:The secondary dcTrack is accessible to the primary dcTrackThe credentials to the secondary are validThe secondary dcTrack has been configured as secondaryThe secondary dcTrack is in the Pending Initialization stateThe secondary dcTrack is the same version as the primary dcTrackIf any of these checks fail, an error message will be displayed. If this occurs, you can correct the issue and re-attempt the setup.

To leverage the High Availability feature, you must have secondary and primary dcTracks configured. The sec-ondary dcTrack must be configured first and will be pending initialization until the primary dcTrack is configured andenabled. Enabling High Availability on the primary dcTrack will begin the initialization process to create and enablethe High Availability cluster.When pending initialization, the secondary dcTrack will operate as a normal dcTrack, until a primary dcTrack ini-tiates the synchronization process with it.To configure a dcTrack system as the secondary node:1. In the GUI of the secondary dcTrack, in the Settings tab > Appliance Settings > High Availability, ensure thatthe Enable High Availability checkbox is checked to ensure that High Availability is enabled. Once HighAvailability is enabled, the bottom of the panel will be unlocked.2. Under High Availability Configuration > Node Type, select the Secondary radio button.3. Click the Save button.Successfully saving a secondary dcTrack’s High Availability configuration will be logged in the audit log, and a mes-sage indicating the successful configuration change will be displayed on the High Availability settings page.Note: At this point, both the Cluster Status and Node Status will display as Pending Initialization because theprimary dcTrack has not yet initialized synchronization with the secondary dcTrack.Note: In the secondary dcTrack, the Force Failover option, Disable Integration Services option, Test Configurationoption, and other configuration options will not be available. These are only configured on the the primary node.The High Availability cluster is created and enabled when the High Availability feature is enabled on the primarydcTrack. A user with the System Administrator role is able to configure High Availability on the primary dcTrack andto initiate the synchronization process with a secondary dcTrack.To configure a dcTrack system as the primary node:1. 1. In the Primary dcTrack’s Settings tab > Appliance Settings > High Availability, ensure that the EnableHigh Availability checkbox is checked to ensure that High Availability is enabled.a. Note: Checking the “Enable High Availability” checkbox in the Primary dcTrack will unlock the abilityto configure the Primary dcTrack, email notifications, and integration settings, and begin the ini-tialization process for creating the cluster.2. Under High Availability Configuration > Node Type field, select the Primary radio button.3. Under Configuration, in the IP Address/Hostname field, enter the IP address or hostname of the SecondarydcTrack.4. Note: Valid IPv4 and IPv6 address are accepted.5. In the Username field, enter the username that the Primary dcTrack should use when initially com-municating with the Secondary dcTrack.6. In the Password field, enter the password that the Primary dcTrack should use when initially communicatingwith the Secondary dcTrack.7. Note: The username and password must be for a user with local, not LDAP, permissions for the SystemAdministrator role. The username and password will not be displayed after you reload the page.8. In the Heartbeat Interval (Sec) field, enter the desired heartbeat interval in seconds. A range from 10-600seconds is supported. The default interval is 60 seconds. See Lost Connectivity (Heartbeat Intervals andRetries) for more information.9. In the Heartbeat Retries field, enter the desired number of heartbeat retry attempts. A range from 1-10 issupported. The default number is 3. See Lost Connectivity (Heartbeat Intervals and Retries) for more inform-ation.10. Check the Enable Automatic Failover checkbox if desired to enable automatic failover. By default, automaticfailover is disabled. Optional.11. Check the Disable Integration Services on Failover box to disable integration services on the Secondarynode after an automatic failover occurs. By default, this option is enabled. Optional.12. Click the Test Configuration button to confirm that all prerequisites have been met. If the prerequisites aremet, this will enable the Save button such that you can setup the cluster13. Click the Save button to save the configuration. This will initiate the process to create the cluster.14. Before starting the initialization process, the Primary dcTrack will confirm the following prerequisites. If anyof these checks fail, an error message will be displayed. If this occurs, you can correct the issue and re-attempt the setupa. The Secondary dcTrack is accessible to the Primary dcTrackb. The credentials to the Secondary are validc. The Secondary dcTrack has been configured as Secondaryd. The Secondary dcTrack is in the Pending Initialization statee. The Secondary dcTrack is the same version as the Primary dcTrackSuccessfully saving a primary dcTrack’s High Availability configuration will be logged in the audit log, and a mes-sage indicating the successful configuration change will be displayed on the High Availability settings page.

The right panel of the High Availability settings page displays the current status for the following:Node Status: Displays the status of the current dcTrack nodeCluster Status: Displays the status of the current clusterIntegration Service Status: Displays whether integration services have been enabled or disabled specificallyfor High Availability through the High Availability UI. This status displays Enabled by default and after ser-vices have been restored.IP of Paired System: Displays the IP address of the secondary node. Note that this setting is only valid whenthe High Availability feature is enabled. Otherwise, the default value is N/A.Note: To update the information displayed, click on High Availability in the left-hand navigation menu.For more information on statuses, see Cluster and Node States .Testing connectivity confirms access from the primary to the secondary dcTrack and ensures that High Availabilityprerequisites are met.Note: The ability to test connectivity is available only in the primary dcTrack.To test connectivity:1. In the primary dcTrack’s Settings tab > Appliance Settings > High Availability, ensure that the Enable HighAvailability checkbox is checked, that the node type is set to Primary, and that the appropriate information isentered for the secondary node..2. Ensure that the secondary dcTrack is configured.3. Click the Test Configuration button.The following prerequisites are confirmed when the user click the Test Configuration button:The secondary dcTrack is accessible to the primary dcTrackThe credentials to the secondary are validThe secondary dcTrack has been configured as secondaryThe secondary dcTrack is in the Pending Initialization stateThe secondary dcTrack is the same version as the primary dcTrackIf the connectivity test is successful, a dialog box indicating success will be displayed. If the connectivity test isunsuccessful, a dialog box indicating an error related to one of the points above will be displayed.Note: The connectivity test is not dependent on the heartbeat interval and retries.

dcTrack supports a number of services that facilitate integration with Power IQ and third-party systems. As part ofthe High Availability feature, these services can be disabled or enabled (restored) as a group to avoid complicationsof having two active dcTrack systems due to either automatic or manual failover.Integration services that can be enabled or disabled as a group include:Power IQ IntegrationsVMware ConnectorsIT Service Management (ITSM)CMDBPush NotificationsRemedy ConnectorRemote Storage of Database BackupsEmail NotificationsNote: System log destinations are not affected by the enabling or disabling of integration services as a group.Integration services can be disabled or restored as a group through the High Availability settings page. Any activeintegration services that are disabled by this feature will be logged internally and can be restored later if desired. Thecurrent setting for any service that was already disabled/inactive at the time the services were disabled will remainunchanged. If integration services are disabled or restored on a primary dcTrack while the High Availability cluster isactive, the settings change will be replicated to the secondary dcTrack.When the user chooses the option to Restore Integration Services, only the services that were previously active willbe restored.CAUTION: The integration service state as shown on the High Availability Configuration screen does not reflect thestate of the actual services. Instead, it reflects whether or not they were disabled/restored through the High Avail-ability feature. If you disable the services through High Availability, and then go to the services themselves and re-enable them, the Integration Services status will still show that they had been Disabled through High Availability.When an automatic failover occurs, the integration services on the secondary dcTrack will be disabled if the userselected the appropriate option on the High Availability settings page. Otherwise, they will remain unchanged.The table below outlines the actions to be completed following a manual failover with integration services enabled:Failover with Integration Remain Unchanged Are RestoredFailover without Integ-Are Disabled Remain UnchangedrationThe table below outlines the actions to be completed once a dcTrack system is restored to service:Restore with Integration Remain Unchanged Are RestoredRestore without Integration Are Disabled Remain UnchangedUsers with the System Administrator role can select or deselect to disable integration services on the secondarydcTrack following an automatic failover. This setting is configured on the Primary using the Disable IntegrationServices on Failover checkbox and can only be set when first building the cluster. .If option is selected, then on automatic failover the secondary shall disabled integration services as per Enablingand Disabling Integration Services as a GroupIf option is unselected, then on automatic failover the secondary shall not change the status of the integration ser-vicesThis setting is selected by default.Note: When a node is active, users can manually select to disable/restore services at any time. When using auto-failover, it’s recommended to select the option to disable them on failover to prevent any issues that might arisefrom an active:active scenario. After an System Administrator assess the situation, they can manually restore(enable) the services on the secondary system.

Users with the System Administrator role can manually force a failover to the secondary dcTrack and either disableintegration services (‘Without Integration’ option) or leave them unchanged (With Integration option) on that dcTrackas part of this action.Note: This option is only accessible from a primary dcTrack when the HA Cluster is Operational and the Primary isin the Active state. To enable the Force Failover button, the user must first select an option for failover with orwithout integration services in the High Availability settings page. Once an option is selected, the Force Failover but-ton in the High Availability settings page will be updated accordingly.To manually force a failover with or without integration services:1. In a primary dcTrack’s High Availability settings page, above the Force Failover button, select With Integ-ration radio button if you want integration services enabled. Select the Without Integration radio button if youwant integration services disabled. The Force Failover button will be updated accordingly.2. Click the Force Failover button. A confirmation dialog box will display.3. In the confirmation dialog box, click the OK button to initiate the failover. Click the Cancel button to close thedialog box without initiating failover.Once the failover has been initiated, a message directing users to manually log in to the secondary dcTrack will dis-play. The manual failover will also be captured in the system audit log.Users with the System Administrator role can disable or restore integration services on an active primary or sec-ondary dcTrack to avoid complications from two active dcTracks using the same services. This option can bechanged using the Disable/Restore Integration Services button in the High Availability settings page.Note: The Disable/Restore Integration Services button is only available when an active dcTrack system is running.The button will display different text based on the status of integration services as set in the High Availability settingspage. If integration services are currently enabled, the button will display text to disable integration services. If integ-ration services are currently disabled, the button will display text to restore integration services.To disable integration services:1. Click the Disable Integration Services button. A confirmation dialog box will display.2. In the confirmation dialog box, click the OK button to confirm that you want to disable integration services. Clickthe Cancel button to close the dialog box without disabling integration services.To restore integration services:1. Click the Restore Integration Services button. A confirmation dialog box will display.2. In the confirmation dialog box, click the OK button to confirm that you want to restore integration services. Clickthe Cancel button to close the dialog box without restoring integration services.Note: Attempts to disable and restore integration services will be logged in the system audit log.

dcTrack supports pessimistic automatic failover, which requires a High Availability cluster with a node for a primarydcTrack application and a node for a secondary dcTrack application. With this configuration, dcTrack can identify afailover situation and act accordingly to support high availability, or virtually 100% uptime.When automatic failover is enabled and the primary dcTrack detects a lost connectivity condition, it will automaticallyassume that the secondary dcTrack is active and will go offline. It will maintain its data and can be re-enabled byusers with the System Administrator role. When the secondary dcTrack detects lost connectivity condition, it willautomatically assume that the primary dcTrack has failed and will become active.Users with the System Administrator role can enable automatic failover from the High Availability settings page onthe primary dcTrack. Integration services can be enabled or disabled following an automatic failover on the HighAvailability settings page as well. Both of these settings can only be applied when initially setting up the cluster.To enable automatic failover:1. In the primary dcTrack’s Settings tab > Appliance Settings > High Availability, ensure that the Enable HighAvailability checkbox is checked to ensure that High Availability is enabled.2. Under High Availability Configuration > Node Type field, select the Primary radio button.3. Under Configuration, in the IP Address/Hostname field, enter the IP address or hostname of the secondarydcTrack.Note: Valid IPv4 and IPv6 address are accepted.4. In the Username field, enter the username that the primary dcTrack should use when initially com-municating with the secondary dcTrack.5. In the Password field, enter the password that the primary dcTrack should use when initially communicatingwith the secondary dcTrack.Note: The username and password must be for a user with local, not LDAP, permissions for the SystemAdministrator role. The username and password will not be displayed after you reload the page.6. Check the Enable Automatic Failover checkbox to enable automatic failover. By default, automatic failoveris disabled.7. Check/uncheck the Disable Integration Services on Failover checkbox to select/deselect to disable integ-ration services on the secondary node after an automatic failover occurs. By default, this option is enabled.8. Click the Save button to save the configuration.The table below summarizes the state transitions for the primary dcTrack following automatic failover:States priorto automaticOperational Active dcTrack N/A N/A N/AfailoverStates fol-lowing suc-High AvailabilitycessfulFailover IsolatedStandby Applic-N/A N/A N/AautomaticationfailoverThe table below summarizes the state transitions for the secondary dcTrack following automatic failover:States priorHigh Availabilityto automaticN/A N/A N/A Operational StandbyStandby Applic-failoverationStates fol-lowing suc-cessfulN/A N/A N/A Failover Active dcTrackautomaticfailover

Users with the System Administrator role can manually initiate failover from the primary dcTrack to force the failoverfunctionality in the secondary dcTrack. They can either disable integration services or leave them active/restorethem on that dcTrack as part of this action.To manually force a failover with or without integration services:1. In a primary dcTrack’s High Availability settings page, above the Force Failover button, select the With Integ-ration radio button if you want integration services enabled. Select the Without Integration radio button if youwant integration services disabled. The Force Failover button will be updated accordingly.2. Click the Force Failover button. A confirmation dialog box will display.3. In the confirmation dialog box, click the OK button to initiate the failover. Click the Cancel button to close thedialog box without initiating failover.Once the failover has been initiated, a message directing users to manually log in to the secondary dcTrack will dis-play. The manual failover will also be captured in the system audit log.If the primary dcTrack successfully notifies the secondary dcTrack to fail over, then the primary dcTrack will switch tothe Failover state, and the active application will transition from dcTrack to the High Availability Standby Application.The secondary dcTrack will switch to the Failover state and will switch the active application from dcTrack to theHigh Availability Standby Application.If the failover is unsuccessful, the primary dcTrack will abort the failover and remain in the Operational state. Thesecondary dcTrack will remain offline until a failover is manually initiated.Once the secondary dcTrack is active, it will include all the synchronized data up to the point where the cluster statusswitched to not operational.The table below summarizes the state transitions following a manual failover:States priorHigh Availabilityto manualOperational Active dcTrack Operational StandbyStandby Applic-failoverationStates fol-lowing suc-High AvailabilitycessfulFailover IsolatedStandby Applic-Failover Active dcTrackmanual fail-ationoverFollowing a failover, users with the System Administrator role can restore the primary dcTrack to service and canenable/disable integration services as part of the restoration process.When the primary dcTrack is in the Isolated state, it can be restored using the Restore to Service button in the HighAvailability Standby Application on the primary node.To restore the primary dcTrack to service using the High Availability Standby Application on the primary node:1. In the High Availability Standby Application, select the With Integration radio button if you want integrationservices enabled. Select the Without Integration radio button if you want integration services disabled. TheRestore to Service button will be updated accordingly.2. Click the Restore to Service button.3. Click the Save button. A confirmation dialog popup box will display.4. In the confirmation dialog popup box, click the OK button to confirm the action.The primary node will transition to the None state and switch the active application from the High AvailabilityStandby Application to dcTrack. This will also disable the High Availability feature on the primary dcTrack.

Users with the System Administrator role can manually restore the secondary dcTrack to service in the event ofissue on the primary dcTrack or if there is a network outage that disrupts communication between the two systems.This option is only available when the cluster status as shown on the secondary dcTrack is not operational. If thecluster is operational, the user will have to wait until the loss of connectivity condition is declared.For manual failover, once a loss of connectivity event occurs, the secondary in this case can only be restored to ser-vice through the High Availability Standby Application on the secondary node.Once the secondary dcTrack is active, it will include all the synchronized data up to the point where the cluster statusswitched to not operational.Note: This action is not dependent on the actual status of the primary dcTrack.To restore the secondary dcTrack to service using the High Availability Standby Application when the cluster statuson the secondary dcTrack is not operational:1. In the High Availability Standby Application, select the With Integration radio button if you want integrationservices enabled. Select the Without Integration radio button if you want integration services disabled. TheRestore to Service button will be updated accordingly.2. Click the Restore to Service button.3. Click the Save button. A confirmation dialog popup box will display.4. In the confirmation dialog popup box, click the OK button to confirm the action.The node will transition to the None state and switch the active application from the High Availability Standby Applic-ation to dcTrack. The High Availability feature will be disabled on the node.Note: If the secondary dcTrack’s Node Status is Incomplete, the data may not be intact for the dcTrack system to bestarted. In this case, you may need to reinstall dcTrack.Users with the System Administrator role may need to disable a cluster in order to complete specific actions, such asrebuilding a cluster when it is no longer operations, performing maintenance, upgrades, and database restores, or touse a secondary dcTrack as an up-to-date copy of a system for testing, sandbox, or development purposes.A cluster can be disabled through either the High Availability settings page of an active dcTrack system or throughthe High Availability Standby Application (HASA).There are two main scenarios where a cluster may be disabled:Cluster status is operational: When the cluster is operational, the primary and secondary dcTracks have con-nectivity, and the cluster can be disabled through the primary dcTrack’s UI.Cluster status is not operational (any of initializing, synchronizing, not operational, or failover): When the clusterstatus is initializing, synchronizing, not operational, or failover, the primary and secondary dcTracks are not com-municating, and you will need to make changes to each node to disable the cluster.Note: If the secondary dcTrack’s Node Status is Incomplete, the data may not be intact for the dcTrack system to bestarted. In this case, you may need to reinstall dcTrack.

When a cluster is operational, it can only be disabled through the primary dcTrack through the High Availability set-tings page. Users with the System Administrator role can disable the cluster.To disable the cluster:1. In the primary dcTrack’s High Availability settings page, uncheck the Enable High Availability checkbox.2. Click the Save button. A confirmation dialog popup box will display.3. In the confirmation dialog popup box, click the OK button to confirm the action.Once the High Availability feature is disabled and this setting is saved, the secondary dcTrack will become activeand disable the cluster and integration services on the secondary dcTrack. The database and file system com-ponents will be left on the secondary dcTrack. The cluster will be disabled on the primary dcTrack, but the integ-ration service settings will remain unchanged. Integration services can be enabled or disabled on either the primaryor secondary dcTrack.Both the primary and secondary dcTracks will retain their initial Node Type setting as displayed on the High Avail-ability settings page. The systems are not clustered, so the Paired Node IP Address value will display as N/A.The table below shows the status changes once the cluster has been disabled:States priorHigh Availabilityto disablingOperational Active dcTrack Operational StandbyStandby Applic-clusterationStates aftercluster isdisabledthroughDisabled N/A dcTrack Disabled N/A dcTracktheprimarydcTrack

When a cluster is in the initializing, synchronizing, not operational, or failover status, the cluster will need to be dis-abled on each system because they are no longer communicating or not yet in sync. Users with the System Admin-istrator role can disable the cluster.Note: Sunbird recommends that the user who is disabling the cluster start with the dcTrack system that is active.To disable a cluster on a dcTrack node where the full dcTrack application is active, use the High Availability Settingspage:1. In dcTrack’s High Availability Configuration page, uncheck the Enable High Availability checkbox.2. Click the Save button. A confirmation dialog popup box will display.3. In the confirmation dialog popup box, click the OK button to confirm the action.The node status will change Disabled. The integration service settings will remain unchanged but can be modifiedeither before or after the cluster is disabled through the High Availability Configuration page.To disable a cluster on a dcTrack node where the the High Availability Standby Application is active1. In the High Availability Standby Application, select the With Integration radio button if you want integrationservices enabled. Select the Without Integration radio button if you want integration services disabled. TheRestore to Service button will be updated accordingly.2. Click the Restore to Service button.3. Click the Save button. A confirmation dialog popup box will display.4. In the confirmation dialog popup box, click the OK button to confirm the action.The node status will change to Disabled. The dcTrack application will be active. The selected integration settingsoption will be applied but can be modified after the cluster is disabled through the High Availability Configurationpage.Once the cluster is disabled, for both the primary and secondary dcTracks, the node status will be None, and thepaired node IP address will display as N/A. The database and file system components will remain the same.Note: If the secondary dcTrack’s Node Status is Incomplete, the data may not be intact for the dcTrack system to bestarted. In this case, you may need to reinstall dcTrack.System Administrators may need to rebuild a cluster following a failover, maintenance, testing, or other instanceswhere the High Availability cluster needs to be disabled.To rebuild a High Availability Cluster:1. Restore both the primary and secondary nodes to service. For more information, see Restoring the PrimarydcTrack to Service and Restoring the Secondary dcTrack to Service.2. Determine which node you want to be the primary and which node should be the secondary based on whichnode has the data you want to retain. You can rebuild the cluster from either node but be sure to choose theone that has the data you wish to preserve. Remember that the data from the designated primary is rep-licated to the secondary.3. Configure the secondary dcTrack. For more information, see Configuring the Secondary dcTrack.4. Configure the primary dcTrack. For more information, see Configuring the Primary dcTrack.For assistance with rebuilding a cluster, contact Sunbird’s Technical Support team.

When a node is inactive (e.g. in the standby, isolated or incomplete state), user’s will not be able to log into the fulldcTrack application. Instead, they will be presented with a High Availability Standby Application (HASA) than canonly be used to review the cluster status and to restore an inactive to service such that the full dcTrack applicationwill be accessible. Only users with a local (non-LDAP) account that has System Administrator privileges can log intothis application.When a user accesses a dcTrack system or node, the user will either see the normal dcTrack application or the HighAvailability Standby Application.The user will see the normal dcTrack application when:The dcTrack system was never part of a clusterThe dcTrack system is an active node in a clusterThe dcTrack system is configured to be a secondary node, but the primary has yet to initiate a connectionwith the secondary node.High Availability is disabled on that nodeThe user will see the High Availability Standby application when:The node status is inactive (in the Isolated, Standby, or Incomplete states)The High Availability Standby Application can be used to:Check cluster statusRestore a secondary node to serviceRestore a primary node to service following a failoverNote: The High Availability Standby Application will show a message on the login page indicating that the accessednode is part of a dcTrack failover cluster but is not currently the active node.
