When High Availability is enabled, data will sync automatically from the primary dcTrack to the secondary dcTrack,as long as the primary and secondary dcTracks have connectivity, and the High Availability cluster is operational.Both the primary and secondary dcTracks will independently check for connectivity to each other using a heartbeator ping. If the initial attempt is unsuccessful, the heartbeat will be retried for a user-configurable number of times,with each retry attempted followed by a specific time interval that must elapse before the heartbeat is retried. If theconnectivity outage lasts longer than the initial attempt followed by the heartbeat retries, then the node will declarelost connectivity.For the primary dcTrack, the default number of heartbeats following the initial attempt is three heartbeats.The default retry interval is 60 seconds. Therefore, the initial default attempt is followed by three heartbeatsspaced at 60 seconds between each heartbeat.For the secondary dcTrack, the default number of heartbeats following the initial attempt is one more thanthat of the primary dcTrack. This additional retry is included to avoid race conditions. Therefore, the initialdefault attempt is followed by three heartbeats spaced at 60 seconds between each heartbeat plus one addi-tional heartbeat.Note: If either the primary or secondary dcTrack is rebooted, the High Availability cluster will continue to be oper-ational, as long as connectivity is reestablished and no data was lost or corrupted during the reboot.Note: When the node is no longer operational, it won’t respond to heartbeat attempts.To configure the primary heartbeat and retry interval:1. In the primary dcTrack, in the Settings tab > Appliance Settings > High Availability, check the Enable High Avail-ability checkbox to ensure that High Availability is enabled.2. In the Heartbeat Interval (sec) field, enter the desired length of the interval in seconds. The range is from 10-600seconds. The default is 60 seconds.3. In the heartbeat Retries field, enter the desired number of retries. The range is from 1-10 retries. The default isthree retries. Note that the number entered is in addition to the initial retry and that the secondary dcTrack willadd one additional retry to the number entered in this field.4. Click the Save button.When setting the Heartbeat Interval and Heartbeat retries values, be sure to take the following into account:1. You don’t want to low of a value that could cause nuisance failovers or for the cluster to transition to a notoperational state during restarts or short-term network issues.2. You don’t want to high of a value such that you lose operation of the system for too long of a period of time inthe event of an issue on the primary.Note that if the primary is down:For Auto Failover: The failover won’t occur until after the internal/retry period expires.For Manual Failover: You can’t make the secondary operational until the interval and retryperiod elapses and the secondary declares lost connectivity and moves to the cluster to theNot Operational state.

If lost connectivity is declared, and automatic failover is enabled:If the primary dcTrack detects lost connectivity, it will assume that the secondary dcTrack has become active,and the primary dcTrack will switch to the failover state and go offline. At this point, a user with the SystemAdministrator role can restore it if necessary.If the secondary dcTrack detects lost connectivity, it will assume that the primary dcTrack has gone offline, andthe secondary dcTrack will become active. The active application will switch from dcTrack to the High Avail-ability Standby Application.If lost connectivity is declared, and automatic failover is disabled, the primary and secondary dcTracks will transitionas noted in the table below:States priorHigh Availabilityto lost con-Operational Active dcTrack Operational StandbyStandby Applic-nectivityationStates afterHigh Availabilitylost con-Not oper-Not oper-Active dcTrack StandbyStandby Applic-nectivityational ationalationdeclaredNote: If either the primary or secondary dcTrack is offline, it will not transition until it is back online.When connectivity is lost to either the primary, secondary, or both the primary and secondary dcTracks, email noti-fications will be sent to the email addresses specified in the High Availability settings page for the primary dcTrack.Note: SMTP settings must be configured to send email notifications. For more information, see SMTP Server Set-tings.To configure lost connectivity email notifications:1. In the primary dcTrack, in the Settings tab > Appliance Settings > High Availability, check the Enable HighAvailability checkbox to ensure that High Availability is enabled.2. In the High Availability Lost Connectivity Email Notification Configuration panel, in the Email Addressesfield, enter the email addresses that you would like to receive notifications. Multiple email addresses can beseparated by a semicolon.3. Edit the subject and message if desired. Optional.4. Click the Save button.Note: Lost connectivity email notification settings can only be configured on the primary dcTrack. These settingswill be synced to and used by the secondary dcTrack in case lost connectivity is detected.Note: If both the primary and secondary dcTracks detect lost connectivity, each dcTrack will send a separate emailnotification.

dcTrack’sevents log when High Availability is enabled.

When High Availability is enabled, data is replicated from the primary dcTrack to the secondary dcTrack as part ofthe High Availability synchronization process and is kept synchronized while the cluster is operational.The following data will be synchronized:The full contents of the database on dcTrackThe full contents of the Models LibraryThe Remedy ConnectorThe Syslog Destinations as set through Settings > dcTrack Settings > Appliance Administration > Mail,Proxy, & SyslogThe NTP Servers as set through Settings > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration > Display & TimeThe SSL certificateThe following data will not be synchronized:The audit log (each system maintains an independent log)Database backupsThe network configuration, including firewall settings, as applied through the consoleSecurity Configuration changes applied through the consoleAny PDF reports that the user generatedImported CSV filesSystem logsNote: When a synchronization process is initiated, all existing data on the secondary dcTrack shall be lost. The pro-cess can start with either an empty dcTrack database or with one with data.

dcTrack 6.3 and above include the High Availability feature. When upgrading or restoring your dcTrack instance todcTrack 6.3 or above from dcTrack 6.1.1 or earlier, the following default settings will be applied:The High Availability cluster will be disabledAutomatic failover will be disabledAutomatic resumption of integration services will be disabledThe heartbeat internal for the primary and secondary dcTracks will be set to 60 secondsThe number of retries for the primary dcTrack will be set to three retriesThe number of retries for the secondary dcTrack will be sent to four retriesWhen upgrading dcTrack 6.3 to newer releases, the High Availability feature will retain its existing settings.The HA cluster must be disabled in order to either restore a database or to upgrade dcTrack. The system does notallow upgrades or restores to be performed while the High Availability Feature is enabled.To perform a software upgrade:1. Disable the High Availability cluster. See Disabling a Cluster for more information.2. Upgrade the secondary dcTrack.3. Upgrade the primary dcTrack once the secondary has successfully been upgraded.4. Rebuild the High Availability cluster. See Rebuilding a Cluster for more information.To perform a database restore:1. Disable the High Availability cluster. See Disabling a Cluster for more information.2. Restore the database to the primary dcTrack.3. Rebuild the High Availability cluster. See Rebuilding a Cluster for more information.The primary dcTrack is the system of record. Once the primary dcTrack is operational and available, it will auto-matically sync its data to the secondary dcTrack.

dcTrack version 7.0.0 has a new look and feel! dcTrack’s new GUI style not only gives it a more modern appearancebut has been designed to more elegantly highlight information and logical actions. This design is intended to makeselections more intuitive for the novice user, while eliminating unnecessary key strokes for advanced users allowingthem to quickly navigate through the application.The dcTrack application can be viewed in one of two modes, Light Theme and Dark Theme. Both modes aredesigned to highlight logical next step buttons, icons and menu items, as well as provide greater feature access fromthe tool bar eliminating extra clicks.Steps to toggle between Light Mode and Dark Mode:1. Click the User Menu in the dcTrack header tool bar2. Select the Toggle Theme option from the menuThe GUI will immediately toggle between Modes.How to Set User Preferences Such as Language and Dark ModeThe Disk Extender is a feature that allows dcTrack to automatically detect when the existing disk space in your hyper-visor system has been increased.If your dcTrack system is running out of space, simply follow the steps below to increase your existing disk space:1. Power down your Power IQ/dcTrack system.2. Go into your hypervisor system and increase the size of the existing disk.3. Power your Power IQ/dcTrack system back on. On boot your system will detect the additional capacity andextend the partitions to leverage it.Note: The disk extender only detects increases to existing storage. It will not detect a new disk.

Default is 25.Destination:TCP SMTP Email Source: Any Other common ports include 587Selectable(STARTTLS) and 465 (Implicit TLS).The Settings Tab in dcTrack only displays for System System Administrators. This section covers the settings avail-able to System System Administrators The following table summarizes the dcTrack Appliance and Application Set-tings menu options and their descriptionsFor information on how to change your individual user preferences, see Edit Your User Information (Non-SystemAdministrators).About About Information, Appliance Version, Total Licenses Used Licenses, Available LicensesApplication Settings: Company Standard Models, Planned for Decommission, CustomizePower Port Names on Integrated Rack PDUs, Auto Power Budget, Parts Management, DCPower Settings, Bulk Update Power Budgets, Models Library Ports Clean UpAudit LogApplicationDisplay & Locale: Display Settings, Locale SettingsAdministrationEmail SettingsProduct Licensing: Add a license, See Feature, Type of License, Count, Total Licenses UsedLicenses, Available LicensesProxyPower IQVirtualizationsAsset & CMDBIntegrationsTicketing systemsWebhooksWorld mapAppliance ServicesData BackupsHigh AvailabilityHTTPS CertificateIP Based Access ControlAppliance Admin-istrationLog ForwardingODBC AccessProduct UpgradeSNMP SettingsTime SettingsUser Accounts: Add, delete, assign roles and groups.User Groups: Add, delete, assign roles and group membersAuthorization &AuthenticationAD & LDAP: Active Directory or LDAP configuration for users and groups.Password RequirementsSAML: SAML configurationSession SecurityTrusted Certificates: Manage Certificates of servers that are trustworthy.Note: All forms in the Settings tab display an “Unsaved Changes” warning message if you make changes andattempt to navigate away from the form without saving your changes. You will have the option to either discard yourchanges or return to the form.Note: The Settings tab is searchable from the search box at the top of the left navigation menu.

You can change the default message that displays on the dcTrack login page, sometimes called the dcTrack splashscreen, to a customized message.To change the login page message:1. Click Settings.2. In the Login Page Message section. provide the Header and Body text.3. You can use html tags for formatting.Header: Text entered in this field displays on the login page in a bold font, as the heading to the messageBody: Text entered in this field displays in a normal font, as the main content of the message.Allowed html tags: strong, em, a, fontAllowed html attributes: href, title, color4. Click Save Message. Log out of dcTrack to return to the login page and view the message.Use SNMP to retrieve dcTrack system health information, such as application up time, IP routing, system contactsand so on.1. In the Web Client, navigate to Settings >dcTrack Settings > Appliance Administration > SNMP Settings. TheSNMP Settings panel displays.2. In the MIB-II section, in tthe Read Community String field, enter the community string used to access theSNMP network. Required.3. Enter the system contact, system name and system location if needed.4. Click the Save button. A confirmation message is displayed.You can now use any third-party SNMP manager, such as an SNMP MIB Browser, to access the system health viaMIB-II.

The following table summarizes performance indicators from the MIB-II and Host Resources MIB that are exposedby the SNMP agent:System Information (e.g., sysUpTime, Number of users, Number of system processes) hrSystemhrDevice: hrDeviceT-Device Information (e.g., Device types, Processors, NICs)ablehrDevice: hrPro-CPU Utilization/Processor LoadcessorTablehrDevice: hrNet-Network and Partition Table InformationworkTable, hrPar-titionTableMemory and Disk Usage hrStoragehrSWRun, hwSWRun-Running processesPerfInstalled software hrSWInstalledTabledcTrack 5.3.0 introduces REST API Version 2 support for Webhooks. A REST API client in dcTrack will push noti-fications to the service specified to receive the notifications. The notifications provide summaries of the changes thathave resulted in an auditable event in dcTrack. These include changes to item details, port details, item status, andport connection status.The REST API client is configured from Settings > dcTrack Settings > Integrations > Webhooks as shown inthescreenshot below.The table below summarizes available settings. All values are required except “aggregationTime” and “aggreg-ationCount.”If not defined, these parameters will be set to the default values. You only need to provide values for the parametersyou want to update.Used to enable notifications to the specified service.Enable Notification“Enabled” refers to whether the notification is enabled and has a value of true or false.The URL of the service where notifications will be sent. Requires the use of https.External URL“urlString” has a maximum length of 255 characters.The time period to aggregate auditable event notifications before sending out a notification.Aggregation Time“aggregationTime” is an integer measured in seconds, ranging from 15 to 86400 seconds, with adefault of 15 seconds.The number of auditable events to aggregate before sending out a notification. The lesser oftime period or count will be used to determine if a notification is to be sent.Aggregation Count“aggregationCount” is an integer in seconds, ranging from 100 to 1000 seconds, with a defaultof 200 seconds.The username to be used by the REST API client for notifications.Username“userName” has a maximum length of 255 characters.The passphrase to be used by the REST API client for notifications.Passphrase“passPhrase” has a maximum length of 40 characters.Once all of the required fields have been supplied, use the Test Connection button to verify your configuration.You can use also the following APIs to retrieve or modify the Webhooks configuration or to delete the Webhook.Retrieve the Noti-fication ConfigurationRetrieve the current Webhook configuration information.Update the Webhook configuration information. You can update the Webhook configurationModify the Noti-with payload when the service is turned down. You only need to provide values for the para-fication Configurationmeters you want to update. Returns updated Webhook configuration information.You can use also the following new APIs to retrieve or modify the Webhook configuration or todelete the configuration.Clear the Notification Deletes the Webhook configuration.Note: To view a Webhook JSON payload example, see Webhook JSON Example in the dcTrack API Guide.

Certain display settings can be managed by System Administrators. Admins can choose to display a Custom Logoin the dcTrack header and can also control whether users can view HTML widgets in Dashboards The Display &Local Settings are accessible in the Settings Tab Application Administration > Display & LocalNote: For new users, the admin's account (username "admin") user preferences for Language, Theme, Unit Sys-tem, Data Separator, Date Format and Cabinet Elevation preferences are used as the default preferences, how-ever the Language used on the Login screen for new users is set from the setting on the Display & Locale page.Allowing the system to display HTML widgets introduces the risk that an HTML widget may exploit web security vul-nerabilities. For this reason, this capability is not enabled by default.See Also Dynamic Content-Security-Policy.Steps to allow users to view HTML Dashboard Widgets:1. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration > Display & Time2. In the Display Settings panel, check the Allow user-created HTML widgets on the dashboard check box3. Click the Save buttonOnce enabled users will be able to view HTML widgets on dashboards. If this feature is not enabled users will bepresented with the locked widget display when attempting to view HTML widgets.

Steps to define a custom Logo in the dcTrack header:1. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration > Display & Time2. Check the Show a custom uploaded logo check box3. Use the browse button to navigate to the image file4. Select the image5. Click the Save button6. Click the Save Display Settings buttonNote: Logos must not exceed 150 pixels wide, 48 pixels high, or 512 KB in size.The Trusted Certificates tab under the Settings > Authorization & Authentication sidebar menu displays a panel list-ing the available trusted certificates. The fingerprint of each certificate is a hyperlink that leads to the certificate’s Cer-tificate Details Panel when clicked. Users who have the System Administrator role can view and interact with theTrusted Certificates table to add or remove a trusted certificate.

1. Click the Import Certificate button in the Trusted Certificates panel. The New Trusted Certificate Panel dis-plays2. Click the Choose File button in the New Trusted Certificate Panel to open the file selector dialog and selectyour trusted certificate file.3. Click the Upload button to add the certificateNote: The trusted certificate file will be validated to ensure that the certificate file is not empty, does notexceed the maximum file upload size and does not encounter any errors when attempting to parse the cer-tificate.4. Upon successful import, the new trusted certificate displays in the Trusted Certificates panel.System Administrators can remove a trusted certificate from either the Trusted Certificates panel or the CertificateDetails panel.To remove a trusted certificate from the Trusted Certificates panel, click the Trashcan/Remove Certificate icon nextto the certificate that you want to remove.To remove a trusted certificate from the Certificate Details panel, click the Delete button

The Certificate Details panel provides additional information about the trusted certificate. To view a certificate’sDetails panel, click the certificate’s fingerprint link in the Trusted Certificates panelThe following table summarizes the information displayed in the Certificate Details panel:Displays one or more of the following fields (varies by certificate contents):CountryDomain ComponentLocalityIssued ToNameOrganizationOrganization UnitPostal CodeState or ProvinceDisplays one or more of the following fields (varies by certificate contents):CountryDomain ComponentLocalityIssued byNameOrganizationOrganization UnitPostal CodeState or ProvinceData for the following fields:Validity PeriodIssued On: Date the certificate was issued.Expires On: Date the certificate expires.Data for the following fields:VersionMiscellaneousSerial NumberSHA1 FingerprintBackups of system data, users and configuration settings are automatically created every 24 hours or can be con-figured to run based on a user defined schedule (See Automated Database Backups). Optionally, you can create abackup as needed by following the steps in this topic.It is recommended that you manually back up your dcTrack database before upgrading or reinstalling dcTrack (tocreate a database backup file that you will use to restore your dcTrack data).Use a dcTrack recovery license in order to make a disaster recovery backup of your database, if needed.The Backup page contains a grid list of available archives with the following columns:File - Archive Filename (link to download archive file)Timestamp - Timestamp when the archive was generatedmd5sum - md5sum generated hash value. Click the folder icon to copy the hash value to your clip boardSize - Size of the archive file

SchedulingBackup Interval - How often automatic backups should be runEvery HourEvery 2 HoursEvery 4 HoursEvery 8 HoursEvery DayDaily Backup Schedule - Time of day to begin the automatic backupEncryptionNote: dcTrack encrypts data backup files using a GnuPG/PGP public key that you generate. You can gen-erate PGP Encryption Keys using free tools. Go to https://www.gnupg.org and look for a binary for your oper-ating system on the Downloads page.Encrypt Backup - Check if you want backups to be encryptedIf encrypting backups you are required to provide the GnuPG/PGP Public KeyRemote StorateService used for storing backups remotely.Available Services include:AWSSCPSFTPFTPYou must supply the required configurations for each service typeTo manually create a new Backup1. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Appliance Administration > Data Backups.2. In the Backup Tool bar, click the Create button.The file is created and added to the top of the list under Filename.An MD5 file is also created along with the backup file for verification purposes.Unless manually deleted, four days of backups are retained before they are deleted and no more than two backupsare retained for any given day.dcTrack allows System Administrators to create an Announcement Banner that is displayed directly above thedcTrack menu bar. Once the announcement is set up, it will remain displayed until the setting is either disabled orthe message is changed.The message can be up to 2 lines of text and the font and background color can be configured by the user.Steps to configure dcTrack Announceent Banner:1. Navigate to dcTrack Settings > Authorization and Authentication > Session Security2. Under the Application Announcement Banner section provide the following information:1. Click the Enable check box. This will enable the other fields for entry.2. Supply the text you wish to display in both line 1 and line 2.Note: If the entered text exceeds the screen length, hovering over the message will display thetext as a tool tip3. Specify the hex value to be used for the Background color. The associated color will display in the adja-cent box.4. Specify the hex value to be used when displaying embedded links in the message. Users can clickembedded links at any time to navigate to the specified site.Note: Initally the values will default to Green as the backgound and orange for links. These col-ors will clearly display in both dcTrack light and dark modes but can be changed to any coloryou choose. Font color will automatically adjust to either black or white depending on the back-ground color to ensure text is easily clearly.5. Click the Save button to save your selections.Note: The header will be immediately updated upon clicking the Save button for the admin. Forusers that are currently logged in, the banner will be refreshed after 5 minutes. The banner isimmediately displayed when new users log in.
Watch a video on how to use the import feature. https://youtu.be/8R-UsdiumcM

Once dcTrack is installed, follow the steps outlined in this section to build your first data centers in dcTrack and additems and connections to them.There are pre-steps to perform before you build your first data centers.The pre-steps include upgrading your Item Models Library and adding items to dcTrack Lists, to name just two. It isimportant to complete these steps so all models and menu options are available to you during File Import.Ensure you do not miss a step by following the checklist provided in Checklist - Build Your First dcTrack DataCenters, and Add Your First Items, Connections and Users.dcTrack File Import is the recommended method to build one or more data centers since it eliminates many manualsteps. This includes automatically enabling Virtual Power Chains for each location individually, creating connectionswithin the cabinet such as from the server to the top of rack network, connections to a switch, connections frompower supply to rack PDU, the ability sync one or more Power IQs, and so more.It also helps organize your data since you can add all of your location, item and connection information to the FileImport. The template can be used as your Primary import file. You can then create individual files for import by sav-ing the Primary file under different names and including only the items for import.Note: You can still manually add data center locations, although it is not the recommended method. SeeUse FileImport to Add, Edit Delete and Move.Begin a File Import by clicking the Import button in the dcTrack main tool barAt a high-level, you will:1. Download the File Import template from the Import Page.2. Populate the template with your data. Save a primary file and create individual Import Templates by saving cop-ies.3. Individually import Locations, Cabinets, Rack PDUs, Devices, Data Connections and Power Connections.Note: dcTrack checks to ensure you do not exceed your cabinet licenses. Cabinets that exceed the license limit arenot imported and dcTrack informs you of this.4. Use File Import in the Web Client and follow the steps provided in the File Import dialog.5. Upload your data center drawing files via the Visualization page in the Web Client so the file objects sync withthe items you imported into dcTrack.6. Use the Sync button on the Visualization tool bat to sync items that did sync during the drawing file upload, ifneeded.

Note: This checklist provides up to four columns to track tasks for up to four data centers. This is not a restriction onthe number of data centers you can add at once using File Import - you can import as many data centers as neededat the same time. If you have more than four data centers to import, make copies of the checklist.Collect and Clean Your Existing DataThis is data you will import into dcTrack to populateyour data centers. Gather any files you have thatcontain cabinets, items and so on. This may includespreadsheets, databases and so on.Locate or Create the Data Center Drawing FilesFiles must be in .DWG format.(Optional) Locate Data Center Image FilesNext, ensure you have completed the following dcTrack configuration steps before beginning the File Import. Detailedinformation on performing these steps is included in this section.Update the Item Models LibraryThis is a system-level function that applies to all data center locations. In the Web Client, select Settings >Models Library > Actions >Update Models Library.Update FieldsThis is a system-level function you perform and it applies to all data center locations. In the Web UI, select Set-tings > Fields Management> Pick List Choices from the Explorer Menu to access Lists.(Optional) Automatically Add and Manage Users/User Groups via LDAP or Active Directory and/or ManagedcTrack Users and GroupsYou can add local user groups now or at a later time, if needed. This is a system-level task you configure in theWeb Client.You do not have to create all users at this point; users can be added at any time. dcTrack supports –Local AuthenticationRemote AuthenticationImport LocationsIn the Web Client, select Assets > File Import. See .Import CabinetsUse File Import to add all cabinets to all data cen-ters at once, or add them to one data center at atime. See .Import Rack PDUsUse File Import to add all rack PDUs to all data cen-ters at once, or add them to one data center at atime. See .Import Device ItemsUse File Import to add all devices of every type toall data centers at once, or add them to one datacenter at a time. See .Upload and Sync Drawing FilesEach location needs its own drawing file.See .Add and Configure Power Infrastructure Items -Cooling Units, UPS Units and Floor PDUs See Addand Configure Power Infrastructure Items -Cooling Units, UPS Units and Floor PDUsBefore circuits can be imported, these items mustbe added and configured.This step can be performed now or at a later time,but it is recommended you perform the step now.You can import structured cabling in bulk using FileImport.Use File Import to Create Power and DataConnectionsOnce all power related items such as rack PDUs,floor PDUs, UPS units and so on are added, use FileImport to add all power connections. Add con-nections to all data centers at once, or add them toone data center at a time.Use File Import to Import Virtual Power ChainConnectionsIf needed, import Virtual Power Chain connectionsfor locations that have VPC enabled. VPC can beenabled during the Location import.Test and VerifyTest the application and verify the data for completeness and accuracy by using dcTrack on a trial basis andincorporating dcTrack into your standard data center management processes.Once you've performed these steps, you can go on to enable or configure other dcTrack features, such as:Configure dcTrack to Use Standard ModelsDefining Required Fields for Your dcTrackEnable or Disable Request Bypass (Change Control Workflow Options)Integrate with One or Multiple Power IQs

Before adding data centers, items and locations for the first time, update the Item Models Library. This helps ensureyou are work with the most current models available.Note that you can do one of the following to request a model/make be added to the Sunbird Models Library file con-tact:Add a Model to the Models Library (provided you have privileges to do so).Contact Sunbird Professional Services and Support to request a model be added to the library and included inthe next Sunbird Models Library file releases

Updates are performed using the Library Update Wizard that walks you through each step of the process.Note: Customers currently on dcTrack 2.6.1 (or earlier) are advised to update to the latest available Sunbird ModelsLibrary file before upgrading to dcTrack 5.1.0.1. If you have not already done so, download the most recent Sunbird Models Library file and save it locally.2. In the Models Library, select Actions > Update Models Library to access the Library Update Wizard.3. On the first step (welcome screen), click Start a New Update Session to start the wizard. The results of the pre-vious update will be displayed if available.4. On the second step, click Browse to locate the Sunbird Models Library file you saved locally.The file upload takes place in two stages: uploading and then processing/staging. Once this step has com-pleted, the following message is displayed: "Models Library Staging is successful without any errors or warn-ings. You may now proceed to next step." Click the green arrow to the right of the steps to proceed.5. Map information.Each step displays the items that do not exactly match the database objects. Users will be able to add non-matching items to the database or can select objects from a list of potential matches.Items that match exactly will be automatically updated in the database. These items are not displayed.If there is information in the Sunbird Models Library file that is not in your Item Models Library, it is automaticallycopied to your library once the wizard completes.Step 3 maps Data Connectors.Step 4 maps Power Connectors.Step 5 maps Protocols.Step 6 maps Data Rates.Step 7 maps Breakers and Fuses.Step 8 maps Makes.Step 9 maps Models.Certain rows in the grid may be flagged with a Warning or Error icons. Hovering the mouse over the icon revealsthe issue that you may be able to correct by changing the Best Match selection, or for certain errors, you mustchoose the Skip action and resolve the problem in your system.6. In Step 9, you will be able to generate a spreadsheet of Classis and Blade Items affected by the update (if any)and a spreadsheet of Actions on Models in the Update. Click the Export button to view these options.7. On Step 10, click Begin Library Update to begin the library update.New models are added and existing model information is updated once Begin Update is selected.As the process is underway, monitor the progress using the progress bar. No additional input is required, andthe update can be left to run unattended.8. Once the update is complete, the results will be displayed in the Results and Progress box.

Note: Customize Standard and Custom Fields before you create your first data center locations and add items andconnections for the first time. Add attributes to fields so they are available when you perform an import. This isimportant because dcTrack does not add items to fields during the import. Trying to import information that is not ona field causes errors during the import, and you must manually fix them before that data is added.The elements contained in Standard and Custom Fields are used to populate drop-downs and menus in dcTrack.For example, the Function drop-down on New Item page is populated by the Item Function drop-down.Standard Fields include default attributes that can be configured as needed so they fulfill your specific requirements.For example, you can add new customers to the Customers Standard Field list contents. Standard Fields are usedacross the dcTrack application.Custom Fields can be used to capture information specific to your data center needs that are not included in dcTrackby default. Item Custom fields appear in the Custom Fields sub-tab on the Item Details page in the Web Client andCircuit Custom Fields appear on the Circuit Detail page.For information on managing Standard and Custom Fields, see Adding, Editing, and Deleting Standard and CustomFields in the Online Help or User Guide.Important: This topic applies to users who are configuring remote LDAP authentication for the first time, meaningyou are adding a new LDAP server and new users and/or user groups.Note: dcTrack version 7.2.0 introduced support for One Time Passwords via LDAP. Prior releases required issuing2 requests to authenticate a user, one to authenticate and one to gather the user's details. As a result the secondrequest failed if the user was flagged with a One Time Password. In dcTrack 7.2.0 and beyond a single request isissued which will both authenticate the user as well as gathering the user's details.However, you must take some additional steps to now move to remote LDAP authentication. For detai

This topic walks you through gathering server information, adding the LDAP server, configuring general server set-tings and sync settings in dcTrack, as well as searching for and adding users and/or user groups.This topic also describes enabling and disabling LDAP in dcTrack, and how to delete an LDAP server.An Active Directory server section and LDAP server section are provided since the information you need to gatherand the steps vary slightly.System Administrators can use LDAP and/or Active Directory (AD) in to automatically add and manage users and/oruser groups in dcTrack. This is an alternative to local authentication, or manually adding and managing LDAP users.See Local User Authentication and Manually Add and Manage Users and Groups via LDAP or Active Directory(Search), respectively.Unlike manually adding LDAP users, you can add both users and user groups with this feature.Additionally, changes to individual users and user groups on the remote LDAP server are automatically reflected indcTrack. Syncs are performed at intervals you configure in dcTrack's Common Settings.For example, if you change a user's email address on the LDAP server, once a sync occurs, the address is changedin dcTrack. Another example would be when you add a user to an LDAP user group. Once the user is added to theuser group, the user is automatically added to dcTrack with the same permissions as the other members in thegroup.

All of the following actions are accessed from the LDAP Servers page. The LDAP Servers page is accessed from theSettings tab.1. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Authorization & Authentication > AD & LDAP to open the LDAP Serv-ers page.You need the information listed below in order to configure Active Directory and/or LDAP servers in dcTrack. Youshould gather this information before beginning the add server process in dcTrack.Two worksheets are provided below: one to help you gather Active Directory information and another to help yougather the LDAP information.
