1. Click Add Server on the LDAP Servers page.The Add LDAP Servers page opens.Complete the fields in each section that apply to your specific needs. Use the configuration information you gatheredearlier to complete each section.Note: Configuration settings vary slightly between Active Directory and LDAP.

1. Select Active Directory Server as the server type.2. Select the order in which the server will be listed in the LDAP Servers table. This dictates the order in whichdcTrack communicates with the servers when multiple servers are configured.3. Select the Active checkbox to enable the server, or leave it deselected and return to activate it at a later time. Itmust be active in order to be in use.The information you enter in the remaining sections is specific to the server type you are configuring: either ActiveDirectory or LDAP.For this reason, Active Directory and LDAP settings are broken out into two sections on this page: Active DirectoryServer Configuration in dcTrack and LDAP Server Configuration in dcTrackScroll down the page to view LDAP setting instructions.4. Domain - applies if Active Directory only. The domain name of the server.5. Use Host - select if you want to use a specific hostname or IP Address to access the Active Directory server.6. Hostname/IP Address - enter the Active Directory server's hostname or IP address if Use Host is selected.7. Use TLS/SSL - select if using TLS/SSL encryption.8. Port - the default is Port 389 if TLS/SSL encryption is not enabled, and Port 636 is the default if TLS/SSL encryp-tion is enabled. The port number can be edited to a different value, if necessary.

9. If you need to validate certificates, select Check Server Certificate.10. Next, click the Manage Certificates link to open the Trusted Certificates page. The certificate needs to be PEMformat to upload.11. Click Import Certificate to open the Import Trusted Certificate page. The certificate needs to be PEM format toupload12. Click on the "Choose File" text box to open your browser to locate the certificate, then click Import to import thecertificate.You can use the Back button in your browser to return to the Add LDAP Server page.The information entered here identifies where searches are performed to locate users on the server.13. Base DN - specify a Base DN (directory level/entry) under which the authentication search query will begin.dcTrack can do a recursive search downward from this Base DN..For example, depending on the scope of the search, if the Base DN is dc=sunbird,dc=com, the search query for theuser entry will be made over the whole directory structure.If the Base DN is cn=Administrators,cn=Users,dc=sunbird,dc=com, the search query will begin in the Administratorssubdirectory (entry).14. Login Name Attribute - the login name that corresponds to the server type. The default for Active Directory issAMAccountName.15. Search Filter - enter a user's attributes in this field if you want the search query to be restricted to only thoseentries that meet the criteria. The default for Active Directory is (objectClass=user).16. Search Scope - level of the server directory to look for users; either the Base DN and one level below the BaseDN, or the Base DN and the entire subtree below.17. Follow Referrals - select this option to allow the dcTrack LDAP client to follow referrals provided by the LDAPserver if referral objects are encountered.18. Search Credentials:Leave "no search" to use the credentials provided by the user on log in.Select "anonymous" if no credentials are required.Select "use admin credentials" and enter the admin user credentials in the Admin DN and Admin Passwordfields. The admin credentials will be used for the service account when conducting searches.

19. User Groups for Authorization and Common Setting – ‘Sync Group Members’ will be used to enable the ability toautomatically add and manage users from imported user groups.20. Use Group Search DN - select to specify the group DN to search. Select this option if the group DN search is dif-ferent than the search used for users.21. Group Search DN - this is where the search for the user group will begin in the directory.22. Group ID Attribute - the default for Active Directory is sAMAccountName.23. Group Member Attribute - the default for Active Directory is member.24. Group Search Filter - the default for Active Directory is (objectClass=group).25. Group Search Scope - level of the server directory to look for groups; either the Base DN and one level belowthe Base DN, or the Base DN and the entire subtree.26. Optional Test Connection is to test with an account. If you have a known, valid test account to use to test theserver setup, you can test from here without having to try to login with that account.27. Click Save to save the settings and add the server.Once added, the server is listed on the Add LDAP Server page.

1. Select LDAP Server as the type.2. Select the order in which the server will be listed on the LDAP Servers table. This dictates the order in whichdcTrack communicates with the servers when multiple servers are configured.3. Select the Active checkbox to enable the server, or leave it deselected and return to activate it at a later time. Itmust be active in order to be in use.The following steps describe LDAP settings you configure. Scroll up to view Active Directory settings if you are con-figuring an Active Directory server.4. Domain - does not apply to LDAP.5. Use Host - select to use a specific hostname or IP address to access the LDAP server.6. Hostname/IP Address - enter the LDAP server's hostname or IP address when Use Host is selected.7. Use TLS/SSL - select if using TLS/SSL encryption.8. Port - the default is Port 389 if TLS/SSL encryption is not enabled, and Port 636 is the default if TLS/SSL encryp-tion is enabled. The port number can be edited to a different value, if necessary.

9. If you need to validate certificates, select Check Server Certificate.10. Next, click Manage Certificates to open the Trusted Certificates page. The certificate needs to be PEM format toupload.11. Click Import Certificate to open the Import Trusted Certificate page.12. Click on the "Choose File" text box to open your browser to locate the certificate, then click Import to import thecertificate.You can use the Back button in your browser to return to the Add LDAP Server page.The information entered here identifies where searches are performed to locate users on the server.13. Base DN - specify a Base DN (directory level/entry) under which the authentication search query will begin.dcTrack can do a recursive search downward from this Base DN.For example, depending on the scope of the search, if the Base DN is dc=sunbird,dc=com, the search query for theuser entry will be made over the whole directory structure.If the Base DN is cn=Administrators,cn=Users,dc=sunbird,dc=com, the search query will begin in the Administratorssubdirectory (entry).14. Login Name Attribute - login name that corresponds to the server type. The default is the user ID.15. Search Filter - enter a user's attributes in this field so the search query will be restricted to only those entries thatmeet this criterion. The default is (objectClass=inetOrgPerson).16. Search Scope - level of the server directory to look for users; either the Base DN and one level below the BaseDN, or the Base DN and the entire subtree below.17. Follow Referrals - select this option to allow the dcTrack LDAP client to follow referrals provided by the LDAPserver if referral objects are encountered.18. Search Credentials - leave "no search" selected if no search is required.Select "anonymous" if no credentials are required.Select "use admin credentials" and enter the Admin DN username and Admin Password. These credentialswill be used for the service account when conducting searches.

19. User Groups for Authorization and Common Setting – ‘Sync Group Members’ are used to enable automaticallyadding and managing users from imported user groups.20. Use Group Search DN - select to specify the group DN to search. Select this option if the group DN search is dif-ferent than the search used for users.21. Group Search DN - this where the search for user groups will begin in the directory.22. Group ID Attribute - the default is gidNumber.23. Group Member Attribute - the default is memberUid.24. Group Search Filter - the default is(objectClass=posixGroup).25. Group Search Scope - level of the server directory to look for groups; either the Base DN and one level belowthe Base DN, or the Base DN and the entire subtree.26. Optional Test Connection is to test with an account. If you have a known, valid test account to use to test theserver setup, you can test from here without having to try to login with that account.27. Click Save to save the settings and add the server.Once added, the server is listed on the Add LDAP Server page.1. On the Add LDAP Server page, click Search.The Search for LDAP Users and Groups page opens.2. Select the server you want to search.The remaining server information is completed based on the server you selected earlier, or you can edit the inform-ation by entering a new server to search.3. Select the type of search - Users or Groups, depending on how the server is configured in dcTrack.4. Select the Follow Referrals checkbox, if desired.5. Search Scope is prepopulated based on the scope you defined when adding the server.You can change the scope of the search, if desired.This is the level of the server directory to look for users or groups. You can search just the Base DN by selecting"Base", search the Base DN and one level below the Base DN by selecting "One", or search the Base DN and theentire subtree by selecting "Subtree".6. Click Search to locate users or user groups on the server.7. A list of results is displayed once found. You can now add users and/or groups to dcTrack from those found.To add users or groups found in an LDAP search, select the checkbox next to each user and/or user group in the list,then click Add.In order to search and add user groups, the ‘Use Groups for Authorization’ option must be enabled on the Serverpage.When searching for and adding user groups, one or more groups can be selected at a time. The users will not beautomatically added unless the Common Settings – ‘Sync Group Members’ is enabled.When searching for and adding user groups, clicking on a user group causes the group members to be listed belowthe user group grid. One or more group members can be selected to be added.Successfully added users/user groups are listed as "Exists as LDAP user" and the checkbox next to the name isremoved.Once added, individual users are granted distinct permissions and authenticated on a per user basis.Users in user groups are granted common access to specific features or functionality.Any changes you make to a user or user group on the server are reflected in dcTrack. For example, if you delete auser from a user group, they are no longer able to access the features they previously could in dcTrack.

This information can be edited and configured now or at a later time.8. To edit user information or login credentials, navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Authorization & Authentic-ation and select User Accounts.You can easily identify users added via LDAP since the LDAP DN field is populated in their row.9. Click on a user's name to open their User Information page.10. Click Edit on the User Information page.11. All editable fields are activated.12. Login is required and must contain the username. 3 characters minimum. 40 characters maximum.Important: If authentication is required by your email system, the dcTrack username must be the same as the user'semail account username*. If the usernames do not match, emails cannot be successfully sent from dcTrack.For example, if the username assigned to an email account is jqpublic, the dcTrack username must be jqpublic.If authentication is not required by your system, usernames do not have to match.13. Required Mail is required and must contain a correctly formatted email address.Note: Account username refers to the username assigned to the email account; it does not refer to the name por-tion of the user's email address. Typically, the username and name portion of an email are the same, but this maynot be the case.dcTrack allows you to configure common settings that control the number of users and/or user groups returned in asearch. This feature also allows you to enable LDAP syncing. LDAP syncing controls the interval between whendcTrack and the LDAP server are synchronized.There are several times when group synchronization will occur. Note that in each of these scenarios both the "SyncGroup Members" option found on the Common Settings page and the "Use Groups for Authorization" option foundon the Settings page for each individual server must be enabled. If either of these options is not enabled, group syn-chronization will not occur.Group Synchronization occurs:During periodic sync as determined by the Sync Interval defined in Common SettingsWhen performing a manual sync by clicking the "Sync Now" button in Common SettingsWhen a new user that does not exist in dcTrack but does exist in LDAP/AD logs into dcTrack for the first timeWhen an existing dcTrack user logs in, his groups are not automatically synchronized. Groups for existing users willbe synchronized during the next manual or periodic sync. The user information for existing users (Name, Email) how-ever is updated each time the user logs into dcTrack.1. Click Common Settings on the Add LDAP Servers dialog opens.The Editing Common LDAP Settings page opens.2. Select Enabled to enable the dcTrack LDAP client3. Select the Max Search Results from the drop-down.4. Select the Enable LDAP Sync checkbox to enable LDAP server syncing.5. When "Sync Group Members" and "Use Groups for Authorization" are enabled, users will be added to dcTrackautomatically or removed from dcTrack once the user groups are imported into dcTrack.6. Select the Synch Interval from the drop-down. Updates will be made whenever a user logs in or the specifiedsync interval whichever comes first.7. To sync immediately, click Save and then click Sync Now.8. Click Save to save the settings. You can use the Back button in your browser to return to the Add LDAP Serverpage.

This enables or disables LDAP support in dcTrack. It does not enable or disable a specific LDAP server.1. If LDAP is disabled, click the "LDAP is disabled" button to enable it.2. Once enabled, the button changes to "LDAP is enabled". Click the button again to disable LDAP.1. Click the X link in the row of the LDAP server you want to delete.2. Click OK when prompted to delete.

Local users are validated based on credentials you configured in dcTrack and provide to users.User accounts are added from the dcTrack Settings tab.Note: Only users with the system administrator role can change user names in the user accounts settings page. Allother users can only view user names and do not have access to change their own user name in their user profile.1. From Settings > dcTrack Settings > Authorization & Authentication, click User Accounts. The User list pageopens displaying a list of all the user accounts created for the system.2. Choose Add > Add. A blank user information page opens.3. Enter the following required fields:Username - must be at least 3 characters, but no more than 255 charactersFirst NameLast NamePasswordConfirm Password4. You can optionally enter the following fields:EmailDescriptionMail ServerSMTP PortNo PasswordRequest Emails - Applicable only for user accounts with the Gatekeeper roleNote: As of dcTrack version 7.0.1 the User Name supplied when logging into dcTrack is no longer Case Sensitive.This applies to both Local and LDAP user accounts.

The following steps cover importing locations, verifying locations were imported, importing items and connections,verifying items and connections were imported, and uploading and syncing drawing files with locations.1. Import locations first if you have not already done so. Once locations exist in dcTrack, import items and con-nections.2. Begin a File Import by clicking the Import button in the dcTrack main tool bar3. Once you select the File Import option, the File Import dialog opens. Use Browse to locate the import file.As soon as you select the import file, the file is validated by dcTrack to ensure it is formatted correctly. All errorsencountered during file validation must be corrected before proceeding to 'Process Import'.4. If no validation errors are found or once corrected, click the green arrow on the right of the process bar to con-tinue to the Process Import step.Warning or errors are displayed, if found.As dcTrack imports your data, a progress bar is displayed at the bottom of the window.5. Once the import is complete, you can go on to view the newly added locations, begin another import session, orselect any option from the top menu bar to move to another activity.Any errors encountered during import are listed in the Results section of the File Import dialog, and all valid data areimported.Select "Save Results to File" to create a file containing only invalid data. You can then fix the issues and import thedata again.6. Locations appear in the Default Location drop-down, Location drop-down, on the Items List under Assets and soon.7. If you entered TRUE for "Enable Virtual Power Chain", ensure VPC is enabled by selecting Assets > Locationsin the Web Client.8. The VPC checkbox is selected for locations that are VPC enabled.If VPC is not enabled for a location, you can enable it from this page.9. If needed, integrate dcTrack with one or more Power IQs. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > ApplicationAdministration and open the Power IQ Integration Settings tab. You can then use File Import to sync integratedPower IQs. See Use File Import to Sync Integrated dcTrack and Power IQ.10. Next, import cabinets and items if you have not already done so.11. You can perform this step now or at a later time, but note that cabinets and items must exist in the data center inorder to sync drawing files. Otherwise, you must map or import them after syncing.12. Use File Import and follow the same steps that are outlined above.No readings are displayed in the widgets on the Web Client Dashboard until:Items that can send SNMP readings are added and configured to send them, and/or you are integrated withPower IQ.Items sending readings are powered on.This is also true on item pages once items are added.14. Import power and data connections once items are imported.15. You can perform this step now or at a later time.16. Use File Import and follow the same steps that are outlined above.17. To view newly added items or connections, click Refresh on the Items List or Circuits List page.Note: For items, filter the list by Origin = Import. You can also filter by Location so only imported items for the spe-cified location are displayed.18. Next, upload each location’s drawing file, if applicable.This is done in the Web Client using the Upload feature on the Floor Maps page.Upload each data center's drawing file separately.19. Click on the Visualization tab to open the Floor Maps page.20. From the Location drop-down, select the location you want to upload the drawing file to.21. Click Settings if the Upload icon is not displayed already.22. Click Upload, then use browse to locate and select the .DWG file.The upload time may vary depending on file size and network speed.Once the file has uploaded, a processing message is displayed while dcTrack processes and syncs the file.dcTrack syncs the objects in the drawing file with existing dcTrack items of the same name.Processing typically takes a few seconds, and does not require you to stay on the Floor Maps page.A message indicates when the file is being rendered. Click OK to close it or allow it to close on its own.A successful upload is indicated by the floor map appearing and a green checkmark icon at the top of the page.The floor map loads, and all synced cabinets are listed in the Items List on the left.23. Cabinets and items that are not synced during the drawing file upload must be synced using the Sync Button onthe Floormap tool bar.Items that are not sync'd will have a status value of "No Match" in the Item ListTo sync objects:24. Click the Sync button on the tool bar25. Select the unmatched item from the item list26. Click on the corresponding match in the Floor Map27. Click the Sync Selected Item in List and Drawing button

If Cooling units, UPS units, and floor PDUs exist on your floor map drawing file, they are added to dcTrack when youupload and sync the file with a site/location.Infrastructure items can be added in bulk as individual items. However, since each item is part of a power chain, theyare typically created at the same time.The items are created and configured in the Web Client Specifically:Each Cooling unit must be added to a Cooling Zone.Each UPS unit must be added to a UPS bankEither a busway or power panel must be configured for each floor PDUCreate the power outlet connectionsNote: Power outlet circuiting can be imported rather than manually created. See Import Power Outlet Circuiting.This topic walks your through each step to create your infrastructure power chain. You can find each step in indi-vidual topics as well.Steps to Add Cooling Units:1. Click Assets > New Item or click on the New Item icon on the Items List under Assets.2. Select the Cooling unit make and model.3. Assign a name to the Cooling unit.4. Select a location for the Cooling unit, if different from the one already selected in the Location drop-down.5. Enter following fields for Cooling Unit specifications.Sensible Capacity (Tons)Sensible Capacity (kW)Age Derated (Required)Airflow Rate (cfm)You can enter the value for Capacity (Tons) or Sensible Capacity (kw), dcTrack calculates the value for otherusing this formula Sensible Capacity (Tons) * 12,000 * 0.0002930711 = Sensible Capacity (kW).Age Derated field can be used to further reduce the Cooling Unit Capacity to the Cooling Unit's age. Age Deratedvalue should be between 0.1 and 100.Note : If the model selected have these values then items will inherit the model's value. Nominal Capacity valuesare the Nameplate value for the model.6. Next, go to configuration sub tab and add the Cooling unit to a Cooling Zone.7. You must add the Cooling unit to a Cooling Zone before you can mark the unit as Installed.8. To assign a Cooling unit to a Cooling Zone, select a Cooling Zone from the Unit Assignment to Zones and clickSave.9. If the Cooling Zone does not exist, create one and assign the Cooling unit to it. Cooling Zones are created in theAvailable Cooling Zones section of the page.10. Click Add a Zone.11. Enter Cooling Zone name.12. Click Save in the toolbar.You can also assign multiple Cooling Zones to a Cooling Unit. See here Cooling Zone.htmTo create the UPS, UPS Bank and Floor PDU power chain, follow the below steps:1. Create UPS Units2. Create a UPS Bank3. Create UPS Bank Load Devices4. Connect UPS Bank Load Devices to UPS Units5. Create Floor PDUs6. Connect Floor PDUs to UPS Bank Load DevicesNote: The configuration settings for the UPS and Power Panel can also be set via File Import

One or more UPS Units can be aggregated using the UPS Bank which in turn feeds one or more Floor PDUs. Eachpower chain in your data center may have one or more UPS Units.1. In the Assets tab > Item List, click the Add an Item button. A new Item page will open in a new dcTrack tab.2. In the New Item page, select the UPS Unit’s make and model.3. Assign a name to the UPS Unit.4. Select a location for the UPS Unit, if different from the one already selected in the Location dropdown.5. In the Configuration sub-tab enter the following information:a. Rating (kVA)b. Rating (kW)c. Rating (Vac)d. Output Wiring6. Save the UPS item.7. Repeat for any additional UPS Unit items.You will need a UPS Bank for each power chain in your data center. Typically, data centers have 2 redundant powerchains. A UPS Bank is technically a Switchgear which in dcTrack is represented using the Class/Subclass AC Dis-tribution/Switch. Therefore, an AC Distribution/UPS Bank and AC Distribution/Switch electrically and functionally arethe same, but in dcTrack the UPS Bank is a special case of a switch since it is the switchgear that feeds from theUPS Units and distributes out to the Floor PDUs.1. In the Assets tab > Item List, click the Add an Item button. A new Item page will open in a new dcTrack tab.2. In the New Item page, select the UPS Bank’s make and model. You may use the Generic UPS Bank model.3. Assign a name to the UPS Bank.4. Select a location for the UPS Bank, if different from the one already selected in the Location dropdown.5. In the Configuration sub-tab enter the following information:a. Rating (A)b. Rating (Vac) - This should also match the Voltage of the UPS Units.c. Output WiringNote: The above 3 values are the specification of the Busbar that is inside the UPS Bank switchgear.d. Redundancy – this depends on the number of UPS Units that you will connected to the bank in Step 13below. You will want to update this value after connecting all the UPS units to this bank.e. Rating (kVA) and Rating (kW) are read-only. They are automatically calculated based on the numberof UPS Units that you will connect to the Bank in step 8 below and the Redundancy setting.6. Save the UPS Bank item.7. Repeat for any additional UPS Bank items.8. In the Switch Devices sub-tab of the UPS Bank, click the Create Switch Devices button and choose LoadDevice. You will repeat this step for as many UPS Units and Floor PDUs there are connecting from and to thisUPS Bank. A load device is the large breakers that are installed in the UPS Bank.a. Select the Make and Model for the Load Device.b. Give the Load Device a name. This name must be unique within the UPS Bank item only.c. Give the Load Device an optional number for easier reference within this UPS Bank.d. The Connector Type is inherited from the Model of the Load Device. If this remains blank, it is becausethe Load Device Model does not have the Connector Type set. You may want to create multiple LoadDevice models for each Connector Type you want to use. Each Connector Type displays it own sym-bol in the Single Line Diagram.e. Rating (Vac) is read-only and is inherited from the UPS Bank itself, which was selected in the Con-figuration sub-tab.f. Phase is read-only and is inherited from the UPS Bank itself. (It will show Three Phase Delta if theBank’s Output Wiring is 3-Wire + Ground, or Three Phase Wye if the Bank’s Output Wiring is 4-Wire +Ground.g. Rating (A) must be equal to or less than the Rating (A) of the UPS Bank.h. Derate 80%. Uncheck this box if the Load Device breaker is 100% rated.i. The remaining fields are optional.j. When the Rating (A) was filled in, you will notice a form appears to the right. This specifies how thisLoad Device connects internally within the UPS Bank switchgear.1. For a Load Device that feeds from the UPS Units select the following:1. Line Side:a. Connects to: Extb. Fed From: Select the UPS Unit’s Output.2. Load Side:a. Connects to: Bus A.2. For a Load Device that feeds to the Floor PDUs, select the following:1. Line Side:a. Connects to: Bus A2. Load Side:1. Connects to: Ext.Note: Bus B and Bus C are optional and would only be used when the Switchgear has more then one bus. Whenmultiple buses exist, a Load Device would connect them together. These 3 bus notations should not be confusedwith the 3 poles of a Three Phase circuit.k. Click Createl. Create all other Load Devices and select the appropriate selections at step j based on what this loaddevice will connect to.m. Save the UPS Bank Item.n. At this point, you should have a UPS Bank connected to the UPS Unit(s). If you go back to the UPS item(s) (Refresh it, if it was already open)and in the Configuration sub-tab, the UPS Output section should display the Bank name that this UPS Unitis part of and the total capacity of theUPS Bank. If this total is higher than expected, you may need to adjust the Bank’s Redundancy field.

1. In the Assets tab > Item List, click the Add an Item button. A new Item page will open in a new dcTrack tab.2. In the New Item page, select the floor PDU’s make and model.3. Assign a name to the floor PDU.4. Select a location for the floor PDU, if different from the one already selected in the Location dropdown.5. In the Configuration sub-tab enter the following information:a. Rating (kVA)b. Rating (A) – Should be a number that is close to the result of this formula: Rating (kVA) * 1000 / (Rating(Vac) * SQRT(3) * NEC Derating), where the Rating (Vac) is the voltage of the item feeding the FloorPDU and the NEC Derating is 80% for Data Centers in the United States.c. Class/Subclass: Select UPS Bank optiond. Fed From: Select the UPS Bank Load Device feeding this Floor PDU.If you do not have a UPS Bank created, you can also select VPC UPS Bank from the drop-down. ACVPC must be enabled for the location in order to view VPC UPS banks in the drop-down. See Enableor Disable VPC for a Location.e. The Rating (Vac) and Input Wiring will be automatically filled in based on the Fed From selection.f. Save the Floor PDU item.g. Repeat these steps for each additional Floor PDU.h. In the Power Panels sub-tab of each Floor PDU, create one or more power panels that are eitherinternal to the Floor PDU (Local), remotely placed panels or RPPs (Remote), or busway systems feed-ing from the Floor PDU (Busway). Click Create a panel and fill in all the required fields to create eachpanel accordingly to the panel specifications. Note that the panel name needs to be unique only withinthe Floor PDU.i. Click Create buttonj. Repeat for each additional panel for this Floor PDU.k. From the list of power panels in this sub-tab, you can click each panel name to open that panel andbegin adding breakers within the panel which would also include creating the Power Outlet items thatare fed from each of the breakers.1. Back on the Power Panels sub-tab, click on the desired power panel to view its Item Details page.2. In the Power – [x] Poles, [y] Breakers sub-tab, click the Bulk Edit button to edit the breakers. Alternatively, inthe Assets tab > Items List, click the Export button and select either of the following options:a. Download Import Template to download the import template as a CSV file.b. Export into an Import Template > Branch Circuit Breakers to download an import template populatedwith the panel and busway breakers as a CSV file.3. Open your CSV file.4. Follow the instructions in the CSV file to add breakers.5. In the Assets tab > File Import page, import the edited CSV file to create the breakers. This will also create theoutlets and connect the breakers to those outlets.

At this point, if you are planning on using File Import to create power outlet circuiting, note the following pre-requisites.Each floor PDU and its busways must be created in dcTrack before you can import power outlet circuiting.Each floor PDU's power panel and the power panel's poles and breakers must be created in dcTrack beforeyou can import power outlet circuiting.Important: At this point, if you are planning on using File Import to create power outlet circuiting, note the followingprerequisites -Busway Power Outlet PrerequisitesEach Floor PDU and its busways must be created in dcTrack before you can import power outlet cir-cuiting.The power outlets that were created cannot contain any ports, poles or breakers in dcTrack.Power Panel Outlet PrerequisitesEach floor PDU's power panel the power panel's poles and breakers must be created in dcTrack beforeyou can import power outlet circuiting.The power outlets that were created cannot contain any ports in dcTrack.You can now do one of the following based on your needs:Manually Configure a Floor PDU for Power Outlet Circuiting ImportsManually Configure a UPS Unit and Floor PDUs with BuswaysThe Cooling Zone items previously called CRAC groups will have its own item details page. Cooling Zone items arenow also listed in the Asset List.Steps to create Cooling Zone:1. In a Cooling Unit Item details page go to Configuration subtab.2. Click Add a Zone in Available Cooling Zone.3. Enter Zone Name4. Click Create.You can also create Cooling Zone by following the same steps as mentioned above in Cooling Zone item details.Location of a Cooling Zone is the Data Center location of the Cooling Units assigned to it.Note: Cooling Zone can have Cooling Units assigned with different capacities. Cooling Units that are in a floor orroom level can be assigned to any Cooling Zone in that Data Center Location.To View or Edit Cooling Zone items in item details page click View or Edit button in Available Cooling Zone. You canalso open Cooling Zone item details page from the Item List.Configuration Sub tab of the Cooling Zone have following fields which are editable.1. Compensation Factor - Accepts numeric values 1-200. Default is 100. This field is used to increase or reducethe overall calculated capacity of a Cooling Zone. For example, if the Compensation Factor is set 90 thenSensible Capacity (Tons) and Sensible Capacity (kW) will be 90% of the calculated value for the CoolingZone.2. Redundancy - This field is used to set the Redundancy for the Cooling Zone. The drop down options willdepend on the number of Cooling Units assigned to the Cooling Zone.Following fields are read-only and display Cooling Zone Capacity.1. Nominal (Tons) - Sum of Nominal (Tons) for all units in the Cooling Zone minus spare Cooling Units.2. Nominal (kW) - Sum of Nominal (kW) for all units in the Cooling Zone minus spare Cooling Units.Spare Units in the Cooling Zone are the largest X Cooling units in the Zone, where X is the number after + inthe Redundancy value.3. Sensible (Tons) - Sum of [Sensible (Tons) of each Cooling Unit in the Cooling Zone * Cooling Unit's Percentin Cooling Zone] * Compensation Factor (%) of Cooling Zone.4. Sensible (kW) - Sum of [Sensible (kW) of each Cooling Unit in the Cooling Zone * Cooling Unit's Percent inCooling Zone] * Compensation Factor (%) of Cooling Zone.5. Age Derated (Tons) - Sum of [Sensible (Tons) of each Cooling Unit in the Cooling Zone * Cooling Unit's Per-cent in Cooling Zone * Age Derating (%) ] * Compensation Factor (%) of Cooling Zone.6. Age Derate (kW) - Sum of [Sensible (kW) of each Cooling Unit in the Cooling Zone * Cooling Unit's Percent inCooling Zone * Age Derating (%) ] * Compensation Factor (%) of Cooling Zone.You can edit Cooling Zone standard and custom fields. However you can not edit Make, Model and Location field ofa Cooling Zone.Once you have created the Cooling Zone, you can assign Cooling Units to this Cooling Zone. To assign a CoolingUnit to a Cooling Zone, select the Cooling Unit in the Unit Assignment to Zone and save the item.

To assign one cooling unit to multiple cooling zones in the GUI:1. On the cooling unit's item detail's page, click Edit to enter edit mode.2. In the Configuration subtab, in the Unit Assigned to Zones list, click the plus icon to add a zone.3. Click the trashcan icon to remove a zone.4. The zone percentages must add up to less than 100%. If greater, the Save button is disabled.5. All percentage fields are highlighted in green when they add up to 100%.6. If you add a new cooling zone row , but do not select the cooling zone, you can save the item, but if you closeand return to the item, the added and unassigned cooling zone row will not be retained, because it was neverassigned to a zone.7. You can add up to 6 zone assignments for one cooling unit.Audit Trail will have a record of Cooling Zone assignment and the percent in zone for each Cooling Zone.To assign one cooling unit to multiple cooling zones via CSV import:If you uses the ADD operation with the COOLING UNIT object and included the Cooling Zone column with a value,this will assign the new unit to the specified zone at 100%.The ASSIGN operation can also be used with the COOLING UNIT object, but requires the following columns:NameLocationCooling ZonePercent in ZoneThe assignment percentage is set to the value specified in Percent in Zone. If this assignment brings the total for thisCooling unit over 100. An import error is returned for this row: "Assignment causes Percent In Zone for this unit toexceed 100% for all assigned zones"1. Select the Cooling Zone item from Asset list and click the Delete icon. You can also delete the Cooling Zonefrom its item details page.2. Before deleting a Cooling Zone, make sure all the Cooling Units are unassigned from the Cooling Zone.

dcTrack version 7.1.0 introduced support for Power Supplies on Cooling Units. Both the Models Library and ItemDetails page contain a Power Supply sub tab for setting and updating Power Supply Ports.Steps to manage Power Supply Ports for Cooling Unit Models or Items:1. Navigate to the Detail Page of either the Model or Item2. Click on the Power Supply Subtab3. The Port Name Prefix is defaulted to "PS" but can be changed4. Enter the Quantity of Ports you want to create. (You may create up to 98 Ports)5. Upon entering the Quantity, the requested number of Ports are created in the grid6. Enter the Redundancy7. Supply the required Connector, Phase Type, Volts, Power Factor, Watts(N), and Watts(B)8. Supply any additional optional field data9. Click the Save button to save the dataAfter creating the Power Supply Ports, the Cooling Unit can be connected to either a Rack PDU or Power Outlet.

Create the items in the power chain that the busway or power panel will connect to.Note: When creating certain items, there is information that must be entered in order to connect one item to anotheritem in the power chain. However, these fields may not be indicated as *required in the dcTrack interface. This isbecause they are 'technically' not required to create the item in the dcTrack database. For example, in order to com-plete the busway, you must enter the floor PDU's specification information even though those are not requiredfields to create the floor PDU.If a field is required to complete the busway creation process, it is identified in the steps that follow as "Required".Create your power chain and busway:1. Click Assets.2. Click the New Item icon.3. Select the Make and Model of the UPS unit.4. Enter a name for the UPS unit.5. Select the Location of the UPS unit (if different from the default).6. Enter the UPS unit's specification information.7. Select/Add the UPS bank on the Configuration sub tab based on the specifications8. Enter additional information if needed, then click Save. The item's tab turns green.9. In the Web Client, click the New Item icon.10. Select the Make and Model for the floor PDU.11. Enter a name for the floor PDU.12. Verify the floor PDU location.13. Enter the floor PDU specifications. Required14. Enter the floor PDU input information. Required15. Important: At this point, if you are planning on using the File Import to create power outlet circuiting, review theprerequisites for adding a busway or power panel.16. Each floor PDU's power panel the power panel's poles and breakers are created in dcTrack.17. The power outlets are created and do not contain any ports in dcTrack18. Busway Power Outlets -19. Each Floor PDU and its busways are created in dcTrack20. The power outlets are created and do not contain any ports, poles or breakers in dcTrack.Note: These steps DO NOT involve configuring floor PDUs for use with imported power outlet circuiting function.See Manually Configure a Floor PDU for Power Outlet Circuiting Imports.Prior to adding and configuring a busway or power panel, create the items in the power chain it connects to.Note: When creating certain items, there is information that must be entered in order to connect the item to anotheritem in the power chain. However, these fields may not be indicated as *required in the dcTrack interface. This isbecause they are 'technically' not required to create the item in the dcTrack database. For example, in order to com-plete the busway, you must enter the floor PDU's specification information even though those are not requiredfields to create the floor PDU.If a field is required to complete the busway creation process, it is identified in the steps that follow as "Required".

To create the UPS, UPS Bank and Floor PDU power chain, follow the below steps:1. Create UPS Units2. Create a UPS Bank3. Create UPS Bank Load Devices4. Connect UPS Bank Load Devices to UPS Units5. Create Floor PDUs6. Connect Floor PDUs to UPS Bank Load DevicesNote: The configuration settings for the UPS and Power Panel can also be set via File ImportOne or more UPS Units can be aggregated using the UPS Bank which in turn feeds one or more Floor PDUs. Eachpower chain in your data center may have one or more UPS Units.1. In the Assets tab > Item List, click the Add an Item button. A new Item page will open in a new dcTrack tab.2. In the New Item page, select the UPS Unit’s make and model.3. Assign a name to the UPS Unit.4. Select a location for the UPS Unit, if different from the one already selected in the Location dropdown.5. In the Configuration sub-tab enter the following information:a. Rating (kVA)b. Rating (kW)c. Rating (Vac)d. Output Wiring6. Save the UPS item.7. Repeat for any additional UPS Unit items.

You will need a UPS Bank for each power chain in your data center. Typically, data centers have 2 redundant powerchains. A UPS Bank is technically a Switchgear which in dcTrack is represented using the Class/Subclass AC Dis-tribution/Switch. Therefore, an AC Distribution/UPS Bank and AC Distribution/Switch electrically and functionally arethe same, but in dcTrack the UPS Bank is a special case of a switch since it is the switchgear that feeds from theUPS Units and distributes out to the Floor PDUs.1. In the Assets tab > Item List, click the Add an Item button. A new Item page will open in a new dcTrack tab.2. In the New Item page, select the UPS Bank’s make and model. You may use the Generic UPS Bank model.3. Assign a name to the UPS Bank.4. Select a location for the UPS Bank, if different from the one already selected in the Location dropdown.5. In the Configuration sub-tab enter the following information:a. Rating (A)b. Rating (Vac) - This should also match the Voltage of the UPS Units.c. Output WiringNote: The above 3 values are the specification of the Busbar that is inside the UPS Bank switchgear.d. Redundancy – this depends on the number of UPS Units that you will connected to the bank in Step 13below. You will want to update this value after connecting all the UPS units to this bank.e. Rating (kVA) and Rating (kW) are read-only. They are automatically calculated based on the numberof UPS Units that you will connect to the Bank in step 8 below and the Redundancy setting.6. Save the UPS Bank item.7. Repeat for any additional UPS Bank items.8. In the Switch Devices sub-tab of the UPS Bank, click the Create Switch Devices button and choose LoadDevice. You will repeat this step for as many UPS Units and Floor PDUs there are connecting from and to thisUPS Bank. A load device is the large breakers that are installed in the UPS Bank.a. Select the Make and Model for the Load Device.b. Give the Load Device a name. This name must be unique within the UPS Bank item only.c. Give the Load Device an optional number for easier reference within this UPS Bank.d. The Connector Type is inherited from the Model of the Load Device. If this remains blank, it is becausethe Load Device Model does not have the Connector Type set. You may want to create multiple LoadDevice models for each Connector Type you want to use. Each Connector Type displays it own sym-bol in the Single Line Diagram.e. Rating (Vac) is read-only and is inherited from the UPS Bank itself, which was selected in the Con-figuration sub-tab.f. Phase is read-only and is inherited from the UPS Bank itself. (It will show Three Phase Delta if theBank’s Output Wiring is 3-Wire + Ground, or Three Phase Wye if the Bank’s Output Wiring is 4-Wire +Ground.g. Rating (A) must be equal to or less than the Rating (A) of the UPS Bank.h. Derate 80%. Uncheck this box if the Load Device breaker is 100% rated.i. The remaining fields are optional.j. When the Rating (A) was filled in, you will notice a form appears to the right. This specifies how thisLoad Device connects internally within the UPS Bank switchgear.1. For a Load Device that feeds from the UPS Units select the following:1. Line Side:a. Connects to: Extb. Fed From: Select the UPS Unit’s Output.2. Load Side:a. Connects to: Bus A.2. For a Load Device that feeds to the Floor PDUs, select the following:1. Line Side:a. Connects to: Bus A2. Load Side:1. Connects to: Ext.Note: Bus B and Bus C are optional and would only be used when the Switchgear has more then one bus. Whenmultiple buses exist, a Load Device would connect them together. These 3 bus notations should not be confusedwith the 3 poles of a Three Phase circuit.k. Click Createl. Create all other Load Devices and select the appropriate selections at step j based on what this loaddevice will connect to.m. Save the UPS Bank Item.n. At this point, you should have a UPS Bank connected to the UPS Unit(s). If you go back to the UPS item(s) (Refresh it, if it was already open)and in the Configuration sub-tab, the UPS Output section should display the Bank name that this UPS Unitis part of and the total capacity of theUPS Bank. If this total is higher than expected, you may need to adjust the Bank’s Redundancy field.1. In the Assets tab > Item List, click the Add an Item button. A new Item page will open in a new dcTrack tab.2. In the New Item page, select the floor PDU’s make and model.3. Assign a name to the floor PDU.4. Select a location for the floor PDU, if different from the one already selected in the Location dropdown.5. In the Configuration sub-tab enter the following information:a. Rating (kVA)b. Rating (A) – Should be a number that is close to the result of this formula: Rating (kVA) * 1000 / (Rating(Vac) * SQRT(3) * NEC Derating), where the Rating (Vac) is the voltage of the item feeding the FloorPDU and the NEC Derating is 80% for Data Centers in the United States.c. Class/Subclass: Select UPS Bank optiond. Fed From: Select the UPS Bank Load Device feeding this Floor PDU.If you do not have a UPS Bank created, you can also select VPC UPS Bank from the drop-down. ACVPC must be enabled for the location in order to view VPC UPS banks in the drop-down. See Enableor Disable VPC for a Location.e. The Rating (Vac) and Input Wiring will be automatically filled in based on the Fed From selection.f. Save the Floor PDU item.g. Repeat these steps for each additional Floor PDU.h. In the Power Panels sub-tab of each Floor PDU, create one or more power panels that are eitherinternal to the Floor PDU (Local), remotely placed panels or RPPs (Remote), or busway systems feed-ing from the Floor PDU (Busway). Click Create a panel and fill in all the required fields to create eachpanel accordingly to the panel specifications. Note that the panel name needs to be unique only withinthe Floor PDU.i. Click Create buttonj. Repeat for each additional panel for this Floor PDU.k. From the list of power panels in this sub-tab, you can click each panel name to open that panel andbegin adding breakers within the panel which would also include creating the Power Outlet items thatare fed from each of the breakers.

1. Back on the Power Panels sub-tab, click on the desired power panel to view its Item Details page.2. In the Power – [x] Poles, [y] Breakers sub-tab, click the Bulk Edit button to edit the breakers. Alternatively, inthe Assets tab > Items List, click the Export button and select either of the following options:a. Download Import Template to download the import template as a CSV file.b. Export into an Import Template > Branch Circuit Breakers to download an import template populatedwith the panel and busway breakers as a CSV file.3. Open your CSV file.4. Follow the instructions in the CSV file to add breakers.5. In the Assets tab > File Import page, import the edited CSV file to create the breakers. This will also create theoutlets and connect the breakers to those outlets.At this point, if you are planning on using File Import to create power outlet circuiting, note the following pre-requisites.Each floor PDU and its busways must be created in dcTrack before you can import power outlet circuiting.Each floor PDU's power panel and the power panel's poles and breakers must be created in dcTrack beforeyou can import power outlet circuiting.

Creating your busway can be completely entirely in the Web Client. The steps that follow tell you when to do so.1. In the Web Client, click the New Item icon.2. Enter the busway Make and Model.3. Select a Busway subclass model. Required4. Enter a name for the outlet in the Item Name field.5. Update the location and any additional information, if needed.6. Click Save.7. In the Web Client, click the New Item icon.8. Enter the power outlet information. Required9. Select a cabinet and position for the outlet. Required10. Click Save on the outlet's page.11. In the Web Client, click Clone on the outlet's item page.12. Enter the number of cloned outlets for the busway you are creating - do not create ports for another busway.13. In the Clone dialog, clone only the following:a. Child itemsb. Parent-child associationsc. Power portsd. Custom fields (if applicable)14. Click Clone.When creating a data panel port:• The data port can connect to another data port on the same data panel.• The far end of the connection can be in another site• A data port connection can go directly to an existing network item within the same or a different site.

Before you can import data and power connections into dcTrack, the items used in the connections must exist. So,import your rack PDUs, devices and so on. Add or configure ports on devices if needed. Note that you can manuallyadd your items instead of importing them.You must also create your power infrastructure in dcTrack. This means adding Cooling units and then adding theCooling Units to Cooling Zones, adding UPS units and adding UPS units to UPS banks, and creating your floorPDUs, breakers, poles, busways and so on. See Add and Configure Power Infrastructure Items - Cooling Units,UPS Units and Floor PDUs.

Use the Create Power Connections worksheet in the Import Template to create power connections and import theminto dcTrack.The connections between all of the items in a power chain form a complete circuit.'Power connections' refers a connection between a starting item, such as a server or switch, and an ending item thatis either a rack PDU or outlet.It is important to designate the item's power supply port as the starting point, and the power outlet's input power portor rack PDU's input power port, as the ending item.Once connected, these form the first half of a power circuit.The remaining portion of the circuit is the upstream power connection to the power source, which consist of the floorPDU, power panel or busway, and UPS unit.These connections already exist in dcTrack. They are created when you create your structured cabling.Note: You can use the File Import to import power outlet circuiting. This eliminates having to manually create cir-cuits from power outlets to either busways or power panels on existing floor PDUs.Alternatively, you can connect items to virtual power chains if you are not ready to create 'normal' power circuits.Connect items to virtual power chains manually, or import virtual power chain connections in bulk using the FileImport.You cannot use a single file that includes a variety of hop quantities for each circuit. Make one file for all circuits thatuse no cabling hops, one file for those that have only one hop, one file for those with 2 hops and one file for thosewith 3 hops.For a list of the requirements and/or prerequisites, as well as recommendations and examples of spreadsheets, seethe worksheets in the templates.Importing power connections follows the same basic steps using the File Import as other imports.(Optional) Verify the circuits are imported by looking them up. Use the search and filter options on the Circuits List inthe Web Client.You can submit Connect Requests for one or more circuits now or at a later time. Submit a request in the Web Clientfrom the Actions menu on the Circuits List.See Submit Circuit Requests from the Actions Menu.
Your structured cabling layout must already exist in dcTrack before importing connections.

Use the Create Data Connections worksheet in the Import Template to create data connections and import them intodcTrack.Data circuits can consist of up to eight end points:1 end point at the beginning of the circuit ~ 1 end point at the end of the circuit with up to 3 hops in between, eachconsisting of 2 end points.A spreadsheet file cannot include circuits that have a different number of hops. So, create individual import files for:Circuits with no cabling hopsCircuits with 1 hopCircuits with 2 hopsCircuits with 3 hops

Watch a video on how to use file import template on the Support Portal.This topic outlines how to create a file that will import Virtual Power Chain connections. For detailed steps on usingthe File Import feature, see Use File Import to Add, Edit Delete and Move.System Administrators and Gatekeepers can also add VPCs manually in the Web Client. For details on File Import,see Manually Create Virtual Power Chain Connections.The Virtual Power Chains created from the spreadsheet are made up of connections between existing dcTrackitems and virtual items in the Virtual Power Chain.Therefore, the items that will be connected to the Virtual Power Chain connections must exist in dcTrack. Using FileImport to add the items or add them manually. See Use File Import to Add, Edit Delete and Move and Add andEdit Items.Virtual Power Chain must be enabled for the location(s). You can enable VPC when adding locations manually orwhen importing locations using File Import by setting the Enable Virtual Power Chain field to TRUE in the ImportTemplate. See Enable or Disable VPC for a Location and Use File Import to Add, Edit Delete and Move, respect-ively.Note that you do not need to create the items that make up the Virtual Power Chain; these Virtual Power Chainitems exist by default.Dashboards can be accessed via the Dashboard tab in the main navigational menu of the dcTrack Web Client.Dashboards are divided into the following categories, with a corresponding folder accessible from the left panel ofthe Dashboard tab:Standard: Each standard dashboard page represents one category of common Key Performance Indicators(KPIs). The pre-configured widgets on each dashboard page align with the metrics most relevant to thatspecific category.Personal: These dashboard pages are created, edited, and deleted by each user from a combination of stand-ard, SQL, HTML, and custom widgets.Shared: Users can share a dashboard they have created to make the dashboard public. Shared dashboardsare read-only for all other users.Favorites: Each user has their own folder of favorite dashboards. These can be any standard, personal, orshared public dashboard; however, these dashboards are read-only for all users.Widgets are the building blocks of your dashboard and are prepopulated on dashboard pages. Each widget displaysdata on a specific KPI or metric, with some widgets having additional dropdown selectors to filter the data for addi-tional granularity.In addition to preconfigured widgets, customizable widgets also are available. These include chart widgets, SQL gridwidgets, and HTML widgets.

A user with the System Administrator role or a globally defined Gatekeeper or Operator role can do the following:View all dashboard pagesMove and resize widgetsAdd, edit, or delete any widgets, including custom widgets but excluding default chart widgetsOnly a user with System Administrator role can upload widgetsA user with the System Administrator or a globally defined Gatekeeper role also can set the permissions for SQLgrid widgets.All other users can view all standard dashboard pages; however, they may not have permissions to view the data fora specific widget. In this case, the widget will display a message indicating that the user does not have permissionsto view the data.Personal DashboardsCan only be viewed by the user who created them.Shared DashboardsCan be viewed by all other users, with the exception of data that they do not have permission to view. Other userscannot edit shared dashboards.Favorited dashboardsCan be any standard, personal, or shared public dashboard and are read-only to all users.Hidden DashboardsWhen logged with a System Administrator or Gatekeeper role a new Standard folder dashboard will appear as thelast dashboard called "Hidden".Users with sufficient permissions can move widgets in and out of this dashboard like they do for any other dash-board.When logged in as a user that doesn't have sufficient permissions, any dashboard marked as hidden will not beshown in the UI.When any dashboard page in any folder is empty (i.e. does not have any widgets, because they have been movedout of that page), that dashboard will not be displayed.Users with sufficient permissions will continue to see empty dashboards so that they are able to move widget backinto themFor any user, when a folder has no dashboards, that folder would not be displayed.Example:The user has not favorited any dashboards, therefore, the Favorite folder will not be displayed.However, if the user does favorite a dashboard, the Favorite folder will appear and will contain the dashboard thatwas favorited.Note: Dashboards contain no data when no items have been added to dcTrack or when dcTrack has not been con-figured.The left navigational menu of the Dashboard tab provides one-click access to each dashboard page. The menu canbe collapsed to provide additional on-screen space or can be expanded to display the labels and icons for eachpage. Each dashboard page represents one category of common Key Performance Indicators (KPIs). The pre-con-figured widgets on each dashboard page align with the metrics most relevant to that specific category.Excluding the Enterprise Overview, Enterprise Health, and custom dashboard pages, each dashboard page has alocation selector dropdown that allows you to define the location that you want data for.All of the widgets on a dashboard page that support a Location filter will reflect changes in this selector. Location fil-tering applies to the Data Center, Floor, or Room hierarchy levels that contain assets. When a widget that supportslocation filtering is moved to a page without a Location selector in the toolbar, the widget will display its own locationselector. When a widget that does not support a location filter is moved to a page with a location selector in the tool-bar, this widget will not reflect changes in the location selector.The table below summaries the available dashboard pages:Enterprise Over-Dashboard with widgets that display data on all data centers inNoviewyour enterpriseEnterpriseDashboard with tile widgets that display color-coded warningNoHealthand critical health event data for locations in your enterpriseDashboards with widgets that display the impact of changes on aWhat-If Noproject and sub-location basisDashboard with widgets that display data on the assets for a spe-Inventory Yescific locationDashboard with widgets that display space capacity data for aSpace Yesspecific locationDashboard with widgets that display power capacity data for aPower Yesspecific locationDashboard with widgets that display environmental data, includ-Cooling Yesing temperature and humidity, for a specific locationDashboard with widgets that display data on the connections forConnectivity Yesa specific locationDashboard with widgets that display data on the moves, adds,Change Yesand changes for a specific locationData Reports Dashboard with widgets that display data in tabular form YesDashboard with widgets designed to measure compliance withDCOI Nothe Data Center Optimization Initiative (DCOI) mandateCustom Dashboard with custom SQL or HTML widgets NoNote: If you navigate away from the Dashboard tab, it will load the previous dashboard page upon your return.For additional information please see the videos atDashboards in 6 Minutes

Users can create, edit, and delete dashboard pages. Newly created dashboards are added to the Personal dash-board folder.1. In the Dashboard tab, click the Add a Dashboard button. The Add a New Dashboard popup displays.2. In the Add a New Dashboard popup, provide the following information:a. Dashboard Name: The name of the dashboard. Required.b. Dashboard Icon: This is the icon that will display next to the dashboard name in the Dashboard side-bar. Required.3. In the widget grid, select the widgets that you want to add to your dashboard.4. Click the Create icon to create your dashboard.

1. In the Dashboard tab, click the Manage Dashboards icon. The Manage Dashboards popup box will display.2. In the left Dashboards panel, select the Dashboard that you want to edit. Once selected, the DashboardDetails panel on the right of the pop up will populate with the selected dashboard's details.3. In the Dashboard Details panel, make your desired edits.4. Click the Save button to save your changes.1. In the Dashboard tab, click the Manage Dashboards icon. The Manage Dashboards popup box will display.2. In the left Dashboards panel, select the Dashboard that you want to delete.3. Click the Delete icon. A confirmation popup will display.4. In the confirmation popup, click the Yes button to confirm the deletion.For additional and updated information please see the video atHow to Create and Manage Personal Dashboards

With any standard widget, you can drill down to the raw data that drives the chart. This feature is useful if you want toview, search or export the raw data for just a single chart in a tabular format.To access the drill-down view of a specific chart, click the drilldown icon on the chart.The drill-down view provides a summary of the data, the original graphical chart, and the raw data in a widget similarto the SQL grid widget with a donut chart, so you can sort and filter the data as needed. You can also export the datato CSV or PDF.The six squares in the top left corner provide a summary of the salient metrics for the chart. The Sum, Average, Min-imum and Maximum, and Minimum Difference and Maximum Difference are shown for Bar Charts, while the Trend,Average, Minimum, Maximum, Minimum Change and Maximum Change are shown for a Line Chart.Hover over the Average, Maximum, or Minimum value boxes in the drilldown view of any dashboard widget to dis-play a red line indicating the respective value on the chart for faster analysis.For Multi-bar and multi-line charts, the summary is calculated on the sum of the bars within a group or the sum of alllines.Next to the summary is the original chart. Note that you can still filter the data in the chart.At the bottom in the Details Grid widget, you'll find the raw data. Click the Filters icon on the right to filter the data andto show and hide columns.The Details grid widget supports the following functions for each column by clicking the downward chevron next toeach column’s title:Sort Ascending/DescendingHide ColumnCopy to clipboardGroup by the column, and then you can use the aggregate function on another column.Aggregate functions to do a count or find the minimum or maximum value and to calculate the sum or aver-age, select the Agg: Remove option to clear the aggregate functionPin to the left or rightThe three-dots configuration icon enables you to configure the grid by hiding/showing columns.The drill-down view of every dashboard widget includes a doughnut chart of the data displayed in the Details Grid.This data can be grouped by make, class, status, and other attributes. It can also be aggregated by Average, Count,Maximum, Minimum, and Sum.To export the data to CSV or PDF, click the Export icon in the upper right corner of the Details grid widget and selectthe appropriate option.The PDF report will be produced according to the current view of the grid with filtering, sorting, and grouping.To share the drill down view of the widget, click the Share Link icon, and then copy and paste the shareable link intothe application of your choice.To return to the dashboard, click the Back to Dashboard button.Note: On Stranded Power widgets on the Power Dashboard, you may notice that the drilldown view shows only onebar for stranded power and that the widget reverts back to the default sub-location parameter selection. This is bydesign to ensure that the data is accurate and useful, without meaninglessly aggregating the data. As strandedpower is the main focus of the widget, the chart drilldown view focuses on just that.

Excluding the Enterprise Overview, Enterprise Health, and custom dashboard pages, each Standard dashboardpage has a location selector dropdown that allows you to define the location that you want data for.When you select a new location, the widgets will refresh automatically with the data for the location you have selec-ted.If there is no data for a widget for the new location, the widget will display an error.To add a location selector to a Personal dashboard, check the Includes Location Selector checkbox under the Dash-board Details panel in the Manage Dashboards popup.Note: You will only be able to select the locations and to see the data that you have the appropriate permissions for.

You can refresh either the entire dashboard page or a specific widget to update and see the latest data.To refresh the entire dashboard page, click the Refresh icon in the toolbar.To refresh an individual widget, click the Refresh icon in the upper-right corner of the widget.Note: This icon is normally hidden until hovering over any part of the widget.You can also set the Refresh time for the widget through the Widget Settings.1. Click the Widget Settings (hamburger) icon in the upper right corner of the widget.2. Select the Widget Settings option. The Widget Settings pop up box will display.3. In the Widget Settings pop up, type in the desired Refresh duration in seconds. The minimum number ofseconds is 300.4. Click the Save and Close icon to save your changes and return to the dashboard.The widgets on each dashboard page can be reordered and resized for more effective data analysis and to give youmore control over how you use the space on each dashboard.While resizing a widget, a green shadow indicates the new placement or size of the widget that will result when themouse button is released.To move or reorder a widget, hover your cursor over the widget’s title area, then click and drag the widget to thedesired area of your current dashboard page.To resize a widget, hover your cursor over any edge or corner then drag the widget to your desired size. The widgetlayout is designed so that no blank space is allowed above a widget, but it is allowed to the left or to the right of a wid-get.You can also zoom on a widget by temporarily maximizing it. To maximize a widget, either double-click the title areaor click the Actions menu for the widget and selecting Maximize. To restore the widget to its original size, double-click the title area again or click the Actions menu and select Restore. This action is not saved and is allowed for allusers regardless of their roles.Other widgets on the dashboard will shift and resize to accommodate the new size or location. While a widget is max-imized, it is not possible to move or resize other widgets.

You can set a dashboard page to open by default when you access the Dashboard tab.To make the dashboard page your default:1. In the Dashboard tab, click the Manage Dashboards icon.2. In the Manage Dashboards dialog pop up, in the left Dashboards panel, select the dashboard that you want tomake your default. Once selected, the Dashboard Details panel on the right of the pop up will populate withthe selected dashboard's details.3. In the Dashboard Details panel, check the checkbox next to the Default field to make the dashboard yourdefault.4. Click the Save icon to save your changes.You can set any dashboard page as a favorite to add it to your Favorites folder in the Dashboard side panel.To share/unshare a dashboard page:1. In the Dashboard tab, navigate to the dashboard you want to favorite.2. Click the Favorite icon in the Dashboard toolbar. When the dashboard is shared, the Favorite icon text willchange to Remove Favorite.3. Click the Remove Favorite icon to remove the dashboard from your Favorites folder.Personal dashboard pages in the Favorites folder will have the owner's (creator's) username appended to the pagename in parentheses.Note: Since Favorite dashboards accessed from the Favorite folder are read only, to edit a Favorite dashboard thatyou created, you need to select it within your Personal folder.

You can search for a dashboard page by typing its name in the search box at the top of the Dashboard tab sidepanel.Simply type in a few letters from the dashboard page name into the search box, and any page containing those let-ters in order will be displayed in the side panel. All dashboards that do not match and any folders with no matchingdashboards will be hidden.To cancel the search, delete the text in the search box or click the Cancel (X) icon in the search box.You can modify the order in which dashboard pages are listed in the Personal and Favorite folders. The order is spe-cific to each user and will not affect how other users see the same dashboard pages.The order can be changed in Personal and Favorite folders that contain more than one dashboard.To modify the order of your dashboard pages within a Personal or Favorites folder:1. In the Dashboard tab, click the Manage Dashboards icon.2. In the Manage Dashboards dialog pop up, in the left Dashboards panel, select the Folder whose order youwant to edit.3. In the left Dashboards panel, drag and drop the dashboards to change their order.4. Click the Save button to save your changes.

You can share a Personal dashboard to make it publicly viewable and read only by other users.To share a dashboard page:1. In the Dashboard tab, navigate to the dashboard you want to share.2. Click the icon with the tool tip Add to Shared Folder in the Dashboard toolbar. Your personal dashboard pageis added to Shared folder.Dashboard pages in the Shared folder will have the owner's (creator's) username appended to the page name in par-entheses.To remove from shared folder click the same icon and it will remove your personal dashboard page from the Sharedfolder. You need to be in Personal folder to remove your dashboard page from the Shared folder.Note: Since Shared dashboards accessed from the Shared folder are read only, to edit a Shared dashboard thatyou created, you need to select it within your Personal folder.Whether printing a Dashboard page, an individual Widget or the detail behind a Widget, you can choose to use a cus-tomized logo in the header of the report. To assign a customized logo navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings >Application Administration > Display & Local and upload the image you want to use. For more information on assign-ing a custom logo please refer to Configure Display Settings.To print a Dashboard page click the Print button in the Dashboard tool bar while the page is displayed.To print an individual Widget, click the hamburger icon of the widget and select print from the menu.To print the detail of a widget drill down into the widget and click the download icon and select your print option fromthe menu.Your logo will appear in the upper right corner of each report.Ex. Printing a Dashboard PageEx. Print an Individual WidgetEx. Print an Widget DetailNote: Some users may experience difficulty with widgets printing over page breaks when printing a dashboard. Toavoid this issue, adjust your dashboard layout to a 3x3 grid (so your widgets are three rows tall and you can fit threestacked widgets per page), and then print your dashboard in landscape orientation. To figure out how to make a wid-get three rows tall, resize your widget to the smallest height then drag your mouse to expand it one row taller.Another way to adjust the layout is to resize your browser to a width of about 1300 pixels.For additional information please see the video atHow to Print Dashboards and Project to Slide Show

You are able to add three types of new widgets through the Dashboard toolbar to Standard or Personal dashboardpages: SQL widgets, Health Tile widgets, and Chart widgets. For more information on these widget types, see Cus-tom Widgets.When adding new widgets, dcTrack allows you to add a SQL or Health Tile widgets directly to both Standard andPersonal Dashboards. Chart widgets however, can only be uploaded to Standard Dashboards. To place a widget ona Personal Dashboard, you must copy the widget from an existing Standard Dashboard. For example, if you want toupload a new widget to add to your personal Dashboard, first you would download the widget to a Standard Dash-board and then copy it to your Personal Dashboard.To add a new SQL, or Chart Widget to a Standard dashboard:1. Navigate to the Standard dashboard page where you want to add the widget.2. Click the Add a Widget icon in the Dashboard tab menu.3. Select the desired widget type from the Add a Widget dropdown.a. If you are adding a SQL Grid Widget, select SQL Grid from the dropdownProvide a Name for your widget and the SQL query to return the data you are looking for.b. To upload a new Chart widget, select the Upload Chart Widget option. From the dialog box, nav-igate to the directory where your widget resides, select it and click upload.c.

You can also copy a widget from a Standard dashboard page to a Personal Dashboard page.1. Navigate to the Widget you wish to copy and click the Actions icon in the top right corner of the widget (threehorizontal lines)2. Select the Copy option from the menu and provide the number of copies you would like and the PersonalDashboard you wish to copy to3. Your selected widget will be added to your Personal DashboardYou can also choose to copy Widgets directly from your Personal Dashboard.1. Navigate to the Personal Dashboard you wish to copy to2. Select the Copy Widgets option from the drop down menu3. Select the Widgets you wish to copy from the dialog and click Copy4. Your selected Widgets will be copied to your DashboardYou can edit the settings of each widget by through the Actions menu > Widget Settings popup.1. Click the Actions menu > Widget Settings for the widget you want to edit.2. In the Widget Settings popup, make your desired changes.3. Click the Save button to save your changes.Editable widget settings include the following:TitleCaptionChart typeChart type specific settingsRefresh rate (seconds)X-axis settingsLeft Y-axis settingsRight Y-axis settings

Additionally, each SQL Grid, and HTML widget can be configured or edited by clicking the Actions icon and selectingWidget settings.For SQL Grid and HTML widgets, you can edit the widget title and the code, and then click the Save button to saveyour changes. Additionally, the SQL Grid widget allows for the setting of a Refresh Interval. Enter a number ofseconds for the widget to automatically refresh. Enter 0 to disable automatic refresh. You will still be able to click thewidget’s refresh button to manually refresh it.After confirmation, the widget will refresh.Some of the widgets include additional dropdown sub-menus (parameters) that allow you to filter the data or toprovide additional granularity.Click the dropdown in a specific widget to select the parameter value.These parameter values may be defined by default in dcTrack or customized to your organization.When a parameter is changed, the widget will automatically update with the data for the new parameter value.To save a particular parameter value as the default selection, click the Actions menu > Save Parameters in the wid-get.

You can modify chart type for any chart or gauge widget through the Widget Settings.To modify the chart type:1. In the Dashboard tab, click the Actions menu > Widget Settings for the widget whose chart type you want toedit. The Widget Settings popup will display.2. In the Widget Settings popup, in the Chart Type field, select the desired chart.3. Click the Save button to save your changes.To print a widget, click the Actions menu for the widget and select Print Widget. The print dialog will open, with thepreview displaying a printer-friendly version of the widget.Note: The widget can also be printed or saved to PDF using this method.

Widgets can be saved as images for use in presentations or other content outside of dcTrack.To save a widget as an image, click the Actions menu for the widget and select Save As Image.Note: The resulting image does not include the widget’s title. However, you can name the image file the same nameas the widget.Note: Saving a widget as an image file is not supported by Internet Explorer. To save the widget as an image filesuccessfully, please use another supported browser, such as Google Chrome.Widgets on Standard and Personal dashboards can be moved to other Dashboards within the same folder by click-ing the Actions ico, selecting the Move Widget to option from the dropdown, and specifying which dashboard page tomove the widget to from the list.After the dashboard is selected, the widget will be moved to the last position on the new dashboard.

Custom, SQL, and HTML widgets as well as all widgets on Personal dashboards can be deleted by clicking theActions icon and selecting Delete Widget from the dropdown.You will be asked to confirm the deletion.After confirmation, the dashboard page will refresh with the widget deleted.Note: Only custom widgets can be deleted.Each widget includes a caption or description explaining the presentation of the data in the chart.To display the caption, click, the information icon in the upper right corner of the widget. The caption displays at thebottom of the widget..To hide the caption, click anywhere on the caption or click, the information icon in the upper right corner of the wid-get.

dcTrack allows you to copy existing widgets to any existing Personal Dashboard page. Widgets can be copied mul-tiple times in a single step.Steps to Copy a Widget:1. Click the Actions Icon on the Widget toolbar2. Enter the number of times you wish to copy the Widget3. Select the Dashboard Page you want to copy the Widget toThe copied Widget(s) are appended to the bottom of the selected Dashboard page.In addition to the default widgets in dcTrack, three types of custom widgets provide users with the capability toaddress KPIs not covered by the existing widgets. Custom widgets include the following:SQL Grid WidgetHTML WidgetChart WidgetCustom widgets can be added to dashboard pages by clicking New Widget in the Dashboard tab menu and select-ing the desired widget.Users with a globally defined Operator role or above can create, configure, and delete custom widgets.Custom widgets are not limited to the Custom dashboard page; they can be placed on any dashboard page exclud-ing the Enterprise Health dashboard page.

The SQL grid widgets allows you to use SQL commands to query dcTrack’s ODBC tables and displays the results ina data grid.The data in SQL grid widgets can be exported to CSV and PDF files by selecting the respective options from theActions menu.1.
