In the Dashboard tab, on any dashboard page except the Enterprise Health dashboard, click Add a Widget >SQL Grid Widget. The SQL Grid Widget Settings popup displays.2. Configure the SQL grid widget.a. In the Name field, enter your desired title. By default, the title is “New Sql Grid Widget.”b. In the SQL Query (ODBC) box, enter your SQL statement.c. In the Refresh field, enter your desired refresh duration in seconds. By default, this value is set to3. Click the Save button to save your changes. The widget will be automatically updated with the data.Note: All fields are required.To edit your SQL query, widget title, or refresh rate, click the Actions button and select Widget Settings. The SQLGrid Widget Settings popup displays.You can hide/display specific columns in each SQL grid widget by clicking the Show/Hide icon and select-ing/deselecting the columns you want to hide/display.For guidance on creating SQL queries, please refer to the API Guide, which can be downloaded from the Help menuin the upper right corner of the Web Client.System Administrators and global Gatekeepers can add or remove permissions for grid widgets via the Actionsmenu > Permissions button. Only the Viewer role can be assigned to a user or user group.

When columns with the following names are added to a SQL Grid widget, that column becomes a link in the Widgetand the underscore id columns are hidden.'item name' or 'itemname' becomes a link and takes user to item list with a search executed for that itemname. If item_id is also included, it will go directly to the item details.'firstnodeitem' or 'first node item' with "circuit_id" and "CircuitType" included in the query links to the circuittrace.Note: "CircuitType" must be either "Data" or "Power" (ex. 'Power' as "CircuitType")'floormap' or 'floor map' with "location_id" included in the query links to the Floor Map.'project number' or 'projectnumber' or 'project' with "project_id" included in the query links to Project Details'part number' or 'partnumber' or 'part' with "part_id" included in the query links to Part Details.'request number' or 'requestnumber' or 'request' with "request_id" included in the query links to RequestDetail.'workorder number' or 'workordernumber' or 'workorder' with "workorder_id" included in the query links toWorkorder Details.'widgettitle' or 'widget title' or 'title' with "widget_ref" included in the query links to that widget in whicheverdashboard it's in.Note, column names are case insensitive.For assistance with writing queries to use the SQL grid widget, please contact Sunbird Technical Support.The HTML widget is a custom widget that allows you display data visualizations using your own HTML code or byembedding information or widget from a 3rd-party system. Use this widget to add weather tools, maps, or other visu-alizations.1. In the Dashboard tab, on any dashboard page except the Enterprise Health dashboard, click New Widget >HTML Widget. A new widget is added to the dashboard page. The HTML Widget Settings popup displays.2. Configure the HTML widget.a. In the Title field, enter your desired title. By default, the title is “New HTML Widget.”b. In the HTML box, enter your HTML code.3. Click the Save button to save your changes. The widget will be automatically updated with the data.Note: All fields are required.To edit your HTML code, click the Actions icon and button and select Widget Settings. The HTML Widget Settingspopup displays.

When using the HTML widget, keep in mind the following limitations:dcTrack uses the HTTPS secure protocol to load the web client application. Inherent to this protocol,browsers do not allow loading content from another domain using the unsecured HTTP protocol. Therefore,you will not be able to embed content using the HTML widget unless it loads using HTTPS.If you are embedding content that requires login credentials, you will first have to login to this page eitherwithin the widget if presented with the login dialog or independently from another tab in the same browser.Certain content when embedded may redirect the browser to an embedded URL and navigate you away fromdcTrack.Custom chart widgets are available for users who want specific metrics that are not covered by the available defaultwidgets. Any existing chart type can be used to create a custom chart widget.If you would like a custom chart widget created, simply contact a Technical Support Specialist via the Sunbird sup-port portal (https://support.sunbirddcim.com), and the widget file will be created and sent to you.You can add the chart widget file to dcTrack by clicking New Widget > Chart Widget and uploading the file to yoursystem.Once you upload the file, the widget will be added to the dashboard page and can be configured as needed.

dcTrack provides an Enterprise Health Dashboard as a way to view the overall health of your data centers. Toaccess the Enterprise Health Dashboard, go to the Dashboard tab and select the second dashboard page.In order to display information for each location, you must be integrated with Power IQ and optionally have a floormap synced with the location in dcTrack.Note: Since you are integrated with Power IQ, you do not need to separately add a drawing file to the floor map wid-get in Power IQ; you maintain the floor map along with all other data in dcTrack once you are integrated.The Enterprise Health Dashboard is configurable, so you can select the locations you want to display, choose a cus-tom title and add an additional static piece of information, as well as adjust the size and position of each tile. There isno limit to the number of tiles that can be added.Tiles can be created for each data center, floor, or room location you have access to. They contain the measuredtotal active power readings for the location and its children. The tiles pull data every 30 seconds. When new dataarrives, the tiles visibly refresh by sliding in on the screen. If none of the tile’s data has changed, only the tile’s titlewill slide across.The tiles are color-coded so you can easily identify the data center's overall health:GREEN: Normal. No warning or critical events.YELLOW: Warning. Warning level events reported. A triangle with an exclamation mark is displayed next tothe number of events.RED: Critical. Critical level events reported. A circle with an X is displayed next to the number of events.GRAY: No Data. Object is not synced or you do not have permission to view it.To add a tile:1. Click New Widget > Tile Widget on the Enterprise Health dashboard page.A tile widget is created, and the Tile Widget Settings dialog appears.2. Select Location: Select the data center location you want to add from the dropdown.3. Tile Name: Enter a name for the tile. The default is the location name.4. Custom Label: This is for your own use. Enter a label for the value you enter in the next Custom Value field.(For example: “Staff”5. Custom Value: Enter text or number. Example, 6 to indicate the number of staff working at this location.6. Click Save to save your changes.Back on the Enterprise Health dashboard page, the tile widget will refresh with the data for the location.

You can change the location that appears in a tile or edit a tile name.1. Click on the Gear icon in the corner of a widget.2. Click the Widget Settings icon.3. In Select Location, select your desired location from the dropdown.4. In Tile Name, enter the name for the tile Widget.5. Enter the Custom Label (optional).6. Enter the Custom Value (optional).5. Click the Save button and icon to save your changes.Change the position of a tile on the Enterprise Health page by positioning your cursor over the name/title area of thetile and dragging the tile to a new location on the page.Increase or decrease the size of the tile by positioning your cursor over any edge or corner of the tile and resizing thetile to fit your needs.

Remove a tile from the page by selecting the Actions menu > Delete Widget. You will be asked to confirm the dele-tion.From the Enterprise Health dashboard page, you can drill down to a location's specific Health Floor Map to view thelocation's health in more detail.Click the location's tile to open a location's Health Floor Map from the Enterprise Health dashboard page or click theActions menu > Go to Visualization.The Health Floor Map for that location opens in a Floor Map view.Objects are color-coded based on event severity. If a warning or critical event has occurred and is still active, thecabinet is shown at a warning or critical level.A legend in the Report section at the top of the map describes the meaning of each color code.GREEN: Normal. No warning or critical events.YELLOW: Warning. Warning level events reported.RED: Critical. Critical level events reported.GRAY: No Data. Object is not synced or you do not have permission to view it.You can also click on the Visualization tab in the Web Client to open a location's Floor Maps page, then select"Health Map" from the Report drop-down.The Health Floor Map is specific to the location that is currently selected in the Location dropdown in the upper left ofthe Floor Maps page. Switch to another location by selecting from the Location drop-down.Switch to another report view of the location by selecting a different report, such as "Budgeted Power per Cabinet,"from the Reports dropdown.

dcTrack allows you to create a report that can be emailed immediately or scheduled to generate automatically andemailed on a set frequency.Note: dcTrack supports scheduling SQL Grid Widgets in addition to HTML and Chart Widgets.Note: Admin users cannot see all scheduled reports in the system.Note: If a user is deleted (not deactivated), dcTrack reassigned scheduled reports to the admin account.To schedule or email a report, click the Schedule icon on the Dashboard toolbarOn Demand reports can be created allowing users to access a pre-configured report and send it on an ad hoc basiswithout having to reselect the widgets each time.Note: Sending widgets via email may be limited by your SMTP server.Steps to create an On Demand report:1. From the Schedule Report page click the Create buttonNote: If no reports exist it is assumed you are creating a new report so the Create button is not dis-played.2. Assign a Report Name to this report. (Required)3. Select the"Send" action ("On a Schedule" or "On Demand") (Required)4. Specify the Email informationTo - Any valid email address. Recipient does not have to be a dcTrack user (Required)Cc - Any valid email address. Recipient does not have to be a dcTrack userSubject - Email topic as described by the user (Required)Attachment - Image size for the attached widgets (hovering over the Attachment label will display theresolution for each size)Small - 1024 X 576Medium - 1280 X 720Large - 1920 X 1080Body - Email body as supplied by the user5. If you are scheduling a Chart Widget and want to include the detailed data in the email as a .csv attachment,check the "Detail" check box6. Select the Widgets you wish to include in the reportTo select all reports click the Select All icon in the header7. Click the Save button to save the Report settings8. You can also optionally click the Send Now button to immediately send the emailYou can also select a existing report to email by selecting the report and clicking the Send Now button.Steps to create and schedule a report:1. From the Schedule Report page click the Create button2. Assign a Report Name (Required)3. Select the"Send" action you want to perform ("On a Schedule" or "Now") (Required)4. To schedule a report that will generate automatically based on a frequency select "On a Schedule"4. Select the time you wish the report to be generatedNote each time the report is generated the widgets will reflect the data as it existed at that time5. Select the frequency you want the report to be generated and emailedDaily, Weekly, Monthly6. Select the rate by which to adjust the frequencyFor example to generate the report every two weeks, specify a frequency of "Weekly" and a rate of "2".The rate can be a value between 1 and 1000.7. For Weekly frequencies, specify the day of the week to generate the report (Sunday - Saturday). For Monthlyfrequencies, specify the day of the month to generate the report (1st - 31st).8. Specify the first date to generate the report.9. If the first date to generate the report does not follow the frequency rules specified, the report will be gen-erated on the next date that follows the frequency rules. For example if the frequency is Weekly on Mondaybut the start date specified is 06/26/2019 which is a Wednesday. The first report will be generated on7/01/2019 which is the first Monday following the start date.10. Specify the last date the report is to be generated. If this date is not specified, the report will continue to gen-erate based on the specified frequency until an End date is added to the report or the report is deleted.11. Specify the Email informationTo - Any valid email address. Recipient does not have to be a dcTrack user (Required)Cc - Any valid email address. Recipient does not have to be a dcTrack userSubject - Email topic as described by the user (Required)Attachment - Image size for the attached widgetsBody - Email body as supplied by the user12. If you are scheduling a Chart Widget and want to include the detailed data in the email as a .csv attachment,check the "Detail" check box13. Select the Widgets you wish to include in the report14. Click the Save button to save the report.15. You can also optionally click the Send Now button to immediately send the emailExisting reports can be edited by selecting the report from the report list, making the necessary changes and clickingthe Save button.Reports can also be Cloned. Cloning is useful when creating a report that closely, but not exactly resembles anotherreport.Steps to Clone a report:1. Select the Report you wish to Clone2. All of the field values from the original report are retained except for the Report Name field which is cleared.3. Supply a new Report Name and modify any fields that should be changed.4. Click the Save ButtonNote: The widgets in the attachment files reflect the data as it existed when the image was createddcTrack allows users to create links to widgets that can be shared with both dcTrack and non dcTrack users viainternal portals, embedded in documents or included in email. The data reflected in the widgets is current withinminutes of the time the link is clicked.Steps to create a shareable link1. Click Get Public Embeddable Link from the actions menu of the widget you wish to create a link to2. From the pop up window click Copy To Clipboard3. Click Close to close the windowThe URL may now be pasted from the Clipboard into documents, emails or internal platforms like SharePoint or Jira.Note: Widget images have a 10 minute cache period, so if it has been more than 10 minutes since the last time thelink was accessed, the Widget image is refreshed with current data.For additional information please see the video atHow to Display Dashboard Widget Data

The widgets on the Web Client Dashboard show no external data when no items have been added to dcTrack® orconfigured to get readings.When no information is available on the Web Client Dashboard, the widgets display a message indicating that nodata is available.

This section contains information on the features and reports available in the Visualization tab in the Web Client.The Visualization tab in the dcTrack Web Client contains the Floor Maps and Data Network Diagrams.A floor map is rendered when you upload a .DWG drawing file for each of your data center locations in dcTrack. Theobjects on the floor map are then synced with items in dcTrack.From here:View Data Center Conditions Using Floor Map ReportsSet Floor Map Report ThresholdsPrint a Filtered Floor Map ReportZoom In on a Report Section to Print ItDownload a Location's Existing Floor Map Drawing FileExport the Floor Map Report Data List to a .CSV FileFloor Maps can be viewed in two modesFloor Map 2D ModeFloor Map 3D ModeData Network Diagram provides capability to visualize entire Data Network for a single location or across multiplelocations.Data Network Diagrams can be viewed in two formats.Mesh ViewTier ViewFor details see Data Network DiagramsThis section contains information on the features and reports available in the Floor Map.

The Floor Map Toolbar is designed to make it faster and easier for you to access all of the Floor Map features.Location List This list will contain all of the eligible Locations that the user has permissions for.This button will open up the Configuration window where you can upload/download your drawingsConfigurationas well as other features. For specific information on configuring your Floor Maps please see theIconFloor Map Configuration section of this guide.This button will open up the floor map drawing for editing. For specific information on editing FloorEdit IconMaps, please see the Editing Floor Maps section of this guide.Refresh Refreshes the floor mapPrint Report Print a floor map report3D Toggles between 2D and 3D mode. 3D mode is enabled by default.Home Returns to the home view. Also clears the Isolate feature.If the selected a location thatcontains multiple rooms, clicking this button allows you to select one ofthe rooms which will then bring that room into focus. If you are already focused on a room the drillDrill Down icondown icon displays in reverse and once clicked you will return to the parent drawing which containsall rooms for that location.Isolate Isolates user-selected cabinet(s)Search Searches for items on the floor map based on user-defined criteriaConnectivity Enables the display of a selected item’s power and data connectionsMeasure Enables the measurement of cord lengths on the floor mapTiles Enables the configuration of perforated tiles on the floor mapReports Correlates data from multiple user-selected reports on the floor mapThermal Map Enables the thermal and pressure map time-lapse video on the floor mapLayers Enables displaying or hiding layers in the .dwg file on the floor mapColor Configure options for the floor map featuresClick the Configuration icon on the Visualization toolbar to access the floor map configuration pop-up. In this pop-up,you’ll be able to configure options for floor map features. Note that these Configuration options can only be appliedto all locations.Tab SummaryDrawing File Man-Upload and download floor map filesagementSet orientation of North indicator and specify floor map units, cabinet position, and gridDrawing Optionslabeling3D Settings Set Cabinet Contents to Always or Auto and specify additional item tool tip fieldsSpecify which layers to display by default and indicate the layer type (None, Cable Tray,Layer Configurationor Grid Marker)Connectivity Con-Assign the default cable colors for patch cords, structured cabling, and distributedfigurationcablingReports Thresholds Set the thresholds for each floor map report

When you create a location in dcTrack, you can upload a drawing file of the data center. Each object on the drawingfile is then synced with items in dcTrack.Drawing files can be uploaded when the data center is initially created or at a later time. See Use File Import to Add,Edit Delete and Move.Note that Floor Map functions are not available until a drawing file is uploaded and synced with items in a location.Once synced, you can use the Floor Map to:Monitor temperature and cabinet capacity in your data center using various Floor Map Reports.Monitor the overall health of the data center using the Health Map report.Download the Floor Map file, make changes to it, and upload the file so the changes are reflected in dcTrack.Locate objects that are not synced with items in dcTrack.Select cabinets on either the Floor Map or Items List to view their Cabinet Elevation.Access an item's page by double-clicking on an item in the Items List or on the Floor MapAccessing a Cabinet Inspector by selecting an item on the Floor Map or Items List, then clicking the Informationicon on the Cabinet Elevation selecting Cabinet Inspector from the drop-down menu.The processes for uploading and re-uploading a drawing file are the same:1. Click the Visualization tab to open the Floor Maps page.2. In the Floor Map toolbar, click the Configuration icon. The Floor Map Configuration pop-up displays.4. In the Upload drawing dialog, use the Browse dialog to locate and select the .dwg, .dxf or .vsdx file.5. In the Upload Drawing dialog, click the Upload button.The upload time may vary depending on file size and network speed.dcTrack syncs the objects in the drawing file with existing dcTrack items of the same name.Processing typically takes a few seconds and does not require you to stay on the Floor Maps page.6. A popup will display a Drawing File Upload Success message when the upload is complete. Click the OK buttonto close the popup.A successful upload is indicated by the floor map appearing and a green checkmark icon next to the Status Field inthe Drawing File Management tab. The Status field will update to display a Drawing Is Ready message.7. Click the Close Button in the lower right corner to close out of the Configuration popup. The floor map loads, andall synced cabinets are listed in the Items List on the left.Note: If the processing failed, a red icon with an X is displayed and the No File Available message is displayed onthe page.Cabinets and items that are not synced during the drawing file upload can be synced using the Sync function in theFloor Map menu bar.When Sync mode is enabled, all other modes will be canceled and the drawing is set to the Home view. The cab-inets are colored red or green based their status as synced or not.Green: Objects in the drawing that are not synced with the databaseRed: Objects in the drawing that are not synced with the databaseNote: Objects in the database that are not synced with the drawing will display a "No match" status in the Items Listin the left panel.Available sync options vary based on which item, if any, you have selected.Select your items and the click the desired Sync icon to complete the operation. Sync operations include the fol-lowing:When the user selects a "NoSync SelectedTypically, this would mean that these twomatch" item from the list andSync selectedItem in List anditems don't have the same names, which isan object in the drawing thatitemsDrawingwhy they were not autosynced.is not syncedUnsync theThe selection of the synced item can beUnsync SelectedWhen a Synced item is selec-item from themade in the list or the drawing because ifeither is clicked, the other is selected, sinceItemtedobject in thethey are already in sync.drawingAlways enabled and does notThis will unsync all objects in the database andUnsyncs allUnsync All Itemsrequire any item to be selec-the drawing. You will have to re-sync all objectsitemstedmanually or re-upload your drawing.Note: To sync Suspended Cabinets to objects in drawing, make sure to select the option Sync for SuspendedMounting.

Once a data center's original drawing file is uploaded to dcTrack, that file is considering your primary drawing file.Drawing files are uploaded when you manually add a data center location or create locations in bulk using FileImport. See Manually Upload and Sync a Drawing File and .An existing, primary floor map drawing file can be downloaded from the Web Client, and the file saved locally.You can then makes changes to the drawing file and re-upload it to dcTrack.Since the file is the primary drawing file, once dcTrack renders the drawing, the changes are reflected on the FloorMap pages in both the Web Client.Note that changes are not made in real-time since you must download the file, make changes, and upload it.Downloading an existing drawing file is also useful if, for example, you want to use it to create a copy to use as a tem-plate for a new data center location drawing.It is also useful to download and retain a copy or as a backup.Note that downloaded files are copies of the original files until they are uploaded again.To download a floor map drawing file:1. Click the Visualization tab to open the Floor Maps page.2. In the Floor Map toolbar, click the Configuration icon. The Floor Map Configuration pop-up displays.3. In the Floor Map Configuration pop-up, in the Drawing File Management tab, click the Download button.The following steps cover importing locations, verifying locations were imported, importing items and connections,verifying items and connections were imported, and uploading and syncing drawing files with locations.1. Import locations first if you have not already done so. Once locations exist in dcTrack, import items and con-nections.2. Begin a File Import by clicking the Import button in the main dcTrack tool bar.3. Use the Browse button to locate the import file.As soon as you select the import file, the file is validated by dcTrack to ensure it is formatted correctly. All errorsencountered during file validation must be corrected before proceeding to advancing. Use the arrow at the top of thepage to advance to the next step or to return to a previous step.Warning or errors are displayed, if found.If there are no issues with the import file format, a success message is displayed.4. (Optional) Select Proceed on Warning, if desired.5. Click Begin Import.As dcTrack imports your data, a progress bar is displayed.Once the import is complete, you can go on to view the newly added locations, otherwise all valid import operationsare completed.Any errors encountered during import are listed in the Results section of the File Import dialog, and all valid data areimported.Select "Save Results to File" to create a file containing only invalid data. You can then fix the issues and import thedata.6. To view the new locations in the Web Client, navigate to Assets > Locations. You may need to refresh the grid tosee your newly added Locations.7. Locations appear in the Default Location drop-down, Location drop-down, on the Items List under Assets and soon.11. The VPC checkbox is selected for locations that are VPC enabled.If VPC is not enabled for a location, you can enable it from this page.12. If needed, integrate dcTrack with one or more Power IQs. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > ApplicationAdministration > Integrations to open the Power IQ Integration Settings page. You can then use File Import tosync integrated Power IQs. See Use File Import to Sync Integrated dcTrack and Power IQ.13. Next, import cabinets and items if you have not already done so.14. You can perform this step now or at a later time, but note that cabinets and items must exist in the data center inorder to sync drawing files. Otherwise, you must map or import them after syncing.15. Use File Import and follow the same steps that are outlined above.No readings are displayed in the widgets on the Web Client until:Items that can send SNMP readings are added and configured to send them, and/or you are integrated withPower IQ.Items sending readings are powered on.This is also true on item pages once items are added.16. Import power and data connections once items are imported.17. You can perform this step now or at a later time.18. Use File Import and follow the same steps that are outlined above.19. To view newly added items or connections, click Refresh on the Items List or Circuits List page.Tip: For items, filter the list by Origin = Import. You can also filter by Location so only imported items for the spe-cified location are displayed.20. Next, upload each location’s drawing file, if applicable.This is done in the Web Client using the Upload feature on the Floor Maps page.Upload each data center's drawing file separately.21. Click on the Visualization tab to open the Floor Maps page.22. From the Location drop-down, select the location you want to upload the drawing file to.23. Click Settings if the Upload icon is not displayed already.24. Click Upload, then use browse to locate and select the .DWG file.25. In the Upload Drawing dialog, click Upload.To quickly locate items that were not synced, do the following -26. In the Web Client, click on the Visualization tab. The Floor Maps page loads.27. Select your location from the Location drop-down in the left panel if it is not displayed by default.28. Select a report from the Reports drop-down (it does not matter which report you choose). Note that Settingsmust be disabled to view the Reports drop-down, Click on the Settings button to disable it.Gray objects on the floor map indicate they are not synced.29. To sync unsynced objects, navigate to the Visualization page and Click the appropriate Sync option30. If necessary, manually sync objects that did not synch.31. To manually link the drawing file objects with existing items in dcTrack, do the following -'Items found in dcTrack' box - select the dcTrack item you want to link thedrawing file object to'Objects found in AutoCAD Drawing' box - select the drawing file object you want to link to the dcTrack itemyou just selectedClick 'Link dcTrack Item with AutoCAD Object'.If objects in the drawing file were not linked to existing dcTrack items, import them into dcTrack.For more information on drawing file template requirements and recommendations, see Creating Floor Map Draw-ing Files - Templates and Requirements.

In the dcTrack Web Client, if you open the Floor Maps page under the Visualization tab and a message indicates nodrawing file is available, that means a drawing file has not yet been uploaded for the location.A drawing file is uploaded to dcTrack for each location and is required in order to render the floor map.Floor maps are available in the Web Client under the Visualization tab.Use floor map reports to review environment, sensor, power and capacity data at the cabinet level.Data are displayed graphically on the floor map using color coding, and in list format in the Data List.Filter, sort, print and export data from the floor map reports as needed.Floor map reports are viewed directly on the Floor Map page under the Visualization tab in the Web Client.For information on creating floor map drawing files, see Creating Floor Map Drawing Files - Templates andRequirements.

You can use the auto report thresholds defined in dcTrack for each report or customize each report's thresholds.The thresholds for each report vary based on the report.Note: Use caution when considering changing a report's threshold.Reports are generated on a per user basis and apply to the current dcTrack session. Each user must generate theirown reports to retrieve up-to-date data.However, if any changes are made to report thresholds in dcTrack, they are applied at the application level. Thismeans all dcTrack users are impacted.The thresholds depend on your needs, and what each report allows (see the individual topics in Floor Map Reports(Web Client).Floor map report thresholds can be changed on the Floor Map Settings pop-up, accessible by clicking the Configureicon on the Floor Map toolbar.Alternatively, you can click the Edit Threshold icon in the Reports Legend and Data section when you have selectedone or more floor map reports. You can also click in each colored field to change the respective threshold.To edit floor map report thresholds:1. Select Visualization in the Web Client to open the Floor Maps page.2. Check the Location dropdown to ensure you are working in the location you want to generate floor maps for.3. In the Floor Map toolbar, click the Configure icon to open the Floor Map Configuration popup. Alternatively, youcan click the Edit Threshold icon in the Reports Legend and Data section when you have selected one or morefloor map reports.4. Click the Reports Thresholds tab to view a table of reports and their threshold settings, as well as the low andhigh threshold settings. Clicking the Edit Threshold icon will automatically open the Reports Thresholds tab.5. For the Thresholds field, use the report's default threshold settings by leaving "auto" selected or click theThreshold drop-down and select "custom" to enable the Low and High fields.6. To set custom thresholds, ensure that the custom option is selected for the Thresholds, and then click in theassociated Low and High fields to type in your custom thresholds. When you have a report selected on the floormap, you can also click in each colored threshold field to type in the threshold.Note: If a value outside the accepted low or high range is entered, a field error is indicated and the field resets to 0when you leave it.7. Click the Apply to All Locations icon to apply the threshold updates to the reports.8. Click the X in the upper right corner of the Floor Map Settings popup to exit. The new thresholds are appliedimmediately.After generating a cabinet floor map report, the report data are displayed in graphical and list format.You can select up to five reports to enable on the floor map to make it easier for you to select the right location foryour items based on common capacity constraints, such as space, power, and cooling.To select a report, click the Reports icon and click each of the reports that you’d like to view. The floor map will auto-matically update as each report is selected. The number of floor map reports selected with be displayed at the bot-tom of the list.The Reports Legend and Data panel to the left of the floor map will display the results for each cabinet.The color of the cabinet on the floor map indicates the data range the cabinet falls into based on the data rangesdefined for the report.Red cabinets = high end of the data rangeBlue cabinets = low end of the data range for temperatureYellow cabinets = medium of the data rangeGreen cabinets = low or acceptable end of the data rangeGray cabinets = no report data availableNote: Not all reports can be used with a Planning Date. For those reports, “Selected Planning Date not applicable”will display in parentheses next to the title of each report.Thresholds can be edited by clicking the Edit Threshold icon in the Reports Legend and Data panel, or by accessingthe Reports Thresholds tab under the Floor Map Settings section.The actual cabinet color displayed when correlating data across multiple reports will vary based on the thresholdsand priority of the conditions illustrated by the colors (Red, Yellow, Blue, Green). The following chart can be helpfulin interpreting reports that leverage different color coding (red/yellow/green or red/green/blue):Green Red RedGreen Green GreenGreen Blue BlueYellow Red RedYellow Green YellowYellow Blue YellowRed Red RedRed Green RedRed Blue RedNote: Cabinets that are gray are not linked to items in dcTrack and should be synced.Note: Report color coding is only applied while you are viewing a report. Default floor map colors are restored onceyou switch back to the standard floor map view.Note: For more information on thresholds and customizing them, see Set Floor Map Report Thresholds.

To print a floor map report from the Web Client, click the Print icon on the Floor Map menu bar.You can print a copy of a floor map using any standard or network printer.You can also print to PDF, XPS, or any other print driver.When you print a floor map report, both the floor map and Report Data List are included.If you applied filters to the report, such as filtering to include only cabinets belonging to a specific customer or itemtype, the printed report contains only the filtered data in both the Report Data List and floor map.1. Select the report.2. Apply the filter.3. Select Print and print the report. Only the filtered data are included in the report.

If you zoom into a specific section of the floor map report, such as zooming in on a specific grouping of cabinets, onlythe data for the items in focus are included in the floor map and Report Legend and Data when you print the report.1. Select the report.2. Use the Zoom icon on the Floor Map menu or your mouse to select and zoom in on an area of the floor map.3. Select Print and print the report.Only the area you zoomed in on and the data for that area are included in the report.In addition to printing floor map reports that include both the Floor Map and Data List, you can export the report datafrom the Report Data List and save it to a .CSV file.1. Select the report, apply a filter and/or zoom into a specific report section (if needed).2. Click the "Export to CSV" icon at the bottom of the Report Data List once the report data loads.3. After the report downloads, open the report and save it locally.The .CSV file contains the data listed in the Report Data List for the selected report.For information on specifying a save location, see How to Specify a Default Save Location for Downloaded Files.

The table below lists the capacity and environmental reports and their descriptions available in the Web Client on theVisualization tab.Reports are available in 2D and 3D. To toggle between 2D and 3D reports, click the 3D icon in the visualization tool-bar.For more information on 3D floor maps, see Using the 3D Visualizer (Web Client).Floor map reports use both color coding and text to display data. Your default units of measure are used for thereport data. For information on changing the default unit of measure, see Define a User's Default Unit of Measure.Custom thresholds can be applied to the reports. Thresholds range from 0 - 999, up to one decimal (for example,80.6). To apply custom thresholds, select a report and click the Edit Thresholds button on the Report panel.Data can be filtered by Customer, Function, Grouping, and Type. For more information on accessing, filtering, gen-erating and printing/saving floor map reports, see View Data Center Conditions Using Floor Map Reports.Displays the total number of used rack units (front andUsed RUsback) out of the total number of rack units in the cab-inet.Displays total number of available rack units (front andAvailable RUsback) out of the total number of rack units in the cab-inet.Displays the percent full per cabinet (either front orPercent Fullback rails occupied).Displays the total weight of all of the items in the cab-Weightinet plus the cabinet weight.Displays the weight capacity per cabinet (based on theWeight CapacityLoad Capacity value set in the Configuration sub-tab ofthe cabinet’s item detail page).Note: Capacity values for each cabinet must be set forthe report to display the correct percentages. If nocapacity value is set, the Percent column in the ReportData list will display a “No capacity set” message.Displays the weight per cabinet divided by the cabinetStatic Loadfootprint area.Displays the temperature sensors at the rear of acabinet.Temperature BacksNote: Readings from temperature sensors that arephysically not “in” the cabinet are not included in thisreport.Temperature Fronts Displays the temperature sensors at the cabinet front.Displays the relative humidity sensors at the cabinetRelative Humidity atFrontsfront.Displays the relative humidity sensors at the cabinetRelative Humidity atBacksback.Displays the actual Amps across all input cords for allMeasured Ampsrack PDUs in a cabinet.Displays the measured power of each cabinet in kWMeasured Powerfrom the Rack PDU Inlets in each cabinet as retrievedfrom Power IQ the last time the Rack PDU was synced.Displays the sum of budgeted power in kW for eachcabinet based on the items in the cabinet.Used Effective PowerBudgeted kW for each item is defined when creatingpower supplies for items.Displays the potential power (the maximum effectiveUsed Potential Powerpower) in a cabinet.Reports Cabinet Capacity (Power Capacity (kW) less thesum of the Potential Power for all the Items containedAvailable Power (Potential)in the Cabinet. Low numbers are displayed in red andhigh numbers are displayed in green. This report sup-ports Items “Planned for Decommission” based on thedate selected in the dcTrack Header.Displays remaining capacity by subtracting theCabinet's power capacity from the measured power ofAvailable Power (Measured)each Cabinet in kW. The measured data is from theRack PDU Inlets in each Cabinet as retrieved fromPower IQ from the last time the Rack PDU was synced.Reports each Cabinet’s “Power Capacity (kW)” field.Power CapacityLow numbers are displayed in red and high numbersare displayed in green.Color codes floor items with yellow and red when thereare warning or critical level events, respectively, asso-ciated with the floor item.Health MapNote: This report is only visible when the location indcTrack is integrated with Power IQ.The Layers feature in dcTrack enables users to show or hide the layers in their floor map drawing files to make betteruse of your AutoCAD or Visio drawings.To enable Layers, click the Layers drop-down in the Visualization tool bar. From here, you can select or deselect thelayers you want to show or hide. To set the layers displayed by default, go to the Layer Configuration tab in the FloorMap Configuration pop-up, accessible by clicking the Configuration icon in the Visualization menu bar.Cable trays are layers so they are shown or hidden using the Layers drop-down. However, when they are des-ignated as Cable Trays in the Layer Configuration tab, they are drawn at a specified elevation that is less than orgreater than 0 and therefore are not considered part of the background image.

Multi-field search is available on the floor map, enabling you to quickly locate items in your data center.To search on the floor map, simply click the Search icon to enable search mode, and type your criteria into thesearch box. Hit the Enter button to isolate the search results. The floor map will automatically isolate the items thatmatch your criteria.The search results will be displayed in the Items List in the panel to the left of the floor map. Clicking on a result in theItems List will highlight the corresponding cabinet in blue on the floor map.To clear your search, click the red X in the search bar.To save your results as a view, click the Views dropdown in the Search bar and click the Save Current List SettingsAs… icon. You will be able to name your view and save it. It will then appear in the Views menu under My Views. Mul-tiple list views are available for each user.dcTrack version 9.0.0 introduced the ability to search in conjunction with Color coding. The display of the results ofthe search depends on when the color coding is applied.

If the color code feature is activated first and then a search is initiated the following will occur:The left panel is divided into thirds. At the very top is the color legend, below that is the color list, below that isthe Item search results3D view removes all cabinets where neither the cabinet nor the Items in the cabinet match the search resultIf the search matches on cabinets contents but not the cabinet itself, the cabinet displays with the light greenstandard color and is transparentIf the search matches the cabinet itself, the cabinet will display in whatever color it is assigned in color codingIf none of a cabinet's contents match the search, the cabinet remains solid.if some cabinet contents match the search, then the cabinet becomes transperant.If the search feature is activated first and then the color code feature is activated the following will occur:The left panel is divided into thirds. At the very top is the color legend, below that is the color list, below that isthe Item search resultsNon-matching cabinets with non-matching contents are hiddenIf the cabinet itself is a match, it retains its original color.

System Administrators and Global Gatekeepers can choose to highlight Items on Floor Maps by assigning colorsbased on Standard or Custom Field Values. For example, users can highlight and quickly see all of the Items for asingle Project or multiple Projects.Prior to dcTrack version 9.0.0 colors were assigned automatically and could not be changed. dcTrack version 9.0.0introduced the ability to customize colors allowing users to select which colors are assigned to each value.Color Coding is available in both 2D and 3D Modes.Note: dcTrack will assign up to 20 unique colors to the Floor Map. For this reason selections are limited to 20 Items.Steps to Color Code a Floor Map:1. Navigate to the Visualization > Floor Maps2. Select the Location whose Floor Map you want to see3. Click the Color button on the Visualization Tool Bar4. A sub Tool Bar is displayed with a drop down list for selecting the Field you want to filter onNote: Available fields include most Standard and Custom fields with the exception of Text and Text areafields and fields that are unique for each Item (i.e. Item Name).5. Once the Field is selected the second drop down list is populated with all of the values applicable to that field.6. The list will have all values selected, however you can deselect values to suit your needs7. The left Side panel will display the Color Code List with an Item list below. The Item list includes all items thathave a value set for the selected field. The floor map will also display with the colors applied.8. Initially dcTrack custom colors are applied9. The list as well as the floor map can be filtered by clicking the colors in the color box.a. Click once to filter out the selected color. The color inside the clicked circle will be cleared while allother circles remain solid. The Items associated with the selected color will be removed from the ItemList and the floor map. You may click as many colors as you like to remove those colors as well.b. Double click to filter out all colors except the selected color. The color inside the clicked circle willremain solid while the circle for all other colors will be cleared. The Item list and the floor map will filterout all Items for every color except the selected color. You may click as many other colors as you liketo add them back in.c. Click again to restore the color list to its original state10. To set Custom colors, click the edit icon in the Color Code List11. This will open a dialog box with the Color menu open and the selected field pre-populated. The selected fieldcan be changed to set color values for a different field.12. Initally all color assignments will be set to "auto" and the Custom Color column will be empty13. To set a custom color to a field value, select it from the custom color drop down. This will display the color inthe custom color field and change the assignment from "auto" to "custom". If a custom color has not beenassigned to a value it will appear in the list with the notation "(Not used)" next to the color. You can only applya color to one value. If you attempt to assign the same color to a second value, the color will be removed fromthe first value and the Color Assignment Default for that value will be set back to "auto".14. Clicking "Clear All" will remove all custom assignments and mark the color as "Not used".15. To revert a custom color assignment, change its assignment from "custom" to "auto". This will revert the colorback to the default color assigned by dcTrack. The custom color will remain selected in the Custom Color fieldand will still appear in the color drop down list as if it was assigned. Reserving the color in this way allows youto quickly flip back and forth between custom and default colors without having to reassign from the list. Sinceit will still appear in the list without the "Not Used" notation, users will know not to use this color for a differentassignment.16. Click the Save button to apply all assignments17. Click the "Auto Assign Colors as Custom" button to freeze color assignments. This will revert all colors to thedcTrack default colors, but will mark the color as "custom". This prevents inserting a new value from changingall of the colors after the new field. For example.a. Value AAA is assigned the color Redb. Value CCC is assigned the color Bluec. Value DDD is assigned the color Greend. Inserting a value of BBB will not affect the color assignments of CCC or DDD.18. Custom colors are applied to the floor map drawing objects that have custom colors set, while the otherobjects are set using dcTrack's default colors. The Item List Panel is also displayed using the same colorscheme as the floor map.Click the icon on the color tool bar to clear the filter and return the Floor Map to its original state.You can also assign Colors by clicking the Config icon on the Floor Map tool bar and clicking on the "Color" tab onthe left side menu.All of the items added to the currently selected location are listed in the Items List on the Floor Maps page whetherthey are linked to floor map objects or not.The various features available on the Floor Maps page apply to only those items in the Items List that are linked toobjects in the floor map, however.

Clicking on a cabinet on a floor map opens its Cabinet Elevation view in the Cabinet Elevation pane to the right of thefloor map.Cable connectivity can be visualized relative to other items on the floor map. This feature can be helpful if you wantto determine what applications are supported by specific items and how they may be impacted by maintenance.Click the Connectivity icon on the Visualization toolbar to enable Connectivity mode.From the Items List or the Floor Map, select the item that you want to view connectivity for.Note: You can also enable Connectivity mode following an item search on the floor map.In the Connectivity menu, from the Selected Item Ports dropdown, select your desired ports from the lists of powerand data ports. The ports shown will vary based on the type of item you select. Power and data ports can be selec-ted simultaneously.Two radio button options are available for displaying connectivity: Full Circuit or Endpoints Only.The Full Circuit option will display the full circuit for the selected ports. Patch cords are depicted as arc lines, whilethe structured or power distribution cabling are displayed as straight lines. All circuit nodes are included. The End-points Only option will only consider the endpoint nodes of a circuit and display only those items. It will displaystraight lines between the selected item and all other items of all circuits, skipping all items that may be in the middleof the circuit.Note: If the selected item is a Data Panel or a Rack PDU and the Endpoint Only option is selected, then the secondradio button option switches to either Structured Cabling (straight lines that represent the structure cabling for datapanels as lines between data panel pairs) or Distribution Cabling (for rack PDUs as lines between a rack PDU andthe floor PDU that it is fed from.

The floor map in dcTrack 6.1 has been enhanced support for cable distance measurements and tracing so you nolonger need to walk your data center floor with a tape measure.To enable measure mode, click the Measure icon in the Visualization toolbar. On the floor map, you can immediatelystart to draw your cable distances by clicking and dragging your mouse on the floor map. The total distance willupdate automatically.dcTrack also enables you to account for vertical distance. Simply type in the near- and far-end vertical distances totheir respective fields in the Measure menu.To stop your current measurement, press the Stop button on the Measure menu. To start a new measurement, clickthe Start button and begin drawing on the floor map.The 3D Visualizer feature allows users to view 3D visualizations of floor maps in the Web Client.

To view visualizations in 3D, go to the Visualization tab and click the 3D icon in the Floor Map toolbar. Users cantoggle between 2D and 3D seamlessly by clicking this icon. The default view is in 3D.With 3D enabled, the camera can be rotated to change the user’s view of the floor map.Note: If there are any scaling issues observed, ensure that the Floor Map Drawing Units are correctly set. This canbe done by clicking the Configuration icon in the Floor Map toolbar > Floor Map Configuration> Floor Plan and chan-ging the Drawing Units appropriately.The following camera options are available for 2D and 3D floor maps:Orbit/Rotate: Hold the left mouse button and drag up, down, left, or right to orbit or rotate the view of the floormap. (Note: Orbit/Rotate is disabled for 2D floor maps.)Zoom: Use the mouse wheel or click the minus and plus icons in the Floor Map toolbar to zoom in or zoomout.Pan: Hold the right mouse button and drag up, down, left, or right to pan.

The Home View provides a view of the entire floor map and is the first view that users see on the Visualization tab inboth 2D and 3D modes.To return to the Home View, click the Home icon on the Floor Map toolbar or press the ESC button.Users can Isolate cabinets in 3D for a detailed view of the cabinets and their contents in a specific area.

To enable Isolate mode, click the Isolate icon on the zoom panel or hold down the shift key. The 3D objects on thefloor map will flatten to make selection easier and more precise.Once enabled, a column will appear on the floor. This is the selection cursor. Hold down the left mouse button toincrease the rage of the selected area the cursor bigger and select floor objects. When selected, floor objects thatare enclosed within the cursor will rise up. The contents of these selected floor objects will display.Clicking on an object selects that object and highlights it in the item list on the left. If the Cabinet Elevation view onthe right is expanded, a selected item in the cabinet will be identified with two red triangles. For more information onviewing the items in a cabinet, see View the Items in a Cabinet from a Cabinet's Item Page. For more information onCabinet Elevation Views, see Cabinet Elevations .Note: Double-clicking on an item in the cabinet will display its Item Detail page.To clear the Isolated cabinets, click the Home icon on the Floor Map toolbar or press the ESC key.

The Contents Selector is a radio button option that allows users to choose whether to hide or show the contents ofcabinets in the 3D floor maps. The Contents Selector is located under Configuration > Cabinets from the Visu-alization toolbar.When the Contents Selector is toggled to Always, the contents will always be displayed, and when the user viewsthe overall floor map, the cabinets will appear as if the doors are open.When the Contents Selector is toggled to Auto, the cabinet contents will be hidden when the user views the overallfloor map, and the cabinets will appear as if the doors are closed. However, when cabinets are selected in Isolatemode, those cabinets will automatically display their contents.Note: Selecting Auto rather than Always is recommended for large data centers to improve the performance of the3D visualizations.You can also select two Cabinet item fields to display as the cabinet label to provide additional information.1. Select the cabinet item field in Line 1 drop down in the Cabinet Label section.2. Select the second cabinet item field in Line 2 drop down. Once you select the field in Line 2 dropdown the Enable checkbox is checked. The second field will only be displayed in the floor map ifEnable checkbox is checked.3. To apply this setting to all the locations, click on Apply to all Locations. Otherwise just close thisdialog and the changes will apply to only the selected location.Isolate the cabinet to view the content inside the Cabinet. You will notice the two fields that you selected in the set-tings appear at the top of the cabinet.In both 2D and 3D modes, north is indicated by a red arrow in the bottom right corner of the screen. In 3D mode, thenorth indicator will change as the user rotates the floor map.The north arrow is useful to you correctly orient a cabinet. If you see a cabinet facing the cabinet next to it, ratherthan facing the aisle, then the Cabinet Facing field for this cabinet needs to be changed with respect to the northarrow of the drawing. You can double-click the cabinet from the Items list on the left to open the Item Details pageand edit this field.

dcTrack provides the ability to indicate on floor maps where your perforated tiles are located.Users can place tiles and set the percentage open for each tile. They also can set a default percentage open forplaced tiles. Placed tiles display in gray on the floor map.Tiles are tracked as assets, so users can export the data using an SQL Grid Widget and make use of it in com-putational fluid dynamics (CDF) applications and other systems.To place perforated tiles, select the Tiles icon on the floor map toolbar, then simply click on each tile that you want toset as perforated.To remove a perforated tile, click on it to turn it back to a normal closed tile.In this mode, you can also click a tile from the Items List on the left, and the corresponding tile will be highlighted inthe floor map view.In Edit Perforated Tiles mode, the Items List displays all tiles by their coordinates and percentage open. You can sorttiles by their tile coordinate (by either letter or number included) or their percentage open (in ascending or des-cending order).To select a tile and view its coordinates, simply click on it in the floor map. The tile coordinate and X,Y coordinatesare displayed at the bottom of the screen for easy reference.

The Default % Open field specifies the default percentage open of newly placed tiles as an integer. The default is 0percent. To set the default percentage open, type your desired default percentage open into the field.Once you have set the default percentage open, simply click a tile to apply the default to that tile.1. Specify the default percentage open.2. Click a tile to set its default percentage open to the default you have specified.3. Click the Save button to save your changes.4. Click the red X to cancel your changes.Note: You can change the default percentage open at any time; however, the default values of previously placedtiles will not be affected.Performance issues such as lag or choppy visuals may indicate a decrease in frame rate in 3D mode. For the 3Dfloor maps, around 30 FPS is sufficient. The maximum possible is 60 FPS. As you interact with the floor maps, youmay experience slight drops in frame rate.Users can view their frame rate by toggling the Frames Per Second (FPS) monitor when in 3D mode.Factors affecting the performance of 3D visualizations include:Hardware limitations and the amount of available RAM on the computer running the browser. With manyother applications running on the computer, the 3D performance may degrade even if the computer has morememory than recommended. For the best 3D experience, users should ensure that their hardware meets theminimum requirements to run dcTrack.The number of 3D objects. A very large data center with many items in the cabinets will perform slower thana small data center or a data center that has fewer items per cabinet. To alleviate this issue in large data cen-ters, you may toggle the Contents Selector on the visualization toolbar to Auto rather than Always.
To toggle the FSP monitor, press Ctrl+M at any time in 3D mode.The monitor will appear on the upper right side of the screen.

dcTrack provides a thermal map layer and pressure map layer that can be overlaid on the floor map in the Visu-alizations tab. Integration with Power IQ is required to use the thermal and pressure map overlays and time-lapsevideo.dcTrack uses readings from the environmental sensors deployed in your data center to create the thermal map. Thesensor readings are used in a standard algorithm for interpolating the data away from each sensor and using allsensors surrounding each sensor. Therefore, the more sensors deployed in your data center, the more accurate theinterpolation will be.Reports and other functions of the Visualization tab are not affected by the thermal and pressure map overlays, soany of the visualization reports selectable in the Reports dropdown can be run simultaneously with the overlays.A time-lapse video displays thermal or pressure map images in a continuous loop to show the change in tem-perature over time. The sensor readings needed to create the time-lapse video are retrieved from Power IQ. Thetime-lapse video can be created with the smallest time interval between each map image equal to the Power IQpolling rate.1. In the Visualization tab, click the Thermap Map icon to display the Thermal Map submenu.2. The controls to configure the time-lapse video will display at the bottom of the floor map.Note: If dcTrack is not integrated with Power IQ, you will see the following message in a tooltip: “There is nodata to render a thermal map. Verify sensor configuration and Power IQ integration.” In this case, you will notbe able to toggle the thermal map overlay.4. Period: Select from the dropdown the period of time for which you want to view the thermal map sensorreadings. Options include: Most Recent, Past Hour, Past Week, Past Month, Past Year, and Last Year.Most recent is selected by default.5. Type: Temperature or Pressure. Temperature is selected by default.6. Position: Top, Middle, or Bottom. For example, selecting Middle uses readings from only the middlesensor on each rack. Sensor Position is selectable only for Temperature sensors. If Pressure is selec-ted, Sensor Position will not be selectable.7. Plane: Both, Horizontal, or Vertical. Map Type is selectable only for Temperature sensors. If Pressure isselected, Map Type will not be selectable.8. Period: Most Recent, Past Hour, Past Week, Past Month, Past Year, and Last Year. For example, select-ing Last Year will start the thermal time-lapse video with readings from last year.9. The map will update immediately based on your selections. Controls will display along the bottom of themap to pause and play the time-lapse video. Click Exit to exit the popup and return to the map.6. Refresh: Click the Update button and icon to refresh the thermal map overlay and display the mostrecent readings. A tooltip on the Update button will provide the date and time for the current readings.7. To disable the map and return to the standard 3D mode, click the Thermal Map icon again.Note: Clicking the X button on the video play toolbar also returns the thermal map to the Most Recent readings dis-play.

A drawing file is a high-level, graphical rendering of a data center floor layout.Cabinets, floor PDUs, UPS units, and Cooling units that exist on the data center floor are depicted in the drawing fileas objects.Optionally, the drawing can include the data center floor's structured cabling and raised floor tiles.A drawing file is uploaded to dcTrack for each location.Steps to upload a drawing file:1. Click the Configuration Icon on the Visualization toolbar.2. In Floor Map Settings dialog check the location selected. The location selected here will be same as the loc-ation selected in Floor Map view.3. Click the Upload button in Drawing File Management Tab.4. Select the drawing file saved in your PC.5. Repeat the same steps to upload the drawing file for each location.Note: Before a drawing file is uploaded, messages in the Web Client floor maps indicate no drawingfile exists for the location.During the upload process, dcTrack automatically links drawing file objects with existing dcTrack itemsthat have the same name. For example, a PDU object named PDU-1 is linked to a PDU-1 item indcTrack.Any objects that are not linked during the upload because they have no matching items are importedinto dcTrack using the File Import, or added manually.Once the drawing file is uploaded, the floor map is rendered on the Floor Maps page under the Visu-alization tab in the Web Client.When discussing drawing files, 'objects' refers to graphical representations of cabinets, floor PDUs, UPS units andCooling units in an AutoCAD drawing file.'Shapes' is used when referring to these same items in a Microsoft Visio drawing file.

dcTrack supports either AutoCAD® or Microsoft Visio®.dcTrack 8.1.1 introduced support for uploading Visio 2013 or later drawing files (.vsdx) directly to dcTrack. Whenbrowsing for drawing files, in addition to the existing support for .dwg and .dxf files, users can now opt to select Visio(.vsdx) files. When downloading drawing files, dcTrack will always download the last file uploaded to the appliance inthe same format it was previously uploaded.Use your existing .DWG drawing files so long as they are created using a supported version of Microsoft Visio® orAutoCAD®. See Supported Drawing File Software and File Format.Using your own drawing files may require additional validating to ensure the files meets minimum requirements so itcan be successfully uploaded, rendered and synced in dcTrack.The Sunbird designed Visio stencil can be used with your Visio files.

Sunbird provides generic Microsoft Visio and AutoCAD drawing files to use as templates, or as examples to followwhen creating your own Visio or AutoCAD drawing files.Templates are downloaded from the Sunbird dcTrack Support Website.Sunbird's Microsoft Visio drawing file template provides predefined layers for optional and required drawing shapesand elements.This includes:Individual layers for buildings, row labels, cabinet shapes, floor PDU shapes, UPS shapes and Cooling Unitshapes.Layers are provided, but you are not required to create them for each of these elements and shapes in a drawing afile.Individual layers for each type of cable when drawing cable routesCable routes are optional drawing file elements, but if they are used layers are required.Individual layers for perforated tiles and grid markersPerforated floor tiles and grid markers are optional drawing file elements, but if they are used layers are required.See Raised Floor Tiles (Optional) - Drawing Requirements

Sunbird provides a Microsoft Visio stencil containing the shapes and connectors used to create shapes in a dcTrackdata center drawing file.If needed, download the stencil as a standalone file from the Sunbird Support website.Use the stencil in the Sunbird template, or your own Visio drawing file.Add the stencil to your Visio My Shapes folder so it is available as needed. See Add the dcTrack Stencil toMicrosoft VisioAfter you download the dcTrack Microsoft Visio drawing file stencil, you can add it to Visio so it is available wheneveryou need it.Note: These steps are specific to Visio 2003.1. Download the Sunbird dcTrack Visio stencil and save it to your local machine if you have not already done so.See Download the Microsoft Visio dcTrack Stencil2. Open the folder you saved the stencil to.3. Open Visio, then click File > My Shapes > Organize My Shapes. The My Shapes folder on your computer opens.4. Copy the dcTrack shapes stencil from the folder, then paste it into the My Shapes folder.5. Close the My Shapes folder.6. In Visio, click File > My Shapes. The dcTrack stencil is listed. Select the stencil to use it in a drawing file.

A username and password are required to access the Sunbird Support website at http://support.sunbirddcim.com.If you do not have a username and password, contact Professional Services and Support from the Support websiteor via email (tech@sunbirddcim.com).A username and password are required to access the Sunbird Support website at http://support.sunbirddcim.com.If you do not have a username and password, contact Professional Services and Support from the Support websiteor via email (tech@sunbirddcim.com ).The Microsoft Visio stencils are in the same zip file as the drawing files.For information on adding the stencil to Visio, see Add the dcTrack Stencil to Microsoft Visio.

As a best practice, Sunbird recommends a single working copy of your data center drawing be used throughout yourorganization.The following Microsoft Visio drawing file requirements must be met to successfully save the file in AutoCAD fileformat (.DWG), and visualize the floor map properly in the dcTrack Web Client once the drawing file is uploaded.The file must be converted to a .DWG file to upload it to dcTrack.Shapes in Visio represent objects on a floor map in dcTrack.

When using US units for Microsoft Visio drawing files, the Measurement Units setting must be set to Inches, not Feetand Inches.1. Select File > Page Setup.2. Select the Page Properties tab.3. Select Inches from the "Measurement units" drop-down.A shape's border must be closedUnless a shape is on a layer, the border outline can be black or any other color of your choosing.For more information on border color when working with layers, see Shape Border Layer Requirements - VisioFiles

Each shape created in a Microsoft Visio file must use a solid fill color, but the fill color cannot be 01:White.Aside from the colors used by the objects on the floor map generated from the drawing file, the shape's fill color doesnot impact dcTrack.When creating shape names note that:Item names cannot be duplicated within a dcTrack location, so each shape's name must be unique in the draw-ing file that is uploaded and synched with the location.Duplicate names do not cause errors, but the shapes are not linked during the synch AutoCAD® process.Shape names cannot contain the characters ' \ ? &The shape name cannot be the same name as an item in an Archived StatusGive each shape a unique ID using the Text tool, or entering it directly into the shape. Add Text to a Visio Shape.

Do not begin Microsoft Visio® layer names with the word "dcTrack" unless you are directed to do so.Microsoft Visio® layer names cannot contain spaces. Use underscores or dashes to separate words if needed.For example, Layer1, Layer-1, or Layer_1When using layers in a Microsoft Visio drawing file, a shape on a layer cannot have a black border.If it does, when the file is converted from a .VSD file to a .DWG AutoCAD file and then uploaded to dcTrack, theshape's fill is changed to black even if another fill color is applied to it.For example, you create a rectangle with a black border and blue fill on a layer in a Visio file to represent a Coolingunit object on the floor map.When the file is converted to a .DWG and then uploaded to dcTrack, when the Cooling unit object appears on thefloor map in dcTrack its fill is black, not blue.Avoid this by setting the shape's fill, border and layer to the same color - see Set a Shape's Border, Fill and VisioLayer to the Same Color.Note: In Microsoft Visio drawing file, objects can be assigned to multiple layers. When the object is assigned to mul-tiple layer dcTrack pick the first assigned layer and additional layers are ignored.

dcTrack uses AutoCAD's® color 81 for its cabinets.The example here demonstrates creating the RGB custom color custom in Microsoft Visio that matches theAutoCAD cabinet color. The steps apply to creating any custom color, however.Apply custom colors to shape borders, fills, layers and so on.1. Access the dialog to change the color for a shape's fill, border, layer and so on.2. Click on More Colors… from the "Color:" drop-down in the dialog.3. The Colors dialog opens. Select the Custom tab, and enter the following RGB colors:Red = 159Green = 255Blue = 1274. Click OK to create the custom color and apply it.Following are dcTrack's minimum, AutoCAD drawing file requirements.

An object's outline must be closedWhen creating object names note that item names cannot be duplicated within a dcTrack location, so each object'sname must be unique in the drawing file that is uploaded and synched with the location.Duplicate names do not cause errors, but the objects are not linked during the synch AutoCAD® process.Object names cannot contain the characters ' \ ? &The object name cannot be the same name as an item in an Archived Status
Do not begin AutoCAD® layer names with the word "dcTrack" unless you are directed to do so.When using AutoCAD to create your floor map drawings, follow these recommendations.

Cabinet Object - Color: dcTrack uses AutoCAD's® color 81 for its cabinetsCabinet Object - Command: Draw cabinet outlines on separate layers in the drawing file to make future modi-fications and global changes easier.Cabinet Object - Layers: Draw cabinet outlines on separate layers in the drawing file to make future modi-fications and global changes easier.Object Outline - Command: Create objects using a polylineObject Outline - Layer: Create the object outline on a different layer than the hatchObject Outline - Color: Set the color of the object outline by layer

Object Hatch - Layer: Draw solid hatches on separate layers in the drawing file so it is easier to make futuremodifications and global changes.Create the hatch on a different layer than the object outlineObject Hatch - Pattern: Use a solid pattern for the hatch within an outline.Object Hatch - Color: Set the color of the hatch by layerSunbird recommends using the following colors for hatch layers:Color 81 for a cabinet Solid HatchColor 254 for all Facility Items like UPS, Floor PDU, HVAC, Plant Bay and DC BayNames must be unique within each drawing file for each location. For more information, see Object Name Require-ments - AutoCAD Files.Object Labels - Layers: Draw object labels on separate layers in the drawing file so it is easier to make futuremodifications and global changes.Object Labels - Text Formatting: Object labels should use Arial Bold set to 9 inch height. The text heightassumes the AutoCAD drawing is drawn on a 1:1 scale.Use Multiline Text for object labels, and make sure they are contained within the object outline.Create either a Standard Text label or Multiline Text label to identify each data center row represented in the drawingfile.Cabinet Labels - Position in Row: Since dcTrack does not pull cabinet row position information from drawingfiles during the sync AutoCAD drawing file process, the cabinet label can contain any number.This means numbers that appear in cabinet labels can be part of the cabinet name, or used to represent the cab-inet's position in the data center row.Once cabinets are added to dcTrack by syncing a drawing file, their row position can be assigned manually. Rowpositions are assigned on a cabinet's item page in the Web Client.For example, a cabinet labeled "CAB1" in a drawing is can be assigned to position 4 of a row on its item page byselecting from the Position in Row drop-down.Row Labels - Row Label Drop-Down: The row label in the drawing file should match a selection available in theRow Label drop-down on the Create New Item page in the dcTrack Web Client.Select the row when creating a new cabinet for the data center location represented by the drawing file.
In your drawing file, create a layer called dcTrackGridMarker.

Draw a grid marker on a layer called dcTrackGridMarker.The figure shown here is an example of a grid marker starting at a location where the A1 tile doesn't exist.Note: The blue lines are temporary. They were drawn to represent the location of the A1 tile exactly.Also note the corner and direction of the inside line.Draw the grid marker using the Rectangle command in AutoCAD or the Rectangle shape in Microsoft Visio.When you draw the rectangle, match the original A1 tile coordinate exactly.The figure below shows an example of a grid marker at the A1 tile.Note: This example represents a full tile, but you may need to create a marker where a half tile or no tile exists.Inside this square, use the Line command or Line tool to draw a Line from the exact corner of the square to theapproximate center. Do not use the Pline command to draw this line.Draw the line to the corner that represents the 0,0 coordinate. In other words, the line starts at the corner andextends in the direction the numbers and letters increase.Do not draw any other objects on this layer.The figure below shows an example of a grid marker at the A1 tile but it is not a full tile.To create tile, the marker must have the dimensions of a full tile.Note the corner and direction of the line inside.

If the A1 tile doesn't exist because of the geometry of the room's walls, create temporary lines to extend the raisedfloor grid to where the A1 tile would be, then draw the square marker there.Delete the temporary lines once you are done drawing the marker.dcTrack 8.1 allow you to visualize Busway objects in floormap. You can also visualize the tap boxes that are placedinside the Busway.To visualize Busway objects follow the steps below.1. Download your existing floor map drawing file and update it to include busway objects in a separate layer.2. Make sure you give busway objects the same name as your busway items in dcTrack.3. Upload the updated drawing file.4. In the Visualization toolbar, click on Configure and go to Layers.5. Select the layer type Busway for the layer where your busway objects are drawn in the diagram.6. Set elevation for this layer.7. Close the Configure dialogue and do a refresh.Busway objects will show in the floor map.To visualize the Tap Boxes, isolate Busway objects. You can do this either by isolating one or more cabinets in therow where Busway is placed or isolating the entire row.You can also view all the Tap Boxes associated with the Busway when isolated. Hover over each Tap Box to get atool tip that shows name, class, make, model and status.You can navigate to Busway item details page when you double click the Busway object in the floor map. You canalso navigate to the Tap Box (Busway Outlet) item details page when you click the Tapbox in the floor map.The elevation of each Busway object in the floor map can also be set individually. This elevation can be set to a num-ber different from the elevation set for the Busway layer.Steps to set elevation of each Busway Object :1. In Busway Item details page enter the number for Placement field Elevation AFF(in).2. This field is used to capture the elevation of the Busway item above the finished floor in inches.3. Save the item.4. Go back to Visualization and do a Refresh.5. Isolate the Busway with updated Elevation.Note : Elevation set for the Busway Object over-ride the Elevation set for the Busway Layer.

dcTrack allows you to visualize the cabinets with suspended mounting in floor map.Cabinets with suspended mounting can be rendered in floor map without adding them in the drawing file. The pos-ition and the height of the suspended cabinets can be set using the item field Elevation (AFF). This field accepts bothpositive and negative value. You can enter a positive value for the cabinets that are placed above the floor and neg-ative value for cabinets that are placed below the floor.Note : When there are no free-standing cabinet in a row, suspended cabinet in that row are not rendered. Howeveryou can follow the steps below to visualize these suspended cabinets in the floor map.To view suspended cabinets go to Visualization > Floor Map. All suspended cabinets are rendered automatically onthe floor map.1. Download your existing floor map drawing file and update it to include suspended cabinets in a separatelayer. Suspended cabinets can be drawn in the diagram same way as cabinets are drawn.2. Make sure you give your suspended cabinets the same name as your suspended cabinets created indcTrack.3. Upload the updated drawing file.4. In the Visualization toolbar, click on Configure and go to Layers.5. Select the layer type Suspended for the layer where your suspended cabinets are drawn in the diagram.6. Set elevation for this layer.7. Close the Configure dialogue and do a refresh.Suspended cabinets display in the floor map. You can also isolate the suspended cabinets to view the items in thesuspended cabinets.To sync Suspended Cabinet items to the object in the drawing make sure the check box Sync for Suspended Mount-ing is checked. When this option is checked Suspended Cabinets will be included in the sync precess just like Free-Standing Cabinets.Compartment Cabinets can also be visualized in 3D.Steps1.
