Create the Suspended Cabinets and place at same row and position in row.2. Enter the value for Elevation AFF for each cabinet. The value for this field should depend on the order of thecabinets placed.For example if there are three Cabinets CAB1, CAB2 and CAB3 and the height of cabinet model is 24 inchthen value for this field for these cabinets should bea. CAB1 -> 1b. CAB2 -> 24c. CAB3 -> 48Go to the Floor Map and you can see the cabinets in 3D as screen shot below.System Administrators and Global Gatekeepers can choose to highlight Items on Floor Maps by assigning colorsbased on Standard or Custom Field Values. For example, users can highlight and quickly see all of the Items for asingle Project or multiple Projects.Prior to dcTrack version 9.0.0 colors were assigned automatically and could not be changed. dcTrack version 9.0.0introduced the ability to customize colors allowing users to select which colors are assigned to each value.Color Coding is available in both 2D and 3D Modes.Note: dcTrack will assign up to 20 unique colors to the Floor Map. For this reason selections are limited to 20 Items.Steps to Color Code a Floor Map:1. Navigate to the Visualization > Floor Maps2. Select the Location whose Floor Map you want to see3. Click the Color button on the Visualization Tool Bar4. A sub Tool Bar is displayed with a drop down list for selecting the Field you want to filter onNote: Available fields include most Standard and Custom fields with the exception of Text and Text areafields and fields that are unique for each Item (i.e. Item Name).5. Once the Field is selected the second drop down list is populated with all of the values applicable to that field.6. The list will have all values selected, however you can deselect values to suit your needs7. The left Side panel will display the Color Code List with an Item list below. The Item list includes all items thathave a value set for the selected field. The floor map will also display with the colors applied.8. Initially dcTrack custom colors are applied9. The list as well as the floor map can be filtered by clicking the colors in the color box.a. Click once to filter out the selected color. The color inside the clicked circle will be cleared while allother circles remain solid. The Items associated with the selected color will be removed from the ItemList and the floor map. You may click as many colors as you like to remove those colors as well.b. Double click to filter out all colors except the selected color. The color inside the clicked circle willremain solid while the circle for all other colors will be cleared. The Item list and the floor map will filterout all Items for every color except the selected color. You may click as many other colors as you liketo add them back in.c. Click again to restore the color list to its original state10. To set Custom colors, click the edit icon in the Color Code List11. This will open a dialog box with the Color menu open and the selected field pre-populated. The selected fieldcan be changed to set color values for a different field.12. Initally all color assignments will be set to "auto" and the Custom Color column will be empty13. To set a custom color to a field value, select it from the custom color drop down. This will display the color inthe custom color field and change the assignment from "auto" to "custom". If a custom color has not beenassigned to a value it will appear in the list with the notation "(Not used)" next to the color. You can only applya color to one value. If you attempt to assign the same color to a second value, the color will be removed fromthe first value and the Color Assignment Default for that value will be set back to "auto".14. Clicking "Clear All" will remove all custom assignments and mark the color as "Not used".15. To revert a custom color assignment, change its assignment from "custom" to "auto". This will revert the colorback to the default color assigned by dcTrack. The custom color will remain selected in the Custom Color fieldand will still appear in the color drop down list as if it was assigned. Reserving the color in this way allows youto quickly flip back and forth between custom and default colors without having to reassign from the list. Sinceit will still appear in the list without the "Not Used" notation, users will know not to use this color for a differentassignment.16. Click the Save button to apply all assignments17. Click the "Auto Assign Colors as Custom" button to freeze color assignments. This will revert all colors to thedcTrack default colors, but will mark the color as "custom". This prevents inserting a new value from changingall of the colors after the new field. For example.a. Value AAA is assigned the color Redb. Value CCC is assigned the color Bluec. Value DDD is assigned the color Greend. Inserting a value of BBB will not affect the color assignments of CCC or DDD.18. Custom colors are applied to the floor map drawing objects that have custom colors set, while the otherobjects are set using dcTrack's default colors. The Item List Panel is also displayed using the same colorscheme as the floor map.Click the icon on the color tool bar to clear the filter and return the Floor Map to its original state.You can also assign Colors by clicking the Config icon on the Floor Map tool bar and clicking on the "Color" tab onthe left side menu.

With dcTrack version 9.0.0 and beyond, the Floor Map search feature has been enhanced to allow users to applyColor Coding in conjunction with the Search. When searching with color, the results of the search are still isolated,however the search results display in the color assigned by the Color Feature. The rules for applying colors withsearch are as follows:When the search matches on a cabinet's contents but not the cabinet itself, the cabinet will display in a trans-parent light green color.When the search matches the cabinet itself, but none of the contents match, the cabinet displays in the solidcolor assigned by the color feature.When search matches the cabinet and also some of the contents, then the cabinet is displayed in the trans-parent color assigned by the color feature and the qualifying contents display in their assigned color.Example:Colors are applied based on ClassSearch on Customer = "ABC Production" - When neither Cabinet or Contents match the search the cabinet isgrayed out and collapsedIsolate match on Contents but not the Cabinet itselfCabinet is transparent Light Green.Contents are assigned actual color (Device-Green)Isolate match on Cabinet but not the ContentsCabinet is solid assigned color (Orange).Empty Cabinet because nothing qualifiedIsolate match on Cabinet and ContentsCabinet is transparent assigned color (Orange).Qualifying Contents are assigned color (Data Panel -Peach)dcTrack 8.2 allows you to visualize entire data network in a location or across locations.Network Diagrams have two type of View.Mesh View - This view displays all connected items excluding patch panels.Tier View - This view displays all connected network items.Please refer to the topics below for complete details about this feature and the steps involved in configuring networkdiagrams.Network Diagram ToolbarCreate and Manage Network DiagramConfigure Network TierConfigure Node DisplayNode InteractionsEdit and Reset Network Diagram

The Network Diagrams can be viewed in Mesh View Format. This view displays all the connected items excludingPatch Panels.To view only the leaf nodes in the Mesh View, click Display Options and uncheck Show Leaf Nodes.The Network Diagrams can be viewed in Tier View Format. This view displays all the connected network itemsYou need to Configure Network Tiers to display this view properly. See Configure Network Tier for more details.If the Network Tiers are not configured all your connected network items will show in Not assigned Tier. To includethe items not assigned to a Tier in the drawing, make sure the option Show items not assigned to Tier is checked inManage Network dialog.

The toolbar in the Data Network Diagram gives you the options to configure and manage the diagrams.Refer to the table below for more details.Manage Dia-Opens a dialog to create and manage diagrams.gramsRefresh Refreshes the diagram.Print Prints the diagramMesh View Changes the view of the diagram to Mesh View.Tier View Changes the view of the diagram to Tier View.Home Returns to home view.Search Searches for item in the diagram based on user-defined criteria.Edits the diagram and saves the updated diagram. Also provides options to undo, redo orEditreset the diagram to original position.Color Highlights the item in diagram based on Standard or Custom Field values.DisplayConfigure options for node display, links badge.OptionsTo create and manage Network Diagrams you must have user role "Manage Network Diagrams".Steps to create a diagram1. Click Gear Icon in Data Network Diagram Toolbar.2. In the Manage Network Diagram dialog -> Name and Locations, click Add a Diagram.3. Select Locations from the drop down. You can select one ore more locations.4. Select the option Show intra-location connections if the diagram is only connections within the location. If youare creating diagram for more than one location you can select Show inter-location connections which willshow the connections across the locations. Show Inter-location connections option will be disabled if the dia-gram has only one location.5. Enter name for the diagram.6. Select default view for the diagram.7. Check Default Diagram check box if you want to make this diagram as default diagram, otherwise leave itunchecked.8. Save the diagram.The newly created diagram will be added to the diagram selector drop down.You can also create a diagram from an existing diagram when by clicking Save As and entering a name for the newdiagram.Note: For each data center location a System Diagram will be created with default configuration. System diagramscan not be deleted. Name and Locations for a System Diagram can not be modified.Steps to edit diagram:1. Click Gear Icon in Data Network Diagram Toolbar.2. In the Manage Network Diagram dialog -> Name and Locations, select the diagram you want to edit. Bydefault the diagram settings of the diagram opened in Data Network Diagram screen are loaded.3. Edit the diagram information.4. Save the diagram.To delete a diagram, select the diagram you want to delete from the diagram selector at the top of the dialog andclick Delete.

Network Diagrams can be displayed in a Tier View. In this view each node in the diagram is assigned to a Tier.Steps to configure Network Tier.1. Navigate to Visualization -> Data Network Diagram. Click Gear Icon in Data Network Diagram Toolbar.2. In the Manage Network Diagram dialog -> Network Tiers, select Field Name.3. Select Field Values.4. Define Order for Network Tier. All the field values are assigned to Network Tier based on their order wherefirst one will show at the top followed by the second and so on. You can change the order alphabetically or byselecting a field value and moving it up or down by clicking Move Up or Move Down. You can assign morethan one Field Value to same Network Tier.5. Optionally select the option Show Items not connected if you want to include items that are not connected inyour diagram. If you want to include items not assigned to Tier in your diagram select the option Show Itemsnot assigned to Tier.6. Save.Network Tier configuration will be saved for the diagram selected in the diagram selector.Note: If you have not done Tier Configuration for your diagram, all the connected network nodes will show in Not-Assigned Tier.Node Display in a network diagram can be changed to Model Images, Shape and Icon.To change Node Display click Display Options in Network Diagram toolbar and select an option from the menu.Model's image for each node comes from the model's library. However Shape and Icon for the nodes can be con-figured based on item fields.1. Navigate to Visualization -> Data Network Diagrams.2. Click Gear Icon in Data Network Diagram Toolbar.3. In the Manage Network Diagram dialog -> Node Display, select display type.4. Select Field Name from the drop down.5. Select Field Values.6. For each Field Value select Shape.7. Click Save.When display type is Icon follow the same steps as mentioned above and select Icons in step 5 for each field value.Note: When selecting Field Name, make sure the items in your database have field value entered for the selectedfield.To edit the fields displayed in the tooltip:1. In the Manage Network Diagrams dialog, select Item Tooltip Fields.2. Select your desired fields from the drop-down lists. You can configure up to five fields.3. Click Save.Note: The Domain name displayed is based on Item configuration, not the IP Address assignment.

In the Network Diagram the details of a Node are displayed in a tool tip when hovering over the node.Item fields included in the tool tip are configured by clicking the Manage Diagrams button and selecting the "ItemTootlip Fields" option from the side menu panel. You can include up to 5 standard or custom fields to display in thetool tip.To get more information about each node, click the hamburger icon which is displayed when you hover a node. Youneed to zoom in your diagram to get this hamburger icon. You will get following options when you click this icon.Item Details – Navigate to item details page of that node.Port Inspector – Open the port inspector dialog.All Ports Circuit Trace - Navigate to Connectivity -> Circuit Trace showing all the data circuits for that NodeAll Ports Circuit List – Navigate to Connectivity -> Circuit list. The list is filtered to show all the data circuits forthat node.Chassis Elevation – Opens the Chassis Elevation Dialog. This option appears only when the node is aChassis.To view all the circuits between two nodes, double click on the connected line which will navigate directly to the Cir-cuit Trace page.When you hover over the connected line a tooltip will show the detailed information about the Number of Hops, Cir-cuits and Port Names for the connected nodes.You can also include the Hop Counts or Circuit Counts in the diagram. To enable this option click Display Option inthe toolbar and select the option for Link Badge.Note: All the above options apply to both Tier View and Mesh View.The position of the nodes in the network diagram can be edited. This applies to both Tier View and Mesh View. Youmust have user role Manage Network Diagrams to edit the diagram.Steps to Edit Network Diagram:1. Navigate to Visualization -> Data Network Diagrams.2. Click Edit button in Data Network Diagram toolbar.A sub-menu appears with options Undo, Redo, Reset and Save.3. Drag and drop the nodes to move them to a better spot in the diagrams. You can also select multiple nodesand move them together. This can be done by holding down the Ctrl key and then clicking to select multiplenodes or just hold the Ctrl key and drag to draw a rectangle around a group of nodes which can be movedtogether.While holding the Ctrl key if you click on a node already selected in the group, it would be unselected from thegroup.4. Click Save to save the diagram.While editing the diagram if you want to undo the last action performed, click Undo or press Ctrl + Z on the keyboard.To redo the last action performed, click Redo or press Ctrl + Y on the keyboard.You can also reset the diagram to its original position using the Reset option. All the saved positions will be deletedwhen the diagram is reset.Note: In Tier View you can drag an item up or down but within the Tier Height.

System Administrators and users with the "Manage Network Diagrams" role can choose to highlight Items on DataNetwork Diagrams by assigning colors based on Standard or Custom Field Values. For example, users can highlightand quickly see all of the Items for a single Project or multiple Projects.Note: dcTrack will assign up to 20 unique colors to the Diagram. For this reason selections are limited to 20 Items.Steps to Color Code a Data Network Diagrams:1. Navigate to the Visualization > Data Network Diagrams2. Select the Location whose Diagram you want to see3. Click the Color button on the Visualization Tool Bar4. A sub Tool Bar is displayed with a drop down list for selecting the Field you want to filter onNote: Available fields include most Standard and Custom fields with the exception of Text and Text areafields and fields that are unique for each Item (i.e. Item Name).5. Once the Field is selected the second drop down list is populated with all of the values applicable to that fieldand the "Colors" field defaults to "auto".6. The list will have all values selected, however you can deselect values to suit your needs7. The left Side panel will display the Color Code List with an Item list below. The Item list includes all items thathave a value set for the selected field. The diagram will also display with the colors applied.8. Initially dcTrack custom colors are applied9. The list as well as the Diagram can be filtered by clicking the colors in the color box.a. Click once to filter out the selected color. The color inside the clicked circle will be cleared while allother circles remain solid. The Items associated with the selected color will be removed from the ItemList and the Diagram. You may click as many colors as you like to remove those colors as well.b. Double click to filter out all colors except the selected color. The color inside the clicked circle willremain solid while the circle for all other colors will be cleared. The Item list and the Diagram will filterout all Items for every color except the selected color. You may click as many other colors as you liketo add them back in.c. Click again to restore the color list to its original state10. To set Custom colors, click the edit icon in the Color Code List11. This will open a dialog box with the Color menu open and the selected field pre-populated. The selected fieldcan be changed to set color values for a different field.12. Initally all color assignments will be set to "auto" and the Custom Color column will be empty13. To set a custom color to a field value, select it from the custom color drop down. This will display the color inthe custom color field and change the assignment from "auto" to "custom". If a custom color has not beenassigned to a value it will appear in the list with the notation "(Not used)" next to the color. You can only applya color to one value. If you attempt to assign the same color to a second value, the color will be removed fromthe first value and the Color Assignment Default for that value will be set back to "auto".14. Clicking "Clear All" will remove all custom assignments and mark the color as "Not used".15. To revert a custom color assignment, change its assignment from "custom" to "auto". This will revert the colorback to the default color assigned by dcTrack. The custom color will remain selected in the Custom Color fieldand will still appear in the color drop down list as if it was assigned. Reserving the color in this way allows youto quickly flip back and forth between custom and default colors without having to reassign from the list. Sinceit will still appear in the list without the "Not Used" notation, users will know not to use this color for a differentassignment.16. Click the Save button to apply all assignments17. Click the "Auto Assign Colors as Custom" button to freeze color assignments. This will revert all colors to thedcTrack default colors, but will mark the color as "custom". This prevents inserting a new value from changingall of the colors after the new field. For example.a. Value AAA is assigned the color Redb. Value CCC is assigned the color Bluec. Value DDD is assigned the color Greend. Inserting a value of BBB will not affect the color assignments of CCC or DDD.18. Custom colors are applied to the Diagram drawing objects that have custom colors set, while the otherobjects are set using dcTrack's default colors. The Item List Panel is also displayed using the same colorscheme as the Diagram.Click the icon on the color tool bar to clear the filter and return the Diagram to its original state.21. You can also assign Colors by clicking the Config icon on the Diagram tool bar and clicking on the "Color" tabon the left side menu.dcTrack 9.0.0 includes a new Power Single Line Diagram (SLD) feature. This feature allows users to visualize theentire Power Chain and use this view to understand connectivity and relationships. Users can also view readingsand capacities at a glance to better understand load balancing and Fail-over impacts.This feature can be managed by System Administrators and Users that have the new auxiliary role"Manage PowerSLD" role. Please refer to the documentation on Auxiliary Functional roles for additional information.Generating a Power Single Line DiagramConfiguring a Power Single Line Diagram

To create and manage Power Single Line Diagrams users must have the "System Administrator" or "Manage PowerSLD" role.Steps to create a diagram1. Navigate to Visualization > Power Single Line Diagrams2. Select the Location you wish to generate the Diagram forAll of the power items in all descendant locations will be included in the single Line Diagram. Forexample if a Data Center has 2 Rooms and the Data Center level is selected, power items from bothrooms will be displayed in the diagram. If a specific Room is selected only power items for that roomwill be displayed in the diagram.3. The Diagram is automatically generated based on the connections you have defined in dcTrack4. The panel on the left is an Item list containing all the Facility Items reflected on the diagram. Note will not beall the Items in the data center.5. To obtain additional details about any Item, select the Item either from the Item List on the left or clicking theItem in the diagram. This will display the detail panel which contains the power sum information for the item.The readings for the Item will come from Power IQ if the item is integrated or they can be entered using theActual Readings API.The top of the diagram will always start with an AC Service class item, if not present then a generator, if neither ispresent a UPS Bank item. The objects rendered in the chain will end when a Floor PDU is reached.6. For very detailed diagrams, zooming in will allow you to see the labels and other pertinent electrical char-acteristics more clearly7. Clicking the Print button in the tool bar will allow you to print a copy of the diagram image.Note, if you are already using the power chain currently in dcTrack, the Floor PDUs, UPS Banks, and UPS alreadyexist, and will be displayed on the diagram.For additional information about modifying the layout and features of the automatically generated Single Line Dia-gram see Configure Power Single Line DiagramsWhile Power Single Line Diagrams are generated automatically, they can be configured to suit you needs.Steps to configure a diagram1. Click the configure icon in the tool bar2. On the Configuration screen, you can choose up to 5 Item fields to appear in the tool tip on the diagram. Thedrop down list contains all Item Standard and Custom fields.3. The fields you select will appear in tool tips in addition to 5 default fields which are:Class/SubclassItem NameMakeModelStatus4. These settings apply to the currently selected Location. To configure settings for a different Location, selectthe location from the Location drop down5. To apply these settings to all Locations click the "Apply to All Location" button6. To move items on the diagram, click the Edit button available on the tool bar to enter Edit Mode.7. While in Edit Mode you can drag-and drop items to move them to a better place on the diagram. When drag-ging an Item, the connected lines will move with the Item. These lines can also be adjusted to add or removeturns and reduce overlap, however all lines will be rectilinear.8. To move multiple Items together, you can select multiple Items by drawing a rectangle around the Items. Youcan also select multiple Items by holding down the CTRL key and clicking on the Items.9. Click the "Undo" button on the tool bar to undo the last change10. Click the "Redo" button on the tool bar to reinstate the last change that was un-done.11. Click the "Reset" button to restore the diagram to its original state12. Click "Save" to save you changes. The saved diagram will load each time the Location is selected.13. You can resize the digram using the magnifiers in the lower right corner of the diagram or use the scroll buttonon your mouse14. Click the "Home" button in the tool bar to restore the diagram to its size the last time the diagram was saved.

dcTrack includes a World Map feature enabling you to visualize your data center infrastructures across the world.The World Map is accessed from the Visualization menu. It provides a tree view of all your locations as well as avisual representation of their locations.The hierarchy of the tree is Country > Data Center > Floor > Room. If the address of the Location has been suppliedthe tree will display a building icon next to the Location, if not a question mark "?" icon is displayed.Setting up the World Mapa. Navigate to Settings > Integration > World Mapb. Both a Tile Server and Geocoding Server are automatically provided upon installing dcTrack version9.0.0. These servers can be replaced to utilize your own servers. Both servers are required to properlyrender the World Map in dcTrack.The Tile Server provides the image tiles. Image tiles are small square image files that arestitched together to look like a single large image of the map. The tile server must allow crossorigin requests in order for the test connection button to work correctly.The Geocoding Server points to a web service that takes in an address and returns the cor-responding location coordinates.

a. Navigate to Visualization > World Mapb. The left panel of the page will display the country of every location in your data basec. Click the arrow to expand the treed. A node is displayed for each data center. If the data center has children, click the arrow next to thedata center to display the children nodese. If an address has been supplied for the data center, it is displayed with a building icon in front of thenamef. If no address was displayed for the data center, or if the Longitude and Latitude can not be determinedfrom the address supplied, the data center is displayed with a leading "?".g. An pin icon is placed on the map for the location of each data center3. Right click on any level or any pin icon to display its sub-menu with options applicable to each level- Jump to location details in Edit mode where address can be sup-plied - Available on Data Centers whose address is invalid- Jump to the Floormap for the selected location - Available onData Center level only- Jump to the locations Details page in view mode- Jump to the Item List filtered to Items located in the selected loc-ation- Jump to the add a location detail page to add a new location- Rename the selected location- Jump to the add an Item page with the selected location pre-pop-ulated4. Hover over the Data Center icon to view health statistics5. Double Click any icon pin to navigate to the Floor Map for that location provided one exists6. World Map tool bara. Click the refresh button to collapse the location tree on the left and reposition the Map to the area thatencompasses all of your locationsb. Click the print button to print an image of the mapc. Click the world button to reposition the Map to the area that encompasses all of your locationswithout collapsing the location treed. Click the Health button to display the Pin icons in a color (red, yellow, green) that represents thehealth state of the Location (the same as the Dasgboard Enterprise Health tiles)e. Click the Show Labels button to display pin labels on the map. This button allows usersto toggle between hiding and showing pin labels. This setting is per user and will remain the setting until theuser clicks the button to change the view. The default is Hidden.f. Click the Resolve Address button to have dcTrack calculate the Longitude and Latitude for any data cen-ters with addresses that do not have a Longitude and Latitude set.See Also Dynamic Content-Security-Policy.This section covers the asset management features available in dcTrack.

The Asset tab in dcTrack has been enhanced to make it faster and easier for you to find items, including a new andimproved Asset Management toolbar:Add an Item Opens a new page to add an itemView Opens one or more selected Item Details pages in View modeEdit Opens one or more selected Item Details pages in Edit modeBulk Edit Edit multiple selected ItemsClone Opens one or more clones of the selected Item Details pagesActions Dropdown that enables you to make item requestsDelete Deletes the selected itemsRefresh Refreshes the Item Details pageReports Prints an Item Details report for the selected itemExport Dropdown where you can export the Items List or download the Import TemplateShare Generates a share link to the current Items List viewFloor Maps View the selected item on the floor map in the Visualization tabPort Inspector View Port Placement for selected ItemPermissions Add or delete permissions. Only available to users with the appropriate permissions.The Items List now can be filtered based on criteria for any of the available columns:You can reorder the columns by dragging and dropping. You can also edit an Item’s Name, Alias, Type, Function,Contact, Contact Team and Customer, PO Number, Project Number, Purchase Price, Contract Amount, LocationRef and Notes in line in the Items List.As with the floor map search results and other dcTrack features, you can save and share your current view by click-ing the Views dropdown and clicking the Save Current List Settings As… icon. Multiple list views are available foreach user. To clear the view, click the Clear icon in the right corner.

When pasting into the filter input box of a column in any of the full-page lists that support querying with “OR”,dcTrack will no longer insert an “OR” between every space in the string. dcTrack has been enhanced to only insertan “OR” when a Carriage Return/Line Feed (CRLF) is detected. This new feature allows users to copy columns ofdata from a spreadsheet or multiple lines from a text editor and paste it into a dcTrack list to search by all the row val-ues of this column. For example, a column of strings you would like to search for can be copied directly from Exceland pasted into dcTrack for immediate filtering. When the data is pasted, dcTrack will automatically surround eachstring with double quotes forcing exact match filtering on each string. You can, however, also choose to toggle thedouble quotes off in which case dcTrack will perform a contains search on each string. Pressing CTRL+Q on yourkeyboard toggles the quotes on and off.Note: When pasting on top of existing text, if the pasted text does not contain CRLF, then it will paste it where thecursor or highlight was in the existing text. But if the pasted text does contain CRLF, then it will overwrite the exist-ing text completely.dcTrack version 8.1.1 includes a new “Copy to Clipboard” option in the column headers for all full-page lists. Userscan copy the value of a single cell, a single cell on multiple rows, or an entire column of data. When this feature isused, data can be pasted into spreadsheets or other applications, and each cell will be pasted as a separate row.Users can also paste the data as filter criteria in any dcTrack list filter input box and the data of multiple cells willhave an “OR” inserted.To copy data of one cell, select the row of that cell. To copy multiple cells of a column, use the CTRL or SHIFT keysand select those rows. To copy an entire column, no selections are needed before clicking the Copy to Clipboardoption. Note however, that an entire column refers to the rows that have been loaded which is identified in the ListStatus bar just above the list.

As a further enhancement to the “Copy to Clipboard” feature introduce in dcTrack 8.1.1 which allows users to copyand paste columns of data, dcTrack 8.1.2 now supports copying and pasting rows of data. When one or more rowsare selected, users can copy the selected rows by pressing “CTRL+C” or by clicking the copy icon that appears inthe list filter status bar near the (x Selected) label. When either action is taken, the (x Selected) label changes to (xCopied) for 1 second to indicate the copy was performed. The copied data can then be pasted into other editors.When pasting into Excel, the rows and columns are preserved including the dcTrack column headers.The Copy Row feature is supported in the following major lists:Locations List Work Orders ListItems List Projects ListParts List Tickets ListParts Transactions EventsCircuits List Models LibraryStructured Cabling List Connectors LibraryRequests List Parts LibrarydcTrack version 9.0.0 can now support hyperlinks for any text field on the Item list. If a text field, either Standard orCustom contains a valid URL it will be converted into a hyperlink. This will allow users to navigate directly from thelist without having to access the Item Details page. As with hyperlinks on the Detail page, the hyperlinks on the Itemslist will always open in a new tab.

To specify which columns are shown or hidden, click the Show/Hide columns icon in the upper right corner:The Show/Hide Columns dialog displays. All columns are displayed by class. You can check or uncheck the boxnext to each to show or hide the corresponding column.At the top of the dialog are filtering capabilities. You can search for columns by typing your criteria into the searchbox, specify standard or custom fields, filter by panel on the Item Details page, or select Shown or Hidden columns.The available columns will update automatically based on your selections.To save your selections, click the Apply icon.Being able to provide a dcTrack user with a link to a specific Item Details or Search results or Reports page can savetime and simplify the process of sharing information. With a shareable link, users can copy and paste the link intoother applications and share it with their team, without having to explain how to navigate to the specific page ordefine the exact search parameters. The link obscures any information that may otherwise be included in the URLthat is not intended to be shared with all users.To share a link to your Items List search or filtered results, click the Share icon on the Asset Management toolbar.In the Get Quick Link dialog, copy the link and paste it into your email, chat, or other applications where you wouldlike to share the link. Any logged-in dcTrack user will be able to see the same results, except for any items that theydo not have permissions to view.

dcTrack's Bulk Edit feature allows you to edit multiple fields, both Standard and Custom, across multiple Items dir-ectly from the Web UI. This feature can be used as an alternative to File Import when there is a need to quicklyupdate information for a large number of Items. Bulk Edit enforces all of the same rules as editing a single Item.Because of this when editing Items for a variety of Classes, the fields eligible for selection is limited to only thosefields that apply to each of the selected Item's Classes. For example the "Type" and "Function" fields would containdifferent selection options depending on the Class of the Item you are editing. For this reason, these fields would notappear in the "Field to edit" list if the Items being edited are for multiple Classes. Similarly, Custom Fields that arenot applicable to all of the selected Item's Classes would also not appear in the list.Note: Operators must have the "Bulk Import" Role assigned to use this feature.Note: Class is a required column for bulk editing.Steps to Bulk Edit Item fields:1. Navigate to the Asset > Asset List2. Filter and select the Items you wish to edit and click the Bulk Edit button on the Tool Bar.3. Upon clicking the Bulk Edit button the Bulk Edit dialog is displayed.The dialog includes the number of selected Items and a list of the Classes associated with the selected Items.If multiple Classes are included in the Edit, a warning message is displayed indicating that because multipleClasses are involved, certain fields cannot be edited.4. Select the Field you wish to edit from the Field List. You can also search for Fields by typing the Field Nameinto the Search box. A field can only be selected a single time. Once selected the field is removed from thelist.5. After selecting the Field to be edited, you may enter new values in the "New Value" field or select the "Clear"check box to clear the field value.Clicking the "Clear" option will clear all the data in this field for each selected Item.Entering a "New Value" will update the field with the new value for all of the selected Items. The type ofentry depends on the individual Field Type.For Single Select Pick List fields you will be required to select a single option from a listFor Multi Select Pick List fields you may select one or more options from a listFor Date Fields you may select a date from the Date Selector or you may enter a date directlyinto the fieldFor Check Box Fields will present as a Check Box that you may check or leave uncheckedText and Numeric fields will present as a text field where you may enter a value6. As the data for each row is completed, a new row is created allowing you to select another field to edit.Note: You may edit a maximum of 5 fields at a time.7. When you have completed your edits, Click the Apply button to apply the changes to the selected records.8. After Clicking the Apply button, a Progress Bar is displayed showing the progress of the changes.9. Upon Completion you will receive a message indication the number of Items updated and the number ofItems skipped. Items could by skipped for various reasons. For example if a user has view only permission onone or more of the Items, or an Item has a pending Request issued.10. The asset list automatically refreshes after a bulk edit operation.The following is detailed information and step-by-step instructions on the File Import feature.

Use File Import in the Web Client to:Create data center locations, cabinets, items, connections, ports and parts.Move Cabinets, Rackable Devices and BladesNote: dcTrack checks to ensure you do not exceed your cabinet licenses. Cabinets that exceed the license limit arenot imported and dcTrack informs you of this.Perform the following operations for cabinet items, device items, connections and ports:ADDEDITDELETEAdditionally the following operation is available for Cabinets, Rackable Devices and BladesMOVE - For additional information on MOVE see Use File Import to Move Cabinets, Rackable Devicesand Blades.For information on using EDIT and DELETE, see Use File Import to Edit or Delete Locations, Cabinets, Items orConnections.All item classes and subclasses can be added, edited and deleted using File Import. You can delete items so long asthey are in a Planned status and you have edit access to the location and cabinet.Note: dcTrack checks to ensure you do not exceed your cabinet licenses. Cabinets that exceed the license limit arenot imported and dcTrack informs you of this.

Sunbird provides Import Templates that can be downloaded directly from the Import menu available on the Main toolbar.The Import Templates are designed to make the import process as easy as possible.Sunbird highly recommends using the sample templates or exporting into an Import template even if you have yourown spreadsheets already. You can copy and paste your data into the Import Template if you are using your ownspreadsheet, then "clean it" based on the standards outlined in the spreadsheet. This ensures the import runssmoothly.The Import Template includes the most commonly required fields needed to perform imports and updates, as well asa listing of additional fields you can add.Instructions on the data you must enter in each field, as well as sample data, are also included in the Import Tem-plate.File Import supports .XLS, XLSX and .CSV file formats.It is good practice to capture all of your data for all of your locations in a single Import Template and use that as aPrimary template. You can then save copies as individual import files - one for locations, one for cabinets, one forrack PDUs and so on.

Importing a spreadsheet does not import the data on each worksheet at once; you must import each worksheet'sdata separately.It is recommended that you create an import file for each item type and connection type, and delete the worksheetsthat are not being imported. Doing this helps ensure you do not import the same item's data more than once andmakes tracking your imports easier.It is also good practice to delete the worksheets that are not part of the import. However, leaving the other work-sheets in the import file does not cause the import to fail - the data are simply not imported.If you do not create individual import files, be sure you open the right worksheet in the primary file when you performthe import. File Import imports the locations/items/connections on the worksheet that is open - all other worksheetsare ignored during the import. For example, rack PDUs are imported if that the Rack PDU worksheet is open, but noother data on any other worksheet is imported.Delete any blank worksheets in the spreadsheet, if applicable. And ensure there are not hidden worksheets in thetemplate. By default, there are no hidden worksheets, but if you marked worksheets as hidden, delete them.

It is recommended you follow the import order laid out by each of the template's worksheets - Step 1 Locations (ifapplicable), Step 2 Cabinets, Step 3 Rack PDUs and so on.Do this because you cannot reference items that are not already imported. For example, you cannot create a powerconnection to a rack PDU that does not already exist in dcTrack.Sample data and other default information are preceded in the spreadsheet by a hashtag #. For example - # Fieldsthat are required to add an item are indicated by an asterisk *.The hashtag tells dcTrack not to import the data the follows it. You do not have to delete this data from the spread-sheet to successfully import.If you want to included information, for example notes, in the spreadsheet and want it to be ignored during theimport, insert a # in front of it.Note: If you perform a File Import and the expected data was not imported, verify data are not preceded by ahashtag. Since dcTrack ignores the data after a hashtag, warnings or errors are not generated, but the data are notimported.Note: You must leave the hashtag # in front of "Operation". # Operation is a template field; it is not meant to beimported into dcTrack.

Following are high-level notes on entering data into a spreadsheet. These are notes on various import fields. Spe-cific instructions for each field are provided in the worksheet.For information on syncing dcTrack and Power IQ data during an import, see Use File Import to Sync IntegrateddcTrack and Power IQ.Required fields in the template are indicated by an asterisk*. The data will not import unless required fields areentered. Required fields change depending on the item and operation.When adding and item or connection, if the status is not entered in the spreadsheet, it is imported in a Plannedstatus. Optionally, you can change an item's status during the import to either Installed or Storage.To add items in an Installed status, you must complete fields marked with two asterisk **.When entering US States, use full state names – do not use abbreviations. To view a list of States, ppen a Location inEdit mode and view the State drop-down list.If you configure a location to use SI (metric) units, you must provide metric values in the spreadsheet for that loc-ation.To add a data center image file for each location during an import, enter the images location in the Locate PicturePath.The fields that appear by default on each spreadsheet are required fields and commonly used fields.In addition to these fields, you can copy and paste fields from among those listed on the item’s corresponding"Applicable Fields" worksheet or "AllAppicableFields" worksheet. For example, you can add a Serial Number fieldfor Device Item imports by copying and pasting the field from the "All Applicable Fields" worksheet.

When you initially access an import file, dcTrack verifies it is in a proper file format and reports any file format errors.Once you click Begin Import, dcTrack performs a line-by-line validation and reports errors encountered for a line. Alloperations (ADD/EDIT/DELETE) that are valid are completed. Only those operations where errors are encounteredare not completed. You can correct those errors and re-import with the updated data.Warning and error information are presented in the File Import dialog in the Results section.Warnings are displayed when data may require attention but are not considered invalid, such as port index conflictsresolved automatically on import.An error may be a duplicate name or invalid number of characters in a field. When an error is encountered, dcTrackdisplays the invalid data as well as the line on the spreadsheet the data is entered.Errors must be fixed before that row of data can be successfully imported. However, the remaining data in thespreadsheet are imported so long as they are valid.Use the Save Results to File function. This allows you to save a file with only rows containing invalid data causingerrors. You can then make changes directly to that file and then re-import it.Alternatively, highlight the information in the Results section, then use Ctrl+C to copy and paste the information to afile. Reference the information when you update the incorrect data.

Select Proceed on Warning if you want dcTrack to continue with the import but display data that caused the warning.For example, duplicate serial numbers on items can generate a warning.If Proceed on Warning is not selected, dcTrack does not import the data.

The following steps cover importing locations, verifying locations were imported, importing items and connections,verifying items and connections were imported, and uploading and syncing drawing files with locations.1. Import locations first if you have not already done so. Once locations exist in dcTrack, import items and con-nections.2. Begin a File Import by clicking the Import button in the dcTrack main tool bar3. Once you select the File Import option, the File Import dialog opens. Use Browse to locate the import file.As soon as you select the import file, the file is validated by dcTrack to ensure it is formatted correctly. All errorsencountered during file validation must be corrected before proceeding to 'Process Import'.4. If no validation errors are found or once corrected, click the green arrow on the right of the process bar to con-tinue to the Process Import step.Warning or errors are displayed, if found.As dcTrack imports your data, a progress bar is displayed at the bottom of the window.5. Once the import is complete, you can go on to view the newly added locations, begin another import session, orselect any option from the top menu bar to move to another activity.Any errors encountered during import are listed in the Results section of the File Import dialog, and all valid data areimported.Select "Save Results to File" to create a file containing only invalid data. You can then fix the issues and import thedata again.6. Locations appear in the Default Location drop-down, Location drop-down, on the Items List under Assets and soon.7. If you entered TRUE for "Enable Virtual Power Chain", ensure VPC is enabled by selecting Assets > Locationsin the Web Client.8. The VPC checkbox is selected for locations that are VPC enabled.If VPC is not enabled for a location, you can enable it from this page.9. If needed, integrate dcTrack with one or more Power IQs. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > ApplicationAdministration and open the Power IQ Integration Settings tab. You can then use File Import to sync integratedPower IQs. See Use File Import to Sync Integrated dcTrack and Power IQ.10. Next, import cabinets and items if you have not already done so.11. You can perform this step now or at a later time, but note that cabinets and items must exist in the data center inorder to sync drawing files. Otherwise, you must map or import them after syncing.12. Use File Import and follow the same steps that are outlined above.No readings are displayed in the widgets on the Web Client Dashboard until:Items that can send SNMP readings are added and configured to send them, and/or you are integrated withPower IQ.Items sending readings are powered on.This is also true on item pages once items are added.14. Import power and data connections once items are imported.15. You can perform this step now or at a later time.16. Use File Import and follow the same steps that are outlined above.17. To view newly added items or connections, click Refresh on the Items List or Circuits List page.Note: For items, filter the list by Origin = Import. You can also filter by Location so only imported items for the spe-cified location are displayed.18. Next, upload each location’s drawing file, if applicable.This is done in the Web Client using the Upload feature on the Floor Maps page.Upload each data center's drawing file separately.19. Click on the Visualization tab to open the Floor Maps page.20. From the Location drop-down, select the location you want to upload the drawing file to.21. Click Settings if the Upload icon is not displayed already.22. Click Upload, then use browse to locate and select the .DWG file.The upload time may vary depending on file size and network speed.Once the file has uploaded, a processing message is displayed while dcTrack processes and syncs the file.dcTrack syncs the objects in the drawing file with existing dcTrack items of the same name.Processing typically takes a few seconds, and does not require you to stay on the Floor Maps page.A message indicates when the file is being rendered. Click OK to close it or allow it to close on its own.A successful upload is indicated by the floor map appearing and a green checkmark icon at the top of the page.The floor map loads, and all synced cabinets are listed in the Items List on the left.23. Cabinets and items that are not synced during the drawing file upload must be synced using the Sync Button onthe Floormap tool bar.Items that are not sync'd will have a status value of "No Match" in the Item ListTo sync objects:24. Click the Sync button on the tool bar25. Select the unmatched item from the item list26. Click on the corresponding match in the Floor Map27. Click the Sync Selected Item in List and Drawing buttonIf Power IQ Integration is configured and enabled for a location, you can sync individual locations or items fromdcTrack to existing data centers or assets from PIQ.Steps to Integrate dcTrack and Power IQ using file import:1. Verify the hierarchy and Location names in dcTrack match Power IQ2. Generate an export file from Power IQ using the external export feature. This export includes all of thecolumns required by dcTrack's Import feature.To access the external Export use https://<Power IQ IP Address>/admin/integration/export3. From the dcTrack Location Detail page, associate the Location you wish to synchronize with the appropriatePower IQ instance4. Navigate to Settings > Data Model Sync to verify the dcTrack Location's status is Integrated5. If not all Floors and Rooms appear as integrated use the Map Action in Data Model Sync to Map them.a. Select the entity you want to map (Floor, Room) on the left side (dcTrack side) of the page.b. Select the associated Power IQ entity to be mapped on the right side of the pagec. Click the Map option on the Actions menu6. Import the Rows, Cabinets, Rack PDUs and devices using the CSV file generated in Step 2.7. Before importing make sure you change the Operation in the file to MAP8. Navigate back to Data Model Sync9. Refresh the page10. Verify the Status of each entity (Location, Floors, Rooms, Aisles, Rows, Cabinets, Rack PDUs, devices) isIntegratedIf Power IQ Integration is configured and enabled for a location, you can sync individual locations or items fromdcTrack to existing data centers or assets from PIQ.When entering Power IQ information enter:Power IQ Appliance Name, IP Address or Hostname: This information is provided by your network SystemAdministrator.Power IQ Object External KeyThe Power IQ Object External Key can be pulled from Power IQ by doing the following:1. In the Power IQ, open the Settings tab.2. Click Enterprise Relationships.3. In the CSV Data Mapping Actions section, click Export Relationships.A .CSV file such as this is generated. The fields that are circled indicate the information you need. You can copy andpaste this information into the Import Template.Insert a new line for each location or item, and enter the required integration information.You can then add the following information to your integrated Power IQs using File Import.

Before you can import data and power connections into dcTrack, the items used in the connections must exist. So,import your rack PDUs, devices and so on. Add or configure ports on devices if needed. Note that you can manuallyadd your items instead of importing them.You must also create your power infrastructure in dcTrack. This means adding Cooling units and then adding theCooling Units to Cooling Zones, adding UPS units and adding UPS units to UPS banks, and creating your floorPDUs, breakers, poles, busways and so on. See Add and Configure Power Infrastructure Items - Cooling Units,UPS Units and Floor PDUs.

Use the Create Power Connections worksheet in the Import Template to create power connections and import theminto dcTrack.The connections between all of the items in a power chain form a complete circuit.'Power connections' refers a connection between a starting item, such as a server or switch, and an ending item thatis either a rack PDU or outlet.It is important to designate the item's power supply port as the starting point, and the power outlet's input power portor rack PDU's input power port, as the ending item.Once connected, these form the first half of a power circuit.The remaining portion of the circuit is the upstream power connection to the power source, which consist of the floorPDU, power panel or busway, and UPS unit.These connections already exist in dcTrack. They are created when you create your structured cabling.Note: You can use the File Import to import power outlet circuiting. This eliminates having to manually create cir-cuits from power outlets to either busways or power panels on existing floor PDUs.Alternatively, you can connect items to virtual power chains if you are not ready to create 'normal' power circuits.Connect items to virtual power chains manually, or import virtual power chain connections in bulk using the FileImport.You cannot use a single file that includes a variety of hop quantities for each circuit. Make one file for all circuits thatuse no cabling hops, one file for those that have only one hop, one file for those with 2 hops and one file for thosewith 3 hops.For a list of the requirements and/or prerequisites, as well as recommendations and examples of spreadsheets, seethe worksheets in the templates.Importing power connections follows the same basic steps using the File Import as other imports.(Optional) Verify the circuits are imported by looking them up. Use the search and filter options on the Circuits List inthe Web Client.You can submit Connect Requests for one or more circuits now or at a later time. Submit a request in the Web Clientfrom the Actions menu on the Circuits List.See Submit Circuit Requests from the Actions Menu.
Your structured cabling layout must already exist in dcTrack before importing connections.

Use the Create Data Connections worksheet in the Import Template to create data connections and import them intodcTrack.Data circuits can consist of up to eight end points:1 end point at the beginning of the circuit ~ 1 end point at the end of the circuit with up to 3 hops in between, eachconsisting of 2 end points.A spreadsheet file cannot include circuits that have a different number of hops. So, create individual import files for:Circuits with no cabling hopsCircuits with 1 hopCircuits with 2 hopsCircuits with 3 hopsWatch a video on how to use file import template on the Support Portal.This topic outlines how to create a file that will import Virtual Power Chain connections. For detailed steps on usingthe File Import feature, see Use File Import to Add, Edit Delete and Move.System Administrators and Gatekeepers can also add VPCs manually in the Web Client. For details on File Import,see Manually Create Virtual Power Chain Connections.The Virtual Power Chains created from the spreadsheet are made up of connections between existing dcTrackitems and virtual items in the Virtual Power Chain.Therefore, the items that will be connected to the Virtual Power Chain connections must exist in dcTrack. Using FileImport to add the items or add them manually. See Use File Import to Add, Edit Delete and Move and Add andEdit Items.Virtual Power Chain must be enabled for the location(s). You can enable VPC when adding locations manually orwhen importing locations using File Import by setting the Enable Virtual Power Chain field to TRUE in the ImportTemplate. See Enable or Disable VPC for a Location and Use File Import to Add, Edit Delete and Move, respect-ively.Note that you do not need to create the items that make up the Virtual Power Chain; these Virtual Power Chainitems exist by default.

Using File Import to bulk import power outlet circuiting greatly reduces the amount of time it takes to build your infra-structure in dcTrack.Bulk importing eliminates the need to create each power outlet manually in the Web Client, and then create eachconnection from the power outlet to either a busway or power panel.In order to bulk import power outlet circuiting, you must first add and configure your floor PDUs and either each floorPDU's busway (without poles) or each floor PDU's power panel (with poles and breakers). Whether you createbusways or power panels depends on your infrastructure requirements.Use the 07_ Power_Outlet_Circuiting_Import_Wizard_Spreadsheet_dcTrack5.x.xls template to import power outletcircuiting.Carefully review the prerequisites for importing power outlet circuiting before you begin. Prerequisites are providedin the Sunbird template, and in this topic.Before beginning a power outlet circuiting import, the following prerequisites must be met.Manually add or use File Import to bulk import your floor PDUs. These can be in the same or a different location. SeeAdd and Configure Power Infrastructure Items - Cooling Units, UPS Units and Floor PDUs.Manually add or use File Import to bulk import these items. See Manually Configure a Floor PDU for Power OutletCircuiting Imports.Power Panel Outlets:Each floor PDU's power panel the power panel's poles and breakers are created in dcTrack.The power outlets are created and do not contain any ports in dcTrackBusway Power Outlets:Each Floor PDU and its busways are created in dcTrackThe power outlets are created and do not contain any ports, poles or breakers in dcTrack.If you bulk import these items, use the 02_ All_Items_Import_Wizard_Spreadsheet_dcTrack5.x.xls template.

To import power outlet circuiting, use the Power Outlet Circuit worksheet of the Import Template.All spreadsheet columns are required for power outlet circuiting imports.If you are importing power outlet circuiting for both power panels and busways, perform separate imports using sep-arate spreadsheets.

This feature is available from the Items List, Connectivity List and Project List toolbars. Filter the Items List to containthe records you want to Export. From the List tool bar, click the "Export" menu button and select the "Export into anImport Template" option. For Items, you can additionally select from a list of Templates available for export.When exporting Items, two additional options are available, "All Columns", "Visible Columns". The "All Columns"option will export all columns applicable to the Item including all Custom Fields. The "Visible Columns" option dis-plays only the Columns currently in the grid as well as any fields required by Import that are not in the current grid.Using templates makes exports easier since you do not have to manually filter data in dcTrack to ensure therequired fields are exported. And, since the required fields are exported to the template by default, this feature alsohelps ensure re-imports run smoothly.Use this feature if, for example, you want to add serial numbers to a large number of items using the File ImportEDIT operation.To do this, export the data to the Item template so data for all required fields are exported. In the export template,required are identified with an asterisk and prepopulated with each data. You can then insert a Serial Numbercolumn in the spreadsheet, if needed, enter the serial numbers for each item, and reimport the file.Note : When exporting the data with the 'Visible Columns' option, some columns not visible in the list are stillincluded in the exported file and marked with double asterisks.Any filters that are applied to the list view are applied to the template file.Note: This feature is not available for Intelligent Capacity Search results.dcTrack provides you with the ability to export items and connections from the Items List and Circuits List, respect-ively. This feature is useful for exporting data that you want to import into a third party system that does not requirethe same columns required by dcTrack's import feature.From the Item list click the Export Button on the grid list toolbar and select the "Export Items Exactly as Shown"option. You can then select to export "All Rows", or only the "First 500 rows".When "All Rows" is selected, all of the records that satisfy the current filter in the grid are exported. This includesrows beyond the visible portion of the grid.When "First 500 rows" is selected, only the first 500 records based on the current sort are exported.Any filters and sorting that are applied to the list view are applied to the export file. If you added fields to the list view,they are included in the template while fields you removed are not included.From the Connectivity List Click the Export button on the tool bar and select the "Export Circuits" option.For information on specifying a save location, see How to Specify a Default Save Location for Downloaded Files.Note: If you change the order of the columns on the page, remove or add fields and so on, you can make that thedefault view for the list. Select the "Views" icon on the tool bar and then select "Save Current List Settings as...".A Filter information you want to include in the export. For example, filter the list so only specific loc-ations are included and only items in a Planned status at that location are included.B Add or remove fields from the view and then export data. Only the columns that are still visible are includedin the export.C Move columns by clicking on them and dragging them to a new position in the list view. The columns appearin the export file in the order you specify.

After performing an Intelligent Capacity Search, cabinets that meet the parameters your specified are listed in theResults section of the Intelligent Capacity Search page. This export is useful for auditing free cabinet space, determ-ining available ports, determining the amount of free watts per cabinet, and locating the far end connection to cab-inets to name just a few.You can sort the results in the Results list by clicking on a column header. You can also reorder the columns by click-ing on them and dragging them to a new position. When you export, the sort order of the items and the order of thecolumns is applied in the export file.

In addition to using File Import to add locations, items and connections, you can use it to update information and per-form deletes.To do this, first use the Export to Template feature in dcTrack to export the data you want to edit or delete. Next,make changes to the template and reimport it. Use the EDIT or DELETE operation, as needed. See Export Data toImport Templates for Reimporting.You can update information for an item or delete an item so long as you have edit access to it.Updates can include, but are not limited to, bulk renaming items, assigning IP addresses in bulk to ports, changingthe status of items in bulk, deleting items or connections with a status of Planned, in bulk and so on.

Updates may include bulk name changes, adding information to existing items such as serial numbers, updatingrack PDU IP addresses, modifying Part Numbers on Installed Items and so on.Enter EDIT in the # Operation fields for each item you want to update.Update information, as needed.For example, change item names by inserting a New Name column in the Device Items worksheet, enter the newitem names and update them using File Import.Complete all required and use the instructions on the page as a guideline for each field.Complete all required fields.OperationObjectNameLocationAdd columns to worksheets, if needed. Refer to the item's corresponding "Additional" worksheet that is found inthe template.Follow the same steps to perform an import that are described in Add Cabinets, Items, Ports and Connectionswith File Import.Select Proceed on Warning if you want dcTrack to continue with the import but display data that caused thewarning. For example, duplicate serial numbers on items can generate a warning.It is also possible to modify Part Number on an Installed Item. This might be necessary if you have two Models withthe same Model Name but different Part Numbers and an Item was linked to the wrong Model. If the Item is in aPlanned status, you can simply modify the Item from the Item Detail page, however this is not possible on InstalledItems within the UI. In this case you should use File Import to make the change as follows.1. Export the Item using the "Export into an Import Template" option (you can also manually create the importfile).2. Change the operation to "UPDATE MODEL"3. Enter the following information# Operation * Object * Location * Name * Make * Model * New Part Number *4. Import the file into dcTrackTo use this feature the new model must have the same Model Name, Class, Subclass, Mounting, Form Factor andRU Height as the original Model. Please note, the Model cannot be changed for an Item in the Archived status, andthe change will not affect the Items Ports.If Proceed on Warning is not selected, dcTrack does not import the data.Use the DELETE operation to delete items and connections in bulk. For example, if you added cabinets to the wronglocation, delete the cabinets at once using File Import.All delete rules that apply when deleting items individually apply to deleting items in bulk:The item must be in a Planned stateNo open requests or work orders can exist for the itemYou must be the person who created the item or have edit privileges to the itemThe item cannot be deleted if a power or data connection exists to itDeleting an item may impact other items it is associated with, as well as any connections. This is why you cannotsimply open a cabinet's item page and delete an item from that page for example.When you delete items, additional ports created for the item, IP addresses, applications added to it, and so on, isalso deleted.The item is permanently deleted from the database.If it is linked to an object on the floor map, that link is severed but the object itself is not affected.It is removed from the cabinet elevation if it was added to a cabinet.To delete items:Enter DELETE in the # Operation field.Complete all required fields.OperationObjectNameLocationFollow the same steps to perform an import that are described in Add Cabinets, Items, Ports and Connectionswith File Import.Note that you are not prompted to confirm the deletion.Refresh the Items List or Circuits List to ensure the items were deleted.

This topic outlines how to create an import file that will bulk change the status of items.For detailed steps on using the File Import feature, see Use File Import to Add, Edit Delete and MoveYou can update item statuses so long as you have edit access to the location and items.Export the items you want to update.Ensure the Operation is set to Edit.Complete all fields with a double asterisk**.Complete all required fields marked with an asterisk*.Change the status for each item in the Status column.Use File Import to reimport the items.This topic outlines how to create an import file that will rename items in bulk. For detailed steps on using the FileImport feature, see Use File Import to Add, Edit Delete and Move.This is a useful feature if, for example, you have cloned one or more items and now need to rename the clones.1. First, filter the Items List so only the items you want to export and rename are listed. In this example, clones arelisted.2. Use the Export feature in dcTrack to export the items.3. Export the items to the Item template so all required fields for a successful import are included. Note that a NewName column is included in the Item template.4. Save the file locally.5. Once the items are successfully exported, you will be prompted to save the file locally.6. Open the Item import template you just created.7. The # Operation field will be set to EDIT. Note that you must leave the hashtag in front of Operation.8. Format the file as needed. At a minimum, all required fields must be included.CabinetObjectMakeModelLocationNameNew Name9. Leave the Name column as is, then enter the new item names in the New Name column.10. Save and close the file, then return to the Web Client.11. Use File Import to rename the items. Click the Import button on the Main dcTrack tool bar to begin.12. After the import is finished, you can return to the Items list and after refreshing the list, view the renamed items.

Watch a video on how to use import. https://youtu.be/8R-UsdiumcMThis topic outlines how to create an import file that will bulk add IP addresses.For detailed steps on using the File Import feature, see Use Use File Import to Add, Edit Delete and Move.Use the File Import to bulk update existing rack PDU or probe IP addresses, or bulk add IP addresses to existingrack PDUs or probes.Specifically, you can:Apply a Single IP Address to Rack PDUs or Probes in BulkApply a Different IP Addresses to Each Port on Rack PDUs or Probes in BulkThere is no interruption in data capture when you update IP addresses, unlike when you delete an IP address or adda new IP addresses to rack PDUs or probes.Note: For rack PDUs configured to operate with a Proxy Index, bulk IP address updates and/or Proxy Indexupdates are not supported.In this scenario, the rack PDUs or probes and their ports already exist in dcTrack.A bulk import is used to update or add a single IP address to each rack PDU or probe.The IP address is assigned to the first port on the rack PDU or probe.dcTrack uses the port's index number to determine the first port. The port index number information is pulled fromthe Item Models Library. The port index order is determined by the rack PDU or probe's make.Begin by generating or locating a spreadsheet template containing the rack PDUs or probes.Sunbird recommends using the Export Data to Import Templates for Reimporting feature in order to ensure thetemplate is formatted correctly.Next, update the rack PDU or probe information in the spreadsheet and format it (if needed).In this example, IP addresses are being bulk added to rack PDUs in dcTrack.Enter the IP address you want to apply to the rack PDU or probe under the IP Address column.If needed, insert a column called IP Address to enter this information.Enter FALSE for each row under the "Data Ports from Library" column so dcTrack knows not to include port inform-ation pulled from the Item Models Library.Insert this column, if needed.Save the file locally and close it.Import the file using File Import. For detailed steps on using File Import, see Use File Import to Add, Edit Deleteand Move.(Optional) Open the Web Client and verify that the IP addresses were updated or added. You can do this from theItems List or by opening each item's page and verifying the IP address was updated/added on the Data - N Ports tab.

In this scenario, bulk import is used to update or add a different IP address to each port on existing rack PDUs orprobes.The IP address is assigned to the correct port by mapping the IP Address Port Name column in the spreadsheet withthe port names on each rack PDU or probe.The IP Address Port Names in your spreadsheet must be exactly the same as the port names on the rack PDU orprobe.The names of each port can be found on the item's page on the Data - N Ports tab in the Web Client.Note: For rack PDUs configured to operate with a Proxy Index, bulk IP address updates and/or Proxy Indexupdates are not supported.Begin by generating or locating a spreadsheet template containing the rack PDUs or probes.Sunbird recommends using the Export Data to Import Templates for Reimporting feature in order to ensure thetemplate is formatted correctly.Next, update the rack PDU or probe information in the spreadsheet and format it (if needed).For this example, IP addresses are being bulk updated for specific ports on rack PDUs in dcTrack.Enter the exact names of each port under the IP Address Port Name column.Add the column if needed.Enter the new IP address you want to apply to the rack PDU ports under the IP Address column.If needed, insert a column called IP Address to enter this information.Enter FALSE for each row under the "Data Ports from Library" column so dcTrack knows not to include port inform-ation pulled from the Item Models Library.Insert this column, if needed.Perform a File Import.File import/ export can be used to create, edit and delete structured cabling. You must have the System Admin-istrator or the "Bulk Import" role to create and manage projects.

Data panels must exist for structured cabling to be created.If creating fan-out cabling, the network switch and its ports must exist.Structured Cabling can be created with existing data panel ports or by creating new data panel ports.1. Download the Import Template file from the main Import page. The import template file have examples foradding, editing and deleting structured cabling.2. Follow the instructions in the import template and prepare the import file.3. Import the file.Use ADD operation when creating the structured cabling and the data panel ports. If the data panels already haveports created use the EDIT operation to create the Structured Cabling.DELETE operation will just disassociate the structured cabling between the data panels, data Panel Ports will not bedeleted. If the structured cabling is part of a circuit, it cannot be deleted.

To export the structured cabling, filter the structured cabling list, and select the export option. You can export the listexactly as shown or export into an import template.For information on re-importing files, see Export Data to Import Templates for Reimporting.Note: If you are using a fan-out configuration, you cannot make edits via the Web Client's File Import feature if thestarting item is a network item. To edit network port names or connectors, first export the Items list for data ports,edit the exported file, and re-import. To edit structured cabling attributes, including length, color, or group, exportthe structured cabling connections file, edit the exported file, and re-import.

dcTrack allows you to move Cabinets, Rackable Devices and Blades in bulk using the File Import feature.The Move Import Template is available in the Sample Import Templates file. To access the template click the Importbutton on the dcTrack Main tool bar and select the appropriate template option.Open the Template in Excel and click on the "Move Items" sheet.You can then either delete the other the Sheets in the Workbook, or copy the Move Items sheet to a separate Work-book. Importing a spreadsheet does not import the data on each worksheet at once; you must import each work-sheet's data separately. Use the samples in the worksheet to help you in determining what field data is required foreach Object Type.The Import Template is designed to make the import process as easy as possible.The Import Template includes all of the required fields needed to perform the Move operation.Instructions on the data you must enter in each field, as well as sample data, are also included in the Import Tem-plate.File Import supports .XLS, XLSX and .CSV file formats.Note: If you perform a File Import and the expected data was not imported, verify data are not preceded by ahashtag. Since dcTrack ignores the data after a hashtag, warnings or errors are not generated, but the data is notimported.Note: You must leave the hashtag # in front of "Operation". # Operation is a template field; it is not meant to beimported into dcTrack.

When you initially import a file, dcTrack verifies it is in a proper file format and reports any file format errors.Once you click Begin Import, dcTrack performs a line-by-line validation and reports errors encountered for a line. Allrows that are valid are completed. Only those operations where errors are encountered are not completed. You cancorrect those errors and re-import with the updated data.Warning and error information are presented in the File Import dialog in the Results section.Warnings are displayed when data may require attention but are not considered invalid.An error may be a missing required column or an invalid number of characters in a field. When an error isencountered, dcTrack displays the invalid data as well as the line on the spreadsheet the data is entered.Errors must be fixed before that row of data can be successfully imported. However, the remaining data in thespreadsheet is imported so long as it is valid.Use the Save Results to File function. This allows you to save a file with only rows containing invalid data causingerrors. You can then make changes directly to that file and then re-import it.Alternatively, highlight the information in the Results section, then use Ctrl+C to copy and paste the information to afile. Reference the information when you update the incorrect data.

Select Proceed on Warning if you want dcTrack to continue with the import but display data that caused the warning.If Proceed on Warning is not selected, dcTrack does not import the data.Objects in the Planned state cannot be moved using this feature. For Planned Items use "Edit" to modify anyLocation data.When moving a Cabinet, all of the Cabinets contents is moved with the Cabinet.The Cabinet and all of the Items within the Cabinet retain their current status.All Power Connections associated with the Items within the Cabinet are retained.All Planned Data Connections contained within that extend beyond the Cabinet will be Deleted.All Installed Data Connections contained within the Cabinet are retained.Managed IP Addresses remain unchanged if moving within the same Location.Managed IP Addresses are deleted if moving to a different Location.Un-managed IP Addresses remain unchanged regardless of whether the move is within the same Location ora different Location.
