This section walks you through manually building a cabinet in dcTrack using the Create New Item function, and thenmoving the cabinet to an Installed status either by submitting an Install Item Request or changing its status manually(if you have permissions to do so).Note: You can also use File Import to add cabinets and items, as well as their data and port connections. During theimport, provided you have privileges to do so, you can also move them to an Installed, Stored or Archived status.Using File Import is particularly useful for importing large numbers of items.You know the data center exists in dcTrack if it is available for selection in any of the Location drop-down lists andyou can access it.You must have add/edit privileges assigned to your role to add cabinets and items in dcTrack.You know you have edit access to the data center location if you are able to open a New Item page from the Assetstab.

Once you have built a cabinet, you can then clone it (if needed). Cloning is a faster way to create new items ratherthan creating them from scratch. For details, see Cloning.Note: Cabinet items and device items can be also be added to dcTrack using the following methods, provided youhave permissions to do so:Importing using File Import. See Add Cabinets, Items, Ports and Connections.Items are added in the Assets tab.At a minimum, *required fields marked with a red asterisk must be completed.Custom fields designated by your System Administrator and fields required based on item class may also berequired.You must have add/edit privileges assigned to your role to add cabinets and items in dcTrack.You must be a System Administrator or a user with the "Bulk Import" role to import cabinets and items using the FileImport.Note that passive items are added from the Items tab on a cabinet's item page. See Add Passive Items .Blade chassis are added like any other item, blades are added from the Blades tab on the chassis' item page. SeeAdd Blade Chassis and Blades.Note: Adding a Zero-U height cabinet follows the same process as adding any standard item. For information oncreating a model for a Zero-U height cabinet, see Add a Model to the Models Library.To add standard items in dcTrack:1. To add a new item, click the orange Add an Item icon in the Asset Management toolbar or select the Assetstab > Add an Item.2. A New Item page with just the Hardware panel will display. When you enter the Make (required), the Model(required) field will automatically populate with the models of the selected make.3. Once selected, the Identity, Placement, and bottom panels will display.4. Add the Name in the Identity Panel.5. Add the Placement in the Location panel.6. Click the Save button to create your new item.Note: If the item you are creating is a VM, check the VM box next to the Make field in the Hardware panel. TheClass will automatically be updated to Device / Virtual Machine, and only the Name and Location will be required.

Items can also be created and added automatically to a Cabinet from a Cabinets Item Detail Page. To add an Itemdirectly from a Cabinet:1. From the Items List under the Assets tab, select the cabinet you want to add the item to.2. Open the cabinet's page in Edit mode.3. Click on the Items in Cabinet sub tab.4. Click the "Add an Item in Cabinet" button.5. This will open a New Item tab. The Location and Cabinet for the new Item will default to the same values asthe Cabinet. You must then complete the remaining required fields and save the new record.6. Once Saved, the Item is added to the Cabinet.If you cannot find a make or model, there are next step options. See What To Do if A Make or Model Is Not Avail-able for SelectionTip: In the Model dialog, Filter Model Information and View "My Company Standard" Models. If your Gatekeeper orSystem Administrator designated models as 'My Company Standard', only those are displayed.A cabinet or item name must be unique within the location. The only exception to this rule is if you reuse the name ofcabinet or item that is decommissioned archive (it is in an Archived status).A name can contain up to 64 alphanumeric characters.A name cannot contain the characters \ & ? 'Selecting a System Admin or Admin Team limits those who can edit the item to the item's creator, anyone in the Sys-tem Admin role and anyone on the Admin Team.Note that you can click the Cabinet link to Access a Cabinet's Page from an Item's Page (if applicable).A cabinet model can be defined to be Zero U height. This allows floor space to be reserved to prevent overloadingconditions.The "Rackable" mountings of Transformers and Power Panel Items are not currently supported. dcTrack however,will allow this mounting type for their models. This was done so when they are supported you will not have to go backand add that mounting in the Model screen.When dcTrack does support this mounting type for Transformers and Power Panel Items, they will be mounted in ACBays only. They will not be mounted in Cabinets.

Multiple Items can be selected from the Items List on the Items in Cabinet subtab for either viewing or editing. Oncethe Items are selected, clicking the View button will open a tab for each selected item in view mode. You can alsoopen the Items in Edit Mode by clicking the Edit button.If you do not know a specific cabinet that can accommodate the item or if a specific cabinet can accommodate anitem, consider using Intelligent Capacity Search to locate one in your data center. See Use Intelligent CapacitySearch to Locate or Qualify Cabinet Space for One or More Items.When setting the Contract Start and End Dates, the Contract Start Date must precede the Contract End Date, andthe Contract Start Date must be on or after the Purchase Date.When setting the Installation Date, it must precede the Contract End Date.When setting the Purchase Date it must be on or prior to the Installation Date, and the Purchase Date must be priorto the Contract End Date.Note: Click the Settings icon in the Cabinet Elevation to open the Cabinet Legend.When selecting the Orientation, Depth Position and/or Rails Used by the item, use the illustration depicting the frontand back of the cabinet, and the front and rear rails of the cabinet. This is a useful reference when creating an itemand selecting position information.Use Drag-and-Drop an Item to a New U Position in a Cabinet or Change an Item's U Position in a Cabinet (ifapplicable).You can go to the Data - N Ports tab on applicable item pages to:Create a Data Port, Edit a Data Port (Web Client) and Delete a Data Port (Web Client)Assign a Unique IP Address to an Individual PortAssign Multiple IP Addresses to the Same PortAssign the Same IP Address to Multiple Ports on the Same Port Team and Manage Them Together Assignthe Same IP Address to Multiple Ports on the Same Port Team and Manage Them Together.Assign the Same IP Addresses to Multiple Ports on a Port Team but Manage Them SeparatelyAccess a Connected Item's Page from the Data Port TabConnect to a Server via a Data Port IP Address (Web Client)Connect to a New Data Circuit Page (Web Client)Trace a Data Port CircuitYou can go to the Power - N Ports tab on application item pages to:Create Power Ports (Web Client), Edit a Power Port, Remove Power Ports (Web Client) and DeletePower Ports (Web Client)Connect to a New Power Circuit Page (Web Client)Trace a Power Port CircuitAccess a Connected Item's Page from the Power Port Tab (Web Client)You can go to the Sensor - N Ports tab on applicable item pages to:Create Sensor Ports for Sensors in Cabinets (Web Client)Create Sensor Ports for Sensors Outside of Cabinets (Web Client)Edit Sensor Ports (Web Client)Delete Sensor Ports (Web Client)The tab turns green once saved. The item is now in a Planned status.At this point, Submit an Install Item Request now or at a later time. You submit multiple Install Item Requests fromthe Items List.Find Items on the Floor Map by Clicking the Floor Maps Icon located at the top of the page. The item must besynched with a floor map or there is nothing to locate.

When creating a data panel port:The near end and far end cabinets in the connection cannot be the same.The data port can connect to another data port on the same data panel.The far end of the connection can be in another siteA data port connection can go directly to an existing network item within the same or a different site.

If Cooling units, UPS units, and floor PDUs exist on your floor map drawing file, they are added to dcTrack when youupload and sync the file with a site/location.Infrastructure items can be added in bulk as individual items. However, since each item is part of a power chain, theyare typically created at the same time.The items are created and configured in the Web Client Specifically:Each Cooling unit must be added to a Cooling Zone.Each UPS unit must be added to a UPS bankEither a busway or power panel must be configured for each floor PDUCreate the power outlet connectionsNote: Power outlet circuiting can be imported rather than manually created. See Import Power Outlet Circuiting.This topic walks your through each step to create your infrastructure power chain. You can find each step in indi-vidual topics as well.Steps to Add Cooling Units:1. Click Assets > New Item or click on the New Item icon on the Items List under Assets.2. Select the Cooling unit make and model.3. Assign a name to the Cooling unit.4. Select a location for the Cooling unit, if different from the one already selected in the Location drop-down.5. Enter following fields for Cooling Unit specifications.Sensible Capacity (Tons)Sensible Capacity (kW)Age Derated (Required)Airflow Rate (cfm)You can enter the value for Capacity (Tons) or Sensible Capacity (kw), dcTrack calculates the value for otherusing this formula Sensible Capacity (Tons) * 12,000 * 0.0002930711 = Sensible Capacity (kW).Age Derated field can be used to further reduce the Cooling Unit Capacity to the Cooling Unit's age. Age Deratedvalue should be between 0.1 and 100.Note : If the model selected have these values then items will inherit the model's value. Nominal Capacity valuesare the Nameplate value for the model.6. Next, go to configuration sub tab and add the Cooling unit to a Cooling Zone.7. You must add the Cooling unit to a Cooling Zone before you can mark the unit as Installed.8. To assign a Cooling unit to a Cooling Zone, select a Cooling Zone from the Unit Assignment to Zones and clickSave.9. If the Cooling Zone does not exist, create one and assign the Cooling unit to it. Cooling Zones are created in theAvailable Cooling Zones section of the page.10. Click Add a Zone.11. Enter Cooling Zone name.12. Click Save in the toolbar.You can also assign multiple Cooling Zones to a Cooling Unit. See here Cooling Zone.htmTo create the UPS, UPS Bank and Floor PDU power chain, follow the below steps:1. Create UPS Units2. Create a UPS Bank3. Create UPS Bank Load Devices4. Connect UPS Bank Load Devices to UPS Units5. Create Floor PDUs6. Connect Floor PDUs to UPS Bank Load DevicesNote: The configuration settings for the UPS and Power Panel can also be set via File Import

One or more UPS Units can be aggregated using the UPS Bank which in turn feeds one or more Floor PDUs. Eachpower chain in your data center may have one or more UPS Units.1. In the Assets tab > Item List, click the Add an Item button. A new Item page will open in a new dcTrack tab.2. In the New Item page, select the UPS Unit’s make and model.3. Assign a name to the UPS Unit.4. Select a location for the UPS Unit, if different from the one already selected in the Location dropdown.5. In the Configuration sub-tab enter the following information:a. Rating (kVA)b. Rating (kW)c. Rating (Vac)d. Output Wiring6. Save the UPS item.7. Repeat for any additional UPS Unit items.You will need a UPS Bank for each power chain in your data center. Typically, data centers have 2 redundant powerchains. A UPS Bank is technically a Switchgear which in dcTrack is represented using the Class/Subclass AC Dis-tribution/Switch. Therefore, an AC Distribution/UPS Bank and AC Distribution/Switch electrically and functionally arethe same, but in dcTrack the UPS Bank is a special case of a switch since it is the switchgear that feeds from theUPS Units and distributes out to the Floor PDUs.1. In the Assets tab > Item List, click the Add an Item button. A new Item page will open in a new dcTrack tab.2. In the New Item page, select the UPS Bank’s make and model. You may use the Generic UPS Bank model.3. Assign a name to the UPS Bank.4. Select a location for the UPS Bank, if different from the one already selected in the Location dropdown.5. In the Configuration sub-tab enter the following information:a. Rating (A)b. Rating (Vac) - This should also match the Voltage of the UPS Units.c. Output WiringNote: The above 3 values are the specification of the Busbar that is inside the UPS Bank switchgear.d. Redundancy – this depends on the number of UPS Units that you will connected to the bank in Step 13below. You will want to update this value after connecting all the UPS units to this bank.e. Rating (kVA) and Rating (kW) are read-only. They are automatically calculated based on the numberof UPS Units that you will connect to the Bank in step 8 below and the Redundancy setting.6. Save the UPS Bank item.7. Repeat for any additional UPS Bank items.8. In the Switch Devices sub-tab of the UPS Bank, click the Create Switch Devices button and choose LoadDevice. You will repeat this step for as many UPS Units and Floor PDUs there are connecting from and to thisUPS Bank. A load device is the large breakers that are installed in the UPS Bank.a. Select the Make and Model for the Load Device.b. Give the Load Device a name. This name must be unique within the UPS Bank item only.c. Give the Load Device an optional number for easier reference within this UPS Bank.d. The Connector Type is inherited from the Model of the Load Device. If this remains blank, it is becausethe Load Device Model does not have the Connector Type set. You may want to create multiple LoadDevice models for each Connector Type you want to use. Each Connector Type displays it own sym-bol in the Single Line Diagram.e. Rating (Vac) is read-only and is inherited from the UPS Bank itself, which was selected in the Con-figuration sub-tab.f. Phase is read-only and is inherited from the UPS Bank itself. (It will show Three Phase Delta if theBank’s Output Wiring is 3-Wire + Ground, or Three Phase Wye if the Bank’s Output Wiring is 4-Wire +Ground.g. Rating (A) must be equal to or less than the Rating (A) of the UPS Bank.h. Derate 80%. Uncheck this box if the Load Device breaker is 100% rated.i. The remaining fields are optional.j. When the Rating (A) was filled in, you will notice a form appears to the right. This specifies how thisLoad Device connects internally within the UPS Bank switchgear.1. For a Load Device that feeds from the UPS Units select the following:1. Line Side:a. Connects to: Extb. Fed From: Select the UPS Unit’s Output.2. Load Side:a. Connects to: Bus A.2. For a Load Device that feeds to the Floor PDUs, select the following:1. Line Side:a. Connects to: Bus A2. Load Side:1. Connects to: Ext.Note: Bus B and Bus C are optional and would only be used when the Switchgear has more then one bus. Whenmultiple buses exist, a Load Device would connect them together. These 3 bus notations should not be confusedwith the 3 poles of a Three Phase circuit.k. Click Createl. Create all other Load Devices and select the appropriate selections at step j based on what this loaddevice will connect to.m. Save the UPS Bank Item.n. At this point, you should have a UPS Bank connected to the UPS Unit(s). If you go back to the UPS item(s) (Refresh it, if it was already open)and in the Configuration sub-tab, the UPS Output section should display the Bank name that this UPS Unitis part of and the total capacity of theUPS Bank. If this total is higher than expected, you may need to adjust the Bank’s Redundancy field.

1. In the Assets tab > Item List, click the Add an Item button. A new Item page will open in a new dcTrack tab.2. In the New Item page, select the floor PDU’s make and model.3. Assign a name to the floor PDU.4. Select a location for the floor PDU, if different from the one already selected in the Location dropdown.5. In the Configuration sub-tab enter the following information:a. Rating (kVA)b. Rating (A) – Should be a number that is close to the result of this formula: Rating (kVA) * 1000 / (Rating(Vac) * SQRT(3) * NEC Derating), where the Rating (Vac) is the voltage of the item feeding the FloorPDU and the NEC Derating is 80% for Data Centers in the United States.c. Class/Subclass: Select UPS Bank optiond. Fed From: Select the UPS Bank Load Device feeding this Floor PDU.If you do not have a UPS Bank created, you can also select VPC UPS Bank from the drop-down. ACVPC must be enabled for the location in order to view VPC UPS banks in the drop-down. See Enableor Disable VPC for a Location.e. The Rating (Vac) and Input Wiring will be automatically filled in based on the Fed From selection.f. Save the Floor PDU item.g. Repeat these steps for each additional Floor PDU.h. In the Power Panels sub-tab of each Floor PDU, create one or more power panels that are eitherinternal to the Floor PDU (Local), remotely placed panels or RPPs (Remote), or busway systems feed-ing from the Floor PDU (Busway). Click Create a panel and fill in all the required fields to create eachpanel accordingly to the panel specifications. Note that the panel name needs to be unique only withinthe Floor PDU.i. Click Create buttonj. Repeat for each additional panel for this Floor PDU.k. From the list of power panels in this sub-tab, you can click each panel name to open that panel andbegin adding breakers within the panel which would also include creating the Power Outlet items thatare fed from each of the breakers.1. Back on the Power Panels sub-tab, click on the desired power panel to view its Item Details page.2. In the Power – [x] Poles, [y] Breakers sub-tab, click the Bulk Edit button to edit the breakers. Alternatively, inthe Assets tab > Items List, click the Export button and select either of the following options:a. Download Import Template to download the import template as a CSV file.b. Export into an Import Template > Branch Circuit Breakers to download an import template populatedwith the panel and busway breakers as a CSV file.3. Open your CSV file.4. Follow the instructions in the CSV file to add breakers.5. In the Assets tab > File Import page, import the edited CSV file to create the breakers. This will also create theoutlets and connect the breakers to those outlets.

At this point, if you are planning on using File Import to create power outlet circuiting, note the following pre-requisites.Each floor PDU and its busways must be created in dcTrack before you can import power outlet circuiting.Each floor PDU's power panel and the power panel's poles and breakers must be created in dcTrack beforeyou can import power outlet circuiting.Important: At this point, if you are planning on using File Import to create power outlet circuiting, note the followingprerequisites -Busway Power Outlet PrerequisitesEach Floor PDU and its busways must be created in dcTrack before you can import power outlet cir-cuiting.The power outlets that were created cannot contain any ports, poles or breakers in dcTrack.Power Panel Outlet PrerequisitesEach floor PDU's power panel the power panel's poles and breakers must be created in dcTrack beforeyou can import power outlet circuiting.The power outlets that were created cannot contain any ports in dcTrack.You can now do one of the following based on your needs:Manually Configure a Floor PDU for Power Outlet Circuiting ImportsManually Configure a UPS Unit and Floor PDUs with BuswaysCreate the items in the power chain that the busway or power panel will connect to.Note: When creating certain items, there is information that must be entered in order to connect one item to anotheritem in the power chain. However, these fields may not be indicated as *required in the dcTrack interface. This isbecause they are 'technically' not required to create the item in the dcTrack database. For example, in order to com-plete the busway, you must enter the floor PDU's specification information even though those are not requiredfields to create the floor PDU.If a field is required to complete the busway creation process, it is identified in the steps that follow as "Required".Create your power chain and busway:1. Click Assets.2. Click the New Item icon.3. Select the Make and Model of the UPS unit.4. Enter a name for the UPS unit.5. Select the Location of the UPS unit (if different from the default).6. Enter the UPS unit's specification information.7. Select/Add the UPS bank on the Configuration sub tab based on the specifications8. Enter additional information if needed, then click Save. The item's tab turns green.9. In the Web Client, click the New Item icon.10. Select the Make and Model for the floor PDU.11. Enter a name for the floor PDU.12. Verify the floor PDU location.13. Enter the floor PDU specifications. Required14. Enter the floor PDU input information. Required15. Important: At this point, if you are planning on using the File Import to create power outlet circuiting, review theprerequisites for adding a busway or power panel.16. Each floor PDU's power panel the power panel's poles and breakers are created in dcTrack.17. The power outlets are created and do not contain any ports in dcTrack18. Busway Power Outlets -19. Each Floor PDU and its busways are created in dcTrack20. The power outlets are created and do not contain any ports, poles or breakers in dcTrack.

Note: These steps DO NOT involve configuring floor PDUs for use with imported power outlet circuiting function.See Manually Configure a Floor PDU for Power Outlet Circuiting Imports.Prior to adding and configuring a busway or power panel, create the items in the power chain it connects to.Note: When creating certain items, there is information that must be entered in order to connect the item to anotheritem in the power chain. However, these fields may not be indicated as *required in the dcTrack interface. This isbecause they are 'technically' not required to create the item in the dcTrack database. For example, in order to com-plete the busway, you must enter the floor PDU's specification information even though those are not requiredfields to create the floor PDU.If a field is required to complete the busway creation process, it is identified in the steps that follow as "Required".To create the UPS, UPS Bank and Floor PDU power chain, follow the below steps:1. Create UPS Units2. Create a UPS Bank3. Create UPS Bank Load Devices4. Connect UPS Bank Load Devices to UPS Units5. Create Floor PDUs6. Connect Floor PDUs to UPS Bank Load DevicesNote: The configuration settings for the UPS and Power Panel can also be set via File ImportOne or more UPS Units can be aggregated using the UPS Bank which in turn feeds one or more Floor PDUs. Eachpower chain in your data center may have one or more UPS Units.1. In the Assets tab > Item List, click the Add an Item button. A new Item page will open in a new dcTrack tab.2. In the New Item page, select the UPS Unit’s make and model.3. Assign a name to the UPS Unit.4. Select a location for the UPS Unit, if different from the one already selected in the Location dropdown.5. In the Configuration sub-tab enter the following information:a. Rating (kVA)b. Rating (kW)c. Rating (Vac)d. Output Wiring6. Save the UPS item.7. Repeat for any additional UPS Unit items.

You will need a UPS Bank for each power chain in your data center. Typically, data centers have 2 redundant powerchains. A UPS Bank is technically a Switchgear which in dcTrack is represented using the Class/Subclass AC Dis-tribution/Switch. Therefore, an AC Distribution/UPS Bank and AC Distribution/Switch electrically and functionally arethe same, but in dcTrack the UPS Bank is a special case of a switch since it is the switchgear that feeds from theUPS Units and distributes out to the Floor PDUs.1. In the Assets tab > Item List, click the Add an Item button. A new Item page will open in a new dcTrack tab.2. In the New Item page, select the UPS Bank’s make and model. You may use the Generic UPS Bank model.3. Assign a name to the UPS Bank.4. Select a location for the UPS Bank, if different from the one already selected in the Location dropdown.5. In the Configuration sub-tab enter the following information:a. Rating (A)b. Rating (Vac) - This should also match the Voltage of the UPS Units.c. Output WiringNote: The above 3 values are the specification of the Busbar that is inside the UPS Bank switchgear.d. Redundancy – this depends on the number of UPS Units that you will connected to the bank in Step 13below. You will want to update this value after connecting all the UPS units to this bank.e. Rating (kVA) and Rating (kW) are read-only. They are automatically calculated based on the numberof UPS Units that you will connect to the Bank in step 8 below and the Redundancy setting.6. Save the UPS Bank item.7. Repeat for any additional UPS Bank items.8. In the Switch Devices sub-tab of the UPS Bank, click the Create Switch Devices button and choose LoadDevice. You will repeat this step for as many UPS Units and Floor PDUs there are connecting from and to thisUPS Bank. A load device is the large breakers that are installed in the UPS Bank.a. Select the Make and Model for the Load Device.b. Give the Load Device a name. This name must be unique within the UPS Bank item only.c. Give the Load Device an optional number for easier reference within this UPS Bank.d. The Connector Type is inherited from the Model of the Load Device. If this remains blank, it is becausethe Load Device Model does not have the Connector Type set. You may want to create multiple LoadDevice models for each Connector Type you want to use. Each Connector Type displays it own sym-bol in the Single Line Diagram.e. Rating (Vac) is read-only and is inherited from the UPS Bank itself, which was selected in the Con-figuration sub-tab.f. Phase is read-only and is inherited from the UPS Bank itself. (It will show Three Phase Delta if theBank’s Output Wiring is 3-Wire + Ground, or Three Phase Wye if the Bank’s Output Wiring is 4-Wire +Ground.g. Rating (A) must be equal to or less than the Rating (A) of the UPS Bank.h. Derate 80%. Uncheck this box if the Load Device breaker is 100% rated.i. The remaining fields are optional.j. When the Rating (A) was filled in, you will notice a form appears to the right. This specifies how thisLoad Device connects internally within the UPS Bank switchgear.1. For a Load Device that feeds from the UPS Units select the following:1. Line Side:a. Connects to: Extb. Fed From: Select the UPS Unit’s Output.2. Load Side:a. Connects to: Bus A.2. For a Load Device that feeds to the Floor PDUs, select the following:1. Line Side:a. Connects to: Bus A2. Load Side:1. Connects to: Ext.Note: Bus B and Bus C are optional and would only be used when the Switchgear has more then one bus. Whenmultiple buses exist, a Load Device would connect them together. These 3 bus notations should not be confusedwith the 3 poles of a Three Phase circuit.k. Click Createl. Create all other Load Devices and select the appropriate selections at step j based on what this loaddevice will connect to.m. Save the UPS Bank Item.n. At this point, you should have a UPS Bank connected to the UPS Unit(s). If you go back to the UPS item(s) (Refresh it, if it was already open)and in the Configuration sub-tab, the UPS Output section should display the Bank name that this UPS Unitis part of and the total capacity of theUPS Bank. If this total is higher than expected, you may need to adjust the Bank’s Redundancy field.1. In the Assets tab > Item List, click the Add an Item button. A new Item page will open in a new dcTrack tab.2. In the New Item page, select the floor PDU’s make and model.3. Assign a name to the floor PDU.4. Select a location for the floor PDU, if different from the one already selected in the Location dropdown.5. In the Configuration sub-tab enter the following information:a. Rating (kVA)b. Rating (A) – Should be a number that is close to the result of this formula: Rating (kVA) * 1000 / (Rating(Vac) * SQRT(3) * NEC Derating), where the Rating (Vac) is the voltage of the item feeding the FloorPDU and the NEC Derating is 80% for Data Centers in the United States.c. Class/Subclass: Select UPS Bank optiond. Fed From: Select the UPS Bank Load Device feeding this Floor PDU.If you do not have a UPS Bank created, you can also select VPC UPS Bank from the drop-down. ACVPC must be enabled for the location in order to view VPC UPS banks in the drop-down. See Enableor Disable VPC for a Location.e. The Rating (Vac) and Input Wiring will be automatically filled in based on the Fed From selection.f. Save the Floor PDU item.g. Repeat these steps for each additional Floor PDU.h. In the Power Panels sub-tab of each Floor PDU, create one or more power panels that are eitherinternal to the Floor PDU (Local), remotely placed panels or RPPs (Remote), or busway systems feed-ing from the Floor PDU (Busway). Click Create a panel and fill in all the required fields to create eachpanel accordingly to the panel specifications. Note that the panel name needs to be unique only withinthe Floor PDU.i. Click Create buttonj. Repeat for each additional panel for this Floor PDU.k. From the list of power panels in this sub-tab, you can click each panel name to open that panel andbegin adding breakers within the panel which would also include creating the Power Outlet items thatare fed from each of the breakers.

1. Back on the Power Panels sub-tab, click on the desired power panel to view its Item Details page.2. In the Power – [x] Poles, [y] Breakers sub-tab, click the Bulk Edit button to edit the breakers. Alternatively, inthe Assets tab > Items List, click the Export button and select either of the following options:a. Download Import Template to download the import template as a CSV file.b. Export into an Import Template > Branch Circuit Breakers to download an import template populatedwith the panel and busway breakers as a CSV file.3. Open your CSV file.4. Follow the instructions in the CSV file to add breakers.5. In the Assets tab > File Import page, import the edited CSV file to create the breakers. This will also create theoutlets and connect the breakers to those outlets.At this point, if you are planning on using File Import to create power outlet circuiting, note the following pre-requisites.Each floor PDU and its busways must be created in dcTrack before you can import power outlet circuiting.Each floor PDU's power panel and the power panel's poles and breakers must be created in dcTrack beforeyou can import power outlet circuiting.

Creating your busway can be completely entirely in the Web Client. The steps that follow tell you when to do so.1. In the Web Client, click the New Item icon.2. Enter the busway Make and Model.3. Select a Busway subclass model. Required4. Enter a name for the outlet in the Item Name field.5. Update the location and any additional information, if needed.6. Click Save.7. In the Web Client, click the New Item icon.8. Enter the power outlet information. Required9. Select a cabinet and position for the outlet. Required10. Click Save on the outlet's page.11. In the Web Client, click Clone on the outlet's item page.12. Enter the number of cloned outlets for the busway you are creating - do not create ports for another busway.13. In the Clone dialog, clone only the following:a. Child itemsb. Parent-child associationsc. Power portsd. Custom fields (if applicable)14. Click Clone.Passive items include wire managers, blanking plates, cabinet shelves, and so on.Passive items are added to cabinets.Passive items are added to a specific cabinet by creating them directly on the cabinet's item page from the Items tabwhile the page is in Edit mode or by creating them from their own Item Detail page.Once added, passive items are displayed in the Cabinet Elevation and are considered by dcTrack to be installed.To add a passive item to a cabinet from its Item detail page.:1. Click the Add an Item button from either the Item List or any Item detail page2. Select the Make and Model of the Passive Item you want to Add3. Give the Item a name. You can also leave the Name field blank to auto generate the name.a. Passive item name is auto-generated using the format “[Cabinet Name]-[YY]RU-[XX]-U[ZZ]-[F/B]” wherei. YY = zero-padded RU height of the passive itemii. ZZ = zero-padded U Position in the cabinet of the passive item. When Passive items are placed aboveor below the cabinet then ABV is used and BLW is used for below. Letter U will not be used. Forexample: 1A-02RU-GN-ABV-Fiii. XX = abbreviation for passive item subclass: GN = General, BP = Blanking Plate, SH = Shelfiv. F/B = Indicates the used rails. -F = mounted on the Front rails. -B = mounted on the Back rails and -FB =mounted on Both Rails (Front and Back)4. To immediately assign the item to a cabinet, select the cabinet from the drop down. You can also leave the fieldblank and edit it at a later time when you are ready to do the assignment. Once assigned to a Cabinet, it willappear on the "Items in Cabinet" subtab of the Cabinet Item. If the Item Name field is left blank then Cabinet,Rails Used and U position fields are required to auto-generate the name.5. Once the Item is assigned to a cabinet, the Passive Item itself will have an "Items in Cabinet" subtab that lists allthe Items assigned to the Cabinet.Once a Passive Item is created, it will appear in the Item List and can be selected to View/Edit it's detail page.Passive Items can also be added from Cabinet Item details.To add a passive item to a cabinet from the "Items in Cabinet" subtab on the Cabinet's Item detail page:1. From the Items List under the Assets tab, select the cabinet you want to add the passive item to.2. Open the cabinet's page in Edit mode.3. Click on the "Items in Cabinet" sub tab.4. Click the "Add Passive Item" button to enable the Create Passive Items panel.5. This will open a dialog panel to the right of the list. Select the Make and Model of the Passive Item to be added.Note the Models List is populated with only those Models whose Class is "Passive"6. If the Item name is left blank, dcTrack will automatically generate the name. If you want to assign your ownname, simply type it into the Item Name field.7. Click the Add button at the bottom of the dialog to add the Item to the Cabinet.Status field for Passive Item is read-only. When the Passive Item is created without a cabinet, the item status will bePlanned. When the Passive Item get assigned to a Cabinet, status field inherits the value from the Cabinet.Note: Passive Items no longer support duplicate names. After upgrading to dcTrack 9.2.0, existing Passive itemswith the same name as their model will be updated using the new syntax for auto generated name: “[CabinetName]-[YY]RU-[XX]-U[ZZ]-[F/B]”. If duplicate names are found, they will be updated with the addition of ^^itemId.Passive Items can also be managed via File Import and can be exported from the Asset List in the import templateformat or exactly as shown.Passive items are no longer included when exporting Cabinet items.

Since passive items are associated with a specific cabinet, no status is applied to them and they do not movethrough dcTrack's® Change Control workflow process, so you can edit a passive item's information at any timeprovided you have edit privileges for the cabinet.To edit a passive item's information:1. Open item details page of Passive item in edit mode.2. Make changes as needed.3. Click Save.Passive Items can also be edited from Cabinet item details page.1. In the Asset List, select the cabinet containing the passive item you want to edit.2. Open the cabinet's details page.3. Click Edit to enable edit mode.4. Click the Items in Cabinet tab.5. Select the passive item from the list.6. Click Edit. The Cabinet Passive Item details page opens in a new tab.7. Make changes as needed.8. Click Save. The changes are reflected in the Cabinet Elevation and in the Items list under the Assets tabStatus field for the Passive items is read-only and they inherit the status of the Cabinet. Action requests do not applyto Passive Items and are disabled.1. When the cabinet status is changed to Archived or Storage, the Passive item's status also changes asCabinet and Cabinet, U Position fields get cleared. Status Field remain read-only and Item name does notchange. Cabinet and U position fields remain editable for Passive items.2. When a Passive Item with Archived or Storage status is assigned to cabinet, the status field is updated tomatch the status of the cabinet. Item name of the Passive Item is updated if the item is placed in a differentcabinet or u position. If the Passive Item name was not auto-generated, the item name will not be updatedwhen the Passive item is placed in a different cabinet or u position.Passive items are associated with a specific cabinet, therefore, no status is applied to them and they do not movethrough dcTrack's Change Control workflow.Because of this, you can delete a passive item from a cabinet at any time provided you have Edit privileges for thecabinet.Passive items can be deleted using delete button in Asset List or item details page of Passive items.Since the Passive items in a cabinet are also listed in the Cabinet Item details, they can also be deleted from there.1. In Asset list, select the cabinet containing the passive item you want to edit.2. Open the cabinet's page in Edit mode.3. Click on the Items in Cabinet tab.4. Select the passive item from the list.5. Click the Delete icon. The item is deleted immediately. You are not prompted to confirm.

1. Blanking Panels are added as a passive device. Passive items are any items that do not have any data or powerport capabilities. They serve a direct purpose to the workings of the data center (i.e. shelves, blanking panels, cablemanagers, etc.) Example: APC, Panel.2. Passive items can be seen in the asset list, from their own Item detail page as well as cabinet detail > Items inCabinet3. You can export passive items from the Asset List. Exported file can be re-imported to add, edit or delete passiveitems.4. Blanking Panels impact cabinet capacity planning – they are considered “used space”.5. In the UI passive items can be added by going to the cabinet, items in cabinet, and add passive item. They canalso be added from their own Item detail page.6. Reporting – passive items are displayed in rack elevation report. Go to Assets, select a cabinet, Reports, CabinetElevation Report.7. There is a widget that displays Cabinet elevations without passive items. Request this widget from tech@sun-birddcim.comBlade chassis, and the blades or items that are mounted inside the chassis, are all added as separate items.Both device and network blade servers are supported.Other devices can also be mounted inside a blade chassis. Specifically:Power suppliesI/O devicesFansManagement modulesAdd these items to dcTrack as you would any other item.When you add the blade or item to dcTrack, you select the chassis it is mounted in.Depending on how it is configured, devices may be mounted vertically and horizontally within the chassis. Addi-tionally, a chassis may be configured to fit devices that are for full height, half height, quarter height, and doublewidth.Blades or items can be added to a chassis directly on the chassis page after it has been saved, or by adding theblades or items individually and then assigning them to the chassis.After blades or items are added to a chassis, the slot the item occupies is colored red in the depiction of the chassison the chassis page in the Blades tab. An orange dot in the slot indicates it is the anchor slot.Once added, the chassis and any blades or other devices housed in the chassis are listed as individual items on theItems List page.

Blade chassis can be configured in different ways in dcTrack depending on the chassis model. For example, chassiscan be configured to use full or have size slots in the chassis, and so on.It is recommended but not required that the chassis model you are adding be configured to fit your needs before youadd the chassis in dcTrack. This ensures that the chassis is ready to accommodate the blades or other items youadd to it.Blade chassis cannot be marked as Installed until the cabinet they are associated with is marked as Installed.Blades and other items can be added to the chassis while you are creating them, or created separately as individualitems and then added to the chassis.To create a blade chassis:1. Select Assets > Items List.2. Select the chassis make. Required3. Select the chassis model. Required4. Enter a name for the chassis in the Item Name field. The name cannot contain the characters \ & ? ' Required5. Select the location the chassis is installed at. Required6. Select the U position of the chassis. Optional7. Complete any additional fields as needed.8. Click Save.The chassis is displayed in the Cabinet Elevation, and in the Chassis View section of the page. The chassis is red toindicate it is in the Planned status.9. If needed, blades or items can be added to the chassis once the chassis has been saved.a. From the Blades tab on the chassis page, click the New Item icon. A New Item page opens.b. The Make field defaults to the make selected for the chassis.c. The Model field defaults to the blade model supported by the chassis. Leave this field as is, or selectanother blade or item to add to the chassis.d. Enter a name for the item in the Item Name field. Requirede. From the Slot drop-down, select the slot in the chassis that will house the blade. Only available slots are adisplayed. Optionalf. Complete any additional fields as needed.g. Click Save.If you selected the chassis and slot position for the blade, click on the Blades tab in the middle of the page to viewthe blade in the chassis. The blade is red to indicate it is in the Planned status. An orange dot in the slot indicates it isthe anchor slot.Submit an install item request for the item in addition to submitting a separate request for the chassis.Submit an Install Item request by clicking on Actions > Install Item Request, then click OK on the install confirmationmessage. A confirmation message is displayed. For a receipt of the action, save it to a file locally using Save File, oruse Ctrl+C to copy the confirmation in the message, paste into a file, and save the file locally. Click OK to close themessage.Alternatively, submit one or more Install Item requests at once using Ctrl+click to select them on the Item's List page,then clicking Actions > Install Item Request.Note that the request can be issued now or at a later time.Check the status of the request at any time from the Web UI by clicking Change > Requests.After the Gatekeeper has reviewed and approved the request, a work order to actually perform the task is issued bythe Gatekeeper. Once the work order is marked as Complete in dcTrack, the action is considered complete. TheGatekeeper must then mark the request as Complete.Blades and other items can be added to the chassis while you are creating them, or created separately as individualitems and then added to the chassis.The steps in this topic walk you through creating a blade as in individual item, and adding to an existing chassiswhile you are creating it.Blades can be created in dcTrack without first creating the chassis the blade will be housed in. However, you cannotchange a blades status to Installed without first assigning it to a cabinet and chassis.Once a blade is associated with a chassis, in order to change a blade's status to Installed, the cabinet and chassisstatuses must be in an Installed state.Note: A chassis and its blade devices are all listed as individual items on the Items List page.To add a blade server:1. Select Assets > Items List.2. Select the blade make. Required3. Select the blade model. Required4. Enter a name for the blade in the Item Name field. The name cannot contain the characters \ & ? ' Required5. Select the location the blade is installed at. Required6. Select the cabinet containing the chassis the blade will be housed in. This field is required in order to change theblade's status to Installed.7. Select the chassis the blade will be installed in. OptionalFrom the Slot drop-down, select the slot in the chassis that will house the blade. Only available slots are a displayed.This field is required in order to change the blade's status to Installed.Complete any additional fields as needed.Click Save.If you selected the chassis and slot position for the blade, click on the Blades tab in the middle of the page to viewthe blade in the chassis. The blade is red to indicate it is in the Planned status. An orange dot indicates it is theanchor slot.If you try to add the blade to a chassis that does not have slots defined, a warning message appears. Selecting Yesadds the blade to dcTrack and the chassis, but the blade is not displayed in Chassis View section of the page withinthe chassis until the chassis is configured.Submit an Install Item request by clicking on Actions > Install Item Request, then click OK on the install confirmationmessage. A confirmation message is displayed. For a receipt of the action, save it to a file locally using Save File, oruse Ctrl+C to copy the confirmation in the message, paste into a file, and save the file locally. Click OK to close themessage.Alternatively, submit one or more Install Item requests at once using Ctrl+click to select them on the Item's List page,then clicking Actions > Install Item Request.Note that the request can be issued now or at a later time.Check the status of the request at any time by clicking Change > Requests.After the Gatekeeper has reviewed and approved the request, a work order to actually perform the task is issued bythe Gatekeeper. Once the work order is marked as Complete in dcTrack, the action is considered complete. TheGatekeeper must then mark the request as Complete.Once blade chassis and blades are added, create a circuit between a blade's logical port and a network blade in thesame chassis as needed. You can also create data and power circuits between the blade and other items asneeded.dcTrack does require that a Chassis be placed in a Cabinet before any Blades can be added to that Chassis. Theremay be situations however, where you want to place blades in a Chassis that is not yet in a Cabinet. To work aroundthis requirement, you can create a Zero-U cabinet in a "storage location" and use that to satisfy the restriction thatthe Chassis must be in a cabinet. Since the Cabinet is 0U, it will not be included in the Cabinet count for licensing.

To submit an Install Item request:1. Add a cabinet or an item, on the Items list.2. Select your new item.3. Select Install Item Request from the Actions menu to submit the request. Select Yes when prompted toconfirm.For more information on requests and the Actions menu, see Item Action Request Types.If Request Bypass is enabled, the request is processed immediately. If Request Bypass is disabled, the request issubmitted to the Change Control workflow and processed.Alternatively, change the item's status from the Status drop-down on the item's page,provided you have privilegesto do so.Note: A cabinet must be in an Installed status in order to add items to it.You must have Edit privileges to an item to edit it. For details, see Edit Access Privileges to Items.You can edit item information in the Web Client for any item that was created in the Web Client.Opening an Item's Page in Edit mode displays the following:Updateable Hardware information fieldsUpdateable Identity fieldsNote that editing the System Administrator and Admin Team may impact who can and cannot edit the item inthe future. See .Updateable Placement informationNote that you can change the item's U position from the U Position drop-down, or using drag-and-drop in thecabinet elevationFor more information, see Drag-and-Drop an Item to a New U Position in a Cabinet and Change anItem's U Position in a Cabinet.6 Updateable Configuration tab information.7 Updateable Asset and Maintenance tab information.8 Updateable Custom field tab information.From the Data - N Ports tab:Edit a Data Port (Web Client)Create a Data PortDelete a Data Port (Web Client)Power port information is updated for items on the Power - N Ports tab.Edit a Power PortRemove Power Ports (Web Client)Delete Power Ports (Web Client)Create Power Ports (Web Client)Edit a Power Port on a Rack PDU

When setting the Contract Start and End Dates, the Contract Start Date must precede the Contract End Date, andthe Contract Start Date must be on or after the Purchase Date.When setting the Installation Date, it must precede the Contract End Date.When setting the Purchase Date it must be on or prior to the Installation Date, and the Purchase Date must be priorto the Contract End Date.From the Sensor - N Ports tab, if applicable:Edit Sensor Ports (Web Client)Delete Sensor Ports (Web Client)Creating Sensor Ports for Rack PDUs and Probes (Web Cli-ent)Update, delete or add blades to chassis, if applicable.Note that you can change the position of a blade in a chassis by making a new selection from the Slot Pos-ition drop-down on the blade's item page, or by dragging-and-dropping the blade into another open slot inthe same chassis. See Drag-and-Drop a Blade to a New Slot in a Chassis and Changing a Blade'sSlot Position in a Blade Chassis.The Data Ports sub-tab provides a grid of ports that have been created for data panels with links to connected items.Edit capability is provided in the grid for Port Name, Index, Color Code, Grouping/VLAN, Connector (only if not con-nected), Cable Grade, and Comment.The sub-tab also provides trace capability so users can view the circuit where the connection is being made or used.To view the circuit details, click the Trace button.The sub-tab also provides the ability to initiate bulk import of structured cabling and connect for data panel ports notalready in use. For more information, see Use File Import to Add, Edit, and Delete Structured Cabling .

The Power Ports sub-tab provides a grid of ports that have been configured for the power outlets with links to con-nected items. Edit capability is provided in the grid for attributes that are not associated with connections, such asPort Name, Index, Color Code, Connector (only if not connected), Wire Gauge, and Comment.Note: You cannot make edits for connected assets on attributes associated with the connections.The Power Panel Power Poles and Breakers sub-tab provides grid of power panel poles and breakers with links toconnected items. The columns in the grid cover the power panel's Pole, Breaker Rating, Connected Item, Status,Free Budgeted Power and Phase.The sub-tab also provides trace capability.

Users with the appropriate permissions are able to designate power supply ports as optional on items.Power ports can be designated as optional on the Item Details page.To designate a power supply port as optional:1. In the Item Details page, click the Edit button to enable Edit mode.2. On the Power Ports tab:a. Check the checkbox in the Optional column next to the port you want to designate as optional.b. Uncheck the checkbox if you want to designate that port as non-optional.3. Click the Save button to save your changes.In additional to the optional or non-optional designation, power supply ports have Port ID to make it easy to uniquelyidentify the port you want to modify.For power supply ports that are designated as optional:Changes made to an optional power supply port are made only to that port.Optional power supply ports are excluded from port counts, lists, reports, and dashboard widgets.Optional supply ports cannot be connected, and ports that are connected cannot be designated as optional.Optional power supply ports do not need unique names, indices, or other editable fields that are required tobe unique for non-optional ports.Optional supply ports are not subject to validations; however, names and other attributes must still be valid interms of length, characters, etc.Power supply ports can be designated as optional or non-optional via bulk File Import.Designating power supply ports as optional or non-optional is captured in the system audit log.Optional ports are included when the item is cloned.

Aisles and rows have been added to dcTrack's EDM hierarchy and are collectively referred to as sub-locations.Users with the appropriate permissions can edit the Placement (Cabinet) panel on Item Details pages to reflectaisles and rows as sub-locations when applicable. To specify an aisle or row in the Placement panel, simply selectthe desired aisle or row from the appropriate dropdown. To add an aisle or row, simply select the icon to launch theaisle or row dialog.As in previous versions of dcTrack, positions in rows continue to be numbered 1-300. Upon upgrade to dcTrack 6.0from a previous version, all existing rows will be migrated. However, instead of typing in the row to specify it, userswill need to select a row via the Row Label dropdown to specify the row.Authorized users also can add, edit and delete aisles and rows via File Import.Aisles and rows are included in the Cabinet Detail and Item Detail reports.Note: Aisles and rows are included in the Data Model Sync when integrated with Power IQ.Note: For Aisles, Name is the only required field and must be unique.

1. In the Assets tab, select an item and click Edit to enable Edit mode for that item.2. In the Placement (Cabinet) panel, click the Manage icon next to the Aisle Label.3. If no aisle has been specified, the Add Aisle dialog displays.4. If an aisle has been specified, the Edit Aisle dialog displays. Click Create to access the screen below.5. Add the Name (required) and Capacity (Optional), then click Save. At this point, you can create additionalaisles or click Close button to close the dialog.1. In the Assets tab, select an item and click the Edit icon to enable Edit mode for that item.2. In the Placement (Cabinet) panel, click the Manage icon next to the Aisle Label.3. In the Edit Aisles dialog, select the aisle you want to edit from the Search list. The Name and Capacity fieldswill automatically populate with the data from the selected aisle.4. Make your edits to the Name and Capacity fields, then click the Save button. At this point, you can selectother aisles to edit or click the Close button to exit the dialog.

1. In the Assets tab, select an item and click Edit to enable Edit mode for that item.2. In the Placement (Cabinet) panel, click the Manage icon next to the Aisle Label.3. The Edit Aisles dialog displays.4. In the Edit Aisles dialog, select the aisle you want to delete from the Search dropdown. The Name and Capa-city fields automatically populate with the data from the selected aisle.5. Click Delete to delete the aisle. At this point, you can select other aisles to delete or click the Close button toexit the dialog.Note: For Rows, Name is the only required field and must be unique. If you want to specify a Parent aisle for a row,you must create the parent aisle before associating the row with the Parent aisle.

1. In the Assets tab, select an item and click the Edit icon to enable Edit mode for that item.2. In the Placement (Cabinet) panel, click the Manage icon next to the Row Label.3. If no row has been specified, the Add Row dialog displays.4. If a row has been specified, the Edit Row dialog appears. Click Create to access the Add Row dialog above.5. In the Add Row dialog, provide the Name, Capacity, and Parent aisle. You can choose from the aisles list ortype in the Search box to filter available aisles by your criteria.6. Click Save to save your changes. At this point, you can continue to create additional rows or click Close toexit the dialog.1. In the Assets tab, select an item and click the Edit icon to enable Edit mode for that item.2. In the Placement (Cabinet) panel, click the Manage icon next to the Row Label.3. In the Edit Row dialog, select the row you want to edit from the Search dropdown. The Name, Capacity, andParent aisle fields automatically populate with the data from the selected aisle. You can choose from theaisles list or type in the Search box to filter available aisles by your criteria.4. Click the Save button to save your changes. At this point, you can continue to edit additional rows or click theClose button to exit the dialog.

1. In the Assets tab, select an item and click the Edit icon to enable Edit mode for that item.2. In the Placement (Cabinet) panel, click the Manage icon next to the Row Label.3. In the Edit Row dialog, select the row you want to delete from the Search dropdown. The Name, Capacity,and Parent aisle fields will automatically populate with the data from the selected aisle.4. Click Delete to delete the row. At this point, you can select other rows to delete or click the Close button to exitthe dialog.Authorized users can add, edit, and delete aisles and rows via File Import.Step 2 in the Import Template is specific to sub-locations. The screenshot below is provided as an example.The Operation is ADD, EDIT, or DELETE. The Object is SUBLOCATION. The Sub Location Type indicates whetherthe sub-location is an aisle or row. The Sub Location Name is the name specified for the aisle or row. Parent SubLocation is only applicable to rows.For a full specification of every field that is applicable to sub-locations, see the Subloc All Applicable Fields tab in theImport Template.

You are not able to edit items:If you do not have edit privileges to them. See Edit Access Privileges to ItemsIf there is an outstanding Work Order pending for them.A user's ability to edit an item is based on:Whether or not the user's role has Edit privilegesFor example, Viewers cannot edit any items, System Administrators can edit all items.The System Administrator defined for the item in the System Admin drop-down, if applicableThe Team defined for the item in the Admin Team drop-down, if applicableThe item's workflow statusItems with an Approved request cannot be edited; the item's Work Order must be marked Complete to edit the item.For additional information, see Manage a User's Edit Access to Items.

Deleting items in dcTrack means permanently removing them from the database before they are put into use in thedata center - that is, when they are in Planned status.dcTrack allows you to delete items while they are in a Planned status because doing so does not have adverseeffects on other items, as opposed to items that are installed.An item in an Installed state cannot be deleted.Instead, decommission the item to storage to remove it without purging it from the application.Or, if you want to completely remove it from the application, decommission it to archive and then purge it. Once it isin an Archived status, it can be completely remove them from the database. See Purge Archived Items fromdcTrack.The following criteria must be met to delete items from dcTrack:The item must be in a Planned stateNo open requests or work orders can exist for the itemYou must be the person who created the item or have edit privileges to the itemThe item cannot be deleted if a power or data connection exists to itDeleting an item may impact other items it is associated with, as well as any connections. This is why you cannotsimply open a cabinet's item page and delete an item from that page for example.When you delete items, additional ports created for the item, IP addresses, applications added to it, and so on, isalso deleted.The item is permanently deleted from the database.If it is linked to an object on the floor map, that link is severed but the object itself is not affected.It is removed from the cabinet elevation if it was added to a cabinet.1. In the Web Client, click Assets > Items List. The Items List page opens.2. Select the item you want to delete. Only one item can be deleted a time.3. Click Delete.4. Click Delete on the confirmation message.

To delete an item from its item page:1. After opening the item's page from the Items List page, click Delete.2. Click Delete on the confirmation message.Cloning is a faster way to create new items rather than creating them from scratch.Cloning cabinets along with the items in it is particularly useful if many or all cabinets in your data center are thesame and are populated with the same devices. Rather than having to create a new cabinet and add devices to iteach time you add a new cabinet, you just clone an existing cabinet, then edit the clone's information as needed tomake it unique.Update each clone's information so it is unique, such as updating the item names, by manually editing the inform-ation or using making bulk updates. Bulk updates are made by first exporting the clone's information to a .CSV file,updating the information in the .CSV, and then reimporting the file using dcTrack's File Import.Clone a single item, or multiple items at once. Depending on the item being cloned, you can elect to clone an item'sdata ports, power ports, sensor ports and custom field data. You can also elect to maintain parent-child relationshipsbetween items, such as the parent-child relation of chassis-blades.When cloning cabinets, you can elect to clone just the cabinet, or cabinet and all the cabinet's items. When youclone the entire cabinet and its items:All items within the cabinet are clonedAll zero U items on the cabinet, such as zero U rack PDUs attached to the front/back/left/rear of the cabinet, areclonedAll device items above and below the cabinet, such as a busway outlets, are cloned. Free-standing items, suchas floor PDUs, are not cloned; they must be cloned individually as single items or multiple itemsThe parent-child relationships between the cabinet (parent) and the items in the cabinet (children) is maintainedwhen a cabinet is cloned. For example, each child item in the cabinet remains in the same U position within thecabinet, the rail orientation of the child item remains the same and so on.The parent-child relationships between the children of the child items are maintained. For example, the rela-tionship between blades that are the children of a chassis within a cloned cabinet are maintained.The following are examples of parent-child relationships maintained during the cloning process where they alreadyexist for items and cabinets:Parent cabinet > Child devices in cabinet > Children of child devices within the cabinetParent chassis > Child bladeParent network stack > Child network itemsParent floor PDU > Child panel

No special privileges are needed for cloning.You must just be able to create, edit and delete items in dcTrack.Supported Classes and SubclassesAny item class and subclass in dcTrack can be cloned.For example, chassis and blade devices, floor PDUs and power outlets, virtual machines and so on.Clones can be created from items and cabinets in any status.During the cloning process, you assign either a Planned or Storage status to the cloned item.

Up to 999 clones can be made at a time from an existing item or cabinet.Cloned Item Naming Conventions for Standard ItemsStandard, cloned item names consist of the Original Item Name plus ^^ followed by a clone IDFor example:Original item - DELL-R710Clones - DELL-R710^^7384, DELL-R710^^7385For network stacks, if the parent-child relationship between other items connected to the stack are maintained dur-ing the cloning process, the clone names consist of the ORIGINALITEM_STACKNAME plus ^^ and the < clone'sstack primary item id >For example:Original item and network stack - BLADE1_NET1Clones - BLADE1__NET1^^4566, BLADE1__NET1^^4567For each stack member, the new item name is made up of the ORIGINALITEM_STACKNAME-0n^^<clone's stackprimary item id> where n is a number greater than 0For example:Clones - BLADE1__NET1-01^^4566, BLADE1__NET1-02^^4566, BLADE1__NET1-03^^4566If the parent-child relationship with other items connected to the network stack is not maintained during the cloningprocess, the clone names consist of the ORIGINALITEM_ITEMNAME1^^<clone's item id>For example:Original Item - CHASSIS1_BLADE1Clones - CHASSIS1_BLADE1^^7789, CHASSIS1_BLADE1^^7790

Following are examples of supported cloning scenarios.Single item cloning is supported for:A single cabinetA single device item, including chassis and bladesA single device virtual machineA single network item, including chassis and bladesUPSFloor PDUPower outletRack PDUCooling UnitsProbeCloning single items and their item containers:A free-standing device item with its container cabinetA free-standing network item with its container cabinetCloning single items and their children:A cabinet with items it containsA chassis with blades it containsA network stack with multiple stack membersCloning multiple items:A blade chassis with blades from one cabinet, an Ethernet switch, and a rack PDU from another cabinetCloning multiple items with children:A cabinet with some items, including a blade chassis with bladesA cabinet with all items, including a blade chassis with blades1. In the Web Client, select Assets > Items List to access the Items List page.2. In the Item List, double-click on the item you want to clone.The item's page opens in a new tab.3. Click Clone at the top of the page. If the Clone icon is disabled, the item cannot be cloned.The Cloning Dialog opens, and the Selected Item(s) box contains a list of the items to be cloned.4. Complete the required fields at a minimum."Times to clone selected Items(s)" - number of clones to create RequiredLocation - location to add the clones to. Required"Status of cloned Items" - status to apply to the clones."Include children Items" - select to clone the item's children. Checkbox is disable if not applicable."Maintain parent-child associations" - selected by default when "Include children Items" is selected, deselectto sever the parent-child relationship."Include Far End Data Panel and Structured Cabling" - select to maintain the connection between the itemand data panel, and any structured cabling.Select include data ports, power ports, sensor ports and custom fields as needed."Filter Items List to show cloned Items" - leave selected to automatically open the List Items page and filterthe page to display newly cloned items once they are created.5. Click the Clone button. Your cursor becomes a timer as the cloning process runs.Once the cloning process completes, the Cloning Dialog closes.Cloned items are contained on the Item's List page.The Items List page opens automatically if you selected the "Filter Items list to show cloned Items" checkbox on theCloning Dialog (see View Newly Created Clones).6. Edit the newly cloned information as needed (see Update a Clone's Information), then update its status( Update a Clone's Status).

Click Clone at the top of the Items List page.If the Clone icon is disabled, one or more items cannot be cloned.The Cloning Dialog opens. The Selected Item(s) box contains a list of the items to be cloned.4. Click the Clone button. Your cursor becomes a timer as the cloning process runs.Once the cloning process completes, the Cloning Dialog closes.Cloned items are contained on the Item's List page.The Items List page opens automatically if you selected the "Filter Items list to show cloned Items" checkbox on theCloning Dialog (see View Newly Created Clones).6. Edit the newly cloned information as needed (see Update a Clone's Information), then update its status( Update a Clone's Status).To clone a single cabinet and its contents to create new cabinets:1. In the Web Client, select Assets > Items List to access the Items List page.2. In the Item List, double-click on the cabinet you want to clone.The cabinet's page opens in a new tab.3. Click Clone at the top of the page to open the Cloning Dialog.If the Clone icon is disabled, the cabinet cannot be cloned.The Cloning Dialog opens, and the Selected Item(s) box contains the cabinet to be cloned.4. Complete the required fields at a minimum."Number of times to clone selected Items(s)" - number of clones to create RequiredLocation of cloned Items- location to add the clones to. Just the cabinet is cloned if not selected."Maintain parent-child associations" - selected by default when "Include children Items" is selected, deselectto sever the parent-child relationship."Include Far End Data Panel and Structured Cabling" - select to maintain the connection between the itemand data panel, and any structured cabling."Include Data Ports" - select to include the Data Ports of the Cabinet's children. This option is onlyapplicable when the "Include children Items" option is selected.Include Custom Fields Data - select to include Custom Field data on cloned Items."Filter Items List to show cloned Items" - leave selected to automatically open the List Items page and filterthe page to display newly cloned items once they are created.Click the Clone button.Note: If cloning a cabinet would cause you to exceed your dcTrack® license, you are prevented by dcTrack fromcloning the cabinet.Once the cloning process completes, the Cloning Dialog closes.Cloned cabinets, and cloned cabinet items if they were cloned too, can be viewed on the Item's List page.The Items List page opens automatically if you selected the "Filter Items list to show cloned Items" checkbox on theCloning Dialog. In the Item List, use select the cabinets you want to clone.3. Click Clone at the top of the Items List page.If the Clone icon is disabled, it means one or more of the cabinets you selected cannot be cloned.The Cloning Dialog opens, and the Selected Item(s) box contains the cabinet to be cloned.4. Just the cabinet is cloned if not selected."Maintain parent-child associations" - selected by default when "Include children Items" is selected, deselectto sever the parent-child relationship."Include Far End Data Panel and Structured Cabling" - select to maintain the connection between the itemand data panel, and any structured cabling.Select include data ports, power ports, sensor ports and custom fields as needed."Filter Items List to show cloned Items" - leave selected to automatically open the List Items page and filterthe page to display newly cloned items once they are created.Note: If cloning a cabinet would cause you to exceed your dcTrack® license, you are prevented by dcTrack fromcloning the cabinet.Once the cloning process completes, the Cloning Dialog closes.Cloned cabinets, and cloned cabinet items if they were cloned too, can be viewed on the Item's List page.The Items List page opens automatically if you selected the "Filter Items list to show cloned Items" checkbox on theCloning Dialog. 'Cloning' is indicated as the origin of each clone in the Origincolumn. The clone retains this origin value throughout its life in dcTrack.When cabinets with items are cloned, they are displayed on the Items List page.The cloned cabinet items and their items are displayed in the Name column, and cloned cabinets they are containedin are displayed in the Cabinets column.The Items List is filtered by default to display only the newly cloned items, or cabinets and cabinet items that werecloned.By default, the list is sorted by the date and time each clone was created (as indicated in the Created On column).

Once clones are created, make changes to each clone's information as needed so it is unique. For example, changethe clone names, update serial numbers, aliases and so on.Manually update cloned item information, or use the export and import features in dcTrack to quickly update multipleitems and cabinets at once.Manually Update ClonesManually update a clone's information using the Edit feature just like any other item in dcTrack. See Editing Itemsand Circuits for information on editing each type of item.Quickly update the information for a large number of clones at once using dcTrack's export and import features.Export the cloned item and/or cabinets and cabinet item information to an Item Template from the Items List, makeupdates to the items such as bulk renaming, updating serial numbers and so on, then use File Import to reimport theitems and update them all at once.For details, see Export Data to Import Templates for Reimporting, Use File Import to Edit or Delete Locations,Cabinets, Items or Connections and Use File Import to Bulk Rename Items.Note: Users with the Operator Without Delete role cannot change the model of a cloned item because they cannotdelete item ports, which is required to change the model.

When a clone is created, you can elect on the Cloning dialog to put it in a state of Planned or Storage.After a clone is created, you can manually update its status or bulk update its status as you do with any other item.For details on bulk updating status of clones, see Use File Import to Update the Status of Items in Bulk.Manually update the status of clones using the Actions menu or Status drop-down menu.Depending on your role's privileges, submit an Install Item Request by selecting from the Actions menu in the WebClient to install the item, or change the items status directly on the item page by selecting from the Status drop-downmenu.Once items are added to dcTrack, you can apply various methods to quickly locate items and information aboutthose items.Search for a Specific Item in the Data Center - Web Client Quick Item SearchUse Quick Item Search in the Web Client to locate a specific item in the data center.Enter your search criteria and press the Enter key on your keyboard to begin the search. The Quick Item Search sup-ports full or partial search criteria.Results of the search are then displayed on the page where they can be accessed by double-clicking on them, orusing the Edit or View buttons.Note: Use the Export to CSV file feature to export the search results to and save the information (if needed).

Change an item's U position in a cabinet by:Selecting a new position from the U Position drop-downOrDragging-and-dropping an item in a cabinet elevation to move it to a new position within the cabinetSee Drag-and-Drop an Item to a New U Position in a Cabinet.Drag-and-drop is supported in the Web Client.For rackable and non-rackable items, you can drag-and-drop from one U position to another available U position inthe Cabinet Elevation. You can do this anywhere in dcTrack where you can view the Cabinet Elevation.You must have edit permission for the item you want to drag and drop from one U position to another.When using this feature in the Cabinet Elevation of item details, item must be in edit mode.In the item details Cabinet Elevation you can only drag and drop that item. You can not drag and drop other items inthe item details Cabinet Elevation.However Cabinet Elevation in other screens of dcTrack like Item List, Visualization, Capacity Search you can dragand drop any item from one u position to another u position.Passive items are dragged-and-dropped in the Cabinet Elevation on the cabinet's item page.Zero-U items are not supported.You can also drag-and-drop an item to a different cabinet. See Drag and Drop an item to a different cabinetYou cannot move an entire cabinet using drag-and-drop. Instead, submit a Quick Move Item Request. See MoveItem Requests for Cabinets.Privileges See Edit Access Privileges to Items.Statuses Items in any status with the exception of Archived.Any rackable/non-rackable item of any class, drag-and-drop is supported in the Cabinet Elevation.Passive items, , drag-and-drop is supported on the cabinet's page.ItemsZero-U items are not supported.See Identifying an Item in a Cabinet Elevation.Drag-and-drop an item to any free position within the same cabinet that has sufficient, contiguousrack units to accommodate the item.Once saved, the item's previously occupied space is made available for new items.Drag-and-drop can be performed in a Cabinet Elevation while in Text view and Image view.Drag-and-drop items mounted on the front rails to RUs on the front of the cabinet from the FrontPosition in cab-view.inet and elev-Drag-and-drop items mounted on the rear rails to RUs on the rear of the cabinet from the Backation viewview.Drag-and-drop items mounted on both rails from either the Front view or Back view.See Cabinet Elevation Drop-Down - Front, Back, Image and Text.Drag-and-drop is not supported when moving items above or below cabinets. Select either Aboveor Below from the U Position drop-down to move an item above or below a cabinet, if applicable.Connections All connections are retained.Note: You must drag-and-drop items located on front rails from the Front elevation view and items on rear rails fromthe Back elevation view. Items mounted on both rails can be dragged-and-dropped from either the Front or Rearelevation view.To drag and drop items within a location follow below steps :1. Left-click on the item in the Cabinet Elevation, then drag-and-drop the item to a position in the cabinet with suf-ficient contiguous rack units to accommodate it.For the available U position, you will notice a green highlight.For example, U positions 30 and 31 are free in a cabinet. You can drag-and-drop a 2 RU server from its current loc-ation of U position 28 to U position 30 and you will notice green highlight when you place it at U position 30. If you tryto drop the item at U position 31 you will notice a red highlight, the item will move back to the original U position andcannot be dropped.The U Position drop-down is updated with the item's new RU once the item is dropped into its new position.The item's connections are retained when its position is changed within the cabinet.Note: You need to Save the item only when you are dragging and dropping the item in Cabinet elevation of itemdetails page.Optional: If you are using dcTrack's Change Control workflow, you can submit a Quick Move Item Request insteadof using drag-and-drop or manually changing the item's position in the Slot drop-down.

As of dcTrack 7.2 users can move items from one cabinet to another by dragging the item in the cabinet elevationfrom one cabinet to another cabinet. This feature is available in the Items List where you can select multiple cabinetsand view the cabinet elevation for selected cabinets.Rackable and Non-Rackable items can be moved from one cabinet to another with drag and drop.Passive items can also be dragged and dropped from one cabinet to another cabinet.Zero-U items are not supported.You must have edit access for the item and the destination cabinet where you want to drop the item.You can drag and drop only one item at a time.Drag-and-drop an item in Installed Status from one cabinet to another cabinet will issue a move request and the itemdropped will be a new “when-moved” item. The original dragged item remains in its original cabinet till the moverequest is complete.Privileges Requires edit access of item and the destination cabinet.
