See here Configuring Options forSingle and Multi-Select List Typefor more details.You can also enter additional Project information by creating custom fields. See here Project Custom Fields for moredetails.

Project can be edited to correct or update data after the project is created.Steps to Edit a Project:1. Navigate to the Project List page from the from the Change menu.2. Double click the row for the record you want to edit, or you can select one or more rows from the list and clickthe Edit button on the tool bar (when editing multiple rows each record will be opened in a separate detailpage tab).3. Enter the updated information.4. Save the Project.Project can be deleted.Steps to Delete a Project:1. Navigate to the Project List page from the from the Change menu.2. Double click the row for the record you want to delete, or you can select one or more rows from the list andclick the Delete button on the tool bar.Note : You need to have System Administrator or Global Gatekeeper role to delete a project. Users with loc-ation level Gatekeeper permission can not delete project.

Items can be assigned to Projects using the standard item field Project Number.Steps to assign items to projects :1. Navigate to the item you want to assign project.2. Click on the Asset and Maintenance sub tab at the bottom of the Item Details page.3. Click the Edit button for the Item4. Click Project Number field and select the project number you want to assign the item to. The drop down list ispopulated with all the projects created in dcTrack database. You can search for Project Number by typing theProject Number or Project Name.5. Save the item.Click on the hyperlink icon in the Project Number field to navigate to Project Detail screen.You can also assign items in bulk using :Bulk Edit : When items are already created in dcTrack. See Bulk Edit Item Fields for more details.File Import : When you are creating items in bulk using file import. Include Project Number column in the csvfile to be imported.Public API : When you are creating items using Public API. Include the Project Number field in the request.Place Items using Capacity Intelligent Search : When you place the items in bulk using Capacity Search. SeePlacing Items using Capacity Intelligent Search for more details.Note : In dcTrack 8.1 onwards you can not create project number on fly by entering new project number whenadding or editing items/ circuits via UI, File Import or API. Project Number entered should be an existing ProjectNumber in dcTrack database.All the items that are assigned to Project will show in the Items sub tab of Project Detail screen. The list also includesthe items that were previously assigned to this Project.Item list in this sub tab show all the items assigned to the project. The list include all the columns from Item List. Tospecify which columns are shown or hidden, click the Show/Hide columns icon.Refer to the table below for details on Items Sub Tab toolbar.Add anOpens a new page to add an item. Project Number field will be auto populated for the new itemItemRemoveUnassign the selected items from the project. If the selected item has pending Request, it will not befrom Pro-removed from the Project.jectView Opens one or more selected items in View modeEdit Opens one or more selected items in Edit modeBulk Edit Opens the Bulk Edit dialogue to bulk edit selected item fieldsActions Drop down that allows toggling Request Bypass, Install, Decommission requests etc.Delete Deletes the selected itemsRefresh Refreshes the Item List subtabShow inNavigates to the Item List filtered to just the Items for the ProjectAssets

Steps to unassign item from the project :1. Navigate to project you want to unassign the item.2. Click Items sub tab in Project Details screen.3. Select one ore more items in the list and click the button Remove from Project.Item list is refreshed and the selected item is unassigned from the project.Circuits can be assigned to Projects using the standard circuit field Project Number.Steps to assign circuits to projects :1. Navigate to the circuit you want to assign project.2. Click Circuit Detail.3. In the Circuit Detail dialogue, click Edit button.4. Click Project Number field and select the project number you want to assign the circuit to. The drop down listis populated with all the projects created in dcTrack database. You can search for Project Number by typingthe Project Number or Project Name.5. Click Save and close the dialogue.You can also assign circuits in bulk using :File Import : When you are creating circuits in bulk using file import. Include Project Number column in the csvfile to be imported.Public API : When you are creating circuits using Public API. Include the Project Number field in the request.Note : In dcTrack 8.1 onwards you can not create project number on fly by entering new project number whenadding or editing items/ circuits via UI, File Import or API. Project Number entered should be an existing ProjectNumber in dcTrack database.

All the Circuits that are assigned to Project will show in the Circuits sub tab of Project Detail screen.Circuit list in this sub tab show all the circuits assigned to the project. The list include all the columns from CircuitList. To specify which columns are shown or hidden, click the Show/Hide columns icon.Refer to the table below for details on Circuit sub tab toolbar.Add a Cir-Opens a new page to add Circuit. Project Number field will be auto populated for the new circuit.cuitRemoveUnassign the selected circuits from the project. If the selected circuit has pending Request, it will not befrom Pro-removed from the Project.jectView Opens one or more selected Circuits on a single or multiple tabs in View mode.Edit Opens one or more selected Circuits on a single or multiple tabs in Edit mode.Delete Deletes the selected Circuits.Refresh Refreshes the Circuit List.Actions Dropdown that allows toggling Request Bypass, Connecting or Disconnecting Circuits.Show inNavigate to filtered item list containing the items assigned to selected projects in the list.AssetsSteps to unassign circuit from the project :1. Navigate to project you want to unassign the circuit.2. Click Circuits sub tab in Project Details screen.3. Select one ore more Circuits in the list and click the button Remove from Project.Circuit list is refreshed and the selected circuit is unassigned from the project.

dcTrack 8.1.0 allows you to keep track of all the Requests and Work Orders created for a Project.When the items and circuits get assigned to a Project, Requests created for those items and circuits also getassigned to the Project.You can view the list of Requests assigned to a Project in the Request Sub tab of Project Details screen.Work Orders created for those Requests also get assigned to the same Project Number.You can view the list of Requests assigned to a Project in the Request Sub tab of Project Details screen.dcTrack allows you to define relationship between Projects. You can set the relationship of any of your projects suchas parent/ child or other relationship. You can also specify whether one project starts after another to streamline theprocess.Steps to Create Project Relationship :1. Navigate to the Project List page from the from the Change menu.2. Double click the row for the Project you want to create Relationship.3. Click Relationship sub tab of Project.4. Click Add a Relationship.5. Provide the following information to create Relationship.a. Relation Type : Select the Relation Type from the drop down. If the Relation Type you are looking fordoes not appear in the drop down option then you can create Relation Type from Field Managementscreen. See here Configuring Options for Single and Multi-Select List for more details. Required.b. Project Number : Select the Project Number from the list. You can also search for the Project by enter-ing the Project Number or Project Name. Required.c. Comment : Optional.6. Click Create.Related Project will appear in the Relationship sub tab.To Delete Project Relationship :1. Navigate to the Project List page from the from the Change menu.2. Double click the row for the Project you want to delete Relationship.3. Click Relationship sub tab of Project.4. Select one or more Relationships from the list.5. Click Delete.Note : To create and delete Project Relationship, you must have edit permission for the Project.You can also create and delete Project Relationship using File Import /Export. Refer to the examples in the sampleimport template for Projects. See here Importing and Exporting Projects for more details

Changes to project's information are tracked in the Audit Trail log. Each Project's Audit Trail log is accessible fromthe Project's Audit Trail sub tab on the Project Detail page.Project Audit Trail log also captures the record when an item, circuit get assigned to a project or are unassigned fromthe project.You can sort and filter the audit trail grid as needed. You can also export the audit trail log in csv and pdf format.To view the audit log for projects across the database you can design your own custom sql grid widget. For addi-tional information about creating Sql Grid Widgets see Custom Sql Grid Widgets.File import/ export can be used to create, edit and delete projects. You must have the System Administrator or the"Bulk Import" role to create and manage projects.

Projects exported from the Project List grid page. Users have two options when exporting Projects. You can "ExportProject List Exactly as Shown" or "Export into an Import Template". When exporting the list exactly as shown, youcan export only selected rows, First 500 rows or All rows. dcTrack will generate a .csv file that contains a record foreach row in the list with just the columns available in the current view.When exporting the list into an Import Template, you can export only the visible columns or export all the columns.The exported .csv file will contain a record for each row in the list. The Operation column in the template will be set to"Edit" for each Project row.Exactly as ShownImport TemplateTo import Projects access the main File Import page by clicking the Import button located at the top of every dcTrackpage.You can then select the file you wish to import by clicking the Browse button to begin the upload process.Note: Import templates for all object types can be downloaded from the main import page by clicking the appro-priate option from the right side panel.For additional information on using the File Import feature, please refer to the help on Use File Import to Add, EditDelete and Move.

dcTrack 8.2.0 and beyond includes a new Ticketing feature. This feature allows you to create and manage Ticketsbetween dcTrack and any external Ticketing system that provides public REST API access to their Ticketing data.Additionally, this feature also supports manual Tickets that are not integrated with any external system but allow youto track progress and tasks within dcTrack.For information about Ticketing integration please see: Integrate with Ticketing SystemsTicket ListTicket Custom FieldsAdding and Managing TicketsAssigning Items to TicketsAssigning Circuits to TicketsTicket RelationshipsTicket Audit TrailTo access the Ticket List, navigate to Change -> Tickets.This list contains a row for each Ticket in dcTrack regardless of whether it was created in dcTrack or created viaintegration. Every field applicable to a Tickt is available on the grid.You can Show or Hide columns using the Show/Hide icon in the upper right corner of the grid. Fields in the gridcan be repositioned by dragging and dropping the column to the desired position. Each field is filterable and sortablefrom the column header.

Add aOpens a new page to add a TicketTicketView Opens one or more selected Tickets in View modeEdit Opens one or more selected Tickets in Edit modeDelete Deletes the selected TicketsRefresh Refreshes the Ticket ListThe Fields Management feature now includes support for Ticket Custom fields in addition to its existing support forProject, Items, Circuits and Parts. Custom Fields. Ticket Custom Fields enable organizations to capture and displayadditional Ticket data that may not be covered by dcTrack's Standard Fields.Users with the System Administrator role or who have the Field Management Operator auxiliary role can add, edit,and delete Custom Fields.For detailed information on managing Custom Fields please see: Standard and Custom Fields

Tickets can be added via the Web Client or created from an external application via Ticketing integration. Users witheither the Operator, Gatekeeper or System Administrator role can add and manage Tickets.Steps to Add a Ticket in dcTrack:1. Navigate to the Add a Ticket page from the from the Change Menu or select the Add a Ticket button on theTickets List tool bar. Provide the following information in New Ticket Tab.2. External System - For integrated Tickets, select the Connector record from the drop down. For Tickets thatshould not be integrated, leave this field blank.3. Ticket Number - If you have selected a Connector indicating this is to be an integrated Ticket, this field will beread-only. When the record is saved, the field will be auto populated with the dcTrack generated Ticket Num-ber. Upon successful integration, this field will be updated with the Ticket Number for the associated Ticket onthe external system. For non-integrated Tickets, you can supply a globally unique value or leave the fieldblank and dcTrack will auto populate the field with the dcTrack generated Ticket Number.4. Summary - Enter a brief description for the Ticket. This field is optional on dcTrack but depending on the fieldmapping could be required by the external system.5. Ticket Type - For non-integrated Tickets, this field is read only. For Integrated Tickets, select the Ticket Typefrom the drop down list. This list is populated with the Ticket Types defined in the Connector record for theselected Connector.6. Ticket Purpose - Select the Ticket Purpose from the drop down. This field is optional on dcTrack but depend-ing on the field mapping could be required by the external system.7. Other Purpose - When the selected Ticket Purpose is "Other", you must select the appropriate Other Pur-pose from the drop down. This list is populated with the user defined options supplied as Pick List Options forthe "Ticket Other Purpose" field in the Field Management feature.8. Location - Select the associated Location from the drop down. This list is populated with all dcTrack Loca-tions that can contain assets. This field is optional on dcTrack but depending on the field mapping could berequired by the external system. This field is required if you want to supply a value in the Project Number field.9. Description - Enter a detailed Description for the Ticket. This field is optional on dcTrack but depending onthe field mapping could be required by the external system.10. dcTrack Status - Read Only. This field is updated automatically for Tickets managed by dcTrack's Workflowfeatures.11. Status Date - Read Only. This field is updated automatically for Tickets managed by dcTrack's Workflow fea-tures. It displays the date the "dcTrack Status" field was last updated.12. Ticket Status - Select the appropriate Ticket Status from the drop down. This list is populated with the userdefined options supplied as Pick List Options for the "Ticket Status" field in the Field Management feature.This field is optional on dcTrack but depending on the field mapping could be required by the external system.13. Due Date - Enter the Due Date for the Ticket. This field is optional on dcTrack but depending on the field map-ping could be required by the external system.14. Priority - Select the appropriate Priority for the Ticket from the drop down. This list is populated with the userdefined options supplied as Pick List Options for the "Ticket Priority" field in the Field Management feature.This field is optional on dcTrack but depending on the field mapping could be required by the external system.15. Severity - Select the appropriate Severity for the Ticket from the drop down. This list is populated with theuser defined options supplied as Pick List Options for the "Ticket Severity" field in the Field Management fea-ture. This field is optional on dcTrack but depending on the field mapping could be required by the externalsystem.16. Project Number - Select the appropriate Project Number for the Ticket from the drop down. This list is pop-ulated with the all of the valid Projects on dcTrack whose Location matches the Ticket Location. This field isoptional on dcTrack but depending on the field mapping could be required by the external system.17. Assigned To -Select the appropriate Assignee for the Ticket from the drop down. This list is populated withthe user defined options supplied as Pick List Options for the "Ticket Assigned To" field in the Field Man-agement feature. This field is optional on dcTrack but depending on the field mapping could be required bythe external system.You can also enter additional Ticket information by creating custom fields. See here Ticket Custom Fields for moredetails.

Any Ticket can be edited to correct or update data after the Ticket is created. For integrated Tickets, fields owned bythe external system will be read only. Fields owned by "dcim" or "both" can be updated and upon saving will bepushed to the external system.Steps to Edit a Project:1. Navigate to the Ticket List page from the from the Change menu.2. Double click the row for the record you want to edit, or you can select one or more rows from the list and clickthe Edit button on the tool bar (when editing multiple rows each record will be opened in a separate detailpage tab).3. Enter the updated information.4. Save the Ticket.Any Ticket on dcTrack can be deleted. Tickets deleted on dcTrack will also be deleted on the external system if the<pushDeleteToTicket> element in the Ticketing Config file is set to "true".Steps to Delete a Ticket:1. Navigate to the Ticket List page from the from the Change menu.2. Double click the row for the record you want to delete, or you can select one or more rows from the list andclick the Delete button on the tool bar.

Items can be assigned to Tickets from the Items sub tab on the Ticket Detail page or via integration when configuredin the Ticketing Connector Config. For more information on integrating Item assignments please see the Integratewith Ticketing Systems documentation.Steps to assign items to Tickets in dcTrack:1. Navigate to the Ticket you want to assign the Item to.2. Click on the Item sub tab at the bottom of the Ticket Details page.3. To create a new Item that is automatically assigned to the Ticket, Click the "Add an Item" button.4. To Assign an existing Item(s) click the "Assign an Item" button.5. Select the Item(s) you want to assign from the Search for Items dialog. You can filter using any columns tonarrow your selection options.6. Once you have selected the Items to be assigned, click the Select Items button.7. The selected Items will be assigned to the Ticket on dcTrack and if configured in the Connector will be asso-ciated to the Ticket on the external system.8. To remove an Item association click the "Remove from Ticket" button.Clicking on the hyperlink in the Item Name field will navigate to the Item Detail screen.Additional Actions available from the Item Sub tab tool bar:Add anOpens a new page to add an item. The new Item will be automatically associated to the Ticket.ItemRemoveUn-assign the selected items from the Ticket.from TicketView Opens one or more Item Detail pages in View modeEdit Opens one or more Item Detail pages in Edit modeBulk Edit Opens the Bulk Edit dialogue to bulk edit selected item fieldsActions Drop down that allows toggling Request Bypass, Install, Decommission requests etc.Delete Deletes the selected itemsRefresh Refreshes the Item ListCircuits can be assigned to Tickets using the standard circuit field Ticket Number.Steps to assign circuits to Tickets :1. Navigate to the circuit you want to assign to a Ticket.2. Click Circuit Detail.3. In the Circuit Detail dialogue, click Edit button.4. Click Ticket Number field and select the Ticket number you want to assign the circuit to. The drop down list ispopulated with all the Tickets created in dcTrack database whose Location matches the circuit or Tickets withno Location specified. You can search for Ticket Numbers by typing the Ticket Number in the Ticket Numberfield.5. Click Save and close the dialogue.

All the Circuits that are assigned to a Ticket will display on the Circuits sub tab of Ticket Detail screen.The Circuit list in this sub tab displays all the circuits assigned to the Ticket. The list includes all the columns from Cir-cuit List. To specify which columns are shown or hidden, click the Show/Hide columns icon.Refer to the table below for details on Circuit sub tab toolbar.Add a Cir-Opens a new page to add a Circuit. The circuit will be automatically associated with the Ticket.cuitRemoveUnassign the selected circuits from the Ticket.from TicketView Opens one or more selected Circuits on a single or multiple tabs in View mode.Edit Opens one or more selected Circuits on a single or multiple tabs in Edit mode.Delete Deletes the selected Circuits.Refresh Refreshes the Circuit List.Actions Dropdown that allows toggling Request Bypass, Connecting or Disconnecting Circuits.Show inNavigate to a filtered item list containing the selected Circuits First Node items.AssetsdcTrack allows you to define relationships between Tickets. Relationships between integrated Tickets are managedthrough the settings defined in your Ticketing Connector xml. If relationships have been defined for Integrated Tick-ets, an additional button is displayed in the Ticket Detail Page tool bar to create the Related Ticket. The label for thisbutton is defined as part of the Relationship definition in the Ticketing Connector configuration file. For additionalinformation about setting up the Ticketing Connector is dcTrack, please see: Integrate with Ticketing Systems.Please Note: For integrated Tickets, you should never create Relationships from the Relationship sub tab. Rela-tionships created from this sub tab will not be reflected on the external application.Steps to create a Relationship for an Integrated Ticket:1. After defining the relationship in the Ticketing Connector Configuration file, navigate to the Ticket you wish tocreate the relationship for.2. In the top tool bar you will see a button to create the Child Ticket as defined in the configuration.3. Click the "Create ..." button to open a new Create Ticket page.4. Supply the data for the integrated fields on the new Ticket.5. Click Save to save the new Ticket.6. Refresh the page to see if the Ticket is successfully integrated. If the Ticket was successfully integrated theAuto Generated Ticket Number will be replaced by the Ticket Number as it exists on the external application.For Integrations that use polling, the refresh will reflect the new Ticket Number only after the next Poll hasoccurred.7. Once successfully integrated, the related ticket is displayed on the Relationship sub tab for both the ChildTicket and the Parent Ticket.For manual Tickets (Tickets that are not integrated with an external application), Relationships are created from theRelationship sub tab.Steps to Create Ticket Relationships for non integrated Tickets:1. Navigate to the Ticket List page from the from the Change menu.2. Double click the row of the Ticket for which you want to create the Relationship.3. Click the Relationship sub tab of Ticket.4. Click Add a Relationship.5. Provide the following information to create Relationship.a. Relation Type : Select the Relation Type from the drop down. If the Relation Type you are looking fordoes not appear in the drop down option then you can create a new Relation Type as a pick list optionfrom the Field Management screen. See Configuring Options for Single and Multi-Select Lists for moredetails. Required.b. Ticket Number : Select the Ticket Number from the list. You can also search for the Ticket by typing theTicket Number into the field. Required.c. Comment : Enter any Comments related to the relationship. Optional.6. Click Create.The Related Ticket is displayed on the Relationship sub tab for both Tickets.To Delete a Ticket Relationship :1. Navigate to the Ticket List page from the from the Change menu.2. Double click the row of the Ticket for which you want to delete the Relationship.3. Click Relationship sub tab of Ticket.4. Select one or more Relationships from the list.5. Click Delete.

dcTrack provides the following default, prepopulated libraries:Item Models LibraryConnectors LibrarySNMP LibraryThese libraries are used by dcTrack when populating fields that require model information, connector types, equip-ment make names, and so on.Libraries can be edited by System Administrators so they can be customized based on company-specific needs.For example, you can designate certain models 'My Company Standard'. This allows users to filter model dialogs sothey display only those models used by your company.Another example is the ability to add or update model and connector images, add new models rather than wait for alibrary upgrade from Sunbird, manage blade chassis by defining anchor slots, slot numbering and so on.The Items Models Library is available in dcTrack 5.1.0 and higher. The Connectors Library is available in dcTrack7.2.0 and higher.

dcTrack uses the terms Sunbird Models Library file and Item Models Library.The Sunbird Models Library file is maintained by Sunbird and distributed to clients to update their Item ModelsLibrary with new model information."Item Models Library" always refers to your local library. This is the library on your sever that is updated with newmodels from the Sunbird Models Library file.The Sunbird Models Library file is available for download on the Sunbird DCIM Professional Services and Support athttp://support.sunbirddcim.com.Note: A username and password are required to access the DCIM Professional Services and Support site. If you donot have a username and password to access the website, contact Professional Services and Support via the Sup-port site.Updating the Item Models Library after you have implemented dcTrack for the first time is important in order toensure you are using the most current version.Updating before doing a large bulk import of items is a recommended practice so you can ensure all of the most cur-rent makes and models are found.Regularly updating your Item Models Library once you are using dcTrack ensures data consistency since Sunbirdadds new models on a regular basis. If you do not update the library, you run the risk of having library entries that aresimilar but not identical.For example, Sunbird may add a new server model named Server-1000. If you manually add the same model butcall it Server 1000, both model entries are available for selection by users.However, if you have already added models manually, you can map them to models in the Sunbird Models Libraryfile during the library update.

The Sunbird Models Library file files are incremental, not cumulative. This means each Sunbird Models Library filerelease contains only newly added models and updated models; the file does not contain all of the models in theentire Sunbird Models Library file.For example, file version 5.0.042 does not contain all the models in file 5.0.041.Note: If you have not updated each time a new file version was release, update to each of the previous Item ModelsLibrary versions before you update to the latest.You can do one of the following to request a model/make be added to the Sunbird Models Library file contact:Add a Model to the Models Library (provided you have privileges to do so)Contact Sunbird Professional Services and Support to request a model be added to the library and included inthe next Sunbird Models Library file releasesFor more information, see What To Do if A Make or Model Is Not Available for Selection.

Updates are performed using the Library Update Wizard, which walks you through each step of the process.Until the actual update has started, you can return to previous steps to make changes or cancel the update to clearall settings. If you cancel the update to close the Models Library update wizard, your uploaded file and changes willbe lost.Note: Only one Models Library update can occur at a time.Note: Download the Sunbird Models Library fileand save it locally before attempting to update the Models Library.You will need the file to update the library.1. If you have not already done so, download the most recent Sunbird Models Library file and save it locally.2. In the Models Library, select Actions > Update Models Library to access the Library Update Wizard.3. On the first step (welcome screen), click Start a New Update Session to start the wizard. The results of the pre-vious update will be displayed if available.4. On the second step, click Browse to locate the Sunbird Models Library file you saved locally.The file upload takes place in two stages: uploading and then processing/staging. Once this step has com-pleted, the following message is displayed: "Models Library Staging is successful without any errors or warn-ings. You may now proceed to next step." Click the green arrow to the right of the steps to proceed.5. Map information.Each step displays the items that do not exactly match the database objects. Users will be able to add non-matching items to the database or can select objects from a list of potential matches.Items that match exactly will be automatically updated in the database. These items are not displayed.If there is information in the Sunbird Models Library file that is not in your Item Models Library, it is automaticallycopied to your library once the wizard completes.Step 3 maps Data Connectors.Step 4 maps Power Connectors.Step 5 maps Protocols.Step 6 maps Data Rates.Step 7 maps Breakers and Fuses.Step 8 maps Makes.Step 9 maps Models.Certain rows in the grid may be flagged with a Warning or Error icons. Hovering the mouse over the icon revealsthe issue that you may be able to correct by changing the Best Match selection, or for certain errors, you mustchoose the Skip action and resolve the problem in your system.6. In Step 9, you will be able to generate a spreadsheet of Classis and Blade Items affected by the update (if any)and a spreadsheet of Actions on Models in the Update. Click the Export button to view these options.7. On Step 10, click Begin Library Update to begin the library update.New models are added and existing model information is updated once Begin Update is selected.As the process is underway, monitor the progress using the progress bar. No additional input is required, andthe update can be left to run unattended.8. Once the update is complete, the results will be displayed in the Results and Progress box.

Each model in the Sunbird Models Library file is given a version number based on the library update file it is issuedin.The library version you can upgrade to depends on your current version of dcTrack.3.x and later users, download the Sunbird Models Library file for your current dcTrack version.dcTrack 2.x users should contact Professional Services and Support via the Support website at http://sup-port.sunbirddcim.com for assistance.The Library Update Wizard provides a step-by-step walkthrough for updating the dcTrack Models Library and asso-ciated information as well as additional features that are available at different steps during the Wizard. For high-levelsteps when using the Wizard, see Item Models Library.Users are able to review the items in the update file that do not already exist in their databases and to compare theseitems with those in their databases that they may want to map. The best match is automatically displayed in the rowfor the item. The user can select to Use Best Match or Add.In the case of models, the user can select to User Best Match, Add, Skip or Always Skip. The details for the model inthe file and the model in the database are displayed, and differences are highlighted for easy comparison.Validation is performed on current selections and any errors or warnings are flagged using the appropriate icons. Allerrors must be resolved or skipped before the update can begin.To start the Library Update Wizard in the Web Client, select Settings > Models Library > Actions > Update ModelsLibrary.

The Models Library Update Wizard launches in a new tab within the Models Library.The progress bar along the top of the screen displays your progress through the wizard's 10 steps. Your current stepis marked in purple. Completed steps are marked in green. At any time before the update takes place, you mayreturn to the previous steps to edit your selections.A welcome message with important information on using the wizard displays on the left of the screen. The results ofthe last update session, if available, display in the Results of Last Update Session box on the right of the screen.To start a new update, click the green Start a New Update Session button.Note: Only one update can take place at a time. You cannot attempt to update the Models Library if another updateis already in progress.You need to download the most recent Sunbird Models Library file and save it locally to update the Models Library.The file is a Microsoft Access (mdb) database file and includes updates to the model data in your library.Click Browse to select the file and begin the file upload.The file upload takes place in two stages: uploading and then processing/staging. Once this step has completed, thefollowing message is displayed: "Models Library Staging is successful without any errors or warnings. You may nowproceed to next step."Note: When you upload a Models Library Update file (.mlu) to dcTrack, if a standard or network device model in thefile matches a model in your library and the "Do Not Update" option for the model is false, the ports in the MLU filewill overwrite the ports in your library regardless of whether the ports were modified by you. For Rack PDU powerports, if you modified any port, all power ports will be considered modified and no ports will be added from the MLUfile.Note: The file upload can be canceled at any time by closing out of the tab or by clicking the Cancel button abovethe progress bar.

The wizard walks users through mapping the information in the file with their current database for each of the fol-lowing items:Data ConnectorsPower ConnectorsProtocolsData RatesBreakers & FusesMakesModelsEach step displays the models that do not exactly match the models. Users will be able to add non-matching modelsto the database or can select objects from a list of potential matches.Models that are exact matches of models in the database will be automatically updated in the database. These mod-els are not displayed in the wizard.Map data connectors that are in your library to data connectors in the Sunbird Models Library file.

Map power connectors that are in your library to power connectors in the Sunbird Models Library file library.Protocol information includes Ethernet/IP address, HSSI information and so on that is in your library but not in theSunbird Models Library file.

Map data rates if, for example, a network item in your library may have a data rate of 2GB.If the model does not exist in the Sunbird Models Library file, add it so it is associated with the network item when thelibrary update is complete.Map circuit breakers and fuses if there are circuit breakers and fuses in the Sunbird Models Library file that are not inyour library, they are added.

If there are new makes in the Sunbird Models Library file that are not in your library, they are automatically copied toyour library during the data connectors step.If needed, map makes that are in your library to makes in the Sunbird Models Library file.Mapping is needed if makes in your library are named differently than those the Sunbird library.If an exact match to your library model is found in the Sunbird Models Library file, dcTrack updates your library withthe latest model information, ports and image (if any).If no exact match is found, dcTrack looks for the best match for the model. If a match is not found, dcTrack promptsyou to find a match or add it to the library.If you map a model in your library to a model in the Sunbird Models Library file but the models are not an exactmatch, all models that are currently using the Sunbird Models Library file model are updated in the database toreflect the new library model you apply.Note: In dcTrack version 9.0.0 and beyond, Model uniqueness will be determined based on the combination ofModel Name and Part Number.

In Step 9 of the wizard, dcTrack provides you with the following two options:Generate a spreadsheet to review all of the chassis and blade models affected by the upgradeGenerate a spreadsheet file to review the actions that will be taken for each model that is included in the updatefile during the upgrade processClick the Export button to view these options and to generate the files for review.Click the green Begin Library Update button to begin the update. The results will be displayed in the Results and Pro-gress box below the button.The red Start a New Update Session button at the bottom of the screen will start a new session and return you toStep 2 to upload a new file.Note: Up until you click the Begin Library Update button, you may return to previous steps to make changes to yourselections.

The Item Models Library contains the models and makes for each item you can add to dcTrack.dcTrack version 9.0.0 introduced several new Standard Model fields:Part NumberDescriptionMade inWarranty PeriodWeight Capacity - Applies to Cabinet, DC Bay, Plant Bay and AC Bay onlyAll of the new fields are optional, however the rule for determining uniqueness of a model will now include Part Num-ber. In other words, the combination of Model Name and Part Number must be unique across the data base includ-ing Model Aliases.For example, consider Model 1 whose Model Name is DL360 and whose Part Number is 123. Model 2 has a ModelName of DL360 and Part Number 456. In this scenario dcTrack will allow an alias of "DL360" to be created (the com-bination of Model Name: "DL360" Part Number: Null is unique), but would not allow alias "DL360 123" to be created(this would be considered a duplicate of Model 1).These fields can be used in File Import as well as CMDB configuration files.The following information is listed in the grid (from the far left column to the right column):MakeModel NamePart NumberDescriptionClassSubclassHeight (RUs)MountingFormHeight (RUs)Potential PowerOutput Volts (Vac)StatusMy Company StandardModels In UseCustom ModelsChassis Slot Count FrontChassis Slot Count BackData Ports CountPower Ports CountFront Image AvailableBack Image AvailableCreated OnModel VersionOriginNotesDon’t UpdateAdditional Model fields can be added to the grid by clicking the Show/Hide button.Select Settings > Models Library from the main navigational menu. The Models Library UI will display.Note: The Models Library is accessible from the Settings menu because managing the Models Library is an admin-istrative function. Only System Administrators are able to manage the Models Library.To view model details, double click on the row.On the Model Details page, the details are grouped logically and sub-tabs are provided for data ports, power ports,and chassis slot setup (if available).Note: If you are using Internet Explorer 10, you may encounter behavior where the power port grid for a rack PDUmay appear empty or as if rows are missing. Scroll the power port grid up or down to display the ports. Alternatively,use Chrome or a different version of Internet Explorer.A button is provided on the tool bar for viewing, adding, and deleting the model’s images.From this page you can Add and Delete images, as well as drag and drop Port labels to their correct position.To return to the Model Details page, click the Save or Cancel button at the bottom of the Model Image panel.

Use filter and sort to locate models in the Item Models Library.The library can be filtered and sorted based on criteria you select in the Filter by and Sort by dropdowns.In addition to these criteria, you can define an = variable to the filter and sort criteria.The available = variable selections vary based on the sort by and filter by criteria you select.The selections you apply to the filter and sort criteria are reflected on the page once they are made.

If you cannot find a specific make and model when attempting to add a new item to dcTrack, you can do one of thefollowing:Contact Professional Services and Support at http://support.sunbirddcim.com or via email at tech@sun-birddcim.com and request the information be added to the Sunbird Models Library file.Once the information is added, the next time you upgrade your Item Models Library with the latest Sunbird ModelsLibrary file, the new make and model are added.Submit a request to your System Administrator to manually add the make and model to your Item ModelsLibrary, if you do not have privileges to do so.Manually add the make and model to your Item Models Library, if you have privileges to do so.In addition to upgrading your Item Models Library with Sunbird Models Library file, you can add models to your lib-rary.Fields marked with an asterisk (*) are required.1. Go to the Settings tab > Models Library.2. In the Models Library, click the Add a Model icon in the upper left of the screen to open a New Model tab.3. Select the Models's class type from the Class drop-down.4. Select the model’s subclass from the Subclass drop-down. If the selected class does not have a subclass, thenthis field becomes read only and displays N/A.5. Select the Model's make from the Make drop-down. To add a new Make, click Makes in the New Model tab toopen the Manage Makes dialog. Enter the required information and click Save to create the make.Note: You can add another name by which the Make can be found in dcTrack for the Make by entering an Aliasin the "Alias" field of this dialog. This can useful when mapping models for newly discovered assets via fileimport or integration.6. Supply the Model name.7. Optionally supply the Part NumberNote: In dcTrack version 9.0.0 and beyond, Model uniqueness will be determined based on the combination ofModel Name and Part Number.8. Select the Model's mounting from the Mounting dropdown.9. Select the ModelForm Factor from the Form Factor dropdown.10. Enter the number of rack units required.11. Height is completed automatically based on the number of rack units.12. Enter the model's depth.13. Enter the model's weight.14. Leave Don't Update deselected.Note: This feature only applies when editing a model. It prevents changes you make to model information frombeing overwritten during a library upgrade.15. Select the My Company Standards checkbox if you want this model to appear as a selection when users filtermodels in certain dialogs.16. In the Specification Tab, enter the fields specific to the Model. All of the fields in the Model Specification Subtabare optional and can be used to provide additional model information.17. To specify an Alias for the Model, click the Miscellaneous Subtab and click on the "+" icon.18. Rules can also be applied to the Model by selecting the desired Rule on this subtab.19. Click to expand the Model Image pane and click Add to select and add front and rear images of the device to thelibrary. Images must be a .BMP files.Images are not required, but you must provide an image(s) to add ports to the model.Sunbird recommends the file size be 500KB or smaller so images load quicker in cabinet elevation views.20. Save the images and collapse the Model Image pane to return to the New Model tab.21. Click Save to save the model.Add data (comm) and Power ports to the model if applicable.At a minimum:No two ports of the same type can have the same index number. This means -Each physical, logical or virtual data port index number must be uniqueEach sensor port index number must be uniqueEach power port index number must be uniqueA port index number cannot be 0.Devices cannot have more than 8 power ports, so power port index numbers can only be numbered 1-8. Formore information, see Port Index Numbering and Port Naming.

1. In the Web Client, access the Settings tab > Models Library.2. Click to select the model you want to edit from the Models List.Note: You cannot update a model with items in use. You must unassign a model from all items before updating it.3. Click the Edit icon to enter Edit mode.4. Make changes as needed and/or update images as needed.Note: A cabinet model can be defined to be Zero U height. This allows floor space to be reserved to prevent over-loading conditions.5. Deselect the 'My Company Standard' checkbox if you want the model to be removed from the filtered options inmodel lists (Std.). See Designate Models as 'My Company Standard' in the dcTrack Item Models Library.6. If editing data (comm) or power ports:No two ports of the same type can have the same index number. This means -Each physical, logical or virtual data port index number must be uniqueEach sensor port index number must be uniqueEach power port index number must be uniqueA port index number cannot be 0.Devices cannot have more than 8 power ports, so power port index numbers can only be numbered 1-8.7. Select the Don't Update checkbox if you do not want the changes you are making to the model to be overwrittenwhen you perform a library upgrade.8. Click Save.To delete a model:1. In the Web Client, Navigate to Settings > Models Library.2. In the grid, click the check box to the left of the model to be deleted. The selected row will be highlighted.3. Click Actions > Delete.Note: The Delete action will be disabled if the Model selected is in use.

In dcTrack, aliases are additional terms by which a make or model can be matched. When adding items in bulk,through Power IQ or VMware integration, with external ticketing, or via file import, and you encounter item makesand/or models that are not recognized by dcTrack, you can map the make or model to an existing make or modelusing the actual name or an alias.1. Navigate to Settings > Models Library.2. Click the Makes button on the Models Library toolbar. The Manage Makes dialog popup displays.3. Provide the make details.4. Type the desired alias into the Alias field.5. Click the Add icon ("+") to add the alias.6. Click the Create button to create the new make.

1. Navigate to Settings > Models Library.2. Click the Makes button on the Models Library toolbar. The Manage Makes dialog popup displays.3. Select the make that you want to add an alias to.4. Type the desired alias into the Alias field in the Make details.5. Click the Add icon ("+") to add the alias.6. Click the Save button to save your changes.Note: Existing Make Aliases cannot be modified. You must delete the existing Alias and then add a new Alias tomake a change to an existing alias.1. Navigate to Settings > Models Library.2. Click the Makes button on the Models Library toolbar. The Manage Makes dialog popup displays.3. Select the Make with the alias that you want to delete.4. Select the Alias you want to delete from the list of aliases.5. Click the Delete icon (garbage can) to delete the alias.6. Click the Save button to save your changes.

1. Navigate to Settings > Models Library.2. Click the Add a Model button on the Models Library toolbar. A New Model page opens in a new dcTrack tab.3. Complete the required Model fields.4. On the Miscellaneous sub-tab, type the desired Alias in the Alias field and click on the "+" to add the alias.5. Click the Save button to save your changes.1. Navigate to Settings > Models Library.2. Select the model to which you want to add an alias to from the list. The Model Details page opens in a newdcTrack tab.3. On the Model Details page, in the Miscellaneous sub-tab, enter the Model's Alias and click the "+" to add theAlias. A new alias is added to the Alias grid.4. Click the Save button to save your changes.Note: Existing Model Aliases cannot be modified. You must delete the existing Alias and then add a new Alias tomake a change to an existing alias.

1. Navigate to Settings > Models Library.2. Select the Model whose Alias you want to delete. The Model Details page opens in a new dcTrack tab.3. On the Model Details page, in the Miscellaneous sub-tab, select the alias you want to delete from the Alias listbox.4. Click the Delete icon (garbage can).5. In the confirmation screen, click the "Yes" button to confirm the deletion.6. Click the Save button to save your changes.The alias will be removed from the Alias grid.

dcTrack 6.3 introduces the ability for System Administrators to map or add models to their dcTrack Models Librarywhen adding items. This makes it faster and more efficient for users to add items while ensuring the integrity of theirdcTrack data.When adding items in bulk, through Power IQ or VMware integration, with external ticketing, or via file import, andyou encounter item makes and/or models that are not recognized by dcTrack, you can map the make or model to anexisting make or model. You can also add them to the Models Library.In dcTrack, a wizard will guide you through the steps to match or add makes and models.These steps may also be replicated in the wizards for adding items via file import or in bulk, depending on if the newitems match existing makes and models. For example: In the file import wizard, the steps for matching and addingmakes and models may be displayed after the import file is uploaded and validated and only if the file includesmakes and models that are not currently found in the dcTrack Models Library.

This step displays the makes that do not match any of the makes in the dcTrack database. You're presented with thepossible best match in dcTrack and can either use the suggested best match, add the make, or skip making achange by selecting the corresponding checkbox in the Select an Action column.This step displays the models that do not match any of the makes in the dcTrack database. You're presented withthe possible best match in dcTrack and can either use the suggested best match, add the model, or skip making achange by selecting the corresponding checkbox in the Select an Action column.

In this step, you can individually add the models that you have selected to add to the Models Library.To add a model, provide the required model details and any other additional information, and then click the Save but-ton. These models are added to dcTrack upon saving.To change your selection from adding a model to skipping a model or using the best match candidate, return to theprevious screen in the wizard ,and then select the appropriate option in the Select an Action column. Any previouslyadded models will remain in the database.Chassis slots can be defined by updating the dcTrack Item Models Library.Alternatively, manually edit existing blade chassis slots, or setup slots when manually adding new chassis models.(See Add a Model to the Models Library).Important: Before you make changes to a chassis or blade model that is being used already, see Notes on MakingChanges to Chassis Slots.The following slot information is configured in the Item Models Library from the Slot Setup page:This refers to the way the blade faces in the slot chassis - Front or Back.In device chassis, device or network blades can face either Front or Back.Chassis FaceIn network chassis, network blades can only face the Front.When creating a blade to add to a chassis, this is the Chassis Face on a blade's item page.Slot ori-How the slots are positioned in the chassis - vertically or horizontallyentationSlot Con-This refers to the number of bays on the Chassis. If applicable Slot Containers can be set for both thetainersFront and Back of the ChassisSlots per Con-This refers to the number of slots in each of the Slot Containers. Slots per Container x Slot Containerstainerwill give you the total number of slots in the ChassisDoes the Chassis support Blades that span two Containers. Spanning is only permitted on Chassis withSpanningan even number of Slot ContainersDouble Wide Does the Chassis support Blades that span two adjacent slots in a ContainerDoes the Chassis support Blades that occupy a quarter slot. Quarter Blades are only permitted onQuarter BladesChassis whose Slot Containers are a multiple of 4 and allow Spanning.Full blades - blades that occupy two slots in different bays, or span two baysFull, double blades - blades that span two bays, and occupy two adjacent slots in each bayHalf blades - blades that occupy half a slotHalf, double blades - blades that occupy a half slot, or occupy two adjacent slots in each bayQuarter blade - blades that occupy a quarter slotSlot Sizes Shown VerticallyBlade slot sizesSlot Sizes Shown HorizontallyThe anchor position is the baseline slot position in the chassis. When a blade can span two slots, theanchor slot is the reference slot for the blade's position in the chassis.Slot anchorThe anchor position of the blade is defined when setting up slots in a chassis.Anchor slots are indicated by an orange dot.dcTrack slot numbering is used internally by the application and can not be changed. However, whenplacing Blades, Slot Labels are visible.Slot num-By default, dcTrack tracks orders slots in chassis from left to right starting in the lower right (slot 1),beringthen wrapping to the row above, and continuing the numbering from left to right.One chassis bay can contain up to 64 blade slots. The total number of slots depends on the model.The slot numbering order used by dcTrack may differ from the manufacturers ordering method.To accommodate this, dcTrack allows you to change slot labels so they accurately represent themodel.Labels should be used when referring to a Blade's position in a Chassis.Slot labelingIf needed, mark slots as unavailable.Slot Unavail-Slots may be unavailable because they slot does not exist at the position.ableAlternatively, you can mark a slot as unavailable if you never want to use the slot to place a blade.Note that if you mark a slot as Unavailable, the slot becomes unavailable in all of the chassis' models.

Chassis Bays can be placed on a Model by clicking the "Bay Placement" button on the Slot Setup subtab of theModel detail page.When placing Bays, you can either enter its coordinates, or place the Bay visually.To place Bays using coordinates:1. Select the Bay label from the top pane. The adjustment panel will display the Bay number being placed.2. Enter the Top, Bottom, Left and Right coordinates for the Bay. The Height and Width will be automatically cal-culated based on the provided coordinates. The line above theTo place Bays visually:1. When the screen is initially opened, rectangles will be pre-drawn dividing the Bays equally over the full face ofthe chassis.2. Using your cursor, drag the corners of the rectangle to re-size the Bay or place your cursor on the Bay tomove it.When positioning Bays, they may not overlap or be placed outside the boundaries of the image.To assist you in accurately defining the Bay placement when placing multiple Bays, you can fine tune the placementfrom the Bay Bulk Alignment panel.The following fields are used to fine tune the alignment:1. Face - indicates whether you are placing Bays on the Front or Back of the Chassis2. Bays - Select the Bays you would like to align from the drop down3. Align - You can choose to align the selected Bays by:1. Top Edge2. Bottom Edge3. Left Edge4. Right Edge4. To match - This is the Bay that will be used as the guide for alignment. For example, if Left Edge is chosen, allof the selected Bays' Left edge will align with the left edge of the "To match" bayHeight and Width will be automatically calculated base on the alignment of the Bays.Users with the appropriate permissions are able to designate power supply ports as optional on models. This featureenables users to leverage several power supply port options without creating multiple version of the same model.Power ports can be designated as optional on the Model Details page.To designate a power supply port as optional:1. In the Model Details page, click the Edit button to enable Edit mode.2. On the Power Ports tab:a. Check the checkbox in the Optional column next to the port you want to designate as optional.b. Uncheck the checkbox if you want to designate that port as non-optional.3. Click the Save button to save your changes.

For power supply ports that are designated as optional:Changes made to an optional power supply port are made only to that port.The ports required for redundancy do not include power supply ports that are designated as optional. Sim-ilarly, optional power supply ports are excluded from port counts and reports.Optional power supply ports do not need unique names, indices, or other editable fields that are required tobe unique for non-optional ports.Optional power supply ports are not included in port placement for model images.Optional supply ports are not subject to validations; however, names and other attributes must still be valid interms of length, characters, etc.Power supply ports can be designated as optional or non-optional via bulk File Import.Optional ports are included when the model is cloned.A Models Library update will not affect power supply ports designated as optional.The Models Library provides System Administrators with the ability to export select models and re-import them intoanother system as if models were being added or updated on the target system. As a result, users can stage modellibrary updates and modification in a test or development system, not the production system, and can extract andupload the model library data separated from full database backup.To export models from the Models Library:1. In the Models Library, click the Export dropdown in the Models Library toolbar2. Select your desired export option from the following:a. Export Details Into Import Template, Group by Modelb. Export Details Into Import Template, Group by Object Typec. Export Images Into Zip Filed. Export Both Details and Images Into Zip File, Group by Modele. Export Both Details and Images Into Zip File, Group by Object Typef. Download Template FileNote: You can only export up to 50 models at a time. If your current view displays more than 50 models, you mayhave to search and/or filter your library to limit your results, or you can complete multiple exports.To re-import the models:1. Click the Import button in located in the Main tool bar2. On the File Import screen, click on the browse to upload the file.3. Once the file is uploaded and validated click on green arrow to Process Import.4. When the file import process is successfully completed, results are shown with errors and warnings.Once the import is complete, you can save the results using Ctrl+C or save the result into a file.

Both model details and images can be imported and exported from the Models Library. Model details can be expor-ted into the Import Template CSV file, while images or details with images are exported to a ZIP file. Model imagesare PNG files, stored in an Images folder, and follow the naming convention <make>_<model name>_<Front orBack>.PNG. A ZIP file of exported model details with images will include the Images folder and the Export ModelsCSV file, which includes the model details.To re-import the models and images, click the Import button on the Main dcTrack tool bar. On the first screen of theFile Import dialog, you will need to select either a CSV file if you want to import model details or the ZIP file of theImages folder if you want to import images. The file will be uploaded and then processed, and the information will beupdated in the Models Library.Note: You will need to re-import the models and images separately, with the images uploaded to dcTrack first, fol-lowed by the models. Edits to model details can be made in the CSV file. Updated images should be saved to theImages folder as PNG files, follow the naming convention <make>_<model name>_<Front or Back>.PNG, and beplaced in the ZIP file.Note: Image file names are URL encoded when exported from dcTrack and should be URL encoded when re-importing. URL encoding will ensure that any spaces or special characters in the file name are interpreted correctly.See example below:doFile Import for models also supports a CHECK operation that allows you to check if the models entered in a csv filematch the models in dcTrack's Models library. This operation will provide a score for what is thought to be the "BestMatch" and as of dcTrack 9.0.0 it will also include up to 20 other suggestions when a 100% match can not be found.Note: The same algorithm will be applied to all areas where a lookup is performed on a Model (Library Update,CMDB Integration etc.)1. To check if there is match to a model, download the Item Models template from File Import screen2. In the template got to the Check Tab and enter the Make and Model Name.3. Import the file in dcTrackNote: Importing a Models Library update file with an empty part number field will make the part number of the match-ing model empty.4. In the Review Result section you can view the Check Result. You can also Save Results to File which would down-load a csv file.Results

Models ports can be updated, and the updates can be applied to all item instances of that model.From the Model Details Page, select the ports that need to be updated and click the Export Ports button. This willexport a CSV file that contains rows for the selected ports of the model. The ports will be repeated for each instanceof an item for that model.The exported CSV file can be imported again to update the existing item ports and add new ports based on theupdated Model.The Operation for Ports that are not found on an Item will be set to ADDThe Operation for Ports that exist on an item will be set to EDITIf required, this csv file can be edited prior to importing.In dcTrack 7.1 Model’s details page was enhanced to add Specification to enter fields specific to Models. Thesefields are class/subclass specific.The following is a list of fields that appear in Specification Tab. All of the fields are optional fields and will display inthe Models list. By default, these fields will be hidden in the list, however you can use the show/hide feature inModels list to display these fields.Nominal Voltage BatteryNumber of Cells BatteryDischarge VPC BatteryCapacity 1 (AH) BatteryBatteryCapacity 1 Rate (Hours)Capacity 2 (AH) BatteryCapacity 2 Rate (Hours) BatteryCompensation Factor (%) Cooling Unit/ Floor PDU / Rectifier / UPSNominal Capacity (Tons) Cooling UnitNominal Capacity (kW) Cooling UnitAirflow Rate (cfm) Cooling UnitCassette Slots Data PanelOutput Capacity (Amps) DC Power System / RectifierDevice / Blade Chassis / Blade Server /StandartCPU SocketsNetwork / Blade / Chassis /NetworkStackDevice / Blade Chassis / Blade Server /StandartRAM SlotsNetwork / Blade / Chassis /NetworkStackDevice / Blade Chassis / Blade Server /StandartExpansion SlotsNetwork / Blade / Chassis /NetworkStackDevice / Blade Chassis / Blade Server /StandartDaughter Board SlotsNetwork / Blade / Chassis /NetworkStackDevice / Blade Chassis / Blade Server /StandartDisk BaysNetwork / Blade / Chassis /NetworkStackDevice / Blade Chassis / Blade Server /StandartPower Supply SlotsNetwork / Blade / Chassis /NetworkStackCPU Type Device / Blade Server / StandardCPU Quantity Device / Blade Server / StandardRAM GB Device / Blade Server / StandardRating (kVA) Floor PDUMain Breaker (A) Floor PDUMax Panels Floor PDU / DC BayRating (kVA) UPSRating (kW) UPSRating (Vac) UPSOutput Wiring UPSWeight Capacity (lbs) Cabinet / DC Bay / Plant Bay / ACThese fields can be exported when exporting Models and included in the CSV file when importing Models.For additional information please see Import/Export Models from the Models Library.

Busway Outlet Breaker configuration can be done for the models. You can specify the number of poles and addbreakers to Busway Outlet models. When items are created with these models, items inherit the breaker information.1. In the Models Library, open Busway Outlet model in edit mode.2. Click Edit Panel in Specification Tab.3. Select the Number of Poles from the drop down.4. Select the Phase from the drop-down. When Phase type "Single Phase (3-Wire)": is selected the option "Neut-ral Switch Breaker" is added.5. Select the Breaker Size and Rating (A) in Breakers to Add panel.6. Click text "Click here to add breaker" in Breaker Rating column to add breaker.7. Select the connector from the drop down in Connector column.8. Save the model.Phase for the pole can be toggled by double clicking the Phase box. When Phase A is double clicked, it will changeto B. When Phase B is double clicked it will change to Phase C. When Phase C is double clicked it will change to A.So to change from Phase A to C user will have to double click twice.Phase boxes for 3 Pole breaker can not be edited and are disabled for editing. 3 Pole breaker must have Phase A,B, C in sequence.

1. Click on Edit Panel in Specification sub tab.2. Click on the pencil icon in the Breaker Rating column to change breaker size and rating. To delete breakers,click on delete icon.3. To edit Connector, select different connector from the drop down.4. Save the model.You can also add more pole positions by selecting higher number for Number of Poles.To delete existing pole positions, select lower number for Number Poles. Breakers created for those pole positionswill also be deleted.Note: Busway outlets can also be edited via import, and you can modify the number of poles even after the break-ers are created. However, when creating busway outlets via import, the number of poles value is not supported.dcTrack 8.1 introduces new model field called "Compensation Factor".This field apply to following classes.1. Cooling Unit2. Floor PDU3. Rectifier4. UPSThis field accept the percentage value (1 - 200)and default to 100. This percentage value is used to calculate the out-put capacity for item when created from model.For example, if the Compensation Factor for UPS is set 90 then Compensated (kVA) and Compensated (kW) will be90% of the values entered for Rating (kVA) and Rating (kW) respectively.When the UPS item is created, it will use the Compensated (kVA) and Compensated (kW) values.The following is the list of fields that are calculated based on Compensation Factor.Nominal Capacity (Tons) Sensible Capacity (Tons) Cooling UnitNominal Capacity (kW) Sensible Capacity (kW) Cooling UnitRating (kVA) Compensated (kVA) Floor PDUMain Breaker (A) Compensated (A) Floor PDUOutput Capacity (Amps) Compensated (Amps) DC Power System / RectifierRating (kVA) Compensated (kVA) UPSRating (kW) Compensated (kW) UPSSpecifications fields in the table are the list of fields the Compensation Factor apply to. Compensated fields are thelist of fields that are calculated based on the Compensation Factor entered.Compensated fields are read only till the Specification fields are entered. Once the Specification fields are entered,Compensated fields are auto-calculated and the fields become user entered fields.

The Connectors Library contains all of the connector and connection cord types used by dcTrack.Connectors are used to populate various fields in dcTrack such as the Connectors drop-down available when cre-ating ports for an item, or the Connector drop-down in the Create Port dialog when adding ports.As of dcTrack version 7.2.0, users are able to manage the Connector Library directly from the Web Client.Connector Library in Web UI can be accessed from Settings -> Connector Library.System Administrators and users with Library Operator role can add, edit and delete connectors in Connector’sLibrary.1. In Web UI, go to the Settings tab > Connector’s Library.2. In the Connector’s library, click Add a Connector in the upper left of the screen to open a New Connector tab.3. Enter a name for the connector. Name must be unique. Required4. Select a type for the connector. RequiredNote: If you are creating connector for power ports that support Direct Current select type Power (DC), oth-erwise select Power (AC). When creating Connectors for data ports, select type Data5. Select the connector's attribute: You can also enter connector’s attribute by typing in and that attribute getsadded to the drop-down list.6. Enter the Channels. Required. By default it has value 1. Channels are used to build many to one, one to manyor or many to many connections.7. Enter a description for the connector. Optional8. In Connector Image Panel click on Add button and locate the image you want to use. Images must be in PNGformat. You can also use the Paste Button to paste the image from your clipboard. Make sure you havecopied the image to Windows Clipboard.a. On your local machine or server, locate the image you want use. Images must be in BMP format.b. Copy the image to the Windows® Clipboard.c. In dcTrack, click Paste in the Image box in the Connectors Detail section of the page9. Click Save to Save the connectorTo Edit a connector, select Connector from Connector’s List and click on Edit to open Connector details.Make updates and click on Save to Save the ConnectorNote: Once connector is saved Type cannot be changed.To Delete a connector , select one or more Connectors from Connector’s list and click on Delete to deleteConnector.Connectors that are in use by items and models can not be deleted. You can check the columns Items usingConnector and Models using Connector , if the number is greater than 0 for any of these two columns the con-nector can not be deleted. Delete button will be disabled if you select a In use Connector.You can also delete Connector from Connector details page by clicking on the Delete button in the toolbar.Note: On upgrade to dcTrack 9.2.0, all the existing Connectors will have the Channels value 1.

Items in the Item Models Library and Connectors Library can be copied and pasted into other applications such asMicrosoft Word®, Photoshop®, and so on.1. In the Web UI, navigate to Settings > Models Library or Settings > Connectors Library.2. Right click on the image you want to copy and select the Copy Image option3. Open the application you want to past the image into, then paste it using the application's paste function.New connectors can be created by cloning an existing connector. When you clone a connector, the connector’s com-putability and its image are also cloned.To clone a connector, select a connector from Connector’s list and click on Clone.The Clone button is disabled when you select more than one connector from the list.The new connector page opens with the connector details already populated, edit the Connector Name and click onSave.The Clone option is also available in the Connector details page.

Adding, Editing and Deleting Connector’s CompatibilityTo add Compatibility to a connector, select the connector from the list open the connector details in edit mode.1. In the subtab Compatibility with this Connector click on Add.2. Select the Connector from the dropdown. RequiredNote : You can create compatibility only with connectors of same type.3. Select the Cord/Adapter from the dropdown. Optional4. Click on Create.5. Save the Connector.Compatible connector gets added to the list of Compatibility with this Connector.You can also view the list of all Compatible Connectors in dcTrack in the subtab All Connectors Compatibility List.The list also includes the associated Cord/Adapter information for two compatible connectors. This list is read onlyand cannot be edited.You can edit the compatibility by changing the cord/adapter. Click on Cord/Adapter cell and select the cord from thedrop down and Save the Connector.To delete Connector’s Compatibility, select one or more Connectors from Compatibility with this Connector list, clickon Delete and Save the Connector.Note: If there are connections using these compatible connectors, then compatibility cannot be edited or deleted.You will get a warning message when saving the ConnectorThe list of all Connection Cords or Adapters can be accessed from the Connection Cords or Adapters subtab of Con-nector Details.Steps to add a Connector Cord or adapter:1. Select a Connector from the Connector list and open Connector details page.The Connection Cord or Adapters subtab is available in all the Connector’s details pages so you can selectany Connector from the list and open the Connector details in view or edit mode.2. Click the Add button in the Connection Cords or Adapters subtab.3. Enter the Cord/Adapter Name. Required. You can also select an existing Connection Cord from the drop-down.4. Select Type. Required.If you have selected an existing Cord/Adapter, then you may select same or different Type.5. Select Color. OptionalIf you have selected an existing Cord/Adapter with the same Type, then you must select different Color tocreate new Cord/Adapter.To create a New Cord/Adapter, Name together with Type and Color must be unique.6. Click on Create.Connection Cord you just created will get added to the Connection Cords or Adapters list.To Edit an existing Connection Cord or Adapter click on individual cell in the list. The list supports inline editing.To Delete an existing Connection Cord or Adapter select one or more Cord or Adapter from the list and click onDelete button.Note: If the Connection Cords or Adapters are in use by connections then it can not be edited or deleted, and youwill get a warning message.

System Administrators and Gatekeepers with the Manage Library functional role can designate item models as MyCompany Standard in the Item Models Library.These are models that are used most often in your data center, or models standardized by your organization.For example, if you only use Raritan Dominion PX2-5701 and PX2-5725 rack PDUs in your data center, designatethose PX models as 'My Company Standard' in the Item Models Library.Once a model is designated as a 'My Company Standard', you can -Configure dcTrack to Display Only 'My Company Standard' ModelsThis is applied at the application level, and allows users to see only models designated as 'My Company Standard'.For example, you can configure dcTrack so only PX2-5701 and PX2-5725 rack PDUs are displayed to users asmodel selections.Configure dcTrack to Display All ModelsThis allows users to display all models, or check the Std. checkbox to filter their options so only 'My Company Stand-ard' models are displayed.To set a specific model as a 'My Company Standard':Tip: While you go through the process of designating standard models, if you find models you use are missing fromthe library, note them and then submit a request to Sunbird Customer Support to include them in the next ItemModels Library build.Alternatively, add the model to the library manually. See Manually Add New Models to the Item Models Library.1. Navigate to Settings > Models Library.2. Select a model from the model list box.3. In the Model Details section of the page, click on the My Company Standard checkbox.4. Repeat these steps for each model you want to mark as a standard model.You can now:Configure dcTrack to Display Only 'My Company Standard' Models.Configure dcTrack to Display All Models.

The Set My Library tool is used to quickly designate a large number item models as 'My Company Standard', ratherthan manually designating each model individually in the Item Models Library.The tool is used if you have already created a large number of items in dcTrack with different model types. Forexample, it is used to apply 'My Company Standard' to cabinet models, server models, rack PDU models and so onyou have created since you began using dcTrack.If you do not have a large number of items with different model types, manually designate the models 'My CompanyStandard' models. See Designate Models as 'My Company Standard' in the dcTrack Item Models Library.1. Get the Set My Library tool by downloading the "IP address and Designate My Company Standard ModelsImport Tool" file from the Sunbird Support site at http://support.sunbirddcim.com.2. Extract the Implementation Import Tool.mde file from the zip file and save it locally.3. Double-click on the file to run the tool.4. Enter your dcTrack access information to connect to dcTrack.5. Use one of the following tool options to designate your 'My Company Standard' models:Designate (tag) all of item models currently in use in your locations as 'My Company Standard' models.This means the model for every item currently in use in dcTrack is designated as 'My Company Standard'.OrExport a spreadsheet containing all models in the Item Models Library.You can identify those that are already designated as 'My Company Standard' if they have a value of TRUE in theirStandard column.You can remove any model's 'My Company Standard' designation by accessing it in the Item Models Library anddeselecting the 'My Company Standard' checkbox. See Edit an Existing Model in the Models Library.

By default, only models designated as 'My Company Standard' are displayed to users. See Designate Models as'My Company Standard' in the dcTrack Item Models Library.The Std column does not appear in any Models dialog since there is no need to select it in order to filter the list foronly those models.To display only 'My Company Standard' (if needed):1. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration2. Click the Application Menu Item3. Enable the Company Standard Models feature

By default, only models designated as 'My Company Standard' are displayed to users. See Designate Models as'My Company Standard' in the dcTrack Item Models Library.However, you can configure dcTrack to display all models designated in addition to those designated as 'My Com-pany Standard' in the Item Models Library.Users can view all models available in the Item Models Library or filter the list for 'My Company Standard' models.When this option is disabled in dcTrack, the Std column appears in Model dialogs.To view all Models disable the "Limit Models to My Company Standard" option.1. In the Web UI , navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Applicaton Administration.3. Deselect "Limit Models to My Company Standard"dcTrack version 9.0.0 introduced a new user interface for managing Makes in the dcTrack Models Library.Steps to Add a new Make:1. Navigate to Settings > Models Library2. Click the Makes button in the Tool Bar to open the Manage Makes dialog3. To add a new Make click the Add button on the tool bar and populate the applicable fieldsa. Name - Requiredb. Alias - Optional You can supply more than 1 alias for a given Makec. Notes - Optionald. Customer Service - Optionale. Technical Support - Optionalf. Account Number4. Click the Save button to create the new recordTo edit an existing Make click the Edit button in the tool bar. In edit mode you can modify any of the field data includ-ing the "Name field.If the Name field is changed, the change will apply to all existing Models currently assigned to the Make.

dcTrack version 7.2.0 introduced the Parts Management module. When enabled, this feature allows users to create,manage and track assignments for their Parts inventory. Please refer to the topics below for complete details on howto enable this feature and the steps involved in managing your Parts Inventory.
