This section covers the network and power connectivity management features available in dcTrack.In the data center, structured cables are the highways, and the connections are the on/off ramps.dcTrack allows you to go from Point A to Point B with ease by managing your structured cabling in bulk.To view the list of Structured Cabling :1. Navigate to Connectivity -> Structured Cabling.2. Select the Location of your data center from the location selector. By default the default Location set in theuser preference setting will be selected.This list contains all the record of Structured Cabling created in dcTrack. Each Data Panel pair is listed twice in thelist, once for each direction. This list also contains the records for Structured Cabling created between Data Paneland Network Items.You can Show or Hide using the Show/Hide icon in the upper right corner of the grid. Fields in the grid can berepositioned by dragging and dropping the column to the desired position. Each field is filterable and sortable fromthe column header.Please refer to the topics below for complete details about this feature and the steps involved in managing yourStructured Cabling.Create Structured Cabling and Data Panel PortsCreate Structured Cabling between Data Panel and NetworkCreate Structured Cabling with Existing PortsCreate Structured Cabling between MPO Data PanelsDelete Structured CablingCreate and Manage Port Label TemplateBulk Edit Data Panel PortsUse File Import to Add, Edit and Delete Structured Cabling

To Create Structured Cabling in Web Client :1. In Connectivity Tab, click Add Cabling .2. A New Structured Cabling Tab will open.3. Provide the following information for Step 1. Near Enda. Item Class : Rad Only field.b. Location : Select the location of the data panel. Required. Default selection is the default location setas per user preference.c. Cabinet : Select the cabinet. The cabinet elevation view appears to the left when the cabinet is selec-ted. Required.d. Data Panel : Select the data panel item. Required.e. Select Ports : Select Existing or Create New. If the Data Panel items already have ports, you canselect existing to create structured cabling for existing ports, otherwise select Create New which willcreate data panel ports and the structured cabling.f. Starting Label Index : Enter the value for Starting index. The default value is the next available datapanel port index which is 1 greater than highest existing index. Required. This value is used to gen-erated the port label when the template selected uses ${ne_index} or {fe_index}.g. Starting Order Index : Enter the value for Starting Order index. The default value is the next availabledata panel port index which is 1 greater than highest existing index. Required. This value is startingindex for the new ports that get created.h. Connector : Select the connector from the drop down. Required. Default selection is RJ45.i. Channels : This field is auto-populated based on the channel value for Connector but the field remaineditable allowing you to change the value.4. Provide the following information for Step 2. Cable Propertiesa. Quantity : Enter the number of data panel ports/cables you want to create. Required.b. Media : Select the media type of the cables. The default value is Twisted Pair. Required.c. Cable Grade : Select the Cable Grade. Optional.d. Length (ft) : Enter the length of the cable in feet. Optional.e. Color Code : Select the color code of the cable. Optional.f. Grouping / VLAN. Select the grouping / vlan of the cable. Optional.5. Provide the following information for Step 3. Far Enda. Item Class : Select the item class for the far end item. If you are creating structured cabling betweentwo data panels, select the class Data Panel. If you are creating Port Mirror set up, select Network.See here for more info on Port Mirroring. For details on creating structured cabling between data paneland network item using Web Client. See here Create Structured Cabling between Data Panel and Net-work for more details.b. Location : Select the location of the data panel. Required.c. Cabinet : Select the cabinet. The cabinet elevation view appears to right when the cabinet is selected.Required.d. Data Panel : Select the data panel item. Required.e. Select Ports : Select Existing or Create New. If the Data Panel items already have ports, you canselect existing to create structured cabling for existing ports, otherwise select Create New which willcreate data panel ports and the structured cabling.f. Starting Label Index : Enter the value for Starting index. The default value is the next available datapanel port index which is 1 greater than highest existing index. Required. This value is used to gen-erated the port label when the template selected uses ${ne_index} or {fe_index}.g. Starting Order Index : Enter the value for Starting Order index. The default value is the next availabledata panel port index which is 1 greater than highest existing index. Required. This value is startingindex for the new ports that get created.h. Connector : Select the connector from the drop down. Required. Default selection is RJ45. Near Endand Far End Connectors must be same or compatible to each other, otherwise structured cabling can-not be created. See here Adding Editing and Deleting Connectors Compatibility.htm for more details.i. Channels : This field is auto-populated based on the channel value for Connector but the field remaineditable allowing you to change the value.6. Provide the following information for Step 4. Port and Cable Labelinga. Near End Template : Select the template for port label. Required. See here Create and Manage PortLabel Template for more details.b. Same as Near End : When checked, the far end item ports will be created using the same template asnear end template.c. Far End Template : Select the template for Far End item. This field is required when the check boxSame as Near End is unchecked.When structured cabling is created with existing ports, Cable Labeling section is hidden because the portlabels have already been created.7. Click Preview to button to preview the port labels for near end and far end data panels.8. Click Step 5. Create Cabling.To verify the data panel ports, open the item details page of the near end and far end data panel and visit Data PortSub tab.The Data Ports sub tab of data panel item details page provides the options to Create Ports without structuredcabling.If you want to create ports without structured cabling, click the Create Port button. This will open the create port dia-log.Complete the required fields and click the Create Button. This will create the port with the Far End Item field leftblank.

dcTrack allows you to create Structured Cabling between Data Panel and Network items which is called Port Mir-roring. See Port Mirroring for more details.To Create Structured Cabling between Data Panel and Network in Web Client :1. In Connectivity Tab, click Add Cabling .2. A New Structured Cabling Tab will open.3. Provide the following information for Step 1. Near Enda. Item Class : Rad Only field.b. Location : Select the location of the data panel. Required. Default selection is the default location setas per user preference.c. Cabinet : Select the cabinet. The cabinet elevation view appears to the left when the cabinet is selec-ted. Required.d. Data Panel : Select the data panel item. Required.e. Select Ports : Select Existing or Create New. If the Data Panel items already have ports, you canselect existing to create structured cabling for existing ports, otherwise select Create New which willcreate data panel ports and the structured cabling.f. Starting Label Index : Enter the value for Starting index. The default value is the next available datapanel port index which is 1 greater than highest existing index. Required. This value is used to gen-erated the port label when the template selected uses ${ne_index} or {fe_index}.g. Starting Order Index : Enter the value for Starting Order index. The default value is the next availabledata panel port index which is 1 greater than highest existing index. Required. This value is startingindex for the new ports that get created.h. Connector : Select the connector from the drop down. Required. Default selection is RJ45.i. Channels : This field is auto-populated based on the channel value for Connector but the field remaineditable allowing you to change the value.4. Provide the following information for Step 2. Cable Propertiesa. Quantity : Enter the number of data panel ports/cables you want to create. Required.b. Media : Select the media type of the cables. The default value is Twisted Pair. Required.c. Cable Grade : Select the Cable Grade. Optional.d. Length (ft) : Enter the length of the cable in feet. Optional.e. Color Code : Select the color code of the cable. Optional.f. Grouping / VLAN. Select the grouping / vlan of the cable. Optional.5. Provide the following information for Step 3. Far Enda. Item Class : Select the item class for the far end item. If you are creating Port Mirror set up, select Net-work.b. Location : Select the location of the Network item. Required.c. Cabinet : Select the cabinet. The cabinet elevation view appears to right when the cabinet is selected.Required.d. Network Item: Select the Network item. The list only include the Network items that have free portsequal to Quantity entered in Step 2. Required.e. Ports : Select the Network Port list from the drop down. Port Range included in the list start from thefirst available port with same Media type selected for the Data Panel item. Required.f. Issue Connect : Select the check box if you want to issue connect request to the Port Mirror circuitsthat will be created when you create Structured Cabling. If unchecked, the Port Mirror circuits will becreated in Planned status.6. Provide the following information for Step 4. Port and Cable Labelinga. Near End Template : Select the template for port label. Required. See here Create and Manage PortLabel Template for more details.7. Click Preview to button to preview the port labels.8. Click Step 5. Create Cabling.To verify the data panel ports, open the item details page of the Data Panel item and Network item and visit DataPort Sub tab.Since the Structured Cabling between Data Panel and Network creates Port Mirror circuit, it will be listed as a sep-arate record in the Circuit List.Data Ports sub tab of data panel item details page also have the option to Create Structured Cabling. When clicked,it will navigate to New Structured Cabling tab. Follow the same steps as above to create structured cabling.

Structured Cabling can be created between Data Panels where both the ends have MPO Ports and have equal num-ber of channels.To create the structured cabling follow the steps mentioned here Create Structured Cabling and make sure to selectthe MPO connector.The number of ports created for the data panels will be same as the Quantity entered.Additionally, structured cabling can also be created between a multichannel MPO port and a non-mpo port having 1channel.Repeat the same steps as mentioned above to create Structured Cabling but select the appropriate connectors forthe ends.When both the ends do not have same number of channels, the number of ports created for both the ends will be dif-ferent. For example when Near End Connector has 6 channels and Far end has 1 channel and Quantity is 2 thennumber of Ports created for the Near End which is an MPO port will be equal to Quantity and number of Ports cre-ated for Far end will be Number of channels for MPO Port * Quantity. In this example 12 Far end data panel ports willget created.Since the quantity of Ports created at both ends are different, the same port template cannot be used for both theends as it will result in duplicate Port labels.Note: Channels for Near End and Far End can have different value but one end must have value 1. However, whencreating Port Mirroring where one end is a Data Panel and the other end is a Network item, Channels value must besame for both the ends.You can view the ports created in the Data Port subtab of the data panel item details.In the Data Panel Port subtab, the Far End column will have a hyperlink text FE:<Multiple Ports>, since one near endport connects to multiple far end ports. When this hyperlink text is clicked, the port list shows the list of connecteditems and the far end item for that port at the right.When the hyperlink text FE:<Multiple Ports> is clicked again the Connected items list for that port disappears andthe port list returns to normal view.You can also see the list of Connected Items and the Far End Item Ports by clicking Expand Channels button in thePort list toolbar. This button appears in the toolbar only when at least one port in the list has multiple channels. Whenall the ports in the port list are single channel ports this button is hidden.In the Expand Channel view you can see the list with one row for each channel, button label changes to CollapseChannels. To Collapse the port list click Collapse Channel.

The Data Ports sub tab of data panel item details page provides the options to create the port without structuredcabling.If you want to create ports without structured cabling, click the Create Port button. This will open the create port dia-log.Complete the required fields and click the Create Button. This will create the port with the Far End Item field leftblank.To Create Structured Cabling :1. In the data panel item details, click Create Structured Cabling in the Data Ports subtab.2. A New Structured Cabling Tab will open with Near End data panel info pre-populated.3. Select Existing option in Select Ports.4. Select the ports from the drop-down.Connector and Channels fields are read-only and populated based on the ports selected. All the selected ports musthave same, Connector, Media, Cable Grade. Therefore, when you make the first selection, then all unselected portswith a different connector, media, cable grade from the first selected port will be disabled and cannot be selected.Provide the following information for Step 2. Cable Propertiesa. Quantity : Read Only. It is populated based on the number of near end port selected.b. Media : Read Only. It is set to the Media of near end ports.c. Cable Grade : Read Only. It is set to the Cable Grade of near end ports. If the selected ports do not have avalue for cable grade, they remain editable, and you can select a cable grade to assign to the existing selec-ted ports, which will then be updated with structured cabling.d. Length (ft) : Enter the length of the cable in feet. Optional.Provide the following information for Step 3. Far Enda. Item Class : Select the item class for the far end item. If you are creating structured cabling between two datapanels, select the class Data Panel. If you are creating Port Mirror set up, select Network. See here for moreinfo on Port Mirroring. For details on creating structured cabling between data panel and network item usingWeb Client. See here Create Structured Cabling between Data Panel and Network for more details.b. Location : Select the location of the data panel. Required.c. Cabinet : Select the cabinet. The cabinet elevation view appears to right when the cabinet is selected.Required.d. Data Panel : Select the data panel item. Required.e. Select Ports : Select Existing.f. Ports : Select Ports from the drop-down. The list includes all the ports where the structured cabling is not cre-ated. This list may include the ports that are connected but without structured cabling. All the ports in this listhave same media type and same cable grade as the near en. All the ports have same or compatible con-nector as near end.g. Connector : Read Onlyh. Channels : Read Only.When structured cabling is created with existing ports, Cable Labeling section is hidden because the port labelshave already been created.1. Click Preview to button to preview the port labels for near end and far end data panels.2. Click Step 5. Create Cabling.To verify the data panel ports, open the item details page of the near end and far end data panel and visit Data PortSub tab.

To delete Structured Cabling :1. Navigate to Connectivity -> Structured Cabling.2. Select the Location of your data center from the location selector. By default the default Location set in theuser preference setting will be selected.3. Filter the list to get the record of Structured Cabling that need to be deleted.4. Select those records of Structured Cabling and click Delete.You must have edit privileges to delete data panel ports. When you delete data panel ports, the structured cablingthat connects the near end data panel and far end data panel also get deleted.Connected and marked in use data panel ports cannot be deleted.To delete data panel ports:1. In the Web Client, click Assets > Items List.2. Open an existing data panel item's page in edit mode.3. Click on the Data Ports tab.4. Click on the port or ports you want to delete. Use Ctrl + click to select multiple ports at once.5. Click Delete on the Data Ports tab.6. Save the item.If the ports selected are connected or marked in use and can not be deleted, you will get a message confirming theports deleted. Port list will be refreshed, deleted ports will be removed from the list ports that got skipped remainselected.dcTrack 8.1 allows you to create port label template for data panels. Once the template get created, it can be used togenerated port labels for data panels. Templates are available across sites. You must have edit privileges to createa template.To Create a Template :1. In the Web Client, select Connectivity Tab -> Add Cabling.2. In the New Structured Cabling Tab, click Managed Saved Template.Note : New Structured Cabling Tab can also be opened from Create Structure Cabling button in Data Ports sub tabof Data Panel item.3. Enter the Template in the field Add a Template. Refer to the Port Label Template Syntax for more informationon variable and syntax used for creating new template.4. Test the template by clicking the bolt icon next to Add a Template field. If the template is valid, you will get amessage confirming the same. You can also Preview the template result if all the required fields to create thestructured cabling are entered.5. Click the plus icon to add the template. The plus icon appear only if the template is valid. Newly created tem-plate will appear in the Saved Template List.To Delete a Template :1. Select the template in the Saved Template list.2. Click the delete icon.You can also select multiple templates by holding the Ctrl key and click delete icon to delete the selected templates.To Edit a Template1. In New Structured Cabling Tab, click the pencil icon next to Near End Template field. To Edit Far End Tem-plate, click the pencil icon next to Far End Template.2. This field will become a text box. Edit the template.3. Click Preview button to test the updated template. If the template is valid, preview will show. If the template isinvalid, you will get a message confirming the same.To cancel the edit, click x icon and the field will become drop down.Note : Edited template can not be saved and will not appear in the Saved Template List. However you can edit anexisting template and create structured cabling using the edited template.

Bulk Edit feature allows you to edit port attributes of multiple data panel ports.1. Open Data Panel Item in edit mode.2. In the Data Ports sub tab, select multiple data panel ports.3. Click Bulk Edit.4. Provide following information to update the ports.a. Select Column to update : In the drop down, select the port field that you want to bulk update.b. Select Value : In the drop down, select the field value. The drop down list will be populated based onthe column selected.5. Click Apply. If you want to clear the data on the select field, click Clear.6. Save the item.Since data panel ports in dcTrack are connected through structured cabling, the field values for the FarEnd Item will also get updated.Following are the rules for the fields that can be updated using Bulk Edit optionChannels : Can be updated by entering a value. cannot be updated when the ports are con-nected.Cassette Part : Can be updated to any Cassette Part Instance from the drop down listColor Code : Can be updated to any color code from the drop down list. Color Code of the farend item also get updated.Grouping/VLAN : Can be updated to any value from the drop down list. Grouping/VLAN of thefar end item will also be updated.Connector : For connected ports or ports having a Far end, selected connector must be com-patible with the connector of the port it is connected to. For ports that are not connected or donot have a Far end, it can be updated to any connector from the drop down list. When Con-nector is selected, the drop down to choose from will be reduced to only the Compatible con-nectors for all the selected ports that are connected. As each port is updated with the selectedconnector, the compatibility is checked for that port and the port is skipped if the chosen con-nector is not compatible with the port connector on the other end of the connection or with theport connector of the far end item.Media : Can only be updated for ports that are not connected. Media for the far end item alsoget updated. When Media is selected, when updating each of the selected ports, a port that isconnected will be skipped. Ports that are not connected but have structured cabling will getupdatedCable Grade : Can be updated to the Cable Grade which maps to the same media type. Whenthe media is updated and the existing Cable Grade value do not apply to that Media type, it willbe cleared for the selected ports.Comments : Can be updated.Following fields can be cleared using Bulk EditGrouping/VLANColor CodeCommentCassette PartdcTrack 8.1 allows you to create IP Subnet using File Import feature.It is recommended that you define your subnets before you begin assigning IP addresses to data ports or setting upport teams in the Web Client. Subnets are defined for a particular location, so you can have different subnets foreach data center you create in dcTrack.Steps to Import IP Subnet :1. Navigate to File Import page by clicking the Import button located at the top of every dcTrack page.2. Download the sample import template for IP Subnet.3. Follow the instructions and the examples in the sample import template to create import file for addingIP Subnet.4. Import the file.Once the file import is successful, you can assign IP addresses to data ports from the newly created IP Subnet. Seehere Assigning IP Addresses to Data Ports for more details.Note : IP Subnets can not be exported from Asset List. You can either create SQL widget or download the SQL wid-get IP Availability from Sunbird Addons Siteand export the data in SQL widget to CSV file. For more details on SQLwidgets see SQL Gride Widgets.

Virtual Power Chains (VPC) are used to connect power circuits without needing to build out all thepower infrastructure components (power chains) in dcTrack.In addition to the existing support for AC Virtual Power Chains, dcTrack version 9.0.0 introduced sup-port for DC Virtual Power Chains.These are useful if, for example, you want to build out a cabinet and create power connections, but donot want to build your power chain at the same time. You can add all of your items to the cabinet andconnect each circuit to a VPC.Each item in the VPC is created automatically by dcTrack; you do not to create the VPC items.The AC VPCs include connectors, power outlets, power outlet ports, power panels/busways, breakers,floor PDUs, UPS units, and UPS banks. DC VPCs include connectors, DC Plants, DC Rectifiers andDC Plant Panels.VPCs have unlimited power capacity since they are virtual, so you can use them to connect as manypower circuits as needed.For AC Power Connections, you connect rack PDUs to Virtual Power Chains at the outlet level. Altern-atively, connect items at the rack PDU inlet level like 'normal' power circuits.For DC Power Connections, when creating a circuit and the selected node is for a device power supply(direct current phase), you connect the the power supply directly to a Generic VPC Plant Panelbreaker.When creating a circuit and the selected node is for a DC FAP or Rack Inverter Inlet, you connect theInlet directly to a Generic VPC Plant Panel breaker.

Gatekeepers and System Administrators can enable and disable Virtual Power Chain Settings for locationsin dcTrack.The appropriate VPC type (AC, DC) must be enabled for the location in order to create connections toVirtual Power Chains of that type. See Enable or Disable VPC for a Location.By default, AC Virtual Power Chain Settings are enabled when a new location is created, however DCVirtual Power Chain settings are not enabled by default.

This can be done manually or by enabling VPC in a spreadsheet and importing using File Import. Forinformation on enabling VPC during an import, see Use File Import to Import Locations, Items and Con-nections Use File Import to Add, Edit Delete and Move.Virtual Power Chain connections can be created manually or using File Import. See Manually CreateVirtual Power Chain Connections and Use File Import to Import Virtual Power Chain Connections.

The connections are managed by dcTrack's Change Control workflow like 'normal' power connections;requests are submitted for them, statuses are applied to them, and they can be updated and deleted.The only differences are:The power port you connect to is selected for you when creating the connection.You select whether to connect to the VPC A (virtual UPS bank A) or VPC B (virtual UPS bank B)power chain.

Once Virtual Power Chain connections are made, you are able to budget and track an item's powerconsumption in the data center as you would an item connected to a 'normal' power circuit.Additionally, item power supply, rack PDU, DC FAP and Rack Inverter inlet connections are validatedagainst ratings and tracked. This allows you to review budgeted values at the item or cabinet level.Switch a Virtual Power Chain Connection to a "Normal" Power Circuit, or Switch "Normal" Power Cir-cuit to a Virtual Power Chain ConnectionWhen you are ready to create your 'normal' power chain, you can switch from VPC circuits to 'normal'circuits - you do not have to recreate the power circuits.Alternatively, you can switch existing power circuits to connect to VPCs and then switch them back at alater time. See Switch from a 'Normal' Power Circuit to a Virtual Power Chain. See Switch from a'Normal' Power Circuit to a Virtual Power Chain (Connect and Disconnect).Enable VPC for one or more locations so you can create Virtual Power Chains.This can be done manually in the Web Client, or by entering TRUE for "Enable Virtual Power Chain" on the ImportTemplate and then importing the information using File Import.From the Locations pageVia File ImportSystem Administrators and users with the "Bulk Import" role can also import virtual power circuits into dcTrack ratherthan connect them manually. For details on File Import, see Use File Import to Import Virtual Power Chain Con-nections.The virtual power circuits created from the spreadsheet are made up of connections between existing dcTrack itemsand items in the Virtual Power Chain.1. In the Web Client, Assets > Locations.2. Click the Location you want to enable VPC for.3. Check the appropriate Virtual Power Chain checkbox to enable VPC for the selected location.4. Uncheck the appropriate Virtual Power Chain checkbox to disable VPC for the selected location.

Watch a video on how to use file import template on the Support Portal.This topic outlines how to create a file that will import Virtual Power Chain connections. For detailed steps on usingthe File Import feature, see Use File Import to Add, Edit Delete and Move.System Administrators and Gatekeepers can also add VPCs manually in the Web Client. For details on File Import,see Manually Create Virtual Power Chain Connections.The Virtual Power Chains created from the spreadsheet are made up of connections between existing dcTrackitems and virtual items in the Virtual Power Chain.Therefore, the items that will be connected to the Virtual Power Chain connections must exist in dcTrack. Using FileImport to add the items or add them manually. See Use File Import to Add, Edit Delete and Move and Add andEdit Items.Virtual Power Chain must be enabled for the location(s). You can enable VPC when adding locations manually orwhen importing locations using File Import by setting the Enable Virtual Power Chain field to TRUE in the ImportTemplate. See Enable or Disable VPC for a Location and Use File Import to Add, Edit Delete and Move, respect-ively.Note that you do not need to create the items that make up the Virtual Power Chain; these Virtual Power Chainitems exist by default.Only System Administrators and Gatekeepers with privileges to the location can enable VPC settings. See Enableor Disable VPC for a Location.Virtual power connections are created in the same way as "normal" power circuits except that you connect items atthe port or rack PDU level to the VPC.

Submit a Connect Request or Disconnect Request for the circuit when it is created, or at a later time:Select an action request from the Actions menu on the circuit's pageOrSelect one or more circuits on the Circuits List that are in the same current status, then select a request from theActions menuThe request you can submit depends on the current status of the circuit and you must have edit access to the circuitto submit a request for it.If Request Bypass is enabled, requests are automatically processed from the initial submit request stage to the WorkOrder Complete stage.When Request Bypass is not enabled, requests move through each stage of the dcTrack Change Control workflow.For information on the Change Control workflow process and Request Bypass, see Request Bypass and ManualChange Control.Virtual Power Chains are identified by 'VPC' as part of their Circuit Trace and Last Node Item.You can easily locate circuits connected to a VPC on the Circuits List using search, filters and sorting.For example, filter and search by -Type = PowerSearch Circuit Trace = VPC (or some variation of the circuit path)Last Node Item = VPC

Once you are ready to create your real power chain, you can switch your connection from the Virtual Power Chain tothe 'normal' power circuit.You must have edit access to the circuit to switch.Note that you can also switch from a 'normal' circuit to a Virtual Power Chain. See Switch from a 'Normal' PowerCircuit to a Virtual Power Chain (Connect and Disconnect).Access the Circuits List by selecting Connectivity > Circuits List.Open the circuit you want to change by:Selecting it in the Circuits List and click View/Edit at the top of the page.OrDouble-clicking on it to open the circuit's page.Click on Node 2 to open it. This is where you begin the new circuit with the new power source.Click the Normal button on the Item List tool bar.Select the power source from the Items List.Select the power source outlet port from the Port List.Click Accept Changes.The remainder of the circuit is built automatically by dcTrack.Save the circuit to submit a request to switch the VPC to a 'normal' circuit.If Request Bypass is enabled, requests are automatically processed from the initial submit request stage to the WorkOrder Complete stage.When Request Bypass is not enabled, requests move through each stage of the dcTrack Change Control workflow.For information on the Change Control workflow process and Request Bypass, see Request Bypass and ManualChange Control.

You can switch a 'normal' power circuit in a Planned, Installed or Powered-off status to connect to a Virtual PowerChain.This is useful if you need to move an item from a location where the power chain is completely built out, to a locationwhere it is not. The Virtual Power Chain acts as a placeholder for the actual power circuit in the interim.After you no longer need to items connected to a Virtual Power Chain, you can switch the connection back to a 'nor-mal' power circuit. See Switch from a Virtual Power Chain to a 'Normal' Power Circuit (Connect and Dis-connect).You must have edit access to the circuit, and Virtual Power Chain Settings must be enabled for the location.Access the Circuits List by selecting Connectivity > Circuits List.Open the circuit you want to change by:Selecting it in the Circuits List and click View/Edit at the top of the page.OrDouble-clicking on it to open the circuit's page.Click on the rack PDU node, Node 2, to open it.Click on either the VPC A or VPC B button on the Item List tool bar.Click Save to save the circuit.The remainder of the circuit is built automatically by dcTrack.If the circuit is in a Planned status, save the circuit.If the circuit is in an Installed status, you must submit a Disconnect Request for the 'normal' circuit since you can-not change the number of nodes in the circuit and then save it.

In dcTrack, each node represents a point in a circuit, and connections link each node in the circuit.For example, a server connects to a rack PDU at the rack PDU's inlet, the rack PDU connects to floor PDU's poweroutlet, and so on.For more about how these relationships, see dcTrack Hierarchy and Item Classes.When building circuits in dcTrack, you join nodes, to create connections, to complete your circuit.Each node and connection in the circuit is displayed using a graphical representation of the circuit. You can view thecomplete circuit from the starting item to the ending item, including each item in between.To save a data circuit, you must connect at least two nodes.

Data circuits can begin with any Item that has Data Ports.Data circuits that begin with a Device class item can end with:• Another Device class itemor• A Network class itemData circuits that begin with a Network class item can only end with another Network class itemCircuits cannot end with any other class of item. However, dcTrack allows you to create partial data circuits that canend with a data panel. For more detailed steps on how to created Partial circuits, see Build Partial Data Circuits.Power circuits can begin with an item having either a Power Supply Port or an Input Cord. The Power chain must bebuilt before creating a power circuit. If your power chain is not built, you may use Virtual Power Chains to connectpower circuits.For detailed steps on how to build circuits using Virtual Power Chain, see Manage Virtual Power Chains.Partial power circuits start with a rack PDU and end on a power infrastructure item. You can connect a device with apartial power circuit to make it a complete circuit.

When you click on the Add a Circuit button, the circuit you are building is displayed in its own New Circuit tab. A reddot in the New Circuit tab indicates the circuit is not yet saved, a green dot means it is saved. Once you save the cir-cuit, dcTrack generates the circuit name and the Circuit becomes available on the Circuits List.You can also build multiple circuits in a single tab. This tab is called a Multiple Circuits tab. A green dot is displayedon this tab only when all of the circuits in the tab are saved. If any of the circuits have unsaved changes, the tab willdisplay a red dot.See additional information on building Data and Power Circuits:Building Power CircuitsBuilding Data CircuitsView a specific data or power circuit by double-clicking on it to open its circuit page, or by selecting one or more cir-cuits and clicking the View button on the tool bar. Multiple circuits can be viewed in single tab. To view multiple cir-cuits in single tab, select the circuits from the circuit list and select the View in Single Tab option from the Viewmenu. To view circuits in multiple tab, select the View in Multiple Tab option.

Edit a specific data or power circuit by selecting the circuit and clicking on the Edit button in the toolbar. This opensthe circuit in edit mode. Multiple circuits can be edited in single tab. To edit multiple circuits in single tab, select thecircuits from the circuit list and select the Edit in Single Tab option from the Edit menu. To edit circuits in multipletabs, select the “Edit in Multiple Tab” option.Editing an installed circuit generates a Proposed Circuit and issues a Disconnect Request. This is applicable whenediting either a Data Circuit or a Power Circuit.Note: Decommissioning a circuit removes the entire circuit. It does not place the circuit back in the planned status.The Circuit List in dcTrack has been enhanced to make it faster and easier for you to manage Data andPower Circuits, including a new and improved Asset Management toolbar:Add a Cir-Opens a new page to add one or more CircuitscuitView Opens one or more selected Circuits on a single or multiple tabs in View modeEdit Opens one or more selected Circuits on a single or multiple tabs in Edit modeDelete Deletes the selected CircuitsRefresh Refreshes the Circuit ListActions Dropdown that allows toggling Request Bypass, Connecting or Disconnecting CircuitsExport Dropdown that allows users to export Circuits and Download the Import TemplateCircuitView the Circuit Detail page for a selected CircuitDetailSearchView tips for better advanced searchesHelp

The Circuit List now can be filtered based on criteria for any of the available columns:You can select the columns that appear in the list by clicking the Show/Hide columns icon on the far right side ofthe grid. You can reorder the columns by dragging and dropping them into the desired position.As with the Item List search results and other dcTrack features, you can save and share your current view by clickingthe Views drop-down and clicking the Save Current List Settings As… icon. Multiple list views are available for eachuser. To clear the view, click the Clear icon in the right corner.To specify which columns are shown or hidden, click the Show/Hide columns icon in the upper right corner:The Show/Hide Columns dialog displays. All Standard and Custom Circuit fields are displayed. You can check oruncheck the box next to each to show or hide the corresponding column.At the top of the dialog are filtering capabilities. You can search for columns by typing your criteria into the searchbox, specify standard or custom fields, filter by sub-tab on the Circuit Details page, or select Shown or Hiddencolumns. The available columns will update automatically based on your selections.To save your selections, click the Apply icon.

Rather than manually build circuits when a large number must be created, System Administrators and users with the"Bulk Import" role can use File Import to import circuits into dcTrack in bulk.For details, see Use File Import to Add, Edit Delete and Move.To build a data circuit:1. In the Web Client, click Connectivity > Add a Circuit. A New Circuit tab is opened with an empty node highlightedin blue and an Item List for selecting the Item for this Circuit Node.2. From the Item List, select the item from which the circuit is initiated. Required3. Next, select the data port from the Ports List from which the connection originates. dcTrack validates the portselection to make sure there are no issues. RequiredWhen building the first node, you can switch to building a power circuit instead of a data circuit by selecting thePower Ports tab from the Port List.Once you have moved on to creating the next node, the option to select Power Port is no longer available, so youwould need to start building the circuit over.4. Continue adding nodes as needed by clicking on Next Node in the Item List tool bar and selecting the Items andPorts from the list. When selecting the port list from second node onwards, you will see an option to show onlycompatible ports that are most likely to be used for building this circuit. By default, this option will be enabled, ifyou want to view all the available ports for the selected item, can click on Show All Ports in the Port List toolbar.If there is an issue between the node item or port you selected and the item and port of the previous node, a Cautionicon ( ) is displayed at the bottom right of the node. Click on the node to view the conflict details. Make changes ifneeded.Note: If you make changes and have already added additional nodes, the nodes that follow are deleted. dcTrackdisplays a warning when this will occur.5. Click Save.6. Submit a Connect Request now or at a later time.You can also build multiple data circuits in single tab by selecting an item and selecting multiple ports for that item.You can continue to build the circuits by clicking Next Node and selecting the same item for the next node for all thecircuits by leaving each circuit checked. In this case you will have to select the same number of ports for the seconditem as the number of circuits being built.If the number of free ports or compatible ports selected for second node is less than the number of multiple circuits,the selection would only apply to the first n number of the circuits. For example: If you are building 4 circuits and theitem selected for the second node only has 2 free ports, the item selected would only apply to the first two circuits.You can also select different items for the second node when the first item is the same for all the circuits. In this case,you select each circuit and build them individually.Once all the circuits are built, you can save all the circuits by selecting all the circuits by clicking the checkbox at thetop left corner of the page and clicking Save or by saving each circuit individually by selecting that circuit.Once all the circuits are saved, you can submit a connect requests for all the circuits.

When building or editing a data connection, users are allowed to manually enter Cord Type, Cord Color and Cord IDfrom the Cord Detail dialog. Cord Length and Cord Side however can be automatically calculated for you. Whenbuilding or editing a connection, upon saving the record, the Cord Length and Cord Side are automatically cal-culated and stored with the connection.Opening the Cord Detail dialog will display the calculated length and side in a message at the bottom of the dialog.This calculated value is also populated in the Cord Length and Cord Side fields. You can always override the cal-culated value and supply your own values. Upon saving it will always be the values that are stored in these fields thatwill be saved with the connection record. If the Cord Detail dialog is opened again it will continue to display the cal-culated values in the message at the bottom of the page, however it will retain any values that you have overriddenin the actual fields.When viewing the Circuit trace you can view the length values by toggling the Show Lengths button. The individualCord Lengths are displayed below the cords and if a length exists for every cord in the circuit, the Total Cord Lengthis also displayed.Cord length and side can only be calculated when both items in the connection reside within the same Cabinet. TheTotal Circuit Length is only calculated when every cord in the circuit has a value.When calculating Length and Side, dcTrack takes into consideration, the Uposition of both Items, the placement ofthe connected ports, whether or not the cords pass through a wire manager. with an allowance for the distancebetween the item sides and cabinet side.

dcTrack allows you to build two types of partial data circuits• A Left Partial data circuit is one that starts with any item with free data ports and ends with a data panel.• A Right Partial data circuit is one that starts with a data panel and ends with a network item.When a partial circuit is created, it is saved as an independent circuit.When another circuit is built that joins to the partial circuit, the circuit is saved as a new circuit.Partial Data circuits can be connected to make a complete circuitWhen a Left partial circuit is connected to a right partial circuit it will be saved as full circuit.This can be done by editing a left partial circuit and connecting it to a right partial circuit.orBuilding a new circuit by selecting the far end data panel of a left partial circuit as the first node. This loads theleft partial circuit. Then click on the Next Node button and select the far end data panel of another left partialcircuit and click Save.For example:Left partial circuit Dev~DataPanel 1– DataPanel 2 when connected to RightPartial circuitDataPanel 3-DataPanel 4 ~ Network will be saved as a complete circuit.The Circuit List will display complete circuit Dev~DataPanel 1– DataPanel2 ~ DataPanel 3-DataPanel 4 ~ Network and right partial circuit DataPanel3-DataPanel 4 ~ Network.The Network Item can be connected to a left partial circuit and will besaved as a complete circuit.This can be done by editing the left partial circuit and on the nextnode selecting the network itemOrAdd a new circuit and for the first node select the far end data panelof the left partial circuit. This loads the left partial circuit. Click theNext Node to select the network item and save the circuit. This canalso be done by clicking on the Connect button on the Item Detailpage of the far end data panel which loads the left partial circuit inthe Connectivity page and then select the Network item for thesecond node.Device items can be connected to a right partial circuit and will be saved as a completecircuit. The Circuit list will display the complete circuit and the right partial circuit.Partial circuits that are part of a full circuit are read-only. They are editable only if:The full circuit that it is a part of is edited to use another unrelated node in place of the partial circuit.The full circuit that it is a part of is deleted or disconnected.To delete or disconnect partial circuits, the partial circuits must first be removed from existing circuits they are usedin.Complete circuits can also be formed by connecting a Network Item to a Left Partial Circuit.Steps:1. When building a circuit in the first node, select the Network Item you wish to connect from the Item List grid2. Next, select the data port from the Ports List from which the connection originates. dcTrack validates the portselection to make sure there are no issues.3. Click the Next Node button4. In the next Node, select the Far End Data Panel of the Left Partial Circuit. This will add the left Partial circuit tothe trace.5. Click Save to save the Circuit. After click the Save button, you will recieve a message indicating "Circuits start-ing with a Network Item will be saved in reverse order".6. After the Save, the circuit will flip placing the Network Item in the Last Node.This process can also be performed via File Import.Steps:1. Enter "DATA-CONNECTION" in the Object column2. Enter "EDIT" as the Operation (EDIT is the only supported Operation for this type of Data Connection)3. Enter the Location, Item Name and Port Name of the Network Item in the corresponding Starting columns4. Enter the Location, Item Name and Port Name of the Far End Data Panel (Left Partial Circuit) in the cor-responding Ending columns.

File Import will allow users to connect and disconnect Right Partial Circuits. This can only be done using the FileImport feature.Steps:1. Specify EDIT in the Operation column2. Specify the Item name of the Data Panel of the first Right Partial Circuit in the Starting Item Name column3. Specify the Item Location of the Data Panel of the first Right Partial Circuit in the Starting Item Locationcolumn4. Specify the Port on the Data Panel of the first Right Partial Circuit in the Starting Item Port column5. Specify the Item name of the Data Panel of the second Right Partial Circuit in the Ending Item Name column6. Specify the Item Location of the Data Panel of the second Right Partial Circuit in the Ending Item Locationcolumn7. Specify the Port on the Data Panel of the second Right Partial Circuit in the Ending Port column8. Upon completion of the import, a new complete circuit will be created.ExampleDP1:A01 -DP2:B01 - NW1DP3:C01-DP4:D01 - NW2In the Import file the Starting Item Name would be DP1 and the starting Port Name would be A01. The Ending ItemName would be DP3 and the Ending Port Name would be C01.After file import the result would be the new complete circuit saved as NW1-DP2:B01-DP1:A01-DP3:C01-DP4:D01-NW2, the second Right Partial circuit DP3:C01-DP4:D01-NW2 will still appear as separate circuit in the Circuit List,but will be considered read-only.Data Panel ports without structured cabling can be connected to a device or switch. Such circuits can include one ormore hops of data panel before it ends on data panel without structured cabling.To build the circuit:1. In the Web Client, click Connectivity > Add a Circuit. A New Circuit tab is opened with an empty node highlightedin blue and an Item List for selecting the Item for this Circuit Node.2. From the Item List, select the item from which the circuit is initiated. Required3. Next, select the data panel port from the Ports List. If the data panel port does not have a far end a warning mes-sage will notify the same.5. Click Save.This circuit is not considered as a partial circuit and may include one or more hops of data panels before ending on adata panel without structured cabling.When structured cabling is created for this data panel port, the circuit will be saved as a partial circuit.

Port Mirroring in a Circuit is when one data panel is connected through structured cabling to a network item and eachof the ports on the data panel align exactly with the ports on the network item. Once the data panel's ports areconnected to a network item through structured cabling, there will be straight line between the data panel and thenetwork item. This circuit will appear as a separate circuit in the circuit list.For example if a data panel has 5 ports which are connected to 5 ports of a network item through structured cabling,the circuit list it will contain 5 different circuits.Port Mirrored circuits can be created via File Import or using Web client. See Create Structured Cabling betweenData Panel and Network for more details.To create Port Mirrored Circuits using file import you should use the Structured Cabling import template where theData Panel is the Starting Item and the Network Item is the Ending Item.Note : Port Mirrored Circuits appear in the Circuit List. However these circuits can not be exported from Circuit List.You can export it as Structured Cabling from Asset Tab by selecting the Data Panel item or Network item from thelist, clicking Export button in the toolbar and selecting Export into an Import Template -> Structured Cabling.You can connect a Right Partial Circuit to a Port Mirrored Circuit, however you can not connect two Compound RightPartial Circuits (circuits that connect to a Mirrored Port).File import allows you to connect Right Partial circuit to a Port Mirror.Steps1. Specify EDIT in the Operation column2. Specify the Item Name of the Data Panel of the Right Partial Circuit in the Starting Item Name column3. Specify the Item Location of the Data Panel of the Right Partial Circuit in the Starting Location column4. Specify the Port on the Data Panel of the Right Partial Circuit in the Starting Port Name column5. Specify the Item Name of the Data Panel of the Port Mirror circuit in the Ending Item Name column6. Specify the Item Location of the Data Panel of the Port Mirror circuit in the Ending Location column7. Specify the Port on the Data Panel of the Port Mirror circuit in the Ending Port Name column.Note: You can also specify Data Panel of the Port Mirror Circuit in the Starting Item Name column and Data Panelof Right Partial Circuit in the Ending Item column.ExampleDP1:A01 -DP2:B01 ~NW1 : Right Partial CircuitDP3:C01-NW2 : Port MirrorUpon completion of the import the Right Partial circuit will become a complete circuit and will be saved as NW1~DP1:A01 -DP2:B01~ DP3:C01- NW2.The Port Mirror circuit DP3:C01- NW2 will appear as a separate circuit in the circuit list.When the complete circuit NW1~ DP1:A01 -DP2:B01~ DP3:C01- NW2 is deleted or disconnected, the right partialcircuit and the port mirror circuit will stay and show as separate circuit in the circuit list.

Port Mirror circuits can be connected via UI or ImportSteps to connect via UI1. Go to item details page of the data panel, in the data port subtab select the port whose far end item is Networkport and click connect.2. In Connectivity select the item for the next node. Select the data panel item and port.3. Click Save.Steps to connect via File Import1. Specify EDIT in the Operation column2. Specify the Item name of the Data Panel of the first Port Mirror Circuit in the Starting Item Name column3. Specify the Item Location of the Data Panel of the first Port Mirror Circuit in the Starting Item Location column4. Specify the Port on the Data Panel of the first Port Mirror Circuit in the Starting Item Port column5. Specify the Item name of the Data Panel of the second Port Mirror Circuit in the Ending Item Name column6. Specify the Item Location of the Data Panel of the second Port Mirror Circuit in the Ending Item Locationcolumn7. Specify the Port on the Data Panel of the second Port Mirror Circuit in the Ending Port columnCircuits like NW1 – DP1 ~ DP2 – DP3 ~ DP4 – DP5 ~ DP6 – DP7 ~ DP8 – NW2 which is a combination of two right par-tial circuits with Port Mirror are called Compound Circuits.This type of circuit can be built via file import.Steps1. Build this circuit "DP2 – DP3 ~ DP4 – DP5 ~ DP6 – DP7 ~ DP8 – NW2" using ADD operation via file import.2. Connect the right partial circuit created in the step above to Port Mirror circuit NW1-DP1 using EDIT oper-ation. Specify DP1 as the starting item and DP2 as ending item.After the file import the circuit will be saved as NW1 – DP1 ~ DP2 – DP3 ~ DP4 – DP5 ~ DP6 – DP7 ~ DP8 – NW2.

You are able to build data circuits between:Device blade ~ network bladeDevice blade ~ chassisdcTrack supports:Multiple blades connected through one or more logical blade ports at the same timeOne or more virtual machine virtual ports connected to a device/network virtual machine host, then connected tothe host's logical network portOne or more blade servers connected through the same network blade logical portIf Node 1 is a blade with a logical port, Node 2 must be a network blade with a logical port in the same chassis as theNode 1 blade.Unlike other circuits, dcTrack does not complete a circuit based on the connection created for the existing port whena port on an item is already in use.See Building a Data Circuit for details on creating data circuits.

dcTrack allows you to switch an item's power or data connections for both Planned and Installed connections. Thisallows you to make changes without having to issue separate disconnect and connect requests.For example, if you install a new rack PDU in a cabinet to replace an existing rack PDU, you can switch each item'sconnection from the old rack PDU to the new rack PDU. The same is true if you want to switch ports or connecteditems on a Data Circuit.In all cases, you must have edit access to the circuit.This action can be performed when circuits are in an Installed, Powered-off, or Planned status.To switch a connection, simply open the item's circuit in edit mode, select a new connected Item or Port and Savethe Circuit.You can also switch multiple power connections in single tab.1. Select the power circuits of the old Item from the circuit list.2. Open circuits from the old Item in edit mode.3. Select each circuit by clicking on the original Items node and select the new Item from the item list.4. Use ctrl+click to select rack PDU output for each circuit.5. Click SaveSubmit a new Connect Request.For multiple circuits, , select all the circuits by checking the checkbox at the left top select the Connect Request fromthe Actions menu in the toolbar.The request can be processed when Request Bypass is enabled or disabled. If Request Bypass is enabled, therequest is processed immediately. If Request Bypass is disabled, the request moves through each stage of theChange Control workflow. For information on the Change Control workflow process and Request Bypass, seeRequest Bypass and Manual Change Control.dcTrack supports the following virtual machine (VM) data circuits:VM virtual port ~ device/rackable VM host ~ device/rackable hosts physical portVM virtual port ~ device/blade server VM host ~ device/blade hosts physical portVM virtual port ~ device/blade server VM host ~ device/blade hosts logical port ~ blade chassis ~ blade chassisphysical portIf Node 1 is a virtual machine, Node 2 in the data circuit can only be a rackable, device item or device blade.Additionally, the virtual machine cluster the Node 2 item belongs to must be the same as the Node 1 virtual machinecluster.If the virtual machine is managed by VMware, then the Node 2 item must be a parent node of Node 1.Unlike other circuits, dcTrack does not complete a circuit based on the connection created for the existing port whena port on an item is already in use.See Building a Data Circuit for details on creating data circuits.

MTP/MPO fiber patch panel-to-patch panel connections are the same as any other connection between two items.However, MTP/MPO fiber patch panel-to-network/device item connections using an LC-harness are more complex.The connection is complex due to the one-to-many relationship between the multiple LC connectors that plug intothe network/device item ports.dcTrack 9.2.0 introduces a new property Channels which applies to Connector, Model port and Item port. Channelsare used to track the number of circuits that can run through the port (i.e. communication paths). A port with multiplechannels can accept multiple connections. For example: 6 (1-channel) ports with LC connectors can all connect to asingle Port with MPO connector having 6 channels. This allows 6 circuits to be created that are all using the sameMPO port.Prerequisites for building MPO Circuits.1. In the Connector's library, create MPO connector and enter a value for the Channels. For example an MPO-12 should have 6 channels, MPO-24 should have 12 channels. If you already have MPO connectors in theConnector's library, update the Channels value.2. Define the connector compatibility for MPO connectors so that circuit can be built between the ports havingmpo or non-mpo connectors.3. Create MPO ports on your items. If you do not have items created in dcTrack , follow the steps here Add andEdit Items to create items. For best practices, it is recommended to create MPO ports directly on the model.This ensures that any items created from the model will automatically inherit the ports.4. Next, create structured cabling. See here Create Structured Cabling with MPO Data Panels if you have MPOData Panels, otherwise see here Create Structured Cabling to create structured cabling. You can skip thisstep if structured cabling is already created or you do not manage structured cabling.

MPO circuits can be built in dcTrack in the same way as other data circuits. However, since MPO ports support mul-tiple connections, each port must have multiple channels.Consider the use case below where a server port that is an LC 1-Channel is connected to the Data Panel that hasMPO 6-Channel Connectors and which is further connected to MPO 6-channel Switch ports.The cord used on the left side is typically referred to as "Octopus", "Breakout" or "Harness". 5 more circuits can becreated from 1-Channel ports in Node 1 and the rest of the circuits comes up as previously built circuits.Steps to build circuits this circuit in dcTrack:1. In Connectivity, add a circuit and select the item and the port for the first node.2. For the second node, select the data panel which has the MPO port. The far end right panel is shown as thethird node.3. For the fourth node, select the network item that has MPO port.4. Save the Circuit.When the circuit is saved it will have two records in the Circuit List, one full circuit and one shared right partial circuit.In this case the two data panels and network switch form a shared right partial circuit. The shared right partial circuitcannot be disconnected when used in a full circuit.Since the MPO port on the data panel can still accept five more connections, it will appear in the list of availableports when building a circuit. This port will no longer appear in the list when all its channels are connected.You can also build all 6 circuits for this use case in the same tab by selecting 6 servers ports together from itemdetails page, when the first node is the same item for all the 6 circuits and then selecting the MPO data panel portand for the fourth node, selecting the network MPO port.When these circuits are saved, the circuit list will have 7 records where 6 circuits are full circuits and 1 circuit is theshared right partial circuit.Circuit trace will also show the Leg value when two ports on either side of the cord have different number of chan-nels. In this use case the first node of the circuit is 1 channel port which connects to 6-channel MPO port, hence the6 circuits have a Leg value from 1 to 6. Leg value here indicates which leg of the Octopus or Breakout cable the Cordis using.The Cord Information dialog also includes a Leg field to indicate which leg the cord is using. This field appears onlywhen the two ports on either side of the cord have a different number of channels. This field is a drop-down and theoptions includes the leg numbers available for connection.For example, when a single-channel server port is connected to a 6-channel MPO port, the drop-down menu willoffer options 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6, with 1 selected by default. After the circuit is saved, the available options will be 2, 3,4, 5, and 6, indicating that Leg 1 of the cable is in use. This field is editable, so you can change the leg value to otheroptions available in the drop-down.A new column Breakout Leg is added to the Circuit List which display the Leg value for each circuit. This column willbe blank when all the ports used in the circuit have same number of channels.View each circuit node info by clicking the hamburger icon on each node. This opens a menu with the followingoptions.1. Item Details – Click here to go to the Item Details page of the selected node.2. Port Inspector – Click here to open the Port Inspector for the item of the selected node.3. Show in Floor Map- Click here to see where the item is in your data center. You will be redirected to the Visu-alization tab showing the floor map of your data center.4. View Partial circuit – You will get this option only if this circuit was built using a partial circuit. This option willdisplay the Partial circuit in the current tab.You can also view cord information for Patch Cords and Structured Cabling between two nodes.To view cord information, click on the patch cord or structured cabling between two nodes. This opens a dia-log window with the associated cord information.If you have opened the circuit in edit mode, you can also edit the Patch Cord Information. Saving the circuitalso saves the cord details.You can only edit cord information for patch cords, for structured cabling the Cord Information dialog is readonly.If your circuit is built using a partial circuit, the cord information for the partial circuit will not editable whenopened from the full circuit. You can edit the cord information in the partial circuit which will update the cordinformation for the full circuit.

Network to network circuits are called as Uplinks. dcTrack allows you to visualize a circuit from the Network item atthe end of the circuit to the next circuit or circuits that lead to another network item.To view Uplink Circuit :1. In the circuit trace, click hamburger icon on the last node.2. In the menu go to the option View Uplink Circuit. You will see the list of Uplink Circuits.3. Click the Uplink Circuit that you want to view.Uplink Circuit will show as a separate circuit below in the same tab.To print a single circuit, click the print button in the toolbar.To print multiple circuits, select all the circuits by checking the checkbox at the top left corner of the page and clickprint button in the toolbar.Note: When multiple circuits are viewed in single tab, each circuit will have checkbox to select the circuit and per-form any action.

Power infrastructure in dcTrack can be built out using the Web Client and File Import.The high-level process for building a power chain in dcTrack is as follows:1. Create a UPS. Users with the appropriate permissions can create a UPS using the Add an Item button in theAssets tab.2. Create a UPS bank. A UPS bank is a child of a UPS and can be created in the UPS Item Details page.3. Assign the UPS to the UPS bank. The UPS can be assigned to a UPS bank from the UPS Item Details page.4. Create a floor PDU. Users with the appropriate permissions can create a floor PDU using the Add an Itembutton in the Assets tab.5. Create the power panels for the floor PDU.6. Create panel and busway breakers via File Import or UI. This will also create outlets if outlet do not exist andconnect breakers to those outlets.The following diagram depicts an example power chain:In order to build out power circuits from the IT equipment power supplies, the power chain must be created first. At aminimum, this power chain must include UPS units, UPS Banks, Floor PDUs with power panels and Power Outletsat the Cabinets. Alternatively, the Virtual Power Chain (VPC) can be used.As of 9.0.0, the power chain can be expanded beyond the UPS units all the way to the Utility Feed and Generatorspassing through any number of Switchgear, switchboard, Power Panel and Transformer. For Instructions aboutadding and connecting these facility items, refer to Connecting Facility Items.To create the UPS, UPS Bank and Floor PDU power chain, follow the below steps:1. Create UPS Units2. Create a UPS Bank3. Create UPS Bank Load Devices4. Connect UPS Bank Load Devices to UPS Units5. Create Floor PDUs6. Connect Floor PDUs to UPS Bank Load DevicesNote: The configuration settings for the UPS and Power Panel can also be set via File Import

One or more UPS Units can be aggregated using the UPS Bank which in turn feeds one or more Floor PDUs. Eachpower chain in your data center may have one or more UPS Units.1. In the Assets tab > Item List, click the Add an Item button. A new Item page will open in a new dcTrack tab.2. In the New Item page, select the UPS Unit’s make and model.3. Assign a name to the UPS Unit.4. Select a location for the UPS Unit, if different from the one already selected in the Location dropdown.5. In the Configuration sub-tab enter the following information:a. Rating (kVA)b. Rating (kW)c. Rating (Vac)d. Output Wiring6. Save the UPS item.7. Repeat for any additional UPS Unit items.You will need a UPS Bank for each power chain in your data center. Typically, data centers have 2 redundant powerchains. A UPS Bank is technically a Switchgear which in dcTrack is represented using the Class/Subclass AC Dis-tribution/Switch. Therefore, an AC Distribution/UPS Bank and AC Distribution/Switch electrically and functionally arethe same, but in dcTrack the UPS Bank is a special case of a switch since it is the switchgear that feeds from theUPS Units and distributes out to the Floor PDUs.1. In the Assets tab > Item List, click the Add an Item button. A new Item page will open in a new dcTrack tab.2. In the New Item page, select the UPS Bank’s make and model. You may use the Generic UPS Bank model.3. Assign a name to the UPS Bank.4. Select a location for the UPS Bank, if different from the one already selected in the Location dropdown.5. In the Configuration sub-tab enter the following information:a. Rating (A)b. Rating (Vac) - This should also match the Voltage of the UPS Units.c. Output WiringNote: The above 3 values are the specification of the Busbar that is inside the UPS Bank switchgear.d. Redundancy – this depends on the number of UPS Units that you will connected to the bank in Step 13below. You will want to update this value after connecting all the UPS units to this bank.e. Rating (kVA) and Rating (kW) are read-only. They are automatically calculated based on the numberof UPS Units that you will connect to the Bank in step 8 below and the Redundancy setting.6. Save the UPS Bank item.7. Repeat for any additional UPS Bank items.8. In the Switch Devices sub-tab of the UPS Bank, click the Create Switch Devices button and choose LoadDevice. You will repeat this step for as many UPS Units and Floor PDUs there are connecting from and to thisUPS Bank. A load device is the large breakers that are installed in the UPS Bank.a. Select the Make and Model for the Load Device.b. Give the Load Device a name. This name must be unique within the UPS Bank item only.c. Give the Load Device an optional number for easier reference within this UPS Bank.d. The Connector Type is inherited from the Model of the Load Device. If this remains blank, it is becausethe Load Device Model does not have the Connector Type set. You may want to create multiple LoadDevice models for each Connector Type you want to use. Each Connector Type displays it own sym-bol in the Single Line Diagram.e. Rating (Vac) is read-only and is inherited from the UPS Bank itself, which was selected in the Con-figuration sub-tab.f. Phase is read-only and is inherited from the UPS Bank itself. (It will show Three Phase Delta if theBank’s Output Wiring is 3-Wire + Ground, or Three Phase Wye if the Bank’s Output Wiring is 4-Wire +Ground.g. Rating (A) must be equal to or less than the Rating (A) of the UPS Bank.h. Derate 80%. Uncheck this box if the Load Device breaker is 100% rated.i. The remaining fields are optional.j. When the Rating (A) was filled in, you will notice a form appears to the right. This specifies how thisLoad Device connects internally within the UPS Bank switchgear.1. For a Load Device that feeds from the UPS Units select the following:1. Line Side:a. Connects to: Extb. Fed From: Select the UPS Unit’s Output.2. Load Side:a. Connects to: Bus A.2. For a Load Device that feeds to the Floor PDUs, select the following:1. Line Side:a. Connects to: Bus A2. Load Side:1. Connects to: Ext.Note: Bus B and Bus C are optional and would only be used when the Switchgear has more then one bus. Whenmultiple buses exist, a Load Device would connect them together. These 3 bus notations should not be confusedwith the 3 poles of a Three Phase circuit.k. Click Createl. Create all other Load Devices and select the appropriate selections at step j based on what this loaddevice will connect to.m. Save the UPS Bank Item.n. At this point, you should have a UPS Bank connected to the UPS Unit(s). If you go back to the UPS item(s) (Refresh it, if it was already open)and in the Configuration sub-tab, the UPS Output section should display the Bank name that this UPS Unitis part of and the total capacity of theUPS Bank. If this total is higher than expected, you may need to adjust the Bank’s Redundancy field.

1. In the Assets tab > Item List, click the Add an Item button. A new Item page will open in a new dcTrack tab.2. In the New Item page, select the floor PDU’s make and model.3. Assign a name to the floor PDU.4. Select a location for the floor PDU, if different from the one already selected in the Location dropdown.5. In the Configuration sub-tab enter the following information:a. Rating (kVA)b. Rating (A) – Should be a number that is close to the result of this formula: Rating (kVA) * 1000 / (Rating(Vac) * SQRT(3) * NEC Derating), where the Rating (Vac) is the voltage of the item feeding the FloorPDU and the NEC Derating is 80% for Data Centers in the United States.c. Class/Subclass: Select UPS Bank optiond. Fed From: Select the UPS Bank Load Device feeding this Floor PDU.If you do not have a UPS Bank created, you can also select VPC UPS Bank from the drop-down. ACVPC must be enabled for the location in order to view VPC UPS banks in the drop-down. See Enableor Disable VPC for a Location.e. The Rating (Vac) and Input Wiring will be automatically filled in based on the Fed From selection.f. Save the Floor PDU item.g. Repeat these steps for each additional Floor PDU.h. In the Power Panels sub-tab of each Floor PDU, create one or more power panels that are eitherinternal to the Floor PDU (Local), remotely placed panels or RPPs (Remote), or busway systems feed-ing from the Floor PDU (Busway). Click Create a panel and fill in all the required fields to create eachpanel accordingly to the panel specifications. Note that the panel name needs to be unique only withinthe Floor PDU.i. Click Create buttonj. Repeat for each additional panel for this Floor PDU.k. From the list of power panels in this sub-tab, you can click each panel name to open that panel andbegin adding breakers within the panel which would also include creating the Power Outlet items thatare fed from each of the breakers.1. Back on the Power Panels sub-tab, click on the desired power panel to view its Item Details page.2. In the Power – [x] Poles, [y] Breakers sub-tab, click the Bulk Edit button to edit the breakers. Alternatively, inthe Assets tab > Items List, click the Export button and select either of the following options:a. Download Import Template to download the import template as a CSV file.b. Export into an Import Template > Branch Circuit Breakers to download an import template populatedwith the panel and busway breakers as a CSV file.3. Open your CSV file.4. Follow the instructions in the CSV file to add breakers.5. In the Assets tab > File Import page, import the edited CSV file to create the breakers. This will also create theoutlets and connect the breakers to those outlets.

At this point, if you are planning on using File Import to create power outlet circuiting, note the following pre-requisites.Each floor PDU and its busways must be created in dcTrack before you can import power outlet circuiting.Each floor PDU's power panel and the power panel's poles and breakers must be created in dcTrack beforeyou can import power outlet circuiting.UPS specifications can be viewed from the UPS Specification panel of a Configuration sub-tab on a UPS ItemDetails page.The Configuration sub-tab on UPS Item Detail pages includes the following panels:UPS OutputUPS SpecificationUPS Input (Inlet)UPS Input (Bypass)UPS Units in BankThe data in the UPS Specification panel includes the following:Rating (kVA)Nameplate (kVA)Rating (kW)Nameplate (kW)Rating (Vac)Output WiringYou can also assign the UPS to a bank in the UPS Specification panel through the UPS Bank dropdown.To edit these specifications, click the Edit icon to enter Edit mode, make your changes, and then click the Save iconto save the new configuration.UPS Items will now be created with 3 Power Ports (these will be automatically created for existing UPS Items uponupgrading to 9.0.0).UPS InletUPS OutputUPS BypassPhase Type for these Ports are same as the Output Wiring in the specification field, Volts come from the Rating(Vac) field.Rating (A) of the ports are calculated using the following formulaRating (A) = [Rating (kVA)x1000] / [Rating (Vac)x1.732]Rating (A) column can be inline edited for the saved UPS item, however the updated Rating(A) value cannot be lessthan the calculated Rating(A) and cannot be greater than 1.5 times the calculated value.When UPS Ports are connected, UPS Inlet and UPS Bypass the Rating(A) must be < = Rating(A) of Fed From Itemand UPS Output, Rating(A) must be > = UPS Bank Load Device Continuous Rating A

Steps to create a Battery String for an UPS Unit:1. Navigate to the Item details Page of an UPS.2. In the Edit Mode, click the Create Battery Strings button on the Batteries Subtab. The "CreateBattery Sting" button is only enabled when Discharge VPC and Target Runtime for the UPS are> 0.3. Select the Model for the Battery from the Model drop down.Note: Battery Models must be created in dcTrack before creating a Battery string.4. Once the model is selected, the Battery Model Specification section is populated with the val-ues from the model and is read only. The value for the Peukert Exponent is calculated based onthe Battery model specification fields. These fields are read only and cannot be edited.If the model you have selected is missing any of the Specification fields, you will not be able to createthe Battery String and will receive an error message when saving the UPS Item.5. Battery Name Prefix: User defined prefix. (Required)6. String Name: User defined name. (Required)7. Batteries in the String: Required. Based on the number entered, Nominal String Voltage (Vdc),Cells in String and String Voltage at Discharge (Vdc) are calculated.8. Capacity (AH) @ X Hours @ VPC. Required. For this field X is the value for Target Run TimeHours, and VPC is the Discharge VPC value for the UPS.Note: If the Discharge VPC of the Battery and the UPS are equal, and Target Run Time Hours of theUPS matches one of the Capacity Rate Hours from the Models Library, the Capacity Amp-Hours fieldis filled from the Battery Model for the matching hour, otherwise it is left blank and the user must inputthis value.9. Installation Date. OptionalAge is calculated in years based on the Installation date you have entered.10. End of Life Factor (%). Required. By default, it is set to 100 but can accept any integer between1-100.Capacity @ EOL (AH) is calculated based on the End of Life Factor (%)11. Click on Create and close.12. Save the item.Batteries created appear in the list grouped by the Battery String. The following information can beedited inline in the list.Capacity (AH) @ X HoursEnd of Life Factor (%) Accepts any integer between 1-100.Value of Capacity @ EOL (AH) and Estimated Run time Hours will be updated based on the End ofLife Factor. Estimated Run Time Hours is also updated when you enter a value for Additional Load (A).Note : Additional Load (A) value can be used to simulate additional load to determine its impact onEstimated Run TimeBattery Strings can also be created when creating Battery Items via File Import. Download the ImportTemplate file and in the Plant or Rectifer & Battery tab, follow the instructions and examples to assignthe Battery to a String when adding Batteries via File Import.UPSs can be assigned to a specified UPS bank in the UPS Specification panel of a Configuration sub-tab on a UPSItem Details page.Note: You must have permissions to edit the UPS in order to edit the Configuration sub-tab information.To assign a UPS to a UPS bank:In the UPS Item Details page of the UPS you want to assign, click the Edit icon to enter Edit mode.Click the Configuration sub-tab.In the Configuration sub-tab, in the UPS Specification panel, select the desired UPS bank from the drop-down.Click the Save icon to save the configuration.Note: The UPS dropdown only populates the UPS banks that are in the same location as in the UPS unit.

Users with the appropriate permissions can view, add, edit, and delete a UPS bank from the Available UPS Bankspanel in the Configuration sub-tab of a UPS Item Details page.The available UPS banks are listed based on the location of the UPS. For example, if the UPS in located in Site A,the available UPS banks listed in the Available UPS Banks panel will be those in Site A.
