If the UPS is alreadyassigned to a UPS bank, that UPS bank will be automatically selected in the Available UPS Banks panel and will beused to populate the UPS Units in Bank panel.The Available UPS Banks panel lists the following information for each bank:Bank: The name of the UPS bankUnits: The number of UPS units assigned to the bankRedundancy: N or N+1, depending on the number of UPSs assigned to the UPS bankkVAVoltsAmpsTo add a UPS bank, only the UPS bank name is required.1. In a UPS Item Details page > Configuration sub-tab, click the Edit icon to enter Edit mode.2. Click the Add a Bank button in the Available UPS Banks panel.3. In the Available UPS Banks panel, in the Bank Name field, enter the name of your UPS bank. Note: TheBank Name must be unique; otherwise, you will receive an error.4. Click the Create button.Upon successful creation, the new UPS bank will appear in the Available UPS Banks panel and in the UPS Bankdropdown in the UPS Specification panel.Note: You must have permissions to edit the UPS in order to edit the Configuration sub-tab information.

Only a UPS bank name and its redundancy can be edited.5. In a UPS Item Details page > Configuration sub-tab, click the Edit icon to enter Edit mode.1. In the Available UPS Banks panel, select the UPS that you want to edit.2. Click the Edit button in the Available UPS Banks panel.3. Edit the Bank Name and Redundancy fields as desired.4. Click the Save button to save the new configuration.Upon successful saving, the new bank name and redundancy will be reflected in the Available UPS Banks panel.Only the new bank name will be reflected in the UPS Bank dropdown in the UPS Specification panel.Note: You must have permissions to edit the UPS in order to edit the Configuration sub-tab information.Deleting a UPS bank will remove it from the Available UPS Banks panel and from selection in the UPS Bank drop-down in the UPS Specification panel, but it will not delete the UPSs that are assigned to the bank.1. In a UPS Item Details page > Configuration sub-tab > click the Edit icon to enter Edit mode.2. In the Available UPS Banks panel, select the UPS that you want to delete. You can select all UPS banks byclicking the checkbox at the top of the grid. You can also select multiple UPS banks by holding the Shift but-ton to select multiple consecutive items, or the Ctrl button to select multiple non-consecutive items.3. Click the Delete link in the Available UPS Banks panel.The items will be deleted and removed from the Available UPS Banks panel and the UPS Bank dropdown in theUPS Specification panel.Note: You must have permissions to edit the UPS in order to edit the Configuration sub-tab information.

Users with the appropriate permissions can view, add, edit, and delete a UPS in a UPS bank from the Available UPSBanks panel in the Configuration sub-tab of a UPS Item Details page.The panel lists the UPSs assigned to the UPS bank selected in the Available UPS Banks panel. If the UPS is alreadyassigned to a UPS bank, that UPS bank will be automatically selected in the Available UPS Banks panel and will beused to populate the UPS Units in Bank panel.The panel lists the following information for each UPS:NamekVAkWVoltsAll UPS units of a UPS bank should have same output voltage and output wiring. Changing the output voltage andoutput wiring of UPS can result in changing these values for all the units in UPS bank. The rating or UPS capacitycannot be changed once the UPS is assigned to a bank.From the UPS Units in Bank panel in the Configuration sub-tab of a UPS Item Details page, you can view, add, edit,and delete UPSs assigned to a UPS bank.Note: You must have permissions to edit the UPS in order to edit the Configuration sub-tab information.Select a UPS in the Available UPS Banks panel, and then click the View icon. This action will open the UPS ItemDetails page in a new dcTrack tab in View mode.

In the UPS Units in Bank panel, click the Add a UPS button. This action will open a New Item page in a new dcTracktab with the UPS item details prepopulated based on the UPS bank selection.Select a UPS in the Available UPS Banks panel, and then click the Edit icon. This action will open the UPS ItemDetails page in a new dcTrack tab in Edit mode.

Select a UPS in the Available UPS Banks panel, and then click the Delete icon. This action will delete the UPS.AC Power panels can be viewed in the Power Panels sub-tab of the Remote and Local Floor PDU or AC Dis-tribution/Power Panel Item Details page.Note: You must have the appropriate permissions to view, create, or delete a power panel.

1. In a Floor PDU Item Details page > Power Panels sub-tab, click the Create a panel button.2. In the Create a panel screen, provide the following information:a. Panel Type: Local, Remote, Busway. Note: When Busway is selected, the No of Poles, Pole Layout,Pole Numbering, and Start First Pole Number At fields are disabled.b. Panel Name: The name of the panel. Can be selected from the dropdown or manually typed in.c. Phases: Single Phase(Two-Wire), Single Phase(Three-Wire) ,Three Phase Wye and Three PhaseDelta. Once you select the phase, a diagram will display in the right side of the panel.d. Phase Voltage: Provides voltage values that are prepopulated based on the Phases selection.i. Output Voltage: Provides output voltage values that are prepopulated based on the selectedphase voltage.e. Wire Colors: Provides a list of wire colors. Prepopulated based on the phases selection.f. Rating (A): Enter any value greater than 0 or select a value from the drop down.g. No of Poles: The number of poles.h. Panel Layout: Two Column or Single Column.i. Pole Numbering: Provides pole numbering based on the pole layout selection.i. Single Column: Odd, Even, Sequential, Grouped A,B,C, Grouped 1,2,3, Grouped R,Y,Bii. Two Column: Odd/Even, Sequential, Grouped A,B,C, Grouped 1,2,3, Grouped R,Y,Bj. First Pole Number At: Provides the value for the first pole number. Prepopulated based on the polenumbering selection and the number of poles.Click the Create button.The top panel of the Power Panel subtab displays readings for the panel. The tool bar provides several options forviewing the readingsPrint - Print the Power Panel SubtabShow Remaining/Show Consumption - This button can be toggled between the two options to either showremaining power or power consumedShow in Amps/Show in kW - This button can be toggled between the two options to either display the read-ings in Amps or kilowattsThe following columns are available in the grid.The # PolesState - Open ClosedRating/Continuous Rating - Displays the Rating, the De-Rated value and the voltage for the breakerDestination - This column is broken into two sections the first displays the Status Planned Installed. ForAC Panels it is the Status of the Power Outlet. For DC Items it is the status of the connected Item. The secondsection displays the connector of the Power Outlet or Connector Name when connected to a Floor PDU.When the Power Outlet has multiple ports the connectors will be listed comma separated. The text "+ AddWhip" is displayed when the breaker is not connected to an outlet.Description - Displays the assignment type and assignment text. A caption icon will be dispalyed when thereis a comment, hovering over the caption icon will display the comment text.Ckt - Circuit status when the Power Outlet is connected to equipment. When clicked you are navigated to thecircuit trace. (existing functionality)Customer: Customer field from cabinet item for the power outlet. If customer is not assigned to cabinet, thenthe customer field assigned to the power outlet. In the case where there is no power outlet, the customer fieldwill remain blank.Budget (kw) % of Rating: Budget: Budget value in kw or ampsActual (kw) % of Rating: Actual value in kw or ampsPhase

1. Navigate to the Power Panel subtab on the Floor PDU Item Detail Page2. While in Edit mode click the "add breaker" hyperlink in the breaker grid to open the Breaker Assignment dia-log box3. Supply the field data for the following fields:a. Size: -Pole xxx V, 2-Pole xxx V, 3-Pole xxx V where xxx voltage value is calculated based on the panelvolts and the pole size. (Required)b. Rating (A): The maximum current in amperes the breaker will carry continuously. (Required)c. Assignment: Assignment Type. Drop down includes:a. Cabinet or Row Positionb. Rowc. Sub-Panel : This option only appears when Size is 3-Pole.d. Spacee. Otherd. Row: Drop down options that include all the rows for the selected location. (Required when Assign-ment type is "Row")e. Cabinet or Position: Drop down list of cabinets for the selected Row as well as Future Cabinet Assign-ments that can be used as placeholders while looking for suitable space. (Required when Assignmenttype is "Cabinet or Row Position")f. Floor PDU: Drop down lists all the Floor PDUs for the selected location which are not connectedupstream (to UPS Bank or another Floor PDU Panel) and have Rating(A) less than or equal to Rating(A) entered for the breaker. (Required when Assignment type is "Sub-Panel")g. Space Name: User defined Space Name used when not assigning to a cabinet or row. (Required whenAssignment type is "Space")h. Space ID: User defined ID used when not assigning to a cabinet or row. (Required when Assignmenttype is "Space")i. Comment: User supplied comments associated with the breakerj. Include: Determines if information for the Whip Outlet should be included.a. When assignment type is "Cabinet or Row Position" or "Row" the value is set to Yes and thefield becomes read only.b. When assignment type is "Space" or "Other" the box will be checked but can be unchecked ifnot including outlet.k. Location - List of Locations. Defaults to the location of the power panel. (Required)l. Make - Drop down list filtered to the make of Whip Outlets. Default is Generic. (Required)m. Model - Drop down list filtered to the Power Outlet/Whip Outlet models for the selected Make.(Required)n. Connector - Drop down list of AC power connectors. Default is "NEMA L6-30R". (Required)o. Placement'- Options are Above, Below. "Below" is selected by default.Note: You must have the appropriate permissions to create a power panel.To delete a power panel breaker click the pencil icon in the Rating/Continuous Rating column of the breaker toenter edit mode. Once in edit mode the delete icon is displayed in the column. Click the icon to delete the breaker.Note : You must have the appropriate permissions to delete a power panel.

You can also create and manage Power Panels using file import feature. Refer to the sample import template forexamples and follow the instructions.To Export Power Panels, filter the item list for Power Panels and Export into Import Template -> Items -> AllColumns or Visible Columns.dcTrack 8.1 allows you to create and manage your panel breakers in UI.

To create panel breakers:1. Open item details page of Power Panel in edit mode.2. In the Power Panel sub tab, click on Edit Panel button.3. Provide following information to add the breakersa. Size : Select the size of the breaker.b. Rating (A) : Select Rating Amps for the breaker. You can also enter a number if the drop down list donot have the value that you want to select.4. Provide following information to connect breaker to a Power Outlet. Make sure Enable check box is checked.a. Model : Select the model for the Whip Outlet.b. Placement : Select the placement for the power outlet.c. Connector : Select the connector type for power outlet.d. Location : Select the location for the power outlet.Note : Power Outlets can be created without placing in Cabinet. You only need to specify the Row Label and thePosition in Row where the Power Outlet will be placed.5. All the empty pole positions without any breaker will have a text "Click here to add breaker". Click on the textto add the breaker.6. Select the Row and Cabinet in the Cabinet or Assignment column. If the cabinet do not exist, select the pos-ition in row for the future cabinet.7. Save the itemNote : If you want to add the breakers and do not connect it to a Power Outlet, uncheck the Enable check box inWire Breaker to a Power Outlet.Follow the steps below to edit breakers in UI.1. In the Edit Panel mode, click on the pencil icon in Breaker Rating column.2. Edit breaker size and breaker rating by selecting different value from the drop down.3. Save the item.If the breaker is connected to a Power Outlet that is connected downstream and Circuit Status column have a value,then breaker size can not be edited. Breaker Rating can be updated, however if the selected value is smaller and notsufficient to carry the load of the circuit, an error message will show and the changes will not be saved.

Follow the steps below to delete breakers in UI.1. In the Edit Panel mode, click on the pencil icon in Breaker Rating column.2. Click on the delete icon to delete the breaker.If the breaker is connected to Power Outlet that is connected downstream and the Circuit Status is Planned, thebreaker along with the Power Outlet and the circuit it is connected to will be deleted.If the circuit status is installed, the breaker can not be deleted.dcTrack 8.1 allows you to create and manage your Busway breakers in UI.To create Busway Breakers you need to have Busway Panel and Busway Outlet (Tap Box) item created in dcTrack.

To create Busway breakers:1. Navigate to Asset List, select Busway Outlet and Click Edit to open the item in Edit mode.2. In Busway Outlet Item Details Page -> Configuration Sub Tab.3. Click Edit Panel.4. Select the Number of Poles from the drop down.5. Select the Breaker Size and Rating (A) in Breakers to Add Panel.6. Click text "Click here to add breaker" in Breaker Rating column to add breaker.7. Select the connector from the drop down in Connector column.8. Save the item.Follow the steps below to edit breakers in UI.1. Navigate to Asset List, select Busway Outlet and Click Edit to open the item in Edit mode.2. In Busway Outlet Item Details Page -> Configuration Sub Tab.3. Click Edit Panel.4. Click the pencil icon in Breaker Rating column.5. Edit breaker size and breaker rating by selecting different value from the drop down.6. Save the item.You can also add more Pole Positions by selecting higher number for Number of Poles.If the breaker is connected connected downstream and Circuit Status column have a value, then breaker size cannot be edited. Breaker Rating can be updated, however if the selected value is smaller and not sufficient to carry theload of the circuit, an error message will show and the changes will not be saved.

Follow the steps below to delete breakers in UI.1. Navigate to Asset List, select Busway Outlet and Click Edit to open the item in Edit mode.2. In Busway Outlet Item Details Page -> Configuration Sub Tab.3. Click Edit Panel.4. Click the pencil icon in Breaker Rating column.5. Click on the delete icon to delete the breaker.You can also delete existing pole positions, select lower number for Number Poles. Breakers created for those polepositions will also be deleted.If the breaker is connected downstream and the Circuit Status is Planned, the breaker and circuit it is connected towill be deleted.If the circuit status is installed, the breaker can not be deleted.Panel breakers can be viewed from the Power – [x] Poles, [y] Breakers sub-tab of a power panel’s Item Details page.Panel breakers can be created using the File Import feature in dcTrack.The import template includes a step to add breaker poles, with remote and local panel breakers and busway break-ers requiring slightly different fields.

To create panel breakers:1. In the Assets tab > Items List, click the Export button and select either of the following options:a. Download Import Template to download the import template as a CSV file.b. Export into an Import Template > Branch Circuit Breakers to download an import template pop-ulated with the panel and busway breakers as a CSV file.2. Open your CSV file.3. Follow the instructions in the CSV file to add breakers.4. In the Assets tab > File Import page, import the edited CSV file to create the breakers.Deleting a breaker can be done only through file import with the DELETE operation.

AC Power Panels can be created with phase type Three Phase Delta.See here for steps to create AC Power Panels Viewing Creating and Deleting a Power Panel for a Floor.htmThree-Phase Delta Power Panels that uses 200V can be created by selecting Phase Voltage option 200 I 200. Thistype of Power Panel will support only 2-Pole and 3-Pole breakers.Power Outlets can also be created for Three Phase Delta Power Panels, but only when the Power Panel uses a 200or 208 Voltage. Power Outlets created from this Power Panel will have the same voltage, matching that of the PowerPanel.Single-Phase Power Panels that uses 100 and 200 Voltage can be created in dcTrack. This voltage option applies toall types of Power Panels in dcTrack.When creating a Power Panel with Phase type "Single Phase (3-Wire) a new option "Neutral Switch Breaker" isadded. This option when set to true then No of Poles dropdown will contain the same options used when the selec-tion is Three-phase, because when the neutral switched breakers option is set, the poles on one side of the panelmust be divisible by 3 (because there are three legs: A,N and B).The voltage for the Panel breakers will depend on the Neutral Switched Breakers setting.a. When adding Panel breakers, and the 'Neutral Switched Breakers" is false, if the breaker is 1-pole, thevoltage should be 100, when the breaker is 2-poles, the voltage is 200.b. When adding breakers, and the 'Neutral Switched Breakers" is true, if the breaker is 2-pole and it touches aNeutral phase, the voltage should be 100, when the breaker is 2-pole and it touches the A and B phases orwhen it is 3-poles, the voltage is 200. (1-pole breakers are not supported in this panel)dcTrack allows you to print Panel Views for multiple Power Panels.These steps apply to AC Distribution / Power Panel, Floor PDU / Local or Remote panels1. In the Asset list, select the Power Panels that you want to print.2. Click Report -> Power Panel3. If you would like to print the Report, once rendering is complete click the Print button in the lower right side ofeach page of the report.4. If you would like to exclude the Panel Level readings, click the "Hide Panel Readings" button in the tool bar.This button allows you to toggle between Hiding and Showing the PanelTo print Panel view for Busway Tap Boxes follow the steps below1. Open a Busway item details page.2. In the Power Tap Boxes sub tab, hover over the Tap Box image and click the hamburger icon.3. Click Panel View from the menu.4. In the Busway Outlet Breakers dialogue, click the Print button.5. The display of Panel Readings can be toggled using the "Hide Panel Readings" button.

dcTrack 8.1 allows you to view budget and actual values for PDU Panel Main Breaker.For Local and Remote Power Panels you can view this information in the Power Panel sub tab of panel item. Thisinformation read only and the values are in Amps.Actual readings for PDU Panel Main Breaker come from Power IQ and will only show when your dcTrack is integ-rated with Power IQ.For each panel breaker you can view the budget and actual value in the columns Budget % of Rating and Actual %of Rating respectively.By default these columns show percentage of consumed capacity in kW. To see these values in Amps, click thetoggle button Show in Amps.You can also view the remaining capacity for the breakers by clicking the toggle button Show Remaining.When you hover over these column cells, you will get the summary of budget and actual values for each breaker in atool tip.Actual value for each breaker will come from Power IQ if dcTrack is integrated with Power IQ. However if yourdcTrack is not integrated with Power IQ, you can use file import feature to add actual reading for each panel break-ers.Note : Toggle buttons Show Remaining and Show in Amps apply to the columns Budget % of Rating and Actual %of Rating.dcTrack allows you to create Busway item and add Busway Outlets (Tap Boxes) to the Busway.You can view all the Tap Boxes associated with a Busway item in Power Tap Boxes sub tab of Busway item details.For the Busway Main Breaker and for each Tapbox you can also view the Actual and Budget values. See BuswayBreaker Measurement for more details.You can also check for Empty Positions where you can add more Tap Boxes when you click the toggle button ShowEmpty Positions.To Hide Empty Positions, click Hide Empty Positions.Note : You can assign more than one Tap Box at the same Position in Row.

To view Busway Panel measurements, go to Power Tap Boxes sub tab of Busway Panel item.Here you can view the Budget and Actual values for the Busway Main Breaker. Also you can view consumed andremaining capacity for each Tap Box associated with the Busway.Actual readings for Busway Main Breaker come from Power IQ and will only show when your dcTrack is integratedwith Power IQ.You can also view the percentage of consumed capacity for Budget and Actual values in kW for each Tap Boxesassociated with the Busway. To view remaining capacity, click the toggle button Show Remaining.Note : Toggle buttons Show Remaining apply to Budget(kW) and Actual(kW) for each Tap Box.Budget and Actual values for individual busway breakers can be viewed in the panel view for Tap Box or in the Con-figuration sub tab of Busway Outlet item.For each breaker you can view the budget and actual value in the columns Budget % of Rating and Actual % of Rat-ing respectively.By default these columns show percentage of consumed capacity in kW. To see these values in Amps, click thetoggle button Show in Amps.You can also view the remaining capacity for the breakers by clicking the toggle button Show Remaining.When you hover over these column cells, you will get the summary of budget and actual values for each breaker in atool tip.Actual value for each busway breaker will come from Power IQ if dcTrack is integrated with Power IQ. However ifyour dcTrack is not integrated with Power IQ, you can use file import feature to add actual reading for each buswaybreakers.Note: Busway breaker readings in dcTrack are the sum of the actual amps from the RPDUs connected to the panelbreaker. To obtain these readings, the busway outlets must be connected to smart rack PDUs that are integratedwith Power IQ.Please refer to the topic below for additional informationViewing, Creating, Editing and Deleting AC Panels and BreakersFor Information on Breaker Assignment for AC please seeBreaker Assignment for DC

dcTrack 8.1.1 allows you to set up redundant pair for Floor PDU and mirror their Local and Remote Power Panels.All the mirrored Power Panels will be in full sync for all the changes like adding / removing breakers, circuiting poweroutlets, assigning power outlets to cabinets, editing text assignments etc.In order to mirror Power Panels its parent Floor PDU must have a redundant pair.Steps for setting redundant pair:1. Navigate to Item Details page of Floor PDU.2. In the Relationship sub tab click Add Relationship.3. Select Relation type Redundant Pair.4. Select the Floor PDU from item drop down.5. Click Create.Redundant Floor PDU must be in the same location and must have same rating for Main Breaker (A). Only one FloorPDU can be set as Redundant pair to another Floor PDU.You can also create and delete Item Relationship using File Import /Export. Refer to the examples in the sampleimport template for Item.Note : Relation Type Redundant pair applies only to item class Floor PDU and DC Bay. This Relation type can notbe managed in Field Management.Once the Redundant Pair is set up, Local and Remote Power Panels of the redundant Floor PDU items can bemirrored.Following are the prerequisite to mirror Power Panels.1. Floor PDU must have redundant pair.2. Local Power Panels to be mirrored must have the same name.The above rule only applies to Local Power Panels because in dcTrack the name of the Local Power Panel isunique per Floor PDU. This rule will not apply to Remote Power Panels because their name uniqueness isper location.3. Power Panels to be mirrored must be configured identically. They should have same amps rating, number ofpoles, layout and numbering scheme. Phase and Volts must be same. If there are breakers already created,they must be identical in size, position, rating and assignment.Note : When one of the Power Panel to be mirrored have breakers and other Power Panel have no breakers, thenthese Power Panels can also be mirrored. Once they are mirrored the existing Breakers from the Power Panel willbe copied to its mirrored counterpart.Steps to Mirror Local Power Panel.1. Navigate to Item Details page of Floor PDU.2. Click Edit button in the toolbar.3. In the Power Panel sub tab check the Mirrored column.Steps to Mirror Remote Power Panels.1. Navigate to Item Details page of Floor PDU.2. Click Edit button in the toolbar.3. In the Power Panel sub tab check the Mirrored column.4. Select Remote Panel from the drop down.5. Click Ok.Mirrored Panels will be in sync. Any changes made to one of the panel will get updated to its mirrored counterpart.However any connections made to the Panel Breaker Power Outlets will not be included in the sync. Mirrored PanelBreakers Power Outlets can connect to different items downstream.To remove the mirroring, uncheck the Mirrored column for the respective Power Panel or delete the relation typeRedundant Pair for Floor PDU item which will un-mirror all the Power Panels of that Floor PDU.Once the mirroring is removed, the panels will no longer be in sync and any changes made will not be copied.You are able to:Build a "Normal" Power CircuitBuild a Partial Power CircuitsAdditionally, you can:Switch an Item's Power or Data Connection (Connect and Reconnect) rather than having to submit a Dis-connect Request and rebuild a circuit.Connect to a Virtual Power Chain if you want connect to a VPC until you are to build your power chain at a latertimeSwitch from a 'Normal' Power Circuit to a Virtual Power Chain (Connect and Disconnect) if you want to con-nect to a VPC until you can once again switch back to a 'normal' circuitSwitch from a Virtual Power Chain to a 'Normal' Power Circuit (Connect and Disconnect) once you areready to build your power chain

To build a power circuit:1. In the Web Client, click Connectivity > Add a Circuit. A New Circuit tab is opened with an empty node highlightedin blue and an Item list for selecting Items for this circuit node.2. From the Item list below, select the item from which the circuit is initiated. Required3. Next, select the port the connection originates from. dcTrack validates the port selection to make sure there areno issues. RequiredWhen selecting the port list from second node onwards, you will have the option to show only compatible portsthat are most likely to be used for building this circuit. By default, this option will be enabled, if you want to viewall of the available ports for the selected item you can click on Show All Ports in the Port List toolbar.4. When building the first node, you can switch to building a data circuit instead of a power circuit by selecting thePower Ports tab from Port List.5. Once you have moved on to creating a power circuit for the next node, the option to select Data Port is no longeravailable. To switch to building a Data circuit, click the Refresh button which will reset the circuit and bring youback to the first node.6. To continue building the circuit click the Next Node button in the Port List toolbar and select the item and port forthe next node.7. Select the power item the device will be connected to, then select the power port. One of the following occurs:If you select the rack PDU output for a rack PDU that is already connected upstream, the remainder of thecircuit is displayed automatically.For example, Server ~ rack PDU ~ input cord ~ power outlet ~ PDU panel ~ floor PDU ~ UPS bank.If the circuit is not already connected upstream, click Next Node to continue building the circuit.If there is an issue between the node item or port you selected and the item and port of the previous node, a Cautionicon ( ) is displayed at the bottom right of the node. Click on the Caution icon to view the conflict details.Note: If you make changes and have already added additional nodes, the nodes that follow are deleted.8. Click Save to save the circuit.9. Submit a Connect Request now or at a later time.After the power circuit is saved, you can view the actual load and the reading for each node by clicking on the buttonShow Reading in the toolbar. You can also hide the readings by clicking on Hide Reading Button.You can also build multiple power circuits in single tab. You can do this by selecting an item and selecting all of theports for that item. This will build the same number of circuits as the number of ports you have selected in single tab.Click on Next Node and select the item for next node and so on.Partial power circuits start with a rack PDU and end on a power infrastructure item.You cannot join two partial circuits together to create a compound circuit.

You can submit a Disconnect Request or Connect Request for circuits in dcTrack. Like item action requests, theseare requests to perform actions in the data center.A disconnect or connect request can be submitted separate of an item request. For example, you can submit a Dis-connect Request for a rack PDU's circuit without needing to move the rack PDU and submit a Move Item Request forit.When submitting requests from the Actions menu, you can select multiple circuits from the Circuits List and submit arequest for them at the same time.Requests can be submitted while in Request Bypass is enabled or disabled.A circuit's status does not change until a request is submitted for it. Once an action request is submitted -If you are working in Request Bypass, the request is processed automatically and either approved or rejected.The request is submitted for review if Request Bypass is disabled.For information on checking a request status, see Requests and Work Orders.Circuit request can also be submitted from Circuit TraceIf you have more than one circuit opened in single tab, select the circuits by selecting the checkbox next toeach circuit and submit a request for them at the same time.The Circuit Trace column on the Circuits List page provides the circuit's path to items in dcTrack. Use the columnbased filtering feature on the page to narrow results.View a specific data or power circuit by double clicking on the circuit on the Circuits List page, or by selecting one ormore circuits and clicking the View button on the toolbar. When only a single circuit is selected in the list you will betaken directly to the Circuit Trace page for the selected circuit. When multiple circuits are selected the View buttonwill provide a drop-down list allowing you to select whether to view the selected circuits in a single tab or multipletabs.When viewing a circuit trace, the Status icon will display the current status of each circuit. The icon will display a "P"for planned circuits and an "I" for Installed circuits. This icon is displayed on both Data and Power Circuits. Hoveringover the icon displays a tool tip with additional information.

Users with View access and above can trace a power port circuit directly from the Power - n Ports tab on an item'spage in the Web Client.Select a single port or use Ctrl + click to select multiple ports, then click Trace.The circuit page opens under the Connectivity tab.

Users with View access and about can trace a data port circuit directly from the Data - n Ports tab on an item's pagein the Web Client.Select a single port or use Ctrl + click to select multiple ports, then click Trace.The circuit page(s) open under the Connectivity tab.When saving the edits made to an Installed circuit, both the Original circuit and a Proposed version of the circuit arecreated.To view a list of Proposed Circuits, filter the Circuit grid on the Proposed Column by selecting "Yes". This will providea list of all Proposed Circuits.Clicking the View link in the Proposed column on the Circuits List page allows you to view a proposed circuit.

You can delete power circuits in a Planned status as long as you have edit access to the circuit.When you delete circuits, the entire circuit is deleted; this means all connections in the circuit are deleted.Partial Circuits that are part of a Full Circuit cannot be deleted. These Circuits must first be removed from the Full Cir-cuits in which they are used.Circuits are deleted in the Web Client by:Selecting one or more circuits from the Circuits List, clicking Delete at the top of the page, and clicking Yes whenprompted to confirm the deletionOrOpening a circuit's page, clicking Delete at the top of the page, and clicking Yes when prompted to confirm thedeletion.When multiple circuits are opened in a single tab, select the circuits to be deleted by selecting the check boxnext to each circuit and clicking the Delete button.Note: Decommissioning a circuit removes the entire circuit. It does not place the circuit back in the planned status.Note: The steps to delete normal power circuits and virtual power circuits are the same.While data and power circuits are being built, click the Refresh button on the New Circuit page to clear all the nodesyou have created so far and begin again.When building a single circuit in a tab, the Refresh button clears all the nodes except the first one.When building multiple circuits in single tab, only the selected circuit will be reset by clicking the Refresh button.

When working on an item in dcTrack, there are a few common use cases that cover the majority of scenarios whencreating connections. For example, when creating data port connections, you typically connect to either a top-of-rack or end-of-row network switch configuration. Alternatively, you may want to connect to a far-end item, withouthaving to be concerned about the structured cabling in-between or knowing exactly which port on which data panelyou need to connect to.dcTrack’s Quick Connect feature enables users with the appropriate permissions to make data port and power portconnections more efficiently by making the connections for them.There are two types of Quick Connect options for connections:Best Candidate: The items and ports contained within the cabinet are given preference when displaying thepossible items and ports available that can be connected to. The Best Candidate results for data ports displaythe possible items and ports available that match the connector and port media. Available ports are weightedbased on location, item class, number of hops, redundancy, color, V-LAN group, protocol, and data rate(speed). The Best Candidate results for power ports display a list of available ports that match the connector,phase, and volts. Available ports are weighted based on power chain capacity, item class, color, redundancy,phase balancing and positional symmetry.Best Path: The far-end item that needs to be connected to is identified, and dcTrack presents the best avail-able options to make the connection. The Best Path results for data ports display a list of available ports thatmatch the connector and port media. Available ports are weighted based on target item free ports, followedby data panels located in the cabinet.The Best Candidate and Best Path options are available for connections between items and data ports. Only theBest Candidate option is available for outlet and power outlet port connections.Note: The ports to be connected must be attached to an item located in a cabinet.You can access the Quick Connect feature from an Item Details page. In the appropriate data ports or power portstab, simply click the Quick Connect icon next to the port you want to make the connection for. The Quick Connecticon will not appear for ports that are connected or ports that are marked in use. For Best Candidate matches,dcTrack will provide a list of available items and ports where you can select what you want to connect to, and thenthe system creates the circuit for you. If connecting to a far-end item with the Best Path option, you enter the name ofthe item (and optionally the location), and the system will present the best paths available for you to connect.

1. In the desired Item Details page in Edit mode, select the Power ports tab at the bottom of the page.2. In the Connected Item column, next to the port you want to make the connection for, click the Quick Connecticon. Ports that are not connected will show as Available in the Connected Item column.3. The Quick Connect dialog will display. Best Candidate results are populated by default. Note that you cansort and filter results by cabinet, item name, port, connector, phase leg, phase load amps, volts, color, source,Amps, CB/fuse, CB/fuse amps, and limit vs. total ports per item. You can also include or exclude ports in thespecified cabinet, direct connections, partial circuits, and ports more than one hop away. Limiting the numberof ports per item will display only the items with minimum number of ports specified. As with other grids indcTrack, you can show or hide selected columns by clicking the Filters icon (three dots) on the right. If youselect the Views dropdown, you're able to create additional views and set one as the default.4. Select the port you want to connect to.5. Click the Connect Selected Port button.6. You'll be taken to the new circuit's Details page in the Connectivity tab.7. Click the Save button to save your changes.1. In the desired Item Details page in Edit mode, select the Data ports tab at the bottom of the page.2. In the Connected Item column, next to the port you want to make the connection for, click the Quick Connecticon.3. The Quick Connect dialog will display. Best Candidate results are populated by default. Note that you cansort and filter results by cabinet, item name, port, connector, color, protocol, data rate, and limit vs. total portsper item. You can also include or exclude ports in the specified cabinet, direct connections, partial circuits,and ports more than one hop away. Limiting the number of ports per item will display only the items with min-imum number of ports specified. As with other grids in dcTrack, you can show or hide selected columns byclicking the Filters icon (three dots) on the right. If you select the Views dropdown, you're able to create addi-tional views and set one as the default.4. For Best Path results, type in the name and location (optional) of the item you want to connect to.5. Select the port you want to connect to.6. Click the Connect Selected Port button.7. You'll be taken to the new circuit's Details page in the Connectivity tab.8. Click the Save button to save your changes.

The Best Candidate results for data ports display a list of available ports that match the connector and port media.Available ports are weighted based on:Location in the same cabinetItem class: Network class, followed by Data Panel, and then by any other classesNumber of hops, if there is a partial circuitRedundancyColorV-LAN groupProtocolData rate(speed)The Best Path results for data ports display a list of available ports that match the connector and port media. Avail-able ports are weighted based on target item free ports, followed by data panels located in the cabinet.The Best Candidate results for power ports display a list of available ports that match the connector, phase, andvolts. Available ports are weighted based on:Power chain capacityItem class: Rack PDUs come first, followed by Power OutletsColorRedundancyPhase balancingPositional symmetryNote: Candidate ports cannot include ports from items that are in “Archived,” “Storage,” or “Hidden” status.

dcTrack version 7.0.0 introduced the ability to create Data Connections between Ports with different media types byincluding a Media Type of "Any". Setting the Media Type on the Data Ports tab of the Item Details page to "Any"allows a Port to be connected to Ports of any Media Type.To change the Port Media Type in dcTrack, navigate to the Item Details page in Edit mode and select “Any” from thedrop down box in the Media column on the Data Ports sub-tab and save the item.Note: Media type cannot be changed when the ports are connected or marked In UseYou can also change the media type to “Any” when creating or modifying data ports for specific models. When themodel is saved, Item Ports created from that model will have a media type of “Any” for each Port that was set in themodel.Media Type for data ports can also be updated through file import. This can be done both for Items as well as mod-els.When connecting Ports with different Media Types, the following rules apply:1. Data connections can be made between two data ports of the same media type.2. Data connections can be made between data ports with Media Type “Any" to other media types i.e. TwistedPair, Coax, Single-Mode, Multi-Mode.dcTrack provides a quick and efficient way to identify Assets associated with a specific Circuit node.This can be particularly useful for impact analysis when it is necessary to identify the Assets affectedby a failure or an expected outage. The "Show in Assets" button available on the Circuit List tool barallows users to quickly navigate to a filtered Items List containing the first node Items for a selectedgroup of Circuits.Steps to identify and filter Items:1. Navigate to the Connectivity > Circuit List.2. Filter on the Node you are interested in. You can use the Show/Hide icon to include the FirstNode Item column in the Circuit List grid.3. Select the individual Items you are interested in or use the Select All check box at the top of thegrid to select all of the Items.4. Click the Show In Assets button on the tool bar.5. You are immediately redirected to the Items List page filtered to the first node Items for the pre-viously selected circuits.

Sunbird provides Microsoft Excel® worksheets that are used to capture structure cabling and power panel data.Worksheets are meant as data capture tools only; they cannot be used like import spreadsheet templates to importdata using File Import.Worksheets are used primarily when you are implementing dcTrack. See the dcTrack Implementation and Integ-ration Guide.

This chapter covers integrating or connecting dcTrack with other systems. These can include:Sunbird's Power IQ® DCIM Monitoring SoftwareCMDBs and Ticketing Systems, such as ServiceNow and BMC's RemedyVirtual Machine technologies, such as VMwareThe diagram below describes the dcTrack System Architecture, and its Open port requirements:

dcTrack can be used as a standalone product or integrated with Sunbird's Power IQ for power and environmentalmonitoring. Integrating allows you to access the functionality of both applications without having to maintain data ineach application.Integrating with multiple Power IQs is especially useful if you have multiple Power IQs at various locations, and eachof those Power IQs is managing a large number of assets. Instead of managing each Power IQ and its assets indi-vidually, you manage them all from dcTrack.Once integration is enabled, all data can be synced between dcTrack and Power IQ.Note: In order to prevent round trips when sending data from Power IQ or dcTrack, both Power IQ and dcTrackmaintain revision numbers. When data is pushed from Power IQ or dcTrack, the revision numbers are compared todetermine which system has the freshest data. The system with the freshest data will make the update and incre-ment both revisions. If the revision numbers are the same no update is performed and the revision numbers are notincremented.Depending on your environment, the first time you integrate multiple Power IQs may require the help of ProfessionalServices to ensure your data are in sync. See Check When to Contact Professional Services and Support andWhen to Begin Multiple Power IQ Integrations on Your Own.It is important you read the information that is specific to your configuration scenario before you use this feature.The Power IQ® data model is relevant to dcTrack users who are integrating an existing dcTrack with Power IQ.From the top of the hierarchy to the bottom:DATA_CENTER: The data center object type. This object has no parent.FLOOR: The floor object type. This object can only have a DATA_CENTER as a parent.ROOM: The room object type. This object can have a DATA_CENTER or FLOOR as a parent.AISLE: The aisle object type. This object can have a DATA_CENTER, FLOOR, or ROOM as a parent.ROW: The row object type. This object can have a DATA_CENTER, FLOOR, ROOM, or AISLE as a parent.RACK: The rack object type. This object can have a DATA_CENTER, FLOOR, ROOM, AISLE, or ROW as aparent.DEVICE: The IT Device object type. This object can only have a RACK as a parent.DOOR: The door object type. This object can have a DATA CENTER, FLOOR, ROOM, AISLE, ROW, orRACK as a parent.These objects represent PDUs and sensors:PDU: The PDU object type. This object represents all types of PDUs in Power IQ, including Rack PDUs, RackTransfer Switches, Cooling Units, Floor PDUs, Floor UPS, Power Panels, and Standalone Meters. Thisobject can have a DATA_CENTER, FLOOR, ROOM, AISLE, ROW, or RACK as a parent.SENSOR: The sensor object type. This object can have a DATA_CENTER, FLOOR, ROOM, AISLE, ROW,or RACK as a parent.

This may alsooccur if you integrated and continued to enter data in Power IQ.Contact Professional Services and Support for help syncing your data.You are using Power IQ and want toThis means Power IQ is populated with data and you want to push the dataintegrate with a new dcTrack.to a new dcTrack installation that does not contain data.You do not have to take extra steps when you move to dcTrack 4.0.0.dcTrack uses the Power IQ IP address and access credentials you alreadyYou are currently using a dcTrack that isprovided to automatically associate your dcTrack and Power IQ.already integrated with a Power IQ andknow your data is synced correctly.Important: If you believe your data is out of sync between dcTrack andPower IQ, Professional Services and Support must help you sync your data.This means integrating a new or existing dcTrack with a new Power IQYou are integrating with a one or moreinstallation that contains no data.new Power IQs.See Integrating Multiple, New Power IQs with dcTrack.

When dcTrack is integrated with Power IQ, in order to maintain data integrity, all integrated items should beadded and updated in dcTrack. The only exception is when the functionality exists in Power IQ only.Please refer to the following links for specific information related to Power IQ Integration.The Power IQ Data ModelWhen to contact Professional Services and when to Proceed on your ownIntegrate an existing dcTrack to a fresh Power IQIntegrate an existing Power IQ to a fresh dcTrackIntegrating multiple new Power IQs with dcTrackImport or Synchronize an Entire Data CenterSteps to Add an RPDU in dcTrack and integrate with Powwe IQAuto Update Rack PDU Inlet and Outlet NamesRetrieving Sensor ReadingsManually Configure dcTrack Items to retrieve Readings from One or More ItemsSync Multiple Ports at the Same TimeSensor IntegrationDecommission RPDUs in dcTrack when integrated with Power IQDelete/Disable Power IQ integrationData Model SyncSyncing Power IQ and dcTrack Floor Maps

For specific instructions on how to integrate dcTrack and Power IQ please refer to the documentation below thatbest describes your installation:Steps to Integrate an Existing dcTrack with a New Power IQSteps to Integrate an Existing Power IQ with a new dcTrack1. Make sure you have a current back-up of Power IQ2. Set Power IQ auto back-up time xxx to match dcTrack (make sure Network Time Protocol is enabled on bothsystems)Note: In dcTrack versions prior to 8.1.0, the backup time was 1AM Eastern Time and could not be changed. IndcTrack version 8.1.0 and later the backup schedule can be configured by the user.4. Add the Power IQ appliance to dcTrack Integration grida. Power IQ Label - Required - Label used to identify the integration recordb. Power IQ IP Address - Required - IP address of the Power IQ instance you want to integrate withc. Power IQ Username - Required - Username to be used for authentication to the Power IQ instance Toproperly integrate with Power IQ, the chosen Power IQ Username must have the System Admin-istrator Role in Power IQ.d. Password - Required - Password associated the specified Usernamee. Auto-sync-Username - Required - Local dcTrack Username that will be used in audit trail records thatresult form the integration.f. Power IQ version - Read Only - This value is retrieved from Power IQ upon successful integrationg. Last Sync - Read Only - Date and Time of the last synch. Reading Refresh Interval - This is the amount of time dcTrack will consider readings to be up to date. IfReadings are older than the interval they will be refreshed automatically the next time a page with read-ings is accessed. If the readings were refreshed within the time-frame of this interval dcTrack will notrequest fresh readings. Additionally, if a user requests readings manually by clicking the "Get Read-ings" button, readings will only be refreshed if the last reading was outside of the time-frame of theinterval.For example, if the Reading Refresh Interval is set to 10 and readings are refreshed at 9:15, readingswill not be eligible for a refresh until 9:25.This setting affects readings on the following pages:a. Item Detail page (Power Ports and Sensors)b. Circuit Tracec. Floor Mapsd. Dashboard Widgets that report readingsNote: the Reading Refresh Interval is available in dcTrack version 9.0.0 and later.5. Enable Integration6. Navigate to Locations. Assets > Locations7. Associate each Location you want to integrate with the Power IQ you just added8. Once the Location is associated with the Power IQ instance, the Location Name will appear under the PowerIQ column in the same row as its associated dcTrack Location.9. Select the row(s) you wish to process.10. Click the Sync button in the tool bar11. You will be presented with a pop up describing the process. You can either click the OK button to continue theprocess or click the Cancel button to return to the Integration page.12. Once the process starts, a progress bar is displayed at the bottom of the page.13. You can cancel the process at any time by clicking the Cancel button.Note: You may continue processing on dcTrack while the Import is running. If any user returns to this page whilethe process is running, the progress bar is displayed and refreshed with the current progress.

1. Make sure you have a current back-up of Power IQ2. Set Power IQ auto back-up time xxx to match dcTrack (make sure Network Time Protocol is enabled on bothsystems)Note: In dcTrack versions prior to 8.1.0, the backup time was 1AM Eastern Time and could not be changed. IndcTrack version 8.1.0 and later the backup schedule can be configured by the user.2. Export the list of PDU Makes and Models from the Power IQ Facility Item Table3. Export Power IQ Enterprise Relationships from the Data Management panel under the Settings Menu4. Make sure the exported list of Makes and Models are in the dcTrack Models Library and the port assignmentsare accurate.5. Add the Power IQ appliance to dcTrack Integration gridNote: To properly integrate with Power IQ, the chosen Power IQ Username must have the System AdministratorRole in Power IQ.6. Enable Integration7. Select the Data Center you wish to import from the bottom grid8. Click the Import button in the tool bar9. You will be presented with a pop up describing the process. You can either click the OK button to continue theprocess or click the Cancel button to return to the Integration page.10. Once the process starts, a progress bar is displayed at the bottom of the page.11. You can cancel the process at any time by clicking the Cancel button.Note: You may continue processing on dcTrack while the Import is running. If any user returns to this page whilethe process is running, the progress bar is displayed and refreshed with the current progress.Before using this feature, review Check When to Contact Professional Services and Support and When to BeginMultiple Power IQ Integrations on Your Own to determine if you should proceed on your own or with the help ofSunbird Professional Services.To integrate with a Power IQ:1. Add the Power IQ information to dcTrack on the Power IQ Integration tab under Settings > dcTrack Settings >Application Administration > Integrations2. Enable integration with the Power IQ.3. Select the Power IQ Integration instance you just added4. From the bottom grid, select the Power IQ Data Centers you wish to integrate5. Click the Import button on the tool bar

1. Click the Settings tab > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration > Integrations > Power IQ sub-tab.2. On the Power IQ sub-tab, in the Power IQ Systems grid, provide the following information for each Power IQ thatyou want to add:a) Power IQ Label: The user-defined name for the Power IQ to distinguish between different PowerIQs.b) Power IQ IP Address: Required. The IP Address for the Power IQ.c) Power IQ Username: Required. The username for the account that will be used to access the PowerIQ via its REST API. The account must have the System Administrator Role.d) Power IQ Password: Required. The password for the account that will be used to access the PowerIQ via its REST API.e) dcTrack Username: Required. The account that the Power IQ will use to communicate updates todcTrack via its notification API. Must be a local account. The credentials associated with the accountwill be provided to Power IQ via Registration API, without manual user configuration.f) Power IQ Version: Version of Power IQ that dcTrack will interface with. Retrieved from the Power IQREST API.g) Date of Last Full Sync: The date of the last full sync with Power IQ.h) Enable Integration: Check or uncheck the box to indicate whether integration is enabled or disabled.Note: dcTrack 5.2 introduces enhancements to the enterprise data model and synchronization that require integ-ration with Power IQ 5.2 to support the new features. If integrating with a previous version of Power IQ, dcTrack willoperate in legacy mode.3. Optional. Test Connection. Once you have populated the fields in the Power IQ Settings grid and checked theEnable Integration box, you can check that the Power IQ is accessible by clicking the Test Connection button at thetop right of the grid.4. To edit a Power IQ, click the field that you want to edit in the grid and make your desired changes.5. To delete a Power IQ, select the Power IQ that you want to delete and click the Delete Power IQ icon and button.You can associate multiple locations with a Power IQ via dcTrack Settings > Location Settings or on the Detailspage for specific Locations.1. Under the Settings tab > Location Settings, select the Location that you want to associate with Power IQ.2. Under Power IQ Host, use the dropdown to select your desired Power IQ.3. Click the Save button to save your changes.4. Optional. Click the Enable Virtual Power Chain box to enable the Virtual Power Chain.Or1. In the Locations List page, select the Location that you want to associate with Power IQ.2. Click the Edit Button to open the Location Details page in Edit mode.3. In the Settings panel in the Location Details page, select from the dropdown the Power IQ you want to associatedcTrack with.4. Optional. Click the Enable Virtual Power Chain box to enable the Virtual Power Chain.

Integration between Power IQ® and dcTrack® has been improved in dcTrack version 7.0.0 making it even easier tosynchronize data between the two systems. dcTrack now allows users to Import or Synchronize entire data centerswith a single click.Users have the ability to Import an entire non-integrated Power IQ data center, or Synchronize data betweendcTrack Locations and Power IQ data centers that have already been associated at the dcTrack Location level. Formore information on associating a Power IQ instance with dcTrack see Adding, Editing and Deleting Locations.Steps to import a Power IQ data center into dcTrack1. Navigate to the Power IQ integration tab (Settings > Application Administration > Integrations)The top half of this page all lists all of the Power IQ instances that have been added to dcTrack. For inform-ation on adding Power IQ instances see the help topics under Integrate with One or Multipl Power IQs.2. Select the Power IQ instance you want to work on. Only a single Power IQ can be selected at a time.Once a Power IQ is selected the bottom half of the page is populated in the following way: The left side of thegrid is populated with all dcTrack Locations currently associated with the selected Power IQ instance, fol-lowed by dcTrack Locations not associated with any Power IQ. The right side of the grid is populated withPower IQ data centers associated with dcTrack Locations (these Power IQ data centers appear on the sameline as the dcTrack Location they are associated with), followed by Power IQ data centers not associated withany dcTrack Location.Note: there may be a gap between the last associated Power IQ data center and the first non-associateddata center if dcTrack locations exist that are not associated with any Power IQ.3. From the bottom grid select the data center(s) you wish to Import. Selecting one or more non-associatedPower IQ data centers will enable the import button on the tool bar. Selecting one or more associated datacenters will enable the Sync button on the tool bar. You may not process a combination of associated andnon-associated data centers. Selecting a combination of associated and non-associated data centers willcause both the Sync and Import buttons to be disabled.4. Click the Import button to proceed.5. Before the process begins you will be presented with a pop up describing the action you selected and thedata that will be affected. You can either click the "OK" button to begin the process, or click the "Cancel" but-ton to cancel the operation.6. While the activity is running a progress bar is displayed at the bottom of the page. The user may navigateaway from the page while the activity is running and continue to process in dcTrack. Any user who accessesthe Integration page while the process is still running will be presented with an updated progress bar.When importing a Data Center from Power IQ the following entities are created on dcTrack when applicable:Data CenterFloorsAislesRowsRacksIT DevicesRack PDU Inlets/Outlets (with current readings)Specific Sensors (with current readings)Absolute Humidity SensorsAir Pressure SensorsAir Flow SensorsHumidity SensorsDoor SensorsContact Closure SensorsNote: Since Make and Model information for Devices is not available on Power IQ, dcTrack will store these objectsas Incomplete (Invalid) Items. You must edit these Items and supply the missing information. Upon saving theItems in a Complete (Valid) state, they will immediately become integrated.Note: Since Devices could not be completely integrated in the initial Import Process, Connections will not havebeen imported into dcTrack. To complete the Import process, you may use File Import to import Power Con-nections.When Synchronizing a Data Center the data is exchanged as follows:dcTrack will retrieve the Name from Power IQ on initial integration. Once integrated the Name isRack PDUowned by dcTrack. If the Name is modified on dcTrack, the modified Name is immediately pushed toNamePower IQ. Changes to the Name on Power IQ will not be pushed to dcTrack. If the Name is changed onPower IQ, it will be reverted to the dcTrack value when the next sync is performed.dcTrack will retrieve the Names from Power IQ on initial integration. Once integrated changes to theInlet NamesName are not pushed in either direction.dcTrack will retrieve the Names from Power IQ on initial integration. Once integrated updates are bi-Outlet Namesdirectional.Power Con-Connection data is owned by dcTrack. Connections will always be pushed from dcTrack to Power IQ.nectionsdcTrack will retrieve the Names from Power IQ on initial integration. Once integrated updates are bi-Sensor Namesdirectional.dcTrack will retrieve the Cabinet on initial integration. Once integrated updates are bi-directional.Sensor CabinetNote: If the Rack PDU Cabinet is modified, only Sensors that reside in the original Cabinet will beupdated to the new Cabinet.dcTrack will retrieve the Position on initial integration. Once integrated updates are bi-directional.Sensor PositionNote: The presence of a value in the dcTrack X,Y,Z sensor field will map to Outside Air on Power IQ.When pulling data from Power IQ, Outside Air will update the Sensor X,Y,Z field to 0,0,0.Outlet Read-Readings for Measured Amps and Actual Watts are always pulled from Power IQ.ingsSensor Read-Value is always pulled from Power IQ.ings

Once you integrate dcTrack with one or more Power IQs, the information is automatically synced between the twoapplications as long as the Integration checkbox remained selected for the Power IQ on the Power IQ IntegrationSettings page.After dcTrack and Power IQ data is synced, all assets should be added, updated and deleted from dcTrack.The following classes are supported for integration between dcTrack and Power IQ:CabinetsDevicesNetwork and Probe (supported but are considered as Devices and Rack PDUs, respectively.Rack PDUsSee Item Classes and Subclasses for more information on each class).

Synchronization of Outlet Names for integrated Rack PDUs has been enhanced in dcTrack version 7.0.0.When Rack PDUs are initially integrated, the Outlet names from Power IQ are pushed to dcTrack. Once integrated,any changes to Outlet Names on Power IQ are automatically pushed to dcTrack. Similarly changes to Outlet (Port)Names on dcTrack are automatically pushed to Power IQ. This includes changes to Port Names that result from PortConnections when the Auto Update Rack PDU Inlet and Outlet Name feature is enabled. For additional informationSee Auto Update Rack PDU Inlet and Outlet Names.Note: When a Rack PDU is added in dcTrack, the port information is derived from its Model. Once integrated withPower IQ, the ports are updated to match the ports in Power IQ. In some cases this will result in additional portsbeing added to the Rack PDU on dcTrack. These ports are added without values for connector, phase, volts, amps,phase legs, breaker and breaker amps resulting in the Event Log message "<PDU Name> Power Port Outlet xxindex xx was added but requires additional information because it is not in the dcTrack model <model name>". Torectify this issue, you must manually enter the data for the newly added ports.

Both Rack PDUs and Rack UPS can be fully integrated with Power IQ. Once integrated Power IQ will provide thereadings unique to each object.1. Add the Item making sure to fill in the Placement information2. Click Save to save the record3. Click on the Data Port sub tab4. Supply the RPDU's or Rack UPS IP Address6. Click on the SNMP sub tab7. Supply the appropriate Rack PDU/Rack UPS CredentialsFor SNMP 2 complete the following fields:UsernamePasswordCommunity StringFor SNMP 3 complete the following fields:UsernameAuthorization LevelnoAuthNoPriv - requires no additional informationauthNoPriv requires the following:Authorization ProtocolAuthorization PasskeyauthPriv rquires the following:Authorization ProtocolAuthorization PasskeyPrivacy ProtocolPrivacy Passkey8. Click Save9. Click on the Sensors or Power Ports sub tab10. Click the Refresh button11. Sensors are now available12. If you are integrating a Rack UPS, once integrated a "Readings" subtab is added to the Item. This subtab con-tains the readings for the UPS load and readings for the battery from PIQ. This subtab is only available onintegrated Rack UPS.Note: One of the two options below should be used if dcTrack has a Probe item that is not integrated with Power IQAND Power IQ includes a PDU object related to the Probe already.1. If Power IQ has just the PDU (in the correct cabinet) and nothing that represents the IT asset side of theProbe. Do one of the following two choices:a. Delete the unintegrated PDU from Power IQ and then push the Probe via normal mechanismsb. Create an IT asset in Power IQ in the same cabinet as the PDU with Power IQ Integration is Disabled,then Enable Power IQ Integration and map the IT devices (using DMS or import)2. If Power IQ has both the PDU and the IT asset in the correct cabinet, then map the IT devices (using DMS orimport)You are able to get power and sensor readings from devices, rack PDUs, probes, UPS units, PDUs and Coolingunits. See Retrieve Retrieve Power and Sensor Readings.Power and sensor readings are displayed on item pages on the Power - n Port tab and Sensor - n Port tab, respect-ively.These readings are also used to calculate information on the dcTrack Web Client Dashboard, as well as on the floormap and in reports.Readings are pulled from Power IQ when dcTrack/Power IQ integration is enabled for one or more Power IQ sites.For information on integrating dcTrack and Power IQ, see Integrate with One or Multiple Power IQs.If Power IQ integration is disabled, items must be configured manually in dcTrack to get readings. See ManuallyConfigure dcTrack Items to Get Readings from One or More Items.

How readings are retrieved and, therefore, how items sending readings are configured, depends on if you are integ-rated with Power IQ or using dcTrack as a standalone product.If you are integrated with Power IQ, the following must be met in order to get power and sensor readings from items -Item Supports SNMPThe item is capable of reporting data over SNMP.Power Integration EnabledYou must be integrated with Power IQ. The Enable Power IQ Integration feature must be enabled on thedcTrack > Appliance Settings page.Sync Sensors and/or Get ReadingsSync one or more sensor ports, and/or get readings for power ports.Sync individual ports from the item's page, or use the Get Readings function in the Web Client on the FloorMaps page to sync multiple readings at once. See Sync Multiple Ports at the Same Time.Note that the item must be powered on in order to get readings.

If you are not integrated with Power IQ, you will not be able to retrieve power or sensor readings.Note: Get Readings must be clicked in order to retrieve power readings; readings are not automatically retrieved bydcTrack.

Add IP addresses and community strings to data ports, if they are not already added.Note: These steps demonstrate adding IP addresses and community strings to an item's data port manually.However, you can assign IP addresses and community strings to multiple items at once using the File Import. SeeBulk Updating/Adding Rack PDU and Probe IP Addresses Using the File Import.1. In the Web Client open the item's page.2. Create power and/or sensor ports on the item, if needed. See Creating and Managing Ports.3. For power readings:a. Open the Power - n Ports tab, enter any required information that is needed such as budgeted AMPs, name-plate watts and so on.b. Click Get Readings to get a new reading. Note that power readings are not real-time; you must click GetReadings to get the most current reading.4. For sensor readings:a. On the Sensor-Ports tab of the item's page, provide the IP address and SNMP community string. For moreinformation, see Assigning IP Addresses to Data Ports and Port Teaming.b. Click Sync Sensors to get a reading from the item. Note that the item must be powered on in order to get areading from it.To sync multiple sensor ports at the same time, for example if you bulk imported items with all required informationsuch as an IP address and SNMP community string, see Sync Multiple Ports at the Same Time.

Rather than sync ports individually, you can sync all ports at once.If you are integrated with Power IQ, use the Get Readings feature on the Web Client floor map to sync multiple itemsat the same time in order to retrieve sensor and/or power information.1. In the Web Client, click Visualization to open the Floor Maps page. Note that you must have a drawing asso-ciated with the location in order to run floor map reports.2. Select the data center location from the Location drop-down.The floor map for the site opens and contains the items you want to synch.3. Select Reports.4. Depending on the sensor or power reading, select the appropriate report "Temperature Fronts", "TemperatureBacks" or "Measured Amps".5. Click Get Readings in the "Reports Legend and Data" panel to synch all of the readings in the entire data center.The report you selected displays the readings once they are collected.

Sensor Integration in dcTrack version 7.0.0 has been improved to provide additional bi-directional support.For integrated Rack PDUs, updates to Sensor Name, Cabinet and Position in dcTrack, are automatically pushed toPower IQ.From Power IQ, in addition to pushing updates to Sensor Name to dcTrack, updates to Sensor Location and SensorCabinet are also pushed to dcTrack.See the table below for Position Settings mapping.Inlet Top N/A Top FrontInlet Middle N/A Mid FrontInlet Bottom N/A Bottom FrontOutlet Top N/A Top RearOutlet Middle N/A Mid RearOutlet Bottom N/A Bottom RearOutside Air N/A N/A X,Y,Z - Value set to 0,0,0If the Cabinet of a Rack PDU Item is modified, any Sensor residing in the same Cabinet will also be moved to thenew Cabinet. For example if the Rack PDU is in Cabinet 1 and has three sensors. Sensor 1 located in Cabinet 2,Sensor 2 located in Cabinet 1 and Sensor 3 also located in Cabinet 2. If the Rack PDU is moved to Cabinet 3, the InCabinet for Sensor 2 will also be modified to Cabinet 3. The other Sensors would not be affected by the change.

dcTrack 9.0.0 has streamlined the process of Decommissioning Items integrated with Power IQ. In dcTrack 9.0.0and beyond integrated Rack PDUs and IT Devices can only be decommissioned from dcTrack. The items in bothsystems will reflect the Decommissioned status, and the Power IQ items will remain associated with the Cabinetsthey resided in prior to the Decommission. Sensors in Rack PDUs will also remain associated with the cabinet andexternally placed sensors will retain their information. IP addresses will also no longer be removed. For additionalinformation on Decommissioning Items, refer to Put Items in Storage - Decommission Item to Storage Request orArchive Items - Decommission Item to Archive Request.The Data Model Sync feature will display a new status for decommissioned Items. dcTrack items will display either"Integrated/Archived" or "Integrated/Storage" depending on how they were decommissioned and Power IQ Itemswill display as "Integrated/Decommissioned". If you do not want Decommissioned Items to appear at all on the DataModel Sync page, you can select the "Hide Decommissioned Items" option from the Action Menu.Note, Items in dcTrack that are not yet integrated, will only be allowed to "Map" to a Power IQ Item if they are in thesame state (Decommissioned or In Service).

dcTrack allows you to:Delete a Power IQThis is done on the Power IQ Integration Settings page in the Web ClientDeleting a Power IQ removes the Power IQ completely from dcTrack.The sites associated with the Power IQ are not deleted, but the connection is broken because the IP address is nolonger associated with site once the Power IQ is deleted.Disable IntegrationDeselect the Enable Integration checkbox on the Power IQ Integration Settings page in the Web ClientThis stops syncing between dcTrack and the Power IQ.Any data you enter into dcTrack after you deselect Enable Integration for a Power IQ and save is no longer pushedto the Power IQ.Note: When dcTrack and Power IQ are no longer integrated, data is no longer pushed to Power IQ from dcTrack. Ifyou reestablish the integration at a later time, it is important you use the "Sync" feature to synchronize databetween Power IQ and dcTrack. This ensures dcTrack and the Power IQ are in sync.dcTrack provides a Data Model Sync feature for a consolidated view of dcTrack and Power IQ integration. The DataModel Sync feature is accessible from the Settings menu>Data Model SyncThe Data Model Sync page is organized into two tree views: dcTrack on the left and Power IQ on the right.A Refresh button is available to update the views with the objects in the respective Enterprise Data Model (EDM)hierarchies, the object type, and integration status of the objects. To search/filter the views, click in the search barand specify your search criteria based on the table below.The Search feature allows you to search and filter the respective views by the following criteria:Data ModelSearch for objects containing the specified text in their names throughout the enterprise (bothNamedcTrack and Power IQs).dcTrack Name Search for objects containing the specified text in their names throughout dcTrack.dcTrack Type Search for objects containing the selected type throughout dcTrack.Search for objects containing the selected integration status throughout dcTrack. Available statusesinclude the following:dcTrack (Integ-ration) StatusAdd in Bulk: For objects added from Power IQ that are incomplete and require addi-tional configuration. Typically require assignment of make and model. Origin column inItems List will be set to Added in Bulk Incomplete for easy search and filtering of thelist.Added via Power IQ: For objects added from Power IQ that are incomplete and requireadditional configuration. Typically require assignment of make and model.In dcTrack Only: For objects that exist in dcTrack only.Incorrect Parent: For integrated objects for which the parent is not consistent acrossdcTrack and Power IQ.Integrated: For integrated objects.Integrated/Archived: For integrated objects that have been archived in dcTrack.Integrated/Storage: For integrated objects that have been placed into storage indcTrack.Integration Error: For objects where an integration error has been detected. Will typ-ically require unmapping and re-mapping or sync.Unassociated: For locations that are in dcTrack and not associated with any Power IQ.Unmapped: For objects that are currently isolated to dcTrack.Unmapped/Archived: For objects that are currently isolated to dcTrack and have beenarchived in dcTrack.Unmapped/Storage: For objects that are currently isolated to dcTrack and have beenplaced into storage in dcTrack.Power IQ Name Search for objects containing the specified text in their names throughout Power IQ.Power IQ Type Search for objects containing the selected type throughout Power IQ.Search for objects containing the selected integration status throughout Power IQ. Available statusesinclude the following:Add in Bulk: For objects added from Power IQ that are incomplete and require addi-tional configuration. Typically require assignment of make and model. Origin column inItems List will be set to Added in Bulk Incomplete for easy search and filtering of thelist.Added via Power IQ: For objects added from Power IQ that are incomplete and requirePower IQ (Integ-additional configuration. Typically require assignment of make and model.ration) StatusIn Power IQ Only: For objects that exist in Power IQ only.Incorrect Parent: For integrated objects for which the parent is not consistent acrossdcTrack and Power IQ.Integrated: For integrated objects.Integrated/Decommissioned: For integrated objects that have been decommissionedin dcTrack. When IT Devices and Rack PDU objects are decommissioned in dcTrack,their status changes to 'Incorrect Parent' because they remain associated with aCabinet in PIQ, even though the Cabinet field in dcTrack is clearedIntegration Error: For objects where an integration error has been detected. Will typ-ically require unmapping and re-mapping or sync.Note: Only those object types that are common to both dcTrack and Power IQ are included in the view.An Actions menu allows selection of available actions to take on the selected objects in the views.Used to create a mapping between an object In dcTrack Only and In Power IQ Only toindicate that they are the same object.Also used to allow integration for dcTrack objects currently Unmapped (Isolated) fromPower IQ in subsequent sync operations.MapThe Map action will not be enabled for data centers that are in "Legacy" mode. Please readthe description of the action Enable Full Integration Mode for details of switching to full integ-ration mode.Used to add objects that are In Power IQ Only to dcTrack.You will be brought to the details pages for the locations or assets selected. TheAddrequired data can be provided to complete and save the objects.Used to add objects that are In Power IQ Only to dcTrack.Objects are added to dcTrack and can be exported from the items list to add the makeAdd in Bulkand model and then to be reimported in bulk. The Origin column in the Items List will beset to Added in Bulk Incomplete for easy search and filtering of the list.Used to edit objects that are Added via Power IQ or Add in Bulk to dcTrack.Objects that are added directly in Power IQ will require additional information inEditdcTrack. You will be brought to the details pages for the locations or assets selectedwhere additional edits can be made.Used to perform a sync operation on the selected object and its children.Can be used for objects that are Integrated, have an Incorrect Parent, or are In dcTrackSyncOnly.Used to remove an existing mapping between an Integrated object in dcTrack and anobject in Power IQ. Will isolate the object in dcTrack.UnmapAlso used to isolate objects in dcTrack that are In dcTrack Only or have an Incorrect Par-ent.Starting with dcTrack 6.0, dcTrack will integrate rows and aisles with Power IQ.Enable FullIntegrationFor customers who upgraded from a version dcTrack prior to 6.0, their data centers will be inModeLegacy Mode, and rows and aisles will remain unintegrated.In order to move out of Legacy Mode into Full Integration mode, a single data center shouldbe selected (no children) and then action Enable Full Integration mode will be enabled.After selecting this action, the system will do analysis to determine what changes to aisles androws are needed, both within Power IQ and dcTrack.
