Carefully read any warnings shownbefore clicking proceed.Review the result of the changes to aisles and rows to make sure they are to your satisfaction.If so, the data center should be selected (no children) and the Sync action should be selected.This will make sure that any cabinets that are not in the proper row or aisle in Power IQ aremoved to match the hierarchy in dcTrack.Used to perform a sync operation on the selected object specific to the make and modelof newly added items from Power IQ.Sync MakeIf newly discovered makes and models are not found in the Models Library, the user hasand Modelthe opportunity to match or add them via a wizard.Can be used to add makes and models to the Models Library and Item Details pages ofnewly added assets.A Power IQ Appliance selector allows you to select the Power IQ to be displayed in the view.The dcTrack Object Details section provides a summary of details for the object selected in the dcTrack view.If the object has power connections, the ports and connected to item and port are displayed below the details sec-tion.The Power IQ Object Details section provides a summary of details for the object selected in the Power IQ view.If the object has outlet associations, the connected to items are displayed below the details section.Note: If there are newly discovered makes and models not currently in the Models Library that need to be matchedor added, the wizard to map/add these new makes and models will display.

If you have integrated dcTrack with Power IQ, upload your floor map drawing files in dcTrack - do not upload them inPower IQ any longer.When you upload your floor map drawing file to dcTrack, it is automatically pushed to Power IQ in the same wayother data is when the applications are integrated.

The CMDB Connector allows data to be exchanged between dcTrack and any other CMDB application that providespublic REST APIs. The dcTrack Universal Connector and the ServiceNow Connector provide the ability to createAssets on the CMDB system which can be inserted automatically on dcTrack, additionally, the ServiceNow Con-nector provides the ability to create assets on dcTrack that are automatically inserted on ServiceNow. Both Con-nectors support bi-directional updates.dcTrack version 7.2.0 and beyond support integrating a single ServiceNow Instance to multiple dcTracks. This isfacilitated through the new certified Sunbird DCIM Connector application available through the ServiceNow Applic-ation store (see Configuring the Sunbird Connector in ServiceNow). Once the new Connector application isinstalled, users will be allowed to create any number of dcTrack configurations, each pointing to a different dcTrack7.2.0 or later instance. If you chose to continue to support a one-to-one relationship between dcTrack and Ser-viceNow, no additional changes are required to your current configuration, however if you would like to integrate withmultiple dcTracks you need only create additional configurations for each instance supplying the same few para-meters to identify each dcTrack instance. When integrated with multiple dcTrack instances, the DCIM Connectorapplication automatically associates the individual field mappings, Locations and filters specific to each dcTrackinstance to the correct dcTrack.System Administrators can configure the CMDB Connector under the Settings > dcTrack Settings > Integrations >Asset & CMDB.Note: You must perform the following steps in each dcTrack instance you wish to integrate.To configure the CMDB Connector:1. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Integrations > Asset & CMDB2. Click the "Add" button to View the Gallery of available Connectors3. Select the desired Connector from the Gallery. This will open the Add an Asset & CMDB Integration dialog.4. Provide the data for the following fields:a. Type: The Application you are integrating with. This will be automatically populated based on the con-nector selected from the gallery, but can be changed in this dialog.b. Label: The name used to identify this connector. (Required)c. IP Address/Hostname: The IP Address or Hostname that should be used to establish a connection tothe CMDB server. (Required)d. Username: A valid user name for the Service Account on the CMDB server to be used for authen-tication and Audit tracking on the CMDB. (Required)e. Password: The password associated with the Service Account in the previous field. (Required)f. Auto-sync Username: The valid login name of the dcTrack Service Account that will be used when log-ging audit records generated as a result of a pull operation on dcTrack. The minimum role required bythis user is Gatekeeper. (Required)5. Check the Enable Integration checkbox. When enabled, items will be integrated between dcTrack and theCMDB database based on the Field Mappings and Filters specified in the configuration XML.6. Click the Save button to save your settings. This will open the Configuration section of the page.7. In the Configuration section of the page, enter the appropriate XML required to make the API calls. This XMLis used to define the field and value mappings, filters, and any other rules required to manage the dataexchange between dcTrack and CMDB.a. You can upload an existing XML file, by clicking the Load from File button and using the browser dialogto select the XML file.b. You can enter the XML directly into the provided text box.c. To save the XML to a local file, click the Save to File button.5. To test the connection between dcTrack and the remote server using the information supplied on the screenclick the Test Connection button.6. Click the Save icon to save the configuration. If any of the required fields are not completed, the Save buttonwill not be enabled.Note: This option is only enabled if all required fields have been supplied, including the .xml file.7. If you are integrating with ServiceNow, you must also configure the Sunbird DCIM Connector on your Ser-viceNow instance. Please see the help on Configuring the DCIM Connector in ServiceNow for additionalinstructions.Note: If integration is disabled, updates performed on dcTrack will not be pushed to the external application.Upon re-enabling integration users must save the updated records individually to trigger the push.For assistance configuring the dcTrack Ticketing Connector or the Sunbird DCIM Connector in ServiceNow, pleasecontact Sunbird Technical Support at tech@sunbirddcim.com or via the Sunbird Support Portal.

The Sunbird DCIM Connector is now available as a Certified App through the ServiceNow App Store. This singleconnector works in conjunction with the dcTrack's CMDB connector, Ticketing Connector or both to provide all theinformation required to exchange Asset and Ticket data seamlessly between dcTrack and ServiceNow.dcTrack version 9.2.0 has enhanced its CMDB integration with ServiceNow. In addition to its current ability to integ-rate with ServiceNow Hardware Assets, the ServiceNow Connector will now also integrate with ServiceNow CItables. This integration supports bi-directional Inserts and Updates of mapped fields between dcTrack and Ser-viceNow as well as support for CI Relationships. In addition to the CI support, the ServiceNow Connector can nowcreate missing Models on ServiceNow when a new item is pushed to ServiceNow, making it easier to normalizeModels between dcTrack and ServiceNow.For additional information, please refer to the following documents:Steps to Configure the CMDB CI and Asset Connector on dcTrack - Instructions for setting up CMDB integrationsSteps To Configure the Ticketing Connector on dcTrack- Instructions for setting up Ticketing integrationsSteps To Configure the Request Connector on dcTrack- Instructions for setting up integrations triggered fromdcTrack Workflow (Requests and Work Orders)To configure the Sunbird Connector:1. Download and Install the Sunbird dcTrack DCIM Connector.2. Once the application is installed you can search for it by typing “dcTrack” in the ServiceNow Filter Navigator.3. Open the application by clicking the “Settings” menu option under the “Sunbird dcTrack DCIM Connector”menu item.4. Provide the data for the following fields:dcTrack IP Address/Host Name: The IP Address or Host Name of the dcTrack instance you wish tointegrate with. (Required)dcTrack Username: The user name of the Service Account on dcTrack to be used for authentication. Itis required that you use an account with at least the Gatekeeper role specifically designated for integ-ration. (Required)dcTrack Password: The password for the dcTrack Service Account. (Required)ServiceNow Mid Server Name: If running dcTrack from a public IP Address or the Cloud, specify thename of the MID server to be used to facilitate communication and the movement of data between Ser-viceNow and dcTrack.ServiceNow Username: The user name of the Service Account on ServiceNow that will be used forAudit tracking. (Required)Active: Selector used to enable or disable the Connector.5. Once all of the required fields have been supplied, use the “Test Connection” button to verify that ServiceNowis able to communicate with dcTrack.6. If your test connection is successful, you must click the Update button to save your settings.Note: If integration is disabled (Active is not checked), any updates performed will not be pushed to dcTrack. Uponre-enabling integration users must save the updated records individually to trigger the push to dcTrack.For assistance configuring the dcTrack CMDB Connector or the Sunbird DCIM Connector in ServiceNow, pleasecontact Sunbird Technical Support at tech@sunbirddcim.com or via the Sunbird Support Portal.Two additional columns are available on the Item Details List, "Valid" and "Reconciled". These columns are notincluded in the default system view, but they may be selected for viewing by clicking the Show/Hide Columns iconlocated at the far right of the Item Detail grid.These columns are only applicable to Integrated Items. They are set when an Item is added to dcTrack via Integ-ration. The table below illustrates the conditions for setting these values.If dcTrack is able to validate every field with an exact match.1. Exact matchYes Yeson everyThe record is successfully added to dcTrack and no furtherfieldaction is required on the Item.If dcTrack is able to validate every field however a BestMatch was used for one or more fields.Yes No2. Best MatchThe record must be reviewed and Reconciled by the User.If dcTrack could not validate one or more field values andcould not find a Best Match, or a required field value is miss-No No3. Invalid Dataing.The record must be corrected and then Reconciled.

For Integrated Items that are in a "Valid" / "Reconciled" state, the item Detail page will look like any other Item. ForItems that are in an "Invalid" or "Not Reconciled" state, field highlighting is used to reflect the condition of each field.Fields highlighted Green indicate the value in the dcTrack field is an exact match with the value supplied by the integ-rated system.Fields highlighted Yellow indicate dcTrack did not find a value that matches the value supplied by the integrated sys-tem exactly, but has suggested a value that is a likely match.Fields highlighted Red indicate dcTrack was either not able to find an Exact or Best match, or the field supplied bythe integrated system was blank.Hovering over any field will display the original value supplied by the integrated system. Red highlighted fields mustbe corrected and saved before any further processing can occur on the Item. Yellow highlighted fields should bereviewed to ensure dcTrack's suggested value is acceptable.Since the dcTrack Class field is optional and does not have to be mapped in the cmdb config. When pushing data todcTrack, the following rules are applied:1. Any Time the mapped Model exists on dcTrack, the Class will be derived from the Model2. If the Model does not exist but the mapped Class is a valid dcTrack Class, an Incomplete record will be cre-ated using the mapped Class..3. If the Model does not exist and the Class is either invalid or not mapped at all, an incomplete record will be cre-ated and its Class will default to "Device". When the record is corrected its Class will be updated to the Classof the specified Model.Note: There will be some cases where the Model used to correct the record is of a Class that can not be changedfrom "Device". The Model used to correct the record in these cases must be one of Data Panel, Rack PDU or Probe.If the model used to update the record is not one these Classes the record will have to be deleted, the informationcorrected and pushed to dcTrack again.After correcting any red highlighted fields and reviewing any yellow highlighted fields, the final step is to Reconcilethe Item. Reconciling indicates you have verified the field values and acknowledge the data is correct. The Recon-cile button is not displayed for Items that are in a " Valid"/"Reconciled" state, and is disabled for "Invalid" Items. Oncean Item has been Reconciled, all field highlighting is removed.Note: As indicated above, processing is prohibited on "Invalid" Items. While processing is allowed on Items that arein a "Valid"/"Not Reconciled" state, it is not recommended.

1. Open the Item in the Item Details page.2. If the Item is "Invalid", click the Edit button to allow editing and correct the data.3. After the data has been corrected, click Save to save your changes.Note: If the Item is "Valid" but not yet "Reconciled" you can skip steps 2 and 3.4. Once the Item is successfully saved, the Reconcile button will become enabled.5. Click the Reconcile button (this will enable the Save button).6. Click the Save button to complete the transaction.For Items integrated with CMDB, fields where "cmdb" is defined as the System of Record at the field level are dis-abled on the Asset Detail page. Updates to these fields must be performed from the CMDB application. Thisincludes both Standard and Custom fields.Note: Fields that inherit "cmdb" from the Default System of Record in the Preferences section of the CMDB con-figuration file are not disabled.

dcTrack Ticketing Connectors allows data to be exchanged between dcTrack and any other Ticketing applicationthat provides public REST APIs. The dcTrack Ticketing Connectors provide the ability to create Tickets on theexternal application which can be inserted automatically on dcTrack, as well as creating Tickets on dcTrack andautomatically generating the Ticket on the external application. All Ticketing Connectors also support bi-directionalupdates with the ability to specify whether the data in each field is owned by dcTrack, the external system or both.If you are integrating with ServiceNow, you must install the enhanced Sunbird DCIM connector (v1.1.0) availablefrom the ServiceNow App Store. This new version is designed to manage both Assets and Tickets and can be con-figured to integrate a single ServiceNow instance with multiple dcTracks. For additional information on configuringthe Connector on ServiceNow, please see Configuring the Sunbird Connector in ServiceNow.System Administrators can configure Ticketing Connectors under the Settings > dcTrack Settings > Integrations >Ticketing.Note: You must perform the following steps in each dcTrack instance you wish to integrate.To configure the Ticketing Connector:1. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Integrations > Ticketing2. Click the "Add" button to View the Gallery of available Connectors3. Select the desired Connector from the Gallery. This will open the Add a Ticketing Integration dialog.4. Provide the data for the following fields:a. Type: The Application you are integrating with. This will be automatically populated based on the con-nector selected from the gallery, but can be changed in this dialog.b. External System: The name used to identify this connector. (Required)c. IP Address/Hostname: The IP Address or Hostname that should be used to establish a connection tothe Ticketing application. (Required)d. Username: A valid user name for the Service Account on the Ticketing application to be used forauthentication and Audit tracking on the external system. (Required)e. Password: The password associated with the Service Account in the previous field. (Required)f. Auto-sync Username: The valid login name of the dcTrack Service Account that will be used when log-ging audit records generated as a result of a pull operation on dcTrack. The minimum role required bythis user is Gatekeeper. (Required)5. Check the Enable Integration checkbox. When enabled, items will be integrated between dcTrack and theTicketing database based on the Field Mappings and Filters specified in the configuration XML.6. Click the Save button to save your settings. This will open the Configuration section of the page.7. In the Configuration section of the page, enter the appropriate XML required to make the API calls. This XMLis used to define the field and value mappings, filters, and any other rules required to manage the dataexchange between dcTrack and the external application.a. You can upload an existing XML file, by clicking the Load from File button and using the browser dialogto select the XML file.b. You can enter the XML directly into the provided text box.c. To save the XML to a local file, click the Save to File button.5. To test the connection between dcTrack and the remote server using the information supplied on the screenclick the Test Connection button.6. Click the Save icon to save the configuration. If any of the required fields are not completed, the Save buttonwill not be enabled.Note: This option is only enabled if all required fields have been supplied, including the .xml file.7. If you are integrating with ServiceNow, you must also configure the Sunbird DCIM Connector on your Ser-viceNow instance. Please see the help on Configuring the DCIM Connector in ServiceNow for additionalinstructions.Note: If integration is disabled, updates performed on dcTrack will not be pushed to the external application.Upon re-enabling integration users must save the updated records individually to trigger the push.For assistance configuring the dcTrack Ticketing Connector or the Sunbird DCIM Connector in ServiceNow, pleasecontact Sunbird Technical Support at tech@sunbirddcim.com or via the Sunbird Support Portal.

The VMware Connector in dcTrack helps users need identify and track server resources supporting VMware virtualmachines. It leverages the vSphere SDK API to enable the discovery of your virtualized environment by dcTrack,including clusters, hosts, and VMs.VMware is the system of record for integrated clusters, hosts and VMs, and synchronizing with the VM Manager willupdate dcTrack to reflect any changes in VMware. dcTrack also retains the history and audit log of changes.To use the VMware Connector to manage VMs:Define VM Managers in dcTrack by provisioning a vCenter server or ESXi host. See Provisioning a vCenterServer or ESXi Host.Associate One or More VM Managers with Locations. See Associating One or More VM Managers with aLocation.Sync your VM Managers with dcTrack using VMware Inventory Sync. See VMware Inventory Sync.When your dcTrack database is synced to a VM Manager, you're able to view the VM Manager integration statusand other virtualization attributes, such as CPU and RAM, on the Item Details pages for virtual assets.To make it faster and easier to keep the dcTrack database updated, System Administrators can schedule a dailyautomatic sync. Data can also be synced on demand.Note: If a host is not associated with a vm manager dcTrack allows users to manually maintain the list of related vir-tual machines/clusters. Once integrated with a vm manager, it can only be done via the integration and users will nolonger be allowed to make those changes manually.

To integrate dcTrack with one or more vCenter servers or ESXi hosts, you first need to define the vCenter Servers orESXi hosts in dcTrack. The list of associated vCenter servers and ESXi hosts can be found under the Settings tab >dcTrack Settings > Application Administration Integration > VMware sub-tab.The VMware sub-tab displays the following information:VM Manager Name: Name of the VM Manager.URL/Hostname: The IP address or hostname of the VM Manager.Username: The username for accessing the VM Manager.Password: The password associated with the username for accessing the VM Manager.Autosync Username: A valid dcTrack username with the System Administrator role or above. Used for log-ging changes in the audit log and for role-based access control.Daily Auto Sync: When scheduled, will display the daily time when the auto-sync action will be run. By default,this is unscheduled.Version: Automatically populates with the version of the vCenter server or ESXi host.Default Location: Single-select dropdown list of locations the VM Manager is associated with so you canselect the default location of the VM Manager.Last Sync: Provides the status, date, and time of the last sync action.Enable Integration: Check/uncheck the Enable Integration checkbox to enable integration.To define a vCenter server or ESXi host as a VM Manager:1. Click the Settings tab > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration > Integration Settings > VMware sub-tab.2. In the VMware sub-tab, click the Add button to add a VM Manager (vCenter Server or ESXi host).3. Provide the following information:a. VM Manager Name: Name of the VM Manager. Required.b. URL/Hostname: The IP address or hostname of the VM Manager. Required.c. Username: The username for accessing the VM Manager. Required.d. Password: The password associated with the username for accessing the VM Manager. Required.e. Autosync Username: A valid dcTrack username with the System Administrator role or above. Usedfor logging changes in the audit log and for role-based access control. Required.f. Daily Auto Sync: When scheduled, will display the daily time when the auto-sync action will be run.By default, this is unscheduled. Click in the Daily Auto Sync cell to specify the time when you wantthe sync to run each day.g. Version: The version of the vCenter server or ESXi host.h. Default Location: Single-select dropdown of all locations with assets. When selected, it will displaythe default location of the VM Manager. Required.i. Last Sync: Provides the status, date, and time of the last sync action.j. Enable Integration: Check/uncheck the Enable Integration checkbox to enable integration.4. Click the Save button to save your new VM Manager and return to the list of VM Managers.

To make changes to the VM Manager attributes:1. Click the cell in the list of VM Managers that you want to edit.2. Make your desired changes.3. Click the Save button to save your changes.Alternatively, view the VM Manager Details in Edit mode:1. From the list of VM Managers, select the VM Manager you want to edit.2. Click the Edit icon to enter Edit mode.3. Make your desired changes.4. Click the Save button to save your changes.To delete a VM Manager from the list of VM Managers:1. From the list of VM Managers, select the VM Manager you want to delete.2. Click the Delete button.The VM Manager will be removed from the list.Note: You can only delete one VM Manager at a time.

To enable dcTrack to be synchronized with your virtualization environment, you must associate at least one VM Man-ager with a Location in dcTrack.System Administrators can associate a VM Manager with a Location under the Assets tab > Locations page.To associate a VM Manager with a Location in the Locations list:1. In the Asset tab > Locations list, click the VM Manager cell for the Location you want to associate the VM Man-ager with.2. Select your desired VM Manager from the dropdown. You can select more than one VM Manager per Loca-tion.Alternatively, you can select a VM Manager on the Location Details page:1. In the Asset tab > Locations list, select a Location.2. Click the Edit link to open the Location Details page in Edit mode.3. In the Settings panel, select your desired VM Manager from the VM Manager dropdown.System Administrators can schedule an automatic daily sync to keep their dcTrack databases up to date, without ini-tiating a manual on-demand sync.A daily sync can be scheduled for each VM Manager in the Settings tab > dcTrack Settings > Application Admin-istration > Integrations > VMware sub-tab.The daily sync must be scheduled for a specific VM Manager in order for the sync to occur. System Administratorscan specify the hour when the sync for that VM Manager's entire asset inventory takes place by clicking the DailyAuto Sync dropdown. If the VM Manager's daily sync is set to Unscheduled, no daily sync occurs.

At that time, all assets managed by the VM Manager would be either updated or added. This action is independentof the default location; however, all newly discovered hosts will be added in the default location. Newly discoveredVMs would be added in the same location as the associated VM host. Clusters are added without a location. Thetime is based on the local time zone as specified in the Appliance Settings page.To schedule a daily auto-sync when creating a new VM Manager:1. Click the Settings tab > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration > Integration Settings > VMware sub-tab.2. In the VMware sub-tab, click the Add button to add a VM Manager (vCenter Server or ESXi host).3. Provide the following information:a. VM Manager Name: Name of the VM Manager. Required.b. URL/Hostname: The IP address or hostname of the VM Manager. Required.c. Username: The username for accessing the VM Manager. Required.d. Password: The password associated with the username for accessing the VM Manager. Required.e. Autosync Username: A valid dcTrack username with the System Administrator role or above. Usedfor logging changes in the audit log and for role-based access control. Required.f. Daily Auto Sync: When scheduled, will display the daily time when the auto-sync action will be run.By default, this is unscheduled. Click in the Daily Auto Sync cell to specify the time when you wantthe sync to run each day.g. Version: The version of the vCenter server or ESXi host.h. Default Location: Single-select dropdown of all locations with assets. When selected, it will displaythe default location of the VM Manager. Required.i. Last Sync: Provides the status, date, and time of the last sync action.j. Enable Integration: Check/uncheck the Enable Integration checkbox to enable integration.4. Click the Save button to save your new VM Manager and return to the list of VM Managers.

To schedule a daily auto-sync for an existing VM Manager:1. Click the Settings tab > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration > Integration Settings > VMware sub-tab.2. Click in the Daily Auto Sync cell to specify from the dropdown the time when you want the sync to run eachday.3. Click the Save button to save your changes.Alternatively, view the VM Manager Details in Edit mode:1. Click the Settings tab > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration > Integration Settings > VMware sub-tab.2. From the list of VM Managers, select the VM Manager you want to edit.3. Click the Edit icon to enter Edit mode.4. In the Daily Auto Sync field, specify from the dropdown the time when you want the sync to run each day.5. Click the Save button to save your changes.To unschedule a daily auto-sync, specify the Unscheduled option from the Daily Auto Sync dropdown:1. Click the Settings tab > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration > Integration Settings > VMware sub-tab.2. Click in the Daily Auto Sync cell to specify the Unscheduled option from the dropdown.3. Click the Save button to save your changes.Alternatively, view the VM Manager Details in Edit mode:1. Click the Settings tab > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration > Integration Settings > VMware sub-tab.2. From the list of VM Managers, select the VM Manager you want to edit.3. Click the Edit icon to enter Edit mode.4. In the Daily Auto Sync field, specify the Unscheduled option from the dropdown.5. Click the Save button to save your changes.

The status of the last sync, its date, and its time are captured in the Last Sync column in the VM Managers list in theVMware sub-tab. The VM Manager Status Update Date in the Assets tab > Items List also provides the date andtime of the last status update.Possible last sync statuses include:Success: Sync completed successfullyFailure: dcTrack could not connect to the VM Manager, experienced a database issue, or other issue that pre-vented the sync from completing successfullyCompleted with Errors: Sync completed with issues with syncing individual assetsMore details are displayed in a tooltip when hovering over the status on the VM Managers list in the VMware sub-tab.Once the VM manager is associated, you can sync its associated hosts, clusters, and VMs with dcTrack.Access the VMware Inventory Sync page under Settings > VMware Inventory Sync. Objects in dcTrack display onthe left in a tree view, and clusters, hosts, and VMs in the VM manager display on the right. Select the VM Managerthat you would like to sync using the VM Manager dropdown in the right corner.To sync a cluster, host, or VM with dcTrack, check the box(es) next to your desired objects. Then click the Actionsmenu > Sync.If the selected VM Manager is associated with more than one location, a popup will display prompting you to selectthe location where newly discovered assets will be stored. By default, the default location will be selected.Note: If there are newly discovered makes and models not currently in the Models Library that need to be matchedor added, the wizard to map/add these new makes and models will display.The objects will populate in dcTrack, and that status of the objects in VMware will update accordingly. When an itemis selected, its object details will display in the bottom left or right panel respectively.The best practice for doing all adds and deletes via the VM infrastructure and then running the sync tool in dcTrack.When a VM move between Hosts and Clusters within the same VM Manager, dcTrack is during the next sync.However if VM move between different VM Manager, dcTrack will not be updated, potentially requiring manual inter-vention to prevent duplicate items in dcTrack.Note: When the VMware connector reports a "soap failure", it means the error originated from VMware and as suchneeds to be addressed by working with your VM team to troubleshoot the problem.

The following actions are supported by VMware Inventory Sync.Add Add an item to dcTrack from VMware.Map Associate an item in dcTrack to an item in VMware.Unmap Remove the association of an item in dcTrack from an item in VMware.Update one or more items in dcTrack that are currently associated with VMware. Can be at any pointSyncin hierarchy to include all child objects.Sync Make andAllows the user to match/add newly discovered makes and models for the items that have beenModeladded to dcTrack. Will display a popup with the wizard to map/add models.Breaks the integration with the VM manager. The status for the selected node and its child nodes willUnintegratebecome "In dcTrack Only".Edit an item has been discovered in VMware and added to dcTrack. The item configuration in dcTrackis incomplete due to unknown location, make or model.EditCan also be done in bulk by exporting items “Added via VMware”Note: Clusters, hosts, and VMs can also be added via item import/export.The following statuses are supported by VMware Inventory Sync:Integrated Items in dcTrack and VMware have consistent attributes and placement in hierarchy.In VMware Only Item does not have an associated asset in dcTrack.In dcTrack Only Item does not have an associated asset in VMware.Unmapped Item has been intentionally isolated to VMware to prevent its being added to dcTrack.Added viaItem has been discovered in VMware and added to dcTrack. The item configuration in dcTrack isVMwareincomplete due to unknown location, make or model.Incorrect ParentItem is currently associated with a different containing object in dcTrack, e.g. host is associated within dcTrackan unknown cluster.Not Found inItem is in dcTrack but was not found in VMware.VM ManagerThe VM Manager has not yet been associated to one or more locations. Go to the Assets tab > Loca-Location Unas-tions and associate the VM Manager (such as VMware ESX or vCenter Server) with a location. Thissociatedwill enable dcTrack to be synchronized with the virtualization environment.

Once a VM Manager has been provisioned, associated with a location, and synced through VMware Inventory Sync,users with the appropriate permissions can initiate an on-demand sync from the Configuration sub-tab of the ItemDetails pages of virtual assets of the Device class and Virtual Machine subclass.To initiate a sync for an associated VM Cluster:1. From the Item Details page, click the Edit button to enter Edit mode.2. Click the Configuration sub-tab.3. Click the Sync VM Cluster button.To initiate a sync for an associated VM Host:1. From the Item Details page, click the Edit button to enter Edit mode.2. Click the Configuration sub-tab.3. Click the Sync VM Host button.The sync progress bar will display along the bottom of the page, and a notification popup will indicate if the sync hasbeen completed successfully.Note: For the sync to occur, the virtual asset must have a VM cluster or VM host defined in the Configuration sub-tab and it must be integrated with a VM Manager. Otherwise, the Sync VM buttons will be disabled.

To delete a VMware cluster from dcTrack:1. Make sure the cluster is empty2. Go to Setings > Field Management > Pick List Choices3. Select Virtual Maching Cluster from the Field List4. Select the cluster you want to delete and click the Delete buttonNote: If the VMWare cluster has VMs or VM Hosts associated, the cluster can not be deletedFor specific instructions on how to integrate dcTrack and VMWare please refer to the documentation below that bestdescribes your installation:Integration with VMWare when VM Hosts exist in dcTrackIntegration with VMWare when VM Hosts do not exist in dcTrack

1. Navigate to Settings > VMWare Inventory Sync page2. Select the vCenter from the VM Manager drop down3. The VMWare data is loaded in the Right side panel. Since this data does not yet exist in dcTrack, all of theobjects will have a status of "In VMWare Only".4. Select the highest object in the hierarchy (usually a cluster) from the Right side panel.5. Click on the Action Menu and select the Sync optionIf there is more than one Cluster in your VMWare environment, you will have to perform a separate sync for eachcluster.If there are no Clusters in your VMWare environment and the highest object in the hierarchy is Host, perform theSync function for each host.6. The Sync Make and Model Wizard will be launched if there are VM Hosts with unknown Makes or Models.You will be presented with the best possible match in dcTrack for each unknown Make or Model. You caneither use the suggested Best Match, Add the Make or Model, or skip the item completely by selcting the cor-responding check box in the Select an Action column.For more information on the Sync Make and Model Wizard see Matching or Adding Makes and Models with the SyncMake and Model Wizard.7. Once you have matched or added the Makes and Models, click on the green arrow in the Wizard progress barto proceed.Note: If there are no unkown Makes and Models, the Sync Make and Model wizard is not displayed and theSync process will begin.8. You will be redirected to the VMWare Inventory Sync page and the process will begin. You can monitor theprogress of the operation via the progress bar displayed at the bottom of the page. A message is displayedonce the process is complete.Note: While the Sync is in progress, the buttons on the tool bar are disabled to prohibit any other Syncactions, however you may continue to perform other activities within dcTrack.9. Once the Sync operation is completed successfully, the left and right panels will be refreshed and display thedcTrack and VMware data. The status of each sync'd object is now Integrated.10. Once a parent object is sync'd all of its children objects are also sync'd.Note: If a host is not associated with a vm manager dcTrack allows users to manually maintain the list of related vir-tual machines/clusters. Once integrated with a vm manager, it can only be done via the integration and users will nolonger be allowed to make those changes manually.You can integrate existing dcTrack hosts to VMWare hosts by performing the Map action on the VMWare InventorySync page.Before performing the Map, verify the hosts in dcTrack are marked as VM Hosts so they will appear as candidatehosts on the VMWare Inventory Sync page and therefore eligible for mapping.In dcTrack Items belonging to the Device/Standard and Device/Blade classes can be marked as VM Hosts.Steps to mark an Item as a VM Host1. Navigate to the Items Detail page for the device2. On the Configuration tab, select the Is VM Host check box3. Click the Save button on the tool bar to save the item.Once a device is marked as a VM Host, it will appear on the dcTrack left side panel on the VMWare Inventory Syncpage and can be mapped to a host in VMWare.Steps to Map a dcTrack host to a VMWare host1. Navigate to Settings > VMWare Inventory Sync2. Select the VM Manager from the VM Manager drop down list in the top right corner of the page. Since theobjects in VMWare do not yet exist in dcTrack, their status will appear as In VMWare Only.3. Select the dcTrack host from the left panel and the VMWare host from the right panel that you wish to Mapand click the Map button on the tool bar.4. Repeat step 3 for each VM host you wish to integrate.If the hosts are associated with a Cluster in VMWare and the cluster does not exist in dcTrack, the status of themapped hosts will appear as Incorrect Parent. The status of these hosts will be changed to Integrated when yousync the VMWare cluster, which will automatically add the cluster to dcTrack.5. If the mapped hosts in VMWare are associated with a cluster, select the cluster and do a sync.Once the sync operation is complete, the cluster is added and all the virtual machines that are associated with thathost are pushed to dcTrack.If the mapped hosts in VMware are not associated with a cluster you can either sync each host one at a time orschedule an auto sync for that VM manager. Scheduling auto sync will integrate the hosts that are mapped andchange the status to integrated.Note: If a host is not associated with a vm manager dcTrack allows users to manually maintain the list of related vir-tual machines/clusters. Once integrated with a vm manager, it can only be done via the integration and users will nolonger be allowed to make those changes manually.

This section provides information on using dcTrack with asset management stripesAsset Management Sensors and dcTrack 1174Combine the Asset Sensors 1176Connect Asset Management Sensors to the EMX 1177Add the EMX or PX2 to dcTrack 1177Add the Asset Management Tagged Items to dcTrack 1177View Asset Sensor Event Information in dcTrack 1177You can remotely track the locations of up to 64 IT devices in a rack via asset sensors that are connected to either aSunbird EMX or PX2.The IT devices being track are tagged with asset tags.The asset tags use electronic IDs to identify IT device items. One end of the tag is adhered to an item and the otheris plugged in to the asset sensor.A Asset sensorB Asset tag(s) for the IT device(s)C IT device item in a rackThe asset sensors are connected to a EMX or PX2 and configured in them.Note: This image depicts a connection to an EMX-888 for example purposes only.Once asset sensors are connected and configured, they transmit the asset tag ID and positioning information to theEMX or PX2.You can add each item an asset tag is attached to dcTrack, and add the EMX or PX2 to dcTrack. If you provideSNMP information for the EMX or PX2, event information can be transmitted to dcTrack. Specifically, Power IQdetects when an asset tag is connected or disconnected from an asset strip. Power IQ then generates an connect ordisconnect event.When dcTrack polls Power IQ, the connect/disconnect events are pulled into dcTrack.The events are displayed on the Events page in the dcTrack Web Client. For a list of the events that are monitored,see Asset Management Sensor Event Information.To poll and display asset management events in dcTrack -The EMX or PX2 that the asset sensor is connected to must exist in dcTrack.EMX devices are identified as probes in dcTrack; PX2 devices are identified as sensors.Each item connected to the asset strip via an asset tag must exist in dcTrack.You do not need to manually enter the asset tag IDs for items that already exist in dcTrack as long as the items are inan Installed status.Simply, plug the item's asset tag in to an asset management strip that is connected to an EMX or PX2 that exists indcTrack. dcTrack automatically assigns the asset tag ID to the existing item.Note: If needed, the asset tag number can be overwritten.For more details on dcTrack as well as how asset sensors work with dcTrack, contact Sunbird Professional Servicesand Support from the http://support.sunbirddcim.com.

If you are just beginning to use asset management sensors and have not already done so, combine the assetsensors.Note: The following diagram illustrates some asset sensors. Note that Sunbird provides more types of asset sensorsthan the diagram.8U Primary asset sensor with 8 tag ports8U Extension asset sensor with 8 tag ports5U "ending" Extension asset sensor with 5 tag portsConnect the asset management sensor(s) to the EMX or PX2. See EMX Help or PX2 Help for details.If you are daisy chaining asset management sensors, review Daisy-Chain Limitations of Composite Asset Sensorsin EMX Help or PX2 Help.

Before asset sensors can be managed in dcTrack:They must be configured in EMX or PX2The EMX needs to be added to dcTrack as a probe item or the PX2 must be added as a sensor itemThe item the asset management tag is adhered to must exist in dcTrackNote: dcTrack does not support asset management blade extension strips.Add a single EMX or PX2 manually using the Create New Item feature.If you have a large number of EMX or PX2 devices to add, consider using cloning or the File Import.If the items the asset management tags are attached to do not exist in dcTrack already, create them.Add a single manually using the Create New Item feature.If you have a large number of items to add, consider using cloning or the File Import.

Asset sensor event information is available on the Events page in dcTrack.In the dcTrack Web Client, select click the Events tab to open the Event page.Use filters such as:Filter by Event Type = Connectivity FailureFilter by Source = Asset StripClick on a specific event in the list and the event's details are displayed in the Event Detail box on the right side of thepage.The following asset sensor management event information is captured on the Events page in the dcTrack Web Cli-ent.Tip: Use filters to view asset sensor events.An authorized asset tag that is attached to a device is plugged in to the correct plug on the assetAuthorized - Assetsensor.Tag connectedIt is in an Installed status and attached to the device it is expected to be attached to.An asset tag that is attached to an item and plugged in to an asset sensor is detected.Unauthorized - AssetHowever, it is not authorized to be added because it is not marked as Approved in the dcTrackTag connectedChange Control workflow.Asset tag removed Indicates the asset tag is unplugged from the asset sensor.Unknown - Asset TagdcTrack found that the asset tag ID is not attached to the expected item, or that the tag was ori-connectedginally assigned to one item and is now assigned to a new item.

Asset management events can be exported to a .CSV file. For more information, see Exporting Events.For information on specifying a save location, see How to Specify a Default Save Location for Downloaded Files.Events can be purged if you no longer need to monitor them in dcTrack. For more information, see Purge Events.

dcTrack version 9.0.0 introduced the ability to Un-map Integrated Items using File Import. This feature is designed toallow users to break the Integration for specific Items without losing the audit trail for the item. This includes CMDBIntegration, Power IQ Integration, and VMware Integration.Every dcTrack Item has a separate Integration status for each type of supported Integration. To break a specificintegration set the associated integration status to "In dcTrack Only".Steps1. Export the Items you want to Unmap into an Import Template2. Edit the column for the Integration Type you want to unlink and set it to "In dcTrack Only".3. Re-Import the file.Note: The only valid values for the Integration Status columns are the Items current Integration Status or "IndcTrack Only".

dcTrack provides several export options. This allows you to quickly export data based on your specific needs, suchas exporting data to update and re-import, and exporting data for reporting or auditing.dcTrack 8.2.0 and later will run these exports Asynchronously.This improvement allows users to continue working without interruption while large files are generated and down-loaded. Users can execute multiple exports of different types simultaneously and monitor the progress of each indi-vidually. To view the progress of any Export, navigate to the feature where the Export was initiated. If the Export isstill running the Export button displays a spinner icon. To view the progress, click the Export button again whichopens a message box displaying the number of records processed so far and the number of records remaining.You can run multiple exports for different objects types, however you will not be allowed to start multiple exports forthe same object type. For example, you can start a Circuit export while an Item export is still running, but you will notbe allowed to start a second Item export.Please note, logging out of dcTrack or closing your browser will terminate any exports in progress.Asynchronous export is available from the following locations:Asset ListCircuit ListRequest ListWork Order ListEventsLocationsModels Library ListCustom FieldsPick List ChoicesParts Custom FieldsParts Pick List ChoicesParts Library ListProject ListParts ListParts TransactionsExport Data to Import Templates: Use this feature if you want to export data from the Items List in the Web Clientto a template. You can then format the template, make changes and reimport it. For details, see Export Data toImport Templates for Reimporting.Export Data Exactly as Shown: Use this feature to export data from the Assets Items List or Connectivity CircuitsList in the Web Client. You can filter and sort data using this feature so only the data you want is included. Usethe data for reporting, auditing or reimporting. For details, see Export Data from the Items List or Circuits Listto a .CSV File for Reporting, Auditing and Reimports.For information on specifying a save location, see How to Specify a Default Save Location for Downloaded Files.

dcTrack provides you with the ability to export items and connections from the Items List and Circuits List, respect-ively. This feature is useful for exporting data to perform bulk changes such as moving items into an Installed or Stor-age status, bulk renaming items, auditing items and so on.Click the Export button in the Tool Bar and select "Export Items Exactly as Shown". For the Items List, you can thenselect "First 500 Rows" or "All Rows". For the Circuit List, in addition to the previous two options, you can also choseto export only the rows selected in the grid.The exported file will contain only the columns in the current view. Any filters and sorting that are applied to the listview are also applied to the export file.For information on specifying a save location, see How to Specify a Default Save Location for Downloaded Files.

After performing an Intelligent Capacity Search, cabinets that meet the parameters your specified are listed in theResults section of the Intelligent Capacity Search page. The results can then be exported to a .CSV file.This export is useful for auditing free cabinet space, determining available ports, determining the amount of freewatts per cabinet, and locating the far end connection to cabinets to name just a few.You can sort the results in the Results list by clicking on a column header. You can also reorder the columns by click-ing on them and dragging them to a new position. When you export, the sort order of the items and the order of thecolumns is applied in the export file.For information on specifying a save location, see How to Specify a Default Save Location for Downloaded Files.

Intelligent capacity search in dcTrack allows users to quickly and easily locate the optimal placement options for newoptions based on a range of user-provided criteria, including location, make model, RU height, cabinet attributes,and data and power connectivity. Intelligent capacity search can find space for one or more items.Intelligent capacity search is accessible by clicking the Capacity tab in the Web Client.Intelligent Capacity Searches are different from the Quick Item Searches on the Items List in the Web Client and theQuick Search bar in the upper right corner of the dcTrack GUI. While those searches locate specific items, IntelligentCapacity Search locates the cabinet space for the items and/or qualifies the space for the items. Qualifying the cab-inet space refers to the process of determine that the space matches all criteria. If the cabinet space matches all cri-teria, it is qualified.

Use Intelligent Capacity Search if you do not have a cabinet identified to install an item and want to quickly locate acabinet in your data center that can accommodate it. For example, if you need to find a cabinet that can accom-modate an HP DL380, you can search by the model, power requirements, and data connection requirements.You can also use Intelligent Capacity Search when submitting a Move Item Request using the Prepare Move ItemRequest option. These options allow you to search for an optimal destination cabinet to move the item to if you donot have one in mind. For more information, see Use Capacity Search to Locate a Destination CabinetNote: Intelligent Capacity Search is not used for the Quick Move Item Request option since you specify the cabinetan item should be moved to. See Using the Quick Move Item Request Option to Submit a Move CabinetRequestPlacing items is the act of virtually adding the item to the cabinet and then submitting a request to install it.Reserving space holds the cabinet space for the item until the reservation expires ).If you perform a make and model search, you can place the item in the cabinet immediately.

When you perform an Intelligent Capacity Search based on make and model, dcTrack uses information such asdimensions, connectors, data port requirements, power requirements and so on to search for a cabinet capable ofaccommodating the item.When you search by RU height, dcTrack locates cabinets that have available, contiguous rack units that can accom-modate an item. In dcTrack 9.0.0 and beyond, you can also Reserve the space in the selected Cabinets.When you perform an Intelligent Capacity Search based on make and model, dcTrack uses the Models informationsuch as dimensions, connectors, data port requirements, power requirements and so on to search for a cabinet cap-able of accommodating the itemTo perform an intelligent capacity search:1. Navigate to the Capacity Search page from dcTrack's main menu.2. In the Search Criteria pane "Search In" field, specify the sites that you want to search in. You can click toselect multiple sites, select or unselect all, or search from the list of available sites.3. In the Specify by field, select what you want to use when searching. "Model" (use specs in models library)RUs the number of rack units the model(s) require.4. Depending on your selection of Model or RU:For RU enter the number of Rack Units the item you are placing requires. This is the number of con-tiguous RUs the cabinet must have available.For Model, enter the Make and Model of the Item(s) you are placing. The RU height will be auto-matically populated with the height of the model from the Models Library.5. Specify the "Total Quantity" of items you will be placing. This amount should reflect the total number of itemsbeing placed, not the number of items to be placed in each Cabinet.6. Specify the other Optional criteria to use in the search. For details on optional information see1. Optional Intelligent Capacity7. Click the Search for Cabinet button to begin the search8. The search will return all of the Cabinets where the items can be placed. In addition to the Cabinet specs, thegrid will list the following to assist you in selecting the optimum Item placement:Max Fit - This is the maximum number of the Total Quantity that will fit in the cabinet.Reserve Quantity - This is the number of items to be placed in the cabinet (this value is automaticallycalculated but can be overridden)U Position - This is the list of available U Positions in the Cabinet.Available RUs - The number of empty u positionsContiguous RUs - The number of U positions that are next to each other without interruption9. Select your preferred placement methodDistribute based on current list filtering and sort order - This option will select the cabinet placement asit currently exists in the listDistribute as evenly as possible based on list filtering. - This option will automatically evenly distributethe items among the available cabinetsNote: If the Reserved Quantity is less than the Total Quantity, a warning message will appear at thebottom of the page"Warning: you are choosing to reserve fewer items than the number in the Total Quantity Field.Please increase values in Reserve Qty column."10. Click the Reserve button to reserve the space11. If you selected multiple Cabinets you are prsented with the "Edit Item Name" dialog. Here you can specify aProject to link to this reservation, as well as edit the automatically generated Item Names.12. If you selected only a single Cabinet, you are redirected to the New Item page where you can update theName, Make and Model.Note, initially the Make and Model of the Items are set to "Generic" values. You should update to the correct Makeand Model as soon as that information is available.

Required and optional criteria, such as cabinet information, data port information, and power information, can beapplied to Intelligent Capacity Searches to initiate, refine, or expand your results.Required criteria vary by search and are indicated by a red asterisk*.The Search in field is a required field that indicates the location you want to search in. More than one location can bespecified, and the default location is based on the system default.In the Space Criteria panel, you can specify in the Search by field whether you want to conduct a search by model orby RU height.For searches by model, Make is a required field. After you select the desired make, you can select the model fromthe Model dropdown, which will automatically populate with only the models for the selected make.The Quantity per Cabinet field specifies the number of devices of the specified make and model you want in eachcabinet. This field is required if you select to search by model.Note: For model searches, the search is based on items that mount in the rack horizontally and does not supportmodels having blade, non-rackable, free-standing or zero-U mounting type.For a search by RU height, the Make and Model fields will be hidden. While the RU Height field is optional for asearch by model, it is required for a search by RU height. If a model is selected, the RU height is prepopulated basedon data from Sunbird's Model's Library. This value can be increased but not decreased. The default value is 1 RU. Ifyou enter a value of 0 for RU Height, the search results will include ranks with no available RUS. The Space Criteriapanel title will also include text in parentheses indicating the number of RUs specified.

The Cabinet Group, Cabinet Type, Cabinet Function, and Cabinet Customer fields in the Cabinet Criteria panel areoptional for both Model and RU Height searches. The Cabinet Criteria panel title will also include text in parenthesesindicating the number of criteria set.The Data Connectivity Criteria panel prepopulates with data from the Models Library if a model has been selected.The Data Connectivity Criteria panel title will also include text in parentheses indicating the number of ports in thegrid being connected. If a Quantity per Cabinet is set, the number of ports will be multiplied by the quantity. Con-nections can be added, deleted, or disconnected by selecting the data connection (for Add or Delete operations) andclicking the desired action in the panel menu. Data in each column can be sorted ascending or descending.The panel can be maximized by clicking the Maximize Data Connectivity Criteria button in upper right corner of thepanel. The panel will then display as a popup.The columns in the grid include:Port Name (The prefix of newly added port name is always “Eth”)Connect (Required. Where the specified port should connect to: To Data Panel, To Network Item, or Don'tConnect)Connector (Required)Media (Required)Protocol (Required)Data Rate (Required)ColorGrouping/VLANThe Connect, Connector and Media fields are required for search. Warning messages are displayed when search-ing if these fields are empty. The data in these fields can be edited by clicking the desired cell in the grid and eithertyping the changes or selecting a different option from the dropdown.If the Quantity per Cabinet is specified as more than one item, and the ports set to connect to the data panel, thenumber of free ports per item will be multiplied by the Quantity per Cabinet value to meet the search criteria.Even if the Quantity per Cabinet is specified as more than one item, the grid will only show the number of ports forone model.

The Power Connectivity Criteria panel prepopulates with data from the Models Library once a model has been selec-ted. The Power Connectivity Criteria panel title will also include text in parentheses indicating the number of ports inthe grid being connected. If a Quantity per Cabinet is set, the number of ports will be multiplied by the quantity. Datain each column in the grid can be sorted ascending or descending and can be edited by clicking the desired cell inthe grid and either typing the changes or selecting a different option from the dropdown.Power Connectivity Criteria fields include:Quantity and Field Redundancy (Required)Nameplate Watts (Required)Nameplate PercentageBudget Watts (Required)Phase (Required)Volts (Required)Connector (Required)The fields in the grid include:Port NameConnectColorThe Field Redundancy, Nameplate Watts, Budget Watts, Phase, Volts, Connector and Connect fields are requiredfor search. Warning messages are displayed when searching if these fields are empty.The Budget Watts value is pulled from the Models Library. If this field is modified, the percentage will be changed.When you select a value for the Phase field, the contents of the Volts dropdown will change accordingly.Note: The free watts value seen in each row of the power ports modal dialog are not necessarily additive. dcTrackgroups the ports from one or more Rack PDUs by their attributes. All ports with a specific color, connector, voltageand phase are grouped together, however the Free Watts represents the Total Free Watts for the Rack PDU. IfPorts fall into two groups from one Rack PDU, you will see the Free Watts value listed twice, once for each group.Their total does not represent total free, but rather the value of one of them.

The Make and Model Intelligent Capacity Search supports the following item classes,subclasses and mounting types.Rackable and Zero-U:Classes, subclasses and/orDevice items and Network itemsmounting type(s)Standard subclass items (switches, servers, and so on)Chassis device subclass itemsBlade device subclass itemsCabinetsNetwork itemsChassis subclass itemsBlade subclass itemsNetwork stack subclass itemsProbe itemsThe RU Height Intelligent Capacity Search supports the following item classes, sub-classes and mounting types.Device itemsStandard subclass items (switches, servers, and so on)Chassis device subclass itemsBlade device subclass itemsNote: Intelligent Capacity Search does not support power outlets.dcTrack version 9.0.0 introduced the ability to initiate a Cabinet search directly from the Item Detail page of an exist-ing Planned Item. This allows users to quickly and easily locate the optimal placement options while editing an Itemcurrently in the "Planned" status. This is useful if you do not have a cabinet identified to install an item and want toquickly locate a cabinet in your data center that can accommodate it without having to leave the Item Detail page.This feature is designed to work on rackable Device, Network or Probe Items that were previously saved, and is notavailable when adding a new Item.Steps to initiate the search1. Open the Item detail page of the Item you want to place.2. Click the "Edit" button.3. Click the Search icon to the right of the Cabinet field. Note, the search icon is not visible while in "View" mode4. This will open the Capacity Search dialog with the search already executedThe search criteria on the left panel displays the details for the planed item in read-only modeThe Item's existing ports are populated in the Data and Power Connectivity section. These values canbe changed.If the Item was not saved with a cabinet, the Cabinet Criteria field will be blank. If the Item was savedwith a Cabinet, the Cabinet Criteria fields are populated based on the values that exist for that cabinet.These values can be changed.The Location field will default to the Location the Item is in, but can be changed. Note, if the Location ischanged, the Location of the Item will also be changed.5. If any of the Search Criteria is changed, the search results will be cleared and the "Search for Cabinet" buttonmust be clicked to execute a new search.6. To restore the Search Criteria to its original values, click the "Reset" button7. Select a Cabinet and click the "Select a Cabinet" button. This will close the dialog and populate the Item'sCabinet and UPosition on the Item Detail page with the values for the selected Cabinet.

Placing items is the act of virtually adding the item to the cabinet and then submitting an Install Item Request.Reserving space holds the cabinet space for the item until the reservation expires.If you perform a make and model Intelligent Capacity Search, you can place the item in the cabinet immediately.If you place an item, a popup will display with a grid of all items to be placed. The name of the items will be pre-pended with "CAPACITY-SEARCH^^." The name of each item can be changed by clicking in the Item Name cell andtyping in a new value. You can add a project number to the items by selecting the desired project number from thedropdown and clicking the Apply to Selected button.Multiple cabinet rows can be selected by using the CTRL or Shift buttons. Use the CTRL button to select multiplenon-consecutive rows. Use the Shift button and select the first and last rows of a consecutive set to select all therows between and including the first and last.After conducting an Intelligent Capacity Search, you can place one or more items.1. In the Search Results grid, select the item(s) you want to place.2. Click the Place All button.3. In the Edit Item Names popup, make your desired changes.a. To add a project number to one or more items, select the item(s), then select the project number fromthe Project Number dropdown and click the Apply to Selected button.b. To edit the item name, click the item name you want to change and type in the new one.4. Click the Done icon.

Cabinet space reservations are made when an item is created in the Planned Status, assigned to a cabinet and Uposition and the Planning Expiration field is set to a date in the future. For details, see Manage Cabinet SpaceReservations.Creating items using either a Model Intelligent Capacity Search or RU Height Intelligent Capacity Search, makes theprocess of creating reservation easier and allows many items in various cabinets to be created with few clicks. Whencreating the items this way, a default Planning Expiration date is set to 30 calendar days in the future, but that can bechanged before you click the Reserve button.When you perform an Intelligent Capacity Search based on make and model, dcTrack uses information such asdimensions, connectors, data port requirements, power requirements and so on to search for a cabinet capable ofaccommodating the item.

Make and model Intelligent Capacity Searches essentially require you to:Define Criteria for a Make and Model Intelligent Capacity Search and search for a cabinetReview Make and Model Search Results and then either:Locate a Cabinet from the Cabinet Search Result ListOrReset the Intelligent Capacity Search Page and/or refine your criteria if an appropriate cabinet was notfound, then perform another search1 Select the site(s) in which to search for a cabinet to house the item.Select the item's make and model.The RU Height is entered automatically from the Models Library.3 Specify the quantity per cabinet. The default value is 1.4 Select optional cabinet criteria to apply to the search. See Cabinet Criteria - Make and Model Searches.Data port information is retrieved from the Item Models Library and entered by default if it is available.Enter the required information if it is not prepopulated.Update data ports. dcTrack uses the new criteria in its search.Add data ports. dcTrack includes the new data port criteria in the search. Required informationmust be completed if you do. See Adding a Port - RU Height Intelligent Capacity SearchDelete data ports you add - dcTrack excludes the data ports from the search. See Deleting a DataPort - RU Height Intelligent Capacity SearchSet all or some ports to be ignored when searching for a cabinet. See Setting Ports to Don't Con-nect - Exclude Data Ports from a Search.Power information is retrieved from the Item Models Library and entered by default.6Enter the required information if it is not prepopulated.If needed, update power information. See Power Connectivity Criteria - Make and Model Search.7 Click "Search for a Cabinet".A list of cabinets that meets your criteria is displayed in the Cabinet list. Continue to Step 8. See Locate aCabinet from the Cabinet Search Result ListAlternatively, if no cabinets meet your criteria or only partial results are found, dcTrack indicates the res-ults. Use the information to refine your search criteria. See Define Criteria for a Make and Model Intel-ligent Capacity SearchProvided cabinets are available in the Cabinet list:Place the item: See Placing an Item Located from a Make and Model Search.Build circuits: See Building Circuits when Placing an Item.The following topics cover the criteria that can be updated when performing a make and model Intelligent CapacitySearch in order to refine or expand the results of the search.

dcTrack returns a list of potential cabinets that match all or some of the required and/or optional criteria applied tothe Intelligent Capacity Search feature. Results are displayed in a grid format.The Search Results grid contains high-level information about the cabinets such as cabinet name, location, type,group and function (if any).Columns in the grid include:Location: The location of the cabinetCabinet Name: The name of the cabinetTemperature (Max): Highest temp of all sensors in the front of the cabinet based on latest readingsUsed Watts (M)Free Watts (B)U Position: Defaults to the first available RU position in the cabinet but can be updated when placing the itemAvailable RUs: The available rack units in the cabinetContiguous RUs: The largest contiguous U position space in the cabinetGroup: The group of the cabinetType: CabinetFunction: The function of the cabinetData Ports: Number of available data ports in the cabinetPower Ports: Number of available power ports in the cabinetFree Watts: Amount of watts available for the item in the cabinetFar-end Cabinets: The far end cabinet(s) the selected cabinet is connected to (if any)The total number of potential matches as of the specified date and time is displayed at the bottom right of the Intel-ligent Capacity Search page.Each time you click "Search for Cabinet," the search results timestamp is updated, letting you know a new searchwas performed.The total number of available cabinets may change if cabinet space becomes unavailable during the time it takesbetween searches.Both Data Ports and Power Ports have an icon in their fields that, when clicked, will display a popup with a summaryof the details of the ports in the specified cabinet.Multiple cabinet rows can be selected by using the CTRL or Shift buttons. Use the CTRL button to select multiplenon-consecutive rows. Use the Shift button and select the first and last rows of a consecutive set to select all therows between and including the first and last.You can export your results by clicking the three dot icon in the top right corner of the grid.The Planning Date field is an optional field that can be use to filter for capacity that is available from assets that areplanned to be decommissioned on or after the date. The default date is the current date. Only a single date, not adate range, can be specified.Note: The Planning Date field will only be visible when the Apply Planned Decommissions checkbox under the Set-tings tab > dcTrack Settings > Appliance Settings is checked. For more information on enabling the Planned forDecommission feature, see Planning Items for Decommission.The results of the search include the rack units that will be made available, the compatible data ports and powerports, and free watts based on the planning date. You can then reserve space or place assets for the space that isavailable as of the Planning Date.

If you select a cabinet, its elevation view will be displayed in the Cabinet Elevation pane. If you select multiple cab-inets, the lowest row will be displayed.Note: You must expand the Cabinet Elevation pane to view the cabinet elevation. It is hidden by default.If no cabinets can accommodate the item, dcTrack® displays a message on the Capacity page letting you know.If cabinets are found that meet some criteria but not all, dcTrack lists the criteria that are met and the number of cab-inets that meet the criteria (if any).Criteria that are not met because they were not specified as part of the search are also displayed (if any).Use the information in the messages to refine your search criteria.Click Reset to begin a new search, or enter/update data in the Criteria sections.

To reset the intelligent capacity search page, click the Reset button. The page reverts to its original, criteria and anynew results are cleared.Switching between a make and model search and RU height search by selecting their respective radio buttons alsoresets the page.When you search by RU height, dcTrack locates cabinets that have available, contiguous rack units that can accom-modate an item.For example, search your data center for a cabinet that can contain a blade chassis that requires 3 RUs such as RU31, 32 and 33.The only requirements to perform an RU height Intelligent Capacity Search are to select the site(s) to search for acabinet, and enter the number of contiguous RUs the cabinet must have available.

RU height Intelligent Capacity Searches essentially require you to:Define Criteria for an RU Height Intelligent Capacity SearchReview RU Height Search ResultsLocate a Cabinet from the Cabinet Search Result ListOrReset the Intelligent Capacity Search Page and/or refine your criteria if an appropriate cabinet was notfound, then perform another search1. Select the site(s) in which to search for a cabinet to accommodate the item.2. Enter the RU Height.3. Select optional cabinet criteria to apply to the search, if needed.4. If needed:Update data ports. dcTrack uses the new criteria in its search.Add data ports. dcTrack includes the new data port criteria in the search. Required information must be com-pleted if you do. See Adding a Port - RU Height Intelligent Capacity SearchDelete data ports you add - dcTrack excludes the data ports from the search. See Deleting a Data Port - RUHeight Intelligent Capacity SearchSet all or some ports to be ignored when searching for a cabinet. See Setting Ports to Don't Connect -Exclude Data Ports from a Search.5. Enter power port information, if needed. Required information must be completed if you do.6. Click the Search for a Cabinet button.A list of cabinets that meets your criteria is displayed in the Cabinet list. Continue to step 8. See Locate a Cabinetfrom the Cabinet Search Result List7. Alternatively, if no cabinets meet your criteria or only partial results are found, dcTrack indicates the results. Usethe information to refine your search criteria. See Define Criteria for an RU Height Intelligent Capacity SearchSelect the site(s) in which to search for a cabinet to accommodate the item.Enter the RU Height.Select optional cabinet criteria to apply to the search, if needed.See Cabinet Criteria - RU Height SearchesIf needed:Update data ports. dcTrack uses the new criteria in its search.Add data ports. dcTrack includes the new data port criteria in the search. Required informationmust be completed if you do. See Adding a Port - RU Height Intelligent Capacity SearchDelete data ports you add - dcTrack excludes the data ports from the search. See Deleting a DataPort - RU Height Intelligent Capacity SearchSet all or some ports to be ignored when searching for a cabinet. See Setting Ports to Don't Con-nect - Exclude Data Ports from a Search.Enter power port information, if needed. Required information must be completed if you do.See Power Connectivity Criteria - RU Height Intelligent Capacity SearchClick "Search for a Cabinet".A list of cabinets that meets your criteria is displayed in the Cabinet list. Continue to step 8.See Locate a Cabinet from the Cabinet Search Result ListAlternatively, if no cabinets meet your criteria or only partial results are found, dcTrack indicates the res-ults. Use the information to refine your search criteria.The Auto Power Budget feature allows users to gather and use historical data accumulated by Power IQ to adjustthe allocated Power Budget (Watts(B)) for Items. Factors such as Model, Item Status and Time in Service can all beconsidered and used to determine how this information is accumulated and applied.To enable this feature navigate to the Settings > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration > Application pageand select the "Enable Auto Power Budget" check box.Upon checking the box you will receive a warning indicating the Budget Watts for Items and Models that meet thePolicy criteria will be automatically adjusted at the scheduled time.If you click the "No" button, you will be returned to the Application page and the feature will not be enabled. If youclick the "Yes" button, you will be returned to the Application page and may now select the Day and Time you wouldlike the job that processes the adjustments to begin.Note: Until you create and assign policies to Models, no Items will qualify to be adjusted by this process.This panel also provides two additional options.

This feature will replace the Original Power value for all Models or Items, depending on your selection, with the cur-rent Budget Power (Watts(B)) value for one of the Model/Item's non optional Power Supply ports. Upon clicking thisbutton, you will be presented with a warning describing the process and allowing you to confirm whether or not youwould like to proceed. If you choose "No", you will be returned to the Application page and no adjustments will bemade. If you choose "Yes", you will be returned to the Application page and dcTrack will immediately begin the pro-cess of making the adjustments.This feature will immediately replace the Budget Power (Watts(B)) value of each Power Supply port for all Models orItems, depending on you selection, with the Original Power value of the Model/Item. Upon clicking this button youwill be presented with a warning describing the process and allowing you to confirm whether or not you would like toproceed. If you choose "No" you will be returned to the Application page, and no adjustments will be made. If youchoose "Yes", you will be returned to the Application page and dcTrack will immediately begin the process of makingthe adjustments.Note: When the Budget Power (Watts(B)) value is adjusted up for a connected port, power calculations are per-formed to ensure the affected circuits have enough power capacity. If there is not sufficient power, the adjustmentwill not be made, and an Informational message will be written to the Event Log.For additional information please refer to the section on Power Budget Policies.

Model Policies allow users to define the exact criteria to be used for selecting, calculating and applying AdjustedPower Budget values. dcTrack allows users to create and manage any number of Policies that can be applied to dif-ferent Models providing you with the ability to fashion policies that capture and reflect more accurately the actualpower consumptions of specific Items.For additional information please refer to the following documentation.Creating Model PoliciesEditing and Deleting Model PoliciesAssigning and Unassigning Model PoliciesModel Policies can be created by any user with the System Administrator Role, or users with the "Manage Library"Auxiliary Role.Steps to Create a Model Policy1. Navigate to Settings > Models library2. Click the Policies button on the Model’s list tool bar3. From the Manage Power Budget Policies screen, click the Create button and supply the following informationin the Policy Details panel:a. Policy Name: Name of the Policy (Required)b. Period: Range for which to collect readings from Power IQ. Readings collected from the Items duringthis period will be used for calculating the Auto Power Budget value. (Required)Valid Options:Past DayPast WeekPast MonthPast 60 DaysPast 90 DaysPast Yearc. Granularity: Frequency with which readings will be polled and stored for future calculations. Optionsfor Granularity depend on the selected option for Period. (Required)Daily Period > HourlyWeekly Period > Hourly, DailyMonthly Period > Hourly, Daily60 day, 90 day and Yearly Periods > Hourly, Daily, Monthlyd. Statistic: Setting which determines how the readings gathered within the Granularity time frame shouldbe aggregated to derive a single value. For example, an Average statistic for a Daily Granularity set-ting results in the Average of each days readings (Required)AverageMaximumMinimume. Summary for Items: This determines the aggregation method applied to all the readings in a givenPeriod, Granularity and Statistic to derive a single value for each Item. For example, a Past WeekPeriod with Daily Granularity and Maximum Statistic results in 7 Daily Maximums. Then if the Sum-mary is set to Average, the 7 Daily Maximum readings will be Averaged to yield a single value for anItem. This value becomes the Auto Power Budget for the Item after applying the "Ignore Top and Bot-tom (%) and "Additional Safety Margin (%) settings. (Required)a. Averageb. Maximumc. Minimumf.
