Aggregation for Models: This determines the aggregation method applied when calculating the AutoPower Budget value for the Model. The values that result from the "Summary for Items" setting foreach Item are calculated base on this setting to yield a single value for the Model's Auto PowerBudget. (Required)a. Averageb. Maximumc. Minimumg. Only Installed Items Qualify: If checked, only Items that have been in the Installed status for a periodgreater than or equal to the selected Period of the Policy will be included in the Auto Power Budget cal-culations. Items that have been installed for a shorter period will remain excluded until enough timepasses and they qualify for a subsequent run for the Policy. If unchecked, Items in the Planned,Planned for Decomm, or Installed statuses will be included in the calculationh. Ignore Top and Bottom(%): This setting is used to exclude extreme high and low readings before apply-ing the "Summary for Items" and the "Aggregation for Models". For example, if this setting is 1, thenthe Top 1% and the Bottom 1% of Items will be excluded before aggregating the Items to calculate theModel's Auto Power Budget. (Required)Range can be from 0 to 50%i. Additional Safety Margin (%): Percentage value that will be added to the summarized value of eachitem. The result will be the Auto Power Budget for that item. For example, an Item's Summarized valueis 105 Watts and the Additional Safety Margin (%) is set to 20%, the Auto Power Budget for the Itemwill be 105 x (1 + 0.2) = 126 Watts.4. Click the Save Button to save the settings.Complete Example:a. Policy Name = Defaultb. Period = Past Yearc. Granularity = Dailyd. Statistic = Maximume. Summary for Items = Averagef. Aggregation for Models = Maximumg. Only Installed Items Qualify = Checkedh. Ignore Top and Bottom(%) = 5i. Additional Safety Margin (%) = 15Policy Default is assigned to Model A. Model A has 120 Items, but only 100 Items have been in the installedstatus for 12 months or more.Readings for the 100 items are collected. Each Item will have 365 daily maximums. The 18 highest and low-est readings are discarded (365 X 0.05 = 18.25). 329 readings per Item remain. They are averaged per Itemand multiplied by 1 plus the Additional Safety Margin (%). The result for each Item is used to set the AutoPower Budget. Then the Auto Power Budget of the 100 Items are used to calculate the Model's Auto PowerBudget by first discarding the highest and lowest 5 items, leaving only 90 Item's Auto Power Budget values.The maximum of the 90 Item's Auto Power Budget is used as the Auto Power Budget for Model A.

Model Policies can be edited by any user with the System Administrator Role, or users with the "Manage Library"Auxiliary Role.Steps to Edit a Model Policy1. Navigate to Settings > Models library2. Click the Policies button on the Model’s list tool bar3. From the Manage Power Budget Policies screen, select the Policy you wish to Edit.4. Modify the settings you want to change. (Every field excluding the "Measurements" field in Policy Details canbe modified)5. Click the Save Button to save the settings.Changes made to the Policy will be applied when the next weekly Auto Power Budget job is run.Model Policies can be deleted by any user with the System Administrator Role, or users with the "Manage Library"Auxiliary Role.Steps to Delete a Model Policy1. Navigate to Settings > Models library2. Click the Policies button on the Model’s list tool bar3. From the Manage Power Budget Policies screen, select the Policy you wish to Delete.4. Click the Delete button5. Carefully review the warning displayed in the pop up. The warning will indicate how many Models and Itemswill be effected by deleting the Policy.6. If you click "No" you will be returned to the Manage Power Budget Policies page and the Policy will not bedeleted.7. If you click "Yes" the Policy will be deleted. The Budget Status of any Models or Items previously assigned tothe Policy will be set to "Manually Adjusted" and they will no longer be included in any Trend analysis.

Model Policies can be Assigned by any user with the System Administrator Role, or users with the "Manage Library"Auxiliary Role.Steps to Assign a Model Policy1. Navigate to Settings > Models library2. From the Models List, select the Models you wish to assign to a Policy3. Click the Policies button on the Model’s list tool bar4. From the Assign a Policy to Selected Model(s) screen, select the Policy you wish to Assign.5. Click the Assign to Selected Policy Button.When a policy is assigned to a model, Policy scope will be updated to show the Number of Items using the Policy,the Number of Models using the Policy and a list of those Models.One Policy can be assigned to multiple Models, however a Model can be assigned to only one Policy.Alternatively, you can also assign a Policy to a Model by selecting a Model in the Model’s List and selecting thepolicy from the drop down in the Policy column. By default, the Policy column is hidden in the Model List. To displaythe Policy column, click the Show/Hide icon and select the column.Model Policies can be Unassigned by any user with the System Administrator Role, or users with the "ManageLibrary" Auxiliary Role.Steps to Unassign a Model Policy1. Navigate to Settings > Models library2. From the Models List, select the Model(s) you wish to unassign3. Click the Policies button on the Model’s list tool bar4. From the Assign a Policy to Selected Model(s) screen, select the Policy the Model(s) is assigned to.5. Click the Remove from Selected Policy buttonPolicies may also be Assigned and Unassigned by selecting a rowl from the Models List and selecting the Policyoption from the policy column.

Power Supply sub tab of the Item and the Model has following fields that describe how the Budget Watt is gettingupdated for that item or model1. Original Power - Read Only. When no power supply ports are created for the item or model, the value will be0. Once the power supply ports are created, the value is set to the Watts (B) value of the power supply ports.This value does not update if the Watts (B) of the power supply ports are modified later.2. Auto Power Budget - Check box. Checked by default if the model is assigned to a policy, otherwise it will beunchecked. You can uncheck this check box if you do not want the item or model power supply ports Watts(B)to be auto-updated.3. Budget Status - Read Only. This field have following three values and also displays the budget% of Name-plate.a. Default Budget - When Watts(B)/Watts(N) of the power supply port = 0.6, Budget Status is set toDefault Budget(60%).b. Auto Adjusted - When Watts(B) of the power supply port is updated by auto power budget, Budgetstatus is set to Auto Adjusted. For auto-adjusting Watts (B) of the models, they must be assigned to apolicy. For items, their Watts (B) are auto-adjusted only if they qualify according to the policy assignedto their models.For more details on policy setting and how auto-power budget is calculated for items and model, Go toSettings -> Model's Library -> Click Policies in the toolbar -> Click Settings help and read the descrip-tion.c. Manually Adjusted - When Watts(B) of the power supply is not auto adjusted and Watts(B)/Watts(N)value is not equal to 0.6, then Budget Status is set to Manually Adjusted.4. Next Auto Adjust in - Read Only. This field is displayed only when the item or the model qualifies for the auto-adjustment of Watts(B). Otherwise, the field remains hidden. It shows the number of days until the next autopower budget job is scheduled to run, with values ranging from 7 down to 1.Note: When new items or models are created, they are assigned the status 'Manually Adjusted' or 'Default Budget'based on their Watts (B) value. They do not receive the 'Auto Adjusted' status because they lack historical read-ings, which are required to calculate the auto-adjusted Watts (B) for an item or modelFor additional information please refer to the section on Power Budget Policies.dcTrack supports Direct Current Power distribution (DC Power). The DC Power feature allows you to track and man-age assets that require DC Power in their Data Centers in addition to dcTrack's existing AC Power features. Both ACand DC power can be supported in a single Data Center or even a single Asset.

To enable the DC Power feature:1. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration > Application.2. On the DC Power Settings panel, select the "Enable DC Power Management" check box.3. The DC Power setting is saved immediately.4. If you change the DC Power Default setting, you must click the "Apply" button to save this setting.5. After clicking the Apply button you will be asked to confirm your selection.6. To cancel your selection, click the "No" button. To Apply your setting, click the "Yes" button.Note: As indicated in the confirmation message, if the Minimum Voltage value is changed, the application of thenew setting could take a while to complete. The actual time will depend on the number of connected Items in thedatabase. Users may continue to work in dcTrack while the process is running.When this feature is enabled, dcTrack will include Classes, Subclasses and menu options required to support DCPower.You can also set the Minimum Voltage value on this panel. The Minimum Voltage value represents the worst casevoltage when equipment is powered from batteries. This value is used to calculate Budget Amps using the formulaBudget Amps = Budget Watts / Minimum VoltageBy default, this value is set to 44 but can be changed by entering a different value and clicking the "Apply" button.To disable the DC Power feature:1. Navigate to Settings > dcTrack Settings > Application Administration > Application.2. On the DC Power Settings panel, deselect the "Enable DC Power Management" check box.3. The setting will be saved immediately.When this feature is disabled, dcTrack will no longer display Classes, Subclasses and menu options that are specificto DC Power.Note: You may not disable the DC Power feature if DC Power Items exist. You must first delete any DC PowerItems then you can disable the feature.

DC Power Classes and Subclasses will appear in dcTrack when the DC Power feature is enabled.The following are the Subclasses for the DC Power System Item Class:The Plant Subclass Item is a logical Item that groups all of the components of the DC PowerSystem. A Data Center is expected to have two Plant items. One for A and one for B dis-tribution.The Plant Bay Subclass Item is the physical container for Rectifiers, Main Distribution Panelsand Batteries. This item will behave like an IT Cabinet. It will have Rack Units and provide aCabinet Elevation showing the physical location of Rectifiers, Panels and Batteries.The Rectifier Subclass item represents each Rectifier within each Plant. Rectifiers are phys-ically placed in a Bay and their power output feeds the Plant.The Plant Panel Subclass item is the Main Distribution Circuit Breaker or Fuse Board. This isthe Panel that will hold the breakers or fuses that feed the BDCBB/FB. They automaticallyreceive the output power of the collective Rectifiers via the Plant.

Battery Class Items are the individual Batteries. Each battery will belong to a String and the Plant Itemwill Track the String redundancy.Following are the Subclasses for DC Distribution Class Items:DC Bay subclass item are the Battery Distribution Fuse Bay (BDFB) or Battery Distribution Cir-cuit Breaker Bay (BDCBB).This is the Panel that holds the Breaker that feeds the Fuse Alarm Panel inlet.

The following are the DC Power Subclasses for Rack PDU Class Items:DC FAP Subclass Items represent the Fuse Alarm Panels that have Inlets and Outlets.Rack Inverter Subclass Items represent the Rackable Inverters which can transform a dir-ect current (DC) into an alternating current (AC).Rack Rectifier Subclass Items represent the Rackable Rectifiers which can transform analternating current (AC) into direct current (DC).Note: Rack PDU classes also have a Subclass of AC Power, which is a specialized power stripthat is used to provide additional electrical receptacles for an electrical outlet.Power infrastructure in dcTrack can be built out using the Web Client or File Import.The high-level process for building a Power Chain for DC Power infrastructure in dcTrack is as follows:1. Create a Plant. User with the appropriate permissions can create a Plant using the "Add an Item" button onthe Assets tab.2. Create Rectifiers for a Plant. Users with the appropriate permissions can create Rectifies by clicking on the"Create Rectifier" button on the Rectifier sub-tab on a Plant's Item Detail page.3. Create Plant Panels. User with the appropriate permissions can create Plant Panels by clicking the "CreatePanel" button on the Panel sub-tab on a Plant's Item Detail page.4. Create Plant Panel Breakers. Plant Panel Breakers must be created using the File Import feature. See UsingFile Import to Create Plant Panel Breakers.5. Create DC Bays. Users with the appropriate permissions can create a DC Bays by clicking the "Add an Item"button on the Assets tab.6. Create DC Panels. Users with the appropriate permissions can create DC Panels using the "Create Panel"button on the Panel sub-tab on a DC Bay's Item Detail page.7. Create DC Panel Breakers. DC Panel Breakers must be created using the File Import feature. See Using FileImport to Create DC Panel Breakers.Once you have built out the DC Power Chain you can create DC Power circuits by connecting an Item's Power Sup-ply to either a DC FAP or Rack Inverter which would then connect to a DC Panel Breaker to complete the circuit.For details on how to build a DC Power Circuit, please refer to Building a DC Power Circuit.The following diagram depicts an example of a DC Power Chain.

1. From the Assets tab > Item List, click the Add an Item button. A new Item page willopen in a new dcTrack tab.2. In the New Item Page, select the Plant’s make and model.3. Assign a name to the Plant.4. Select a Location for the Plant, if different from the one already selected in theLocation drop down.5. In the Rectifier sub-tab, select Input Volts (Vac) and Input Phase from the dropdown.6. Click on Create Rectifier button to create rectifiers for the Plant. Create RectifierButton gets enabled only when fields Input Volts (Vac) and Input Phase are pop-ulated.7. In Create Rectifier screen, provide the following information:a. Quantity – Required. Enter any number between 1-10.b. Rectifier Name Prefix – Required.c. Make – Required.d. Model – Required.e. Rating (A)f. Rating (Vac) (Required to connect)g. Phase (Required to connect)h. Output Volts – Required.i. Bayj. U Position8. Click on Create Button.9. Set the Rectifier redundancy by selecting an option from Redundancy drop down.10. Click on Save to save the Plant.

1. In the Plant Item details page -> Plant Panel sub-tab, click Create a panel button.2. In the Create a panel screen, provide the following information:a. Panel Name: The name of the Panel being created. Panel Name mustbe unique within the Plant.b. No of Poles: The number of poles. Enter any value greater than 0.c. Rating (A): Enter any value greater than 0 but less than or equal to thePlants Output Capacity value.3. Click the Create button to save your entryThe newly created power panel will be viewable in the Power Panels sub-tab.1. To create plant panel breakers select either of the following options:a. In the Asset Tab > Item List., click the Export button and select Download ImportTemplate to download the import template as a CSV file.b. In Item list filter subclass to Plant Panel and click on Export into an Import Tem-plate > Branch Circuit Breakers to download an import template populated withthe existing plant panel breakers as a CSV file.2. Open your CSV file.3. Follow the instructions and examples in the CSV file to add plant panel breakers.4. In the Assets tab > File Import page, import the edited CSV file to create the breakers.You can also click on Bulk Edit button in Power Pole Breaker subtab in the Panel itemdetails page which will take you to the file import wizard.

1. In the Assets tab > Item List, click the Add an Item button. A new Item page will open ina new dcTrack tab.2. In the New Item Page, select the DC Bay’s make and model.3. Assign a name to the DC Bay.4. Select a location for the DC Bay, if different from the one already selected in the Loca-tion dropdown.5. Click on Save button to save the item.1. From a DC Bay Item Details page > Power Panels sub-tab, click the Create a panelbutton.2. In the Create a panel screen, provide the following information:a. Panel Name: The name of the panel. Name must be unique within the DC Bayb. Maximum Amps: Select from the drop down. You can also enter a value in the textbox if it does not exist the drop down.c. No of Poles: Enter a value greater than 0.d. Power Fed From: Select from where this DC Panel getting the power.e. Plant: Drop down will have the list of all the available Plant Breakers that haveamps greater than or equal to the Maximum Amps selected.f. Distribution Bay: Drop down will have the list of all the available DC Panel Break-ers that have amps greater than or equal to the Maximum Amps selected.Panels can also be configured from the Configuration Subtab of the DC Panel Item detailpageRating field is the Amps rated value of the panel breaker you have selected for PowerFed From field. This field is read only.The newly created power panel will be viewable in the Power Panels sub-tab of DC Bay.

1. To create dc panel breakers select either of the following optionsa. In the Asset Tab > Item List., click the Export button and select DownloadImport Template to download the import template as a CSV file.b. In Item list filter subclass to DC Panel and click on Export into an ImportTemplate > Branch Circuit Breakers to download an import template pop-ulated with the existing dc panel breakers as a CSV file.2. Open your CSV file.3. Follow the instructions and examples in the CSV file to add dc panel breakers.4. In the Assets tab > File Import page, import the edited CSV file to create the break-ers. You can also click on Bulk Edit button in Power Pole Breaker subtab in thePanel item details page which will take you to the file import wizard.Plant Panels associated with a Plant can be viewed in the Plant Panels sub-tab of the Plant's Item Detail Page.Note: You must have the appropriate permissions to view, create or delete a Plant Panel.The following Plant Panel properties can be set in the Plant Panels sub-tab of a Plant Class Item:Name - Name of the Panel to be createdNo of Positions - Number of Pole PositionsRating (A) - Rating from the Fed From Item

1. Navigate to the Item Detail page of a Plant Class Item.2. On the Plant Panels sub-tab, click the "Create a Panel" button. You can not create Plant Panels using the"Add an Item" feature.3. Provide the following details in the dialog box:a. Panel Name: The name of the Panel being created. Panel Name must be unique within the Plant.b. No. of Poles: Enter any value greater than 0.c. Rating (A): Enter any value greater than 0 but less than or equal to the Plants Output Capacity value.4. Click the "Create" button to save your entry.5. Close the dialog boxThe newly created Plant Panel is viewable in the Plant Panels grid on the Plant Panels sub-tab.Note: The Plant must be created and saved before creating its Plant Panels.To delete a Plant panel:1. Navigate to the Item Detail page of the Plant Class Item.2. Click the check box to the left of the Panel(s) you want to delete.3. Click the "Delete" button in the Plant Panel toolbar.You can create and delete Plant Panels in bulk using file import feature. See Importing and Exporting Plant Paneland DC Panel for more details.

The top panel of the Plant Panel subtab displays readings for the panel. The tool bar provides several options forviewing the readingsPrint - Print the Power Panel SubtabShow Remaining/Show Consumption - This button can be toggled between the two options to either showremaining power or power consumedShow in Amps/Show in kW - This button can be toggled between the two options to either display the read-ings in Amps or kilowattsThe following columns are available in the grid.The # PolesState - Open ClosedRating/Continuous Rating - Displays the Rating, the De-Rated value and the voltage for the breakerDestination - This column is broken into two sections the first displays the Status Planned Installed. ForAC Panels it is the Status of the Power Outlet. For DC Items it is the status of the connected Item. The secondsection displays the connector of the Power Outlet or Connector Name when connected to a Floor PDU.When the Power Outlet has multiple ports the connectors will be listed comma separated. The text "+ AddWhip" is displayed when the breaker is not connected to an outlet.Description - Displays the assignment type and assignment text. A caption icon will be dispalyed when thereis a comment, hovering over the caption icon will display the comment text.For Other assignment the text entered in the comment will show in the column and not in the caption icon.Ckt - Circuit status when the Power Outlet is connected to equipment. When clicked you are navigated to thecircuit trace. (existing functionality)Customer: Customer field from cabinet item for the power outlet. If customer is not assigned to cabinet, thenthe customer field assigned to the power outlet. In the case where there is no power outlet, the customer fieldwill remain blank.Budget (kw) % of Rating: Budget: Budget value in kw or ampsActual (kw) % of Rating: Actual value in kw or amps

To create panel breakers:1. Open item details page of Plant Panel in edit mode.2. In the Power Panel sub tab, click the "+ Add breaker" text in the position you are creating the breaker for3. Provide following information in the Breaker Assignment Dialoga. Size : Select the size of the breaker.b. Rating (A) : Select Rating Amps for the breaker. You can also enter a number if the drop down list donot have the value that you want to select.c. Assignment Type - Can be Cabinet, Space or Otherd. Cabinet: Drop down list of cabinets that have free inlets or power supply ports. Available when Assign-ment Type is Cabinete. Item: Drop down list of Items and Ports from the selected cabinet that have free Inlets (DC FAP orRack Inverter) or a free Power Supply.f. Space Name: User defined Space Name used assignment type is "Space"g. Space ID: User defined ID (Required when Assignment type is "Space")h. Comment: User supplied comments associated with the breaker4. Click "Save" to create the breakerTo delete a plant panel breaker click the pencil icon in the Rating/Continuous Rating column of the breaker to enteredit mode. Once in edit mode the delete icon is displayed in the column. Click the icon to delete the breaker.Note : You must have the appropriate permissions to delete a power panel.

Plant Panel breakers can be viewed from the Power – [x] Poles, [y] Breakers sub-tab of a Plant Panel’s Item Detailspage.Plant Panel Breakers can be created using the File Import feature in dcTrack.The import template includes a step for adding Plant Breakers.

To create Plant Panel Breakers, select either of the following options:a. In the Assets tab > Items List, click the Export button and select Download Import Template todownload the import template as a CSV file.b. In the item list filter the subclass to Plant Panelc. Click Export into an Import Template > Branch Circuit Breakers to download an import templatepopulated with the existing Plant Panel breakers as a CSV file.d. Open your CSV file.e. Follow the instructions in the CSV file for adding Plant Panel Breakers.f. In the Assets tab > File Import page, import the edited CSV file to create the Breakers.You can edit the following fields for Plant Panel Breaker through file import with EDIT Operation.No of PolesRated AmpsMeasured Amps

Deleting a Plant Panel Breaker can be done only through file import using the DELETE operation.DC Panels associated with a DC Bay can be viewed in the Power Panels sub-tab of the DC Bay ItemDetails page.Note: You must have the appropriate permissions to view, create, or delete a DC Panel.

The top panel of the Power Panel subtab displays readings for the panel. The tool bar provides severaloptions for viewing the readingsPrint - Print the Power Panel SubtabShow Remaining/Show Consumption - This button can be toggled between the two options toeither show remaining power or power consumedShow in Amps/Show in kW - This button can be toggled between the two options to either dis-play the readings in Amps or kilowattsThe following columns are available in the grid.The # PolesState - Open ClosedRating/Continuous Rating - Displays the Rating, the De-Rated value and the voltage for thebreakerDestination - This column is broken into two sections the first displays the Status PlannedInstalled. For AC Panels it is the Status of the Power Outlet. For DC Items it is the status of theconnected Item. The second section displays the connector of the Power Outlet or ConnectorName when connected to a Floor PDU. When the Power Outlet has multiple ports the con-nectors will be listed comma separated. The text "+ Add Whip" is displayed when the breaker isnot connected to an outlet.Description - Displays the assignment type and assignment text. A caption icon will be dis-palyed when there is a comment, hovering over the caption icon will display the comment text.Ckt - Circuit status when the Power Outlet is connected to equipment. When clicked you arenavigated to the circuit trace. (existing functionality)Customer: Customer field from cabinet item for the power outlet. If customer is not assigned tocabinet, then the customer field assigned to the power outlet. In the case where there is nopower outlet, the customer field will remain blank.Budget (kw) % of Rating: Budget: Budget value in kw or ampsActual (kw) % of Rating: Actual value in kw or amps1. While in Edit mode on the DC Bay Item Details page > Power Panels sub-tab, click the Create apanel button.2. In the Create a panel screen, provide the following information:a. Panel Name: The name of the panel. Name must be unique within the DC Bayb. Rating (A): Max capacity in Ampsc. No of Positions: Number of pole positionsd. Power Fed From: Plant or Distributione. Plant or Distribution Bay Item and Port of either a Plant or Distribution Baydepending on Power Fed Fromf. Rating (A) : Amps rated value of the panel breaker you have selected in thePower Fed From field. This field is read only.3. Click the Create button.The newly created DC Panel will be viewable in the Power Panels sub-tab.Create a panel button will get disabled if the number of DC Panels created for DC Bay is equal to MaxPanels value set for the DC Bay model.To specify a value for the Max Panels, go to DC Bay model details page -> specification sub-tab andenter a value. The value must be greater than or equal to 1.Note: You must have the appropriate permissions to create a DC Panel.

To delete a DC panel, click the power panel you want to delete in the grid, and then click the Deleteicon.Note: You must have the appropriate permissions to delete a DC Panel.You can also use file import to create and delete DC Panels in bulk. See Importing and Exporting PlantPanel and DC Panel for more details.

The top panel of the Power Panel subtab displays readings for the panel. The tool bar provides several options forviewing the readingsPrint - Print the Power Panel SubtabShow Remaining/Show Consumption - This button can be toggled between the two options to either showremaining power or power consumedShow in Amps/Show in kW - This button can be toggled between the two options to either display the read-ings in Amps or kilowattsThe following columns are available in the grid.The # PolesState - Open ClosedRating/Continuous Rating - Displays the Rating, the De-Rated value and the voltage for the breakerDestination - This column is broken into two sections the first displays the Status Planned Installed. ForAC Panels it is the Status of the Power Outlet. For DC Items it is the status of the connected Item. The secondsection displays the connector of the Power Outlet or Connector Name when connected to a Floor PDU.When the Power Outlet has multiple ports the connectors will be listed comma separated. The text "+ AddWhip" is displayed when the breaker is not connected to an outlet.Description - Displays the assignment type and assignment text. A caption icon will be dispalyed when thereis a comment, hovering over the caption icon will display the comment text.Ckt - Circuit status when the breaker is connected downstream to an inlet or power supplyCustomer: Customer field from cabinet item for the power outlet. If customer is not assigned to cabinet, thenthe customer field assigned to the power outlet. In the case where there is no power outlet, the customer fieldwill remain blank.Budget (kw) % of Rating: Budget: Budget value in kw or ampsActual (kw) % of Rating: Actual value in kw or ampsTo create panel breakers:1. Open item details page of DC Panel in edit mode.2. While in Edit mode click the "add breaker" hyperlink in the breaker grid to open the Breaker Assignment dia-log box3. Provide following information in the Breaker Assignment Dialoga. Size : Select the size of the breaker.b. Rating (A) : Select Rating Amps for the breaker. You can also enter a number if the drop down list donot have the value that you want to select.c. Assignment Type - Can be Cabinet, Space or Otherd. Cabinet: Drop down list of cabinets that have free inlets or power supply ports. Available when Assign-ment Type is Cabinete. Item: Drop down list of Items and Ports from the selected cabinet that have free Inlets (DC FAP orRack Inverter) or a free Power Supply.f. Space Name: User defined Space Name used assignment type is "Space"g. Space ID: User defined ID (Required when Assignment type is "Space")h. Comment: User supplied comments associated with the breaker4. All the empty pole positions without any breaker will have a text "Click here to add breaker". Click on the textto add the breaker.5. Save the item

Follow the steps below to edit breakers in UI.1. In the Edit Panel mode, click on the pencil icon in Breaker Rating column.2. Edit breaker size and breaker rating by selecting different value from the drop down.3. Save the item.If the breaker is connected downstream and Circuit Status column have a value, then breaker size can not be edited.Breaker Rating can be updated, however if the selected value is smaller and not sufficient to carry the load of the cir-cuit, an error message will show and the changes will not be saved.Follow the steps below to delete breakers in UI.1. In the Edit Panel mode, click on the pencil icon in Breaker Rating column.2. Click on the delete icon to delete the breaker.If the breaker is connected downstream and the Circuit Status is Planned, the breaker and the circuit it is connectedto will be deleted.If the circuit status is installed, the breaker can not be deleted.

dcTrack 8.1 allows you to create and manage in bulk Plant Panel and DC Panel using File Import.Steps for import :1. Navigate to File Import and click Main Import Template download the import template.2. In the downloaded csv file go to Tab Power Panel.3. Follow the instructions and examples to create an import file.4. Import the file.Steps for Export :1. Navigate to Item List. Filter the list with the Panel items you want to export.2. Export the Panel items using Export into an Import Template -> Items. You can select to export All columns oronly visible columns from the item list. You can export the list exactly as seen by selecting Export -> ExportItem List Exactly as Shown.

DC Panel breakers can be viewed from the Power – [x] Poles, [y] Breakers sub-tab of a DC Panel’s Item Detailspage.DC Panel breakers can be created using the File Import feature in dcTrack.The import template includes a step to add DC Panel Breakers.To create DC Panel Breakers, select either of the following options:a. In the Assets tab > Items List, click the Export button and select Download Import Template todownload the import template as a CSV file.b. In the item list filter the subclass to DC Panel.c. Click Export into an Import Template > Branch Circuit Breakers to download an import templatepopulated with the existing dc panel breakers as a CSV file.d. Open your CSV file.e. Follow the instructions in the CSV file for adding DC Panel Breakers.f. In the Assets tab > File Import page, import the edited CSV file to create the DC Panel Break-ers.

You can edit the following fields for DC Panel Breaker through file import with EDIT Operation.No of PolesRated AmpsMeasured AmpsDeleting a DC Panel Breaker can be done only through file import using the DELETE operation.

The following steps apply to DC Power System / Plant Panel and DC Distribution / DC Panel1. In the Asset List, select one or more Plant items. If you want to Print the Panel view of DC Panels as well inthe same report then select DC Bay items also.2. Click Reports -> Panel View3. If you would like to print the Report, once rendering is complete click the Print button in the lower right side ofeach page of the report.4. If you would like to exclude the Panel Level readings, click the "Hide Panel Readings" button in the tool bar.This button allows you to toggle between Hiding and Showing the PanelThe printed report will include Panel View of all the Plant Panels and DC Panels of the Plant items and DC Bay itemsselected in the Asset list, and display the Panel Readings based on your previous selection.You can also print all the Plant Panels of a single Plant item by navigating to the Plant Item details page and clickingReports -> Panel View. This report will only include the Panel view of that Plant item and again will display or hidePanel Readings based on you previous selection.This version of the report also allows you to print of suppress the Panel Readings.To individually print a Plant Panel view, open the item details page of Plant Panel and click Print button in the PowerPanel sub tab. You can also choose to Hide or display the Panel Readings.To print all the DC Panels of a DC Bay item, navigate to DC Bay item details page and click Reports -> Panel View.This report will only include the Panel view of that DC Bay item and display or hide the Panel Readings based onyour previous selection.To individually print DC Panel view, open the item details page of DC Panel and click Print button in the Power Panelsub tab.

Depending on whether it is a Complete or Partial circuit, DC Power circuits may begin with an Item having either aPower Supply Port (Phase Type Direct Current), DC FAP Input Cord or Rack Inverter Input Cord.Partial Power Circuits will always begin with a DC FAP Input Cord or Rack Inverter Input Cord.To complete a Partial Circuit connect the Partial Circuit to any Item that has a Power Supply Port who's Phase Typeis "Direct Current".The Power chain must be built before creating a Power circuit.Virtual Power Chains are not supported when building DC Power circuits.

Data circuits for DC Power class Items can be built in the same way as AC Power Items. For complete details pleasesee the documentation on Building a Data Circuit.Data Circuits for DC Power Class Items may begin with a Plant, Rectifier, DC FAP or Rack Inverter class items.Left Partial data circuits that end on a Data Panel Item can also be created when the circuit starts with a Plant, Rec-tifier, DC FAP or Rack Inverter class item.Right Partial Data circuits can not be created with any DC Power Class Items.

Before you can import data and power connections into dcTrack, the items used in the connections must exist. Sofirst, import your DC FAP, devices and so on. Next add or configure ports on devices if needed. Note that you canmanually add your items instead of importing them.You must also create your DP Power Infrastructure in dcTrack. This means creating Plants, Rectifiers, Plant Panels,DC Bays, DC Panels and Panel breakers.Please refer to How to Build Power Chain in DC for additional details.

Use the Create Power Connections worksheet in the Import Template to create power connections and import theminto dcTrack.The connections between all of the items in a power chain form a complete circuit."Power connections" refers to a connection between a starting item, such as a Server or Switch, and an ending itemthat is either a DC FAP, Rack Inverter, DC Panel Breaker or Plant Panel Breaker.It is important to designate the item's power supply port as the starting point, and a Plant Panel Breaker, DC PanelBreaker, DC FAP or Rack Invert’s input power port as the ending item.Once connected, these form the first half of a power circuit.The remaining portion of the circuit is the upstream power connection to the power source which consists of the DCPanel, Plant Panel Breaker, Plant Panel and Rectifiers.In the Import sheet the Starting Item for DC Power circuits can be Device, Network or Probe Items where the phasetype for the power supply is Direct Current. DC FAP and Rack Inverter Input cord could also be the starting item.In the Import sheet the Ending Item for a DC Power circuit can be a DC FAP, a Rack Inverter input cord, DC PanelBreaker or a Plant Panel Breaker. When the Ending Item is a DC Panel or Plant Panel, the column Ending Item Par-ent Name is required.Importing power connections follows the same basic steps when using File Import as other imports.For a list of the requirements and/or prerequisites, as well as recommendations and examples of spreadsheets, seethe worksheets in the templates.(Optional) Verify the circuits are imported by looking them up. You can use the search and filter options on the Cir-cuits List in the Web Client to view circuits.You can submit Connect Requests for one or more circuits immediately after the import or at a later time.

You can import data connections for DC Power classes same way you import data connections for AC Power. Referto the sample import template for examples of data connections.Steps to build a DC Power circuit:1. In the Web Client, click Connectivity > Add a Circuit. A New Circuit tab is opened with an empty node high-lighted in blue and an Item list for selecting Items for this circuit node.2. From the Item list below, select the item from which the circuit initiated. Required3. Next, select the port the connection originates from. Select a port that has a phase type of “Direct Current”.dcTrack validates the port selection to make sure there are no issues. RequiredWhen selecting the port, from the second node onwards, you will have the option of only displaying com-patible ports that are most likely to be used for building this circuit. By default, this option will be enabled, ifyou want to view all of the available ports for the selected item you can click the Show All Ports button in thePort List toolbar.4. When building the first node, you can switch to building a data circuit instead of a power circuit by clicking thePower Ports button on the Port List toolbar.5. Once you have moved on to creating a power circuit for the next node, the option to select Data Port is nolonger available. To switch to building a Data circuit, click the Refresh button which will reset the circuit andbring you back to the first node.6. To continue building the circuit click the Next Node button in the Port List toolbar and select the item and portfor the next node.7. Select the power item the device will be connected to, then select the power port. One of the following occurs:If you select the outlet port for a DC FAP that is already connected upstream, the remainder of the cir-cuit is displayed automatically.For example, Server ~ DC FAP ~ inlet cord ~ DC Panel ~ Plant panel ~ Rectifier PlantIf the circuit is not already connected upstream, click Next Node to continue building the circuit. Youwill not get the option to build Virtual Power Chain when building DC Power circuits.If there is an issue between the node item or port you selected and the item and port of the previous node, aCaution icon ( ) is displayed at the bottom right of the node. Click on the Caution icon to view the conflictdetails.Note: If you make changes and have already added additional nodes, the nodes that follow are deleted.8. Click Save to save the circuit.9. Submit a Connect Request now or later.After the power circuit is saved, you can view the actual load and the reading for each node by clicking on the buttonShow Reading in the toolbar. You can also hide the readings by clicking on Hide Reading Button. For DC Circuitsthe reading will be in Amps by default. You can also view the readings in Watts by clicking on the Show in Watts but-ton.You can also build multiple power circuits in single tab. You can do this by selecting an item and selecting all theports for that item. This will build the same number of circuits as the number of ports you have selected in single tab.Then click Next Node and select the item for the next node and so on.dcTrack also allows you to build DC Power circuits that connect a device power supply (AC phase type) to a RackInverter item. Follow the steps below to build a circuit that is connected to a Rack Inverter.1. In the Web Client, click Connectivity > Add a Circuit. A New Circuit tab is opened with an empty node high-lighted in blue and an Item list for selecting Items for this circuit node.2. From the Item list below, select the item from which the circuit is initiated. Required3. Next, select the port the connection originates from. Select a port that has an AC phase type of “Single Phase(2-Wire)” or “Single Phase (3-Wire)”. dcTrack validates the port selection to make sure there are no issues.RequiredNote: Rack Inverter Outlet ports cannot have a phase type of “Three Phase Delta” or “Three Phase Wye”.Hence you can not connect Three Phase device power supply to Rack Inverter outlet.4. To continue building the circuit click the Next Node button in the Port List toolbar and select the item and portfor the next node.5. Select the item the device will be connected to, then select the power port. One of the following occurs:If you select the outlet port for a Rack Inverter that is already connected upstream, the remainder of thecircuit is displayed automatically.For example, Server ~ Rack Inverter ~ inlet cord~ DC Panel ~ Plant panel ~ Rectifier PlantIf the circuit is not already connected upstream, click Next Node to continue building the circuit. Youwill not get the option to build a Virtual Power Chain when building DC Power circuits.6. Click Save to save the circuit. Submit a Connect Request now or later.

Steps to create power ports for DC FAP in the dcTrack Web UI.1. Select the Item from the List page and open its Detail page by double-clicking on it or clicking theEdit button on the toolbar.2. If the record was opened in View mode (used the double click method to open), click Edit on theDetail pages toolbar.3. Click the Power Port Subtab.4. Click Create Ports in the Ports section of the page. The Create Ports dialog appears.5. You must create an inlet cord before creating the first DC FAP Outlet port. To manually create aninlet cord port:a. Select "Inlet" from the Type drop down. Requiredb. The Port Name Prefix will default to "Inlet" but can be changed. Requiredc. Enter the number of Ports you want to create in the "Quantity" field. You can create up to fourinlet cords for a DC FAP item. Requiredd. Select a connector. Once selected, an image of the connector is displayed if an image is avail-able. Requirede. Select the Volts for the Port. For DC FAP Power Ports the only option available for Volts is -48.Required.f. Select the Amps (Rated) for the port. The Amps (Max) are calculated and applied based on thevalue selected for Amps (Rated). You can also select the Amps (Max) first and Amps (Rated)are calculated and applied based on value selected for Amps (Max). Requiredg. Click the "Create" button to create the Port(s)h. Once all ports are created, click Close.If the value that you want to select for Amps (rated) or Amps(Max) is not in the drop down list, you canenter the number and the ports get created with the Amps value you entered.i. Click the "Create" button to create the Port(s)j. Once all ports are created, click Close.If the data center site is in the United States, the rating value is always 80% of the max. For all othercountries, the max value is not applicable. The rating value determines the capacity of the port.6. To manually create a DC FAP Outlet port:a. Select "Rack PDU Outlet from Type drop down. Requiredb. The Inlet Name will automatically default to the first Inlet Cord in the list but can be changed ifmultiple Cords were created. Requiredc. Enter the Port Name Prefix.d. Enter the number of Ports you want to create in the "Quantity" field. You can create up to 99 out-let ports for a DC FAP item Requirede. Select a connector. Once selected, an image of the connector is displayed if an image is avail-able. Requiredf. Select the Volts for the Port. For DC FAP Power Ports the only option available for Volts is -48.Required.g. Select the Amps (Rated) for the port. The Amps (Max) are calculated and applied based on thevalue selected for Amps (Rated). You can also select the Amps (Max) first and Amps (Rated)are calculated and applied based on value selected for Amps (Max). Optionalh. Click the "Create" button to create the Port(s)i. Once all ports are created, click Close and save the item.If the data center site is in the United States, the rating value always 80% of the max. For all other coun-tries, the max value is not applicable. The rating value determines the capacity of the port.DC FAP Power Ports can also be created via File Import.Steps to create DC FAP Power Ports via file import:1. Download the Import Template from Export -> Download Import Template or from Help ->Import Template.2. In the Import Template go to the tab Data, Power & Sensor Ports and follow the instructions andexample in the sheet to import DC FAP Power Ports.You may edit DC FAP Power Ports for Items in the following statuses:• Planned• Installed• Storage• ArchivedYou must have edit privileges to edit an Item's Power Port information.The following information is editable directly in the ports list on the DC FAP’s page on the Power - nPorts subtab:Port Name - Up to 64 characters. Port names cannot be duplicated on a device.To CordIndex – Two ports of the same type cannot have same index.Port AliasColor CodeConnectorNote: For connected Ports, the connector can be updated to any other connector available in thedrop-down list, as all DC Connectors are compatible with each other.Amps (R) – For connected ports when updating to a lower value, power calculationwill be done to make sure, the connected circuit has enough power.Amps (M) – For unconnected portsCommentsYou may also edit DC FAP Power ports via file import.Steps to edit DC FAP Power Ports via file import:1. Filter the item list with DC FAP items where ports need to be edited.2. Click on Export - > Export into an Import Template -> Rack PDU Power Ports.3. In the file edit the port fields and re-import the file.

Steps to create Rack Inverter Power Ports via the Web Client.1. Select the Item from the List page and open its Detail page by double-clicking on it or clicking theEdit button on the toolbar.2. If the record was opened in View mode (used the double click method to open), click Edit on theDetail pages toolbar.3. Click the Power Port Subtab.4. Click Create Ports in the Ports section of the page. The Create Ports dialog appears.5. You must create an inlet cord before creating the first Rack Inverter Outlet port. Rack Inverter musthave DC Inlet. Second Inlet could be a DC Inlet or an AC Inlet.To manually create an inlet cord port:a. Select "Inlet" from the Type drop down. Requiredb. The Port Name Prefix will default to "Inlet" but can be changed. Requiredc. Enter the number of Ports you want to create in the "Quantity" field. You can cre-ate up to two inlet cords for a Rack Inverter item. Requiredd. Select the Phase Type for the Port.e. Select the Volts for the Port.f. Select the Amps (Rated) for the port. The Amps (Max) are calculated and appliedbased on the value selected for Amps (Rated). You can also select the Amps(Max) first and Amps (Rated) are calculated and applied based on value selectedfor Amps (Max). Requiredg. Select a connector. Once selected, an image of the connector is displayed if animage is available. Requiredh. Click the "Create" button to create the Port(s)i. Once all ports are created, click Close.If the value that you want to select for Amps (rated) or Amps (Max) is not in the drop-down list, you can enter the number and the ports get created with the Amps value youentered. If the data center site is in the United States, the rating value is always 80% ofthe max. For all other countries, the max value is not applicable. The rating value determ-ines the capacity of the port.6. Steps to manually create a Rack Inverter Outlet port:a. Select "Rack PDU Outlet from Type drop down. Requiredb. The Inlet Name will automatically default to the first Inlet Cord in the list but can bechanged if multiple Inlet Cords were created. Requiredc. Enter the Port Name Prefix. By default, it is Outlet, but it can be changed.d. Enter the number of Ports you want to create in the "Quantity" field. You can create upto 99 outlet ports for a Rack Inverter item Requirede. Select a connector. Once selected, an image of the connector is displayed if an imageis available. RequiredNote: Rack Inverter Outlet Ports are AC Ports, so the connectors drop down will list onlyAC connectors.f. Select Phase Type. Required. Available drop-down options are Single Phase (2-Wire)and Single Phase (3-Wire).g. Select the Volts for the Port. Available drop-down options include the list of Volts sup-ported for Single Phase (2-Wire) and Single Phase (3-Wire). Required.g. Select the Amps (Rated) for the port. The Amps (Max) are calculated and appliedbased on the value selected for Amps (Rated). You can also select the Amps (Max) firstand Amps (Rated) are calculated and applied based on value selected for Amps (Max).Required.h. Select the Breaker/Fuse Name. Optionali. Select the Breaker/Fuse Amps (Rated). This required only when Breaker/Fuse Nameis filled in.j. Click the "Create" button to create the Port(s)k. Once all ports are created, click Close and save the item.If the data center site is in the United States, the rating value always 80% of the max. For all other coun-tries, the max value is not applicable. The rating value determines the capacity of the port.Rack Inverter Power Ports can also be created via File Import. To create Rack Inverter Power Ports viafile import follow steps below.1. Download the Import Template from Export -> Download Import Template or from Help -> ImportTemplate.2. In the Import Template go to the tab Data, Power & Sensor Ports and follow the instructions andexample in the sheet to import Rack Inverter Power Ports.You may edit Rack Inverter Power Ports for Items in the following statuses:• Planned• Installed• Storage• ArchivedYou must have edit privileges to edit an Item's Power Port information.The following information is editable directly in the ports list on the Rack Inverter’s page on the Power -n Ports subtab:Port Name - Up to 64 characters. Port names cannot be duplicated on a device.Index – Two ports of the same type cannot have same index.Port AliasColor CodeConnectorAll Outlets for Rack Inverter must feed from the same inlet.Note: For connected DC Inlet Ports, the connector can be updated to any other connector available inthe drop-down list, as all DC Connectors are compatible with each other. For connected AC Ports, theconnector can be updated to the compatible AC connectors.Phase Type – Can be updated only for AC Inlet and Outlet Ports.Volts – Can be updated only for AC Inlet and Outlet Ports.Amps (R) – For connected ports when updating to a lower value, power calculationwill be done to make sure, the connected circuit has enough power.CB/Fuse – Only applies to port type Rack PDU Output.CB/Fuse Amps (R) - Only applies to port type Rack PDU Output. For connectedports if the value is updated lower, power validation will be done to make sure cir-cuits affected have enough power.CommentsYou may also edit Rack Inverter Power ports via file import.Steps to edit Rack Inverter Power Ports via file import:1. Filter the item list with Rack Inverter items where ports need to be edited.2. Click on Export - > Export into an Import Template -> Rack PDU Power Ports.3. In the file edit the port fields and re-import the file.Note: If you have created more than two inlets for the rack inverter, when you attempt toedit and save it, an error message will appear saying "Rack Inverter can not have morethan two Inlets, please delete the additional inlets."

dcTrack 8.1 introduces the ability to import one or more battery models with Amp-Hour ratings at various hours andDischarge VPC. This feature allows you to manage Battery model specification data sheet in dcTrack.To add battery amp hour matrix1. Go to the File import and download model template file.2. Open the model template file and in the tab Battery Amp Hour, you will find the instructions and examples.3. Add battery model amp-hour as per the specifications mentioned in manufacturer data sheet. The number ofcolumns for Amp-hours could be based on the duration of hours provided in the manufacturer's data sheet.4. Import the fileNote: Many of the manufacturer’s data sheet have the values listed in Ampere, which should be multiplied to therespective hour to get the Ampere-hour s value. Incorrect values may result into incorrect value for battery's Peuk-ert ExponentOnce the battery model amp-hour matrix are imported, the battery model details page will show this data in tabularformat and following fields become drop down.Discharge VPCCapacity 1 Rate (Hours)Capacity 2 Rate (Hours)Drop down values for the above fields are updated to include the data from the battery amp-hour table.Capacity 1 (AH) and Capacity 2 (AH) fields become read only and the values are populated based on the Capacity 1and Capacity 2 Rate (hours) selected.If the battery model do not have Battery Amp Hour matrix added then the above fields are user entered fields andyou will not see the Ampere-Hours table. Only when you enter the Ampere-Hours for the respective Discharge VPCvia file import you will see the Ampere-Hours table.Peuket Exponent is a read only field for battery models. The value for Peukert Exponent is calculated using followingformulaPeukert Exponent=( Log10(C/A) ) / ( Log10(B/A) - log10(D/C) ) whereCapacity 1 Rate (Hours) , Value A in Peukert formulaCapacity 1 AH, Value B in Peukert formulaCapacity 2 Rate (Hours), Value C in Peukert formulaCapacity 2 AH, Value D in Peukert formulaIf any of the above four fields required for calculating Peukert Exponent is blank then you will get a warning messagewhen saving the model. The model will be saved without any error.Value for the Peukert Exponent should be > 1 and < 2 , if not the model is not saved and you will get an error mes-sage.

Steps to create a Battery String for a DC Plant:1. Navigate to the Item details Page of Plant.2. In the Edit Mode, click the Create Battery Strings button on the Batteries Subtab.Note: Battery Models must be created in dcTrack before creating a Battery string.3. In the Create Battery String dialog, select the Make and Model for the Battery.4. Once the model is selected Battery Model Specification section is populated with the valuesfrom the model. The value for the Peukert Exponent is calculated based on the Battery modelspecification fields. These fields are read only and cannot be edited.If the model you have selected is missing any of the Specification fields, you will not be able to createthe Battery String and will receive an error message when saving the Plant Item.5. Battery Name Prefix. Required.6. String Name. Required7. Batteries in the String. Required. Based on the number entered, Nominal String Voltage (Vdc),Cells in String and String Voltage at Discharge (Vdc) are calculated.8. Capacity (AH) @ X Hours @ VPC. Required. For this field X is the value for Target Run TimeHours, and VPC is the Discharge VPC value for the Plant.Note: If the Discharge VPC of the Battery and the Plant are equal, and Target Run Time Hours of thePlant matches one of the Capacity Rate Hours from the Models Library, the Capacity Amp-Hours fieldis filled from the Battery Model for the matching hour, otherwise it is left blank and the user must inputthis value.9. Installation Date. OptionalAge is calculated in years based on the Installation date you have entered.10. End of Life Factor (%). Required. By default, it is set to 100 but can accept any integer between1-100.Capacity @ EOL (AH) is calculated based on the End of Life Factor (%)11. Click on Create and close.12. Save the item.Batteries created appear in the list grouped by the Battery String. The following information can beedited inline in the list.Capacity (AH) @ X HoursEnd of Life Factor (%) Accepts any integer between 1-100.Value of Capacity @ EOL (AH) and Estimated Run time Hours will be updated based on the End ofLife Factor. Estimated Run Time Hours is also updated when you enter a value for Additional Load (A).Note : Additional Load (A) value can be used to simulate additional load to determine its impact onEstimated Run TimeBattery Strings can also be created when creating Battery Items via File Import. Download the ImportTemplate file and in the Plant or Rectifer & Battery tab, follow the instructions and examples to assignthe Battery to a String when adding Batteries via File Import.Elevation in a Plant Bay works like any IT Cabinet. Rectifiers, Plant Panels and Batteries are mounted in Plant Baysin the same way Devices are mounted in Cabinets with non-rackable mounting.Like Plant Bay, DC Bays support Elevation views. DC Panels are mounted in DC Bays in the same way Devices aremounted in Cabinets with non-rackable mountingYou can use Bay Inspector to get the details about Bay Item totals, available RUs and weight capacity. Click theto open the Bay Inspector dialog.Menu options and settings for Bay elevation are the same as Cabinet Elevation.For more details on Menu options and settings for Cabinet Elevation see Use Cabinet Elevations in the Web Client.

Models for Subclass Plant Panel and DC Panels are auto created when items are created for thesetwo Subclasses.In dcTrack you can create a Plant Panel item by clicking the "Create a Panel" button in the PlantPanels Subtab of a Plant Item. When a Plant Panel item is created, its Model is auto created using theMake and Model of the Plant. Auto created Models will have the following property values:RUs - 10Height - 17.5”Width - 8.75”Depth - 3”Class - DC Power SystemSubclass - Plant PanelMounting - Non-RackableForm Factor - FixedDC Panel Items are created by clicking the "Create a Panel" button on the Power Panels subtab of aDC Bay Item. When a DC Panel Item is created, its Model is auto created using the Make and Model ofthe DC BAY. Auto created DC Panel Models will have the following property values:RUs - 10Height - 17.5”Width - 8.75”Depth - 3”Class - DC BaySubclass - DC PanelMounting - Non-RackableForm Factor - FixedNote: You cannot create Models for Subclass Plant Panel or DC Panel by clicking Add a Model in theWeb UI or via the File Import.Once these Models are auto created, you may not edit the Model's Class, Subclass, Make, Model,Mounting and Form Factor fields. You may edit the remaining Model fields via the Web UI or FileImport.Please refer to the topics below for additional informationSee Creating Editing and Deleting DC Panel Breakerssee Creating Editing and Deleting Plant Panel BreakersFor Information on Breaker Assignment for AC please seeBreaker Assignment

dcTrack 7.1 gives you an option in the UI to derate amps for UPS Banks, Floor PDUs and Floor PDUPower Panels.By default, the Amps for UPS Banks, Floor PDUs and Floor PDU Power Panels in U.S. data centersare derated to 80% of their actual capacity. If, however you have units that are manufactured to oper-ate at 100% of their capacity, you now have the option to not derate those units.Steps to derate UPS Bank Amps1. Navigate to the Item Detail page of the UPS Bank and click the Configuration subtab.2. Select the UPS Bank from the Available UPS Banks panel and click the Edit button3. Check the Derate(80%) check box4. Click Save to save the settingNotice, the Amps(Rated) value for the UPS Bank is derated by 80% of the Amps(Max) value.By default, all of the UPS Banks that are located in Data Centers who's country is listed as the UnitedStates will have this field checked. If you have UPS Banks that are manufactured to operate up to100% of their rating and do not require derating, you can uncheck this field.For Data Centers who's country is listed as something other than the United States, this Derate fieldwill be unchecked by default, however, you can edit the Item and check this option if you wish to deratethe amps of the UPS Bank to 80%.

Steps to derate Floor PDU Amps1. Navigate to the Item Detail page of the UPS Bank and click the Configuration subtab.2. Click the Items Edit button to enter edit mode.3. Check the Derate(80%) check box4. Click Save to save the settingBy default, all of the Floor PDUs that are located in Data Centers who's country is listed as theUnited States will have this field checked. If you have Floor PDUs that are manufactured to oper-ate up to 100% of their rating and do not require derating, you can uncheck this field.For Data Centers who's country is listed as something other than the United States, this Deratefield will be unchecked by default however, you can edit the Item and check this option if youwish to derate the amps of the Floor PDU to 80%.You can derate Floor PDU Power Panels while creating them by selecting the Derate(80%) check box. The derated value will be displayed in a read only field next to thecheck box.Amps for save Power Panels can be derated by selecting the Derate(80%) check box.By default, all of the Floor PDU Power Panels that are located in Data Centers who'scountry is listed as the United States will have this field checked. If you have Floor PDUPower Panels that are manufactured to operate up to 100% of their rating and do notrequire derating, you can uncheck this field.For Data Centers who's country is listed as something other than the United States, thisDerate field will be unchecked by default however, you can edit the Item and check thisoption if you wish to derate the amps of the Floor PDU Power Panels to 80%.

dcTrack items in the Sunbird Models Library file have ports already defined for them. This means you are notrequired to create ports for items.However, should you need to create additional ports or edit or delete data, power or sensor ports, do so in the WebClient directly on the item's page.Create power ports for Device, Network, and Probe class items in the Web Client.

dcTrack uses the port index number to identify ports on a device; it does not use the port name.Assign your ports the correct port index in your import spreadsheet to ensure accuracy.If needed, reference the Item Models Library or the make's documentation for the port index order of the device.If port index names and port index numbers are out of sync, dcTrack cannot identify the correct port on a device.This becomes an issue when assigning IP addresses to ports, syncing devices between dcTrack and Power IQ, andso on.If the port index number is not provided for a device, the port's default index number is assigned based on the order itis created.For example, if you create three physical data ports for a device but do not assign each port an index number, thedata ports are assigned index numbers of 1, 2 and 3 in the order they are created on the device.Note: This applies to all port creation methods - manually creating ports in the Web Client, creating ports whenimporting items using the File Import, and creating ports using an API.When creating ports on devices, follow these rules:No two ports of the same type can have the same index number. This means:Each physical, logical or virtual data port index number must be uniqueEach sensor port index number must be uniqueEach power supply port index number must be uniqueA port index number cannot be 0.Devices cannot have more than 98 power supply ports, so power port index numbers can only be numbered 1-For example:If port index numbers are out of sync for any reason, you can manually update the index numbering for data portsand sensor ports on the Data - N Ports tab and Sensor - N Ports tab of the item's page in the Web Client.You can use the Item Models Library to verify the port index numbers used for devices.Create power ports for Device, Network, and Probe class items in the Web Client.Power ports are created by increasing the number of ports on the device.Create a power port for items in the following statuses:PlannedInstalledPowered-offOff-SiteStorageArchivedTo create a power port:1. In the Web Client, click Assets > Items List.2. Click on the Power Supply- n Ports tab on the Create New Item page, or open an existing item's page in editmode.3. Click Edit to enter Edit mode for the Item4. Enter the Port Name Prefix - Port Names will be created with this prefix plus the Index5. Quantity - create new power ports, up to 98 maximum6. Redundancy - select the power redundancy, if needed.For example, one port = N (no redundancy), one port and one redundant port is N+1, one port and two redundantports is N+2, and so on.7. Click Save at the top of the item's page.

Build power circuitsSee Build a "Normal" Power Circuit and Build a Partial Power Circuits.Edits made to one power port are made to all power ports of the same type on the item.Edit a power port for items in the following statuses:PlannedInstalledPowered-offOff-SiteStorageArchivedYou must have edit privileges to edit an item's power port information.To edit power port information on an item's page:1. Go to Assets > Items List.2. Open an existing item's page in edit mode.Directly update any of these fields in the port list on the Port - n Port tab:Power Port Name - up to 64 characters. Port names cannot be duplicated on a device.Port Alias - User defined port nameIndex - editable. Two ports cannot have the same index number.Color Code - Can be updated by selecting a value from the drop down list or selecting a blank value to clear theColor Code.Connector - For connected ports, must be compatible with the connector of the port it is connected to.Phase Type - Can be updated, changing the Phase Type will update the Volts drop down choices. When theports are connected Phase Type cannot be edited.Volts – Can be updated, however if the ports are connected Volts cannot be edited.Watts (Nameplate) - Can be updated.Watts (Budgeted) – Can be updated to a value less than or equal to Watts (Nameplate).Power Factor - Can be updated. Accepted values are integer between 0.01 and 1.Port Status -User defined Status. These options are set through Field Management Pick List OptionsComments - Can be updated to up to 500 characters3. Click Save at the top of the item's page.

Bulk Edit feature allows you to edit port attributes of multiple power supply ports.To bulk edit power supply port information on an item's page:1. Go to Asset List and an existing item in edit mode.2. In the Power Supply Ports sub tab, select multiple power supply ports.3. Click Bulk Edit.4. Provide following information to update the ports.a. Select Column to update : In the drop down, select the port field that you want to bulk update.b. Select Value : In the drop down, select the field value. The drop down list will be populated based onthe column selected.5. Click Apply. If you want to clear the data on the select field, click Clear.6. Save the item.Following are the rules for data ports that can be updated using Bulk Edit optionColor Code : Can be updated to any color code from the drop down list.Comments : Can be updated by entering a value.Connector : For connected ports, the drop down to choose from is reduced to only the Com-patible connectors for all the selected ports that are connected. If there is at least one uncon-nected port, then all power connectors will be available to select from. As each port is updatedwith the selected connector, the compatibility is checked for that port and the port is skipped ifthe chosen connector is not compatible with the port connector on the other end of the con-nection.Phase Type : Can be updated to another Phase Type from the drop down list. Cannot beupdated if the selected ports are connected.Power Factor : Can be updated by entering a value.Power Supply Part : Can be updated to any Power Supply Part Instance from the drop down list.Volts : Can be updated to a value from the drop down list for the ports that are not connected. Ifthe selected ports have different Phase Type, then Volts cannot be updated.Watts (N) : Can be updated by entering a value.Watts (B) : Can be updated by entering a value. Watts (B) must be less than or equal to Watts(N).Note: When all selected ports for Bulk Edit are connected, the Phase Type and Volts fields cannot beedited. If some of the selected ports are connected, these fields will be available for bulk editing, butconnected ports will be skipped during the update. A message will be displayed indicating how manyports were skipped.Following fields can be cleared using Bulk EditWire GaugeColor CodeCommentPower ports are removed by decreasing the number of ports on a device.You cannot remove power ports that are connected as part of a circuit, so you cannot decrease the number of powerports below the number of connected ports.For example, if you have 3 power ports and 2 of them are being used, you cannot decrease the number of ports to 1.Remove a power port for items in the following statuses:PlannedInstalledPowered-offOff-SiteStorageArchivedTo remove power ports:1. In the Web Client, click Assets > Items List.2. Open an existing item's page in edit mode.3. Click on the Power - n Ports tab.4. From the Quantity drop-down, select a lower number of ports.5. Click Yes to confirm.6. Redundancy - update the redundancy, if needed.7. Click Save at the top of the item's page.

Delete a power port for items in the following statuses:PlannedInstalledPowered-offOff-SiteStorageArchivedYou must have edit privileges to delete ports.A connected power port cannot be deleted, so the Delete icon on the Port tab is disabled.To delete a power port:1. In the Web Client, click Assets > Items List.2. Open an existing item's page in edit mode.3. Click on the Power - n Ports tab.4. Click on the port or ports you want to delete. Use Ctrl + click to select multiple ports at once.5. Click Delete on the Power - n Ports tab.Create a new data circuit using the selected port as the first node by clicking on the port name on the Power - n Portstab on an item's page.Select a single port to start building one circuit, or use Ctrl + click to select multiple ports start building several, thenclick Connect.The New Power Circuit page(s) open under the Connectivity tab.The first node is the item you connected from, and the Node 2 dialog opens automatically so you can begin buildingyour circuit.For more information on building circuits, see Building New Circuits for Items.

See Trace a Power Port Circuit from the Power Port Tab (Web Client).In dcTrack 7.1 it is possible to support Item and Model Power Supplies who's Ports require a differentPhase Type, Connector, Volts and Power Factor.When changing the Phase Type the Volt drop down will be updated base on the Phase Type selected.Note : You no longer need to check the Optional field when Item or Model Power Supply Ports havedifferent Phase Yype, Connector, Volts or Power Factor.Values for Watts(N) and Watts(B) should be same for all the power supplies.

Create a data port on an item in the Web Client manually, or using a template of an existing port.Create data ports when you create Device, Network, UPS, Floor PDU, Rack PDU, HVAC and Probe class items, oradd them to existing items.Alternatively, apply a Data Port Template instead of creating the port.See Apply a Data Port Template to an Item (Web Client) and Create a Data Port Template (Web Client).Create a data port for items in the following statuses:PlannedInstalledPowered-offOff-SiteStorageArchivedYou must have edit privileges to create a port.To create a data port:1. In the Web Client, click Assets > Items List.2. Click on the Data - n Ports tab on the Create New Item page, or open an existing item's page in edit mode.3. Click Create Port.The create port fields appear.4. Select the Port Type:Physical - applies to all supported item classesLogical - applies to bladesVirtual - applies to virtual machines5. Quantity - total number of ports to create. Up to 288 physical ports, and 1 virtual or 1 logical port for networkblades6. Port Name Prefix - update the prefix of the port name, use up to 64 characters. dcTrack numbers ports sequen-tially. Port names must be unique. If port names are duplicated, you cannot save.7. Start Label Index - the default value is the next available index which is 1 greater than the highest existing index.You can enter any numeric value greater than 1. Port indexes must be unique, so if the value you enter exists,you will be prompted to provide a different value.8. Connector - required for Physical data port types only9. Channels - number of channels for the port. The default value is 1.10. Card Part - Card Part assigned to be assigned to the port.11. Media - applies to Physical ports onlyAnyCoaxMulti-ModeSingle-ModeTwinaxTwisted Pair12. Protocol - protocol used by the port to make a connection13. Data Rate - data rate specified for the port14. Color Code - applied to the port15. Grouping/VLAN - applies to the port16. MAC Address - up to 64 character17. Comments - up to 500 characters18. Click Create.The new data ports are displayed on the item page, and the number in the Data - N Port tab is updated.dcTrack uses the port index number to identify the port; it does not use the port name. For information on port index-ing and possible impacts, see Port Index Numbering and Port Naming.15. Click Save at the top of the item's page to add the ports.16. For next steps, see After Creating Data Ports.Create a Data Port Template based on the port (Optional). See Create a Data Port Template (Web Client).Place the ports on the item. See Port Placement Options.

Instead of entering data port information manually, apply a Data Port Template.Templates are created when a data port is originally created. See Create a Data Port Template (Web Client).To apply a Data Port Template when creating a port:1. Click on the Data - n Ports tab on the Create New Item page, or an item's page in edit mode.2. Click Create Port.The create port fields appear.3. From the Port Template box, click on the port template you want to apply.4. Click Apply Template.The port fields are populated with the exception of Quantity, MAC Address and Comments fields. Update them asneeded.If desired, create a new template based on this template by clicking 'Add to Templates'.5. Click Create.The new data ports are displayed on the item page, and the number in the Data Port tab is updated.6. Click Save at the top of the item's page to save the new ports to the item.Create a data port, save its configuration as a template, then apply to other data ports on Device, Network, UPS,Floor PDU, Rack PDU, HVAC and Probe class items.Templates are available across sites.You must have edit privileges to create a template.Create templates from the same classes of items in the same statuses as you can to create data ports.To create a port template:1. Create a data port for an item. See Create a Data Port.2. Enter Type, Protocol and Data Rate at a minimum to create a template.3. Click 'Add to Templates'.The data port configuration is saved as template.All elements of the configuration with the exception of Quantity, MAC Address and Comments are displayed in thePort Templates box.Note: The index number in the port name is 0, for example Eth0, so numbering restarts when the template isapplied to another port.Note: Templates cannot be edited. They must be deleted and recreated.

Create, edit, and delete rack PDU data ports like all others.Trace rack PDU data circuit connections, and start new data circuit connections directly from the Data - n Port tab onan item's page by clicking the Connections icon.For details on these functions, see Data Ports.If a template is applied to a data port, the data port is not affected when the template is deleted.To delete a template:1. Click on the Data - n Ports tab on the Create New Item page, or an item's page in edit mode.2. Click Create Port.The create port fields appear.3. In the Port Template box, click on the template you want to delete, then click Delete Template.The template is deleted. Note that clicking Cancel does not cancel the deletion.

Edit a data port for items in the following statuses:PlannedInstalledPowered-offOff-SiteStorageArchivedYou must have edit privileges to edit an item's data port information.To edit data port information on an item's page:1. In the Web Client, click Assets > Items List.2. Open an existing item's page in edit mode.Directly update any of these fields in the port list on the Data - n Port tab:Port Type - Port Type can be edited only for Device/Blade Server and Network/Blade subclasses sincethese are the only one where the data port supports more than one port typePort Name - Must be unique for an item and cannot be the same as any other Port Alias for the itemPort Alias - User defined port name. Must be unique for an item and cannot be the same as any other PortName for the item.Index - editable. Logical and physical blades can have duplicate port index numbers, but ports on the samedevice cannot.Channels - Cannot be updated if ports are connected.Color Code - Can be updated by selecting a value from the drop-down list. To clear the existing value,select the blank choice at the top.Connector - Required only for physical ports. When the port type is Logical or Virtual, the Connector columnis not required and can be left blank. For connected ports, the newly selected connector must be compatiblewith the connector of the port on the other end of the connection.Media - Required for Physical ports only. When the port type is Logical or Virtual, the Media column is notrequired and can be left blank. This column cannot be updated if ports are connectedProtocol - Can be updated by selecting a value from the drop down list.Data Rate - Can be updated by selecting a value from the drop down list.Grouping/VLAN - Can be updated by selecting a value from the drop-down list. To clear the existing value,select the blank choice at the top.MAC Address - up to 64 charactersCard Part - Can be updated by selecting Card Part instance from the drop-down.Port Status -User defined Status. These options are set through Field Management Pick List OptionsComments - Accepts up to 500 characters.3. Click Save at the top of the item's page.Bulk Edit feature allows you to edit port attributes of multiple data ports.To bulk edit data port information on an item's page:1. Go to Asset List and an existing item in edit mode.2. In the Data Ports sub tab, select multiple data ports.3. Click Bulk Edit.4. Provide following information to update the ports.a.
