Select Column to update : In the drop down, select the port field that you want to bulk update.b. Select Value : In the drop down, select the field value. The drop down list will be populated based onthe column selected.5. Click Apply. If you want to clear the data on the select field, click Clear.6. Save the item.Following are the rules for data ports that can be updated using Bulk Edit optionColor Code : Can be updated to any color code from the drop down list.Grouping/VLAN : Can be updated to any value from the drop down list.Channels : Can be updated by entering a value. For connected Ports, Channels cannot beupdated.Connector : For connected ports, the drop down to choose from is reduced to only the Com-patible connectors for all the selected ports. If there is at least one unconnected port, then alldata connectors will be available to select from. As each port is updated with the selected con-nector, the compatibility is checked for that port and the port is skipped if the chosen connectoris not compatible with the port connector on the other end of the connection.Media : Can only be updated for ports that are not connected. When Media is selected, if a con-nected port is among the selected ports during the update, that port will be skippedCassette Part : Can be updated to any Cassette Part Instance from the drop down list.SFP Part : Can be updated to any SFP Part Instance from the drop down list.Data Rate : Can be updated to any Data Rate selected from the drop down listProtocol : Can be updated to any Data Rate selected from the drop down list.Comments : Can be updated by entering a value.Following fields can be cleared with bulk editGrouping/VLANColor CodeCommentCard PartSFP Part

Delete a data port for items in the following statuses:PlannedInstalledPowered-offOff-SiteStorageArchivedYou must have edit privileges to delete ports.A connected data port cannot be deleted, so the Delete icon on the Port tab is disabled.To delete a data port:1. In the Web Client, click Assets > Items List.2. Open an existing item's page in edit mode.3. Click on the Data - n Ports tab.4. Click on the port or ports you want to delete. Use Ctrl + click to select multiple ports at once.5. Click Delete on the Data - n Ports tab.6. Click Save at the top of the item's page to save the changes to the item.Note: To undo a delete port, before saving the page, click Refresh at the top of the page and select Yes whenprompted not to save your changes. The port is restored, but keep in mind that any other changes you made to theitem before the save are lost.After a valid IP address is assigned to an item's data port, it is displayed on the item's page on the Data - n Ports tabunder the IP Address column.If the link is active, click on it to link to the server.If the server is found and provides a web interface, it opens in a secondary browser window.

Create a new data circuit using the selected port as the first node by clicking on the port name on the Data - n Portstab on an item's page.Select a single port to start building one circuit, or use Ctrl + click to select multiple ports start building several, thenclick Connect.The New Data Circuit page opens under the Connectivity tab.When you select multiple ports and click Connect, you can build the circuits in single tab.The first Node is the item you connected from, and Node 2 is highlighted in blue. You can select the item for thisnode from the item list below and build your circuit.For more information on building circuits, see Build Data and Power Circuits.The 'connected item' is the item connected to the data port.Once an item is connected, the connected item's name becomes a link to that item's page.Access this link from the Data - n Ports tab under the Connected Item column.This column also have an icon next to the Connected Item link which implies the status of the circuitIcon I is for Installed circuits and P is for Planned circuits.You must have View access and above to perform this function.If the port has multiple channels, the same port may connect to multiple items. In that case, the connected item linktext will say 'Multiple Items'. When this link text is clicked the connected items for that port will show at the right in thePort List. Each connected item is linked to it's item details page and it also have an icon which implies the status ofthe Circuit.When the link text 'Multiple Items' is clicked again, the Connected Items list on the right disappears and port listreturns to normal mode.The Port List toolbar includes an Expand Channels button, which appears only if at least one port in the list has mul-tiple channels. If all ports are single-channel, this button remains hidden.Clicking Expand Channels expands the port list to display one row per channel. For example, a port with 6 channelswill show 6 rows, one for each channel. The button label 'Expand Channel' changes to 'Collapse Channel' and click-ing it again will collapse the port list.

See Trace a Data Port Circuit from the Data Port Tab (Web Client).Amp readings for rack PDUs are displayed on the Power - n Ports tab of a rack PDU's item page in the Web Client.Users with View access and above can access an item's page and view the readings.Readings are available once devices are connected to a port on the rack PDU, and are powered up.

Power Ports for Rack PDU AC Power, Rack Transfer Switch and Rack UPS can be edited.Edit a power port for items in the following statuses:PlannedInstalledPowered-offOff-SiteStorageYou must have edit privileges to edit an item's power port information.The following rack PDU information is editable directly in the ports list on the rack PDU's page on the Power - n Portstab:Port Name - Up to 64 characters. Port names cannot be duplicated or be same as Port Alias.Port Alias - User defined port name. Can be updated however it cannot be same as Port Name or Port Alias ofanother PortIndex – Two ports of the same type cannot have same index.Channels - Can be updated for Rack PDU outlets when the ports are not connected.Color Code - Can be updated by selecting a value from the drop down list or selecting a blank value to clear theColor CodeConnector - For connected ports, must be compatible with the connector of the port it is connected to.Phase Type - Can be updated for the ports that are not connected. Changing the phase updates the Volts dropdown choices..Volts - Can be updated for the ports that are not connected.Phase Legs - When Phase Leg is updated, CB/Fuse column will get cleared. Cannot be updated for connectedports.CB/Fuse Amps(R) - Only applies to Port Type Rack PDU Output. This column is required when CB/Fuse isselected for a Port.CB/Fuse – Only applies to port type Rack PDU Output. When changing the CB/Fuse column the drop down willexclude the choices that are used on other ports with different phase legs.Port Status -User defined Status. These options are set through Field Management Pick List OptionsComments - Can be updated.View rack PDU-specific power data, edit certain rack PDU power port information, and access the page of a deviceconnected to a rack PDU.Create Rack PDU Power Ports and Edit a Power Port on a Rack PDU.Create, edit, delete and sync sensors on rack PDUs. See Creating Sensor Ports for Rack PDUs and Probes(Web Client).For details, see:Power PortsEdit a Power Port on a Rack PDUAccess a Connected Item's Page from a Rack PDU Page (Web Client)

When Power IQ Integration is enabled in dcTrack, sensor readings are retrieved automatically from items.Readings are also retrieved for asset strips attached to PX devices being managed by dcTrack, since PX devicesare added to dcTrack as probes.Once Power IQ Integration is enabled, sensor ports cannot be created or deleted in dcTrack.Sensors are detected by dcTrack once added and connected, and readings are pulled from the Power IQ side of theapplication.Some sensor information can be edited on the sensor sub-tab on the item pages in the Web Client.See Edit Sensor Ports (Web Client).Note: Do not disable Power IQ Integration to create or delete sensor port information.

Create rack PDU power ports in the dcTrack Web UI.1. Select the Item from the List page and open its Detail page by double-clicking on it or clicking the Edit button onthe toolbar.2. If the record was opened in View mode (used the double click method to open), click Edit on the Detail pagestoolbar.3. Click the Power Port Subtab.4. Click Create Ports in the Ports section of the page. The Create Ports dialog appears.5. You must create an input cord before creating the first Rack PDU Output port. To manually create an input cordport:a. Select "Inlet" from the Type drop down. Required. You can create up to 4 Inlets for a Rack PDU. Requiredb. Enter the number of Ports you want to create in the "Quantity" field. Requiredc. Select the Phase Type for the input cord (that is, for the rack PDU). Requiredd. Select the Volts and Amps (Rated) for the port. The Amps (Max) are calculated and applied based on thesevalues. Requirede. Select a connector. Once selected, an image of the connector is displayed if an image is available. Requiredf. Click the "Create" button to create the Port(s)a.b. Once all ports are created, click Close.If the data center site is in the United States, the rating value is always 80% of the max. For all other countries, themax value is not applicable. The rating value determines the capacity of the port.6. To manually create a Rack PDU Output port:a. Select "Outlet" from Type drop down. Requiredb. The Input Name will automatically default to the first Input Cord in the list but can be changed if multipleInput Cords were created. Requiredc. The Port Name Prefix will default to "Output" but can be changedd. Enter the number of Ports you want to create in the "Quantity" field. Requirede. Select a connector. Once selected, an image of the connector is displayed if an image is available. Requiredf. Enter the number of Channels. Required. By default the Channels value of Connector is populated.g. Select the Phase Type for the receptacle. RequiredIf the input cord is 3-phase, you must also select the phase leg that indicates the phase or phasesthe receptacle is wired to.h. Select the Volts and Amps (Rated) for the port. The Amps (Max) are calculated and applied based on thesevalues. Requiredi. Select the Breaker/Fuse Name. Optionalj. Select the Breaker/Fuse Amps (Rated). Optionalk. Click the "Create" button to create the Port(s)l. Once all ports are created, click Close.Follow the same steps mentioned above to create Power Ports for Rack UPS.If the data center site is in the United States, the rating value always 80% of the max. For all other countries, the maxvalue is not applicable. The rating value determines the capacity of the port.7. To manually create a data port/comm port:a. See Create a Data Port.8. To manually create a temperature or humidity port:a. See Create Sensor Ports for Sensors in Cabinets (Web Client).10. Click Port Inspector to open the dialog containing the front and rear view of the device you are adding the port to.From this dialog, you can define the location of the ports on the equipment. For more details on this function, seePort Placement Options in online help.View rack PDU-specific power data, edit certain rack PDU power port information, and access the page of a deviceconnected to a rack PDU.Create Rack PDU Power Ports and Edit a Power Port on a Rack PDU.Create, edit, delete and sync sensors on rack PDUs. See Creating Sensor Ports for Rack PDUs and Probes(Web Client).For details, see:Power PortsEdit a Power Port on a Rack PDUAccess a Connected Item's Page from a Rack PDU Page (Web Client)

Power Ports for Rack PDU AC Power, Rack Transfer Switch and Rack UPS can be edited.Edit a power port for items in the following statuses:PlannedInstalledPowered-offOff-SiteStorageYou must have edit privileges to edit an item's power port information.The following rack PDU information is editable directly in the ports list on the rack PDU's page on the Power - n Portstab:Port Name - Up to 64 characters. Port names cannot be duplicated or be same as Port Alias.Port Alias - User defined port name. Can be updated however it cannot be same as Port Name or Port Alias ofanother PortIndex – Two ports of the same type cannot have same index.Channels - Can be updated for Rack PDU outlets when the ports are not connected.Color Code - Can be updated by selecting a value from the drop down list or selecting a blank value to clear theColor CodeConnector - For connected ports, must be compatible with the connector of the port it is connected to.Phase Type - Can be updated for the ports that are not connected. Changing the phase updates the Volts dropdown choices..Volts - Can be updated for the ports that are not connected.Phase Legs - When Phase Leg is updated, CB/Fuse column will get cleared. Cannot be updated for connectedports.CB/Fuse Amps(R) - Only applies to Port Type Rack PDU Output. This column is required when CB/Fuse isselected for a Port.CB/Fuse – Only applies to port type Rack PDU Output. When changing the CB/Fuse column the drop down willexclude the choices that are used on other ports with different phase legs.Port Status -User defined Status. These options are set through Field Management Pick List OptionsComments - Can be updated.Bulk Edit feature allows you to edit port attributes of multiple Rack PDU Power ports.To bulk edit rack pdu power ports information on an item's page:1. Go to Asset List and open an existing rack pdu item in edit mode.2. In the Power Ports sub tab, select multiple ports.3. Click Bulk Edit.4. Provide following information to update the ports.a. Select Column to update : In the drop down, select the port field that you want to bulk update.b. Select Value : In the drop down, select the field value. The drop down list will be populated based onthe column selected.5. Click Apply. If you want to clear the data on the select field, click Clear.6. Save the item.Following are the rules for data ports that can be updated using Bulk Edit optionChannels : Can be updated for Rack PDU Outlets. If the Rack PDU Outlets are connected,channels cannot be updated.Color Code : Can be updated to any color code from the drop down list.Comments : Can be updated by entering a value.Connector : For connected ports, the drop down to choose from is reduced to only the Com-patible connectors for all the selected ports that are connected. If there is at least one uncon-nected port, then all power connectors will be available to select from. As each port is updatedwith the selected connector, the compatibility is checked for that port and the port is skipped ifthe chosen connector is not compatible with the port connector on the other end of the con-nection.Phase Type : Can be updated to another Phase Type from the drop down list. Cannot beupdated if the selected ports are connected or if the selected ports have different Port Types.Phase Legs : Can be updated for Rack PDU Outlets. When the selected ports for Bulk Edit havedifferent Phase Legs, then the Phase Legs cannot be bulk Edited.Rating (A) : Can be updated by entering a value.CB/Fuse : Can be updated by selecting a value from the drop down list.CB/Fuse Amps(R) : Can be updated by entering a value.Note: When all selected ports for Bulk Edit are connected, the Phase Type cannot be edited. If someof the selected ports are connected, this field will be available for bulk editing, but connected ports willbe skipped during the update. A message will be displayed indicating how many ports were skipped.Following fields can be cleared using Bulk EditColor CodeComment

Steps to create Rack Transfer Switch Power Ports.1. Select the Item from the List page and open its Detail page by double-clicking on it or clicking theEdit button on the toolbar.2. If the record was opened in View mode (used the double click method to open), click Edit on theDetail pages toolbar.3. Click the Power Port Subtab.4. Click Create Ports in the Ports section of the page. The Create Ports dialog appears.5. You must create inlets before creating the first Rack Transfer Switch Outlet port.To manually create an inlet cord port:a. Select "Inlet" from the Type drop down. Requiredb. The Port Name Prefix will default to "Inlet" but can be changed. RequiredNumber of Inlets for a Rack Transfer Switch must be 0 or 2. Quantity field is readonly.c. Select the Phase Type.d. Select the Volts.e. Select the Amps (Rated) for the ports. The Amps (Max) are calculated andapplied based on the value selected for Amps (Rated). You can also select theAmps (Max) first and Amps (Rated) are calculated and applied based on valueselected for Amps (Max). Requiredf. Select a connector. Once selected, an image of the connector is displayed if animage is available. Requiredg. Click the "Create" button to create the Port(s)h. Once all ports are created, click Close.If the value that you want to select for Amps (rated) or Amps (Max) is not in the drop-down list, you can enter the number and the ports get created with the Amps value youentered. If the data center site is in the United States, the rating value is always 80% ofthe max. For all other countries, the max value is not applicable. The rating value determ-ines the capacity of the port.6. Steps to manually create a Rack Transfer Switch Outlet port:a. Select Outlet from Type drop down. Requiredb. Select the Fed From. Fed From drop down have third option, Transfer Switch in addi-tion to the two Inlets. By default Transfer Switch will be selected. Requiredc. Enter the Port Name Prefix. By default, it is Outlet, but it can be changed.d. Enter the number of Ports you want to create in the "Quantity" field. You can create upto 99 outlet ports for a Rack Inverter item Requirede. Select a connector. Once selected, an image of the connector is displayed if an imageis available. Requiredf. Select Phase Type. Required. Available drop-down options are Single Phase (2-Wire)and Single Phase (3-Wire).g. Select the Volts for the Port. Available drop-down options include the list of Volts sup-ported for Single Phase (2-Wire) and Single Phase (3-Wire). Required.g. Select the Amps (Rated) for the port. The Amps (Max) are calculated and appliedbased on the value selected for Amps (Rated). You can also select the Amps (Max) firstand Amps (Rated) are calculated and applied based on value selected for Amps (Max).Required.h. Select the Breaker/Fuse Name. Optionali. Select the Breaker/Fuse Amps (Rated). This required only when Breaker/Fuse Nameis filled in.j. Click the "Create" button to create the Port(s)k. Once all ports are created, click Close and save the item.If the data center site is in the United States, the rating value always 80% of the max. For all other coun-tries, the max value is not applicable. The rating value determines the capacity of the port.Rack Transfer Switch Power Ports can also be created via File Import. To create Rack Transfer SwitchPower Ports via file import follow steps below.1. Download the Import Template from Export -> Download Import Template or from Help -> ImportTemplate.2. In the Import Template go to the tab Data, Power & Sensor Ports and follow the instructions.dcTrack allows you to track the Active and Preferred status for Rack Transfer Switch (RTS) Inlets. Forintegrated RTS, the status is retrieved from Power IQ . For non integrated RTS, the Active status canbe set manually.While in Edit mode, you can switch the load for both integrated and non-integrated RTS, however ifintegrated with Power IQ, the next refresh from Power IQ will reset the Active status to once againmatch the status from Power IQ.The Preferred and Active state will appear beside each port name for integrated RTS.For non integrated RTS only the Active status is displayed and will also appear beside the port name.A single integrated RTS inlet can also be both Preferred and Active.The load can only be modeled on connected Inlets. If the load is manually switched to a disconnectedinlet it will automatically revert back to the connected Inlet. To modify the Active inlet, select the Inletfrom the "Model Load on Inlet" drop down. Note, only connected Inlets are enabled in the drop down.When switching from one connected Inlet to another, upon saving you will receive a message indic-ating ""This will change the inlet feeding all the rack pdu outlets wired to the transfer switch andall circuits connected through these outlets will be updated to the selected inlet."

Amp readings for rack PDUs are displayed on the Power - n Ports tab of a rack PDU's item page in the Web Client.Users with View access and above can access an item's page and view the readings.Readings are available once devices are connected to a port on the rack PDU, and are powered up.Power Ports for Whip Power Outlets and Busway Power Outlets are auto created when crating the breakers.However, for the Whip Power Outlet additional Ports can also be created.To create additional Power Ports on Whip Power Outlets1. Go to Asset List and an existing whip power outlet in edit mode.2. In the Power Ports sub tab, click Create Port3. Provide following information to create the Port.a. Port Name : Required. It must be unique.b. Connector : Required. Drop down values include all the ac power connectors from the library.c. Channels : Required. Default value is 1, otherwise it inherit the Channel value from the Connectorselectedd. Color Code : Optional. Drop down values include the pick list choices for Color field from Field Man-agement.e. Wire Gauge : Optional. Drop down values include the pick list choices for Wire Gauge field from FieldManagementf. Phase Type : Read Only. Auto-populated with the phase type of the breaker connected to the outlet.g. Volts : Read Only. Auto-populated with the volts of the breaker connected to the outlet.h. Amps (Rated) : Read Only. Auto-populated with the Amps(Rated) of the breaker connected to the out-let.5. Click Create.6. Save the item.Whip Power Outlet Ports can be bulk edited.Fields that can be bulk edited areChannels : Can be updated for Rack PDU Outlets. If the Rack PDU Outlets are connected,channels cannot be updated.Color Code : Can be updated to any color code from the drop down list.Comments : Can be updated by entering a value.Connector : For connected ports, the drop down to choose from is reduced to only the Com-patible connectors for all the selected ports that are connected. If there is at least one uncon-nected port, then all power connectors will be available to select from. As each port is updatedwith the selected connector, the compatibility is checked for that port and the port is skipped ifthe chosen connector is not compatible with the port connector on the other end of the con-nection.Wire Gauge : Can be updated by selecting a value from the drop down list.Following fields can be cleared using Bulk EditColor CodeCommentWire Gauge

Create sensor ports for rack PDUs and probes in the Web Client when you create a new item, or add ports to exist-ing items.Create a sensor port for items in the following statuses:PlannedInstalledPowered-offOff-SiteStorageArchived

Note: If the Create Port icon is not displayed, Power IQ Integration is enabled and is being used to retrieve assetstrip and/or sensor readings. Sensor ports cannot be created while Power IQ Integration is enabled.To create a sensor port for sensors in a cabinet:1. In the Web Client, click Assets > Items List.2. Click on the Sensor - n Ports tab on the Create New Item page, or open an existing item's page in edit mode.3. Click Create Port.The create sensor fields appear.4. Port Type - sensor port type Required:TemperatureHumidityAsset Strip - only one asset strip sensor port is supported per cabinetAir FlowAir PressureContact Closure - status of either on or off5. Quantity - up to 9999 ports RequiredPort Name Prefix - the sensor port name, up to 64 characters. Each port name must be unique. Defaults totype + nnnn Required6. Sensor Location - leave selected to create in cabinet sensors.To create external sensors, see Create Sensor Ports for Sensors Outside of Cabinets (Web Client).7. Cabinet - the cabinet the sensor is located in/on8. Position - the sensor's position in/on the cabinet9. Comments - up to 500 characters10. Click Create. The Sensor port is added to the item.The new port is displayed on the list on Sensor - n Ports tab.

Create ports for sensors that are not contained in cabinets, such as sensors mounted on the ceiling, wall and so on.The sensor is then plugged in to a sensor port on a rack PDU in a cabinet.Note: If the Create Port icon is not displayed, Power IQ Integration is enabled and is being used to retrieve assetstrip and/or sensor readings. Sensor ports cannot be created while Power IQ Integration is enabled.To create a sensor port for sensors outside a cabinet:1. In the Web Client, click Assets > Items List.2. Click on the Sensor - n Ports tab on the Create New Item page, or open an existing item's page in edit mode.3. Click Create Port.The create sensor fields appear.4. Port Type - sensor port type Required:TemperatureHumidityAsset Strip - only one asset strip sensor port is supported per cabinetAir FlowAir PressureContact Closure - status of either on or off5. Quantity - up to 9999 ports RequiredPort Name Prefix - the sensor port name, up to 64 characters. Each port name must be unique. Defaults totype + nnnn Required6. Select External.7. Enter the sensor's position in the data center using the X,Y,Z coordinate fields. Optional.The X,Y coordinators indicate the sensor's position on the data center floor, and the Z coordinate indicates thesensor's height off the data center floor.Access the location's floor map and hover your mouse over the area the sensor is located to get its approximate X,Ycoordinates.Enter the Z coordinate based on your knowledge.To access the floor map from the item's page:a. On the Create Sensor Port page, click Create to save the sensor information entered so far.b. Next, click Floor Maps at the top of the item page.The Floor Maps page opens under the Visualization tab, and displays the floor map the sensor is located on.c. Hover your mouse over the area the sensor is located on the floor map, and note the X,Y coordinates thatappear at the bottom of the page.d. Click the Assets tab to return to the item's page.8. In the Sensor - n Ports tab, click on the X,Y,Z field of the sensor.9. Enter the X, Y cabinet coordinates from the floor map, then enter the sensor's distance from the cabinet as the Zcoordinate. Separate each coordinate with a comma, but no spaces.For example, 5.6,35.3,9.010. Click Save at the top of the item's page.Provided you have edit privileges to an item in dcTrack, you can assign IP addresses to data ports.Specifically, you can:Assign a unique IP address to an individual portThe IP address is specific to the one port.Assign multiple IP addresses to the same portdcTrack also supports port teaming.Port teaming allows you to assign the same IP address to multiple ports on the same Port Team. You can then man-age each port together via the single IP address, or manage each port individually via the single IP address.Note: dcTrack uses the term "port teaming" to refer to this practice. However, this practice is also referred to as linkaggregation, port trunking, link bundling, Ethernet bonding, network bonding, NIC bonding and NIC teaming.IP addresses are assigned to item data ports in the Web Client on an item's page while it is in Edit mode from theData - Ports tab via a IP Address Assignments dialog.IP addresses are assigned to ports in one of two ways:Select Available IP Addresses for the Selected Subnet.Enter the IP Address Information.

In order to assign an IP address, the item must be added to and saved in dcTrack, and at least one data port mustexist for it. If there are no data ports, there is nothing to assign an IP address to.Items in the Item Models Library have their data ports already predefined for them, but you can create data ports foritems, if needed. See Creating and Managing Ports.Supported IP Address Internet ProtocolIPv4 addresses are supported by dcTrack.Items in the following classes can have IP addresses assigned to them or port teams created for them:Device itemsNetwork itemsUPS unitsFloor PDUsRack PDUsCooling unitsProbes

To assign an IP address or set up a port team, the item must be in one of the following statuses:PlannedInstalledPowered-offOff-siteStorageArchivedAssign IP addresses or create port teams when you add an item and configure its ports, or at a later time.Once assigned, the IP address can be edited or deleted. For impacts of editing and deleting, see Impacts of Editingand Deleting IP Addresses Assigned to Item Data Ports.Refer to each topic for edit or delete impacts, if any.dcTrack allows you to assign multiple IP addresses to the same data port.The data port is assigned a primary IP address.Each additional IP address that is assigned to the port is designated as a 'virtual' IP address, meaning it is not theport's primary IP address.Virtual IP addresses are used for tracking purposes only in dcTrack.You can assign the primary address to the port before or after a virtual address.Use one of the following methods to assign an address to an individual field:Select Available IP Addresses for the Selected SubnetOrEnter the IP Address InformationTo assign multiple addresses to the same port:1. Open the IP Address Assignment dialog if you do not have it open.2. Click the Add icon at the top left of the dialog.3. From the Port drop-down, select the same port as the port you assigned the primary address to.4. Select or enter the IP address to assign as the virtual address.dcTrack validates the IP address at this point.Warnings icons are displayed next to the IP address field and Gateway field if the IP address is used as a Gatewayaddress for a port.5. Select a new IP address or use the address you selected.The CIDR (Classless Inter-Domain Routing), Mask, Gateway and Hostname fields are all populated automaticallybut can be edited if needed.6. Select the domain the IP address belongs to.7. Click the Virtual checkbox and complete any remaining fields as needed or required.8. Enter any comments as needed.9. Click the Add button at the bottom of the dialog.The secondary, virtual IP address is added. "Yes" is displayed under the Virtual column to indicate it is a virtualaddress.10. Close the dialog or continue adding IP addresses.11. The CIDR (Classless Inter-Domain Routing), Mask, Gateway and Hostname fields are all populated auto-matically but can be edited if needed.12. Select the domain the IP address belongs to.13. Click the Virtual checkbox and complete any remaining fields as needed or required.14. Enter any comments as needed.15. Click the Add button at the bottom of the dialog.16. The secondary, virtual IP address is added. "Yes" is displayed under the Virtual column to indicate it is a virtualaddress.17. Close the dialog or continue adding IP addresses. The multiple addresses are listed on the Data - Ports tab onthe item's page.

dcTrack allows you to link multiple ports together by assigning the same IP address to each port. dcTrack then man-ages all of the ports on the port team through the same IP address.You can link multiple ports on the same item and multiple ports on different items to form a port team.This practice differs from port teams consisting of individual ports with the same IP address.In that case, an IP address is duplicated. It is then a distinct IP address that is assigned to another port.dcTrack recognizes each duplicated IP address as a specific to the data port it is assigned to and manages each IPaddress separately. For more information, see Assign the Same IP Addresses to Multiple Ports on a Port Teambut Manage Them Separately.When you edit the IP address, the edit affects all ports on the port team.If you delete an IP address from a port, the port is removed from the port team - it is not deleted.If you haven't already done so, assign the initial IP address to the initial port by doing one of the following:Select Available IP Addresses for the Selected SubnetEnter the IP Address InformationTo assign the same IP address to different ports on a port team and manage them together:1. Locate the item with the data port you want to assign the IP address to and manage on the port team. Open it inedit mode.The port can be on the same item or it can be a port on another item.2. Follow the steps for entering the IP address manually - Enter the IP Address Information.3. Once you have added the duplicate IP address to the data port, click Add at the bottom of the dialog.dcTrack lets you know the port is in use already and prompts you on how to proceed.4. Select "Yes, manage together" to add the port to the port team and manage it along with the other ports via thesame IP address.Continue adding ports as needed.

dcTrack allows you to create port teams where each port is assigned the same IP address but each IP address ismanaged separately.So if you make a change to one port, the change does not affect the other ports on the team.The ports can be on the same item or different items.This is different than teaming the ports by applying the same IP address to the ports in the team and managing theports through the same IP address. For more details on port teaming, see Assign the Same IP Address to MultiplePorts on the Same Port Team and Manage Them Together.Any changes you make to a duplicated IP address for a specific port affects only that IP address for that port - theother IP addresses that are assigned to different ports are not affected by the changes.If you delete a duplicated IP address from a port, its duplicates are not deleted from the ports they are assigned to.If you haven't already done so, assign the initial IP address to the initial port by doing one of the following:Select Available IP Addresses for the Selected Subnet.Enter the IP Address Information.To assign the same IP address to different ports on a port team but manage them separately:1. Locate the item with the data port you want to assign the IP address to and open it in edit mode.The port can be on the same item or it can be a port on another item.Follow the steps for entering the IP address manually - Enter the IP Address Information.2. Once you have added the IP address to the data port, click Add at the bottom of the dialog.dcTrack lets you know the port is in use already and prompts you on how to proceed.3. Select "Yes, manage separately".Continue adding the same IP address to other ports as needed.

IP teaming is supported on import and export of items or data ports via CSV. Two modes are supported for teamingIP addresses via file import and export:Separate mode: The IP addresses can be edited independently on each data portTogether mode: The IP addresses are managed as a group, such that an edit to an IP address on one of thedata ports is propagated to all data ports in the teamYou can specify the IP teaming mode when you add an IP address and that IP address is already in use by anotheritem or port.When you add an IP address and that IP address is already in use by another item or data port, you'll see a warningthat the IP address is already in use. You will need to check the Proceed on Warning box for your edits to executedand saved.Note: Once the teaming mode is specified and the teamed IP address is in use, you cannot change the IP teamingmode.Note: Rack PDUs can be imported into dcTrack with teamed IP addresses only if teamed in Together mode with aproxy index.

dcTrack validates the IP address you assign to a port.Specifically, dcTrack checks for:Subnet Gateway IP addressesdcTrack warns you if the IP address is identified as the Gateway IP address for another item's data port.dcTrack warns you if the IP address you assign does not belong to a defined subnet.Cancel assigning the IP address or continue with assigning the IP address to the data port. dcTrack doesnot prevent you from assigning the address.Duplicate IP addresses/port IP addresses already assigned to a port or port teamdcTrack warns you if the IP address is already assigned by another data port on the same item or another item. Doone of the following:"Enter a different IP"See Assign a Unique IP Address to an Individual Port."Yes, manage together"See Assign the Same IP Address to Multiple Ports on the Same Port Team and Manage Them Together."Yes, manage separately"See Assign the Same IP Addresses to Multiple Ports on a Port Team but Manage Them Separately.

Following are impacts if you edit or delete IP addresses that are already assigned to data ports.These edits and deletions refer to actions performed:In the Web Client on the IP Address Assignments dialog accessed by clicking IP Address on the Data - Ports tabof an item's page while it is in Edit modeEditing an IP address may result in:Updating the IP address for all ports on a port team that are sharing the same IP addressDeleting the association between a data port and IP addressMaking the IP address available for selection from the IP Address Subnets listCause an update to a Power IQ IP address (when update IP address is supported in Power IQ)Cause a deletion or add of a Power IQ IP address (when update IP address is supported in Power IQ, such IPAddress with Proxy Index)Updating the IP address of ports on a team that share the same IPDeleting an IP address may result in:Deleting the association between a data port and IP addressMaking the IP address available for selection from the IP Address Subnets listCause a deletion in Power IQ IP (when update IP address is supported in Power IQ, such IP Address with ProxyIndex)Edit a sensor port for items in the following statuses:PlannedInstalledPowered-offOff-SiteStorageArchivedYou must have edit privileges to edit an item's sensor port information.To edit sensor port information on an item's page:1. In the Web Client, click Assets > Items List.2. Open an existing item's page in edit mode.Directly update any of these fields in the port list on the Sensor - n Port tab:Port Type - port types cannot be change to a type that does not apply to the item.For example, a rack PDU's port type cannot be changed from Physical to Virtual.Sensor Port Name - up to 64 characters. Port names cannot be duplicated on a device.Index - editable. Two of the same type ports cannot have the same index, but different type ports can.For example, you cannot have two Humidity ports with Index 3, but you can have a Humidity port 3 and Temperatureport 3CabinetPositionComments - up to 500 characters3. Click Save at the top of the item's page.

Note: If the Delete icon is not displayed, Power IQ Integration is enabled to retrieve asset strip and/or sensor read-ings. Sensor ports cannot be deleted while Power IQ Integration is enabled.Delete a sensor port for items in the following statuses:PlannedInstalledPowered-offOff-SiteStorageArchivedYou must have edit privileges to delete ports.A connected sensor port cannot be deleted, so the Delete icon on the Port tab is disabled.To delete a sensor port:1. In the Web Client, click Assets > Items List.2. Open an existing item's page in edit mode.3. Click on the Sensor - n Ports tab.4. Click on the port or ports you want to delete. Use Ctrl + click to select multiple ports at once.5. Click Delete on the Sensor - n Ports tab.6. Click Save at the top of the item's page.1. To update power budget for items and models in bulk, navigate to Settings -> dcTrack Settings -> ApplicationAdministration -> Application -> Bulk Update Power Budgets2. Select the Apply to option. Options available are All Items, All Models, All Items & All Models3. Enter the percentage value in Update Budget % of Nameplate to. Accepted values are 1-100.4. Click on the button ApplyFor each Item and Model, Watts(B)will be calculated from percentage of existing Watts(N).In Sunbird's Model Library the default value of Watts(B) is 60% of Watts(N).

The item ports can be marked “In Use” without connecting the port. Once the ports are marked “In Use” they are nolonger available for connection and they do not show in the port list when you are building a circuit.This is done through the Web UI and File Import and is applicable to Data Ports, Power Supply Ports and Rack PDUPower Ports.Steps to mark ports “In Use” through web UI1. Open Item details screen in edit mode2. In the ports sub tab, select the ports you want to mark “In Use”3. Click on the button “In Use” in the toolbar.4. Click Save5. Connected Item column for these ports will change from “Available” to “In Use”Note: Only Item Ports that are available can be marked “In Use”. If a port has multiple channels and is marked as"In Use," none of its channels will be available for connection. Conversely, if any channel is connected, the portcannot be marked as "In Use."These ports can be made available for connections later by marking them “Not In Use”. To make ports availableagain, select the ports and click “Not In Use” in the port subtab toolbar and save the item.Ports can also be marked “In Use” or “Not In Use” through File Import. To make ports available or unavailablethrough File Import, export the items into the Port Import Template file. In the exported csv file, specify TRUE orFALSE in the “In Use” column.TRUE indicates that ports are marked In Use and cannot be connected.FALSE indicates that ports are not in use and will be treated as unused ports.Requests, or action requests, are submitted in dcTrack when a physical action must be performed for an item or cir-cuit in a data center.For example, submitting an Install Item Request to install a new item, submitting a Decommission Item to StorageRequest to decommission an item to storage, submitting a Connect Request to create a new power circuit, and soon.Requests are applied by selecting the Actions menu for both items and circuits.Once a request is submitted, it enters the dcTrack Change Control workflow where it is then processed.When Request Bypass is enabled, all item action requests that are submitted are processed by dcTrack imme-diately.When Request Bypass is disabled, item action requests move through each step of the Change Control workflowand must be approved or reject manually.Requests are displayed on the Requests List page as they move through the Change Control workflow.

The Request List page is accessed via Change > Requests.Requests can be processed individually or multiple requests can be processed at once.All requests for converting an item and disconnecting data/comm ports and power ports are linked together. Thismeans they can be approved by approving any of the associated requests.If there are several requests to decommission items and disconnect data ports and power port connections, theserequests are linked together. Therefore, all requests can be approved at once by approving any one of the asso-ciated requests.

All requests are assigned a request number, which resets to 00001 each year.The first two digits of the number represent the year the request was made. The next five digits are the serial numberof the request.For example: 130002413 = the year 201300024 = the serial number of the requestWhen two requests are associated with each other, they have the same request number and a distinguishing suffix.A related request is assigned a request number that includes a suffix consisting of a dash followed by a two-digitserial number starting at 01 to identify the related request.For example: 1300024-01 and 1300025-01When a single connection is moved, the existing port is disconnected and the new port is connected, which results ina disconnect and a reconnect request pair. Such a disconnect request is given the suffix -DX and the reconnectrequest is given the suffix -RX.Once an action request is issued for an item, it moves through the following stages of the Change Control workflow.The request moves through each stage of the workflow automatically if you are working in Request Bypass or manu-ally if Request Bypass is disabled.For more information on Request Bypass and manual change control, see Request Bypass and Manual ChangeControl.A user submits a request for an item from the Actions menu in the Web Client, orresubmits a request that was previously rejected.Request is submitted or resub-The item is in a Planned status if it is new, or remains in its current status when amitted by a user if it is rejectedrequest is resubmitted.For example, an item is created and is in a Planned status when an Install ItemRequest is submitted for it.The request is either approved (Successful) or rejected (Failed).Request approved or rejectedNote: When a request for the item is approved, the item cannot be edited until therequest is marked as Complete.After the request is approved, a work order is generated to perform the actual taskWork order is issuedrequested, such as installing an item, moving an item and so on.The work order action is performed. The request is completed in the data center.Work order is completedFor example, the server is installedWork order is marked as Com-Once the action is completed in the data center, the work order is marked as Com-plete in dcTrackpleted.Once the work order is marked as Completed, the request is marked as Completedand the item is moved into its new status.Request is completed andmarked as Complete in dcTrackFor example, an item moves from Planned to Installed once its Install Item Requestis marked as Complete.

Each request's current stage in the request workflow is displayed in the Request Stage column of the Requests Listpage in the Web Client.When you click on a request, its current stage is identified in the Request Stage in the Details panel as well.The current stage of the request, along with the additional stages the request must go through and the sequence ofthose stages, is displayed in Request Task Status tab on the Request Details page.dcTrack assigns a request number to the Move Item Request.Sub-request numbers are assigned to connections or blades associated with the Move Item Request (if applicable).For example, the Move Item Request number 1004 can have a Recreate Connection sub-request 1004-01 asso-ciated with it.

dcTrack allows you to perform a Move Item Request for a cabinet even when there are pending requests for theitems in the cabinet.For example, you can submit an Install Item Request for a server in a cabinet and then submit a Move Item Requestfor the cabinet. The cabinet move is allowed to proceed even though there is an outstanding Install Item Request forthe server.Pending requests can be completed before or after the Move Item Request for the cabinet is completed.When you submit a Move Item Request for a cabinet, a message indicates that a request is outstanding for an item.When you submit a request for an item in the cabinet when there is a Move Item Request pending for the cabinet, amessage indicates that a request is outstanding for the cabinet.For information on cabinet move requests, see Move Item Requests for Cabinets.Following is a list of the item requests and additional impacts, if any, when the request is submitted and you performa Move Item Request for a cabinet.If the item is installed before the cabinet move:All power circuits in a Planned status or Installed status remain connected.Install ItemAll data circuits in a Planned status are disconnected and deleted when the Work OrderRequestis marked Complete or the request is successfully processed.If the item is installed after the cabinet move, new connections are created to the designated loc-ation/item/port after the cabinet is moved.Power-off ItemThe item is moved to a Powered-off status independent of the item's location.RequestPower-on ItemThe item is moved to a Powered-on status independent of the item's location.RequestIf the Take Item Off-site Request Work Order is marked Complete and existing connections areTake Item Off-siteretained.RequestThe item is only moved to the cabinet once the item is brought back on-site.Bring Item On-siteIf the Bring Item On-site Request Work Order is marked Complete, the item's connections areRequestretained.If a Decommission Item to Storage Request is submitted for the cabinet, all connections are dis-Decommissionconnected.Item to StorageIf there is an item with a pending Move Item Request in the cabinet and a Decommission Item toRequestStorage Request is submitted for the cabinet, the item's connections are disconnected.If a Decommission Item to Archive Request is submitted for the cabinet, all connections are dis-Decommissionconnected.Item to ArchiveIf there is an item with a pending Move Item Request in the cabinet and a Decommission Item toRequestArchive Request is submitted for the cabinet, the item's connections are disconnected.All power circuits in a Planned status or Installed status remain connected.Move Item RequestAll data circuits in a Planned status are disconnected and deleted when the Work Orderis marked Complete or the request is successfully processed.Convert Item toThe item is converted and all connections are disconnected before the cabinet is moved.VM RequestAt any time, you can access the Requests List under the Change tab in the Web Client to find out a request's currentstage in the Change Control workflow.On the Requests List, you can view the Request Stage under the Request Stage column.On a Request Details page, this information is available in the Request Stage Field in the Details section. You canfind more information on the task associated with each stage in the Request Task Status tab.For more on stages, see Lifecycles, Statuses, Action Requests, Change Control Workflow and Stages.For more on the request workflow, see Request Workflow.

To create a request for an item in dcTrack, you need to submit a request through the Actions menu on the Items listor on any Item Details page. Disallowed requests are grayed out and will be in accessible. For more information, seeRequest Workflow and Asset Lifecycle and Workflow.dcTrack provides two Move Item Request options: Quick Move Item Request and Prepare Move Item Request.Move rackable, device items and rackable, network items using Quick Move Item Request and Prepare MoveItem Request.Move cabinets using Quick Move Item RequestPrepare Move Item Request cannot be used to move cabinets.Use Quick Move Item Request when you know:the location you want to move an item tothe cabinet you want to move an item tothe location you want to move a cabinet and/or its items toUse Prepare Move Item Request:When you know the cabinet you want to move an item to but need to qualify the cabinet before you move theitem to it, orWhen you do not know the cabinet you want to move the item to and need to locate one that can accom-modate the itemFor details on using these move options with cabinets and items, see Move Item Requests for Cabinets.

In dcTrack, an asset or item passes through specific states that correspond to its lifecycle stage.Assets and items in dcTrack can fall under one of the following lifecycle states:PlannedInstalledPowered OffOff SitePlanned DecommStorageArchivedNote: Powered Off and Off Site are sub-states of Installed. An asset that is Installed but not PoweredOff is considered to be Powered On.You transition assets from one state to the next by issuing requests. For example, you transition anasset from the Planned state to the Installed state by issuing a request for the asset to be installed. Ifthe request is approved, a work order is issued to complete the request.There are also transitions that are allowed directly from the Status drop down list while editing an Itemthat do not require you to issue a Request and proceed through the workflow process.Following diagram describes all the state transitions that are allowed in dcTrack either by issuing arequest or directly from the status drop down list while editing an itemIn dcTrack when an asset is created it is set to Planned Status be default. It can also be set to followingstatuses upon creation.1. Planned2. Installed3. Storage4. ArchivedThe transitions that are allowed directly from the Status drop down list while editing an Item that do notrequire you to issue a Request and proceed through the workflow process.The following table outlines these transitions.Planned -> Installed All ClassesPlanned -> Archived All ClassesAll Classes except:Data PanelPower OutletPlanned -> StorageFloor PDUUPSHVACVMAll Clases except:CabinetDevice/Blade ServerNetwork/BladeProbeInstalled -> Planned Decomm.Data PanelPower OutletFloor PDUUPSHVACVMAll Classes except:Data PanelStorage -> PlannedPower OutletFloor PDUUPSHVACVMAll Classes except:Data PanelPower OutletStorage -> InstalledFloor PDUUPSHVACVMArchived -> Planned All ClassesAll Classes except:CabinetRack PDUProbeData PanelPowered Off -> InstalledPower OutletFloor PDUUPSHVACAll Classes except:CabinetRack PDUProbePowered Off -> Planned Decomm.Data PanelPower OutletFloor PDUUPSHVACAll Classes except:CabinetNetwork/NetworkStackOff Site -> Planned Decomm.Network/ChassisRack PDUProbeData PanelPower OutletFloor PDUUPSHVACVMAll Classes except:CabinetDevice/Blade ServerNetwork/BladeProbeData PanelPlanned Decomm. -> InstalledPower OutletFloor PDUUPSHVACVMAll Classes except:CabinetDevice/Blade ServerNetwork/BladeRack PDUProbePlanned Decomm. -> Powered OffData PanelPower OutletFloor PDUUPSHVACVMAll Classes except:CabinetDevice/Blade ServerPlanned Decomm. -> Off SiteNetwork/BladeNetwork/NetworkStackNetwork/ChassisRack PDUProbeData PanelPower OutletFloor PDUUPSHVACVM

Submit a Move Item Request when you want to move rackable, device class items and rackable, network classitems from one cabinet to another cabinet in the same data center location, or to another data center location.You can move items from one cabinet to another by using one of the following options:• Quick Move Item Request option• Prepare Move Item Request option• Use MOVE operation in file import• Dragging-and-dropping items from one cabinet to another in item list cabinet elevationMove Item Requests are not required to move an item from one position to another position within the same cabinet.Instead, simply edit an item's U position in a cabinet by:Selecting a new position from the U Position drop-downOrDragging-and-dropping an item in a cabinet elevation to move it to a new position within the cabinetSee Change an Item's U Position in a CabinetNote: You must have Edit privileges to the item and there must be space available to accommodate the item in thecabinet.However, you can submit a Move Item Request if you are using dcTrack's Change Control workflow and want totrack a move within a cabinet.

You are able to submit Quick Move Item Requests to:Move blade servers (device items) to chassis located in other cabinets in the sameSupported Move Itemlocation or a different locationRequestsMove blades (network items) to chassis located in other cabinets in the same loc-ation or a different locationPrivileges You must have edit access to the blade chassis and blade server or blade.dcTrack notifies you when the blade chassis, blade server, or blade has a pending request.Pending requestsYou are able to proceed with the Move Item Request regardless.Device class items (blade servers)Supported classesNetwork class items (blades)Device class chassis (hold both device blades servers and network blades)The destination cabinet containing the chassis must be in an Installed status.The parent and child must be in the same status. This means the blade must be in the sameSupported statuses des-status as the chassis you are moving the blade to.tination cabinetFor example, you can move an Installed blade into an Installed chassis, a Planned blade intoa Planned chassis and so on.Cabinets that can accommodate the blade chassis are the only cabinets that are listed asoptions to move the chassis to.Placement optionsChassis that can house the blade(s) are the only chassis that are listed as options to movethe blade(s) to.When a Move Item Request is completed, the blade chassis and/or blade is in thesame status as it was prior to the move.Status upon moveFor example, if it is in an Installed status prior to the move, it is an Installed status when themove is completed.Physical data port connections are disconnected when blades are moved from ablade chassis.Logical data connections within the chassis remain intact when blade chassis andConnectionsblades are moved together.Power connections are disconnected.Planned circuits are deleted.Installed and Powered-off circuits are disconnected and must be recreated afterthe move.IP addresses assigned to ports remain when the blade is moved to a chassis in thesame location.IP addressesIP addresses assigned to ports are deleted when the blade is moved to a chassisin a different location.

1. In the Web Client, from the Items List under the Assets tab, select the cabinet you want to move, or select thecabinet and double-click on it to open its item page.2. Click on the Actions menu.3. Select the Quick Move Item Request option.4. A new Item Detail page opens for the move cabinet. The page opens in Edit mode.The page contains all of the information from the cabinet.The cabinet name is the same but includes "^^WHEN-MOVED".All of the items within the cabinet are displayed in the elevation.5. Enter the move information by making changes to the Placement (Cabinet) information on the page:LocationAisle LabelRow LabelPosition in RowFront FacesNote: The Status field will reflect the Planned status. This is not editable.6. Click Save to begin the Move Item Request process.If any of the items in the cabinet have outstanding requests, you are notified. You can proceed with the move or stopthe move.7. A dialog displays the request's progress.Note: You can close the Request dialog while the request(s) is being processed.Note: The images show processing a request when working in Request Bypass.The status of the request/sub-requests and the request number/sub-request numbers are displayed in the dialogonce they are submitted/processed successfully.9. Close the dialog once a 'success' message is displayed, or you receive an error notification.Move Item Request processing varies based on if you are working in Request Bypass or Change Control workflow.The cabinet is moved and is in an Installed status.All of the items are moved along with the cabinet except for power outlets, items above and below the cabinet, anddata panels connected to external infrastructure items.Items are in the status they were in before they were moved.Power connections from the items in the cabinet to the rack PDU(s) in the cabinet are retained; no further action isrequired.Power connections outside the cabinet are retained and can now be connected to a new outlet. For details, seeBuild Power Circuits.A Move Item Request cannot be submitted for multiple items or cabinets at the same time.

Submit a Quick Move Item Request when you want to move a cabinet or a cabinet and its contents from one place ina data center to another, or from one location to another location.For example:Submit a Quick Move Item Request to move a cabinet and its items from a staging area to the data center floor.Submit a Quick Move Item Request to move a cabinet and its contents to a new a data center during an expan-sion.Prepare Move Item Requests do not apply to cabinets. Quick Move Item Requests are supported for cabinets andsupported item classes in cabinets.dcTrack allows you to perform a Move Item Request for a cabinet even when there are pending requests for theitems in the cabinet.For example, you can submit an Install Item Request for a server in a cabinet and then submit a Move Item Requestfor the cabinet. The cabinet move is allowed to proceed even though there is an outstanding Install Item Request forthe server.Pending requests can be completed before or after the Move Item Request for the cabinet is completed.When you submit a Move Item Request for a cabinet, a message indicates that a request is outstanding for an item.When you submit a request for an item in the cabinet when there is a Move Item Request pending for the cabinet, amessage indicates that a request is outstanding for the cabinet.For details on the item requests and additional impacts, if any, when the request is submitted and you perform aMove Item Request for a cabinet, see Move Item Request Requests and Sub-Requests.

When a Move Item Request is submitted for a cabinet, the following may occur:All items in a cabinet are moved along with the cabinet with the exception of:Power outletsItems above and below the cabinetData panels with connections to infrastructure cabling external to the cabinet.Data panels without infrastructure connections or with connections to items in the same cabinet areItems within themoved along with the cabinet. They connections to the items in the cabinet remain intact.cabinetData panels with fan-out connections to network switches within the cabinet are moved with thecabinet. The connections from the data panel to the items in the cabinet remain intact; they are notdisconnected like external connections.If a data panel is used for connections to infrastructure external to the cabinet and connections tonetwork switches within the cabinet, the data panel is removed from the cabinet and put into aPlanned status. The connections to the network switch are disconnected.Item location information is automatically changed for each item in the cabinet.Infrastructure data panels are removed from the cabinet once the request Work Order is markedComplete.Infrastructuredata panelsThe data panels are changed to a status of Planned.Items in the cabinet are disconnected from the data panel since it is removed from the cabinet.Data circuits starting and ending within the cabinet are retained on move.For example, connections to network switches contained in the same cabinet, associations to tem-perature sensors contained in the same cabinet, and so on.Installed dataand sensor portDisconnect requests are automatically issued for data and sensor circuits ending outside the cabinetconnectionswhen the Move Item Request is submitted for the cabinet.For example, data connections to data panels located outside of the cabinet are disconnected, asso-ciations to sensors located in a different cabinet are disconnected, and so on.Power circuits are retained on move.Installed powerThis allows the rack PDU inlet connections to be changed to the power outlet ports at the new loc-port connectionsation when the move is completed.Each connection from the items in the cabinet to the rack PDU within the cabinet are retained.Planned powerAll power circuits in a Planned status or Installed status remain connected.circuitsPlanned data cir-All data circuits in a Planned status are disconnected and deleted when the Work Order is markedcuitsComplete or the request is successfully processed.Managed IPIf moved within the same Location, IP Addresses remain unchanged. If moved to a different Loca-Addressestion, IP Addresses are deleted.UnManaged IPIp Addresses remain unchanged.AddressesA single Move Item Request is issued for the cabinet and all of the items in the cabinet.Request and/orWork OrderThe items in the cabinet are identified in the Move Item Request and/order Work Order.WHEN-MOVEDThe details of the Move Cabinet Item request are available by viewing the Item Details for the <cab-cabinetinet item name>^^WHEN-MOVED; this is available until the request is completed.A single Work Order is issued for the cabinet and all of the items in the cabinet.Work OrderThe same statuses that were applied to the cabinet and the items in the cabinet are applied oncethe Move Item Request Work Order is marked Complete.The Move Item Request details for the cabinet and for each item are captured in the audit trail indi-Audit trailvidually.

1. In the Web Client, from the Items List under the Assets tab, select the cabinet you want to move, or select thecabinet and double-click on it to open its item page.2. Click on the Actions menu.3. Select the Quick Move Item Request option.4. A cabinet page opens for the move cabinet. The page opens in Edit mode.The page contains all of the information from the cabinet.The cabinet name is the same but includes "^^WHEN-MOVED".All of the items within the cabinet are displayed in the elevation.5. Enter the move information by making changes to the Placement (Cabinet) information on the page:LocationAisle LabelRow LabelPosition in RowFront FacesNote: The Status field will reflect the Planned status. This is not editable.6. Click Save to begin the Move Item Request process.You are prompted to confirm you want to proceed.7. Select Yes to proceed with the move, or No to cancel the move.If any of the items in the cabinet have outstanding requests, you are notified. You can proceed with the move or stopthe move.8. A dialog displays the request's progress.Note: You can close the Request dialog while the request(s) is being processed.Note: The images show processing a request when working in Request Bypass.The status of the request/sub-requests and the request number/sub-request numbers are displayed in the dialogonce they are submitted/processed successfully.9. Close the dialog once a 'success' message is displayed, or you receive an error notification.Move Item Request processing varies based on if you are working in Request Bypass or Change Control workflow.The cabinet is moved and is in an Installed status.All of the items are moved along with the cabinet except for power outlets, items above and below the cabinet, anddata panels connected to external infrastructure items.Items are in the status they were in before they were moved.Power connections from the items in the cabinet to the rack PDU(s) in the cabinet are retained; no further action isrequired.Power connections outside the cabinet are retained and can now be connected to a new outlet. For details, seeBuild Power Circuits.

Submit a Prepare Move Item Request if you want to use dcTrack's® Intelligent Capacity Search to:Search for an optimal destination cabinet to move the item to when you do not have one in mind.See Use Capacity Search to Locate a Destination CabinetConsider using the Quick Move Item Request option if you know the destination cabinet and do not need to qualify itbefore submitting the Move Item Request. See Using the Quick Move Item Request Option to Submit a MoveCabinet RequestUse a Quick Move Item Request for cabinet moves. Prepare Move Item Requests are not used for cabinets.Prepare Move Item Requests do not apply to cabinets since the purpose of a Prepare Move Item Request is to useIntelligent Capacity Search to qualify a cabinet in order to ensure it can accommodate an item or locate a cabinet toaccommodate an item.Note: The Item List Action "Prepare Move Item Request" no longer re-directs to the Capacity tab but instead opensin a dialog containing the same content that was displayed in the Capacity tab for the move.dcTrack uses Intelligent Capacity Search to locate a destination cabinet for an item based on the item's criteria, suchas cabinet type, data and power connection requirements, contiguous rack unit requirements and so on.After selecting Prepare Move Item Request from the Actions menu, the Intelligent Capacity Search dialog opens andthe results of the search are displayed.1. Select the item you want to move on the Items List page or open the item's page.2. Select Prepare Move Item Request from the Actions menu. The Intelligent Capacity Search dialog opens.If destination cabinets are found that meet the item's criteria, they are listed in the Search Results section of the dia-log.3. Select a cabinet from the list.Alternatively, update the destination search criteria and perform a new search by clicking the "Search for Cabinet"button4. Once you have selected a Cabinet, click "Move..." at the bottom of the page.5. An item page opens containing the pending move item's information.The pending move item name includes "WHEN-MOVED".All of the information is the same unless you edited it.6. Click Save to submit the request.You are presented with a dialog box explaining the results of Move and prompted to confirm you want to proceed.7. Select Yes to proceed with the move, or No to cancel the move.8. A dialog displays the request's progress.Note: You can close the Request dialog while the request(s) is being processed.Note: The images show processing a request when working in Request Bypass.Move Item Request processing varies based on if you are working in Request Bypass or Change Control workflow.For information on the Change Control workflow process and Request Bypass, see Request Bypass and ManualChange Control.The status of the request/sub-requests and the request number/sub-request numbers are displayed in the dialogonce they are submitted/processed successfully.Move Item Request processing varies based on if you are working in Request Bypass or Change Control workflow.9. Close the dialog once a 'success' message is displayed, or you receive an error notification.10. The "WHEN-MOVED" replaces the original Item and the original Item is deleted.

After a Prepare Move Item Request is initiated, dcTrack displays the results of the search.When cabinets are found that meet all of the criteria, they are listed in a table.If cabinets are found that meet some criteria but not all, dcTrack displays that information in the results area. Detailssuch as what criteria were and were not met are provided (for example, not enough power was available to accom-modate the item).dcTrack lists the number of cabinets that meet each of the criteria (if any).Icons are used in the message to indicate level to which each criteria were met, if they were met at all.Cabinets exist that meet the specified criteria.No cabinets exist that meet the specified criteria.The specified criteria was not defined for any cabinets at the location.Cabinets exist that meet some of the criteria, but no single cabinet meets all of the criteria.When you receive these results, you can:Cancel the Prepare Move Item Request.Update the destination cabinet criteria and click "Search for Cabinet" to attempt to locate a cabinet.If you are qualifying a specific cabinet, you can select the cabinet and submit a Move Item Request even if noneof the criteria are met.Cabinets exist that meet some of the criteria but not all.Cabinets exist that meet the criteria, but no single cabinet meets all of the criteria.No cabinets meet all of the criteria and/or the criteria were not defined for the cabinets so cannot be said to be met.You can resubmit a Move Item Request for a cabinet or item as long as the request is still in one of the followingstages:Request IssuedRequest UpdatedRequest Rejected

A pending move item is created when the Move Item Request is submitted. Pending move items are identified by"WHEN-MOVED" as part of their name.This pending item can be deleted as long as the request has not been approved/marked as Request Complete.The Move Item Request and sub-requests, if any, are deleted when the pending item is deleted.Deleting the pending item does not delete the original item. All original connections remain intact with exceptPlanned connections, which are deleted as soon as a Move Item Request is submitted.The cabinet space reserved for the pending item is made available once the pending item is deleted.Note: Working in Request Bypass, the option to delete a pending item does not apply since the request is auto-matically processed.To delete a pending move item in the Web Client, do one of the following:1. Select the pending "WHEN-MOVED" item from the Items List page and then click Delete.2. Open the item's page and click the Delete icon.3. Click Delete to confirm when prompted.Updating a pending "WHEN-MOVED" item's information regenerates the Move Item Request, and the status of therequest is moved to Request Updated on the Requests page.If a pending "WHEN-MOVED" item is updated, a new request number is assigned to the updated request and newsub-request numbers are assigned to sub-requests (if applicable).If you change the cabinet for the pending item, dcTrack does not qualify the cabinet to ensure it can accommodatethe item.1. In the Web Client, select the item and open it in Edit mode.2. Make updates to the placement information. If changing cabinets, click OK to close the warning.3. Save the updates.4. Close the Request status dialog once the submit process completes.

After submitting a Prepare Move Item Request, then selecting a cabinet from the Intelligent Capacity Search pageand clicking "Move" to begin the submit Move Item Request process, the item's "WHEN-MOVED" page opens in anew tab.Closing the page without saving cancels the request.

A pending Move Item Request can be deleted as long as the request has not been approved/marked as RequestComplete. Sub-requests, if any, associated with the Move Item Request are also deleted.The pending item, identified by "WHEN-MOVED" as part of its name and created when the request was submitted,is deleted automatically.Additionally, the cabinet space reserved for the pending move item is made available.Note: When working in Request Bypass, the option to delete a pending Move Item Request does not apply sincethe request is automatically processed.1. In the Web Client, click the Change tab > Requests to open the Requests page.2. Select the request from the list.3. Click the Actions menu > Cancel Request.

When you need to take an item offsite temporarily but will bring it back onsite at a later date, submit a Take Item Off-site Request.A Bring Item On-site Request is submitted to have items that were moved temporarily off-site returned.For example, submit a Take Item Off-site Request to have a switch removed from the data center and sent to an off-site location for maintenance, then submit a Bring Item On-site Request once it is returned.When you take an item off site, it remains intact in the application so it can be easily reestablished once the item isback on-site.When needed, select Take Item Off-site Request or Bring Item On-site Request from the Actions menu to submit therequest, and select Yes when prompted to confirm.The Off Site state applies to:Items In powered off or storage state.Rackable Items only.Class: Device - Subclass: Standard, Blade Chassis and Blade ServerFor more information on requests and the Actions menu, see Item Action Request Types.If Request Bypass is enabled, the request is processed immediately. If Request Bypass is disabled, the request issubmitted to the Change Control workflow and processed.

Any standard, rackable device or standard, blade server can be converted to a virtual machine as long as the deviceis in a status of Planned, Powered-off or Off-site.To convert an item to virtual machine.1. Open the item's page opens.2. While the item is in a Planned status, it can be converted to a virtual machine simply by deleting the make andmodel, then selecting the VM checkbox.Once the item has been placed in another status, an action to issue a request to convert the item to a VM is needed.1. Click the Actions menu > Convert Item to VM Request.2. Click Yes when prompted to confirm you want to convert the item to a virtual machine.3. Click OK on the Item Request message that confirms your request was submitted.

Once a device is in an Installed status, it is considered to be powered on.You can issue requests to turn devices in the data center on and off as needed. For example, issue a power offrequest for a server.When applicable, Power-off Item Request from the Actions menu to submit the request, and select Yes when promp-ted to confirm.For more information on requests and the Actions menu, see Item Action Request Types.If Request Bypass is enabled, the request is processed immediately. If Request Bypass is disabled, the request issubmitted to the Change Control workflow and processed.For more information on Request Bypass and Change Control workflow, see dcTrack Change Management Work-flow - Change Control and Request Bypass.Select the device and then select Power-on Item Request from the Actions menu to submit the power on request,when needed. Once the item is powered back on, the connections are powered back on as well.If a device is powered on, the Power-on Item Request is disabled in the Actions menu. Alternatively, if the device ispowered off, the Power-off Item Request is disabled in the Actions menu.When an item is powered off, the item's connections remain but are considered to be powered off as well.The Powered Off State applies to Installed Items whose Class is:Device (Rackable)- Standard, Blade Chassis and Blade ServerNetwork - Chassis and NetworkStackProbe

Note: Before submitting a Decommission Item to Storage Request for a rack PDU if you are integrated with PowerIQ, review Decommission Rack PDUs in dcTrack When Integrated with Power IQ.You must follow a different process to decommission rack PDUs.Decommissioning an item to storage means that the item is temporarily in an off-site location, but it remains in invent-ory and will be returned. For example, you may decommission a server to storage but bring it back at a later date fora new purpose.Decommissioning an item to storage is also an alternative to deleting an item that is no longer in a Planned status, oran item you do not want to purge from the application.To decommission more than one item at the same time, use Ctrl + Click or Ctrl + Shift commands to select items onthe Items List.To decommission an item t o storage:1. Mouse-over Assets and select Items to display the Items list.2. From the Items list, select the items you want to decommission.3. Click Actions to expand the Actions menu.4. From the Actions menu, select Decommission Item to Storage Request to submit the Decommission Item toStorage Request.5. Select Yes when prompted to confirm.6. If the selected item is a cabinet, the following apply:7. All items in the cabinet are decommissioned.8. All Data Panels are removed from the Cabinet and set to a Planned Status: When the cabinet has DataPanels, the Cabinet and U position for the data panels are cleared and the status is set to Planned.9. All Power Outlets assigned to the Cabinet are unassigned and left in place: When the Cabinet has Power Out-lets, the Cabinet and U Pos are cleared, but the Row and Position In Row remain. The statuses of the PowerOutlet do not change after the cabinet is decommissioned.10. The following check-box options are available if the item to be decommissioned is a cabinets:a. Keep items mounted in the Cabinet: When checked and the decommissioned item is a cabinet, theCabinet and U Position of each Item in the Cabinet are retained (not cleared). When un-checked andthe decommissioned item is a cabinet, the U Position of each item in the cabinet is cleared. For itemsintegrated with Power IQ, the cabinet field of items that are decommissioned is retained, so that the his-torical readings of those items remain with the cabinet.b. Keep Rack PDUs mounted in the cabinet: When checked, the cabinet and U Position fields of anyrack PDUs are retained (not cleared). When unchecked, the cabinet field remains unchanged, but theU position is cleared.c. Keep Data Connections that are within the Cabinet: When checked, all (both Planned and Installed)data connections that do not extend outside of the cabinet are retained. Planned data connections thatextend outside of the cabinet are deleted. Installed data connections that extend outside of the Cabinethave Disconnect Requests issued.d. Keep Power Connections that are within the Cabinet: When checked, all (both Planned andInstalled) power connections that do not extend outside of the cabinet are retained.
