Planned powerconnections that extend outside of the cabinet are deleted. Installed power connections that extendoutside of the cabinet have Disconnect Requests issued. When un-checked, all planned power con-nections (both within and outside the cabinet) are deleted.a. i. A connection between an item's power supply and a Rack PDU outlet where both theitem and Rack PDU are in the decommissioned cabinet is considered a connectionswithin the cabinet.ii. A connection between an item's power supply and a power outlet is considered outsidethe cabinet.iii. A connection between a Rack PDU's inlet and the power outlet is technically outside thecabinet, however it remain intact to avoid orphaning the connections to the Rack PDUoutlets, therefore, the connection of the inlet of the Rack PDU are modified to connect toa VPC outlet instead.iv. When there are multiple Rack PDUs in the cabinet, all Rack PDUs are sorted by name,then connected to VPCs, if the corresponding VPC is enabled for the location. Other-wise, it will behave as if the Keep Power Connection option is not checked. When we saythe corresponding VPC is enabled, it means if the Rack PDU is AC Power, Rack Trans-fer Switch, Rack UPS, Rack Rectifier subclass, then AC VPC has to be on and if theRack PDU is DC FAP then DC VPC has to be on. And if the subclass is Rack Invertor ora combination of the other classes, both AC and DC VPC has to be on.b. Regarding Power:e. When un-checked, all Planned Power Connections (both within the Cabinet and outside the Cabinet)should be deleted. All Installed Power Connections should have Disconnect Requests issued. (Exist-ing Behavior)Note: The check-box options are not available options when updating an item's statuses via the statusdrop-down (with the Manage Item Status role). See the table below for more information.11. If the decommissioned item is a Chassis, the following checkbox option is available: Keep Blades mounted inthe Chassis.The check-box options in the Decommision to Storage feature are not options when updating items statuses via thestatus dropdown (with the Manage Item Status role)The following table outlines the default behavior of these options when items are archived via the item status drop-down:Keep Blades mounted in the Chassis False dcTrack will remove all blades from the chassis.Keep items mounted in the Cabinet False dcTrack will remove items from the cabinetKeep Rack PDUs mounted in the Cabinet False dcTrack will remove items from cabinetKeep Data Connections that are withindcTrack will remove all connections, inside and outside ofFalsethe Cabinet cabinets/chassisKeep Power Connections that are withindcTrack will remove all connections, inside and outside ofFalsethe Cabinet cabinets/chassisFor more information on requests and the Actions menu, see Item Action Request Types.If Request Bypass is enabled, the request is processed immediately. If Request Bypass is disabled, the request issubmitted to the Change Control workflow and processed.For more information on Request Bypass and Change Control workflow, see Enable or Disable Request Bypass(Change Control Workflow Options).Alternatively, change the item's status to from the Status drop-down on the item's page (provided you have priv-ileges to do so).Important: Before submitting a <archived> for a rack PDU if you are integrated with Power IQ, reviewDecommission Rack PDUs in dcTrack When Integrated with Power IQ.You must follow a different process to decommission rack PDUs.Before you begin, review What Does it Mean to Delete, Store, Archive or Purge Items.Archiving an item allows you to purge it from dcTrack completely, if you choose to do so, unlike decommissioningthe item to storage.Marking an item as archived indicates that the item has been removed from inventory and disposed of.Since you cannot delete items that are in an Installed status, decommission them to an Archived state in order todelete them. You can then purge the items from dcTrack if needed.Once an item is in an Installed state, it cannot be delete from the item's page or in the Item List page in the Web Cli-ent. However, you can submit a request to archive the item.Note: Cabinets with an Archived status are not counted towards used dcTrack licenses.To do this, Select <archived> from the Actions menu to submit the request, and select Yes when prompted toconfirm.For more information on requests and the Actions menu, see Item Action Request Types.If Request Bypass is enabled, the request is processed immediately. If Request Bypass is disabled, the request issubmitted to the Change Control workflow and processed.For more information on Request Bypass and Change Control workflow, see dcTrack Change Management Work-flow - Change Control and Request Bypass.Alternatively, change the item's status to from the Status drop-down on the item's page provided you have privilegesto do so.

Requests can be viewed in the Requests List in the Web Client.In the Web Client, select the Change tab > Requests.The Requests List will display. You can sort and filter the request list by request stage, type, work order number,item name, and other columns as well as hide, show, and reorder columns. You can also save your filtered viewsand set a view as your default.Click on a Request to view its Details page. In Edit mode on the Request Details page, users with the appropriatepermissions can edit the request due date, priority, designate who will be notified for a request task and what the noti-fication email body will contain. Users also are able to view the Request Task Status, and complete various actionsfor the request (such as approving a request and marking it complete).The Request Task Status tab provides details on the status of each task in the request workflow. Note that you canspecify who is notified as each task is completed in this tab.The Request History tab is automatically updated as each task is initiated and can be a point of future reference ifyou ever need to refer to the request and task notifications at a later date.When sub-requests, such as Disconnect requests for data and power connections accompany another request suchas a Move Item Request, the requests are linked.When the Move Item Request is submitted, the Disconnect requests are automatically generated and submitted forthe data and power connections.The Disconnect requests are linked to the Move Item Request and all requests are approved or rejected at the sametime.The work order to captures both the Move Item Request and the Disconnect requests.Linked requests can be identified by their request numbers.

All requests are assigned a request number, which resets to 00001 each year.The first two digits of the number represent the year the request was made. The next five digits are the serial numberof the request.For example: 130002413 = the year 201300024 = the serial number of the requestWhen two requests are associated with each other, they have the same request number and a distinguishing suffix.A related request is assigned a request number that includes a suffix consisting of a dash followed by a two-digitserial number starting at 01 to identify the related request.For example: 1300024-01 and 1300025-01When a single connection is moved, the existing port is disconnected and the new port is connected, which results ina disconnect and a reconnect request pair. Such a disconnect request is given the suffix -DX and the reconnectrequest is given the suffix -RX.Note: If you are working in Request Bypass, dcTrack automatically processes the request and either approves orrejects it.Note: You must have the appropriate permissions to accept or reject requests.If Request Bypass is disabled, manually approve or reject requests from the Web Client.Approve or reject one request at a time, or all requests at one time.To manually approve a request:1. In the Web Client, select the Change tab > Requests.2. Select the request(s) to be approved. Alternatively, you can approve an individual request by clicking on it to goto its Details page, and then proceeding to Step 3.3. Select the Actions menu > Approve Request. The Item Request popup displays a progress bar and indicatewhen the approval is complete. Click the OK button to exit the popup.An email is sent to the request submitter notifying them the request has been approved.On the Requests List, the Request Stage column will update to show the request has been approved. On theRequest Details page, the request stage at the top of the page and the request workflow task status and history atthe bottom of page is updated to indicate the request's status as Request Approved.A work order can now be created for the request. See Create a Work Order.To reject a request:1. In the Web Client, select the Change tab > Requests.2. Select the request(s) to be approved. Alternatively, you can approve an individual request by clicking on it togo to its Details page, and then proceeding to Step 3.3. Select Actions > Reject Request.An email is sent to the requester notifying them the request has been rejected.On the Requests List, the Request Stage column will update to show the request has been rejected. On the RequestDetails page, the request stage at the top of the page and the request workflow history at the bottom of page isupdated to indicate the request's status as Rejected.

The resubmit request features is useful when working in Request Bypass or manual change control.You can resubmit a request for a single item or multiple items from the Actions menu on the Items List or theRequests List. You can resubmit a request for a single item from the Item Details page or the Request Details Page.To resubmit a request:Select Resubmit Request from the Actions menu to resubmit the same request for an item.A request you submitted for an item is rejectedThe resubmit request feature allows you make required changes to the item and then resubmit the request.For example, if an Install Item Request for a server is rejected because the requested installation date cannot bemet, edit the server's installation date, then resubmit the request.A request is not approved when it is automatically processed by dcTrack Request BypassIf you are working in Request Bypass and an original request is not approved during the automatic review process,you can use the resubmit function instead of submitting a new request.For example, if you submit an Install Item Request for multiple items at once from the Items List in the Web Clientand one of the items is not approved, you can make changes to the item and then resubmit a request for it. The otheritems that are correct are processed and approved.For more information and a list of reasons requests fail validation in Request Bypass, see Request Bypass Val-idation Errors.An item is already in an Installed status and you need to edit the item's information without submitting a newaction request type for itIn this case, you make changes to the item's information, save the changes, then resubmit the same request.For example, if you need to change an Installed item's name, you can edit the item name, save the changes, thenresubmit the Install Item Request.

If an item's information is edited after a request is submitted for it, the same request type can be resubmitted or anew request type can be submitted.You cannot resubmit a request for an item that currently has a request pending.For example, if a Take Item Off-site Request is pending for an item, and you attempt to submit a Power-off ItemRequest, dcTrack does not allow you to submit the Power-off Item Request.The pending request's number and a description of the pending request is provided in the message.You can resubmit a request for all request types. You can resubmit a Move Item Request for a cabinet or item aslong as the request is still in one of the following stages:Request IssuedRequest UpdatedRequest RejectedTo delete a request:1. In the Web Client, select the Change tab > Requests.2. Select the request(s) you want to delete.3. Click the Actions menu> Cancel Request.Alternatively, you can cancel a request from its Details page by clicking Actions > Cancel Requests.

Once the actual request has been completed (for example a server has been installed or removed from the data cen-ter), it can be marked as complete.To mark a request as complete:1. Select the Change tab > Requests.2. Click on the request(s) to mark as complete.3. Select the Actions menu > Mark Request as Complete.You can also mark a request complete from the Request Details page by:Selecting the Actions menu > Mark Request as CompleteClicking the Complete Task button under the Complete Request task in the Request Task Status tab in Editmode at the bottom of the page.Once a request is marked as Complete, its status will be updated in the Requests list, the Request Stage field in theDetails panel on the Request Details page, the Request Task Status tab, and the Request History tab.A request's history can be viewed on the request's Details page. This is useful for item auditing purposes and forcases where you need to refer back to activities specific to this request, including work orders issued for the request.In the Change tab > Requests, click the request whose history you want to view.On the Request Details page, click the Request History tab. The left panel displays the Activity, Email NotificationSubject, User who took the action, and date and time. The right panel displays the History Details for a specific activ-ity.Click on the row corresponding to a specific activity to view its History Details in the right History Details panel.

Requests can be archived only if they are in the Request Completed stage.To archive a request:1. In the Web Client, select the Change tab > Requests.2. Click on the request.3. Select Actions > Archive Request.To view archived requests:1. In the Web Client, select the Change tab > Requests.2. Select the request.3. Select View from the Request tool bar or simply double click the RequestEach stage in the request lifecycle has an associated task (Submit Request, Approve Request, Issue a Work Order,etc.) As each task is initiated, email notifications can be sent to the appropriate parties.To edit a default notification, you configure the task template under the Change tab > Actions Menu > ConfigureTask Template. You must have the System Administrator role to configure the task template1. In the Change tab, click Actions > Configure Task Template. The task template dialogue displays.2. Select the task you want to edit from the list of Defined Tasks, and then make your changes in the right panelNote that you can also choose from the available keywords, which are customization tokens denoted byangle brackets (for example, <priority>) that can be inserted into the template and then replaced with theappropriate data when sent.3. Click Restore Defaults to revert your changes and return the task template to its default settings.4. Click Cancel to close the Task Template dialogue

A work order contains the information necessary to physically carryout a request in the data center. Work orders aregenerated from one or more requests.Once a request is approved, a work order is generated for it automatically if you are working in Request Bypass. IfRequest Bypass is disabled, you must manually create the work order.Note: The actions you can take with Work Orders depend on your role's privileges. See Work Order Permissionsby Role.Note: A request much be approved before a work order can be manually created for it.To manually issue a work order:1. In the Web Client, select the Change tab > Requests.2. Click on the request you want to issue a work order for.3. Select Actions > Create Work Order. You will automatically be taken to the Work Order Details page.4. Click the Edit button to enter Edit mode.5. Provide the following information:a. Priority: Low, Normal, High, Urgent. The default is Normal. Optional.b. Due Date. Optional.c. Assigned To: The person to send the work order to. This is usually the person assigned to complete thework order task. Click the Add icon to open the Issue Work Order Notifications dialog and select the personto send the work order to.d. Requests to Include in the work order.6. Click the Issue Work Order button in the Details panel or click the Actions menu > Issue Work Order. The workorder is sent to the person(s) selected.Note: The Work Order Number and Work Order Status are generated by the system and cannot be edited.What you are permitted to do with Work Orders is based on your role. The following table summarizes the defaultprivileges.System Admin-Can view, assign, and approve all Requests and mark them Complete. Can configure the Task Tem-istratorplate.Can view, assign, and approve Requests and mark them Complete (based on locally assigned per-Gatekeepermissions).Can view Requests and Work Orders and mark Work Orders Complete (based on locally assignedOperatorpermissions).Viewer Can view Requests and Work Orders but cannot mark Work Orders Complete.

Work order numbers track a work order as it moves through the dcTrack Change Control workflow.Work order numbers are generated by dcTrack automatically when the work order is initially generated or issued.Work orders appear on the Work Order page, in the work order preview, on the work order printout and so on.Work order numbers consist of:The first two digits of the number represent the year the work order was generated.The next three characters are always WO- to distinguish the number from a request number.The next five digits are a serial number starting at 00001 each year.For example: 14WO-00006 where14 = the year 2014WO = work order00006 = the work order serial numberIf the suffix-X is part of the work order number, that means a Connect or Disconnect Work Order is included.You can edit the details of a work order that has not been issued on the Work Order Details page.1. In the Change Tab > Requests, select the work order that you want to edit from the Requests List.2. Click the Edit button or double-click the work order and click the Edit button on the Work Order Details page toenter Edit mode.3. In Edit mode on the Work Order Details page, make your edits.4. Click the Issue Work Order button or select the Actions menu > Issue Work Order to issue your edited workorder.Note: In Edit mode, you can edit the Request Priority and Due Date, issue the work order or mark the work ordercomplete, and change the requests to include in the work order. The work order number and status are generatedby the system and cannot be edited.Note: Work orders that have been completed cannot be edited.

Once an action request is submitted and approved, a work order is generated to perform the action in the data cen-ter. A work order contains the information necessary to physically complete the work required for one or morerequests in the data center.If a work order is generated for you, you are notified via email.View the work order and/or print the work order if you want a hardcopy of it.You can view the Work Order List by selecting the Change tab > Work Orders. Additionally, you can sort and filterthe list by work order number, status, and other parameters as well as hide, show, and reorder columns, and thencreate and save your own filtered views to see just the work orders that matter to you.Click on a Work Order to view its Details page. On the Work Order Details page in Edit mode, you can set the priorityand due date, view requests associated with the work order and add or remove additional requests to include in thework order.To view work orders:1. In the Web Client, select the Change tab > Work Orders. This opens a list of all work orders you are allowed toview.2. Click the work order you want to view.3. Double-click the work orderTo print work orders:1. In the Web Client, select the Change tab > Work Orders.2. Click on the work order you want to print.3. Click the Print icon to Print the work order.The work orders that include Connect and Disconnect requests can be exported in excel format.To export connection work orders click on the Export button in Work Order details page. An excel file will be down-loaded that will include all the connect and disconnect requests associated with the work order.The exported file is color formatted excel file and have a section for optional additional information that is left blank tobe filled manually.The column headers in the exported file will be in the language set in user preference setting.Note: Export button will be enabled only for the work orders that have connect or disconnect requests.

Completing a work order means the action that prompted the work order to be generated is completed, such asinstalling a server, creating a data or power connection and so on.Once a work order has been completed, it can be closed by marking it Complete in dcTrack.Once it is marked as complete, a notification is sent to the Gatekeeper so they can mark the request as Complete.See Mark a Request as Complete.To mark a work order as complete:1. In the Web Client, select the Change tab > Work Orders.2. Double-click on the work order you want to mark as complete to open it.3. Click the Actions menu > Mark Work Order Complete.You can also mark a work order as complete through either of the following methodsOn the Work Orders List, select the work orders you want to mark as complete and select the Actions menu >Mark Work Order as CompleteOn the Work Order Details page, click the Complete Work Order button in the Details panelOn the Requests page in Edit mode, click the Complete Task button under Complete Work Orders in theRequest Task Status tabOnce a work order is marked as Complete, its status will be updated in the Work Orders list and in the Details panelon the Work Order Details page. The Work Order History tab, the Request Task Status tab, and the Request Historytab also will be updated.Once they are marked as complete, you can archive work orders.To archive work orders:1. In the Web Client, select the Change tab > Work Orders.2. Click on the work order(s) you want to archive.3. Select Actions > Archive Work Order.Note: A Work Order cannot be archived until it has been completed.To view archived work orders:1. In the Web Client, select the Change tab > Work Orders.2. In the search bar, filter by Status: Work Order Archived.3. The Work Orders List will populate with archived work orders.

The only difference between Request Bypass and manual change control is that Request Bypass is an automatedvalidation process while Change Control workflow requires you to manually manage requests. Regardless of themethod, the changes are always logged in Change Requests.For information on what a request is, see Lifecycles, Statuses, Action Requests, Change Control Workflow andStages.When Request Bypass is enabled, all item action requests that are submitted are processed by dcTrack imme-diately.Note: Request Bypass is enabled by default for both System Administrators and Gatekeepers to ensure accuracy.See Default Request Bypass and Manual Change Control Modes.As the request is being processed, an Item Request dialog is displayed. If multiple requests are submitted at once,for example if you are moving multiple blades, the requests are processed individually but at the same time, and aredisplayed in the same dialog.The status of the request as it is validated in each stage of the Change Control workflow is displayed in real-time inthe dialog.Successful indicates that the request passed validation for the stage; failed indicates the request did not pass val-idation.At the end of the process, the request is Approved if the request passed each stage of the validation, or Rejected if itdid not.The request's full history is still tracked by dcTrack and work orders are created even when Request Bypass isenabled. Additionally, requests are assigned request numbers and sub-request numbers.When Request Bypass is disabled, item action requests move through each step of the Change Control workflowand must be approved or reject manually.After the initial action request is submitted, a confirmation that the request was submitted successfully is displayed.Alternatively, if the request failed, the dialog details the error that caused the failure. For more information on pos-sible request errors, see Request Bypass Validation Errors.Either the System Administrator or a another user with the appropriate access manages the process by reviewingthe request, approving/rejecting the request, generating a Work Order to perform the action associated with therequest, and so on. For a description of the steps, see Request Workflow.

Use Request Bypass instead of manual change control if you do not want to manually process each request througheach stage of the dcTrack Change Control workflow.This is especially useful if, for example, your internal change management process does not require more than oneperson to approve requests.Provided you have privileges to do so, you can submit one of the following item action requests for an item. Theserequests are submitted from the Action menu on the Items List or an item's page.Initiates a request to convert the item to a virtual machine.Convert Item to VMWhen you convert a device to a virtual machine, the device's connections, power ports,Requestdisk volumes, and Mac and IP addresses are impacted.Initiates a request to remove the item from the data center to an off-site location.When you take an item off site, the connections you have created for it in dcTrack remainTake Item Off-site Requestintact in the application. This allows you to reestablish those connections once the item isback on-site.Bring Item On-siteInitiates a request to bring the item from an off-site location back on-site to the data cen-Requestter location.Initiates a request to power off an item.Power-off Item RequestWhen an item is powered off, the item's connections remain but are considered to bepowered off as well.Initiates a request to turn an item on.Power-on Item RequestOnce the item is powered back on, the connections are powered back on as well.Decommission Item toInitiates a request to decommission and store the item.Storage RequestDecommission Item toInitiates a request to decommission and archive the item.Archive RequestInstall Item Request Initiates a request to install the item in the data center.dcTrack provides two Move Item Request options - Quick Move Item Request and PrepareMove Item Request.Move rackable, device items and rackable, network items using Quick Move Item Requestand Prepare Move Item Request.Move cabinets using Quick Move Item Request; Prepare Move Item Request cannot beused to move cabinets.Use Quick Move Item Request when you know -Quick Move Item Requestthe location you want to move an item toand Prepare Move ItemRequestthe cabinet you want to move an item tothe location you want to move a cabinet and/or its items toUse Prepare Move Item Request -when you know the cabinet you want to move an item to but need to qualify thecabinet before you move the item to it, orwhen you do not know the cabinet you want to move the item to and need to loc-ate one that can accommodate the itemInitiates a request to resubmit the item if it was rejected by the GatekeeperResubmit request applies to the following requests:Install Item RequestConvert Item to VM RequestTake Item Off-site RequestBring Item On-site RequestResubmit RequestDecommission Item to Storage RequestDecommission Item to Archive RequestPower-off Item RequestPower-on Item Request

Circuit action requests are submitted in dcTrack when a physical action must be performed for a data or power cir-cuit in a data center. Specifically, a Connect Request or Disconnect Request is submitted.Requests are submitted in the Web Client by selecting a circuit on the Circuits List and then submitting a requestfrom the Actions menu, or from the circuit's page by selecting a request from the Actions menu.You can select multiple connections from the Circuits List and submit a request for them at the same time.

By default, the Actions menu in the Web Client contains an option that allows System Administrators to turn RequestBypass on and off.Only System Administrators and users with the Request Bypass role can see this option.This allows users to move between Request Bypass and manual change control for different requests as needed.See Turn Request Bypass On or Off from the Web Client Actions Menu.

When you enable or disable Request Bypass in the Web Client from the Actions menu:The Request Bypass setting is applied to both items and connections regardless of whether you changed thesetting from Assets or Connectivity.The new setting becomes the default until the next time you change it, even after you log off and log back on.The new setting is applied throughout the Web Client.Email notifications are sent when Request Bypass is disabled and you are working in manual change control.Emails notify a Gatekeeper that an action request is submitted for an item or circuit. They can then review therequest and either approve or reject the request.Email notifications for requests are sent automatically to Gatekeepers as long as the feature is enabled for them.See Enable Request Email Notifications for Gatekeepers.

The reasons Request Bypass validation errors occur depend on the request.For example:You submit an Install Item Request for a server.However, the cabinet you are attempting to install the server in is not in an Installed status as required.Validation fails and a message is displayed that indicates what caused the error.You submit a Connect Request for a circuit.However, a data panel that is part of circuit has not been installed.Validation fails and a message is displayed that indicates what caused the error.If multiple requests were submitted and multiple issues were found, they are listed individually in the Request dialog.Review the reason the request could not be processed, correct the issue or issues, then resubmit the request or cre-ate a new request.An item request may fail Request Bypass validation for one of the following errors:Each time a request is submitted, your permission to the submit the request for the item is val-User permission notidated.valid.When submitting one of the following requests, the item's parent item must be in an Installedstatus:Install Item RequestMove Item RequestThe item's parent isnot in an InstalledBring Item On-site Requeststatus.Power-on Item RequestIf the parent item is not in an installed status, it must be submitted along with the item so it ismoved into an Installed status.When submitting one of the following requests for an item, you must provide the item's Place-ment Information, such as Location, Cabinet, U Position and so on, on its Item page in the WebClient:Install Item RequestItem's PlacementMove Item RequestInformation is missing.Bring Item On-site RequestPower-on Item RequestWhen submitting one of the following requests for a parent item, all of its child items must bein the same status or be submitted as part of the same request:Take Item Off-site RequestChild is not in thePower-off Item Requestsame status as the par-ent item.Decommission Item to Storage RequestDecommission Item to Archive RequestCircuit install request In order to submit an Install Item Request for a circuit, the item the circuit is associated withmust be in an Installed status or must be submitted as part of the Install Item Request.cannot be submitted.Parent and child items, such as chassis and blades, must all be in an Installed status in order tosubmit an Install Item Request for a circuit.

An item request may fail Request Bypass validation for one of the following errors:Each time a request is submitted, your permission to the submit the request for the item is val-User permission notidated.valid.When submitting one of the following requests, the item's parent item must be in an Installedstatus:Install Item RequestMove Item RequestThe item's parent isnot in an InstalledBring Item On-site Requeststatus.Power-on Item RequestIf the parent item is not in an installed status, it must be submitted along with the item so it ismoved into an Installed status.When submitting one of the following requests for an item, you must provide the item's Place-ment Information, such as Location, Cabinet, U Position and so on, on its Item page in the WebClient:Install Item RequestItem's PlacementMove Item RequestInformation is missing.Bring Item On-site RequestPower-on Item RequestWhen submitting one of the following requests for a parent item, all of its child items must bein the same status or be submitted as part of the same request:Take Item Off-site RequestChild is not in thePower-off Item Requestsame status as the par-ent item.Decommission Item to Storage RequestDecommission Item to Archive RequestIn order to submit an Install Item Request for a circuit, the item the circuit is associated withmust be in an Installed status or must be submitted as part of the Install Item Request.Circuit install requestcannot be submitted.Parent and child items, such as chassis and blades, must all be in an Installed status in order tosubmit an Install Item Request for a circuit.If there is an outstanding, pending request for an item or connection, the request cannot be processed and dcTrackgenerates an error.If you receive this error, you can:Wait for the pending request to be processed.Delete the pending request and resubmit the new request.A pending request can be deleted on the Requests page as long as it is not in an Approved/Work Order Completestatus.If you are processing multiple requests at the same time, all correct requests are processed and any items withpending requests are not processed. Requests that were not processed are indicated by dcTrack.

Change control is dcTrack's change management workflow process. Change control tracks and manages itemsthrough each individual step of their lifecycle in dcTrack.dcTrack allows you to work in Request Bypass or manual change control.The only difference between Request Bypass and manual change control is that Request Bypass is an automatedvalidation process.Request Bypass is enabled by default for both System Administrators and Gatekeepers to ensure accuracy.However, System Administrators can disable the feature for Gatekeepers.For more details, Request Bypass and Manual Change Control and Lifecycles, Statuses, Action Requests,Change Control Workflow and Stages.When users are assigned a change control related task, such as Gatekeepers reviewing a request or users viewingand printing a work order assigned to them, they are notified via email.Therefore, each user's email must exist in dcTrack and dcTrack must be able to access the email client.See Enable Request Email Notifications for Gatekeepers

A user's dcTrack role determines their Change Control workflow privileges such as approving requests, issuingWork Orders based on requests, and rejecting requests.The table below summarizes the relevant roles and privileges.System Admin-Submit, cancel, and approve Requests and Work Orders and mark them Complete. Also can enableistratorand disable Request Bypass.Gatekeeper Submit, cancel, and approve Requests and Work Orders and mark them CompleteOperator Submit and cancel Requests and mark Work Orders completeViewer View Requests and Work OrdersRequest Bypass Enable and disable Request Bypass when processing requestsNote: The Request Bypass role is an auxiliary functional role that can be assigned in addition to another role.The Planned for Decommission feature allows users to indicate a date when items will be decommissioned and tomake use of the resources that will become available when those items with the Planned for Decommission statusare decommissioned.Once an item has a status of Planned for Decommission, its rack units, data connection resources, and power con-nection resources, will be included in the pool of resources available for planning the deployment of new assetsbased on the date the items are planned for decommissioned and the date that you are planning for.An item that is Planned for Decommission is assigned a Planned Decomm. Date, which is the date that you areexpecting to decommission the item.The Planning Date is a future date that is used to apply Planned for Decommission item resources to asset man-agement and capacity calculations globally throughout dcTrack. If the Planning Date is after an item’s PlannedDecomm. Date, then that item’s resources will be available for planning new deployments, even if the item has notyet been commissioned.For example, you want to replace several aging, basic PDUs with new intelligent rack PDUs. You plan to decom-mission the basic PDUs on April 15. You expect the iPDUs to be installed on April 30. For each basic PDU, you issuea Plan to Decommission Item Request and assign a Planned Decomm. Date of April 15. You create assets indcTrack for the iPDUs and, with a Planning Date of April 30, plan to place the new iPDUs into the same physicalspace that the basic PDUs are occupying. At this point, the basic PDUs are Planned for Decommission, and theiPDUs are Planned items making use of the basic PDUs’ Planned for Decommission resources. Once the basicPDUs are decommissioned, the iPDUs will display in their same U positions, even if the basic PDUs are decom-missioned on a date following April 15.You can also set an item’s status directly to Plan for Decommission on its Item Details page.

To use the Planned for Decommission feature, you must first enable it. By default, this feature is turned off. Only Sys-tem Administrators can enable or disable the Planned for Decommission feature.To enable the Planned for Decommission feature:1. In the Settings tab, select dcTrack Settings.2. In the Application Settings tab under dcTrack Settings, check the Apply Planned Decommissions checkbox.By default, this checkbox is unchecked, so the feature is disabled.3. When the Apply Planned Decommissions checkbox is checked, the Planning Date selector will appear inthe upper right corner of the dcTrack Web Client GUI.Note: If the Apply Planned Decommissions checkbox is checked/unchecked while a user is logged in, the dcTrackWeb Client will update accordingly. Notably, users may or may not be able to specify a Planning Date, and the datashown on various pages may change as a result.The Planning Date is the date that a user wants to plan for. It is used to apply the Planned to Decommission status ofassets to resource and capacity calculations globally throughout dcTrack. This date is set using the Planning Dateselector in the upper right corner of the dcTrack Web Client GUI. You must set the Planning Date to use the Plannedfor Decommission feature.Note: The Planning Date selector is only available when the Applied Planned Decommissions checkbox is checkedunder the Settings tab > dcTrack Settings > Application Settings.To select a date, click the Planning Date selector and click on the date you want to use as your Planning Date.Today’s date is the first date available for selection, and the date you select is highlighted in orange as well as indic-ated in the Planning Date header. Clicking the "Ok" button will set the Planning Date to today’s date.When a Planning Date is selected, the Planning Date selector displays a “Planning Date:[DATE]” message. Whenno Planning Date is selected, the Planning Date selector displays a “Planning Date not applied” message.

System Administrators and Gatekeepers can transition an installed item to the Planned for Decommission statethrough a change request or by changing the status to Plan for Decommission directly on the item’s Details page.The Planned for Decommission date can be used to filter results when searching for capacity from assets that areplanned to be decommissioned.When you submit a Plan for Decommission Item request, a confirmation popup will display to confirm your request.A Planned Decomm. Date for the item is required, although the Priority and Due Date fields are optional.Although a request can be made for an item to be Planned for Decommission, no action is taken to issue workorders at the time the item is in the Planned for Decommission state, until a Decommission to Storage or Decom-mission to Archive request is submitted.The item can be returned to the Installed state by cancelling the request or setting its Status to Installed on the item’sDetails page.To submit a Plan to Decommission request for an item from the Asset Management list:1. In the Assets tab, click the item you want to request to be Planned to Decommission.2. Click the Actions menu > Plan to Decommission Item Request. An Item Request popup will display.3. In the Item Request popup, set the following:a. Priority: Low, Normal, High, Urgent (Optional)b. Due Date (Optional)c. Planned (Required; the default is today’s date)4. Click the Yes button.5. On the success confirmation screen, highlight the text and use Ctrl+C to copy the text into the text file ofyour choice, or click the OK button to exit.To submit a Plan to Decommission request for an item from the Item Details page:1. In the Assets tab, double-click the item you want to request to be Planned to Decommission. The item’sDetails page displays.2. Click the Actions menu > Plan to Decommission Item Request. An Item Request popup will display.3. In the Item Request popup, set the following:a. Priority: Low, Normal, High, Urgent (Optional)b. Due Date (Optional)c. Planned (Required; the default is today’s date)4. Click the Yes button.5. On the success confirmation screen, highlight the text and use Ctrl+C to copy the text into the text file ofyour choice, or click the OK button to exit.Note: The Plan to Decommission Item Request is only available when the item is the appropriate state that allowsthe transition: Installed, Powered-Off or Off-Site.There is no work order for this request; when a Plan to Decommission Item Request is issued, the item will transitionautomatically through Work Order Issued and Work Order Completed stages.The Plan to Decommission state applies to rackable, non-rackable, and zero-U device, network, probe, and rackPDU classes.System Administrators and Gatekeepers can transition an installed item to the Planned for Decommission state bychanging the status to Plan for Decommission directly on the item’s Details page.To set an item’s as status as Plan for Decommission:1. In the Assets tab, double-click the item you want to request to be Planned to Decommission. The item’sDetails page displays.2. On the Item Details page, click the Edit icon to enable Edit mode.3. In Edit mode, in the Identity section, set the Status field to Planned Decomm. via the Status dropdown.4. Click the Save button. An Item Request popup will display.6. In the Item Request popup, set the following:a. Priority: Low, Normal, High, Urgent (Optional)b. Due Date (Optional)c. Planned (Required; the default is today’s date)7. Click the Yes button.8. On the success confirmation screen, highlight the text and use Ctrl+C to copy the text into the text file ofyour choice, or click the OK button to exit.Note: When using File Import to set an item’s status to Planned for Decommissioned a Planning Date will have to beprovided to assign an asset to a U position currently occupied by a Planned to Decommission item.

A Plan to Decommission Item Request can be cancelled by cancelling the request if one is issued. The item can alsobe returned to the Installed state by setting the status to Installed on the item’s Details page. Only System Admin-istrators and Gatekeepers can change the item’s status on the item’s Details page.Note: Cancelling the Plan to Decommission Item Request and reverting the item to the Installed state may affectother items if those items were planned to be moved into the Planned to Decommission item’s capacity. The itemswill have their U positions, slot positions, chassis, and cabinet associations cleared.A Cancel Planned for Decommission confirmation popup will be displayed if a Plan to Decommission item is rever-ted to the Installed state. The popup will indicate the item reverting to the Installed state and the items that may beaffected by having their cabinet, chassis, U, or slot positions cleared.To cancel a Planned for Decommission Item Request by cancelling the request on the Requests List:1. Under the Change tab, select Requests.2. On the Requests List, select the request you want to cancel.3. In the Actions menu on the Requests List, select Cancel Request.4. When the Item Request has been processed, highlight the text and use Ctrl+C to copy the text into the textfile of your choice, or click the OK button to exit.To cancel a Planned for Decommission Item Request by cancelling the request on the Request Details page:1. Under the Change tab, select Requests.2. On the Requests List, double-click the request you want to cancel. The Request Details page opens.3. In the Actions menu on the Request Details page, select Cancel Request.4. When the Item Request has been processed, highlight the text and use Ctrl+C to copy the text into the textfile of your choice, or click the OK button to exit.To cancel a Planned for Decommission Item Request by reverting the item’s status to Installed:1. In the Assets tab, double-click the item whose status you want to revert. The item’s Details page displays.2. On the Item Details page, click the Edit icon to enable Edit mode.3. In Edit mode, in the Identity section, set the Status field to Installed. via the Status dropdown.4. Click the Save button. An Cancel Planned for Decommission confirmation popup will display.5. In the Cancel Planned for Decommission confirmation popup, review the information and click the Yes but-ton.6. On the success confirmation screen, highlight the text and use Ctrl+C to copy the text into the text file ofyour choice, or click the OK button to exit.

File import/export can be used to specify the Planned for Decommission status, Planned Decomm. Date, and Plan-ning date.File export supports the Planned Decomm. status, Planned Decomm. Date, and Planning Date. However, file importonly supports the Planned status with the Planning Date.Note: File import/export of the Planned for Decommission Status and associated dates is only available when theApply Planned Decommissions checkbox under the Settings tab > dcTrack Settings > Appliance Settings ischecked.The Planned for Decommission feature can affect how resources are display throughout dcTrack.

When the feature is enabled and a Planning Date is selected, the floor map Items List is filtered to show items as ofthe Planning Date selected.Cabinet elevation views in the floor map only will show the contents of the cabinet consistent with the Planning Date,with all items that are Planned for Decommission on or before the Planning Date not shown. All Planned items thatare making use of U positions available on or before the Planning Date are shown in their respective places in theelevation.Some floor map reports reflect the data as of the selected Planning Date, while others display data without the selec-ted Planning Date applied. For more information, see Web Client Floor Map Reports.The Items List on the Asset tab includes columns for Planning Date and Planned Decomm Dates. Date ranges canbe selected for both columns.The options to show or hide columns include Planned Decomm. Status, Planned Decomm. Date, and PlanningDate. The Planned Decomm. Date and Planning Date columns are not shown by default; they are only displayedwhen the Apply Planned Decommissions checkbox under the Settings tab > dcTrack Settings > Appliance Settingsis checked.On the Item Details pages, the Planned Decomm. status is available for certain items in the Status dropdown in theIdentity panel. The Placement panel fields may also make use of Planned for Decommission resources.

The Planning Date field is an optional field for Intelligent Capacity Searches that can be used to filter for capacitythat is available from assets that are planned to be decommissioned on or after the date. The default date is the cur-rent date. Only a single date, not a date range, can be specified.When a Planning Date is selected, the Planning Date in the Intelligent Capacity Search panel is automaticallyincluded.The search results are displayed as of the selected Planning Date.For more information, see Use Intelligent Capacity Search to Locate or Qualify Cabinet Space for One or MoreItems.The request type Plan to Decommission Item Request is available. An item that is Planned for Decommission canbe returned to the Installed state by cancelling the request if a request has been issued.For more information, see Submitting a Plan to Decommission Item Request.

Items that make use of Planned for Decommission resources are not mapped to or available to be integrated withPower IQ until they are installed in the cabinet.If an item is already integrated with Power IQ and then moved to a U position that is already filled with a Planned forDecommissioned item, the item will remain integrated.When the Planned for Decommissioned item is decommissioned, the item will no longer be isolated from Power IQ.If a Planned for Decommission Item Request is cancelled, the item will lose the U position and will no longer be isol-ated from Power IQ; however, it will not be mapped.

Various reports are available in the dcTrack Web Client that help you with data center capacity planning, auditingand inventory.Web Client ReportsWeb Client Report DescriptionsThe PDF reports mentioned above are accessible from the Reports button on both the Item List Page and ItemDetail Page.Please note the report menu options are context sensitive and are enabled based on the selected Class of the Item.The Reports button available on the Main Toolbar will automatically redirect you to the dcTrack Dashboard and Wid-gets page.Use the Reports Menu on the Asset List tool bar to easily access the:Cabinet Elevation ReportCabinet Detail ReportItem Detail ReportPower Panel ReportThese reports are useful for auditing data center items, capacity planning, and so on.For example:For auditing purposes, customize a Cabinet Elevation report to review what items are contained in specific cab-inetsFor capacity planning, filter a Cabinet Detail report to display only cabinets in a specific rowWhen doing an audit of items currently installed in the data center, customize an Item Detail report to containonly items in an Installed statusSteps to generate a report:1. Select the Items you wish to report on from the Asset List2. Click the Report button on the Asset List tool bar3. Click on a report option in the menu to open the Print Options Dialog.4. Set the report parameters.5. Click the Run Report buttonReports may also be run for a single Item by clicking the Report button on the Item Detail Page tool bar.

The Cabinet Elevation report contains elevation views of the cabinets being managed in dcTrack.Access the Cabinet Elevation report by selecting Reports > Cabinet Elevation from the Asset List tool bar or theAsset Detail tool bar in the Web Client.You may use all of the filtering features available on the Item List to select only those Items you are interested inreporting. You must select at least one cabinet to enable the Report button.Checking the Select All Icon selects all of the cabinets listed in the Item List. Deselect the Icon to deselect all cab-inets.Use Ctrl + click or Ctrl + Shift + click to select multiple cabinets in the list. Deselect a cabinet by clicking on it.The elevations use the same color-coding and labeling as the elevations displayed on the various pages in dcTrack.For an example of this report, see dcTrack Reports List Sample Cabinet Elevation Report.Specify the cabinet view. This determines how each cabinet's contents are displayed in the elevations that appear inthe report -Front: Only the front view for each cabinet is displayedBack: Only the back view for each cabinet is displayedFront and Back: Both a front view and back view of each cabinet is displayed. The views are displayed side-by-side.Text: The contents of the cabinet are displayed as text. Text is the default elevation view. Color coding is used toidentify the items in the cabinet. and the current status of each itemImage: The contents of the cabinet are displayed as images. An image of the item must be available in the ItemModels Library. Items that do not have images are displayed as Text.Specify the number of cabinets that are displayed on a single page of the report.Up to 99 cabinets can be displayed on a single page.Click the Run Report button to run the report.Note: This does not apply to the Cabinet Detail report.Access the Cabinet Detail report by selecting Reports > Cabinet Detail in the Web Client.Like the Cabinet Elevations report, this report contains either a text-based or visual representation of the CabinetElevations of the cabinets being managed in dcTrack.This report includes additional cabinet details such as the make, model, size, weight, and so on.The elevations use the same color-coding and labeling as the elevations displayed on the various pages in dcTrack.With the exception of specifying the number of cabinets per page, this report uses the same filters as the CabinetElevation Report.For an example of this report, see Sample Cabinet Details Report.

This report displays either text-based representations of items or, when available, images of the items being man-aged in dcTrack.This report includes additional device details such as the make, model, and so on.The elevations use the same color-coding and labeling as the elevations displayed on the various pages in dcTrack.Configure the contents of the report using the filters provided and specifying the various criteria.With the exception of specifying cabinets per page, all of the same functions apply as described for the CabinetElevation Report.You can also:Specify one or more classes of items to display.Specify one or more item statuses. Only items with those statuses are included displayed.Filter the report by item name to display only the items you want.Filter the report by cabinet to display only items that are contained in one or more specific cabinets.For an example of this report, see Sample Item Details Report.In dcTrack 5.2, the Item Details report has been updated to include the eAsset Tag Number data and a section forcustom fields.dcTrack allows you to print Panel Views for multiple Power Panels.These steps apply to AC Distribution / Power Panel, Floor PDU / Local or Remote panels1. In the Asset list, select the Power Panels that you want to print.2. Click Report -> Power Panel3. If you would like to print the Report, once rendering is complete click the Print button in the lower right side ofeach page of the report.4. If you would like to exclude the Panel Level readings, click the "Hide Panel Readings" button in the tool bar.This button allows you to toggle between Hiding and Showing the PanelTo print Panel view for Busway Tap Boxes follow the steps below1. Open a Busway item details page.2. In the Power Tap Boxes sub tab, hover over the Tap Box image and click the hamburger icon.3. Click Panel View from the menu.4. In the Busway Outlet Breakers dialogue, click the Print button.5. The display of Panel Readings can be toggled using the "Hide Panel Readings" button.

1. Open a report by clicking on the Reports tab, then selecting a report from the options.The report's page opens.2. Select the location or locations you want to include in the report.Once the location(s) are selected, only cabinets within the selected location are displayed. If not cabinets exist forthe location, no data are available for the report.The filters and settings you can apply to the report depend on the report type.For details on each filter and setting, see:Cabinet Elevation ReportCabinet Detail ReportItem Detail Report3. Once you have set your filters, select the report contents such as the cabinets or items to include in the report.4. Click on a single criteria.Use Ctrl+Click to select multiple, individual criteria from grid on the page.Use Ctrl+Shift to select multiple, concurrent criteria.5. Check the Select All checkbox to select all criteria.6. Click Run Report to generate the report.Note: The icon is disabled until one or more criteria are selected in the grid.A new tab or new window opens depending on your browser settings, and the report begins to generate.The time it takes to generate a report depends on the amount of data in the report and the report settings, such asthe including images vs. text.A progress bar displays as the report generates.7. Click Cancel to stop generating the report.Once a report is generated, it opens in PDF view in your browser.Note: Your browser settings determine if the report opens in a new tab or window. If nothing happens, make surethat your browser allows popups from the dcTrack Web Client URL.8. Hover your mouse in the lower right of the report to display report controls.Size the report within the browser, if needed.Navigate the report pages.Zoom in and out.Save the report, if needed.Print the report, if needed.Set print options as needed.9. Exit the report by clicking the Close icon in the upper right of the report window.You use filters to customize the information contain in the Web Client reports.If there is specific data you run a report on consistently, you can save the settings so they are your new default.The next time you log in to dcTrack and open the report view, the same filters and settings are applied.The saved settings apply only to the individual report, so you must save settings for each report separately.Settings are specific to you and do not affect other users.Filter your report and then click Save at the top of the report.Note: You are not prompted to confirm and a confirmation is not displayed.The filters and settings you can apply depend on the report type.Clicking Clear clears all of the filters and settings applied to the report.

The following reports are available in dcTrackThese reports are accessible by selecting the Reports tab on the Item List tool bar.Data, such as item names and serial numbers, is not truncated.The chassis that each blade belongs to is identified in the elevations.Item Details reports include cabinet elevations.Various filters can be applied to the reports based on the content.Each report can be printed or saved locally.Cabinet Elev-Contains elevation views of the cabinets being managed in dcTrack.ations ReportThis report provides either a text-based or visual representation of the Cabinet Elevation of the cabinetsbeing managed in dcTrack.CabinetDetail ReportThis report includes additional cabinet details, including cabinet elevation, a listing of items in the cab-inet organized by item class and sorted by position in the cabinet and a summary of the item details.This report displays either text-based representations of items or, when available, images of the itemsbeing managed in dcTrack.Item DetailReportThis report includes additional device details, such as the make and model, as well as a list of power anddata connections identifying far end item and port.This report includes the Panel view of multiple Power Panels. You can select one ore more Power PanelsPower Panelfrom the item list or select one or more Floor PDU items from the Asset List and get single report forReportmultiple Power Panels. This report also applies to DC Objects (Plant Panel and DC Panel).

Data center data and readings are viewed and retrieved in various places in the dcTrack Web Client.Data and readings are provided in the dcTrack interface and/or report format.All users with View privileges can view data center data and readings.In order to get power and sensor readings:The device the readings are pulled from must either be from a Power IQ® device, or from rack PDU that has hadan SNMP MIB configured to pull readings from it.The device must be capable of reporting data over SNMPPower IQ Integration must enabled in dcTrack if dcTrack and Power IQ are integrated.The Get Readings button is not visible if the function is not enabled.The device must have power and/or sensor ports, and an IP address and SNMP community string must beassigned to themGet Readings must be clicked in order to retrieve AMP readings. Readings are not automatically retrieved bydcTrack.You can access the Get Readings button in the Power Ports Tab of a Rack PDU

Effective Power - This reading accounts for the number of non-redundant power supplies connected to theitem. It is the sum of all non-optional and connected power supplies' budget watts minus the redundant sup-plies budget watts.Original Power - When items are created, dcTrack stores the original potential power value. The OriginalPower field is used to store the Potential Power value that is used to revert the auto adjusted Budget Powervalue.Potential Power - Same as effective power but takes into account all the power supplies of the item, not justconnected ones. It is the sum of all non-optional power supplies' budget watts minus the redundant suppliesbudget watts.Redundant supplies - This is the number after the 'N +' in the power supply redundancy.

A failure in either one of the power supplies or the one of the power sources will shut down thisNo RedundancysystemPower SupplyA failure in one of the power supplies will not shut down the system regardless of how they areRedundancyconnected to the power sources(Redundant Power Supplies is less than half the total power supplies)A failure in one of the power sources will not shut down the system regardless of how they arePower Sourceconnected to the power sourcesRedundancy(Redundant Power Supplies is half the total power supplies)A failure in one of the power supplies AND one of the power sources will not shut down the sys-Supply & SourcetemRedundancy(Redundant Power Supplies is more than half the total power supplies)Redundancy is incor-N+x value is invalid for the number of power supplies or N+x value is not selected at allrect

The colors indicate the redundancy level of the item based on how its power supplies are connected to the powerchainN/ANot Connected Redund-Redundant power supply not connected, or connected to the same sourceancyRedundant power supplies connected to different circuits that lead back to the same powerCircuit RedundancysourceRedundant power supplies connected to different circuits that lead back to different powerPower Source Redund-sourcesancy

High-level power and sensor readings are available on the Web Client Dashboard.An item's power and sensor readings are displayed in the Web Client on an individual item's page.Specifically, power readings are displayed on the Power - n Port tab of an item's page, and sensor readings are dis-played on the Sensor - n Port tabs of each item's page.For example:For information on configuring items to retrieve readings, see Configure and Synch Items to Get Power andSensor Readings.This reading accounts for the number of non-redundant power supplies con-Item Effective Power Budgetnected to the item.AreadingThis reading is also available on the Items tab of cabinet item pages.These readings are always visible and real-time.Amp read-BingsAmps (B) - Budgeted AmpsdcTrack calculates the budgeted Amps based on what the rack PDU is connected to.Single-phase calculation: (Watts / PF) / Volts connected at)Three-phase calculation: (Watts / PF) / (Volts x square root (3) )Amps (N) - Nameplate AmpsdcTrack calculates the nameplate Amps using the volts from the outlet the power supply isconnected to.Single-phase calculation: (Watts / PF) / Volts connected at)Three-phase calculation: (Watts / PF) / (Volts x square root (3) )Amps (M) - Measured AmpsMeasured Amps are used to calculate Budgeted Amps.Measured Amps are real-time power readings from Power IQ, or from rack PDUs using theSNMP MIB.

Readings for integrated items are refreshed based on the Readings Refresh Interval defined on the PIQ integrationconfiguration page. Once the Interval is set, Readings are automatically refreshed when accessing the "Item Detail","Circuit Trace", "Floor Maps" and "Dashboard Widgets" pages provided the existing readings are older than the spe-cified interval. This interval is also considered when requesting readings manually (clicking the Get Readings but-ton). For example, if the refresh interval is set to 10 minutes, and the last reading for an item was 11:00, readings forthat item could not be refreshed again until 11:10 even if the Get Readings button is clicked. The time of the last read-ing is displayed in the tool bar for convenience, so you can determine when the next retrieval can be performed.The Get Readings button is only displayed if the item is integrated with Power IQ and the integration is enabled.Users with View privileges and above can access an item's page and retrieve power readings.When Power IQ Integration is enabled, creation and deletion of ports is not applicable..

Readings for integrated items are refreshed based on the Readings Refresh Interval defined on the PIQ integrationconfiguration page. Once the Interval is set, Readings are automatically refreshed when accessing the "Item Detail","Circuit Trace", "Floor Maps" and "Dashboard Widgets" pages provided the existing readings are older than the spe-cified interval. This interval is also considered when requesting readings manually (clicking the Sync Sensors but-ton). For example, if the refresh interval is set to 10 minutes, and the last reading for an item was 11:00, readings forthat item could not be refreshed again until 11:10 even if the Sync Sensors button is clicked. The time of the lastreading is displayed in the tool bar for convenience, so you can determine when the next retrieval can be performed.Readings are retrieved for Environmental sensors and asset strips attached to PX device managed by dcTracksince these devices are added to dcTrack as probes. The Sync Sensors button is only displayed if the item is integ-rated with Power IQ and the integration is enabled.Users with View privileges and above can access an item's page and retrieve sensor information. Sensor inform-ation includes sensor readings, and an updated list of sensors if any were added or removed.You cannot create or delete sensor ports when Power IQ Integration is enabled, but you can edit sensor information.When Power IQ Integration is enabled, creation and deletion of sensor ports is not applicable.When you perform a Sync Sensor, sensor readings are displayed in the Value column of the Sensor - n Port tab ofthe item's page.For example, the temperature in Celsius or Fahrenheit, and so on.The measurement units used are the application default.The column remains blank if it is not available.A notification message is displayed if an event for the asset management has occurred.Asset management events are also recorded in the event log. View events by clicking on the Events tab in the WebClient.

Readings from asset management strips are also retrieved via sensor ports since they are connected to dcTrackthrough either a Raritan EMX or Raritan PX, which are recognized by dcTrack as a rack PDU and probe, respect-ively.For more information on how asset management strips work with dcTrack and how they are configured, seeIntegrate dcTrack with Asset Management Sensors .When you perform a Sync Sensor, 'Available' is displayed in the Value column of the Sensor - n Port tab of the item'spage if the asset management strip is available. The column remains blank if it is not available.A notification message is displayed if an event for the asset management strip has occurred.Asset management strip events are also recorded in the event log. View events by clicking on the Events tab in theWeb Client.

In dcTrack, you can set an expiration date for planned items.This is helpful when you want to reserve cabinet space in dcTrack and set an expiration date beyond which, if theitem is not Installed the cabinet space is cleared.The item field Planning Expiration applies only to items in Planned and Archived status and is where you can set theexpiration date.To set Expiration Date for Planned Items, open Item in edit mode and in the Asset & Maintenance subtab select adate for Planning Expiration.For Planned Items, Planning Expiration can be set to future date including current date.On the day of Planning Expiration date, the item status will change to Archived and the placement fields like Cabinet,U Positions, Slot Position (for Blade server) are cleared and logged in Audit Trail. This will happen automatically andwill not require manual intervention.Planning Expiration can also be set for Items with Archived Status. However, for Archived Items Planning Expirationcan only be set to Past date excluding current date.The new field Planning Expiration is also added to Item list and included in import template for bulk update.Note: Planning Expiration field is a standard item field which is only visible when item is in Planned or ArchivedStatus. This field will be hidden when items is in a status other than Planned or Archived.Access the Events page by clicking the Events tab. This page contains a list of events and event details regardingdcTrack, as well as Power IQ and asset sensor information if you are using them as part of your dcTrackconfiguration.When you click on an event, the details are displayed in the Event Details section on the right side of the page.The information on the Events page can be sorted by clicking on a column header, and filtered by selecting from theFilter By drop-downs. You can also filter by status by selecting from the Status drop-down in the Status column.Clicking Refresh accesses updated events that have been added, modified or deleted by other users. It also per-forms periodic polling of Power IQ for asset management related events or from user initiated operations. For detailson asset management event information. For more information, see Asset Management Sensor Event Inform-ation.Depending on your role, the Events tab provides access to different event management activities.You can filter data based on the day an event occurred, the event type, status and so on.Note: dcTrack stores a maximum of 100,000 events in the Events table. If there are more than 100,000 events lis-ted in the events table, dcTrack automatically runs a nightly process to deletes the oldest events (cleared or not).For more information see Events Table Limit and Nightly Clean-Up

dcTrack allows you to export the information on the Events page to a CSV file.If you filter the information and export it to a CSV, only the filtered information is contained in the file. For example, ifyou filter the page to only display Cleared events and then export the data, only Cleared events are contained in thefile.The event details displayed in the Event details section of the page and all of the information displayed in the tableare included in the export.To export Events page information to a CSV file:1. In the Web Client, click on Events. The Events page opens.2. Click Export to CSV on the Events page and save the exported file to a location of your choice.For information on specifying a save location, see How to Specify a Default Save Location for Downloaded Files.Once an event is resolved or no longer relevant, you can remove the event from dcTrack® by marking it as cleared.Use Ctrl+click to select more than one event.To clear an event:1. In the Web Client, click on Events. The Events page opens.2. Click on the event you want to clear and then click Clear Selected, or click Clear All to clear all of the events atonce. The status is changed to Cleared.

Events marked as Cleared can be purged as needed.Note: Once purged, the event is deleted from the application and cannot be restored.To purge an event:1. In the Web Client, click on Events. The Events page opens.2. Click on the event and then click Purge Selected to purge the selected event only, or click Purge All to purge allevents at once.3. Click Yes when prompted to confirm. The event is deleted from the application.The Power IQ® data model is relevant to dcTrack users who are integrating an existing dcTrack with Power IQ.From the top of the hierarchy to the bottom:DATA_CENTER: The data center object type. This object has no parent.FLOOR: The floor object type. This object can only have a DATA_CENTER as a parent.ROOM: The room object type. This object can have a DATA_CENTER or FLOOR as a parent.AISLE: The aisle object type. This object can have a DATA_CENTER, FLOOR, or ROOM as a parent.ROW: The row object type. This object can have a DATA_CENTER, FLOOR, ROOM, or AISLE as a parent.RACK: The rack object type. This object can have a DATA_CENTER, FLOOR, ROOM, AISLE, or ROW as aparent.DEVICE: The IT Device object type. This object can only have a RACK as a parent.DOOR: The door object type. This object can have a DATA CENTER, FLOOR, ROOM, AISLE, ROW, orRACK as a parent.These objects represent PDUs and sensors:PDU: The PDU object type. This object represents all types of PDUs in Power IQ, including Rack PDUs, RackTransfer Switches, Cooling Units, Floor PDUs, Floor UPS, Power Panels, and Standalone Meters. Thisobject can have a DATA_CENTER, FLOOR, ROOM, AISLE, ROW, or RACK as a parent.SENSOR: The sensor object type. This object can have a DATA_CENTER, FLOOR, ROOM, AISLE, ROW,or RACK as a parent.

Your dcTrack virtual machine must be given priority.Configure your hypervisor so that all required resources are available on the dcTrack virtual machine at alltimes.For VMware users: Note that manipulating ESXi settings or changing the priority of other virtual machines run-ning on the same ESXi host may impact the ESXi scheduling policy. If this happens, resources may be divertedfrom the dcTrack virtual machine, which may result in poor performance or dcTrack malfunctioning.Note: dcTrack supports the following hypervisors: VMware, Linux KVM and Microsoft Hyper-v. Regardless of thehypervisor, Rocky Linux (64-bit ) is the operating system of the dcTrack virtual machine.

Hypervisor host configuration recommendations for dcTrack:Up to 50 8 4 200 or more51 to 750 16 8 200 or more751 to 1500 32 16 200 or more1501 to 3000 64 24 250 or more3001 to 3500 96 24 300 or more3501 to 5000 128 32 300 or more5001 to 15000 192 48 300 or more15001 to 30000 256 64 500 or moreNote: For most modern CPUs, one CPU will be considered two cores. dcTrack diagnostics report includes theamount of CPUs/cores detected by the appliance.Note: For customers with over 30,000 cabinets, please discuss with your Sunbird representative to get the appro-priate sizing recommendation.Note: An additional 3GB of space may be needed to upload the ISO so it can be installed. Alternatively, the ISO canbe installed directly from the DVD.Note4: For Data Bases 5GB or larger, please contact Professional Services and Support from the http://sup-port.sunbirddcim.com.The following TCP ports are required to be open when building your virtual machine:443 - HTTPS (secure channel)This port must be open in order to access the dcTrack login page.

Leaving the following TCP ports open is optional.If you do not leave these ports open, note the requirements and/or limitations indicated here.22 - SSHIt is not necessary to have the SSH port open since SSH functionality is available directly on the virtual machine con-sole.If port 22 is not open, however, SSH cannot be used to access dcTrack to perform diagnostic operations of any kind.5432 - Postgres DBPort 5432 must be open in order to connect via ODBC514 - TCPPort 514 is required to forward system logs.161 - TCPPort 161 is required for SNMP discovery.25, 465, 587 - SMTPEmail SMTP connectivity requires the appropriate port(s) be open. These may vary based on your organization.123 - UDPThis port must be open for NTP time sync to work.

If you are planning on linking objects in a floor map drawing file with items in dcTrack, use either AutoCAD® 2012(and earlier) or Microsoft Visio® to create the drawing files.Sunbird offers AutoCAD and Microsoft Visio drawing file templates you can download. Use the templates to createdrawing file renderings of your data center.Note: Both AutoCAD and Microsoft Visio drawings must be saved as .DWG files in order to upload them to dcTrack.Download templates from the DCIM Support site at http://support.sunbirddcim.com.

Sunbird recommends using default browser font settings (11 px).Customizing the default settings overrides the Web Client's font settings. Display problems may occur with font set-tings later than 12 px.dcTrack is licensed based on the number of cabinets maintained by the application.Contact Sunbird Professional Services and Support for additional information on obtaining a license for dcTrack. Pro-fessional Services and Support can be contacted through the http://support.sunbirddcim.com.

You can create as many user accounts as needed.dcTrack supports up to 80 (eighty) concurrent users, meaning up to 80 users can use the application at the sametime.Units of measure can be either US or SI (metric) measurements. U.S. settings are the default.Measurement settings are applied on a per user basis.The selected measurement units apply to all measurements captured throughout the dcTrack Web Client such ascabinet height, item weight, and so on.To configure measurement settings, see Define a User's Default Unit of Measure.For currency, dcTrack uses US Dollars.

A status is applied to each item and circuit in dcTrack.The status that is applied is based on the last action request associated with the circuit or item. For example, whenan item is added it is in a Planned status. After an Install Item Request is submitted for the item and the request isprocessed and approved, the item moves into an Installed status.The same applies to circuits but different statuses are applied to them. Circuits are in a Planned status when theyare created. Once a Connect Request is submitted and then approved, the circuit moves into an Installed status.Alternatively, if a Power-off Item Request is processed, the item's circuit is moved into a Powered-off status.

The item that has been added and saved to dcTrack but is not yet installed.PlannedA request may or may not have been issued for the item.Installed The item that is installed and is in use.Powered-off The item that is installed but is not in use.Storage Designates that the item is at a storage location, but remains in the inventory.Off-Site Designates that the item is temporarily in an off-site location.Indicates that the item has been removed from inventory and disposed of.Since you cannot delete items that are in an Installed status, decommission them to an Archived state inArchivedorder to delete them. You can then purge the items from dcTrack if needed.Note: The statuses applied to circuits differ from those applied to items.A circuit that has been added and saved to dcTrack, but has not yet been installed.PlannedA request may or may not have been issued.Installed A circuit is installed and is in use.Powered-off A circuit is installed but the item is powered off.

Microsoft Internet Explorer®, mostly commonly Microsoft Internet Explorer 10 (IE10), may not load the dcTracksearch field, menus, and or email, feedback and home icons.If this occurs, switching to Compatibility View in Microsoft Internet Explorer generally fixes the problem.

When you submit an issue to Sunbird Technical Support, you may be asked to provide system logs. Your systemlogs provide additional details about your issue and helps the Sunbird Technical Support team to resolve your issuefaster, particularly for escalated issues.1. In dcTrack, navigate to Settings > Appliance Settings.2. On the Appliance Settings page, click the Download System Logs button3.The logs will be generated and placed in your download directory.For information on specifying a save location, see How to Specify a Default Save Location for Downloaded Files.

When exporting a CSV file or downloading a dashboard widget, you may want to specify the default location wherethe file is saved.1. In your Chrome browser, go to Menu > Settings or type chrome://settings into your address bar.2. On the Settings page, click Show advanced settings... to display the full list of available settings.3. On the Settings page under Downloads, click the Change button to select a new default download location.Note: Check the Ask where to save each file before downloading checkbox to specify the location each time youdownload a file.Your changes are automatically saved.

1. In your Internet Explorer browser, click the Gear icon > View Downloads or click CTRL+J.2. In the View Downloads window, click the Options link.3. In the Download Options dialog, click the Browse... button to select your desired location.4. Click the OK button to save your changes.OverviewItem Top Panels MappingsAsset and Maintenance Subtab Mappings

This section contains the dcTrack field names that should be used in the CMDB config.xml when mapping fields toeither ServiceNow or Remedy for CMDB integration. These field names should be used whenever you are spe-cifying a value for <dcimFieldId> elements.The section topics correspond to the Web Client panels and sub-tabs found on the Asset Detail screen. Each con-tains images and labels to help you to discern the correct name to use for each field label.The Placement Panel fields displayed in the Web will vary depending on the Class, Subclass and Mounting for anItem. Field names however will be consistent across all Items.
